app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: I've only progressed through about 5 of the main story missions.   It's a fun game, confusing if you are unfamiliar with the MGS series.   This timeline   [metalgeartimeline.com]  is a nice read for getting the jist of the story line.   The gameplay is fun, its interesting using your recovery system to shoot people into the sky. I often mess up the controls and end up killing instead of incapacitating the AI which seems to give up searching for a player faster than most stealth games.   As many have mentioned, you can: Go sneaky beaky like, or Go in guns blazing and killing everyone and their mother because you messed up at that one part and broke your silencer on the first shot and now you've gotta kill the guard.   The environments, specifically the rest of the map other than the outposts and bases is, for me, a little bit depressing. It's a desert, sure. There's probably not a whole hell of a lot in there, but there is no reason for you to get on your horse and ride to another side OP or a main mission. I often find myself just calling in a helo and getting extracted so I can redeploy closer to my mission of choice.  One thing I stumbled across is a means of fast travels. Large storage platforms are spread out in the various outposts and you can collect their schedules (forgot the word they use in game, itinerary?). using your box, you can fast travel to other outposts but you need the schedule of the outpost you wish to travel to.   A lot of the story comes from the tapes that you can listen to, now as I've said, there is little reason to run across the map to your next objective, unless you want to listen to the tapes. As soon as you interrupt a tape's play through, you have begin again.   The graphics are truly breath taking and the game has whacky and zany ♥♥♥♥ like all the other MGS games. Emmerich ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ his pants, weird as super natural powered enemies and jiggle physics ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°).  The customization is fun, considering the lack of it from previous games. It's not up there with the likes of Battlefield or other similar games where you can change the handle, site and barrel of the weapon. But its still cool to have.  All in all, i'd give it a solid 8/10. It's a good game, a great game in fact, but its far from perfect for each and every person out there.
From time to time a really nice game, but nothing to have fun with five hours straight.

Don't get fooled by the play time not by the simplicity of the game, I've played this game over and over. And I am awestruck...  I sort of ceased being entertained by games, I found them often to be too simple, too basic, but Choice of Robots did something I have not been prepared for. When I launched the game I was expecting a whimsical futuristic tale, instead I was tossed into an emotional shredding machine, by the time I was done with the game I... cannot explain this. For the first time in my life I understood what it means to love you child, and by god did I love mine. It combines the power of the book with the interactivity of a game to absorb you into the story, you will find yourself pensive about the deeper intricities of the game, I sure as hell am not the same person I was before.   It won't sate everybody however, unfortunately, but those who can appreciate books and futuristic tales will find riveting. Now I need to excuse myself while I cry myself to sleep.

The game is quite interesting and the old 80's style computers actually bring me back to the tandy PC and macintosh I used as a kid. (Yes, I know, im old. I have probably forgotten more about computers then most of you will ever know). In many ways I love the game, and interacting with Kaizen the computer is a concept I have always found interesting. In other ways the computer is just a program in which you see a programers holy grail as you notices small bits of humanity in it. Then again, is it.  (Caution, I am not trying to give away to much but some information past this point could be a spoiler)   The game itself is nothing more then a solution finder with a few brief moments of action to beat the oxygen clock. Half the game is looking around for clues and the other half talking to Kaizen trying to convince it for hints or information. The game itself is quickly played and the gameplay for all endings changes little until the end. You can play threw near the end then just create a save point to return to just to see all the different endings to have to avoid playing threw what you have already done again.  I recomend this game as a good quick puzzle when its on sale. It is a good concept and opens the question to how much control should an AI be given in real life and how will people actually use it to keep control of others. It brings back fond memories and even has hints of HAL from yes that old movie. The downside of this game is its quickly over to soon. The puzzles, though some could be difficult is not much of a match and the solutions to many things is litteraly written on the walls. The plot is put together by remembering what little you can find of the old crew members from articles left behind and logs which you must carefuly put together yourself. And the ending is simply what you say and do at the end. Though there is several endings, it seems repetitive to play through the game again to see each ending, but then again, the game is short.  For me, this was less of a game and more of a interactive movie. I wish it had more to its plot, was longer to play through and had more on the characters. Maybe with time more will be added. I recomend this game to those who like a good puzzle and pays attention to details, but just like a movie, once its over, you know it. Not much point to do it again for a while. I would recommend it but be picky on your expectations with this one.

Plug & Play is delightfully bizarre in ways that are as unsettling as they are endearing.  The playfulness of the vignettes that seem so mix matched and nonsensical trace intimate analogies into a collage of weirdness. It’s pulling from the darkest areas of failed relationships - denied feelings, refusal to communicate, meaningless sex to avoid complicated questions - but in ways that feel hopeful more than pessimistic. Plug & Play isn’t about something falling apart, but learning to pick yourself up when things don’t work out.  I don’t know that I’d consider it especially adept or subtle in how it goes about this, but its sincere commitment to say something important while painting an amusingly offbeat, sex obsessed world is consistently entertaining and surprisingly considered. It might look like madness from the outside, and it is to a point, but it’s madness with a purpose but which also doesn’t get so caught up in showing how much life can suck that it forgets it can also be pretty fun sometimes.   You can read more of my writing on  Kritiqal  [kritiqal.com] .

app_name: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
review_text: Just finished the 2-player local co-op mode with my girlfriend after a few evening sessions (with two xbox 360 controllers plugged in - worked beautifully). The game is so much fun and has offered us so much laughter! It strikes a good balance between solving some challenging (yet solvable) puzzles and combating monsters (with a range of cool weapons). If you are playing with a friend local co-op mode, I highly recommend playing the game in hard difficulty mode (we played the first 90% in medium then switched to hard in the last 10% - so much better in hard!). Guaranteed laughters. (e.g. accidentally falling off the edge and doing silly things :)  Overall, 10/10 for the lightweight and entertaining gameplay elements. A definite great game for couples and friends.

My review for Child of Light:  First of all, I'm going to address 2 concerns that I found in Steam community hub: 1. Uplay Those who're going to buy this game should know that this game is going to use Uplay, Ubisoft own game client. I noticed that many people dislike Uplay for certain reason so gonna respect that. I have my own issue with Uplay as well. So if you want to buy this game, make sure you know what you're getting into.  2. Day 1 DLC When the game is released, the dev put several DLCs immediately, including Golem DLC and Dark Aurora DLC which is the Special Edition bonus DLCs, Light Aurora DLC which is the preorder bonus and several 'cheat' DLC which you can buy extra oculis for your game. Golem DLC gives you a new party member and a small quest to get him, while Light Aurora and Dark Aurora DLC give you skins for Aurora and extra oculis and bonus stats. The 'cheat' DLC is actually consists of oculis, which means you can buy the oculis using real money once. Among these DLCs, only Golem DLC adds a bit of content while the skins just for eye candy. As much as I hate day 1 DLC, if you want to support the dev, buy the Golem and the skins DLC only. Of course you can ignore the DLCs if you don't want to support day 1 DLCs. I myself didn't bought any of the DLCs except Light Aurora since I preorder it.  In this game, you're playing as Aurora, a princess who died and reborn into Kingdom of Lemuria. Story progress smoothly, gaining allies and some plot twist. However, the ending is kinda not to say lame, acceptable but not much impact. There are no voice narration for this game except the narrator herself. Somehow, I wish that each character got their own voices to add more personalities to the characters. You can quite rush the game since the story is quite short. And you can restart again with New Game+ feature so you can start the game with OP Aurora.  The artstyle and graphic is beautiful. When you move Aurora around, you can see her hair move depends on the directions. The backgrounds and landscape are nicely drawn. Character animation during combat is kinda static. And the graphic glitch for Aurora’s hair where she transform into a tomboy during battle is not favorable by many, though I can deal with that.   Now lets talk about combat. It's 2v3 style, where you can bring 2 members in your party to fight 1 to 3 monsters at a time. but you can only change party members during combat and not outside which is annoying. At least let the player decide which member goes on combat first. Before combat, you can only manage on the oculis to be equipped on each party members and use any skill points or healing items. In combat, there will be a timeline. Each member and monsters will be on the timeline. When you reach the casting point, you can give order to the said member ie attack, use item or switch party member. After selecting the action, there will be another timeline for casting. If you're attacked during this time, your attack will be cancelled and you'll be pushed back on the timeline which is also known as interrupt. You can also use this to your advantage to prevent monsters from attacking you. There are no visible health bar for enemies and no bestiary to see the weakness of each enemies so you have to discover it yourself, although some of them are kinda easy to spot. During combat, you can also control Igniculus, which is very useful in combat. he can highlight enemies and show it on the timeline. He can also slow down enemies by blinding them, making their progress on the timeline slower for more tactical approach. He can also heal you. To recharge his energy meter, he can either use potion or just shake the light source and collect the light.  There is oculi crafting in this game, which is combining gems to make different and stronger oculis. Only 3 recipes are showed in the game, others you have to discover yourself (we got internet though ;D). Each oculi type has different effect depending on where you equip it. There are 8 types of oculis; 6 can be found in chests and defeating monsters, the other 2 need to be crafted. There is only 1 secret recipe for a special gem, but other than that, just normal crafting stuff. I wish they had put more depth to the crafting part since it's the essential part in the game.  Each character has their own skill tree. Each skill tree got 3 branches and you can focus on either 1 branch first or balancing between each branch. Each branch focus on 1 special skill for the character. Example for Aurora, she got Slash (physical attack), Light Beam (magic, light damage) and Super Light Beam (magic, light damage, can 1 hit KO) (Disclaimer: The skill name is not correct :P). Each skill will have single targeting or multiple. And no character has similar skills, so it's good to know which one you wanna use during combat. Unfortunately, there's no explanation about the skills during combat, which make it hard for players to choose skills. There's also passive skills available, like Counter-Attack, Counter-Heal etc and it helps very much during combat.  The soundtrack, is a masterpiece. I enjoyed every one of the songs. When I first started the game, I was stuck at the main menu because the song at the time, which is Aurora's Theme is mesmerizing. Even the songs during normal battle and boss fight is good and make me more enthusiastic to play. You can buy the digital album from here or you can listen to it on Spotify. Give it a go, I'm sure you'll like it.  Overall, for the $14.99 price tag, it's totally worth the price. I still need to highlight that this game is not for Uplay haters and Steam elitists, because this game use Uplay as DRM so buying for Steam means using 2 DRMs at a time which is not acceptable for some people (you can see it in the community hub, people still b*tching about it lol). And Uplay is still in growing stage and need much more improvement. Other than that, this game is good and I totally recommend this game especially to RPG fans.

I will resume this game in one word, punishing. So i will break this down easily, when you are making a game, you must adjust the difficulty according to the gameplay mechanics avalibable. The game is clrearly much more hard than the first one (which is nice) but the problem is its badly directed the way they want you to go across all the things. Lets say that if this game has the mechanics and flexibility the TR of the 2000's, it would be an awesome game with just about the right difficulty to keep it chalenging while still punishing you for the mistakes you make. I'm also aware the game has almost 20 years old, but man I grow playing this old games and believe me when I say that it was a common mistake the idea of implementing extreme difficulty with low and unflexible mechanics in games, you may say: 'that is the whole idea' if that so, then why with the advance in tecnology we have, the games are getting more easy? 2 reasons, as the time passes by the mechanics become more natural, the characters are more easy to control and they do less award things and are A LOT more responsive at any command you throw them and the second is marketing (for the sake of hitting the most amount of audiencie possible so everyone can enjoy, therefor much more money).  Now putting aside the unflexible gameplay, the game is pretty solid, havent played enough to talk about the history but seems 'OK', the level desing is pretty awesome and is really well desing to hide the secrets (except for a part on the first level where there is like 2 pickups that require EXTREME coordination (not impossible though) that is more a flaw in the engine where if you are nearby an item lara won't walk to it and interact with it (like underwater) you must step right up and then you can pick it up and this is really annoying because this 2 pickups are in a context where if you aren't fast enough you die and if you pick them up you must pay with a little blood (usually more than 15% of your health, but if you were fast you could make it in one piece but is really hardly likely to happen.), the sound effects has changed a little since the last game and are fairly better, graphics are a bit better (mostly lara's model because now she has her pony tale and it also moves when she runs and if you are in an outside level and idle, the hair will simulate the breeze of wind) and texture overall are at the same quality as the last one, and for the year this game was released they were amazing. Menu still uses the same base, now the compass (which was useless as I never use it) is gone and replaced with a chronometer which give you stats on your game so far, from time taken, secrets founds (which are now 3 little statues per level), and ammo/health packs used, so a pretty nice progress. Also nice progress on the video department, the game doesnt require a DOS OP/DOSbox because windwos 95/98 where already a thing for most PC at the time, plus now in the first start of the game now displays a menu so you can configure it, and the best thing is the res of the game it adapts according to your video card (basically you can run the game on +720p without any problem nor needing to installing nothing).   -Some annoying bugs: -if the 'roof' is a bit close to you, you cant perform a jump at all, and this didnt happen with his successor -If you have custom controls, whenever you relaunch the game, it will use both (your bindings and the default ones, just like the first game) so you need to go to controls in the menu and reselect (everytime you wanna play) 'user controls', otherwise if you bind the space bar with jump you will jump but you also grab your guns.  TL;DR: the game is too punishing for the unflexiblie gameplay/mechanics it has, also the desingners could have done a better job (like as they allowed you to roll in the air and underwater) with some minor details like the way you need to be near an item to pick it up or interact with it on land, grab some of the edges with a less level of exigency and climbing a LOT faster. If you dont mind that things go ahead and play it, otherwise, skip yourself a possible butthurt

app_name: DARK SOULS™: Prepare To Die Edition
review_text: Hard as hell, but once you learn the basics, one of my favorite games of all time

There is a hidden genre of game known only among the hardcore: 'platform hell.' Among its top echelon is the classic, 'I Wanna Be The Guy,' which inspired Steam games Super Meat Boy and VVVVVV. Platform Hell games are identified by one simple trait: the game knows what you are about to do, and punishes you for doing something predictable. A cloud mighdisappear as you land on it, for example, or an apple may fall off a tree UPWARDS as you attempt to jump over it.  As a cataloguer of terrible video game tropes, it is natural that the Angry Video Game Nerds includes many, many, surprises in this game. However, AVGN-Adventures is nowhere near as difficult as these other platformers and is slightly less fun.    The Good:    * Awesome level variety harkening back to several classic video games.  * Dozens of allusions, cameos, and references to Angry Video Game Nerd episodes, classic video games, and video game tropes.  * Your character's light-gun changes color depending on the difficulty level. Pink for easy, orange for normal, and gray for 'old school.' (I was never able to reach one of the higher, unlockable difficulty levels).  * Like Nintendo games of yore, there are plenty of secrets to find.  * Great use of humor.  * Each level ends with a unique boss from nerd-culture.  * Fantastic pause music.    The Bad:    * The levels are a bit short, although they make up it with their difficulty.  * The 'You've got Skill' Steam achievement is duplicated... there are two of them for some reason.  * Control Issue: It is hard to fire your gun to the right if you recently started moving left, and vice-versa. This becomes very annoying.  * Some enemies, like the reindeer on the snow level, have 'magnetism' or something and stay right ON your sprite. since your gun can only fire outwards, it makes them lethal and unfair to fight.  * The game uses the enter key as a pause button, but if you shift+tab out of the game to talk to someone, anytime you hit enter to send your message, the game pauses/unpauses.  * The only level that is truly 'really difficult' is the last one, which is only unlockable after completing all other levels.     The Ugly:    * At times, the game felt more like a chore than a game. I got bored after playing through the first level, but only stuck it out to write this review.  * The game only has a few special items: useless rocks, super scope, 'glitch man,' and 'mecha Jesus.' (I'm making up my own names for these things, I forgot what they're killed.) I was expecting to discover more items as the game continued, but no, there are just the four of them.     The Verdict:    * Pick this up if you like AVGN or platformers, but don't expect a rock-solid experience. I personally did not enjoy my time with it.

app_name: STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy™
review_text: The graphics don't hold up compared to something like The Force Unleashed, but this game is still enjoyable to play. The ability to pick and choose certain missions gives you a little extra leeway in how you play the game, and what items you go into certain missions with. It even has two distinct endings, which is close to how many Mass Effect 3 had when it first came out. All joking aside, both endings do make sense in the context of the game and feel satisfying. The lightsaber combat can be a little BS sometimes, especially on higher difficulties, but whenever you have a good, long fight without randomly insta-dying, it's really satisfying and makes you feel like a Jedi.  7/10.

app_name: Minecraft: Story Mode - A Telltale Games Series
review_text: I'm a livestreamer who plays quite a bit of minecraft on stream - and I was hoping this would be a nice 'middle ground' where minecraft fans could enjoy, but it would be different enough from minecraft to feel like a new game. Barring the fact that I had a blue-screen mid stream (Crashes happen, although while streaming they are very painful).  ** Issue #1 ** Significantly too short. I finished the episode in 1:30. That includes the time it took me to crash, restart, load up my stream, and resume playing and replay through from my last auto-save... If the remaining episodes will be included free as part of the $22 I spent on this, then it may be worth the price, but having to wait to play a game in full when I was under the impression that it was a full game, not an 'early release'...  ** Issue #2 ** Not NEARLY enough time to make choices. I sometimes clicked at the last second and it didn't register, or spent 2 seconds looking at chat to look back and realize I missed a decision point. I guess the game is so short I can do it over...  ** Issue #3 ** Besides dialogue, there was no other choice. In fact, the 'challenges' were button-mashing (PRESS Q A BUNCH OF TIMES REALLY FAST) or the occasional 'DDR-Lite' where you have to press A, S, D, or W to avoid an attack. At best it was an interactive cut-scene where I occasionally did button mashing. Far cry from being able to freely build whatever I want in minecraft...  ** Issue #4 ** I mis-clicked on character creation. I couldn't go back, I couldn't undo, I was stuck with the character I selected. I even tried the 'go back a menu' and it wouldn't let me go back. SO, when picking a character MAKE SURE YOU PICK THE ONE YOU WANT.  ** What I actually Liked ** I didn't hate the experience, just had lots of issues. The story was 'OK' although the story tries to carve you out as a weak and uncool kid, which makes all the 'I'm awesome and kickass' dialogue options seem extremely out of place (even though I chose them, because I'm awesome and kickass). I DID want to continue playing. When the credits rolled I was left with two feelings: 'HOLY CRAP IT'S OVER, WTF, THIS WAS JUST BARELY AN HOUR' and 'WHY IS THE NEXT EPISODE HERE' But for $22 I could have bought an entire TV season of Doctor Who and had 12+ hours of entertainment, whereas I got 1 1/2 hours of entertainment here and a sore finger (from mashing the Q button, BTW - Telltale, you owe me a new Q button).   Overall - I'd say DO NOT BUY until all the episodes are out. Unless you like playing the same game over and over and over, because thats the only way you'll get value out of this.

The multiplayer is sometimes a bit unfair as you get in matches against people with a way higher level than yours, however you always learn new stuff during those games. All in all, just buy the game and you're guaranteed to have a good time.   9.8/10 Here are the five words that describe this game the best: unique, challenging, fun, epic, competitive. I do recommend this game to every shooter fan, the game is worth every single cent.

The Purring Quest is a cute platformer where you play as a cat. The game takes place on a twodimensional plane where you (the cat) has to jump, climb, claw weaker enemies, and avoid bigger enemies like dogs. Along the way there are collectibles: each level has 200 rotten fish to find, one trapped cat, and one other item.  The strengths of the game are in how it feels like you really are playing a cat, with a world that looks to scale and plausible dangers. It is an 'epic quest' but on cat scale. There is no voiced dialog, but at several times the story is told through textboxes. Which is a bit of a shame as the game intro is completely textless but succeeds perfectly in telling the game's story, and is excellently animated for this game style.  Good points are how good the main character is controllable -- as long as you use a controller. The game offers two different jump styles: long jump and double-jump. You can switch as you start the game to a style that you like best. I also tried keyboard controls, but they don't feel as responsive as the controller does. The levels are all relatively easy to get through with a boss fight or other challenge at the end, but they're all very possible. The challenge comes from finding all hidden items. In level three you get a hiding ability that made me laugh... Solid Cat.  Bad points are that the game occasionally likes to hide enemies behind foreground effects. This leads to a cheap death. You do get seven lives and even if you die seven times you can respawn at a checkpoint, but cheap deaths are never fun. You also have falling damage... for a cat. Thematically that just feels wrong.  The game starts in a pretty dark level at a graveyard which may be too scary for younger players - not that anything bad happens, but the mood can be scary. Afterwards everything is lighter and more fun so if playing with a young child consider starting them at level two.  Overall fun game and definitely worth checking out if you like platformers.

Get this game, it's a ton of fun.

A hack 'n slash and puzzle enviroment game where you play as the apocolyptic horseman War, killing angels and demons with a giant two handed sword, made of skeletons called Chaos eater. War the first horse man is basically tricked into starting the apocolypse by angels and demons. Is imprisoned by the charred council ( a neutral party). When he gets back out, he gets his revenge on everyone involved in using him as the scape goat. Witch you find out that their is a huge conspiracy between ALL parties. Ending with War summoning the other horseman (Death, Strife, Fury) to help him get final justice. With crazy blood graphics and a very creative take and artwork of earth after the apocolypse with angel and demon outposts, I loved hacking through this game with Chaos eater. Also with wrath abilities that are basic magic upgrades you'd expect the horseman War would have, his red horse Ruin and lots of custimizable equipment and weapons you find yourself searching for enimies to kill, bosses to fight and waiting for the next bloody vengeful cut scene where War is not ever happy with how he is being treated. Did i mention he has a super mode called Chaos form in witch with in a short amount of time, you become the giant fiery horned abomitable imbodiment of War itself and kill EVERYTHING.

Cyber City 2157 is a rather unique Visual Novel and for this VN, it wasn't necessarily a bad thing.  With all the VNs in the market these days, its very common to find them with nice pristine and crisp art with the characters that they do have, but Cyber City 2157 takes it retro style. Everything feels like it did when I was a kid and because of that, it wasn't necessarily a bad thing. In fact, I actually found it quite appealing to start at least. The story for this game starts off very confusing and then they slowly start unveiling more and more about it. As this is a VN with multiple paths but connections (to a degree) with each, the story became more and more clear. Regardless of that, the story was way better than those fanservice 'dating sim' games that have the most forced stories ever.  I cannot talk as much about this game because there were not exactly blatant flaws that I did not like nor any WOWs other than the ones I talked about. However, since overall I did not feel any negative sentiment from playing this VN, I woudl recommend Cyber CIty 2157.  Rating: 7.4/10 Recommend Price: $1 or below

You know that face you make when your playing an extremely difficult game and your trying to concentrate as hard as possible to not die? Well that's what Penarium does to me. Penarium is a rage-inducingly difficult platformer survival game where you will always feel determined to be able to complete the next level how ever many deaths it takes.   In penarium you control a boy called Willy. He strives to become a top circus performer. His wish comes true when a travelling circus man comes and introduces himself to him. However it's not as he expected. Willy is sent to entertain a crowd of bloodthirsty sadistic people. His goal is to survive in increasingly difficult circus stadiums while being attacked by various different traps. Definitely not an easy task.   That is the main premise of Penarium. You are basically in a small arena that is filled with various traps. You can jump across platforms to avoid these traps. Within these rooms you have different tasks to complete. This can be something as simple as collecting barrels or something difficult like having to stay in a moving spotlight for the allocated amount of time. There was a suprising amount of variety in these different tasks and I didn't find myself getting bored of them at all. My favourite of the tasks was basically a 'simon says' where you have to copy the pattern of pressed buttons in the correct order.   While doing these tasks the traps will change frequently giving you different things to avoid. This keeps the gameplay a challenge and means you can't learn the patterns to make it too easy. The traps you are given are semi-random as well as the patterns they move in. Some levels have a scripted set of traps and others are completely random. There is also a fantastic variety in the types of traps. Each are unique in their own way. They include traps like homing missiles, electric cannons, moving lasers and birds that fly away with the barrels. They each require very different strategies to avoid them and so change up the gameplay for you constantly.   Penarium has 3 different gamemodes. Within the campaign mode you get all of these different modes that I described above. They are organized into levels of increasing difficulty. There isn't a huge of levels in the game being only 30 levels total. However with the insane difficulty that I mentioned earlier they will take a long time to complete each. I estimate i've probably spent around 4 hours on the campaign so far and gotten to level 23.   It then has the arcade mode. This is a pure survival mode. It uses the barrel gamemode. You have to collect as many barrels as possible. It is unlimited and completely random. Attached to this gamemode is a leaderboard so that you can compete against your friends to collect the most barrels possible. This is a nice additional feature because the gamemode would be incomplete without it.   The final gamemode is multiplayer. This is split into 2 submodes which are versus and co-op. This is probably where I had my most fun playing. In versus mode you compete with the other player to click each button that spawns first. You also have the added ability to jump on the other persons head and knock them out for a short period. I had a huge amount of fun in this mode. Then you have co-op. In this mode each of you has a different button to press and you have to stand on them at the same time. Again it is a survival mode and you have to try and do it for as long as possible. There is also a leaderboard attached to this. Unfortunately multiplayer is only local though and can only be enjoyed by a maximum of two people. I would have liked to at least see online multiplayer implemented.   Within the arcade mode you also have a store. This can be used to purchase upgrades that can be used to help you survive longer. I haven't had much of a chance to test this but I thought it was worth mentioning. However i'm not a big fan of this system and would prefer just a straight up survival with no additional benefits.   Penarium itself also has a certain charm to it. The graphics style is designed in a striking pixel art fashion which I absolutely adore. Arenas could very easily be bland and static but they have so much variety to them graphically. The backgrounds are even full of activity and animations that make the world seem very much alive. Penariums cutscenes also have a wonderful charm to them. The voiceover is mesmerizingly good and really sets you in the mood of the game. A wonderful circus soundtrack also helps to build this atmosphere. The only issue I do have with the soundrack is that it can get very repetitive after a while because it doesn't have enough variety.   Overall if you love difficult games and are a fan of platformers then Penarium is definitely a game for you. The developer has gone all out to create an experience full of variety and a beatifully styled world with a unique charm to it. However if you don't like difficult games then you can safely avoid Penarium as it definitely isn't a game for you. But if you do I think the price of £6.99 is more than reasonable for the insane amount of fun you will get.   TheIronicGamers rating system     Don't ever buy this game.    Maybe consider it on a sale.    An average game.     A good game that should definitely be considered.     A must play!   Disclaimer: I was provided with a free early review key by the developer to make this review.

I'll try to keep this brief -   As a Founder from back in 2011/2012 I've played a lot of MWO ever since. I've also played a lot of Mechwarrior dating back to the 90's (Mechwarrior 2: 31st Century Combat) and I can safely say this is the best core 'mech combat I've ever played. They have the feel down and the graphics and art assets are beautiful. Battlemechs have never looked or felt better.  Despite some publisher gimmicks (IGP has since dissolved and is no longer running things) PGI has continued to improve MWO at an accelerated pace and if you like giant stompy 'mechs you will enjoy the core combat.  If there are any negatives I'd sum them up by saying that this game is very likely not going to expand much past an arena 'mech shooter, as much as I wanted it to be something like Mechwarrior EvE Online (in terms of economy and depth) I just don't think that's going to happen.  Even so, I'm ok with that and the 'mech combat itself is pretty deep in that you can customize everything under the sun and again, it's very enjoyabe to play. I'd recommend this game easily if you like the concept or are intrigued and enjoy a 'thinking man's shooter'. Or just plain like blowing stuff up, because in MWO, lots of thing blow up and blow up beautifully.

app_name: 7 Grand Steps, Step 1: What Ancients Begat
review_text: As others have already said - it's a highly addictive game. When board games and RPG meet, the result can only be good if you like both. You start off in the Copper Age and advance your family the way you want to. You can choose between social advancement (which can catapult your family to noble ranks), heroic adventures (which can become a revolution) or inventions (which opens up new techs).  I would recommend the game to everybody, that likes a little board game paired with casual strategy and a nice narrative. :)
What is going on..

Within the realm of Dishonored, you play Corvo Attono. Corvo is given supernatural powers by 'The Outsider' after he was framed for murdering the Emperess of Dunwall. The powers that are given to you allow you to play the game through in different playstyles. Short range teleportation and time stopping can be used both in a violent manner, such as stopping time, teleporting behind enemies and shooting them in the back, or a non-violent manner. Such as teleporting around enemies or stopping time to run past them. On my first playthrough, I played through as non-lethal as possible. This playthrough took me about 12 hours. I am currently on my third hour of my second playthrough; about 3/4 of the way through, Killing everything that gets in my way, the game is considerably shorter but just fun as I do not need to know any of the plot I may be missing. I find it odd that a such a short singleplayer only game can be marketed at 60$ on release it does have some replay value though.

Being a veteran of the Survivor Horror genre (and the many subgenres), I find the concept and execution of this game very refreshing and overall original. The gameplay and setting is simple, pretty much stealth-based in a (very creepy) asylum, but what makes it so terrifying are the very same simple elements. Using only a camera equipped with night vision and batteries that can be depleted, you truly do not know what to expect around every corner or from the Asylum residents (patients?). The no-combat, all survival mechanics also add to the tense gameplay and the very disturbing atmosphere. One of the best games in this genre that I've played in a very long time that has actually managed to creep me out.

ABSOLUTELY MARVELOUS! This is THE simulated city game, one that will be remembered a decade from now.  PROS: -Large maps, quite the accomplishment to run out of building space  -Steam Workshop - Mods/Assets - Pleasantly overwhelmed by the amount of content - nearly every conceivable vehicle make/model, military equipment, airline, vegetation/tree/bush, buildings, statues, and landmarks have been created.   -Maps - easy to make, easy to get off the workshop, game comes with some of course. There's a terrain party website that can copy the topography of your own town/city. Combined with the capability to make your own assets/buildings/props/etc... one can quite accurately recreate their own neighborhood!  -Beautiful! I can run at low res on my laptop or test the gpu on the pc! Tree's sway, chimneys smoke, traffic signals change, every citizen has a name/education level/job/specialty, every building a tenant/resident, every vehicle a destination... attention to detail(s) is obvious.  -Replay Value - Nigh near impossible to create an identical city! Would be worth it at $60usd... the game actually costs <$30... one of the most satisfying purchases I've ever made.  -Self propelled gameplay - building a city can take an hour or a month - its up to you.  -Sometimes I don't even play the game, rather, I'll hop in the cab of a garbage truck and cruise the town for an hour in 1st person mode.  -Stuck it to EA real good!   NOT PROS  -Mods/Assets - it is easy to get overwhelmed. I'd recommend starting without and visit the workshop as needed. Additionally, the in-game menu bars fill up quickly causing side scrolling 200 items to be tedious. Perhaps a wide top-down scroll would be more efficient.  -Sometimes a custom mod/asset will have an error bug.... to be expected. Only time this really mattered was when the After Dark expansion was released - mods that were not updated caused loss of work. Most relevant assets are now after-dark compatable.  -Water physics - the water looks great in this game, however, water has trouble getting into small cracks/canals/crevaces. Making tsunamis is fun/dangerous too:)  -No disastrous events. Could have potential with weather - ie - lightning striking highrises at night - causes fire, fog causing traffic pile-ups, random tsunami

Finally, after Playing Counter-Strike Source for Over 100 Hours I can preety much say that this game is probably the Best Online First Person Shooter ever made. The Community is Colossal, There are a Sh*t load of Servers. But it's not the Amazingly Big Community that makes this game so Big. It's the Gameplay, easy to play, Hard to Master. It's actually a FPS that takes skill. CS:S doesn't use Killsteaks or Perks or any Gadjets and/or Gimmicks, just your Gun.  To those that STILL haven't played this game, please go Buy it Now. Forget the 'Non-Crysis-Realistic' Graphics. In CS:S all you want is to have fun, and that is the Reason why I play Video-Games.   To Have Fun.  Higly Recomended !

Pros: Easy to pick up and play, Simple mechanics, Easy badge (only 5 cards, you get 3 from drops) and the soundtrack is pretty cool. Good atmosphere, a smart robot and a cute space cat. :3  Cons: This is a logic/math puzzle game and there is no real logic to solving the puzzles. Restarting to generate another set of random numbers in hopes of getting a better set seems to be the way to win. When you finally get one that doesn't take 20 minutes to solve 1 part after completing all other parts you'll praise RNGesus. I'm serious, this game requires so much backtracking it's not even funny. RNG and blind guessing at it's finest. Don't bother buying it at full price, it's not even worth $1.99 let alone a dollar more.   Conculsion: If you want to waste time, it would be better wasted on something else. If you want an easy badge, buy this with a coupon or if it goes on sale. I'm considering buying the soundtrack though...

Braid was a unique twist for me, in a world where I thought I had seen every style of platformer.  Braid plays in a similar vein to late-game Toki Tori levels; your character has some control over time as its primary action, but I would say Braid takes the time manipulation to a stronger level.  The main theme outside of time manipulation is the puzzles; each room of the house contains space for a puzzle whose pieces you are collecting as you play. After each 'world' is completed, you put together the simple puzzle, and move on to the next world. As you progress, books on podiums prior to entering the world tell parts of your story.  Time manipulation plays a large role in the game, and becomes crucial as you get closer and closer to the end. It was a new playstyle for me, but definitely fun to work with to solve some of the puzzles. I think the puzzles, in addition to the story, were well-crafted. I initially ignored parts of the story, but it does end up being pretty good.  If you like puzzle/platformers, you'll like Braid.

app_name: Sword of the Stars II: Enhanced Edition
review_text: The initial release of Sword of the Stars II was possibly the most shambolic release of a game I have ever seen, it made Master of Orion 3 look like a masterpiece of finished product.  A year on, and free to people who didn't take up the refund offer on the original, the Enhanced Edition finally shows what Sword of the Stars II should have been on release - a worthy successor to the ground-breaking original. It took them a while, but they got there in the end.  There's still a few rough edges, and some of the easy accessibility of the original is gone, but the sequel shows that they're still willing to challenge some of the design conventions that 4X games all-too-often find themselves blindly defaulting to.

I bought this game for 71p and have gained 10 hours on it... I've only just started nightmare on 1 character... There are 5 difficulties in total and I don't even have the DLC. It does become a bit repetitive but you can leave for a week or so and then get back to mindless slaughtering.  There is one major problem I found with it so far and that is health gaps. From act 4 normal to act 1 nightmare, there is a massive jump in health. Enemies go from like 4k to 50k. They are like mini-bosses and are sponges. I have loads of relics and have 75% Damage Reduction so the enemies deal like 100 damage to me, so I can just sit there spamming, which is a bit boring. Instead of going through Nightmare, I think I might farm the final boss and get my damage up

It's hard to talk about The Wolf Among Us without comparing it to its older brother The Walking Dead as they practically share the same game style. Tell Tale did a great revamp with the point and click adventure genre and what truly shines for their newer instalments are the players dialogue and action inputs that affect that story as you progress.  Playing as Fable sheriff Bigby Wolf (The big bad wolf) you have a bad reputation for having a temper and violent tendencies. The games theme is based around judgement of character and lets you choose to whether live up to your tenacity or redeem yourself in the folks that you serve and protect.  Always thinking about your actions and seeing your consequences unfold blurs the lines of good and bad and that's what makes TWAU really stand out. Will you assert your authority? Show remorse? Keep your cool? or unleash who you really are?  Solve the case, help clean up Fable town. And show your true side.... Your bite maybe worse than your bark.

I've been a fan of The Longest Journey since I came across Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and it left me in a state of emptiness after I finished it, like the feeling you get after you finish a book. I found out about The Longest Journey and played it as well and ever since, The Longest Journey and Dreamfall are one of my favorites games of all time. This game was a gift to me, and it remains to be the best gift I've ever received.  When I learned they would be making a sequel to my favorite games I was so happy but frustrated that I would have to wait so long, but it was worth the waiting! If you're into fantasy, cyberpunk, adventure and story this game will have you come back to it's universe   Stark and Arcadia   over and over again to meet some of the best told and designed characters in amazingly made two different worlds.   Previously, I recommended this game to my friends but I told them they should play the previous games before this one to understand the story and love it, but as I progressed, I saw that this game alone has so much to offer even if you don't know much about the universe the story keeps introducing new characters and shows how the old ones changed as the worlds kept changing. So, even if you haven't played the other games I totally recommend it and I believe it's worth your money.  If you've played the previous games I doubt I need to say more because this game takes the story where it left off.   As soon as you start the game and see the opening cutscene, the game says ''this journey is not going to be an easy one''.     The game has one of the best stories I've ever heard, read or seen and it NEVER lost its magic for me, I was never bored in any part of the game, there was always something else to be curious about something else to explore and understand and try to figure out. The moment you start your Journey, you should be ready to be surprised by anything because this universe is anything but boring. I enjoyed every single moment of it. Exploring the world in Dreamfall: Chapters was especially amazing because of the improved graphics. Every place you wander will have it's own magic with their own colors and a theme unique to them. The game has a fantasy side to it but not in a universe that is filled with Elves and Orcs or Angels and Demons. It introduces so many races with their unique cultures, designs and stories. They beautifully fit in the games universe and they shape it into what it is. The cyberpunk side of the game doesn't look as unique as it's fantasy side, but it brings humans from different cultures together and you will be seeing how they blend in the futuristic world of TLJ. The voice acting is great dialogues are not dull and if you take your time to interact with objects around yourself the protagonist will comment on the objects and Zoë tends to have interesting things to say about pretty much everything. I like her style. Her voice actress is different from the previous game but she does a great job as well. And as I said the story is amazing but I loved how it pulled me in and at some point I was so mad at something that happened I decided harshly and the consequences were so awful it made me feel horrible. So, yes the decisions you make, so far, have great effects, makes you consider the tiniest things over and over again. I hope the fifth book will live up to my expectations and my decisions will affect how the game ends. Though, I'm not sure if I can handle it if it ends badly because of my poor decisions, I will be crossing my fingers.  Yes, I really love the series and I really love this game but I do feel like I must complain about some things that made me frustrated. The controls are bad, sadly. And when you run, you're basically not so much running. So, the exploring part gets a little bit too slow. I'm not saying I don't like exploring, I would've ran around my favorite places over and over again. Well, running is more like fast-paced walking and the animation seems like it as well so I guess it fits. Puzzles are not enough challenging compared to TLJ but considering I was, at some point, randomly clicking on everything trying to find something that works in TLJ maybe this is for the best. Some animations look a little funny but the scenery makes up for it greatly. Some objects are hard to interact with, you need to hover your mouse on them a few times before you can interact. There are some collision problems and I hate not being able to go up some stairs just because they're not important. They're stairs, they're right infront of me, they're wide open for me to walk on, but the game just won't let me. Yes, it is pointless to go up those stairs but I want to.

I played this game after I finished Pixel Puzzles Japan. This game is easier to pick up pieces than Pixel Puzzles Japan. It is harder and longer to beat because the pieces can be rotated. The game now saves puzzle progress so you can exit the puzzle anytime you want, unlike Pixel Puzzles Japan which remove your puzzle progress. Still doesn't support Steam Cloud Synchronization. I can't load the game with another computer.  All pictures are anime alike, but none of them come from real anime. The gallery shows picture in small size and completed puzzle still have pieces curves and pixel pixie is floating in the middle of the image, I can't take a screenshot of them to make a desktop wallpaper. Too bad.  Easy achievements. Basically finish all the puzzles = 100% achievements. Trading cards. Their prices are quite high.  There is hint level bar which filled when you put the pieces correctly. Pixel pixie occasionally fills the bar. Hiding pixel pixie will stop her to fill your hint level bar. Lv 1. Flash Ghost Image (Temporarily shows full image for about 3s) Lv 2. Correct Rotation (Press <ctrl> while holding a piece, and it will be rotated correctly) Lv 3. Show Location (Press <space> while holding a piece, and it will flash its location. The piece rotation is not corrected) There are 25 puzzles + 1 DL-TV puzzle to play. From 60 pcs to 350pcs. If you like anime, and jigsaw puzzles, you might like this game. Note that because of rotating pieces, It took over 4 hours for me to finish the biggest puzzle with 350pcs.

Scratches the tactical game itch. Having the game take place over a period of 300 years and having the player essentially breed their army over several generations was an interesting way to handle resource management inbetween combat encounters instead of just using the XCOM-style base management.  There may be some balance issues between the unit classes you have, and some may not like having most of the classes be permutations on three main classes, but it didn't get repetitive over my playthrough. Massive Chalice may not be a great game for repeated playthroughs, but it was fantastic for a one-off. I love eet.

10/10  This is one of the few games I'd recommend for absolutely everyone. It's absolutely superb in every way possible. Story, art, music, gameplay... Everything.  The art in this game is absolutely stunning. The art style, the multitude of colors and the way the scenery is composed makes the player feel like he/she is playing inside one of the world's greatests works of art.  Gameplay is simple and easy to play, yet mastering the game requires practice. There are no irrelevant weapon upgrades, each and every one of them are great improvements to their respective weapon. Likewise, spirits are also huge improvements. The combination of different weapons, different weapon upgrades, spirits and secret skills makes for an extremely varied gameplay, going from full heads-on approaches towards enemies to more tactical approaches.  The game lasts long enough to have the player invest at least a few hours in the game in his/her first playthrough, while also not being too long so that it feels unnecessarely stretched. Extra modes like New Game Plus add a lot to the game's replay value.  It's hard to even come up with any flaws to mention here. The only one I could think of are some of the Shrine Idols, that can cause the game to become way too hard and not make up for the bonuses they give. But since Idols are completely optional, I wouldn't consider it a flaw.

I've completed the first 5 challenges in an hour, which I feel is enough to get a feel for the game.   Good: -Learning curve is just right (although I'm a professional programmer- might be daunting to non-programmers. -Interesting concept, not seen anything else like it -The PDF programming manual sets out the basics and sets the scene for the 'mystery' -The price is right  Bad: -No in game graphics. I'm assuming if there were any cut-scenes or the like, I would have seen something after 5 levels. Something to develop the story as you go rather than just cut and dried programming challenges would improve the game massively. -Could do with a bit more guidance on what to do when you first start playing. In-game tells you nothing. -Feels more like a tech-demo than a game -Could be so much more

Very impressive graphics over the top of a relatively simple hack and slash game. The story is reasonable, taking you on an enjoyable adventure as your character, Marius, becomes a leader of a Roman Legion seeking retribution against the barbarians who threaten Rome. There isn't all that much to the game mechanics; you have standard attack, block, break guard moves and once you get used to the controls it is fairly straightforward. There are some nice death moves however, where you slice off arms and so on, but these do get a bit repetitive. The multiplayer modes work well in a gladiatorial arena setting, so that's fun for a while with friends. All in all, a game certainly worth picking up in sale for at least a few hours of enjoyment.

WARNING: This game might offend people that take their religion seriously. If you don't like to see any devil related content, its best advised NOT to buy it. Note: This game has a few references to other games made by the same person, its best advised to play Super Meat Boy and The Basement collection first before playing this.  The Binding of Isaac is a 2D dungeon game with a simlar concept of the first Legend of Zelda game made for the Nintendo Entertainment system in the 1980s. I find this game very fun to play because you have a bunch of objectives to do like challenges or completing the game multiple times to get different endings and also unlock new stuff to get in the dungeons. This game features: Multiple endings, Random dungeon maps, 50+ different types of enemies, and 100+ items to collect. If you like Dungeon games or played the 1st Legend of Zelda game then consider this game.  Cost: $5 (Base game) $3 (DLC) Rating: 79.5/100 Good

Just bought this game due to the fact it was on sale, and I am an avid batman fan. So far ive played roughly 30 minutes of the game, and the st-st-stutterrrring has made me want to tear my eyes out.   Keep in mind, im not exactly playing this on a potato (Gtx 980, amd fx-8350@4.5ghz). Ive noticed that the game engine may be affected by single-threaded cpu performance, as only core 1 on my chip is fully utilized at all times. I have a feeling this is what is causing the stuttering, seeing as how my gpu doesnt ever go over 80%utilization, yet my fps is floating around 80-105 ( I am using a 120hz display) These results are the same even when all in game graphics settings are lowered to the minimum.   I cannot recommend this game due to its poor performance. Maybe I will revisit my review if i have a chance to try the game on some different hardware.

The voice acting is even worse than Men of War, but the gameplay is quick, crazy, and there is a fair share of customization to be done when it comes to your inventory. The story is cheesy but the setting is interesting. It is worth mentioning that this is actually a sequel of sorts to Iron Storm as well.  Graphics were pretty good for the time and overall the game is great entertainment for its price. Despite its age the game works very well, which is an interesting point given that when it was originally released hardly anybody was able to play it due to an absolutely crippling amount of bugs in both running, loading, saving, and installing.  This game may also be made by wizards, I found I had access to some of my saves from 2005, long before I had a Steam or even used my current screen name, and I have been through several gaming computers since. Definitely witchcraft or sorcery, no doubt about it.  Pros: Quick mindless gunplay Customization Lots of weapons and levels Sweet armor Alternate history setting  Cons: Mediocre graphics Embarassing voice acting Forgettable storyline Cutscenes drag on a bit

Sword Daughter is the latest visual novel released by Hanako Games although the story is not a Hanako Games original. It was originally written by Rhondi Vilott, and it's representative of the 1980's 'choose your own adventure' type of series. I bring this up now to keep things in perspective.  Although I'm giving this game a positive review, there were some aspects that did annoy me. So I'll comment on the negative things first and then highlight the positive things.  As anyone who's read my reviews of VNs by now, story is the most important aspect for me in determining if I will end up liking a VN. Although I do like the genre somewhat (I like some fantasy aspects although not all; I'm one of those people who isn't a LOTR fan), the writing did put me off at first. It's rare for a story to use the second person perspective, simply because it is difficult to pull off. But I think that the author used it to make the reader engaged more in the story. Most of the characters are either likeable or tolerable, and I thought that the main character Tyrna was in the middle. Now as for the potential love interest Gavin, I didn't like him from the start. He finds Tyrna and depending on the choices that the player makes, Gavin can either be helpful or an obstacle in helping to advance the plot. Aside from that, I really didn't like how in a lot of paths, Gavin would suddenly proclaim his love for Tyrna. I mean, really? No one falls in love that quickly unless they're extremely young and then I don't even think they would fall in love that fast. Gavin annoyed me so much that I wish there was the option to punch him in the face. That would have made me happy. lol  However, these are the only negative aspects I found. So moving on to the positive aspects. The art is extremely beautiful. It's different from the usual art found in VNs but I think that this is fine because of the genre. The music was great, too, and fit pretty well with the scenes. I liked that there were 22 different endings to get and there were enough CGs to make it worth replaying for them as well as the endings.   As I am aware that Sword Daughter is the first in the 'Dragon Roads' series, I do hope that the next book in the series will be adapted to a VN format. I look forward to trying it out and have more hopefuly expectations for it. So yeah, I'm giving this game a thumbs up because I hope to see more.

app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: Before I start, I did not clear the game.. yet, no FOBs.. yet.  So far the game is running smooth, 60 FPS in every cutscene and all the time I am running in the open world. Besides the menu, which does not support your mouse, everything is very well playable with a mouse and keyboard setup. I loved Peace Walker, so the only thing that annoys me -in the gameplay setting- is the missing coop (yes, it was not promised or anything, but as a PW-Lover I miss it.)   Two issues I have found: 1. The unability to alter your emblem, since you end up with like 3 FPS in the creationscreen.. 2. The unstable onlineconnection. Everytime I start the game, I am not able to sign in.   For the rating.. Since I am not only a fan of MGS in total.. But this is most probably the last MGS Hideo Kojima will ever make: 10/10 Despite the flaws that maybe exist currently (hopefully, they fix it in some way), it is the worthy completion to the MGS-franchise. In my 24 Hours, that I played this game so far, I don't think that 60€ (Not $ guys..) were to much for this epic game. I enjoyed at least 23.7 Hours of that.. the rest was creating an emblem ;o  ---EDIT---  Alright, now I have put some more hours in MGS5, time to edit my review..  I have sunk some hours in FOB raiding and defending.. In my opinion it gets old really fast. If you don't take the exact way the game wants you to go, you are screwed. This does not mean, that the infiltration is totally screwed, but it gets a lot harder. The events they hold currently are at least a way to enjoy this feature without the fear of retaliation and receive some bonus. Yet FOB invasions are the real only way to receive some soldiers who are not capped at S-rank.  The emblemcreation-problem was fixed shortly after I put up my review, but I was to lazy to edit it up until now. The serverconnection got a lot better, too. I am signed in as soon as the game starts, and even stay logged in D=  A new feature which was recently added is the almighty MGO (Metal Gear Online). It is free for everyone who bought the game! I didn't get the chance to play it excessivly, yet.. So maybe I will update my review another time, we'll see.  I had something in mind, but I can't recall it at the moment.. Another edit? omg.. _____  Another edit indeed, this time for the badge ;o That's everything

OK, so let's talk here. As of this moment, I have played 31.9 hours total of Evolve, and I absolutely love every single moment. The balance between both monster and hunter is very good, the games won percentage is damn near even, the game itself is beautiful, and no one class is similar at all to the other. I have read many other reviews for this game, and quite a few people are complaining about day one DLC. I do not believe that this is a valid arguement for a negative review for this game at all. Most, if not all big box office games like Evolve have day one DLC, and most if not all have a season pass available for purchase. The DLC currently available is ALL cosmetic, and not at all in any shape or form game changing. There is no pay to win, nor content you cannot unlock simply by playing the game.  Now, as for cost? Let's look at the game as a MOBA title (which it is not, but for monetary purposes, let's look at it this way) Most MOBAs are free to play, but allow you to unlock gods, champions, heroes, etc., etc., for a nominal price of any where between 5 - 10 dollars. Now let's be generous. Let's say, we're paying 5 dollars per 'champion'. There are 5 classes total, Monster, Assault, Trapper, Support and Medic. Each roll has 3 current available characters that you progressively unlock as you play. So, that makes 15 characters. That's 75 dollars worth of content.  As for maps? There are about 7 - 9 of them, if I'm remembering currently... And each of them can have different weather effects, which make them even that much more interesting. I have read many reviews complaining about the lack of maps, but again, let's look at something like Counter Strike: Global Offensive, Call Of Duty (any of them), or any MOBA. You're generally playing the same maps over, and OVER, and OVER again. I feel like most people are looking to pick on the game with this complaint. The maps are beautiful, detailed, and the ecosystem that the devs put together is extremely intriguing (and tasty)  All in all, yes, this game is not for absolutely everyone. BUT, I do recommend it HIGHLY. If you have a friend who owns it, ask to play for a bit. Watch YouTube videos. Make an educated purchase, and this game will not steer you wrong. Happy hunting everyone.

Amazing. Just Amazing. This game is a HUGE step-up from the last game. It's longer which I love because that's the biggest flaw to me for the last game. It has a lot more achievements so I have a lot more to do in the game if the story isn't enough. And best of all, there is a co-op mode. That is the best part of Portal 2. Being able to play with a friend is awesome because it opens up a lot more possibilities for new tests. And those tests go to the community chamber part of Portal. I love being able to create your own test and sharing them with the world. And the story is much better in this than the origonal Portal. It shows the back story to Aperature Science and seeing your friend betray you and your enemie to help you instead of your 'friend' betraying you. Also the end of the game is really good and personally, they don't need to make a Portal 3. It ends so well that they could stop right here. I spent over 100 hours into this game and it's probably one of my favorite all time games. And, it's only what, $15? $20? I don't know. If you don't have this game, first what are you doing? But if you don't GO BUY IT! It's a huge cake and no, that isn't a lie. :)

I cannot in good faith recommend this game. It has everything that all of the previous LEGO games have, but it also comes with its own problems. The main one is that it can be incredibly boring. A few of the missions just don't have anything going on with them. No enemies, no plot points, nothing. Then when the game realizes that you probably should have enemies, it spams you with them, so you literally have to stop everything you're doing every few seconds to beat them. It gets repetitive, and shows that the game developers don't realize that there's a big difference between challenging and annoying.   The makers of Candy Crush also have no idea what that line is, but whatever.   Also, all of the best LEGO games have humor, or, at the very least, characterize their characters pretty well. They're fun to watch. That is not the case with this one. I didn't really care about any of them.   Most of the levels feel like busywork instead of actual levels that advance the story. Heck, some of the levels in between the levels that weren't really levels were more interesting than the levels we got.   I'd say that, if the game got one more re-write for the story, it could have been a lot better. As it was, it had a few glaring problems. I'd say no to this one.

Friends, Romans, countrymen lend me your ears.....  So, I've given this a fair few hours in both solo and multiplayer and feel I've seen enough to give a review.  The first thing to say is that the game does look pretty impressive; the level of detail found in the game assets and environments is wonderful to behold. The character models are good, the lip synching not too bad and the acting top notch for the most part. It's very much a cinematic experience. It's not going to win many awards for historical accuracy but on the whole you do get a compelling atmospheric version of ancient Rome. Presentation and menus are nice but navigating it is a bit clunky, You soon get used to it however.  The gameplay is fairly one dimensional and repetitive but that doesn't mean that it isn't fun, because it is! Essentially this is a third person hack and slash adventure where you block and hack away at an assortment of barbarians. It's fairly easy to pick up and keyboard/mouse is fine if you don't have a controller. Fighting is similar to the Batman games or Devil May Cry but perhaps a little more simplistic. You do get to do some impressive combos and it's quite satisfying chaining them all together. The executions are really quick-time events and it doesn't matter too much if you get them wrong as the end result is the same - dismembered barbarian! The animations for this are good but after a while you know which ones are coming. The campaign so far has kept me interested and there is a hint of the supernatural to the story. There are a number of artifacts/letters scattered about to find so there is a bit of a replay factor there. I'd recommend playing on one of the higher difficulties.  Multiplayer is more of the same but in an arena. It's actually pretty fun and there are four modes to mess about with, (although they are not all that different). There are some tasks to complete whilst running around the arena in your attempt to survive. The arenas are varied and are pretty cool as it all moves about. The multiplayer appears to only support two players, which is a shame as a four player arena experience could have been good fun. You do get to customize your fighter though through experience points and gold. Supporting one of four gods will also affect your experience in the arena.  On the whole it's an average game with above average visuals that's fun to play. I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price but if it's cheap in a steam sale, why not give it a go. For those that say this game isn't worth it, I say it is. I haven't reached the center yet, because I am exploring everything. This game is beautiful, terrifying in scope, and so much fun. I am seriously debating whether or not I actually want to get to the center due to everything this game offers. In scopee, the game offers more than any of us will ever see, and that is amazing once you start to play. From your starter planet, on, you start to realize that you will never see everything a planet has to offer. Then you finally launch into space, and once again you realize this. From pirate battles in space, to sentinels attacking you endlessly this game is both calming and a thrill.   Yes there are issues, but I am sure the team aat Hello Games are working on it, as is the case with every game now-a-days. But once all the bugs are worked out, this game will shine. If you haven't played more than 10 hours, you haven't played the game. So travel on explorers, this game is amazing.

Asymmetric campaign is neat idea. However, as a casual turn-based RPG player, I found the game both complicated to learn and hard at the beginning. In this game I encountered enemies beyond my combat rating very quickly, who to attempt to fight would lead to (I learned) almost certain death. I did not find a gentle introduction into the game. That said, hard core turn-based RPG players may like the complexity of the game and the neat asymmetric campaign. For me, I'll spend my time on other turn-based RPG games with gentler introductions where the developers were keen to make the game easy to learn, such as Age of Wonders III.

This game is a gem, and would go nicely with most any gamers collection. While this game is not for everyone, I have not met a person who didn't like it. If you don't like rougelike games, where you lose all your progress if you die, then this game is not for you. If you do and up buying the game, then an example of your first run though might go as follows.  Get through the first few sectors without much difficulty Go to a nebula Find out your ship is on fire, but only once it's too late Burn to death  OR, it might go something like this  Start fighting a ship Ship blows up you oxygen tanks Rush to repair the oxygen, w/out oxygen to work with Suffocate  PERHAPS, you might, just might, by some miracle of RnGsus, make it to secter 8 in your first run through You'll get excited, because the final boss is coming up Go engage the final boss in battle Prodede to be utterly and completly ahnialated in the most unfair final boss since Dark Souls  If any of that appeals to you, try getting this game. In all seriousness though, this game is very fun. It's fun because it is challenging. If you have a friend who plays it, so much the better; one of the best things about this game is laughing about what happened to your ship with your friend. I should also say that the game isn't that harsh, once you get the hang of it, but the final boss doesn't get any easier.  Final rating: 10/10  Would burn in Nebula again.

You can't really fault the pseudo anime/action comic/superhero presentation of Battleborn. It exudes swagger and charm with a pumping soundtrack that hits all the right notes along with strong voice acting and a varied cast of characters.   So far I've done a few of the story missions, it does indeed seem possible to fail and it's not a snooze fest at all, there is elements of positional strategy at play though it is not a tightly tuned endeavour that novices will have trouble picking up quickly which is refreshing.  The various characters are all very different in play style and function and the helix and loadout systems allow you to fine tune the way you play.   So far it's an enjoyable co-op gun-show that facilitates team play without any high end co-ordination required making it, so far, very light on toxic attitude.  I've not touched the pvp yet but I would be inclined to think that it's going to be a blast.

I just finished the game and I loved every second of it. I even dare to say that it is the best game released ín 2016 so far. If you like a game with a great story, amazing atmosphere and some mystery involved, look no further because firewatch is the game for you. If you liked gone home you will definitly enjoy this game. Just like gone home firewatch's story isn't very long, it took me a little less than 4 hours to beat it. But for me it's not about the quantity of gameplay that matters, but the quality. The characters are interesting, likeable and easy to symphatize with. The dialouge between the main characters are extremely well written. This game may have a compact story but contains all the elements for a great game, and for all the people saying that this game is not worth the money due to its rather short story, it costs just a little more than a movie ticket but it last twice as long. I recomend this game for all the people who like slow paced but story rich games like gone home or any telltale game. Speaking of gome home, firewatch's soundtrack is written by Chris Remo who also wrote the soundtrack for gome home. Do NOT buy this game if you think constant action is a criteria for a good game and can't appreciate great dialouge, story and overall atmosphere.  TL;DR? I'll just summarize with a few pros and cons below.  Pros.  +Great and intriguing story. +Interesting characters. +Well written dialouge. +Beautiful graphics. +Pretty enviroments. +Amazing atmosphere. +Good soundtrack.  Cons. -Occasional framedrops. -Linear story. -Ending felt a litte rushed.

This game is fun.  Its a sequal to the game called PAYDAY.  The entire concept with this game is that you play the part of a bank robber. You and your group and other playable characters are profesional bank robbers/thieves and have robbed many places. In this game you get missions that are banks and a plethora of other things to rob and do . You dont just rob banks, you rob trucks, and trains and a plethora of other places.  As you do this you get money and level up so to speak by getting better and differing equipment among other things also you gain skills which are useful in helping yourself and the other characters helping you.(these characters can be computer controlled or other players)  Anywise, alot of the reviews for this game have started becoming joke reviews....ie to quote a few...'bag throwing simulator' or 'I learned to throw bags inthis game and got a job in real life throwing bags too' etc.  The fact is yes there are times when you will throw bags of money, there are times when you wont. IN fact there are many other things to get besides money...like drugs for example...or items placed to help you.   The interesting thing about this game is that there are mutiple ways to play the game, from taking hostages to doing other things in the area...to playing with other players....to simply soloing.  The fact that there are many ways to play this game....and the fact the developers keep putting out new material...makes this game what i consider one the best types of games to get and to play.  Its not just he game play or graphics and sound....which are not too bad.........they are not super fantastic either....as i have played many games so i am a bit biased.  But the support you get is incredible....and the time and care the developers take to make this game....and the way they speak to the players.....not just arbitrarily doing things or ignoring the players....but actualy giving real information and asking what people think.  That is the sort of game people should play in my opinion...not becasue of the game type but becasue of the support and fun to be had by playing.  Although this same style can lead to many people feeling that its a bad thing....and then those people make up stories how they got alienated or some other outlandish thing....but if you look you will find those are a very small number of posts....and usualy by one player who frakily just doesnt like the game just because.....and they wont even be able to tell you specifc details...that only a person who has actualy played would know.  There is one small issue....and that is a few players you might play with....will cheat like crazy....it was rampant...but isnt anymore...as i assume players found its a heck of alot more fun to just not cheat.  So in the end....I recommend this game....i recommned it for people who like first person shooters....and to people who simply like the idea of playing a bank robber or genral thief....i also recommend this game to peopel with out alot of time who just simply want to jump into a game and shoot and have fun.
