I purchase Payday 1 and 2 both since their release. And just start actual Payday 2 gaming recently. This game looks very good at the first look. It's good to go loud and heist, good to sneak heist.  Somehow after like some hours stealth gaming with friends, I more and more reallize the very big issue of this game - the replication (data sync) mechanism of multiplayer gaming.  Payday 2 replicates attacking, player actions very good, it give you very good attack feedback when you are a client in a MP game.  But there is always a terrible delay of the player movement. I could see my friend run to me throwing me a bag from very far in my sight ,and the bag fell under my feet. This is because his position I see is actually the postion several seconds before. He's actually close to my postion right now. This is not a once or twice issue, this is a issue throughout the whole multiplayer gameplay, which means you have no idea where everyone is actually at. The player position you see are delay displayed.  In go louds, you have no idea where your teammates are going to do. Like in a escape. You see a guy in the back, you run back to him to help him. But he's actually catched up already, what you see is like 3 or 4 seconds ago. Then he see you in the back , he would go back to assit you. Then you both get killed. Or 3 people run to a drill postion, all start to drill because everyone see himself is the first one to get there.  Also, I think it might be a connected issue in multiplayer steath, client gamers are always so easy to be detected by guards. You think you already hide behind objects but the host doesn't know that, it still higher your detected level then you are busted. When I picked the stealth with my friend we didn't realize this ♥♥♥♥. We thought we were not skillful enough though before we switched turns to host and the other guy kept getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off by unreasonable detections. If you are the host or in a offline single gamer mode, you can always sneak like a bird that's ♥♥♥♥ing easy. You can slip through the guards and camera nothing happens.  But if you are a CLIENT GAMER, THERE IS NO FXXKING WAY YOU CAN SNEAK SMOOTHLY. Me and my friend use the same ISP , and we tried in the same LAN. Same issues.  Later I googled it and found another video at youtube, showing him and his friend even had different alert reasons. I don't know if this happened to us but there were several times both of us saw the other one of us caused the alert and we strongly argued over these. Also in his video, the character movement delay is very obvious. There are a lot complaints for years about this but the developers never fix this issue.  I don't know why so many people even level up to 100 for so many times. I get fully mad before I get to the first 100. I probrably would play single player only.

SH3 is one of those games that you need to invest time in. It is a perfect example of a 'Dad game,' as Yahtzee Crowshaw once put it. It's meticulously detailed, and you must learn all of the different eccentricities of the sub to be a great captain.  It uses the real-life technological limitations from WWII to define the gameplay. Want to fire off a torpedo? A standard gas-powered torpedo leaves a trail of bubbles in the water, which ships can detect in advance and will swerve to avoid your torpedo. You can fire an electric torpedo, but you'll need to be close, or else the battery in the torpedo will die and it won't reach your target. SH3 is filled with these sorts of tactical nuances that really make it satisfying to play.  Difficulty is customizable. It can be as simple as 'point the periscope at a target and shoot,' to manually identifying and anaylizing your target's position relative to your own. Difficulty is increased by making the game more akin to real life (limited air, limited fuel, no periscope stablilization, etc.) This helps tremendously, since beginners can relax the difficulty while they familiarize themselves with the ships' systems.  The player is awarded more renown following a mission with high difficulty, compared to a mission with a lower difficulty setting. Renown is SH3's version of experience points. It allows you to 'purchase' upgrades for your sub like improved batteries, hydrophones, conning towers, or even a completely different sub altogether. Medals are awarded after each mission, which you can assign to your crew. This is probably the single most satisfying part of the game; the medals allow your crew to function more efficiently, thus improving things like torpedo reload times.  There's a lot to cover here, so let me just wrap this this up by saying that this is probably the best simulation game I've ever played. I find myself coming back to it every couple of weeks. It's aged quite horribly, but I don't care, since the gameplay is just too good. Forget the sequels in this series, SH3 is the best.

At the full price, no, I would not recommending buying this game.  First of all, it was a wonderful story. The narration between the two characters, including all the backstory that is revealed felt like reading a good book.  The game was everything I expected. It was very professionally done, no major glitches with a clean release. It was a nice adventure/story game.  The downer to me came when I completed the game in 3 hours. While I did not catch every easter egg, I did explore the whole map, all the boxes and took my time taking various routes on the map. The bottom line, for me, is $20 for 3 hours just isn't worth it to me. Had this game been priced at $5 or $10, I would have been more than happy with a positive review.  The worst part was that at the 3 hour point, it falls just outside the time limit for a steam refund. It is almost maddening to know that maybe if I hurried the story along quicker, I could have beaten the game in full AND recieved a steam refund!

This is a hard game to review. The game itself is the arguably the best in the series. Every inch is packed with so much detail and you feel so powerful as Batman. Technically... it's a mess. Crashes are common as are framerate drops and for some reason vsync drops your fps cap by about 10 frames, so capping it to 30fps with vsync enabled gives you a cap of about 22fps??? Also the keyboard remapping is poor, so just use a controller.   So if you have a controller and don't mind the framerate dropping to the low 20's, buy it on special.  In other words: Kudos to Rocksteady for another awesome Arkham game and ♥♥♥♥ the people who made this poor ♥♥♥ port.

The most realistic WW2 FPS out there. Also it's one of the most fun. A must buy if you love tactical shooters or squad based FPS games. However, there is one thing that would make most gamers hate this. That is the realism. It's extremely in-depth, from the battles and locations to the weapon ballistics and overall feel of the game. It makes you catious and wary in firefights and tactical and quick when setting up for one.   Another great thing about this game is it's brutality. I don't just mean difficulty, I mean it's superb visuals. If you're with a group of friends, don't be suprised if they explode in front of you, leaving you to bleed out because some piece of shrapnel pierced your sternum. It's ok though, you'll respawn. Cause that ♥♥♥♥ happens. It's war, son. Brutal, realistic, bloody war. Now get out there, shoot some Nazis, and make your country proud!   7/10

There are a lot of great ideas here, but sadly they are implemented horribly. Combat is floaty and unresponsive. Quests are standard run of the mill kill x rats, gather x berries, etc. Crafting is a boring grind. The staggering amount of things you have to pay for is insane. Worst example I saw in the short time I played was in order to queue up crafting jobs (ex: smelt all your copper ore) you have to buy a consumable item. That lets you craft 10 items at a time, once. Free to play has such massive potential for great consumer experiences (see Path of Exile), but if developers keep putting in blatant money grabs like this that only hinder gameplay, it will continue to have the terrible reputation that it does.

I've tried to like this game and lord knows I've played the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. The problem is that it's not fallout 3 or fallout new vegas. Instead it more and more feels like a hollowed out verision of what someone thought fallout should be. The game is fun to explore and the combat is fun but once you've done something once there's little reason to go back and do it again. The game is so caught up on settlement building that things like proper factioins, back stories, meaniful quests, and interesting characters get tossed out the window. Bethesda had a chance to fix these problems with the DLC and at first it truly looked like they listened. Far harbor got it right and then they announced more settlment DLC with only one other story DLC before calling it quits. It feels like my favorite video game series has hit it's twilight. The game is good but it should have been so much better. In the end Fallout 4 feels like a game that should have been great on par with fallout 3 or close to it. Instead we got a game where they tried and failed to put the effort in to make it shine.

A great quick play with an amazing first person storytelling experience. I would suggest buying this on sale however. The entire premise to this game is following a set path, enjoying what the island has to offer in scenery, and listening to the narrator narate the storyline as you travel through the island. Basically, a letter you wrote, which comes from the title of the game.  If you enjoyed Gone Home, or games like it, you will surely enjoy this game. This was also a Half-Life 2 mod so if you played that then you will definitely enjoy this remastered standalone version of it.

This was arguably the best two bucks I've ever spent. In all seriousness, I highly recommend this game. WHile its rather short, it has an endearing quality to it that, when coupled with it's wonderful story and charming characters, make for a fun ride. If you're thinking about buying it solely for its combat aspect, however, I should add that the combat isn't really there for a thrill of the fight, though some fights may have you on the edge of your seat anyhow. One of the few games I plan to go achievement hunting for.  TL;DR: A really good game, with a good story, and passable combat.

Warning, some spoilers.   You played ME 1 before looking at this, right? If not, go back and get ME1 right now and play it.   OK.   This game takes everything good about ME1, and makes it better. Then it takes the few downsides of ME1 and completely revamps them.   Combat is an order of magnitude better; it feels almost like Halo or Battlefield. You can now interrupt villainous monologues instead of MST3King them as they play on your headset. You can give Tali a cooldown hug, trade witty banter with Garrus, and listen to Jack spew profanity.   Oh, and you can kill a freaking thresher maw with a pistol if you're really good.   Shepard is back, and she (come on, admit it, you played FemShep because MaleShep's voice was unintelligible and you couldn't bring yourself to abandon your beloved character for a new incarnation in ME2) is more badass than ever. She can punch a mecha to death with her bare hands, kill krogan berserkers with a handgun, kill a freaking Reaper with an assault rifle, and repeatedly prove that no matter how much Harbinger rants he is no match for Shepard.   Shepard's friends are...mostly back. Wrex is basically the krogan king, so your Big Guy is Grunt--think adolescent Wrex, or in other words pure testosterone backed up by brute force. Garrus is Space Batman. Tali is all grown up and in charge of awesome missions of her own. Ashley won't talk to you because of the Cerberus thing, but that's OK because at least she's been promoted a bit. Liara is a badass information broker and femme fatale of sorts, and if you don't have Lair of the Shadow Broker buy it as soon as you get this game because it is the best freaking DLC and it exists to reinforce what a badass Shepard is and how badass all her buddies are.   Shep's new friends are...pretty cool. There's Miranda, the arrogant jerk with a ridiculously sculpted body and a skintight catsuit, who becomes slightly less of a jerk over the course of the game; Jacob, the career soldier who at least has his ♥♥♥♥ together; Grunt, who's basically testosterone incarnate; Thane, who's badass; Jack, who's ♥♥♥♥ed up in the head and wears tatoos and little else; Samara, who's a space paladin with...um, lots of cleavage. Looooooooots of cleavage. And then there's the BEST CHARACTERS EVER:   1. Doctor Mordin Solus, who is the best because he:  -offers practical sex advice and doesn't judge -blinks upwards -omits pronouns and this is awesome -is a scientist and science is cool -Sets bad guys on fire -Is the very model of a scientist salarian -and has a cool neck thingy.   and, 2. Legion, who is a geth, and is awesome, and I refuse to hear a word against Legion.   Pros:  +DLC is great, get it all.  +Combat MUCH improved from ME1.  +Soundtrack even more epic.  +Story and characters still awesome.  +Harbinger is best villain.  +Mordin Solus.  +Liara's character development.  +Mordin Solus.  +Grunt in general is great.  +Mordin Solus.  +Legion.  +Mordin Solus.  +The final mission, beyond awesome.  +Mordin Solus.  +Garrus's recruitment mission.  +Garrus in general.  +Mordin Solus.  +Niftu Cal, BIOTIC GOD!  +Mordin Solus.  +Cooldown hug for Tali, best little moment I've seen in a game in a long time.  +Kal'Reegar, great bit character.  +Aria in general.  +Mordin ♥♥♥♥ing Solus.  +Vanguard revamps make it the best class.  +You can shoot a guy while he's in the middle of an evil rant. This is awesome.  +And, last but not least, Mordin Solus. He cannot be emphasized enough.   Cons:  -Still cannot romance Wrex.  -Cannot take up the mating offer you get from a krogan on Tuchanka if you beat the thresher maw.  -Cannot punch out Miranda when she acts really jerkish.  -Jack is a sort of flat and superfluous character, and you already have some decent biotics early-game, so ehhh.   11/10 would assume direct control again.

At first glance, I thought this was going to be a generic city builder with the superficial fluff of playing a dictator to add a few laughs. However, Tropico 3 plays less like a city builder and more like a political simulator. Buildings aren't built to make money for more buildings or to create a better life for your citizens. No, buildings are built only to please the various factions and citizens of Tropico so fewer people consider having El Presidente retire to an 'undisclosed location'. The dictator context is mined for its laughs though and the game uses that sense of humor and a very helpful radio show to establish an instant sense of immersion which falls apart entirely when its variety is quickly exhasted. These extras go from endearing to repetitive all the way to obnoxious in the space of two or three missions. Character creation is where this lack of variety is the most glaring. There is a reasonably wide selection of appearances and traits to choose from, allowing for a real custom character. But with the text of those traits and the introduction of the missions being so specific, the character you've crafted floats away in the contradictions. This is not helped by the fact that El Presidente only has two sound sets, male and female, with the female being so cringe-worthy I only used it once. It is also worth mentioning that, as of the writing of this review, the 'Special Steam Edition' is thoroughly un-Steam. No Steam Achievements, No Trading Cards, No Cloud Saves. Nothing to indicate that this is a Steam game past the title. It doesn't change the way the game is played and Tropico 3 does have in game achievements to scratch that itch, but the lack of Steam features on a game so named seems a little strange. Complaints aside, I enjoyed playing this game, but I don't have plans to come back to it anytime soon. I recommend giving it go, but maybe play through the demo a few times before dropping any money on it.

Where's the tech exchange? Treaties? Backstabbings? Alliances? Trade? Nope just that on or off switch...  When only 0.7% of players have had their homeworld attacked, you know something's gone wrong. (there's an achievement for it ...and it actually shows only 0.7% of players have been awarded it)

review_text: It got laggy, slow responsive time. Good, but not that good.

Action-adventure game with combo-button mashing combat system like Mad Max, Shadow of Mordor, and Batman Arkham Games. Gameplay very similar to Batman: Arkham Asylum, but a tad less polished (and you're not Batman, obviously).  Story is great. Voice acting by Mark Strong...so it's amazing. I'm enjoying this game for the environment alone as it really captures the locale of Warhammer 40K. Uses Unreal 3 engine (so things are shiny), graphics leave much to be desired on the PC, but this was originally an iOS only game, so I'm glad they released this for PC. This is very console-y experience and best played with a controller. I'm using my Steam Controller and it works great. If this was a AAA title, I would be disappointed, but for $14, this is a great game. And if you like playing Rogue Trader or Dark Heresy RPGs, I'd almost say this is a must buy while it's on sale.  So far, I've only played about a few hours, but already it is a nice fun button masher with stunning visuals of Warhammer 40K universe. A deep in depth game, this is not. But you're basically playing your way through a Dan Abnett 40K novel, so that's okay by me. If you're looking for a $60 Eisenhorn version of Arkham City, this isn't it. I see a lot of bellyaching in the reviews and on the forums and seriously, get over it folks. This is a game that is literally cheaper than a movie. If it had come out 5 years ago, it would be tops. But it didn't it came out for mobile platforms in 2016. I, for one, am glad they released it on PC so I can use my controller. Can't imagine playing this on my phone/tablet.  The combat system is a little sluggish compared to some of those other games I mentioned above, but I'm guessing the whole “can be played on iOS device” might be the culprit there. Also the allied AI in the combat is dumb as a box of rocks.   Still recommend as it pretty much just lets you play your way through a Dan Abnett 40K novel. The story, environments, and voice acting are where this game really shines. I can't wait until the next 2!!

I am not often writing recommendations, but for this gem I got to. Larian Studios have done a fantastic job in bringing out a game true to the golden age of CRPG. What you get with Divinity Original Sin is a mix of Baldur's Gate and the original Fallout. Attention to detail is fantastic, although the text elements might sometimes get a bit too heavy for some of you. The combat system is dead on right for me, with a good mix of tactical elements, decision making and choices on how to best approach an enemy. The story is deep and you have plenty of well designed side quests to keep you happy four countless hours. I have the habbit of taking it slow and explore every corner of the enviroment and I can tell you, it is a blast exploring in this beautifully crafted world. Divinity gives you various options on how to approach quests or areas and you are not necessarily bound to have specific character classes with you in order to solve or explore specific areas. In most group RPGs I try to have at least one rouge class character with me (although I do not necessarily prefer it), just to be able to open every chest or get into every location. Larian Studios has managed to prvide access to many areas or access to various situations without depending too much on specific character classes. Just to give you one example, I was surprised to find out that after using my rouge to unlock a door to an abandoned house I desperately wanted to get into, I could have broken down the door with a character that had enough strength or, after managing to get in, I saw that there was another secret entrance through a well in the countryside. Allaround a well designed game!

A fun little arcadey puzzle/strategy game that feels like a board game.    https://youtu.be/o8RMubD5UmM    The gameplay revolves around developing a city column by column. This is done by placing buildings that gather points (Houses) and then to boost those with the help of buff buildings like schools and shops. At the sametime you'll have to be carefull about placing buildings that hamper the living quality of the city, like factorys or even supermarkets, even though they give buffs they can also ruining another area at the same time.  Well just don't place buildings that are negative rigth? And were would the fun be in that? For chalenges sake and because well.. you have to place them as the buildings arent placed like in Cities Skylines or in a RTS game were you can freely decide where and what to place.  Instead the game gives you one or two choices of buildings in the form of cards and aat somepoint you'r gonna have to plonk some factorys down in the middle of happy family suburb.  As you progress the game you can unlock different cards and skills to make you'r concrete jungle more diverse.  Art style is quite nice and it's niceto look at. Graphically you can expect mobile game style graphics, so be wary of that.  In my opinion the game would probably do better on the mobile markets then on Steam, but hey go ahead and give it a shot Mr dev.  In short it's not a bad game but for Pc audiences, not sure if there's enough to it.  Take a look at some gameplay of the game down below to see if it's good enough for you.  https://youtu.be/o8RMubD5UmM

Well, Well, Well. Gemcraft you have become an Executable, and a £4.99 executable at that, which for many of the series followers is a giant betrayal, i am a game designer with a degree in Games Design so i can understand why they made it a pay only game unlike all 4 or 5 previous gemcraft games which By the way if im doing a review im going to be brutally honest.   Gameplay - well rest assured this game lives up to the previous Gemcraft games being the next in the series with the story following the same format as the previous games, the evil darkness is trying to get hold of your spirit forge and you need to stop her (i say her, because it clearly states the 'Evil shadows' are female [possible spoiler]).   game play is very similar to the other games however the biggest difference is there are now 2 new gems, the Black and the White, although the previous games didnt have these gem colours their effects were in the games, if i can remember correctly the Black gem is what the Red gem used to be it will get more powerfull the more it hits an enemy, and the white Gem gets more powerfull the more you upgrade your manapool. i will say that the previous gemcraft game gemcraft the labrinth was amazing, and if 'game in a bottle' make a new game similar and make it cost £4.99 then it should damn well succeed where the others didnt, the map should be 2 or 3 times bigger with more to do on each level.  although there is alot to do in each level theres not as many levels or at least it doesnt feel as if there is. The world map is a grid sytem each tile on the grid is a letter of the alphabet with probably 4 maybe 5 levels in each tile, so there are a lot of levels which is good :) but... for a game that used to be a flash game on the internet i was expecting alot more from an executable that now costs £4.99.  All in all Still the best Tower Deffence Game out there im just dissapointed that there wasnt more new content that the other free games already did.  Verdict - The game is still very good and i still play it even though ive completed all levels, if you cant bring yourself to pay for the game my advice is go online and play gemcraft: Labrinth for free then if you like that one finish it and buy this new one. it is still worth it, and you never know they might rectify the price sometime down the line :)

I always loved DW games, but this spin off is quite a pleasent surprise, you have all the whistles of dw, with an hybrid rpgesque lvling system and equipment , in this case called Skill Cards . The combat is very fluid , very dynamic, and have an adition of a infinite combo system, that if you know what your doing you can chain attacks forever!   Technically , KT finally listened and the game can run at 4k, provide your system can run it, and the graphics are beautifull, run at 60 fps , but it have a 30 fps lock on mid-battles cutscenes for when you destroy a barrier with the cavalry, but they are fast animations and dont distract you from the action, you would only notice that if you run with a fps counter. The transition to in-game engine from anime cutscenes is pretty well done too!  Heard AMD can have drops in fps, i run on Nvidia and didnt had any fps drops was solid 60 all the time.  All in all, its worth its price, lots of fun, and a must have for Musou fans :)

The biggest problem was make a choice: buy Standard, or Starter Edition. Finally, I decided to save this 25€ and buy Starter. Good deal, in my opinion. I was looking for strategy-based FPS by a few months. Rainbow Six Siege is great. Destroyable environment and many mechanics [like breaching through walls or rappeling] adds to this FPS a lot of strategic possibilities. Difference between Standard and Starter Edition isn't painfull at all; it requires more time to spent on collecting all Operators. Graphics are nice, sound very realistic, shooting needs some practise for each weapon, every map has it's own key-spots. Greatly optimalised, 41 stable frames on Ultra settings [RADEON R7 370 4GB]. I've never seen better community, 90% of players are mature, friendly and helpfull. But... The best way to play this game is to play with a team. Communication, synchronisation and strategy are keys to victory. Great game and I don't regret. I hope it'll take my whole holidays.

The good: -Sense of speed and momentum -level design -art style -sound track -sense of scale -the crippling fear of the first jump -skill ceiling -Fear of failing  The ok: -Controls  -use of room scale -replayability  The bad -Motion sickness -no level editor -no mods -Collistions  The good in depth.  This game manages to recreate the feeling of swinging across the world like spiderman and that alone is enough to recomend this game. The sense of speed is unlike anything I have experienced in VR and an understanding of momentum is key. This game takes skill to master but is fairly easy to get the hang of making for some fantastic possibilities and the level design makes sure you have many many ways to reach your destination. All this tied together with a wonderful soundtrack and a windwaker like artstyle makes this game stand out from the others available. The sense of scale is crazy. Looking up at my destination saying to myself 'F*ck thats going to be fun to jump off of' only came once I felt comfortable taking leaps of faith. Often times without thinking its possible to string together an impressive path through the landscape and it rewards you for finding interesting pathways around the level. These aspects make this game absoloutly worth picking up if you don't suffer from VR sickness.  The ok in depth.  The controles work but need to be customizeable. I didn't like the quick snap turn and found it akward to use the grip buttons to jump. The problem was the only other options for the controler setup took away your ability to control how your grappling hooks worked so I was forced to deal with it. Coupple this with a broken trackpad and the controles had a bit to be desired for. The use of roomscale is next to nonexistant but it doesn't really hinder the enjoyment of the game.  The bad in depth.  You cannot play this game if you get sick easy. I am one of few peaople who don't get nausa playing these types of games. I imagine if you werent so lucky your lunch would be on the floor in moments of playtime. The collistion sucks because it tracks the collitions from the center of your play area. This means if you somehow driffted to the left or right to much what is under your feet may just clip through you because the center of your room is where your 'VR Legs' are. This means you have to stay in the center of your room lest you make the platforming way more difficult. The fact that there is no level editor or mods isn't really a horrible horrible thing but I desperatly want more of this game. I want to make my own playground to screw around in. Maybe even multiplayer introducing races or something to give the game a bit more length. The game is somewhat short but thats not a bad thing because its a sweet game. It doesn't overstay its welcome.  All in all if you don't suffer from motionsickness I recomend this game. Its fantastic

Don't buy into the ridiculous bandwagon everyone jumps on for this game. They say that the storyline makes all of this worth playing, they're wrong. 'Oh the main character deteriorates throughout the game, SO DEEP!' 'Oh they really stick it to those CoD games and shows how bad war really is YEAH!' There are a million games out there with a protagonist that develops, a million other games that portray war as anything but glorious (Even CoD 4 does this in many places) These alternative games also play far better than this one.   The level design is dull, combat is just horrible, and the storyline and its oh-so-amazing 'twist' was the most disappointing thing I think I've ever seen coming from just how much people worship it. If you're wanting the next great thing, skip this game, but if you're that curious, then at the very least wait for a sale. I can honestly not express how dull this game is, I won't spoil anything but I'll just say that the whole point the story tries to prove is just moot when the game behind it is a corridor shooter with absolutely no freedom whatsoever.

“… she stares up at you with awe, as if her god has stepped down to earth to face her. Maybe it has.”    Geneforge is a great turn-based role-playing game experience with a deep and meaningful story in combination with a unique take on magic. What it lacks in graphics it gains twofold in detailed descriptions of events throughout the game.   Your decisions have major impact on the game’s conclusion and gameplay is vastly different depending on which of the three classes you choose.   The almost total lack of music and no voice acting should be mentioned as the disadvantages of this classic RPG.    Trivia:    The attempt of futuristic weapons with devastating effects that simultaneously felt sensible and maintained balance were one of the most difficult gameplay issues the developers had to resolve.    Achievements:    The game has no Steam achievements.    Chronology:    Geneforge 5: Overthrow (PC) Classic turn-based role-playing game  (Fantasy + Science Fiction) – 2009   Geneforge 4: Rebellion (PC) Classic turn-based role-playing game  (Fantasy + Science Fiction) – 2007  Geneforge 3 (PC) Classic turn-based role-playing game  (Fantasy + Science Fiction) – 2005  Geneforge 2 (PC) Classic turn-based role-playing game (Fantasy + Science Fiction) – 2003  Geneforge (PC) Classic turn-based role-playing game (Fantasy + Science Fiction) – 2002

First things first, most of the poor reviews for this game are from hardcore racing game fans. this review is from the point of view of someone who has almost never played a racing game before. with that said, i can safely say that the crew is actually a pretty good game.   The story is a little short with me having beat the campaign in a little under 18 hours (over the cource of about 5 days with ocasional side quests to level up my cars a bit before the next race), however the game offers some replay value in that you can go back to any mission you have done and replay it, though the rewards dont change for beating it at a higher level unless you've reached level 50 and unlocked platinum parts, in which case its worth going back and re-doing some missions.  The 'skills' are a touch annoying in that if you accidentaly trigger one while driving about you either need to open your phone and choose abort, open the map to auto abort it, or just let it time out. The game also claims to be MMO, but i played the entire campaign in solo mode because i couldnt find anyone to coop with, instead just getting an error that coop failed because there is no one in my session and in general only actually passing other players on the road a coupple of times every so often.  In general, i did enjoy the story and the game as a whole and ill continue to play it to complete the challenges, skills and the factions missions you unlock after reaching new york. If you havnt played any racing games before, this is quite a good one to start with, BUT i would not reccomend buying this at full price. wait for a sale and get it then.  i will say that i haven't noticed any problems with 'rubber banding AI' or undestructable cops, but thats just me and i also haven't had the game crash on me (yet)

I originally got this game thinking it was a fun Metroid clone. But that label does an injustice for what the game presents. There is an unbelievable amount of items and powerups packed into this game, and thats not even bringing up the most unique thing about this game: glitching the world! That concept really enhances the game experience and presents a new set of challenges and strategies that your basic Metroid clone would lack. It also is paced very well, starting you off nice and slow, but really pushing you come the end when you get more powerful. Even on the easiest difficulty, playing careless will result in death. Doubly true for bosses, which all present difficult but fair challenges. However, a few bosses can be defeated using cheap tricks.  The story knows its place is on the backburner, because the thing that sells this game is the adventure and action. So it is generally not intrusive. And the backstory is revealed only through certain pickups. But it does have some interesting ways of reintroducing itself, ways that you will definitely not see coming. The story isnt anything special, but it was not lazily written by any means.  Overall, Axiom Verge is one of the best games I've played on Steam. And thanks to item percentages, multiple endings, and even a speedrun mode for those who enjoy that challenge, there is replay value there. Whether you get it on sale or not, it is worth the price tag, without question. This game is not just some Metroid clone, its takes that label and glitches it into oblivion.

At first I was skeptical about this because it wasn't advertised very well in my opinion. However, after completeing the game I have to say, this is an amazing stand alone. Now I wasn't born in the 80's but I have watched a lot of 80's movies thanks to my uncle. It captures the 80's future si-fi movie perfectly. The story, the soundtrack are all reminiscent of the 80's. This game has amazing gunplay and sounds and is very much like FarCry 3 but a bit watered down. The story isn't as long, there isn't as many weapons and attachments. The vehicle and wildlife scene are about the same just a bit less diverse. The exploration feels as good as FarCry3, which means that enviroments feel generally the same but different simultaneously. The whole game flows together and never breaks inmmersion. This game needs a fully fledged out sequel!

City building games have been a staple of PC gaming since the beginning. It is a subset of the RTS genre that helped to pioneer both sandbox gameplay and the concept of nearly limitless replayability. Fastforward to the present and the genre remains very much alive and well in Tropico 3; a game that takes the foundation of the genre, adds a great deal of social and economic depth, and finally puts a Latin twist on it for good measure. Developed by Haemimont Games and published by Kalypso Media, Tropico 3 has all the features of a city-building game developed by the mainstream likes of Electronic Arts.  The first thing that will grab your attention is the visual quality. Tropico 3 brings the beauty of tropical islands to life very similar to the way Far Cry did. From lush forests to arid deserts, the varying environments on a single island help to break up any visual monotony that would normally be a problem. Of course, this isn't to say that the random map generator can't and doesn't create maps with little variation. Thankfully, the game does allow you to preview the landscape before starting on a new island.  If the visuals aren't impressive enough, the soundtrack will get certainly get your attention. The music attempts to capture the authentic Caribbean style and does a fairly good job of it. In fact, the only real downside to the soundtrack is that there doesn't seem to be enough tracks. You will hear the same tracks many, many times during one game, which can last for hours depending on whether you're playing in sandbox mode or a campaign.  In order to maintain the game's authenticity, the majority of the voice acting is Spanish. Moreover, any immigrants or workers hired from other countries will mostly speak English. Only the voice acting that the player needs to understand is done in English with a decent Latin American accent. For example, there is a radio announcer that provides regular updates on the situation of the island.  The gameplay isn't the standard city building players have come to expect from games like Sim City. Instead, Tropico 3's focus is on the social, political, and economic development of the island nation. The game introduces a few factions that the people align themselves with such as Capitalists, Communists, Nationalists, Militarists, Environmentalists, Intellectuals, and the Religious. And, the player is tasked with appeasing these factions whether by building structures such as churches or military bases, signing edicts that reduce pollution or ban contraceptives, or signing treaties with either the U.S. or the U.S.S.R.  The faction system brings a lot of depth to Tropico 3, and it isn't just about increasing the happiness of the overall population. Every couple years an election is held on the island that the player must win. Appeasing a majority of the factions helps secure votes, but it's based on more than making all the factions happy. For example, a majority of the population may belong to a single faction, thus making that faction the most important focus. Knowing which factions to appease and when is crucial to getting reelected. The player can choose to give political speeches during each election, and even pick what topics to address, which can have an effect on the voters.  The elections aren't the only thing to worry about it. There is also the potential for members of a faction to become rebels. If the player makes a faction angry enough, it will increase the number of rebels. Then, those rebels will attempt to sabotage infrastructure, take hostages, spread propaganda, and even assassinate El Presidente. Of course, being in good standing with the Militarists (the army) allows the player to fend off against rebel attacks, which even play out on the streets when they occur.  Economically, Tropico 3 is based entirely around three major sources of revenue: industry, agriculture, and tourism. The player can use farms, which can be set to harvest a variety of crops from food to tobacco; industrial buildings, which take those crops and produce products; and/or tourism attractions, which bring people to the island who will spend money.  Based on the map the player is given, some economic resources such as oil wells and mining deposits, may not be available, forcing the player to rely on other ways of growing the economy. Economic progression in Tropico 3 is a slow process, even using the 3x speed feature that's available. Moreover, it needs to be closely watched by the player because of random events that may occur. For example, throughout the game, the state of the world economy may fluctuate, causing an increase or decrease in the price of your exported goods. These events will impact the player's economy dramatically, forcing the player to take action.  Tropico 3 doesn't offer a huge number of building variations or options like many city building games do, but it doesn't need to. The depth of the game doesn't stem from the cosmetic look of the buildings, but from the dizzying level of depth and customization. For example, all the farms look exactly the same, but the player can set each farm on the island to grow a different crop. Better yet, where the farm is placed affects what types of crops it can grow. Some crops grow best at high altitudes, in high humidity, or in sunny areas. Picking the right crop for the right location can make or break your economy.  To add to the depth, the player can also set the wages of the workers based on the job or education level. Even better than that, players can set wages based on each individual building. For instance, the cooks at one restaurant could make $15 while the cooks at the restaurant close to the tourist's hotel could make $20. Players are also able to easily set the wages of all the cooks, regardless of which restaurant they work at, as simply as clicking a button. The same thing goes for the education level options, which allow the player to set the wage of all employees with no education, a high school education, or a college education.  Player will have to deal with a variety of problems such as pollution, economic disparity, crime, housing, political unrest, foreign influence, overcrowding, extreme weather, and a variety of random events that can impact the island. Hurricanes can sweep in and destroy key buildings such as electric substations, which could create rolling blackouts across the island, reducing the output of industry buildings that require power and lowering the overall happiness of the population.  Despite the game's astounding level of depth and options, however, there are a few problems that can cause headaches. For starters, the in-game tutorial is a less-than-adequate introduction to the game mechanics. It does a fine job of getting the player used to the UI and where certain information is represented, but it doesn't explain how to actually grow the economy or reduce the threat of rebellion. For example, the tutorial will tell the player how to build a farm and set a crop, but it doesn't make it clear how exactly it contributes to increasing revenue.  There are also some minor control issues. For example, when selecting a building to place on the map, the player uses the middle scroll wheel to rotate the buildings orientation. However, the scroll wheel is also used to zoom in and out, which means the player needs to zoom in close enough prior to selecting a building to ensure the placement is correct.  Overall, Tropico 3 should be applauded for its depth and customization. The game's visuals along with its unique and authentic soundtrack help draw the player into its Caribbean setting. And, regardless of its few problems, none of which are game-breaking, it does an excellent job of focusing on the political, social, and economic pieces of the game, each of which often affects the others in some way.

Overall, I don't recommend you to buy this game at full price (even though it's just a dollar/euro) and since it seems like a small project/game, I doubt it will ever get updated with some better controls or/and levels, so don't get your hopes up. When I first played this game. My first impression was horrible.. it has that really gloomy dark air about it, the main character is not very attractive (both physically and mentally). Then there's this mysterious old lady called Queen of Maggots appearing out of nowhere and offered something too hard for reason to accept. There's not much you can do in game basically walking around and interact with objects and it really is creepy. I felt anxious, I didn't know what to expect.   By the time I finished this game I find it simply beautiful. The beauty of this game is not explicit; it lies within! Despite having flaws here and there (I had problem launching it and there's the maximum save file issue) I really liked it. The story is rather immersive and interesting, good character definition and almost everything in it is negative in nature (hence the age restriction). I never really looked into something negative as depression and suicide, this game offered me just that.   Recommended :)

The 'B' company fight their way through snowy mountaintops, dense jungles and dusty villages. With a heavy arsenal of deadly weapons and a slew of vehicles to aid them, the crew set off on their mission and they are ready to blow up, shoot down, blast through, wipe out and utterly destroy anything that gets in their way. Total destruction is the name of the game - either online or offline, enemies will soon learn there is nowhere to hide.

Do you like grid based dungeon crawelers? The ones where you and your enemies move square by square and do the sword dance in a 2x2 around each other? Then get this game and its sequel.   They are wonderful games into this genre with so many secrets to find, loot to gather, treasure to take and enemies to fight. Honestly, I'm tempted to add the 'Horror' tag to it for how much it made me nearly crap my pants when I turned a corner and an enemy jumped at me.   But yeah I fully recommend this and the sequel. It gives me that itch to play it when I stop and in my books that makes it a great game

I was sceptical when I first downloaded this game, however after only 2 minutes of gameplay I was hooked. Note that this game should note be taken seriously, if you go in with a playful mood then you should have a good time.

This game was great for the whole hour and change it took me to beat Act 1. It then abruptly ended, at which point I discovered I had not actually purchased a whole game, I'd only purchased half of one. This is a real shame; I wanted to support a great game design team, play a good game, and I even threw in the extra for the soundtrack because I thought 'This team has a vision, and I want to get behind a work of art.' I wasted $18 on half a game and I haven't got a clue where I can claim my soundtrack. I think Tim Schafer should be ashamed to fool people into buying something that isn't complete and then charge them an in-app purchase to play the rest of the game. It's underhanded, sleezy, and I'm not going to be buying from Double Fine or any other company with Tim Schafer's name on it again.  TLDR: Great hour of a game, wouldn't pay 18 bucks for an hour of gameplay though. Super mad that they are charging for the rest of the game, should have charged the price for the whole thing upfront.

(Edited as I wanted to put the review in more depth) Okay, so I've played Heroes and Generals for some time now. I really like the concept of the game, though it has its flaws.  Things it did right:  - The game. The game itself is a wonderful concept that has been made to the liking of many players.  - The guns. You can play as you want. You can buy a semi-auto or an auto rifle depending on your playstyle and upgrade it to your liking  - The modes. There are three main modes of play in Heroes and Generals: Assault, War and Skirmish. Each has its own difficulties and tactics.  Things it did wrong:  - Anti-cheat. This flaw is blatantly obvious, and can be noticed withing 10 or so games. There are a few main types of cheating in this: Wall hacking (Where the player can see other players through the walls), Aimbotting (The cursor tracks players), and XP / credit farming (where one player lets another get a LOT of kills on them, to farm XP and credits).  - Currency. This is well thought out in most places, but when the cost to repair your sniper rifle is more (Per shot) than you gain from a kill, it becomes an issue and you just end up waisting money.  - The players. Most team-mates dont actually care about winning the game or the objective. To them it is more of a CS:GO type of game than it is a strategy, which is what this game tries so hard to be, most players will either be absolutley terrible (Which I can understand, but the matchmaking levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold) should be sorted out) or they will be trolls and team kill or greif.  - Grenades... Oh boy, this one pisses me off. Grenades are not only the most over-powered pieces of ♥♥♥♥ in the game, but you can carry 3 per item slot (Meaning that a normal player can carry a max of 9 with no gun). Players seem to find it enjoyable that you can just throw these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s one after another until you kill the player you are trying to kill. I find this extremely stupid, as not only do these cost more to use than you get per kill, but RETO enforces the idea of using them.   RETO complains about losing money, but they only really have themselves to blame. You need to listen to your players. Think about adding / changing:  - The amount of carriable grenades  - The cost of repairs on certain weapons (As the recon class is now useless)  - An actually somewhat useful anti-cheat system  Aside from that little rant... love the game... would recommend..

Genre: Horizontal, bullet hell type of shmup  Introduction: This is a unique shmup, but not made for everyone. That because of the anime style, some seminudity (removable and NOT needed to enjoy the game, explained later on), fast pace (subjective), and taking a while to getting used to the controls, binding all the many keys to your liking, learning how to use the game features (getting rid of bullets with planeshift, controlling Phase Level), and so on. Once you learn how to play the game properly, it can be really fun, and the online duet revolutionates.  Gameplay: Good The gameplay is fluid, resposive and satisfying. An issue I do not share, but many people seem to do, is that there are many keys for many functions. Your regular shmup has a fire and bomb key, and sometimes a focus or slow-down and a charge attack key. GundeadliGne has fire, rapid fire, mana shot, bomb, focus or slow down, turn, and even a screenshot key! The best way to play the game seems to be in a controller or an arcade stick. Personally, I have to admit that it took me a while to use all keys properly. The two initial characters are said to be one for average players, that is Eryth, and one for beginners, Elixirel. Eryth can only shoot straight, is faster than Elixirel and seems to be able to cause much more damage (don't rapid fire too much or her guns will overheat). Elixirel is able to fire to to various places so you shouldn't bother staying in the front of a boss to do damage, but she's slower than Eryth and sometimes it costs you a life. The bosses bring innovative bullet patterns, most of the time, but either they are good or not is subjective. I say they are. If you're too slow to destroy enemy waves, you'll run out of time and may not be able to finish a mini boss or a boss itself. So the game requires you to go fast, but there's an issue few people might experience. Depending on your computer's hardware, the game may run slower in fullscreen mode and a tad faster in windowed mode. That happened to me, and for some motive I can't get my game to run on fullscreen mode anymore, so I was quite shocked at the difference. If you're scoring high in the game or pulling out death bombs, you'll raise your Phase Level, making the game harder. If you're not ready for high Phase Levels, try using bombs before being hit or even don't bomb at all. Giving up a few lives to not lose them all is the key. It's not explained in the game, but there's a manual you can check by right clicking GundeadliGne in your game library, and it's recommended you do so, as many other features are also explained there.  Game Visuals and Music: Moderate The pixelated graphics are nicely worked. A problem is the seminudity of some of the bosses, that can be hidden editing the .ini file in the game folder. The seminudity turns the game down for some people, making they think that this game is trying to sell with sexual content, but that's NOT the case. In my point of view, It's supposed to add to the chaotic climate of the game, just like in Bayonetta. The characters and other bosses are well designed. The music quality is subjective. The original music is not the greatest out there, neither the arranged version, but they fit so nicely, it seems they are better than they actually are. I was surprised when listening to the game OST on YouTube, as they didn't feel so awesome as in the game.  Game Storyline: Moderate Not really the focus of the game (so it's discounted from the overall rating). The story is presented between stages of the game, a screen of text alongside with character art. It's not the most enticing way to tell a story, but the story itself isn't shallow, neither badly written and translated. It's a continuation of the previous game, Gundemonium Collection. If you want to read it, you can check GundeadliGne's TVTropes page.  Game Entertainment: Good As some people would have trouble adapting to the game's many features, and some people would think bad of this game because of the seminudity, I can't say those people would feel entertained playing GundeadliGne. But if you fit the target demographic of the game, several hours of fun are guaranteed. And even better, if you happen to have a friend that owns the game and lives in the same country as you, both of you can experience the online duet at it's best, that is fantastic. However, if you're playing with someone from other country, you'll have connection issues and the controls are going to be far from responsive.  Overall: Excellent game for people that are okay with all the items listed in the introduction of this review, and have someone to play the online duet mode properly.  Good game for the standard shmup player, but they might have a bad time adapting to the controls and game features, also if they don't mind the anime style and seminudity.  Moderate game for beginners, people that would give up on trying to understand the controls and game features, and only playing the game to pass some little time, also being or not being slightly triggered by the seminudity.  Bad game for people that dislike the anime style overall, that would like to pilot a ship rather, also that thinks that the controls and game features are unnecessarily complicated and that also thinks that the seminudity is there to 'help selling a bad game'.

AWESOME GAME!!! LOVING IT! :)

This fun sandbox adventure game has a lot to offer. You could mine for gold and gems trying to get rich, or maybe go on a killing spree and defeat all the monsters in your way. You can even find islands in the sky! And the best part, you can play with you friends.  This addictive game is a 2-D sand box, boring right, not even close! There are many possibilities in customization for your character and your world. I saw this game before it was finished and thought it was cool, now it’s a masterpiece. It is not often you find such a gem in the gaming world. I already hear the people saying “A 2-D sand box, it’s a Minecraft rip off.” They could not be more wrong but because of people saying that the game doesn’t get much attention. Now let me talk about problems, with the AI in friendly NPCs they walk into enemies and get killed but that is not a problem if you have walls or doors. And the only other problems are small bugs, not bad ones, all I encountered were funny or helpful like a fish out of water when it was not raining and throwing a bomb in your own house then closing the game before it blew up and come back. POOF, the bombs gone. On a unrelated note, I didn’t talk about game play because I could not begin to explain, there is so much stuff to do or see or even make!  This is an amazing game and 9.7 out of 10.

CAPCOM use to be such an upstanding company with a wide diverse catalog of games that while not all award winners were, in fact, rather fun and varied. The Resident Evil series has been wildly skewed since its humble, campy beginnings but it built a lucrative franchise for CAPCOM so it's not surprising that they've been milking this particular cash cow for close to two decades. Unfortunately, their last few additions to the RE series have been ludicrous rather than lucrative, some so terrible that they've become the insult to the injury that the movie adaptations scored in the franchise.   RER2 EP 1 plays absolutely horrendously. The frequent frame rate drops, terrible mouse and keyboard controls, the frankly dated environment graphics, the terrible integration of standing graphics verses interactive graphics, the too short episode (which played like a prolog to the episode rather than an episode), and the blatant lies and hamfisted attempts to cover up those lies about features that were advertised since day 1 of the preorder cycle lead me to conclude that this game was never intended for a PC audience. CAPCOM yet again just wanted to cash in on the PC market money without actually committing effort to adapt to the needs and requirements of the market. It's clear that there was little to no testing for this badly ported title and in how quickly the company was to blame the consumers as well as some unknown copy-editor or intern for the misrepresentation of their product which didn't seem to bother them until the consumers started to complain about missing and/or misrepresented features promised to them.   The cons outweigh the pros thus far in this disastrous addition to the RE series and not even the absolute nostalgic novelty of playing Barry Burton can or ever could take the sting of betrayal, shady business practices, and simply bad ports that CAPCOM continues to employ when it comes to their offerings to the PC market.   TL;DR: This game might look good at first but it pretty much takes a dive within the first few seconds of gaining control of your character(s) and plays like an absolute brick. The story is paper thin, the 'zombies/monsters' are laughable, and the dialog, while well acted, is typical RE ♥♥♥♥♥. My suggestion is to give this game a pass until at least two more episodes and a veritable crap ton of updates and optimization fixes are released because otherwise you're paying for a terrible gaming experience. Save your money for now, my friends.  SCORE: 3/10

Probably I won't play it again for a 100% completed game.

Those on Windows may ignore this comment.  I want to love this game. I really do. As a fan of beat-em-up games, I can't complain about the gameplay itself. The combos are easy, and the game itself is challenging.  Unfortunately, playing this game on Linux with a 360 controller is basically impossible. On the menu screen, right maps to up for some reason. The dodge input doesn't work, the RT and LT buttons do nothing. While I had similar issues with Megabyte Punch, that game at least gives you the ability to change your controls. In Megabyte Punch, you select the command you want to change, then press the button you want to change it to. Simple. In this game, I don't even know how the control changing works. I click one control option, and it always changes to either Y or Z rotation.  It's too bad. Maybe if I ever own a Windows machine I'll try again, but for the time being I'm going to be avoiding this game and the original.

I am loving the game so far. Great acting and great voice acting. The grafics are demanding but look absolutly amazing. On the highest settings I could still run confortably above 70 FPS with very rare (unnoticeable) drops to the 60s. Also I am playing at 1440p on a GTX 1080. I will try it on my gtx 980 another time at 1080p but i expect no changes. Great story. I will not get into spoilers.  Gameplay could be better. 1- There is no crouching function, it is done for you automaticaly when near a smaller 'cover' when under atack.  2- You can't swap the over the sholder view while shooting from one side to the other. Or a first person mode. 3- Aiming seems a tiny bit off. 4- No scope for any of the weapons. 5- Range limit for bullets? I haven't been able to hit a target unless they are within range. swaping for a sub lets me target further and rifle even more so. Do the bullets vanish or lose all damage over such short distance? Probably not. It isn't gamebraking for me, as i just forces you to use the right tool for the right job.   The skills in this game (and skill upgrades) are awesome and you might endup underusing them in exchange of a more shoot-them-all kind of aproach. They do have enemies that will force you to use them a little more.  From me it still gets a 9/10. Haven't finished it yet and I would already prebuy any sequel at this point.

It surprised me how much I enjoyed this. Very much an updated Gauntlet for our time, as good as I *remember* Gauntlet being (i.e. better than Gauntlet actually is if I play the original now). Great non-linear level design with lots of hidden stuff. I'm not usually a huge fan of pixelated graphics, but the ones here work really well and are full of colour, detail, and neat lighting and animations. Haven't tried the co-op yet but expect it'll be great. Character classes make a significant difference in play style. I got 9 hours out of the main campaign and still have the free expansion to do. Recommended.

Probably one of the more underrated games on steam. Shame there won't be more of this series.  Graphics are nothing special, reminds me of games like Kotor and Mass Effect 1. They aren't bad, they're actually pretty pleasing to the eyes, but they wouldn't blow anyone away on release and certainly wouldn't nowadays.   Combat is probably one of the most fun experiences I've had in any rpg. It's generally pretty varied, tons of enemy variety, tons of weapons etc. When you unlock some of the better abilities (like the aoe fire spell as a mage) you actually feel like a badass killing machine. Very rewarding experience.  Haven't completely finished the game yet but main story and faction quests are all pretty entertaining. Not as good as some of the other rpgs I've played (like Kotor) but probably on a similar level to a Fallout or Elder Scrolls story. Not amazing but sufficient. Only complaint is that most of the side quests are very menial, some are decent but for the most part they all just send you in to some dungeon that is slightly different than the last one you went to. Still worth doing as they expand on the story if you're in to that kind of thing.  This is also a lot of content for the money. There's probably at least 60 hours worth of it if you do sidequests and DLC. It really is a shame this series is probably dead, if there was a sequel with a slightly better main story with more engaging main characters and improved sidequests/less repetitive dungeons it would probably be one of the best rpgs out there.  As it stands I would definitely recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed Bioware rpgs and similar games.

Took around 25+ hours to complete first playthrough. Lots of Dialogue, sometimes too much. Setting is great. Music is ok, combat music felt very repetitive. I think I heard the same song over and over for 80% of the battles. I love the changes and additions to cyberware. Played as a Cyberwared-Melee Decker. Money was somewhat of an issue so sometimes you gotta bite your lip and hold out for the best stuff without going for the middle level equipment. Matrix gameplay is different and neat, but still just not that fun. And in certains missions you have to do the decking no matter what, with a time limit no less. I had a great time playing it, maybe not as much as Daggerfall but more than Dead Man's Switch. If they kept making these games, I'd keep buying them. Always feel like they are a good bang for your buck and you'll spend the next few days thinking about the story and looking up alternate endings. The biggest complaint of the entire series is the lack of customization for party members dealing with Karma Points so I imagine replays would get repetitive. But I know it takes alot to balance everything just right for gameplay and storytelling, so that's the price you pay when you run the shadows.

OK now for the real reviews: - Obviously revamped UI. - Remake Voice Acts (Neptune's pitch is higher though) - Gamindustri Main Menu music is awesome. - Now you can rewatch any Video scene straight from Museum. - No more Majekon'nu shares. Don't let the cartoony aesthetic deceive you. This is a quality game. In the JRPG style (menu-based combat), you play as the Vice President of Earth, your typical blowhard politician. But you don't fight as him but as three of 30 or so characters that you collect through a variety of side quests. Each of the characters has different strengths and weaknesses, like elemental resistance, healing, powerful attacks or weaker attacks that hit multiple enemies. Also, each character has a 'talent', which ranges from super handy (like transporting from one location to another, offering powerups, zooming out in the map and speeding/slowing down time) to the useless (changing the music, the weather, etc.) All of the different characters allow you to play to your own playstyle. Want to wallop your enemies? Do it! Want to play it safe with an on-hand healer? You can! There are characters who help you level faster, who restore your energy, and many who do wacky things that have big payouts later at severe detriments now.  The story is silly and full of references to typical JRPG mechanics, Dungeons & Dragons, video games in general, pop culture. The baddies are equally silly, with mutant animals like a Catctus (a cat-shaped cactus) and the Decaffinator (a robot espresso machine). It never takes itself too seriously.  Don't be deceived by the cutesy style. This is a well--crafted game. I spent nearly 40 hours trying to unlock all the characters, do all the sidequests, and unlock all the achievements. IT's a super slick design, great interface. The map is huge with tons of secret areas and collectibles.  Cons (very few and minor): There are certain tasks that can only be completed with certain characters (mainly unlocking other characters). And some of the character unlocking tasks are vague in what you need to do and require either great thought or an online cheat and are not obvious at all. (Es: For the scientist character, you have to just hang around until there's a thunderstorm, which you have no control over). Also, the world is SPRAWLING and there is no actual map that you can access, even to get a vague idea of where you are or where you need to go. There is a character that allows you to zoom out, but it doesn't go nearly as far out as the entire world. Some of the areas are not entirely obvious that you can enter (their ramps to higher/lower areas are often seemingly invisible). Thus, I spent a LONG time in certain areas going in circles, trying to access an area with a non-obvious entrance. You can go down into some of the oceans, too, which took me a LONG time to figure out. However, most of the game is clearly telegraphed with graphics or dialogue as to what you should be doing or going, though not always.  Overall: Great game, especially if you like silliness and menu-based combat. Don't be fooled by its cutesy look. This is a quality game.

It's not a game, it's a meta-game. A game that simultaneously mocks and sings the praises of the gaming culture. Expect some pieces that seem buggy, but that are actually very cleverly crafted puzzles. Expect some crude graphics, which is there for a reason. There's combat, but (with the exception of one optional creature) it's neither very difficult nor real combat. And death - death is an illusion. ;)  So, really, it's not a game - it's a meta-game.

I've not started any of the dlc, just doing the base game. This is a nice trade/rogue/space game using a mission system very similar to how I want to make myself. The proceedural missions scale with your skill possibly too quick, but all fights remain at least a minor challenge so you dont find yourself getting too over powered, or bored for that matter. If combat starts to bother you, mining exploring and salvage make nice distractions, and it all seems to help you gain xp if the next story mission prooves too much challenge.  I've not encountered any crashes and much like self driving cars; the only bugs i find are when i let the ai do the work i should be doing from laziness ;)  Seems like a nice casual trade/space/combat game in many ways reminding me of star trek online space combat.

Even though this game is over 4 years old it still holds up as being one of, if not THE best zombie game on the market. It's not only fun playing single player but it's hilarious when you can get three more friends to join in the zombie killing.  There's of course the standard Easy - Hard difficulities (Here being Easy, Medium, Advanced and Expert). So if you're looking for some mindless slaughtering to do you can put it on easy or if you and your friends is a tatical squad preparing for the zombie apacolypse this is a great way to start!  Also you don't have to play the first game to get into this one, all the maps and more from the first game is in this one. Even if you want to play oldschool there is a mode for that. Speaking of modes, there's Versus mode which is exactly what it sounds like, you control both the infected and the survivors in rounds. The one who ends the final map with the most points win. There is also a realism version of this mode which means the survivers can't see the green/orange/red glow around them as they used to.  There's also Survival which is aslo what it sounds like. Survive for X amount of time and you get bronze, silver or a gold medal depending on the requirments for the map you're playing.  Scavanger is the last major gamemode, here you play as survivor and infected and the objective is to fill a generator with gas. Who wins depends on which team's the fastest.  Then, finally, there's something called mutation. These are pretty much fun little mini modes. For example you have to try and survive an entire campaign on your own, you and all your teamates have katanas and can't get other weapons, you need to carry around a lawngnome to win etc.
This game made me want to grow up to be a dictator as a kid.  10/10
Worth every single cent. Endless fun with or without friends!

The gameplay is really fun, especially the Nemesis system. The story is a bit lacking.  If you're a fan of Assassin's Creed or the Batman Arkham series, you'll most likely feel right at home with the combat and mechanics of this game.  The combat itself is a bit generic, but they added special abilities that you can execute after you have a certain number on your hit counter. It's very counter spam, but counter will not instant kill your enemy, which is a great change, since it makes enemies that much more deadly. To counter the simplicity of the combat system, there are 2 different counter-measures. The first one is... Call in more enemies. You will most always be outnumbered, but they really like to stack on the Uruks... Sometimes you'll be standing in a crowd of 30+ enemies trying to tear into you. The other method of stopping you is to call in a captain. These are special units that have their own strengths and weaknesses. They have high health and can vary in their abilities to destroy you. Because of the Nemesis system, often times not only 1 captain will show up. When I went to attack a Warlord (above a captain) he showed up with a captain as his body guard... 3 more captains showed up during the fight. On top of all the Uruk that were surrounding me. I ran away. Combat diffuculty done right.  Unfortunately, there is a very large downside to the Nemesis system... If you suck at this game. When you die, politics happen. Whatever Uruk killed you gets a promotion to captain, or a higher rank captain. There is also battles between the Uruk captains, so there are a lot of promotions there. This means... if you suck, and die a lot... Your enemies will get stronger and stronger. The longer you survive, the more politics take place during your death. So, surviving a long time is also a bit negative. I wish instead that the Nemesis system was on a timer of sorts. Politics should happen if you don't stop them, rather than wait for you to make a decision... or just die.  The story itself is fairly dull. So far, there are 3 stories going on... You want revenge against Sauron's right hand man. Your friend wants to fight Sauron and his followers, and your spirit companion has amnesia. All 3 arks are fairly generic, and you learn who your companion is pretty early on.  So, this game is great fun, but it's fun because of the gameplay. I really hope that Monolith Productions keeps this Nemesis system in their future games, and expands upon it.  Have fun killing all those Uruk.

I have plenty of things to say.. none of which are positive. Worst.GUI.implented.in.any.game.. EVER. It's so cumbersome, so clunky and absolutely horrendous I can't even begin to describe it. Suffice to say, it gave me grey hairs, wanted me to pull out all the others and stab myself repeatedly just to make the memories go away.  There is not ONE instruction video you can watch without pausing, looking at key binds, continue.. because they can't even say what default keys are, just name functions.  Then.. when you've spent 3 hours just landing your piece of ♥♥♥♥ spacejunk, you try to take one mission. Well fine, after having spent another hour just to learn how to even make menus WORK you manage to pick one up.. hell, you even manage to go to the system it's supposed to happen in.. after having spent another hour how to even get your supercruise and hyperspace jump to work.  Then, when you get there.. you get dropped out in the middle of ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere and have to figure out how in the name of ♥♥♥♥ you're supposed to even find this muppet you've been hired to kill, since traveling inside systems is possibly the worst mechanic ever. 'Oh hey, i'm about to get close to that space station.. whoop, nope, i just flew by it because my ship wont ♥♥♥♥ing exit supercruise.' I can keep overshooting the same space station fifteen times before i even get near it, and when i do.. guess what, pirate i need to kill isn't there either. Then I go back and forth in the system hoping to god I can find the worst, most pathetic criminal known in chartered space.. but no, I can't find the idiot.. because by the time I get a notification and can spend another 2 minutes just OPENING the contacts tab on the UI, it's gone.  Holy mother of ♥♥♥♥.. worst piece of ♥♥♥♥, ever.   It's not a game.. it's a docking, launching and navigating simulator.. and even that is done at in the worst possible way. Forget autopilots, forget 'go to target' oh no son, this is ALL manual.. because spending 5-10 minutes just to land your spacejunk is a fun and immersive thing to do.  Good lord..

Before starting the review, the inputs mentioned below are for the Xbox-360 controller.   Although this shows up as a positive review, this game has some serious flaws. The concept is simple. It's 1986, zombie apocalypse has happened, and you control a character in the middle of this ♥♥♥♥ storm. The game plays as a side scrolling platformer with bits of combat mixed in. The game at its core is fun. Unfortunately, due to clunky controls and some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design input decisions, this game can be extremely frustrating.  At first it's not really that noticeable since the platforming isn't urgent. During later parts of the game where you need to have perfect controls or you die and have to do an annoying 30 seconds to get the place you were previously, it gets a bit tedious to put it nicely. And whoever decided to make the jump button also the 'drop from ledge' button is a ♥♥♥♥ing moron. I have played plenty of platformers where you have to either press B to let go or hit A + Down Input. So good job there Tequila Games. *insert sarcastic thumbs up*  Another flaw was breaking free from a zombie's grasp. I felt that after breaking free and pushing it away from your character would at least stun any other zombies around you for a split second. But lo and behold, you push one away and another just decides to go in dry. This is unacceptable considering I have seen a stun after breaking free from enemies in many other games (mainly Resident Evil). I have no idea why they decided not to include this other than they wanted to increase the difficulty of the game artificially.  The part which was really irritating was near the end of the game. I felt as though there was a huge difficulty spike to not make the game more challenging but to prolong the length of the game just for the sake of prolonging the game. There are plenty of moments where I go 'What the ♥♥♥♥!?' followed by a long stream of cursing. I thought up until that point, the game was a decent platformer. Although the 'rat cage' level was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ considering I didn't want to play a ♥♥♥♥ing Prince of Persia rip off for one and a half hours.  Even though I have mentioned the flaws above, the game is quite beautiful. The art direction definitely represents that this version of 1986 is bleak with no signs of awesome 80's films to cheer everyone up. You could even say that the best character in the game was the world itselft. It's tired, gritty , depressing, and has no guilt about taking the lives of the people that live in it. In all, it's a decent game and I'd definitely say it's worth a play through if you can pick it up on the cheap. I would most definitely not pay full price for it. It's not polished enough to warrant the $14.99 price tag. 8/10

I don't get it. That is all you do, is play a flash game with more button pressing than I have ever seen in any button masher game, ever.  lol fk this game hard, -400/10

app_name: Sengoku Jidai: Shadow of the Shogun
review_text: Too basic overall. For the price, there just isn't enough content.

Totaly worth it. 9/10  It's not 10/10 because there is not any ship editor function.  Random shops, encounters, galaxies, enemies and quests. There are many ship, what is playable, and each have 3 styles, maximum replayability. Challenging boss fight at the end. Different utility rooms (like cloak, droid station, even a teleport). Choosable situation dealing options. Free dlc-s, many mods and it's cheap. What else is needed?

So where to begin with this game, I love the Story and Mystery behind everything you do in this game. The Audio is amazing and engaging. The Art Design is beautiful and stunning. The Stage progression was good and it was easy to understand where you were supposed to go as long as you explore a bit to begin with. Now the Voice recognition is cool and all but there were a few times were I would cough and it would count it as the Command spell or I would say one spell and it would interpret as another and I even set up my own Voice profile in the settings though it was mostly on the dot with what I said most of the time. Oh but I do love the sounds of the language used for the spells it was mystic yet regal.  So to wrap it up I love everything about this game even with the few times I got annoyed at the Voice stuff. I would give this game a 9/10. Mostly because there are a few areas where you can bug the game out a bit and the voice recognition still needs some improvement in techonogly before it can be prefected for a game like this. Still though Great work for a very small team.
