app_name: Sword of the Stars II: Enhanced Edition
review_text: It's a love hate relationship. Of all the 4x games, this one had the most potential but since it was never finished, it went into obscurity. I love the game even in its unfinished state. It has the best tactical battle system of all other 4x space games as well as the most innovative races and tech tree. However there it ends. Everything else is half finished and not polished, riddled with bugs. I still spent countless hours in this game, just for the fleet battles. :)   Only recommeded for die hard 4x fans.
Still one masterpiece, which should been tried out.

To start: I loved playing this game. To a point. The controls seemed awkward at first, but once I got the hang of them, it turned into sheer awesome. That is, for a while. I've played through every single level of this game. Twice, actually. First complaint: I have never received a single achievement. There are 12 achievements. They are all based on story progression. I have none of them. I beat the game twice. There is an issue there.  Next, the... sheer incompleteness of it. There are a huge number of extra missions and things, and... Well, you see, by the end of the game you have three allies. Before a certain point, you only have one. Then, I think, you go up to three. Then back down to two, then up to three again. No matter what time during the game you venture to the optional side-missions, you WILL have all three allies. Even if you have no idea who the hell they are, or if you currently believe that ally to have DIED HEROICALLY. He's just hanging around with you in a sidemission. But that's not even the worst of it. Some of the sidemissions are just plain crap. You have, basically, a bunch of random crap that's really not useful at all and maybe a few mineable things just... there. Around you. Blow 'em up if you like. Maybe a few enemies will wordlessly appear. There's no mission. It's just... There. Pardon for the lack of specifics, but it's been a while since I last played, but... One of the 'sidemissions' is New Moscow, or something like that. The Russian's big main city... Er... Sorry, did I say city? I meant a few defense turrets mounted on buildings that you can blow up if you shoot a hell of a lot. There's not even a shop. Which reminds me, if you expect all the shops to be actually functional, you'll be sorely disappointed. There's quite a few that are just completely and totally nonfunctional. Heck, the 'shop here' button shows up. Mash it 'til your keyboard breaks. Have fun. No point to it. And then there's the mining. I could have enjoyed that so much. I love mining in games. I LOVE open world sandboxes. But you know what? I hated it here. I'd prefer to just waste a missile on a uranium deposit instead of take the time to actually mine it. And I tried. Oh, I tried SO hard. But the default mining equipment is the ONLY mining equipment. There's no way to enhance it. So the 3 or 4 seconds it takes to mine ANYTHING will ALWAYS be that way. And it's just plain not worth it. Not in the slightest. MAYBE if you're mining one of the really, really valuable resources, but still. You can find more money by just looking around and looting things. And don't bother with the secret rooms. They have nice loot, but not nice enough. And beyond that, sometimes the game just stacks crap against you to a stupid extent. One level, the offensive turrets are literally indestructible. Literally. You actually HAVE TO disable them through the control console for them, or you won't even be able to progress in the mission. I blew up the generator that powers the console for those turrets... And wound up trapped in the level, basically. I couldn't do anything at all because I had disabled the console which I literally could not progress without accessing. And the game just... kept going. Didn't really care. And one of the secret rooms I mentioned before? I found it. I could see inside it. I then spent ALL MY AMMO and EVERYTHING I could think of on trying to get into the damned thing. There was nothing. At all. Not in the slightest. This game is a brilliant, beautiful START. ... But it's only a START. It needs to be refined. It needs to be FINISHED. It needs to be added to. And the worst part? The very end of it is just an enormous cliffhanger. And I haven't heard of Miner Wars 2082. They got their money and they're done. You see this on sale? Maybe you get it. Just don't expect things to be perfect. It won't be perfect. It'll disappoint you in a dozen different ways. But if you can get used to the controls, like I did, you might just find you enjoy it enough to bother paying... say... five bucks.  I don't recommend it at-price. If you get a sale, MAYBE. But don't expect it to be complete. You've gotta take it into your own hands a little. And don't be afraid to change the keybindings. I definitely had to.

I wanted to write an honest review about the game amist all the chaos in regards to latest Black Market Update. Ever since the early beta of the first game Payday: The Heist, my friends and I have adored the gameplay and mechanics behind the game that came to be one of my most favorite games imaginable.  Payday 2 (not Overkill) is wonderful, unique experience that I have spent almost 400 hours in with and without friends robbing banks, breaking into art galleries, fighting with the mafia and many other fun times squished in to one big game. This game for me has been one of the funnest I've ever had with a game and the community behind is also lovely even to this day. There are tons of mods (all of which by October 15th 2015, have been claimed to have been broken by the devs) to pick and choose from to customize your experience and make the game even greater then it already is. Just speaking off the top of my head the game has about 40-50 some odd guns to pick and choose from and about 10-20 more dlc weapons to make for a more fun experience. Some can consider these dlc content packs pricey but as shown on the steam store the dlc regularly goes on sale for up to 75% off making the content extremely cheap and affordable for everyone.  The game has about (to the time of this review) 50-70 heists to pick and choose from with unlimited replay ability because the heists will always randomly generate the enemies, objective locations and enemies (minus a few exceptions). There is an exact number for that I just cannot at the time remember what it is.  The DLC is plentiful and a lot of the time well worth its money and the best of all optional to purchase so it doesn't always feel like your locked behind a pay wall barrier. The amount however at first glance can scare a person off so it can be hard for a person to get into the game, rest assured none of which is required to actually enjoy the game as the game has hours upon hours of free content for your enjoyment.  Forgive me as I don't have much experience professionalized reviews and I know I'll probably have this review flagged/report spammed and mutliple thumbs down for my lack of '♥♥♥♥ OVERKill' in any of what I've typed.  I myself am confused and slightly weirded out by the latest update all things considered as Almir did say on release god knows how long ago that was, saying 'no microtransactions'. But really and truthfully, people need to understand that people change, their views on things change and forget about what they said in the past, heck I do it all the time. I promsied my friend I would play some vidya with him but then like an hour later without even consulting him I just decided to sleep instead.  I'm not going to mark this game down because I don't believe that OVERKills choice of adding an optional mechanic that gives extremely minor stats that which don't really make a big difference should disregard all the fun times OVERKill has given me while playing this game and its previous ones. I cannot say how many hacked lobbies I've joined where I've laighed my ♥♥♥ off cause we were in stealth and the gun spawned 100 snipers in the vault and the whole crew was down simotainiously so we lost the mission. Off topic but I don't think we've even given Almir or OVERKill a chance to come out and say why they made the choice in the first place.   I like to consider myself optimistic but I'm willing to stick in there for a bit longer to see if OVERKill can make up for this big mess they brought on themselves.   TL;DR The majority of negative reviews here are bandwagon hate on Almir because I think it was like 2-4 years ago or something he said no microtransactions? I could care less tbh I'll ignore the vaults like I ignore the creates in CS:GO or TF2 and find fun in the game. This game with or without friends is def worth the money and I hope whoever picks it up finds as much fun as I've had playing it.  PS Leave Almir alone he is the community manager not the one who makes these choices.

This. This right here. This is the kind of game that makes being a gamer fun. Something with a cool idea and good execution. Mind you, I love playing games that are 'old school' or 'variation on a theme', like RPGs, new episodes of well-known franchises etc. But sometimes, you find a game that is based on a great idea and it just is such a pleasant surprise.  I stumbled upon this based on TotalBiscuit and Jesse Cox playing this together, having SO much fun in their video. I wanted to get this for quite some time, and when this was on sale, my gf gave it to me as a present. We soon started playing, and omg, it is SO much fun.  You prolly know what the game is about...one person defuses the bomb, the other is the bomb specialist and gives instructions with a manual. As the defuser, you have to describe what you see, so the specialist can figure out what module you are dealing with, and can guide you through defusing it.  PLEASE stick to the rules... don't let the specialist look at the screen, don't cheat. This game can be SO much fun if you adhere to the rules. The timer is merciless, some modules are a breeze while others will have you panic as time is running out while you try to figure out a more complicated riddle.  The basic idea is awesome, and this game is so much fun to play together... defusing a bomb with only seconds to spare is such a rush and feels like a true achievement, and you'll prolly go forth and back between frantically yelling at each other, asking for a better description or the right answer, or just laugh because this is just a ton of fun.   This truly deserves an award for the idea, and for the execution. If you have someone to play this with, don't hesitate, just get it and try it, whether it's on sale or not!

There is no online multiplayer in Natural Soccer.  Your options are local multi-player - which is extremely fun - or single-player.  The single-player option is fun and challenging at first, but gets boring after a while because the league mode is very long, has no promotion or relegation, no cups, no team management, no team roster, no top-scorer stats, nothing that really bonds you to the team or players.   However, I still recommend Natural Soccer to those who want a fun, arcade soccer game to play locally with friends or family.

You spawn in, find a random weapon somewhere and fast, and go ♥♥♥♥ someone up....like it's 1999. you died? well, suck it up. just get your ♥♥♥ back in and try again. Try some tricky movment techniques,----yea this is like unreal tournament but I think this is way better than UT4 alpha as of right now.   LISTEN UP: Free version gives you access to a tutorial mode, all weapons and other pickups to ensure zero ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on competitive games, and SOME maps, so this review will not get a full vesion until I have further played the full game and see what are the pros and cons there. Hitman 2 is one of the the best stealth games that has ever released. I'll add that the foliage physics are now absent from this iteration that were previously found in Hitman: Codename 47. I also like how ballistics work in the game, it's unique. The level design, for it's time, is phenomenal. Such is the case with the storyline. It kept me immersed throughout my playthrough. The environments are enormous this time. And they're filled with NPCs, that may be civilians or enemies, so you won't get bored just wandering around.   The animations, however, are a bit clunky. But, again, taking into account its release date, it seems fair. Besides, it's nothing that would keep you from stop playing. I really, really loved sniping in the game. Some may say that the game is 'hard'. But that's just casuals whining how they can't move the mouse properly. The game's difficulty is realistic when played at expert, the AI becomes even more clever. At professional difficulty the game becomes frustratingly hard, you'd have to be a pro to achieve a silent assassin rating in that! I played it on PS2 and i have to say that ''Hitman'' series was my childhood and ''Silent Assassin'' one of the greatest parts .

Skyborn  is an RPG in the style of classic SNES-era JRPG's. It's fairly typical to the genre, but I found that it had some nice tweaks that kept it interesting.  The turn-based combat system features 'threat' for each party member, which rises as that character does more damage against enemies. Enemies will always attack the party member with the highest threat, leading to some interesting decisions. The characters' special abilities were varied and each party member felt unique. Buffs, debuffs, and other status changes were key to winning battles, so I didn't feel like I was just constantly tapping the button to attack. Several times during the game the characters will be able to upgrade their class, with each of the options granting different new abilities.  There are no random battles, but instead monsters wander around the map. Once they are defeated, they're gone forever, so you can't really over-grind. Leveling up doesn't increase your stats all that much anyway, and most of your stat boosts will come from new equipment. Equipment can be forged from various stones found in the environment and further augmented with gems and other items.  The story involves the conflicts of ground-dwelling humans and winged skyborn who are gifted with magical abilities. It kept me playing and had a few unexpected twists, but wasn't anything truly ground-breaking.  I first started the game on Normal difficulty, but after finding a few battles too easy I switched over to Hard. I found battles much more interesting on this setting and I kept it this way until the very end of the game. The second-to-last boss kept destroying my entire party before they could take any actions. As I was at the point of no return with no way to get better equipment, I could either load up an earlier save, or decrease the difficulty level. I chose the latter. Reading the game's author's comments on Steam, it looks like defeating the final bosses on Hard would have required a lot more effort, so my regret over this decision is minimal.  If you're looking for a relatively-short classic JRPG with a few modern twists, I'd definitely recommend giving  Skyborn  a shot. It's been bundled several times and I expect it to do so again, so you should be able to find it for cheap.

Last Light fails to make you feel like the hunted, the 'victim of natural selection', because only just a minute ago you killed something the size of France and collected a lifetime supply of ammo from a bunch of idiots who forgot their gasmaks.  Regardless, Last Light is a good game if you enjoy FPS's. However, if you are looking for a game to follow the immersive gameplay of Metro 2033, don't bother.

I'd recommend this game for many reasons: A nice, clean art design which stays consistent throughout and let's the player fill in the blanks, ambient sound and music which builds the mood in a tremendous way, and fine work in all details from beginning to end.  But what sticks with me after playing, and what makes me write this recommendation, is the story. The story is the main character here. Every single object, from a cassette tape to a note slipped behind a drawer, tells a story, and with it the larger tale. And that tale is of a family, their surroundings, the people they meet and everything in between. None of them are physically present. None of them are talking to you. But you feel them all the same, as you trace their presence through this empty house, filled by a breath of life so unlike anything that I have ever seen before.  There were times when I felt on the verge of losing myself in Gone Home, despite it's relatively short runtime. The immersion is something out of this world, stirring emotions I'd very rarely felt before in a game. This game needs to become recognised as a work of art, because if this isn't proof that games can be art then I don't know what is. I hope, and I hope that you will hope too, that this will be the dawn of a new type of games, one where story takes the stage, and you find it bit by bit in a lovingly crafted virtual world, invigorated by the breaths of artists, as well as the people that they are underneath.

The best thing I can say about this game is that it made me want to play Wipeout. I feel like I'm a good way through the game and understand how it ramps up. It's a pretty good antigrav/arcade racer (if a bit clunky) but it serves as a reminder that there will never be another Wipeout.  Good: - Visually gorgeous, simplistic style with great effects - Decent music - Good controls/sense of speed - Interesting track designs - Motion looks amazing at 144hz* - With enough speed you can take a jump and fly up to the edge of the skybox - Boss mode is something I've never seen before and is legitimately interesting. Like many racing games, Redout re-uses locations for different tracks but in boss mode, you switch between tracks in the same area multiple times DURING the race, leading to very long laps and also meaning you need to be familiar with them beforehand as the track switching throws you into different parts of each track in a strange order.  Poor: - Redout/Greyout mechanic does nothing for actual gameplay When hitting sharp declines or inclines, you're meant to pitch down or up respectively so you don't see a colour tint effect for half a second. The only time this matters is on extreme inclines so you don't scrape your ship against the ground. - No rebindable keys, not even an alternate layout I would have liked to make the arrow keys turn and A and D strafe, seeing as that's how most games in existence use WASD. - Music tracks are assigned to specific race tracks, which repeat constantly. (1 song per track) Some of the songs also have distracting beeping noises that sound like a low health alarm or something. - Some of the worst A.I. I've seen in a racing game. On tracks full of tight corners they get left in the dust and frequently hit walls but if you pass them in a gentle/straight area (even with a fully upgraded vehicle) regardless of your speed they immediately rocket in front and 'magnetise' to a distance about 5 car lengths ahead, and will continue doing that until another series of tight corners. - Uneven difficulty curve. The first 10 or so events I didn't see another driver outside of the start of the race, then suddenly the aforementioned rubber banding kicked in. Track designs also do not flow well, especially in Alaska. - *Graphical settings do not save. Every time I launch the game I need to raise the max fps, turn off motion blur and turn off v-sync. - COULDN'T TOP SKYNYRD Everything in Redout that tries to emulate the feel of Wipeout, from the announcer to some of the menus to the ship designs, just makes me want to play Wipeout instead. Which I did, and after playing more Wipeout Pure on PPSSPP it's GAME OF THE CENTURY

Great hockey GM game! I have played many hockey based games from AAA to brower games and this games management depth is outstanding. If you want a indepth pure GM mode this game is for you, allowing you to control everything from drafts to contract clauses. Only flaw I can leverage about this game is of course the lack of league and player licensing but that can be overcome with a simple install of fan made update files. Was also impressed the being able to branch out and not be forced to manage a NHL team but instead play a lower tier Finnish league team if I so desired. EHM doesn't deserve to be called Early Access since it is jam packed and destroys anything EA Sports GM mode will be putting out anytime soon. Looking forward to many more hours with this game!   TLDR Hockey GM Crack

Game? Fun? No. Terraria is none of these. This, pathetic excuse for a ♥♥♥♥ing game is one of the worst ways I've spent money in basically my entire life. And I bought it hearing 'good' things about it. No. This is pathetic. Wanna play with a friend? Better know how to take apart your computer piece by piece system wise so you can even begin to access part of it. Oh, you thought you could just invite someone to play? NOPE. BECOME A IT SPECIALIST AND THEN WE'LL TALK. Or what about the actual meat and potatoes of this 'game?' Ha. That's pathetic. 2D minecraft my ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥. Minecraft is a perfectly executed building simulator that allows you to have full access to amazing tools and build a world that is your own. Terarria is a pathetic little side scroller that doesn't let you have any creative freedom. It's obtuse, roadblocks you anytime you even begin to think you've figured something out, and doesn't even have anything fun about it. If I could get a refund for even just my copy, I'd be thankful. But I can't get a refund for the time I spent trying to figure out this sad, pathetic excuse for a game.

Well lets start off with the positive points:  Firstly it has a wide story in which you can do / be whatever you want, many paths for you to take and lots of different battles!   It also has a great feel for battle, even though it's an old game the graphics are outstanding.   It's well worth the $8.00 I payed and I would recomend this to anyone that likes war and fighting games.   There is an endless amount of custamisation that you can do with your charactor / army, this includes / wepans , armor , horses. Then we have / 100s of different units , upgradeable units , followers , forts , armys , kings.   I mean who doesn't want to own thier own army and have a fort controlled by them!   It alos has a great siege gameplay, where if your forts / castle is being attacked you go onto the battlefirled with your army! And when attacking you can meet the enemy at there gates for war!   You can play 3rd and 1st person giving it a realistic feel to the game. I love the way you can go seemlessly through battles and control the world!   Now lets get onto some of the negative points:   Although it's a great game it's multiplayer lets it down massivly, with alot of lagey servers with not many players makes for an unenjoyable experiance, with hackers and glitching a big thing you don't get a good feel for the online.   You can also lose what you have built for 100s of hours in one battle, I guess it gives it a realistic feel, but it's very annoying.   The NPC's are very buggey, with some being glitched just takes the fun out of the game.   Overall I would rate this game 7/10 .   Although it's multiplayer lets it down the single player / campain is amazing, I could spend hours building my army and fighting in spectacular battles accross the kingdom!

This doesn't even deserve the title 'FEAR'.  It's a series of shooting galleries loosely themed to the game. You enter an area, kill a few dozen enemies, then they unlock the door to the next area. This pattern repeats to the end of the game. There are no interesting places, no interesting gameplay - its literally just one big shooting gallery with COD-esque gameplay and a points and ranking system. The plot can basically be summed up as 'Fettel is resurrected and competes with Point Man for Alma's attention', which in my personal opinion completely ruins both characters. Even Beckett, from the god-awful FEAR 2, was ruined by framing him as some sort of weakling who'd be an alcoholic if he weren't in such dire circumstances.  Every single positive point to the series was removed in favor of this ridiculous shooting gallery gameplay. At least the AI is able to do something other than stand out in the open - sometimes.

Back in 2012, I really loved this game.   It was great, a simple PVP game with interesting characters and all the cash shop items could easily be purchased with in-game currency based on your performance during matches. It was everything I liked in a game. Why give it a thumbs down, then, you ask?  Well, first of all, the developers have decided to completely abandon this game because of poor marketing strategies, so no new things will ever be added. The biggest reason of all, though, are the people.  In the past few weeks I came back to this game, expecting it to be that fun and highly competitive game I loved so much. But to my repulsion it's basically become a 'if you hax u win' type deal. It's  filled  with nothing but people who like to spam hacks to win, and gloat about it after. These people don't even have the actual skill to play, only how to pull up base files and edit.   Most of the community has turned to absolute garbage and I refuse to ever play this again until something is done, which, seeing as the main developer hasn't even been online in a year, does not seem likely.

Just finished playing the [slightly] remastered version of Another World. I say slightly because even though they smoothed out the blocky graphics and animations, it still holds a dear place in my heart as they kept the original art style for the time that the technology would allow. Playing this game brought back a lot of memories as I remember playing this on my brother's Sega Genesis 20 years ago! And, most annoying of all, I never beat the game back then! Time restrictions due to tv-limits and homework, coupled with the fact that there was no save option, made the game nearly impossible for a kid like me to beat. So, proudly, I am now able to say I beat the game!  Sure, it doesn't have the snazzy graphics, enthralling plot (there's no real talking throughout the whole game), or variation on gameplay that many of today's games offer, but it was a great game for its time and I can remember that thanks to this anniversary edition. What the game does very well, is pull the player into 'another world' through an immediate introduction of a science experiment gone wrong that transports the player. The characer has no personality, but the goal of trying to guide this lost soul through a strange world is enthralling enough to pull a player in, and forgive the game's lack of contemporary graphics. Infinite respawns upon death, back to the last checkpoint, make the game fun to play and explore, although the game is short. A skilled player could probably beat the game in under two hours upon their first attempt. Quickly executed button pushing requires a certain amount of skill, and some of the puzzles are fun to figure out. A few of the puzzles will most likely require help from this new-fangled contraption called the interwebs...probably a fad :P  I would recommend this game to anyone who wants to see what a great game from 20 years ago (that can still hold its own) is like!  Ratings out of 10: 1 = low, 10 = high. Graphics: 4 (a 9 if this were remade today) Sound: 8 (sound makes up a huge amount of the game's atmosphere, especially since there's no talking) Story: 8 (I may be a bit biased, but I can see this as a great sci-fi novel) Gameplay: 9 (Experimenting your way through a foreign world was a puzzle in itself) Execution: 10 (Gotta give credit to the game for being such a well-done game for its time. Didn't really see much in the way of glitches or problems. Getting stuck on a puzzle doesn't count!) Overall: 8 (I'd love to rate this game higher, but today's gaming landscape is so far advanced compared to 20 years ago. Many indie developers could probably make a game similiar to this if they put their hearts into it.)

This game has had my attention the minute my eyes landed on it and then I saw it on early access, I just had to get my hands on it. It seemed to bring something quaint and unique to the table.. Turns out, that guess was right.  The sceneries being 2D hand-painted is an art in itself. Honestly, I found myself just staring at how beautiful the game was quite a few times, I mean, even the menu was quaint, as much of a redundant thing that may be to mention. Topped with a lovely and perfectly fitting soundtrack from Peter McConnel (Who also put together the soundtracks for; Brütal Legend and Grim Fandango). it's all the little things that just make the entirety of it so appealing.   The story-line giving you two different lives with different things to do on each side is already a concept I quite enjoy, it doesn't overwhelm you with too much to do or a need to switch between the two, it just melds in a whole, brilliantly.  The only thing that may throw it off for some is the movement system and no kind of hints for some puzzles can make for a bit of back and forthing looking for required pieces. That aside making a point and click so enjoyable is quite the achievement.  I'm glad they have gotten far more than their goal funding so there will be a chapter 2 soon released as I cannot wait to play the next adventure. Although I have seen a lot of complaints that it is far too short and too expensive for 3-4 hours of play time just in chapter 1, it is an early access game, you buy it to be part of the process of it growing and bettering itself through good and bad. It's always a given in early access. Now they have more than enough funding for a chapter 2 and most likely quite a few more chapters, I personally think it will end up being quite worth it even though for me it already is, just for the amount of work and detail poured into it, I mean, just the surroundings being hand-painted seems to be such a rare and beautiful thing to see.  Final summation, lovely game, awesome story-line, characters, voice-acting and all around charming game. Will be worth it to see it develop into a full game.   ****REVIEW UPDATE!****  As chapter two has finally come out, I feel this is due for an update.   Now mind you, I still love this game, I however feel that the execution for most of the puzzles in this chapter were even more obtuse and just downright annoying. Now, I'll be dropping a few tiny spoilers to anyone who hasn't played this yet, just a forewarning.  The fact that the game has gone through hoops just to make these incredibly and punishingly difficult really bothered me. I mean, one example is where you need to figure out how to rewire Shay's robot.. After at least an hour of raging, going back and forth, trying every combination I could think of, I still turned out empty handed. It was only when I went and looked up a walkthrough to see what I was doing wrong, that I felt like putting my head through a wall even more. The answer to the rewire was in a picture that was found in Vella's side. This is using information you never would have known been on the other characters side and something I think barely anyone would ever pick up.  Being able to switch to find out information is an okay way to do things, but the characters would have no way to actually find this out from an in-game perspective.   That aside, the entire chapter was put together really nicely with a range of different mini events happening within the game as you unlock and solve puzzles.  All in all, it's still a more than worthwhile play. Offering a total of about 10 hours of play, give or take however much you rage. Word of advice, have a game guide handy for when you get stuck and close to rage quitting, you may already have all the pieces of what you need to continue.

The artwork is gorgeous, and the ability to skip anything you've already read before makes multiple playthroughs MUCH less of a hassle than youd expect. If you ever loved storybooks as a child (and you can set aside a few character flaws...) it's worth the time to indulge in Cinders' world.

If Diablo 2 and Serious Sam had a baby, this is what you get.  Borderlands is a great game, and there is a lot of fun to be had. I played the entire game and all its DLC with three friends, and that's how I'd recommend you play it as well (even with just one friend). The game's main story is not too deep (which it makes up for in over-the-top humour), and the sidequests can definitely get repetitive. However, as long as you've got a friend to experience the chaos with, it's tons of fun.  8/10, and the only reason it's not more is because it will problably be a little bit dull by yourself.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

So i played through the game in two hours. I am an Opposing Force fan and i really loved the idea that there would be more story for Shephard in this game. Sadly there isn't . Most of the time it felt like there was no story at all. You are just running through rooms full of combine and pressing buttons and going to another room full of combines and then teleporting to a next area and repeating all that again.   The flashback events about Shephards past were interesting yet annoying as they screw up the screen with the photonegative filter. Also the bright flashesh at the end were really frustrating as those got me killed multiple times simply because i could not see where i was going or where the enemy is.  I don't recommend paying the full price for this game since there really isn't anything special in this one. To put it simply if you are looking for continuation to Adrian Shephards story then keep looking because it isn't here. If you are however looking for something to waste 2 hours on and this one is on sale then you could buy it.

Valdis Story: Abyssal City is a fast paced  Metroidvania  style game with enough complexity to enable each playthrough to be different but not so much as to make it confusing.   The combat system has light and heavy attacks, guard and parries, offensive and defensive spells, assists(the ability to summon members of your crew to do a unique attack), attack cancelling and dashing, and allows for both ground and aerial combos but eases into the separate systems slowly enough that it isn't confusing.  The game also has a combo system. The longer your combos are the more experience points enemies are worth but getting hit ends your combo so you'll have to use parries and dash cancelling to maximize your combos. Boss fight ranks are based on speed, damage, and your remaining health. Do good enough for an A or S rank and you gain permanent stat increases!  All weapons have different combos and all armors and accessories have unique abilities so instead of just picking the ones with the best stats you can choose the one that best suits your playstyle, even unarmed has equipment to buff it! There are three skill trees (offense, defense, and magic) each with 15 skills but only 20 levels to gain skill points with, though you are awarded a few points for sidequests as well.  You can only save at save points which also fully heal you and are the only healing outside of magic. Anytime you do get a game over you are given a chance to retry, this restarts you in the area you died with full health and mana so you don't have to walk all the way back from the save point everytime you die to a boss.  The games puzzles are all activating doors, by ground stomping or magically charging a switch, and then dashing to get through it before it reseals. Most hard ones are optional so if you aren't good at platforming you can still get through the game and there are some abilities that help make them easier such as double jump and wall jump.   Every area has things you can't get the first time through but the backtracking isn't bothersome because quite a few areas have new bosses when you return and enemies scale with you as to not make it boring.  Overall, Valdis Story: Abyssal City is a great game and I recommend it to anyone looking for an action platformer.

Homeworld. Has it been a decade already? ;) If you haven't played it, you should. If you like sci-fi, space combat simulation, deep story and resource harvesting, this game is for you. The space combat is 3D and you can watch it from any angle. Taking out enemy ships is satisfying and they always go with a pop and boom. Remastered, it has all the sparkle of the first time around, and if this IS your first time around, buckle up!

After really enjoying Poker Night at the Inventory (Poker Night 1) I thought well do I really need another poker game. Surely that one would do right. Well eventually at a slightly reduced price I jumped at Poker Night 2 and I regret never getting it sooner and at full price.   This game is far better.   The humour is better.   The poker engine itself seems better.   Poker Night 2 introduces Omaha poker which I have only really played a couple of times as I find it easier to work with a two card hand than a five but if you have a favourite type of poker you can stick with that and maybe occassionally switch to the other just to mix it up a bit.  Even though theres only still a fairly limited but certainly less limited amount of lines the other characters say it is varied enough to keep those same lines interesting, and the characters refer more to you the player which brings you into the immersion more. You can buy players drinks to uncover their bluffs or make them have poor judgements. Although subjective I do prefer the characters playing here than on the first game. Brock Samson was not to familiar with before playing but it did not stop me enjoying his character enough for me to look into the Venture Brothers.  It certainly is not going to be a game that you are going to play until hell freezes over but if you want the thrills of poker without the cash loss with a mix of the feeling you are playing a video game not random chance simulator 1995. I would certainly say $5 is well spent here.

This game is quite the little masterpiece of a simple puzzle game. Especially considering that it is only $0.99, which is a rediculously low price. This game starts off extremely easy, a bit too easy, but it gradually becomes more difficult after every level. Hook really starts to become difficult once you reach 36, however, almost every level before level 36 are very easy, these levels take no more than 10 - 60 seconds which is way too quick considering these levels take up more than half the game. After then the game really does feel like a relaxing yet challenging puzzle game. The sounds are soothing and soft and the music is so tranquil and beautiful, it really does fit the game perfectly. However, I wish there was a bit more variety to the sounds, as well as more sound tracks just to give the game a bit more variety in terms of audio.  Sounds / Music Score: 7.5/10  Gameplay Score: 7/10  Overall Rating: 7.25/10 (72.5% / Good)  I highly recommend this game, it is perfect if you are looking for a relaxing and simple puzzle game that is easy to learn and cheap! However there wasn't much content, but that is to be expected for a game with such a low price. It is definately worth the dollar and you should definetely purchase it if you enjoy puzzle games.

Notice : this mini review is only about the single player campaign of the game for now.  It took me a couple of hours of gameplay before I started to fall in love with DOOM (all over again!). Apparently, games and gaming develop new ideas relatively slowly, because although I thought I remembered exactly what it felt like to play the first generation shooters, I was initially stunned when faced with a cutting edge, modernized version of the simplistic format in the DOOM reboot.  Like so many have already observed, it's basically fast-paced closed area arena combat - one after another. Repeat. Prepare for the next battle. But as your skills improve, it grows on you. You start to see little things. Like how much the devs must have enjoyed putting this or that over-the-top display of gore and violence into the design. In the end, It's all about the attitude of the protagonist. Anger could hardly be simpler as a theme and motivation, but it just works. Cranking up the volume, tasting blood in my mouth, I charge into the  face  of the towering monster, tear it to pieces and love it all!

app_name: Grand Theft Auto: Episodes from Liberty City
review_text: These two expansions are combined in an awesome standalone pack. If you feel like depressing yourself, play Lost and the Damned. If you feel like having the best GTA 4 experience ever, play The Ballad of Gay Tony. Seriously, TBOGT is what everyone wanted in GTA4, but never received. You get tanks, attack helicopters (missiles AND machine guns), new cars, new guns, and booty calls. Thats not even half of what this game has to offer you. So go out and buy it. You won't regret it.

Aura Kingdom is spectacular. There are 10 different class, including the Guardian, Ravager, Duelist, Brawler, Grenadier, Gunslinger, Ranger, Sorcerer, Wizard, Bard and Ronin, with more classes to come. They all have their own unique style of gameplay, from the Ravager, who deals all out damage to all enemies around him, to the Bard, whose duty it is to keep his teammates alive. As you level up, you earn skill points, one for both Attacking and Defensive stats, of which you can allocate to either damage, speed or critical damage/health, evasion and defence. These play a big part in how you survive against mobs and other players.  The game has many different things to do, including dungeons, where you team up with other players to clear the area, PvP arenas, where you battle other players, a variety of daily quests to complete and bosses to kill, or you can simply find a group of people willing to have a nice chat.   Aura Kingdom has a unique 'pets' system, known as Eidolons, of whom you can earn by gathering different points and purchasing items to create them. Eidolons aid you in battle, and each do something different - Merrilee heals you, Sigrun takes the enemy's attention away from you, and Grimm helps deal a bit of damage. You can also use a combo move with your Eidolon, which also does a nice amount of damage.  Not only does the game allow you to have companions, many skill abilities and a wide variety of playing styles, at level 40, you also unlock a secondary class. This means, as well as having the class you chose at level 1, you get another class, and a weapon, along with all the skills that class has. This allows for every player to have a unique playing style, and caters to the taste of everyone. Not only do you get a secondary class, you also earn 'Envoy Points' every few levels, which you can use in your 'Envoy Path.' In your envoy path, you can upgrade your stats even more, earn special class bonuses which activate on the use of a skill, and even unlock combo moves with your secondary class. AWESOME!   This type of game caters to everyone. It has plenty to do, many things to try out, and has a very unique playing style. I highly recommend this game!

So surprised with this game.   I got it for free, so there is that. However I really thought I would just let it sit in my library and never install it. But after I wanted a little break from Doom I decided what the hell and I let it download while I was at class.   I came back from class, was sick, on meds, very groggy and decided to say, 'whatever, lets play some Wolfenstien. It can't be that bad.' I vaguely remember the other games for Xbox back in high school and nothing from what I remember was worth the hype.   Yet, after just playing for 5mins, I was grabbed by the graphics and the story. I was drawn in not only by the story but how I could get involved almost immediately. I got to kill Nazi's, but also I got to be challenged by it and have so much variety while playing. This game is just plain ol' fun. I cannot stop playing, and every step of the way it grabs you in for more. The levels are so diverse and the overall gameplay is not repetitive. The environments are really fun to explore and have such a cinematic quality to them.   If you are just wandering around the Steam store and wondering what to buy and come across this game, this review and this question, the $19.99USD is well worth it.

This game is a small jewel.  Short, but challenging - for the mind, not the fingers - with a wonderful storyline, but most of all it truly achieves something that many other videogames (and art works in general) fail to reach: true connectedness between its constitutive elements, gameplay and storyline. Where most games are made of a) gameplay and b) story, as two separate elements, here the nature of time and therefore the puzzles to be solved would not make sense without the narrative, and actually make the narrative 'concrete'.  Braid is a post-modern work of art, if only for the explicit tribute to Super Mario, whose elements are used in new ways and assume different (and deeper) significance; and the marvellously moving final act, when the same action shifts in meaning when represented backwards.  The story is told in short fragments, each introducing a world with different time-rules, but it is compelling from the start, and will claim a place in your heart before you even notice

app_name: Call of Duty: World at War
review_text: After playing 12 hours (and even days of playing on console and other accounts) of Call of Duty V: World at War, I can say this game is dead. Well the multiplayer version is due to the lack of good quality servers; most of the servers now are level boosting, bazooka and rifle grenade chaos. Despite the care for hackers, they have ruined it for the consoles but on here its somewhat tolerated. The only thing now is the zombies; the mini game that brought Treyarch its name today. This game mod origanally has 4 WaW maps and now has a plethora of Custom Zombies maps. The only real purpose of this game now the zombies. Unfortunatly, I do not recommend this game now. Rating: 6/10 okay.
Overall it was a pretty good game. Got it really cheap and enjoyed the story. Worth having in the library!

After about 8 hours of playing this game, I can rightly attest that this is one of the better 'Freight Trucking' I've played. It has a lot of feel like it was made as an advanced version of Hard Truck: 18 Wheels of Steel (same company, go figure) and it really says a lot about the game. It can be fairly difficult to adapt to the game at first but it slowly becomes more and more of ease to handle. You have the option to manage camera angles (which is all nice and dandy) but I personally prefer the whole 'Interior Trucker' feel.  With the good things there are also some downs that really stick out and bother me; noticably the necessity of the police to antagonize you for going just a little too fast. The max you can go is 5 miles over - a little irritating because the AI can pull 65 in a 50. Speaking of AI, there are a few moments where the AI drivers will stop at a red light, stop sign, yield sign, etc. and seems like they shut down from doing anything - it's a titch annoying when you're running low on sleep. The stop lights as well seem to be a bit finnicky as well. I've noticed they like to change JUST as you're getting up to it. Either you go through the light and get fined or slam on your brakes and wait for it take it's time to change.  Other than my minor complaints, the game is pretty darn good. I think it could have done better with some things (the sharpness and distance are kind of 'iffy') but overall it's probably one of the best games involving rigs that I've have the luxory of playing.

review_text: When men cried from the music alone. I just stare at the main menu. That main menu alone is enough to give feels. Play the game and wail like a baby in the first 10 minutes. We don't deserve this music.

First frostbite battlefield to also be ported to PC, that means it has huge destructibility and some great physics. Game looks really good for requirements it asks for, has variety of colors and smooth lightning.   Game's campaign is nothing original, story is pretty much what you expect from modern military shooter now-days, with predictable sequences and plot twists. It lasts about 8 hours and takes you in places around the world. But main characters are funny with some great dialog. To be honest i even enjoyed it, that said first 3 hours were really boring. If you are completely new to battlefield series and to modern military fps's I advice you to play it through, but if you are experienced than you probably can skip it.   So what about Multiplayer ? First of all, servers are working, are quite populated, and I never have had problems finding full server with low ping in my region! Only problem you might run in to is that most of the players are experienced and with maxed out stats, so in the beginning game can be really hard, but there are servers which allows only noob players.  There are enough maps, with different environments such as country sides, deserts, jungle or snowy forests. They are really thought out and with destructibility they never look they same, so it makes hard time for campers and it makes you always improvise in general. However some maps are bit harder to play in rush mode if you are attacker.  MP has addictive leveling system. Balanced perks and specializations. Classes have their own unique equipment, but there are some weapons which are available for all classes so in some situations it's quite useful. There are a lot of weapons, and some attachments to them. Also game features several WWII weapons which can be used by all classes. Only I found MG's bit less powerfull than others.  Vehicle controls and combat are really fun, but takes some time to master. There are ground, air and water vehicles.  So to sum it up.  Campaign is nothing new, but definitely not the worst-one and to be honest I found it worth playing. MP is really great, well balanced, addictive and has a great variety of weapons and vehicles . Has some minor problems which you'll probably ignore.  Servers are populated and always running.   So i gave it 8.2.  Thanks for reading!

Clicker Heroes is essentially the gaming equivalent of pet wheatgrass or a tamagotchi minus the need to participate in its development in any thoughtful or meaningful way whatsoever. It is mindlessness and pointlessness reduced, distilled and dripped through a pippette in the form of inane, twee monsters superimposed over infinite credit tickers. It is almost impossible to imagine a more meaningless game--Indeed, as I have previously alluded to, it is not really a game at all. Although I haven't tried it, I have no doubt that one could garner the same sense of satisfaction dispensed by clicker heroes by simpling multiplying random sums on a calculator to see how many decimal places you can get to.  It really is very, very ♥♥♥♥ing stupid.  It's also together quite evil, because clearly what the developers intend by this game is to turn people into rats at pellet dispensers by exploiting human susceptibility to operant conditoning: ' B.F. Skinner (1938) coined the term operant conditioning; it means roughly changing of behavior by the use of reinforcement which is given after the desired response. Skinner identified three types of responses or operant that can follow behavior.'  The particular type of OC driven by clicker heroes is positive reinforcement wed to RNG type drops for items in game ( rubies). Basically, it's gambling. The idea is that you move from something you would consider unthinkable ( spending real currency on rubies in game) to handing over real money to progress in a game which is utterly pointless, requires absolutely no skill whatsoever and is limitless.  This is of course par for the course with clickers ( rat at pellet dispenser games) and to its credit, clciker heroes does offer means by which to gather Rubies and Hero shards without the use to real currency. Irregardless, it is nonetheless exploitative, boring, pernciously repetitive. It's basically a drag net designed to ensnare those addicted to, or susceptible to, degenerate gambling type behavior.  Score: 0/10

Personally I'm in between whether this game was good or not. I have experienced past Gauntlet games (pretty much every one of them) and found the level scheme to be a bit on the lacking side. I like the idea of stages inside each level, that is nice, but the down side is there are also very few levels in each chapter and given that there are only 3 chapters I expected more from this Gauntlet Game. Too much Hype not enough content. I do recommend this game because even though it is short it is a lot of fun. I understand there are more difficulty levels and more items to unlock and upgrade. But I need more Gauntlet action than these levels provided. If there is more Level content going to be added to the game (PLEASE!!!) there is a lot mroe room in the main dungeon before entering the doors to add more areas to branch off of and add more doors or even portals to new realms that have tons more doors and chapters to play. Just please consider this in the near future.

Who doesn't like pinball?? It's fast, easy to play, and no difficulty at all. But this game offers something that no other pinball game does: different tables!   The game is very diversified but the downside is that it's very limited. You basically have to buy the tables so you can play indefinitely on them. I even got to the point where I got 1.25 billion points and it stopped the game saying 'Score Limit Reached'.  So yes, I totally recommend it. Although limited, it's better than any other pinball game I have ever seen. And it's funny too!

I love Metro 2033. I've played through it at least a dozen times at various difficulties with various strategies. The atmosphere is unparalled by any other game in the FPS genre.   Metro 2033 Redux is a soulless husk of the original. In my opinion the pacing, mood, narration have all been essentially ruined, and it doesn't look considerably better graphically.  Beyond my own issues with the game, the gunplay is utterly unplayable. There is no rewarding sense of walking the razor's edge in a combat situation, snapping off shots into the heads of approaching mutants, even the stealth aspects are completely gone. There is no challenge in fighting human enemies at all, while mutants will soak up entire magazines of bullets without dropping. Please do yourself a favor and play the original.

I don't think this is a terrible game by any stretch, but by the time this came out I felt a little underwhelmed by it.  I'm not really bothered about it being the wave thing with different backgrounds, because to be honest that's all I really expected...but I do think it's lost something the demo had in terms of tension, and there just isn't enough variety overall.  In the demo I feel like I failed to complete it a couple of times because I wasn't checking behind me enough or being smart enough with my ammo, so I'd hit a point where I had none left...in the full game I feel like the enemies come so incrementally that you never get overwhelmed, and you're able to conserve ammo so effectively that it never feels tense - I got to the last stage and had over 900 rounds of ammo, so you don't even need to be accurate by the end - in fact I had to stop using the Laser Sight, because it's just so ridiculously effective and the enemies come so gradually, that it's too easy to finish stages with 95%+ accuracy and get constant headshots, so you're rarely in danger of even taking damage.  There are also a few bait and switch moments I feel like never really deliver - the huge monster at the end of the demo/menu, or like in the first stage they have the jump scare of one bursting through the hole in the wall, but then there's not even anything like that for the next 5 levels, or even much enemy variety or feeling like certain weapons are needed in certain scenarios - In the campaign mode at least, it all just feels so limited that there isn't much to keep you hooked by the end - It's not particularly scary or frentic, so for me it falls short as both a horror experience and as an action one.  Haven't tried the Survival mode yet, so maybe that's a little better - I imagine at the very least it becomes more challenging, but the Campaign seems a bit undercooked, even with the expectation it was going to be fairly basic I felt from the demo that it could be quite tense and quite scary, and it's neither really

Nihilumbra is a nice little way to spend the afternoon. It's nothing truly incredible, the visuals don't really have a unified style, the environments are a bit samey and the narration seems forced, but in the end, I enjoyed it.  Nihilumbra has a fairly unique set of mechanics that make for decent puzzles, the character sprite looks incredible, and there's something very original about the story, becoming more introspective and character-focused than I ever imagined it would be. If I'm honest, I expected this to be sort of a lazy indie game clone: Bastion had narration, Limbo had bleak environments and silouhettes, Tag had paint that covers surfaces and alters their attributes, but there's still something unique and special about Nihilumbra, and that's the story. Even though the story centers around (generously speaking) only one character, and even despite the cliched appearance, I was left satisfied nonetheless.

This is a beautifully constructed game.  The dark, supernatural atmosphere is fully immersive, with haunting music and sound effects, a creepy unlockable journal, traditional Scandinavian monsters, and a few jump scares that add to the surreal horror. A warning, though: If you are at all squeamish about blood or death, you will have a hard time playing this.   The artwork is reminiscent of hand-cut paper collages, further enhancing the traditional folk feeling of the game.  As far as gameplay goes, it mainly involves circling through a layered snowy landscape in search of puzzles and clues. As you advance the plot, new paths open up and new interactables appear. The key is figuring out which puzzles you can solve right away, and which you will need to come back to later after you have more information. Backtracking is a key component of the game, but the map is small enough that it never feels like a slog.  The built-in hint system is useful in guiding you through the main plot if you are stuck. It contains a progressive series of hints for each chapter, with the first hint being an extremely vague nudge in the right direction, and the last hint being a blatant spoiler. Players can control which hints are revealed and which remain hidden, so you only ever get as much information as you need.  Something I didn't realize on my first playthrough: Some puzzles require keyboard interaction, some puzzles require the mouse, some require a combination of keyboard and mouse. If you are stuck, it might be because you didn't realize you could click and drag an object to move it, or click and hold an item to carry it.  Some of the achievements are tricky to get, but between the game itself and the achievement descriptions, you should eventually be able to figure them all out.   While this game will likely leave you feeling depressed due to its tragic thematic elements, it is still an amazing little gem, and I would give it an overall rating of 9/10.

Good, old, fun Half-Life. I played it years ago but never got a chance to beat it at all. Maybe because there were many good games years ago, or maybe I was just too lazy to do it. So I did it now. After many years it still brings so many joy while playing and can surprise gamers with so many well done things. In short, even tho many would say that it aged rather not good, it can be applied maybe to graphics alone. There isn't enought words of praise I can tell about how great atmospheric it is, how fun to explore every room and corner is, how interesting story/characters and 'monsters' are made, how memorable music is, how enjoyable gameplay mechanics are, how well Half-Life world and levels are designed. Valve had great idea and Valve had amazing team to make that happen. It's no wonder that it's one of the best games ever made. It's a part of something great, big part of gaming history. After so much time it still have active community, mods are coming out, people play it online. If you never had a chance to play it and you want to learn something about how amazing games were years ago - do it.

Very solid, though the main campaign is almost a bit too long and difficult, and this game is hampered a little bit by the fact that the sequel surpasses it in a lot of ways, so if you're not looking to dive in too deep, just grab the sequel.

Definately worth buying. The game is funny, entertaining, sometimes frustrating and demanding but most of all it presents a brand new concept. Have you ever want to be an explorer? To discover forgotten treasures and artifacts? To fight mummies and... nuns? If yes (or if nuns made you confused) do not think twice!   The Renowned Explorers is a turn-based strategy game with a role-play style and well written droll story. You need to think about your next movement, about your opponents' strengths and weaknesses, you need to consider the bonuses and sometimes you just need to be lucky.   Do not let the graphics trick you. This is a decent and complex strategy game and you will need 30+ hours to learn its mechanics for sure.  Developers work hard on this game, they are in touch with the players and they make a lot of challenges and additional events.  This game brings something fresh I have not played before. Worth taking a go.   10/10 would slap nun again

Currently extremely disappointed! Worst $30 I've spent for a game I currently still own on disc from original launch and know that I love to play. Within my first 2 games of online play, which is the only reason I re-purchased this game for the steep price of $30, I cannot even play. Literally. Can. Not. Play. The lag is terrible, horrible, pathetic. Freezing for 5 seconds at a time, every 20 seconds. Both games I played stalled out at locked screens forcing a resign. I will be honest that I don't know the source of this lag, but I can conclude and deduce that it isn't Steam and it definitely isn't on my end (isp/pc/graphics). For someone that is re-purchasing this game because I already know it's great, it's sad that this issue isn't already fixed on a game that is so old. The main audience you that is thrilled to play this would be that such as myself, returning for the glory days of this game when it was one of the best. Get yourself together. This is a disgrace to a game as good as this is. If this was fixed I would recommend AoM in a heartbeat, but for now, don't waste your time or money if you want to play with other people online. If I wanted to play solo I would pop in my AoM disc and be happy. But in this day and age of online gaming in the Steam multiplayer community, there is no excuse for this.

So! You are a fan of point and click adventure games, but long gone are the days of Guybrush Threepwood, Roger Wilco, and purple tentacles. So, naturally, you've left games like that to the past, and whenever anyone tries to make a new one, it's all focused on graphics, never on story, never on humor, and certainly never the old 'combine these things to make this new thing to solve this puzzle'.  Well, I can say that if that is what you are looking for, The Book of Unwritten Tales is for you. The humor is a good blend of clever, self-aware, and just plain groan-worthy. The puzzles are not too simple and not too complicated. Well...ok, maybe a BIT too simple. Most of them were actually pretty basic, though a few stood out as clever.  My only complaints about this addition to the genre were fairly minor. One of the more classic moments in these types of games was in The Secret of Monkey Island where there was a whole string of events that happens outside of your control and everything occurs off screen with you just sitting there reading the text and listening to the sound effects. A direct homage to that happens in this game, but then a couple more times things similar to it happen....once was funny and a nice tribute, but multiple times sort of makes it feel like lazy writing or a way to advance the story when there's no logical way to tie two events together.  The other issue I had with this was one of...I don't know...dialogue trees? Programming? I am unsure what it would fall under but on multiple occaisons I would find an item and go 'Oh...I wonder if person X would like this items...' and so I go to check and they respond with 'Oh, hey, thanks for getting me that thing I asked for, here is the item I promised in return.' Except that none of that dialogue happened. It skips it entirely. It's not really a PROBLEM, but it certainly breaks the scene a bit and makes you kind of annoyed that you missed what might have been some funny moments.  Those gripes are minor, however, and I recommend this game a lot, even if you've never really played point and click adventures before as there isn't quite as many gaps in logic as you find in many others.  P.S. My favorite character was the dragon.
Played as an evil lesbian Grey Warden. It was awesome.

Mirror's Edge is something different.   To me, Mirror's Edge is in many points one of the best games which I've played in the past few years. But let's get straight to it:    Gameplay:  The core of every game and with Miror's Edge, the guys at DICE have done their job very well. The gameplay is direct and works surprisingly well with mouse and keyboard. Sometimes it doesn't act like you thought it would, but it's still better than in most of the AAA-games nowadays.   Story:  Not much to say. Not the most innovative story and very average. Not too many characters and the ones who are in are well written. The topic is very interesting and the world also. If you spend time on searching about the background of the story it will definetly be worth it.   Graphics:  Even though the game is a few years old, it still looks amazing! The artstyle is very, not to say extremely, clean and the colours very bright and shiny. the animations seem smooth to me and the lighting very atmospheric.   Sound:  Amazing! The soundtrack is just gorgeous and very atmospheric. It makes you start thinking about the world and the story and to be honest, some sounds are just scary which makes it even more atmospheric.   Overall the game is definetly worth checking it out if you like atmospheric, well designed worlds with a good story and if you want to play something else than the average AAA-game with the average gameplay.   And to get back to the beginning: Mirror's Edge is something different.

Dex is like a 2D brawler mixed with a simplified Deus Ex. It nails the cyberpunk aesthetic and many of the quests have multiple solutions, though the game's fundamentals are somewhat lacking. Melee combat is more of annoyance than a challenge because enemies constantly run away from you while you try to hit them. Hacking is a trivial schmup-like minigame that never really gets interesting and stealth is pretty basic.  However, much like Deus Ex, Dex is greater than the sum of its parts. Thanks to solid writing, great atmosphere and open-ended level design that rewards exploration, the game remains compelling throughout its relatively brief playtime.

Terraria ruined my life. University student, 2 important essays due very soon. Boot up Terraria for the first time in about a year, Start playing it for a couple of hours, do some uni work after, everything's going fine. Start playing it again the next day, got a nice little village going for my NPCs, found loads of ore, crafting some great new weapons. Go on an underground adventure.  Underground adventure ends up lasting 8 hours.  Go to sleep, start up the game the next morning. Play for 12 hours. Have completely forgotten what university even is.  Flashforward a few days, playing all day, every day. All I care about is finding rare ore and killing bosses. I dream about ore, all I see in the world has turned to ore.  Most badass guy in all of Terraria. Finally stop playing. Essay is due tomorrow. F***!!!! Highly recommend to those with addictive personality who are easily distracted.
rely gude

The year was 1927. When my father died, i was left with a 25 million dollar inheritance. I was told by so many that I as set for life. But no! I couldnt stand idly by as just another rich man! The movies were the place for me! So I started my own company, Fattened Cow Films as it was called. My very first film was 'The Dusty Trail', It was my dream to make this movie. And obviously being as rich as I was expenses were no bother to me so Money was flowing and what a joyous sight it was! But Alas! before I was done making my movie, I looked at my bank account to see that I was -500 thousand in the red. But I had not even the money to cover the marketing, no I was far from complete! But to my chagrin I could only stand idly by and watch as My film flopped and now I trudge the streets of the poor begging for the alms that fall from the purses of gentlemen.  10/10 would go bankrupt again.
If you are a depressed American this game documents your story accurately.

Well, this is really something else.  Before playing Cry of Fear I wasn't really into horror games - in fact, I don't think I ever played any at all with the exception of a bit of Amnesia and SCP: Containment Breach. The reason I downloaded CoF was because it was a mod for HL1, and I was having serious Half-Life withdrawal symptoms at the time (seriously, where is episode 3?). What I got was not only an encouraging introduction into the horror genre, but one of the best games I've ever played in terms of character, story and suspense.  In particular, the protagonist, a nineteen year old Swedish guy named Simon, really struck a chord with me. Before playing this game I was having some serious issues in my life, dealing with heartbreak and severe anxiety to name a few. I can't say much without spoiling the plot, but the mental trauma that he went through and the way he responded to it let me know that I wasn't alone with these problems. The immersive gameplay of CoF helped me a lot and allowed me to connect to the protagonist more than any other before.  But anyway. As far as gameplay goes, it's relatively simple - if you've HL1 or any other Valve-made FPS, you should have no problem learning the controls. Unique to CoF is the inventory system, in which you can store up to 6 items, and the ability to duel-wield specific weapons. The puzzles are also challenging without being ridiculously hard, and if you get stuck like I did on the 'park puzzle' with the statues then don't be afraid to look the answer up on Youtube.  One criticism though. In order to avoid cheating, the developers have removed most of the console commands which would help you if, say, you're halfway through the game with low health, no ammo, and stuck in a room with 6 monsters armed only with your switchblade. This happened to me and I actually had to go into the game files and modify the damage values for the switchblade in order to progress. Not cool, Team Psykskallar, not cool! What if somebody encountered a game-breaking bug and got stuck in a wall or something? They wouldn't be able to noclip out.   Still, that's pretty much the only criticism I have about this game. Everything else is spot on. If you're a hardened horror fan or relatively new to the genre like me, be sure to give it a go. It's free, after all.

I disagree with the 'feels' crap that people keep going on about in this videogame. It's simply not true, and people are just jumping on a bandwagon to glorify the storyline. It's not the next Heavy Rain or even anything close to it. I didn't feel emotion after finishing the campaign nor did I expect to in a third person shoot 'em up.  The graphics look amazing in this videogame, essentially better than the console versions that I have played. Each enemy has a minor unique aesthetic to them to individualise them and make them seem different, yet still the same to prevent the creation of emotion towards each person that you kill. Sometimes the enemies would throw out occasional dialogue discussing tactics on how to kill you, and they can lose vision of you if you aren't seen from time to time, except when it's a scripted event and they are forced to know where you are at all times.  The main characters are extremely odd, with the three characters that you visit often, one being the protagonist, a man of honor and duty, a person hired to get the job done and the mission completed. Then you have the joker in the squad, a guy who tries to make bad puns and crap jokes every now and then. Lastly, you have the sympathetic nice guy, that always tries to help and agrees with the protagonist in right or wrong situations. Throughout the storyline however, they all seem to change roles pretty quickly. The joker suddenly becomes a serious character that wants to turn back immediately and questions your every move, calling them bad decisions the entire time. The nice guy becomes an annoying person that constantly gets in the way of your moral dilemmas in situations, forcing you to believe in what's wrong and what's wrong.  The storyline contains an antagonist that jokes around with the main character, playing rock music during fight scenes and laughing at the protagonist whenever he can. When the main character does something wrong that he thought was right, he is there to laugh at him and make YOU feel like the bad person in the situation. For example, you hitch a ride on the back of a truck filled with what the characters thought was gasoline, but turned out to be water supplies for the civillians, and the trucks get shot apart and the antagonist is there on the radiospeakers telling you what you just did wrong.  The game is in a third person perspective with a sprint and cover system, but not forcing the game into a serious fighter where you require tactical thinking every move you make. Picture Max Payne 3 but without the slow motion jump diving and gunning in midair, and with sprinting included. Some guns keep you in third person unless they have scopes on them, for example using a sniper rifle will allow you to move into first person perspective to take precise shots at enemies on buildings.  Overall, the game is probably a 7/10. It's a unique game with numerous sand barriers and amazing physics added to it. The game looks spectacular, like as if you could just stand there in a destroyed skyscraper and watch the sand dunes shift and churn with the wind. The storyline isn't anything major, but a minor attempt at something new that puts it out from the Call of Duty and Battlefield franchises.

A very atmospheric walking simulator, very beautiful philosophical game with a weird story/plot and a great aesthetic.   Story is pretty weird, I liked it but not everyone will like it, mainly because of the fact you're going to have to read a lot if you want to actually follow and get invested in the plot of the game, and I highly recommend that you invest yourself in the story, so if you don't like reading I'd recommend you stay away unless you'd just like to explore a nice world.  Some people on here complain about the narrator, that he uses 'overly complicated words' to sound smart, the he is cringeworthy etc... I don't find this to be true at all. If you think the words the narrator uses is to complicated and if you think the narrator misuses the words then yea, it's not the games fault, I think it's you specifically that the words are to complicated for, I think it's YOU that don't understand them. Because he doesn't misuse any words, and words are certainly not hard to understand if you understand basic English. The narrator in the game was very nice to listen to and only helped with the already weird philosophical story, plot and setting of the game.  I will not spoil anything but the atmosphere in the game and the story take many weird, or more correctly dark and gory turns. Find out for yourself but I liked it.  The game itself, the graphics are very beautiful to look at, which is almost always the case with the Unreal Engine. The music is amazing, and the game is  exactly  what you're told it is, it's an exploration walking simulator with little to no actually content/gameplay, this game is obviously marketed to already-fans of walking simulators, so don't buy this if you don't know what you're getting into. If you don't like reading I don't recommend it either, there is a lot of reading as I said if you want to follow the plot, which I recommend that you do. But you don't have to read, if you just want to explore in a very beautiful game while listening to a nice voice actor then there's nothing wrong with that.  The game is a philosophical art piece, so if you enjoy philosophy then get in, and if you enjoy art in the form of games. I enjoyed it very much due to that, it got me thinking. I very often say that Walking Simulators aren't always bad due to the lack of content, they can be great in the way of how they can make you think about things you never thought about. I don't care if you refuse to call walking simulators games, I don't care if you'd like to call them a 'First Person Art Piece Exhibit' or whatever you want to call it, it's a nice game for what it's quite obviously marketed as.   A must buy for any walking simulator fan, for any person who loves philosophy, and for any person who loves art in the form of games, and I recommend it as a new experience to anyone who haven't played a game like this before.  A must buy in my opinion.
