The concept is interesting, but the graphics are crude. The atmosphere is immersing, but the controls are not. The architecture makes you wonder, but the puzzles and scenery progression tell no story whatsoever.  There is no coherence or flow; some puzzles are BAD (looking at you, Pi), the hints are abrupt and without any subtlety. The interaction is poor. Walking up stairways gives headaches from the camera motion; too close to walls and you see through them. Strange things in the scenery prompt questions, but nothing around intends to answer them.  There is a mystery surrounding Kairo, and it is: 'why am I still playing?'

From bad acting and porn mustaches to the exquisite combination of neon lights and electronic synth music, CF3:BD is a shameless throwback to a bygone era. A era when cybernetic men could ride laser-eyed dinosaurs and be gentle in bed. An era when smart, independent women could rock short blond hair without anyone questioning her sexual orientation.  CF3:BD Combines the best and worst of the 80's. If there was a button to high-five enemies in the face, this game would be perfect.  As it stands, it'll have to settle for an 1989/10. It's pretty good if you ask me. This has many comparisions to Undertale, I.E., more focus on story than gameplay, nonlethal combat methods, supported nonlethal combat methods, Wallbreaking story, etc. Although, while I am a big fanboy of Undertale, and have had more fun playing Undertale, that doesn't make this a bad game at all. Infact, it's actually really good. Although, one thing that undertale takes advantage to in this game, is that it has a satisfying ending, that is actually an ending, if you do it right, and multiple nonsatisfying/terrifying endings if you don't. This game, it all leads up to one confusing sequel bait, 'To be continued'. It even says so itself. I'm not joking. At the very least the new game they're making (Of which's kickstarter will be avaliable on the 18th) looks pretty interesting. But let's put it all in a list: PROS: +Good story. It confused me at the start, but kept me interested and immersed until the end. +Very interesting and realistic characters and reactions. +'Say nothing'. It's about time that a game with dialogue, I am now able to say absolutely nothing when I have absolutely nothing to say. Or when there's nothing that I want to say. + In all honesty, I think that the combat is fairly nice. Nothing special, just, nice. I had alot of fun in the VR tutorials. +The ship is laid out like a bloody ship. +The voice acting is top notch from the characters I've heard. + Chess pieces. I like chess pieces. + Your armor looks cool. + It's, VERY immersive. Seriously. +Choices. Alright, you can probably tell that I'm running out of things to say, but that doesn't mean it's a bad game. I'm just running out of things to say. Most of these pros outweigh the mixed points and cons. MIXED POINTS *Admittedly, I think the dialogue is kinda limited. You use the first four function keys, function 4 always being 'say nothing'. It's not nearly as bad as it was in Fallout 4, but it's still kind of limited. However, for the most part, I don't see there needing any more dialogue options, so yeah. *Also, the dialogue system can be quite clunky for some, as there is the fear of pressing the wrong button, not knowing if you pressed the wrong button, and actually pressing the wrong button, and if you are using a controller, I don't know how you would be able to press anything. But I haven't tried it with a controller. So I'm not sure. *The graphics, are, well, I don't have that good of a machine, so I can't really complain about it too much, but they aren't the greatest in the world. But in my eyes, unless they are eyesoaringly ugly, I don't think graphics matter all that much. *Oh. I thought this was going to be in space. *The UI is pretty wierd. I'm one who despises Cyan, and despises it's use in Science fiction games, and despises hologram UI, but that's an opinion, so I am going to leave it as a MP. Now for the negatives. CONS: -Although I have some subjective issues with the UI, the UI isn't always the most responsive, and can be very, VERY -confusing. -The AI in this game is terrible. I was fighting this one shady guy, whom I will not spoil, and he all of a sudden just stopped dead, giving me a clear advantage to headshot him until I defeated him. And then when the ship is being boarded by some bad guys, I just had to go around a corner, and then shoot them. They wouldn't follow me, I just stood behind some bars and masscared them. -The ship you are on gets small when you are used to it. Atleast in System Shock 2 it was a hugemongolous ship with many features. It can get repetetive to wonder around it so much. -Dear lord can some of the objectives be confusing. -Short -The ending. ♥♥♥♥ the ending. -Admittedly, I got this on a free weekend, but I really cannot see myself paying money for this game. Especially with it's sequel (hopefully) coming out. -I get it you wan't to be pacifist, but where did that say you could only have TWO combat sections?  To be truthful, I really like this game's story and atmosphere, and I think its an underrated title. But I can't give it a strong one, seeing as how the sequel (Who's trailer can be found here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PWTWJYXZvq8&index=2&list=PLAu3Msds_3yYijp70y6YVy_RyhDTQKsCW&ab_channel=InterdimensionalGamesInc  ) is going to eventually come out, and then leave this game in the dust, with what seems to be more advanced gameplay and being on an actual mission. Plus it's being developed on UDK 4, as opposed to Source. But if it's free, or on sale for cheap, get this game.

app_name: Call of Duty: Black Ops III
review_text: Multiplayer:  Pros: -New Features -Great maps, except for 1 which I hate (♥♥♥♥IN STRONGHOLD) -More balanced out -No more insta kill knifes, making game more fun -New ways to kill enemies -Specialist, each one having a special weapon or ablity for you to choose from  Cons: -Some of the backdrops (Some, not all) look really fake -Still got these over powered shotguns for all those shotgun noobs enjoyments -A bit of hackers -Hard to find games sometimes if in Third World Country -Servers can be shity sometimes, going over 200 ping on a local server and getting disconnected atleast once a day  Zombies:  Pros: -The map is huge -Great Narrative dude in background -Players talk to each other making it feel more lively -New beast mode -New weapons -New features and Additions -Well Developed Characters  Cons: -Some of the meshes in the game are 2D, which is not acceptable for a triple AA game  -Almost nobody plays it if you live in Third World -Too much to remember and too much tasks which overwealm the player -Have to be online for it (Solo included)  Campaign:  Pros: Non  Cons: Not a campagin I was expecting from Treyarch which normal deliver on their SP part of their games  Nightmare: Seems that all Treyarchs special story narrative went into this seperate campaign than the official one. Much better than that piece of ♥♥♥♥ they call a 'Campaign'  MP rating = 8/10 Zombies = 6/10 Campaign = 1/10 (not worth wasting time on that ♥♥♥♥) Nightmare = 7/10  Overall = 7/10  If you just buy CoD for zombies or Campaign then I would advise sticking to Black ops 1 and 2 zombies. An amazing game full of some of the most clever, hilarious and grim dialogue I've ever seen. This is a game where you love every character, even your nemesis. If you do decide to play this game, I'd say it really is worth your money. There are plenty of unique and amazing endings. Along tons of moments that will make you feel empty, plenty of times you'll feel like you're at home, and times that you will feel like you never want to stop playing.  The game is also fair. It's hard to get frustrated by it, in fact, I've never once seen anyone get mad over it, and that is probably a good enough reason for people who don't play many games to play this one. If you're bad at Bullethell, it's okay, because this game will make you great at it.   A game full of twists, turns, sadness and joy, characters that are not spoken of, and characters you'll love to the end. It deserves the title of 'Best Game of The Year', and I would like to see someone think differently.

The Few's gameplay is simple and can be divided into two parts. First, airplanes, factories, and airfields are built and organized. Then, enemies attack the player and combat mode commences. The goal is to defend the country for certain (It's maximum 50 I think, at least as I saw of achievements) days and survive the enemy raids. The animations, user-interface, and art style are nicely polished and the music fits the theme. The voice acting and monologue for the commander are really kind of great for this game! This is biggest part of the game for me :p atmophere is important for me at every games.  The game is really easy to get into because of its simple game mechanics and built-in tutorial. But unfortunately, there's no hook.. The majority of the game involves waiting to be attacked, but this can be sped up or slowed down by changing the time-pace. Stopping and fast-forwarding through time is definitely a neat feature!! The designation of linear path movements for friendly planes is also part of the gameplay. The main character can also be customized, but it doesn't serve much use in the game. The pilots' names can be changed which is also nice touch to me.. Overall, the game has little variety still.. I don't play that much this kind of 'war' games but if we would say graphics and perspective doesn't matter for me, it's a great 1940 game... Your job is to defend Great Britain by controlling the allied airmen of the Royal Air Force.. And as I can remember the games name exactly comin from here.. So I bought this for really some low money. Cents maybe, I don't remember. But I prefer to review this kind of games, rather H1Z1, Assassin's Creed or bla bla bla a lot of famous games..         Graphics   6.1/10       Voice/Soundtracks   8.0/10       Gameplay   7.7/10       Story   3.9/10       Generally   6.9/10

One of my favorite games, This rogue platformer has got to be one of the best games i have played, With every death, you have a new Character to play with diffrent traits that may help or hinder you, things like being color blind (makes game black and white, nearsighted the screen is only half clear. Being short allows you to slip through tiny passages. Then you unlock your classes that your new charcter could possibly be. The game randomly chooses 3 possible heirs to your last toon.   Then the levels are randomly made, making it nearly impossible to play the same one twice ( there is a way to lock a castle to play agian if you willing to pay the price).   Level up your home to give your next heir an advantage, (this is where you unlock the classes like hokage , barbarian, and lich lord)  A deffinite must play if you like platformers, great casual game that is fun to play.

This is my favorite game that I bought during the Summer Sale. Fast paced and challenging, with perfect controls! Controls can make or break a platformer and these are just great. You move and attack so quickly, but you feel in total control of your ninja the entire time.   You need very good reflexes for this game and the ability to watch a lot of things at the same time. Enemies can react VERY quickly to your character. Good thing the game has a great built in mechanic. When you kill a lot of enemies in a row, in quick succession, you will activate your Rage ability. You become invincible during this and kill everything in 1 hit, not counting bosses.   The game also has an awesome unlock system. I don't know the exact number, but somewhere around 75 different unlockable equipment, abilities and powerups are in the game. I really like this unlock system, because the better you do in the game, the better unlocks you will get access to for your next run. Expect to die a ton when first starting out, then when you start getting access to the upgraded equipment and things, you will get a lot further and eventually complete your first run through the tower.  This game can be beaten in around 4 minutes (go watch the speedrun on Youtube, it looks amazing)! The replay value is extremely high though. Lots of different modes to play, including a boss rush and speedrun mode. The unlockables will keep you busy for a long time. Leaderboards to try and improve your best times and scores. Not to mention the game is just extremely fun to play. With a very low price (pick up the great DLC also!), theres no reason not to get this game.

I think I have enough time in this game to say it\'s awesome.  I\'ve loved shmups since I was little. Besides jrpgs, they were what I played when I was young, and I feel a lot of vertical shmups lately have lost the arcade feel. They\'re inventive and offer new things, but nothing\'s brought me back to nostalgiaville like SGS has.   I originally backed this game when it was in the Kickstarter phase. In their video, they discussed wanting to make a shmup that brought the old-style feel into it. That\'s what sold me, and they delivered.  The music is by my favorite local band, Random Encounter, which is an extreme added bonus.   I would recommend this game to old and new shmup lovers, especially those that fell in love with vertical shmups like Fever SOS, Viper Phase 1, and Xevious.

Great game that differs itself from the other roguelikes. While it may not be a 'procedurally generated' map, and there isn't anything that has a chance of being good or bad (ex: quaff potion, turns out to be a fire potion killing you) except for some abilities that teleport you randomly within a certain tile range (which you can get control of later on anyways). Without those, why should I still play it you ask? For one, this game is incredibly hard (which is a good thing). Every mistake adds up, and you have to think about how you approach enemies depending on your character, which brings me to my favorite part. There are tons of classes and races to choose from, each being unique in their own way. Classes are more rpg oriented, each having unique multiple attacks and tactics to use during the battles.  TL;DR: Great game, you should play it. While there is the free version on their website, this one adds a few more options and an extra class, and helps support the creator, who is a great guy (he actually listens~)

Overall rating 7/10  Really GOOD features: - GRAPHICS, awesome graphics! - ANIMATIONS, well the ones that actully work look amazing. - GAME MODES, there are so many game modes that you can play for year. - SOUNDTRACK, way to go Pharell :D  Yup, thats about it with the good things... now the really BAD sides: - Saving options, sound options wont save, camera wont save, action replays... you actually have to set this things over and over on every game in mycareer (at least thats the mode i noticed it) - BALL STEAL, OMG, it feels like the player doesn't know where the ball is. The animations are so off... And even if you manage to tip the ball you will be lucky if you manage to race to it and catch it because the player gets stuck in steal animation! WOW! - BLOCKS. Again, player doesnt know where the ball is to block it!  - AFTER BUCKET ANIMATION. This must be the worst! Whenever you or teamate scores, your player just jumps around the court celebrating for an hour and you cant move to guard or do anything... - COLLISIONS, ya, the ball will go through you when opponent passes, they will go through you, your player fingers will go through the ball on block attempt and the ball will still go in and score. - ONLINE... lags, disconnections, waiting times... you read it all already... - DIFFICULTY SETTINGS. Simply Stupid. Game logic, no game logic, stupid as broken light bulb. The higher the difficulty the more shots you and your teamates miss, and the opponents make more! Ya its that simple, and that stupid. Like they have no idea how this should work and just said 'OK, LETS LOWER THE FG PERCENTAGE' wow! Great!  How about the lower dificulty opponents dont go on fast breaks, or shot contested shots, or make risky pass, or dont double team, you know, stupider AI. And make them use those things as difficulty goes higher. DONT decrease my FG%. Thats simply stupid! - CPU AI! WOW! Especially defense, WOW! No contested shots, no rotation, no nothing... - SOUND DESIGN! Worst! You cant hear any interviews because of the background noise, unbalanced sound effects... - MyCAREER, they seem to have thrown everything they have at the first season and after that its just stupid boring, nothing happens. Where are the conference interview, locker room chats... whatever....  I still recommend this game for anyone that can accept these REAL BAD glitches/bugs/things...

Rogue-Likes and Rouge-Like-Likes alike all tend to feel alike.   Generally in these genres, you hack and slash your way to death with nothing left to really prove except for the knowledge that comes with drinking a suspicious looking potion and losing all your health to a single swig. You take these tips with a grain of salt as the variability to your death changes with each play-through...Although I use the term 'play-through' lightly since you never actually get through some of the more hardcore rogue-likes without hours and hours of dedication to understanding the game's many quirks and traps.   Desktop Dungeons feels like a solid blend of Rogue-Like and Puzzle with a welcome sense of progression as you earn gold and unlock new classes and races along the way. All of that mixed with the ability to spend 10-20 minutes on a single session is also entirely welcome.   The puzzle-like aspect of the game is a great mix to the genre. Instead of spending your time focusing on surviving until your next death, you know exactly what you need to do: kill all of the enemies. The helpful levels that appear next to the enemy names allow you to expect what's coming whether its a victory or a disappointing failure. Rogue-Likes are always known for their randomized nature with their random levels and random encounters; Desktop Dungeons has these to an extent but when you're level 5 and you're about to swing your sword at a level 9, you know you're not making a sound decision. The screen also turns red when your next move is fatal, which helps quite a bit as well.   The progression in the game also allows for a sense of accomplishment. No longer do you feel that sense of loss when you lose everything you worked so hard to get. Each 'dungeon' is its own instance and if you know you're about to fail you can easily just retire and keep all your money (the items you acquire get sold for more money) which can then be spent on upgrading classes, races and even buying gear to aid you on the next quest you go on.   Along with multiple locations, there's plenty of different quests and challenges you can attack. Each class has its own set of challenges that give you bonus money and there are also general challenges that give you more gold just by doing things like spending a certain amount of gold or piety during a quest.   This game is certainly recommended if you enjoy the difficulty in Rogue-Likes but like to spend a casual amount of time slowly increasing your stats, or in this case, your kingdom.

Okay, so this is my first time doing a review of something, so hopefully I do well. Overall, I thought this was a great game, albeit short, and was a wonderful purchase for such a low price.  Visuals: 10/10 The visuals were a nice upgrade from the original iOS graphics, and many little details and touches really helped the immersion factor of the game.  Sound & Music: 10/10 The music and noises in the background definitely help to set the eerie tone that the devs were going for. While not necessarily memorable, the music and sounds are a must-have in this game, otherwise the atmosphere wouldn't quite work.  Puzzles: 8/10 Many puzzles were a bit too simple, and others were a serious downgrade from the iOS version. In places where you had to use two fingers on the mobile game, you instead just do the switches one after the other with the mouse. In the future, it would be nice if these types of puzzles were altered to suit the PC platform instead of showing leftover better ideas from the mobile version. I also found many puzzles a bit simple, but that could be just me.  Story: 8/10 The conveying of story fragments through sequential letters sprinkled throughout the playthrough was very interesting and worked quite well for the game. However, I would like for the next game (which I have not been able to play, due to my Android phone being incompatible) to have more story-driven elements to it, as I found that by the time of the next letter, I had nearly forgotten the last letter. On my second playthrough, however, I noticed a lot of symbolism sprinkled throughout the game referring to the main story, so perhaps they do a better job of reminding you than I give them credit for.  Enjoyment: 9/10 I enjoyed myself immensely while playing The Room (both the Steam and Android versions) and would reccommend it to most people I know, save those who throw puzzles out the window for Call of Duty or TF2. Regardless, if you like to solve puzzles and like a good atmospheric game, perhaps a little psychologically thrilling story here and there, this is definitely for you.

Terraria is.... I can't even think of a word to describe it. It is an amazing game with plenty to do and TONS of content. Terraria has an actual form of progression and nearly 70x the content. Terraria has about 330 different enemies and 25 bosses and PLENTY of weapons, tools, and other oddities to help combat these intimidating foes. Not to mention the style this game has. You certainly won't mistake this game for anything else.

I, like many, remember Metal Slug in it's cabinet form and burning tons of quarters frantically spamming the fire button to shred enemies. While the game itself is practically the same, the game controls itself cause me to not recommend this game. I LOVE Metal Slug. But it's very frustrating to play with a mouse and keyboard, as the game was meant for a joystick and buttons (i.e. neogeo cabinet style). This means getting steam achievements like not dying is near impossible. If you have a USB classic joystick, this game will ROCK. If you are a WASD/mouse player, this game will make you frustrated and sad.

I'll be honest, here. I did -not- enjoy this game.  The cons were, of course. The atmosphere and perfect sound design. This game even comes with a special headset-only mode to really make you question your sanity. Mix this in with an interesting art design and you have a good start.  However, I find myself not scared. But bored. The game is filled with many rooms, about sixty percent of those pointless. I had many mockery names popping up in my head as I entered room after eventless room. Eventually hoping to find that ONE room to bring me to the next set of rooms.. These names were names such as Walking simulator. Room simulator. Didn't-I-Just-Enter-This-Room-A-Second-Ago Simulator.  The game has three endings, strung together in a few paths that you can take through your playthrough. I did not find myself eager enough to replay this, thus I've decided to watch the other two endings on youtube. I assumed that what I had gotten was the ''Good ending''. But, interestingly enough. I found the bad ending so much more interesting, and to an extent, the scariest part of this whole game. I understand that pacing is an obvious thing to have in horror games, but this was simply: Hey! You ♥♥♥♥ed up! Now let's show you what we've had a kickstarter for!

So I've finally gotten around to playing Darksiders this week. It's been called Ocarina of Time mashed up with God of War. I've never played God of War, but it certainly feels a LOT like Ocarina. It's fun, to be sure, but it's inferior in a couple of ways.   The most glaring is that it's SUPER linear. At least the first 5 hours I've played has been. Whereas most Zelda games resemble an open world (even though the sequence of events is linear). Darksiders very much funnels you from arena to puzzle to arena and is far easier than Ocarina.  Less obvious is where the theme, plot, and characters fall far short of Zelda. You'd think that playing as one of the Horsemen of the apocalypse, War, and battling demons, being a general badass would be freaking amazing. It's really not. Because of the overly grandiose nature of your character and the plot, you really can't connect with any of it on any level, and it feels like you're just going through the motions to get the game done, and it really doesn't effect you in any IRL capacity.  Contrast that with Ocarina, wherein you are a mysterious little boy given the gift of this task of saving your loved ones from a mysterious malevolence starting with nothing at all and finally becoming a young adult with a kick butt arsenal and mad skillz. A little more dynamic, emotionally, than, 'Hey, you're War, you start out powerful and get more powerful. Have fun killin' stuff.'  Overall the game is fun, and worth playing so long as you don't expect it to be different from anything else you may have already played. A solid hack'n'slash with a great aesthetic.

The tons of secrets really justify the maps designs. ( if your Gamma is set properly) they can even be creepy. The Glory kills are repetative but a good addition to the game mechanic.  Ultimately DOOM puts you in that DOOM world with the music, the tempo of the game, the fast pace gamplay, the need to be inquisitive, the crazed demons, DOOM is a well made game, Unlike Rage, Id did DOOM right.

I'll just keep this short and sweet.  As far as a vanilla launch, this is probably the best Civilization we've gotten in the past ten years. Now, optimisation issues aside, there's a lot of content for you to bite down into; basically, all the stuff we had to wait for in expansions back when Civ 5 came out is already here with us right out the gate.  However, there are some optimisation issues; from random crashes to loading screens that never end, its a choppy game and I feel like they had more than enough time with it to prevent such things. But while I am irritated, its still a damn fine 4X strategy game.  If you're a fan of the series, pick it up. If you're new, pick it up if you dont mind spending the cash. If Civ hasn't really done it for you, this isn't going to convert you.

Looks like people have been on a mission to slam this game recently, but I am glad I didn't heed these poor reviews as I very much appreciate this game for what it is and what it offers.   As a previous long-time player of WoW (Vanilla - Cataclysm) and Rift, I had been looking for another game in this vein that would offer a new leveling experience and a new world to explore. Yes, I like questing. Although I've done my share of raiding, endgame is generally my least favorite time -- even with expansions -- and dailies can only be done so long before it becomes another job. So over the past couple years I've tried my hand at a variety of games both paid and f2p -- Elder Scrolls Online, EQ1, EQ2, FFXIV, Neverwinter, DnD Online, LOTRO, Archeage -- in search of a wow-like game that meets my 3 main criteria:    Mouse Movement (after a decade of WoW/Rift -- too old to learn new tricks) (too bad it took $80 ESO to realize)    A crafting system that doesn't make me mental (EQ : O)    No mandatory PVP  Other preferences....    no loading screens at every doorway (wth FFXIV)    no creepy anime-ish child-elf characters    a good class/points system / defined roles & abilities    an auction house    an interesting world/lore with related quests   Yes, pretty graphics are nice. But so far, Alganon is on par with most of the games listed above. And as far as the cash shop, the transactions are reasonable -- more so than I found with LOTRO and Rift (the latter went F2P 2 years after I started and I found myself needing to spend so MUCH more than the $15/mo subscription there).   So if, like me, you're looking to recapture the fun of navigating a new world without spending $60 on a new (or not so new) game (talking to you GW2), Alganon may be worth your download. So far so good for me.....

Way better than SimCity 2013:  - It DOES work off-line! - Customizable regions, up to 32 cities! - Choice of small, medium and large cities, giving you lots of space to expand your cities! - Fully single player game, no trolling firends can 'help' you! - Full modding support with vast community! - Your sims tend to live and work most of the time in the same place, like real life! - Lots of mass transport options, incliding buses, trains, elevated trains, monorail, ferries, airports and even a subway system! - You can drive around your city in one of many availiable vehicles, like cars, buses, trucks, sailing boats and helicopters! - You decide how the cities are connected: road, rail, highway? You're the boss!  All that and more for a fractions of the price, Origin-free, only on Steam.  How that works for ya?

Planetside 2 is a free to play game that's really free -- and fun -- to play. I've been playing free for three months now. I do not feel that my game play is in any way inhibited by my not paying anything. Even while I freeload I am a full participant, with as good weapons as anyone else.  This game is a multiplayer war game done right. The rules and perameters of the game make it move fast. There are no equipment shortages, no competitions for vehicles, no waiting. The game system encourages full participation and cooperation better than the Battlefield series.  I have always been suspicious of free-to-play games. They always seem like come-ons and rip-offs. But I have enjoyed playing Planetside 2 so much, I'm about to become a subscriber.

app_name: Realm of the Mad God Exalt
review_text: I'll start off by saying, this is a fun game. But there are plenty of issues with it.   First off, it's a 2D RPG/Roguelike/Bullet hell game. This is actually a really good combination, the combat is fun and very simple whilst still having a fair amount of depth to it. The everlooming threat of permanent death keeps the game adrenaline filled even when you're fighting a boss you've fought hundreds of times before. The classes are unique and fun to play, each having their own niche. You can deal incredible amounts of damage very quickly with wizards, heal your teammates with priests, or stun monsters and tank with the knight. Or you can rush dungeons with rogues. Or take event bosses with an Assassin. Or clear dungeons with an Archer. For every playstyle, there is a class.  The economy in this game is based off of stat potions. These increase your stats permanently, and are always in demand due to perma death. The least rare and thus least valuable potion is the speed potion, with the holy grail of pots being the life potion. Trading with other players is a fun process, albeit long. Unlike other economies in other games the currency in this game is always being destroyed so it retains it's value instead of constantly being inflated. This makes each boss fight that much more intense knowing that even though the risk is high, the reward is much, much higher.   However the bad in this game is Kabum. The developers of this game have constantly shown they don't understand what the player actually wants. I've stopped playing this game simply because Kabum is terrible. Things they have done include accidentally releasing a warrior kit bundle for 1 gold (premium in game currency worth roughly 1 cent). This instantly tanked the price of the kit and screwed up the economy for a bit. Another thing they did to mess up the game royally was removing the ability of gland mobs to drop pots. This made the price of stat pots rise until they reverted back to the original model. Again, screwing up the economy for a bit.    Altogether a good game ruined by a bad developer.

If you enjoy repetition, dying over and over while you try to figure out where the hell you are supposed to go and pulling your hair out then this is the game for you! It's hard to tell where you are actually going to land and I died repeatedly just because I thought I was centered up over a ledge to find that I was just a little bit off. I stopped at the part where you have to figure out where to go while turning on lights, that go off soon after you turn them on, in a totally black cave thing and trying to find the ledge to stand on while simultaneously targetting the next place you are supposed to grapple to and find the next light source to turn on. Walked off of the path more times than I can count because YOU HAVE NO FEET to use to tell whether or not you are centered up on whatever it is that you are walking across. I don't mind trying something time and again if I know what I am supposed to do and I am failing at it but this game has no direction markers of any kind and I fell to my death more times than not because I ever so slightly walked off the edge of a small path no wider than a foot, respectively, based off of the size of the character's disembodied arm.   I was exilerated at first, the high jumps, the strange world, the bright colors, all very fetching and then the game actually started.. I was quickly annoyed by the grapples to the little floating rocks and the lack of any way to know if you are close enough to grapple onto them or not. Not to mention on many occassions I went to a rock that I thooough was the next one in the succession but alas, no, it was not and seeing as I was out of charges with my grappling hook and it wouldn't recharge, because I had gone the wrong way, I was stuck there, forever.. or until I committed suicide or quit and repawned.  Undoubtedly I didn't make it all that far into the game but that's because within thirty minutes of dying over and over and over it was seriously trying my patience and I wanted to scream and throw my computer out the window. If you like an unfair challenge from a game that is too short, according to all the other reviews I have been reading, and mechanics that are rather clunky and unpolished then this is the one for you.  On a side note, I made a specific category just for this game, this game is the only one in the category and I have yet to find another that annoyed and frustrated me to the extent that this game did so I don't think it will be getting any company anytime soon, the name of this category is: WHAT THE ACTUAL F*CK?????? That is all.

'My review is clean as an elven ♥♥♥♥!' There's not a lot ot say about this franchise that hasn't already been said. Simply put, this series is one of the best examples of when western rpgs finally started to truly compete and surpass jrpgs. If you are under the age of 30, love rpgs, and are interested in seeing the history of video games preserved you simply MUST give this game a chance. It's not perfect, but it does so many things right for the genre it's a crime that there are people going into game design who have never played it.  Pros:  -Minsc, you'll understand when you play the game -Fun story to play through with voice talent ranging from fantastic to meh -New content, classes, party members, etc. over the original game add TONS of replayability -If people support projects like this more and more developers might be willing to go back and restore their old games to make them available for the modern audience  Cons:  -Graphical barrier to entry might be a little high for some but the art design is good enough you can overcome that (You whipper snappers and your photo realistic graphics! In my day you had to make due with only one pixel and you liked it!) -Combat is a little dated and it's not always obvious what decisions you make are really changing things (a lot of stuff goes on under the hood as it were for better or worse) -Minsc can die forever if you aren't careful

There are so many things to like about this game. The art is great, the narration really adds to the atmosphere, and the gameplay is challenging. All the classes have unique skill sets, and the dungeon enimies have good variation as well.   I find the game gets to be a bit of a grind, once you are just trying to level up enough characters to beat the Darkest Dungeon. After about 30 hours, I just got bored of doing the same missions over and over again, but I hope to go back and finish the game eventually.

For those familiar with Dead Island, this is like upgraded and polished version of gameplay from that with removal of some silly aspects (there's still plenty, just the worst) while unfortunately losing things like the smart aiming for melee. Gameplay is generally more varied by a noticeable margin but not immensively and the game kept me interested to play through till the end even though the game took 40 hours for me to beat. I guess people less entertained by people being cut up, blood flowing through the air while parkouring like mad.  Except for the occasionally obnoxious volatiles (they were tolerable/fun at times) and the out of nowhere bombers, I didn't have that many issues with the game. Maybe a few problems with the freerunning when trying to climb walls and it stopping for some obscure reason, but that was so rare it happened like only maybe once every 4-6 hours.  The controls and freerunning are very intuitive like it was in Mirror's Edge which is very refreshing compared ot many other freerunning games where you keep flipping off walls like you totally intended that (NO, STOP DOING THAT!) while this game actually understands your intent by requiring you to do the tiniest bit of effort to signal it instead of attempting to play the game for you.  If you want splattery parkour/freerunning zombie murder game that is fun just because you Can do lots of fun stuff in it, this should be pretty high in your list of games to play (unless you want something utterly silly, then go for Dead Rising 1-2. State of Decay if you want to go in less silly direction). If you however want gritty survival simulator, look to things like the excellent Project Zomboid (don't you dare touch those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ firstperson ones).  Final Words: It's Just Another Zombie Game. Unfortunately :C

Despite only getting into X-com after playing EU, I instantly fell in love with UFO defense. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding, although it is very clunky. I didn't realise how much the atmposphere meant to me until I played this game. TFTDs music is nothing short of horrible. Remember the music that played before a terror mission in UFO? It was just what you needed to get hyped before the mission started. In this game the music sounds like a 1950s low budget horror film. The starting items are confusing as all hell, I mean what is the difference between a dart gun and a harpoon gun? What does a partical disturbance grenade do and how does it differentiate from a magna-blast grenade?!? In UFO defense you could easily understand an items function by looking at its name.   It's due to stuff like confusing names and a game breaking tech tree (researching projects in the wrong order can render the game unfinishable) that you will almost certainly have to rely on a guide if you don't want to restart this game constantly. This isn't even taking into account how difficult the game is which oddly enough is one of the few things that they did right. After getting a hang of the basics and researching some good gear, UFO defense got very easy. The game also feels a lot buggier. I occasionally see a 3 tile long river just floating in the blackness outside the map. Terror missions seem to take place in a village located in bizzaro land where the houses are built into the side of never ending hills. There are 1 tile wide tunnels dotted around the map that exist for no other purpose than to make the mission harder.  The only postive thing I can say about this game is that the combat feels a lot better and is more challenging. However I think it sacrificed too much for it.  In conclusion, just play UFO defense with mods. The atmosphere as a whole is better and the bugs aren't game breaking.

A cracking title that every FPS enthusiast should own. This game is outstanding and delivers a real action packed 4 player cooperative experience whilst challenging your thinking abilities and reaction times. Although each mission is scripted, there are random spikes in gameplay that keep the content fresh and you, on your toes. It's accompanied by a suitable soundtrack that changes as the pace of the game fluctuates and once again gives you that immersive feel which will keep you playing for many hours.   On the whole, this game is well worth the RRP of $30 – The DLC I feel is a tad expensive for what you get and kind of spoils the game a little for me. None the less, this title is a lot of bang for your buck, you will not be disappointed.

Dear fellow gamer   After just 17 hours me and my friend finished a single playthrough of the game in co-op. We discovered something: this game is a must in co-op! We had loads of fun and we were frustrated more than once when we couldn’t kill a boss or troll. But in the end we got through and concluded that this game is more than awesome!! On the other hand we were let down by the final battle, which was simply tooooooo easy, since we had more difficulty defeating the first boss in the game.    THE STORY:  We were pleasantly surprised by the fact that the story is interwoven with the actual storyline of LOTR. You even come across characters as Aragorn, Gandalf, Lord Elrond, Legolas and Gloin (known from the Hobbit-trilogy) and even Frodo and Bilbo Baggins. You follow three companions (Eradan, Andriel and Farin) on their quest to defeat a minion of the dark lord Sauron. On their way they make several friends and stops in the north of Middle Earth.   GRAPHICS:  Not bad at all for a game that is already 4 years old. We saw a fair amount of detail on armours, buildings and the like and didn’t realise we were playing such an old game.   INTERFACE:  Convenient use of hotkeys and a useful minimap! The inventory was a little off, since you had very limited space and images for additional and trivial objects in the world of Middle Earth.   GAMEPLAY:  We found it very useful that you could see the name of your friends on screen even if they were in an entirely different place/room. A very useful feature of the game is that you have the option to exchange items with other players that are only suitable for that particular race. Conveniently enough there were several sell/buy/return to civilisation-points.  -  For the Ranger:  Very smooth movement of the character during a fight and one of the current reviewers enjoyed the swordplay a little too much at times. We liked the convenient switch between two-handed, one-handed, dual wielding and bow very useful. And, contrary to some other RPG’s, the realism of being attacked whilst you are looting or switching weapons was very satisfactory to us! We loved the critical, brutal, legendary, etc. strikes with the swords and headshots with the bow too. They lead to some pretty funny ways of dying! We would’ve loved an alternative attack with hotkey ‘2’ while using a two-handed sort, but that could just be because we didn’t unlock every skill in the skill tree. Conclusion; Eradan was a great ranger. -  For the Lore-master:  Andriel has some great abilities to use in combat, as a supportive mage. For example, she can conjure a magical shield that can protect you against arrows and magical blasts. She also can use her staff as a melee weapon, that is actually quite strong. Because of her Elven ancestry, Andriel can use herbs to fabricate potions to support herself or her companions. This can be decisive at some points in the game. -  For the Champion:  Not applicable (yet), but Farin is awesome!! He got us out of trouble more than once…more like a thousand times…LOL.    ALSO FUN;   - You can use your Eagle friend to do all the heavy work for you.  - You meet a dragon; Which seems to be very popular amongst gamers.  - Turrets!    Overall conclusion:   'The Lord of the Rings - War in the North' is a must have if you are a fan of the LOTR, RPG and/or co-op gaming, with a bit of hack & slash in it. We had hours and hours of fun (and yet more to come) and we didn't get bored with the storyline once, even though all those trolls were a pain. Me and my friend decided that we definitely are going to play this game a few times each year... *Totally not addicted*   Enjoy the game!

This is a great f2p model.  Pros:  *Most paid features are purely cosmetic.  *Pretty nice graphics.  *Each class seems to play entirely different.  *Some quests are pretty creative.  *The community is nice.  *Bazillion amounts of in game achievements, for those of you who like that.  Cons: *When you reach certain levels, you'll sometimes automatically be given a quest. This is alright, except for the fact that a huge screen will pop-up to explain the quest to you, even if you happen to still be in combat. This really isn't so bad, I'm just holding a grudge because it caused me to die once.  *There's a lotta dudes on here that roll a female. I'm well aware this happens on every mmo, but I'm not kidding when it's normal to see female characters outnumber male characters 4:1 at times on this game. I personally don't really care about this, but this is just a fair warning to any fellow bros out there who may get seduced by internet 'women'  *Game just feels way too easy sometimes. At first it made me feel like I was a champ, but then I realized that I was getting to be a high level and the game is still giving me baby steps.  *My biggest gripe is the repetitiveness. The second area has a lot more shops than the first area, which is to be expected, and some of the new shops were pretty cool. The third area had the same exact shops, which I thought was fine. But then I get to the fourth area and realize that for the past 3 areas, aka 30 levels, the shops have been the same. Obviously the equipment was different, but it follows the same forumula (Area 2 sells Area 1 equipment and Area 2 equipment, Area 3 sells Area 2 equipment and Area 3 equipment, etc). At least up to level 40 there was not much variety in the equipment you get. I know at higher levels the loot is a bit different, but this was pretty annoying to me. --- Overall, this game is f2p and has some expected faults. However, being p2w is not a fault, as this game doesn't go by that. Any free game that I can put roughly 24 hours of enjoyed playing time into is fine by me. There will be plenty more hours to come.

app_name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
review_text: Holy ♥♥♥♥, everyone needs to play this game. If you've played a lot of games, there's a lot to appreciate in the design department. It's all so smooth, it never explains anything, and yet it's so intuitive, nothing is ever unclear. This is true in the mechanics and also the story, as every character speaks gibberish. I'd also highly recommend it to people who don't play games, because it's incredibly accessible and one of the best arguments for games-as-art I've yet encountered. The story and the mechanics are blended so perfectly, each reinforcing the other. It's simply masterful. I wish I could write something even half as beautiful as this game.

Now, let's get this out of the way. I don't play Visual Novels, and I actively dislike most of Japanese entertainment offerings from games to anime and manga. So this review is from someone who is not in to this whole scene. I have also read the fan translated version, so my hours in this one don't actually reflect the true hours I've spent on this story.   One note, this is the 'no p0rn' version of the VN, and personally I think it only improves the story. The sex in the fan translated was mostly gratuitous and didn't really add anything useful to the story. I haven't played the story enough to say whether the censorship affected some of the jokes, however. Which would be a shame, because the adult jokes were often quite funny. But the sex scenes were useless. I'll have to get back to you about that.  For some reason, I just love this 'book'. It starts as a pure fluff comedy slice of life kind of thing, with slightly mysterious subtext. It helps to be aware of the Japanese stereotypes of 'kuudere' and 'tsundere', etc. for certain jokes. And make no mistake, there are a lot of jokes in this story.   You'll be laughing with tears in your eyes.  The game starts with a 'common route' where you make some fairly insignificant choices, and then finally you choose the girl you will be pursuing. Yes, the whole game is basically a romance, with the twist of all characters (including protagonist) being emotionally unstable and having usually huge psychological problems.  The game also makes a huge genre shift about 6 hours in, once you're done with the common route. The common route is absolutely hilarious comedy, the story then starts to slowly turn more serious and with less humor. Until you will be crying, and this time not because of laughter.  However, if you make right choices, you will be graced with a good ending, so there is always light at the end of the tunnel. Just warning you that there will be a lot of drama and it all will look very bleak.  There's only two dark spots on the VN and the main one is the presence of a loli. That is to say, the Makina route, which (should) give the creeps for anyone who isn't in to little girls. Yes, technically she's not much younger than Yuuji (the protagonist) but the route even plays up her youthful appearance. So, yes, it's disturbing. My advice for those who find lolis as disturbing phenomenon as I do, is to buy and play the VN but just... well, when Makina gives you money, refuse.  The second, but more of a minor problem, is the Michiru route. Because that sorely tests your suspension of disbelief. The premise of the whole route. The core of the issue... It's just pure and unadultered fantasy magic. But if you can swallow that, it's fine and often quite funny.  Among the best parts of the whole story is the protagonist Yuuji who is both a sarcastic badass, and hilariously unable to understand normal life.

Of the time I've played it , this is very very different then the traditional Tomb Raider games that I've played. The puzzles and the difficulty levels have been bumped up quite a bit and the game has evolved from a traditional console style game to a action packed movie style game. Has great voice acting. I was a bit weary when I heard Square Enix was involved but Square Enix is known for quality games and this one shows it. The full environmental interactivity in the game adds to the possibilities of how you can progress through the game , it seems there is more then one way to get through a portion of each part of the game. Going to be playing this more over the holiday weekend here in the USA, but if you are looking for something new Tomb Raider wise, I would pick this game up over Tomb Raider Legend - Its more fun to play.

Although i perhaps exaggerate now a little bit, but my personal opinion is, that Miasmata is a really astonishing masterpiece. The graphic quality almost reaches the standards of extremely expensive engines made by big companies, but is in fact made by just 2 guys. Surely it has some flaws, like the grainy looking water in the distance and no waves along the shores. The fog sometimes act a little bit strange and there are proplems like torches/sticks dont illuminate the logbook or map. But all of that is compensated by the incredible atmosphere. Starting extremely weak and as easy pray, you have to find water, plants and safe spots to survive. Creating medicine to keep you alive and to find the cure for the plague. Running around the island can be tricky sometimes, because the terrain affects your speed. It requires a lot of strenght to climb up a hill and you may stumble while running down, which causes a headache and in the worst case deadly high fever. Another great feature is, how you can create the map of the island. The easy method is to find pieces of the map around the camps. The other method is to draw a small piece of it by marking 2 known landmarks which are in sight. While exploring the island, you are watched by a creature lurking in the shadows of the Jungle, which will soon start to hunt you down. You dont have weapons and all you can do is to hide, distract the creature or run for you life. But there is one power you have, which will scare the beast away.

I hate it but don't let it stop you from playing it, let me explain below.  i got the game sometime ago at a steam discount, asked my cousin what he tought about it, he said it's a great game and i agree, the latest reviews agree as well, for the 20 out of 25 hours i've played it, it was awesome! i don't remember the last time i had so much fun in an FPS game (other than playing CoD with friends but pretty much that), as for the other 5 hours... ,lately i've been having a lot of problems with a certain 'NAT type: strict' and it pretty much killed it for me, only getting in games where i get some bad lag spikes and it just ruins the whole experience for me, read trough a lot of forums, in one case someone owned a copy of siege on PC and console, when he played on PC he had a strict nat but on console it was open, that was weird, thing is this is the only game i suffer that kind of lag and stuttering, i tried UPnP, port forwarding, wifi, cable, you name it, and it refuses to change at the very least to moderate.  over all, for (i think it was) 25-30$, i got 20 hours on it which were great, even though it doesn't have a single player mode, the situations were a good comparinson of a sort.  my temporary solution is using my phone's hotspot which allows me a moderate nat type, but is it really necessary having my phone plugged in all the time so i can play a game?

The most basic description would be Diablo with a Marvel theme, and that really tells you all you need to know about how it plays. Ignore the meta-gaming about who's the 'best' hero to play and just pick your favorite. This game is very dangerous to have installed. I keep finding myself loading it up instead of working on my backlog. The heroes are so varied in playstyle that it's the most fun I've ever had leveling up alts. If you played this when it first came out (sans the 2015 part of the name) you owe it to yourself to try it again. They've made massive improvements since its launch. Most of the voice acting is great, and none of it is bad (some lines do get annoying due to repetition, but that happens in every game). The free-to-play element is really set up well. The only thing you'll really feel like you need to spend money is extra storage space, but the game is so well done that I don't begrudge them for it. Their hard work deserves to be rewarded somehow. Update: Even more fun and addictive now. Some very intriguing changes going to happen soon too.

Mount & Blade: Warband (along with its predecessor, Mount & Blade) is a game so unique it is difficult to fit it snugly into one category. It's an action RPG, it's grand strategy, it's a simulation, it's open world. This game is a whole bunch of things that melt so perfectly together, and it is unlike any other game I've ever played. For anyone who is even the slightest bit interested in medieval warfare, this is the game you never knew you wanted.  You start out by answering some simple questions about the life your character has lived thus far, and critiquing the way your heroine (or hero) looks. You are thrown into the large continent of Calradia which is split into six unique factions that are constantly at war with each other. The world map is familiar to those of us who enjoy grand strategy games; you can view the land and the castles/towns/villages/hideouts etc. that exist on it at any one time, while your character and her horse moves along it like a pawn on a gameboard. The colors of the names tell you which faction currently owns and controls each piece of land. What you begin to do from here is ultimately up to you. You can try doing favors for lords and kings to win their favor and ultimately work for them, whilst building up a small army of ragtag soldiers that you recruit and hire from various places, or you can be bold and try almost immediately to begin taking over land yourself (which I wouldn't recommend for the first dozen or so hours into the game).  Battles in this game are nothing short of amazing. Both warring sides start out on opposite ends of the map (I've never seen the same battlefield twice, by the way, so I believe they are randomized based on the terrain type you are currently traversing). You can issue commands to your army, and this is fun to mess around with. For example, you can tell your archers to stand their ground and your cavalry to charge the enemy, while giving a different order to infantry. It's all up to you. By default, all units will charge, and for the most part, this is sufficient. You will then meet your enemy in the battlefield, where cavalry can run over infantry, archers can shoot riders off of horses, and you can kill horses while their riders are still living, making them fall face first into the ground before swarming them. Basically, if you've ever seen two opposing sides charge in a movie and have felt that intensity and awe, you can actually play as one of those people involved in Mount & Blade, and each and every time it's amazing. This game is fantastic for nerds like me who love anything medieval; not only are there full out battles like this, but you eventually (and your army) get strong enough to take over castles, towns, etc., and you get to be one of the units that is a part of this, each and every single time.  The goal regardless seems to be to take over the entire map of land, whether through an existing faction or through your own, which you may create once you have a strong enough army to begin taking over land by force. Lords will double cross you, downright insult you, and even beg their respective kings for the rights to a castle you may have taken over yourself, and depending on the circumstance, you may or may not be jipped out of a piece of land you worked hard for. You can then, however, decide to accept that or give a one fingered salute to your king before renouncing your allegiance and going your own way. It is entirely up to you.  I would highly, highly recommend you play as a woman character, even if you are not a woman in real life. The game is fantastic at reflecting the negative attitudes toward women at the time, and those mentalities can highly influence you during the game. For example, I created a woman character and named her after myself, much like I did for the first Mount and Blade. I set about leveling up my character and recruiting soldiers, and picked up a mercenary contract for a faction. After taking over three castles single-handedly for the faction's king, I spoke to the king, introduced myself, and asked to be promoted to being his vassal. He told me outright that he didn't care what I had accomplished. Because I was a woman, I could not be his vassal, and I couldn't own land. I asked him what would happen if I took an enemy castle by force, and he replied that he would 'think about' letting me keep it. This sexist attitude (although very realistic for the time) got me so fired up that I promptly cancelled my contract with the king and began taking over his land by force. After about 40 hours of in-game time, he was exiled from the land, his faction was extinct, and all of his land belonged to a new faction appropriately named 'Rosie's Kingdom of Awesome.' About 40 hours after that, I was Queen of Calradia. But it all started because of my motivation to overthrow an arrogant and sexist king as the woman he insulted, and no other game has done such a great job of inspiring me to create my own grudges and follow through on them until I conquered all.   This game is one of the most perfectly put together pieces of work I've ever played. I've seen people question the graphics, but I think the game is simplisticly beautiful (also, I grew up in the 90s--graphics don't matter to me). The game runs perfectly on my older non-gaming laptop, so that's also a plus for those of you looking for a large scale warfare game that can play on a toaster. There are some glitches, although nothing game-breaking (people spawned on the outside of a castle wall in 2/500 or so sieges I played, and I once had to sit out one siege because I fell through a crack in a floor of a castle tower and floated perpetually until my soldiers won the battle without me and I could exit). The character animations are a bit stiff, but I actually like them that way; it brings humor to the game for me, and if any future Mount & Blade doesn't have the stiff animations, I'll miss them.  Mount & Blade: Warband took 90 hours of my life away in the past week, and very few games can pull me in so relentlessly. This game is one of my personal favorites, along with Mount & Blade (I haven't tried With Fire & Sword yet, but it's only a matter of time). A solid 10/10 from me. Buy this game. Buy it now, and let it consume you. :)

10,000.000 is a very difficult game to discribe as it has multiple genres and elements into it, so it is hard to put be specifc in its genre, so apolagese for any confusion that may happen while you read this.  You are a person who appears to trapped in a prison or dungeon and must collect 10,000,000 (points I guess) to escape. However you can't just simply add on the points you have to constantly beat your score to win by not letting the left side of the wall catch up to you. There are also challenges to help you as well but completing them can be awfully obnoxious.  So the gameplay itself is a puzzle/RPG, you have to match tiles to either get resources for building new structres, attack enemies, use magic, get keys to unlock chests and doors and complete challenges to either earn more points or gain gold to make stronger items or train to gain new abilities.   I haven't completed the game myself because to be honest tile games don't interest me very much. This one though I have made an acception of playing either when I am waiting for something to download or just when I am in the mood for matching tiles. It is also something even your family could probably play and have interest in, but the only way that would happen is if we destroyed Facebook and all the other freegames on it! ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  To anyone who has read this please excuse any mistakes that you see in this post. I tend to struggle a fair bit on grammer. If there are any major mistakes please do let me know.

I typically enjoy Metroidvania games. But let me be perfectly clear here when I say that 'enjoy' does not describe how much I actually love this game. It has the perfect mix of platforming, combat, exploration, and RPG elements all woven into one great game with some beautiful artwork and soundtracks.   One of the best features in my opinion is the choice of 4 unique characters, all of which get their own unique playstyle and weapons. I find that this highly increases the diversity of the game because you'll find yourself able to approach each situation the game has to throw at you in different ways. Whether you prefer to focus on spellcasting, ranged combat, close range melee combat, or really want to hone in on lengthy combo's, this game has a character for you.  The customization of playstyle doesn't even stop there, as the RPG type levelling system allows you to pick skills from different skill trees, and level up in different stats to further customize that character to your own unique niche, which will be further complimented with the character exclusive weapons that you'll be able to pick up along the way and use from the getgo in your next playthrough.  The replayability factor is incredible, and the combat is fun meaning that I do not find it a chore to start a game fresh. Even on normal difficulty, you'll probably find yourself challenged in the same way that classic games did. Challenging enough to not be boring, but not so difficult that you'll want to fling the game across the room.   If by the sound of this review, you feel that this game suits your interests, I highly recommend that you pick it up. It will not disappoint.

Since this is an Indie game, and not a game from a High End compnay, Doctor Entertainment has Crap Servers.  Next, you get your one G, and realize this game will require Farming, great. More fighting Level 9s and Premiums.  Conquest mode would be the best for farming because of the amount of G you can get from Capturing Points alone, until you realize very, VERY few people play Conquest.  So after much more than just a few hours, you buy your Parts from the store, and now you can have fun killing the new players and having a fair fight against the High Levels, and a still unfair fight against Premiums.  In summary, This game is Pay to Play, Laggy, and requires a lot of farming...

A great 4X game all in all - Although you may want to hold off a bit if you're coming from it's predecessor, Galactic Civilizations 2. It is still a bit barebones in some areas like Diplomacy/Espionage but they seem committed to adding all of those features down the road as free content patches while expanding on existing mechanics through DLC and Expansions.  Is it fun? Yes, definitely.  Is it pretty? As pretty as you can expect a 4X to be - And then some.  Replayability? Oh yes - You can create your own races with unique traits and give them personalities so the AI will play them as you intended. The game also features a very robust Ship Designer tool, which lets you design your own ships from scratch. The sheer size of the larger maptypes means you can create games that will potentially last you for weeks - Not unlike that of Distant Worlds with up to (and potentially beyond) a hundred or more unique races provided your hardware is up to the task.  Campaign - In a 4X? I'm not entirely sold on this concept - While it works in some games better than others, it is definitely more of a lore introduction / tutorial campaign than a full on campaign as you would expect from a series like Heroes: Might and Magic, or Age of Empires. It's short but serves as a great springboard into the meat and potatoes of the game - Sandbox games.  On a final note - The developers are very active with the community, taking lots of feedback and suggestions from forum posts and livestream comments. These are definitely people who care about the genre and the game - It's not just about the bottom line.

At a glance, you could easily dismiss this game as another generic military shooter. It is and it isn't. The mission structure is by the books Call of Duty style: move forward, stop, kill a million enemies, move forward a bit and do the same. However, what elevates it above other military shooters is the story.  You're deployed to Dubai -- or what's left of it -- on a mission to locate survivors of a cataclysmic sandstorm. Simple enough, right? It would be, if not for the war raging within. As you explore the ruins of Dubai, questions are raised. How far is too far? Is the pursuit of your mission worth it, in spite of the casualties along the way?  If a thought-provoking story is of interest to you, I strongly recommend Spec Ops. On the other hand, if you are simply looking to kill people with abandon, you're best to look elsewhere. Whilst the shooting is solid, it can't carry the game and actually becomes tedious towards the end.

The master thief of the first Thief game is back and with somewhat improved graphics and new tools to play with. The story picks up some time after the first game and is packed with a new story and cast of enemies and allies, with familiar faces from the first game making a come-back. The game possesses significantly less 'adventure fantasy' elements than the first game although they are not entirely gone. This was actually the first game of the series I played and though its story is more or less able to stand alone, it is even better when you have played the first beforehand. Included in a relatively cheap bundle with the first game this game is a gem at a bargain of a price.

Waste of money.  90's graphics and 80's gameplay. Not the worst game I've bought on steam but definately that half of the scale. Save your money!  UPDATE : After the overwhelming posite reviews I thought I'd put a bit of effort in, thinking maybe I missed something. No, didn't miss much. I can positively absolutely confirm that this game IS A LOW QUALITY CRAP GAME!   Update 2: After trying to play this crap again for over an hour.  Here is a grown up point of view. The graphics are horrible. A 12 year old could draw better grahics. A circle, box and 4 lines is the main character.   O [ ]--   | \ Most of the enemies are stick figures or bouncing circles of different colors.  Gameplay is near pointless and resembles that of the 80's arcade. Same thing endlessly! Randomly generated rooms with random doorways. You can't aim properly, and minor obstacles stop you in your tracks and often prevent you from obtaining the keys etc. This leads to many times being unable to continue as until you kill all the circles, squares of squiggly lines and get the key you can't move on in some rooms. The music is just annoying and after a very short time will be turned off. The sound effects are definately low tech and appear to be an after thought Many time you end up with nowhere to go so you have to start again like I've stated and the boss levels are ridiculously hard and make no sense. Shoot them 50 times they shooot you twice. Your dead! The younger players seem to like it as the endless reviews like 'Awsome game', 'Really Fun', 'Best game ever' 'Funnest game' etc showing that it does have a place for children or those children at heart. Hmmmm! If you are over 12, and want a little bit of intellectual game play then AVOID THIS! IF YOU ARE 12 or less age wise or have the mentality of herpies and are looking for a button masher, random generated 80's style, poorly executed, dungeon game that requires just simply randomly walking around shooting circles or triangle or stick figures then BUY THIS GAME or get your mummy and daddy to buy it for you! Its cheap for a reason! If you do like the 80 style monotonous type games then there is far better games than this, and far better value.

A very fun game, but don't enter into it without some knowledge of the style of FPS that this game is. The casing/stealth, and loud styles of play are very different. Playing with people you know that are careful and methodical to play through a mission loaded lightly and stealthily to get the big pay off without firing a shot is immensely rewarding, but it really is difficult to do with random internet partners. Loading heavy for a firefight is fun also, and it is what you'll get the majority of games.  The rank up mechanic is a bit strange, as you need to play to earn both XP and money, but the real value of playing is to get cards which enable you to buy further weapon mods. An unmodified gun is not half as good as one loaded up with goodies, whether you go loud or quiet.  Keep with it though, its a fun game at a great price point, with lots of replayability.

Well well well. This game in short is Ace of Spades revived with a big focus on gameplay along the lines of Counter Strike 1.6 and Half Life 1 Multiplayer. It really is great fun and the graphics kind of give it a charm that makes it feel like it comes straight out of 1998 or something. The block based levels are great, giving you tons of ways to play a match for example literally pumping a 100 bullet mag into a wall just so other people don't have the cover of said wall anymore. Of course you can also place blocks yourself, building small walls to crouch behind when you reload.  Basicly if you like Counter Strike-ish games with a little twist this sure is a game to pick up, especially now when its on sale.  And the editor where you can make maps, skins for your weapons and for your characters is  amazing . Easy to use for everyone and so many options to be creative with. I bet this is where most people will spend their time.

app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: This game is clearly the best Metal Gear Solid title in the series from a gameplay perspective.  You are given countless ways to approach a situation with a great degree of control, and this makes for some truly memorable moments. However I feel that the story has suffered under the wheels of the Hype train. The game clearly is unfinished, with huge sections of story missing. Big boss throughout the entire game channels Gordon Freeman more than the cocky Jack we met in Operation Snake Eater. Other characters are either underused or underdeveloped.  On top of that, the ending twist while interesting leaves much to be desired and creates more questions than answers.   Overall great gameplay but a disappointing story.
