Edit (2016) They have sold a 'complete edition' when there is more content on the way, so you can pay once for the game with the season pass, pay again for the content that doesn't come in the season pass, then pay one more time for more content not included to be released. To hell with this game.   Edit (4/25/2015) : They added a few new cars and some specs, fixed some bugs and managed to improve the main menu with a slideshow and the online matchmaking with a merge-all lobby system. Perhaps it's enough of a change for you to enjoy this game? Me, I checked and played the 'new' content for a few hours and unninstalled it again, personally I can't find any improvement worth a buyback into this game since my gripe is the terrible driving mechanics alongside the bad physics. I remain true to every word I wrote in this review.   I had high hopes for this game, I played the betas, followed the forums and pre-ordered it. Then I forced myself to like it and play it even after I was completely frustrated by everything I'm about to say.  I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME AT IT'S CURRENT STATE AND/OR PRICE TAG.  Before the ugly : THE CREW is not a complete mess, there is the possibility of having a great amount of fun playing this game depending on what kinda of player you are. One thing it gets right is the map diversion. Every spot, every city or zone as they say, has it's own feeling and design, it's unique, and driving around the map with a friend is sure entertaining. but that's it. if you're not the person who enjoys cross country trips or american cars, there is not much for you here.   Entitled as 'MMO CAR-PG' but you can't develop your character, not a single aspect. In theory, every player has the same exact character, solution? Let's hide other player's driver. and that's it. Let's say you play against remote controlled cars, for immersion's sake. you CAN'T call it an mmo, without character development, the best you'll get are perks, nothing really groundbreaking. but we have cars, don't we?  There are 30~40 cars and all of them seem unfinished, except for the first ones. because you know, 'first impressions are always the most important'. the first five cars have all the specs available, street, dirt, performance, raid and circuit. other cars usually have 2~3 specs only. so you wanna go crazy off road with that expensive car? too bad. also, most cars are American, so no luxury here. what's most stupid is the unbalanced performance cars have, the starter vehicles run faster then the most expensive car in the game.   But driving gets better as your car and player level increases, right? No. That's an excuse for the handling in the game. It doesn't get better. I have 1299 ( Max level ) cars and with assistance off, they just don't grip on the road as the default low level mustang does. With assistance on, it's just 'drifting'. The crew should have stayed as a street racing game only, the street tracks are okay, the handling on street is OK. but when it goes off-road becomes soap ( and not in a good 'Dirt game' way of soap ), on circuit the game just doesn't have enough decent physics to feel solid, and while climbing mountains with raid spec... I wish you good luck trying not to roll 900º in the air after hitting that small rock. this game is unpredictable thanks to it's physics, you never know how is your car going to react to crashes so expect for the worst and try avoiding collisions. worth adding : some elements break, some doesn't, and in this game this is not okay because when someone tries to cut their way trough some houses, the fences breaks. When you're doing the turn on a corner, well, the fence it very likely to be the most solid virtual object you'll ever find.   Progression is BROKEN, I had to try various missions at least three times due to disconnects that WIPED my progress, my statistics are currently like this ' main missions complete : 167% ', and the rewards are ridiculously unbalanced. Let me explain this : I leveled from 1 to 50 in ONE DAY AND A HALF doing no more than 60 PvP matches, 10 or so story missions and some exploration. Yes, I reached maxed level on an MMO in basically a day. It gets better, I was being rewarded 16k bucks every time I finished first on a PvP match, and when you are disqualified because you couldn't get to the finish line in time, well, TAKE THESE 16K BUCKS ANYWAY. You just know they didn't really put any thought into the game's progression when all it takes from level 49 to 50 is 2 races in 10 minutes.   The customization feels incomplete, some categories are there with no parts to purchase for you car, get used to the 'No part available in this category' message. the stickers are single color only and there isn't variety among those, expect to see everyone using the same 2 flame stickers or racing stripes. the real car performance parts are available with a grind of challenges after level 50 which is not very cool given the insane difficulty of some challenges, but don't worry, it doesn't matter how fast your car is... AI CHEATS, it goes off track and spawns in front of you, It rams you constantly and the Catch-up is ridiculous. there are some gifs on Polygon's review of the crew if your interested.   The story is not good, you bounce trough one generic dialog to the next and I couldn't connect to any character of this game, I couldn't care less to be honest and not skipping cutscenes was a challenge at times. At the end of the main story you are rewarded with a mix of every CGI they made for the game, which felt very very lazy.  And I could go on, there is the server instability problem, the always online 'DRM', the NAT problem that causes online atrocities, the lack of mirrors promised by launch, no weather system, the 'crew joining different lobbies' bug, the 'Hitting someone back at 20mp/h and flying like when hit by a giant on skyrim' bug, the 'I regret the money I spent buying this game' case and the first time I actually emailed steam support to ask about their refund policy.   I'm frustrated. I just wish I could go back to those TDU2 Times.   tl;dr  + Every area is unique and has it's own feeling. + Driving with friends can be fun  Edit (4/25/2015) : - A 2014 Racing game Lacking mirrors, promised by launch - Server instability, constant disconnections and progress Wipes - AI CHEATS - Incomplete customization ( Specs were added ) - Not a great amount of cars ( Cars were added )  - Unbalanced car performances - Terrible car handling - Physics make for an unpredictable game - Broken progression system - Broken statistics system - Unbalanced reward system - Outdated graphics ( They fixed DoF at some camera angles ) - Fake car engines - No photo mode - Cliche, generic storyline - Only 7 players on Screen - Season Pass could have been part of the game  - TERRIBLE Online pvp lobby system ( Now fixed )
It's like watching The Miracle of Life over and over and over again! Please play this game.

Middle-earth™: Shadow of Mordor™ is not a game i would normally buy or play. The reviews compared it to the Batman Arkam games and they never appealed so why did i buy this title. Honestly no idea. I think i got it for 50% of during the steam holiday sale but my opinion now would be even at full price this game would be worth the money. The game runs smooth, the action can be breathtaking. The scenery can be a bit samey after a while but half way through it opens up anew area which is a tad greener :) There's a mission you can play early on where you go to one of the strongholds and you have to defeat 100 uruks, when i first tried this i got pumped big time but a few unlocks later and you look forward to those battles with relish. My biggest worry was the controls, as i'm getting on a bit now (middle aged is the term) I honestly can't be bothered with learning multiple button presses combined to create a certain type of attack or defense. Fortunatly the game glides you in gently meaning it's pretty basic early on and it's only as the game progresses that you have these additional features where a press of E here or R there pulles of some amazing manouver. I'm now over 30 hours in and about 70% through the game and i'm dreading the fact i'm closing in on the end. I can only say i highly recommend this, it's fun it's enthralling and it's worth the money.

Better than Mass Effect 1. I am probaly one of the nine people in the world who think so but seriously, I don't have any idea to as why people like the original more! I know everybody claims ME2 isn't an RPG but it is really just as much of an RPG as the first one, with a few exceptions. Sure, they dumbed down a few things but there is still complete exploration, a decent amount of side quests and a leveling system.   The characters in this game are far superior than the ones that occupied the first. I was happy to see Tali and Garrus come back for those were easily my favorites. Wrex was killed off in my first game so I didn't end up meeting back up with him. Just everything about the new supporting cast was great and I didn't find any of them to be bland or boring, except maybe Legion, who shows up later and the game and doesn't have much time for character development.   The final moments in this game are some of the most epic ♥♥♥♥ I have ever laid my eyes upon. So many different outcomes, everyone on my squad survived the final battle so I am not sure how great the other endings are. I can honestly say I will be replaying this series more than once.

As far as story driven FPS games go Call of Juares is as good as they get. This is a game that essentially is a story and at times feels like its many stories at the same time. It’s got very solid gunplay, the art style and westerns setting are very well done. An interesting take on bullet time adds another layer to the game play and the nuggets of truth are  In fact western lore - a very nice touch that adds a little bit of depth to the characters. So as you might have figured, a lot of positives going for the game.  On the downside, the lack of different weapons is a shame. Basically you have a few types of revolvers, a few shotguns and a few rifles. All of the guns feel nice and make a nice sound but within each category the weapons feel pretty much the same. So essentially you only really have like 3 weapons.  As far as the story goes - it’s a guns blazing western fantasy. A fun story but nothing to write home about. The way it's presented though is really great.  The game took about 12,5 h to complete on hard and there are still challenge modes to go through and duels to have. The duel mode is also a nice addition to the game but I can say I did not have as much fun with it as I thought I would.  'A' for effort though.  All in all, a very solid and fun FPS game with a cool story and setting. 8/10

I'm not here to make a long proffesional-looking review, because I am certainly not qualified for that! But, I would just like to say, that this is an awesome game!  It has everything a good zombie survival game needs; big maps, scarce supplies, great atmosphere, a tinge of realism, and most importantly: lots and lots of zombies posing a great threat to anyone who comes unprepared!  It has many similarities with Left 4 Dead (scavange for supplies, fight zombies, and escape), and yet it's so much different. One could argue that this is better in terms of realism, and required skill, but I'd say it depends on what you're looking for in a zombie survival game.  If you want a fast-paced, action-packed, that gives you a sense of victory and greatness: it's Left 4 Dead. But if want a game that gives you a sense of desperation and actual hopelsessness: it's this. In other words: Left 4 Dead is like Resident Evil (without Umbrella and it's dodgy shenanigans), while No More Room In Hell is like a gool 'ol zombie horror movie (or The Walking Dead).
is very good game but i think game need coop For more fun

Even if you have played the original Five Nights At Freddy's and know the AI inside and out, and aren't scared of that game at all anymore, YOU WILL STILL LOVE the sequel. It has a familiar feel to the original, but with some new mechanics, more animatronics, more variables, more chaos, more micromanagement. It feels fresh, new, and absolutely terrifying. The wind-up music box and the empty Freddy head are really scary new mechanics that push and pull you in different directions so you're never comfortable, never safe. This is a must-buy if you got the first game.

This game so far has been very enjoyable to play. Normally I'm not a fan of games that have a lot of grinding required but this one so far has been pretty enjoyable. It has had a rough start so far but IMC is doing what they can to make improvements and has been listening to it's player base and trying to make decisions accordingly.  The trade system is very restrictive at present, but IMC is considering options to alleviate that and make trade a little more open. The current overly restrictive system came about due to efforts to hinder RMT bots/groups. We will have to wait and see what IMC plans to do.  The class system is interesting and IMC has made some interesting decisions with some of these classes. Overall this game has great potential but it will take input and some dedication from the player base to help guide IMC and truly make this game shine.

As another reviewer pointed out, If you look at the global gameplay stats, it becomes clear very few people have played this one beyond the first section. Before looking at this I had the insane idea of trying to complete the time trials, get the hidden object and collect all the stars in each stage. The time trial times are completely unforgiving and after the 10th or 11th level the tedium made me want to stop completely and just play the levels without getting anything. But at that point the frustration had set in and every new level made me think, who in their right minds would bother will all this?  The level of precision needed to even complete some levels (specifically, bouncing and snapping up the item just after you've bounced) finally did me in. Games this difficult need to give you a reason to continue, more than the vainglory of proving to the world that you could 100% Snapshot. As far as I could tell, collecting stars, pictures of the special items in each level, and completing the time trials gives you nothing. We are not living in the days of the NES where money and game options are limited. When frustration and overwhelmedness are the core emotions a game provokes, it is time to put your pride in your knapsack and move on to the next world with the dream that somewhere out there love awaits. Left swipe this one.

If you like games such as L.A Noire and Sherlock Holmes this should be right up your alley. It is different from those games though, because this is you solving your own crime. That means your a ghost, wandering around the town looking for clues. I would say this is a very unique game, and that's rare these days.  Gameplay wise it's simple, look around for clues, draw a conclusion and go to the next place. it's very interesting because you are a ghost and you can simply walk through walls. However you cant go through solid buildings, unless someone opens the door for you. You can also use abillities like poltergeist, mind control and even take over a cat.   This game is extremely story heavy, and the story is really intresting. It kept me coming back until I was done. Even the simple sidequests really intrigued me and made me want to collect every little collectible I could find.  About 1,5 hour of the game is cutscenes and the others are gameplay. It's not that long of a game, but I would actually say this was the perfect lenght. It didn't overstay its welcome and drag out for to long. The story was exciting all the way through, and you could never figure out who it was until the end.   A lot of plot twists in this game, which reminded me of Heavy Rain. The story is great thanks to impressive cutscenes and good voice acting. Any downsides with this game? Only that the demons and the elements were quite repetitive, but that isn't that big of a complaint since the game didn't go on for that long, and I can clearly see that they put the work on cutscenes and story instead.   I really enjoyed my time in this dark and gritty town. This is a game that everyone should play at some point in my honest opinion, it's that damn good. I really hope they will make a sequel or something along those lines.

app_name: Valiant Hearts: The Great War™ / Soldats Inconnus : Mémoires de la Grande Guerre™
review_text: Valiant Hearts is a powerful story about how four peoples' lives are affected by The Great War. It is so rare to see coverage of the First World War, and it is especially appropriate given that nearly 100 years ago, the war was started.  First, some nuts-and-bolts: the game uses Uplay. I am sorry if this is a negative to you, but it is how it works. The game also have full controller support (at least for the XBox360 controller), which doesn't seem to be listed anywhere. The prompts are also in XBox360.  The characters are all fairly likeable, omitting some spoilers. Emile, an older gentlemen pressed into service, is most certainly NOT a soldier at the beginning of the game - and it shows. Freddie seems to be the game's action hero, who is getting called into battle and 'saves the day' for however long the war will let him. Anna is a nurse who seems to be able to solve any problem, no matter the cost. Karl is the unfortunate resident drafted by the German army, interrupting his family life. Finally, there is Walt, who you discover shortly into the game and will help you solve many puzzles - and loves to be petted!  Freddie seems to be a little on the weak side out of the cast. His story makes sense, but the game doesn't go into much detail on the reasons he's in the war. A lot of the focus is (rightfully) given on Karl's problem, to make the war seem real. Anna and Emile definitely round out the main cast extremely well, and I definitely appreciated the little animations when Anna does her thing on the battlefield. Walt, the dog, is understandably thin on character. He's mostly there to drive the game along, because many puzzles require his use. He does get a moment or two very late in the game, however.  Mechanically, the game is very fluid. I encountered no bugs nor crashes. 'War' scenes play out similarly to a side-scroller, dodging machine gun fire and bombs/mortars. 'Puzzle' scenes take place in a limited area, where you have to manipulate the environment using levers, wheels, platforms, or throw items to activate things. The 'war' scenes definitely fit in with the plot, as the first few I was thinking 'Wow, this is war' to 'Wow, this is horrible!' along with the plot. There are a couple of 'Boss' fights as well, with a villain created for the story. These scenes are timed and play out like a 'puzzle' scene. Dying at any point in the game, whether on the field, to a boss, or failing a puzzle, just respawns you at the previous checkpoint. It does break immersion somewhat, however it minimizes the frustration, as you don't tend to respawn all that far from whatever killed you. The one thing that kept annoying me was having to hold the button to activate wheels and levers, and sometimes the wheel turning was a little slower than I anticipated.  Graphically, the game is fantastic, looking much like a comic strip using UbiArt. You can see other soldiers racing into battle during the 'war' scenes behind the main line and their untimely fates... Sometimes objects required for puzzles DO get hidden, like background objects, but there is always a way to solve the puzzle by experimenting. The music and the sound were also great, never taking away from the feel of the game.  Difficulty-wise, the game isn't too hard. Death is resolved by the nearest checkpoint, and some puzzles do allow some room for error. Each character has different puzzle types, with Emile digging, Anna saving people, and Karl doing some trading. There are also a couple of scenes of your car dodging incoming (and oncoming!) obstacles. Anna's puzzles are mostly rhythm-based, and are pretty forgiving with their button prompts. It is unfortunate that your attention is at the top of the screen, rather than on the actions she's taking. A couple of puzzles were tricky, but like all good adventure games, you tend to go 'Ah, I should have though of that!'. Hints are available, 1 minute at a time, however I only had to use hints two or three times at all.  There isn't that much replay, unfortunately. There are 100 collectibles to find throughout the chapters, but each collectible has a bit of a historical remark, such as soldier Dog Tags or Gas Masks. There are also some historical notes on events, such as POW Camps and important battles, along with links to MISSION CENTENAIRE 14-18 and Apocalypse: 10 Lives (both what I assume to be coverage of World War 1). The game does flow with the events of World War 1 for the most part, however it does not show the war's resolution (which is probably outside the scope of the game?). But I definitely got a sense of the impact of the war, even if it is only limited to the France-Germany border.  Overall, the game is beautifully done and I WANTED to finish it and resolve the story. My playtime is about 6 hours for a first playthrough, without finding all the collectibles (maybe around 70% found). The message at the end is very powerful and shows, with great respect, the impact of the people of the war. It is a bittersweet game, where you will laugh at the silly stuff but MAYBE cry at the sad things (the ending was what really got me). I would ABSOLUTELY recommend this game.

Seems kind of decent but the clunky interface pushes me away. Customization optons seem broad but shallow, of the 'here are 50 different +1s' style. The game is front-loaded with annoyances like learning an interface that is slightly off in every way, being offered city positions where you cannot build any buildings, and dealing with wandering monsters vastly stronger than your starting troops. Other reviews suggest that it blossoms in the mid/late game once you get used to all that, then becomes tedious in a drawn-out endgame or with trivial difficulty once you master the options, so I do not feel compelled to get over the initial hurdle.  'Hard to learn, easy to master' is not a good design goal.

'Of course I was drinking. You try to spend five minutes in there sober.'   The adventures of a deadbeat drunk pill addict that only a Rockstar game could tell. Meet Max: A man whose heart was hacked out with a rusty syringe and the wound cauterized with gun powder and whiskey. Only seen holding a gun or a bottle. Max would've put a bullet through his own skull if he wasn't so good at greasing bad guys all over the walls. Suicidal boat rides, condemned buildings, scum-infested ghettos: It's all the same to Max, like picking off a scab and scratching until its numb.  There is no substitute for the dark, bitter grit that is Max Payne.

review_text: Star Wars Knights of the old Republic II, to me, seemed like an awful game compared to the first one, but after going back and playing it again now in 2016, I now see how wrong I was. Kotor 1 still remains superior to the second, but it was pretty close.   If you haven't played the first kotor, please play it before purchasing this game, everything will make so much more sense.  If you decide to buy this game, I highly suggest downloading this mod  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=485537937&searchtext=   This is a restoration mod to add things to the game that originally were supposed to be there, but were cut due to a deadline for the games release. You can download this mod off the steam workshop, so don't worry all of you people who don't like downloading off sketchy mod websites.

Very sad. Developer's got too arrogant with their own ideals of what this game should be and therefore lost what made the game special in the first place. Thief & Thief 2 graphics may not hold up but the games are certainly allot better than this. Dishonored is by far the better game to come out of this lineage.  Complaints: third person takedowns and climbing, very limited floor types and non existent sound travel for footsteps, incredibly small level design and hub map, lack of the original voice actor who is far superior as Garrett and a terrible combat system.  This game may have been saved by taking the Thief developers and water boarding them until they understood what gamers mean with the word 'immersion'. All of the above compliants take the player out of his experience as Garrett.  You could of made a better game by re-release the orignals Thief games with new textures and lighting.  A sad day for a sacred franchise of PC gaming.

This game is a follow up to Post Mortem, and introduces a second playable storyline involving FBI agent Victoria McPherson. She is investigating a string of grisly murders in Chicago and this ties in to a case her grandfather, Gustav 'Gus' McPherson worked whilst in 1920s Prague.   It is a simple point-and-click type game that involve some rather puzzling puzzles to be solved along the way. The story itself is reasonably interesting, but the character development and voice acting are somewhat lacking. The ending seems to raise more questions than it gives answers, but it is, on the whole, an enjoyable game to play. The soundtrack/score by Tom Salta is particularly well-crafted, working brilliantly to convey the atmosphere of a scene.

This is the zombie apocalypse game that I always wished existed. I LOVE 'anyone can die' type games. And for the first two weeks or so, anyone could and DID die. The country bumpkin deputy fell first...the trucker mom and I had to abandon him as we ran for our lives from a hardware store.  Then the IT nerd and the trucker mom's daughter were killed at the national park when we tried to split up to survive a horde.  Then the trucker mom and the tough cop got caught in the middle of a shootout between rival gangs. Between the gunfire and the zombies that were attracted to it, it became a blood bath. In addition to the trucker mom and the tough cop dying, the flight attendant with PTSD got bit. She killed herself that night.  Then the televangelist got jumped...there was no way for us to get to him in time.   Finally, there was nobody left except myself and a young naive farmer girl. We were doomed.  Until we stumbled onto the scene of a car wreck, where a gay former Army Ranger agreed to join our group. That was the turning point. Once he was on my team, things got much easier. We still lost the occasional member from time to time, including one of my survivors murdering another one, but all in all we grew to about 30-40 survivors - each with a unique skill set, backstory, All along the way, I was making hard decisions that affected the rest of the group. I did eventually lead the team to safety, and it definitely felt earned.  I will make one complaint, and it's one you don't hear a lot: This game takes FOREVER to beat. A ridiculously long time. I'd say the first 50% was a real nail-biter where I was loving every second of it. Then the next 20% I was starting to feel a little OP, but still liking the game. Then the last 30% becomes 'JESUS CHRIST WHEN DOES THIS GAME END???'  It gets very repetitive in the last 20-30 hours or so, and every single battle...regardless of whether it's zombie hordes or major human 'bosses', becomes a cakewalk.   But even with that pacing complaint, this is still a phenomenal game and I highly recommend it for anyone who likes the feeling of the lives and deaths of dozens and dozens of characters depending on you for survival.

Fans of this classic Microsoft game will appreciate the new Extended Edition. It includes many graphical updates which makes the game much more playable than the older version, and it also includes the amazing Titans expansion which adds unique gameplay elements. The campaign has a nice plot and varied settings to keep you hooked, and there are plenty of interesting unit types not seen in other RTS games. Local multiplayer is extremely fun and a total blast from the past. I recommend picking this game up if you have fond memories of the original, or if you are just looking for a good RTS game to play with some buddies.
Pretty fun game when your bored but buy it when its on sale.

A hardcore clicker, very challenging for you have to keep your rythm at over 180cpm constantly from the start to the finish with tiny breaks for simple secondary tasks (with WASD) or while the levels load - yep, no saves, no pauses, levels start instantly, a small mistake in timing and you start from the very beginning. No feeling of satisfaction when your character shoots his fireworks - just a 2 second break to take a deep breath before the new run. This gameplay idea is original among others in the genre, but the design feels so ugly.. I know the South Park stupidity style suits the concept, still even in these boundaries you can do much better. The main compliant is the monotony of the process - the random interfering encounters and funny achievements get old very quickly, the need to start it all over for the 100th time is barely justified.  Сложная щелкалка, бросает вызов в том плане, что нужно поддерживать ритм свыше 180 щелчков в минуту от начала до конца (хе-хе) с перерывчиками на простые побочные задания (при помощи WASD), либо на загрузку уровней - да, никаких сохранений, пауз, уровни стартуют мгновенно, малейшая неточность по времени нажатия и начинай по новой. Нет чувства удовлетворения от салютов главного героя - лишь 2-хсекундный перерыв, чтобы вздохнуть перед очередным забегом. Идея довольно оригинальна среди собратьев по жанру, но дизайн крайне уродлив... Понятно, что глуповатость Южного парка подходит для этой концепции, но и в этих рамках можно сделать много лучше. Основная претензия к монотонности происходящего - случайные вмешательства и забавные достижения быстро приедаются, и необходимость в 100й раз начинать снова ничем не оправдана.

Did you like AC 4: Black Flag? Well, I have good news for you: basically, this game is a improved version of BF.    A different perspective of the gameplay and storyline. You play as a Templar and it influences gameplay as well (for example, instead of assassination contracts, where you had to kill one target, there is assassination interceptions when you do the opposite, which feels really refreshing).    Instead of dull and boring Edward Kenway, we have Shay Cormac - harismatic and deep character that has more morality than his 'predecessor'.     Instead of mainstream caribbean, we have North Atlantic sea with it's icebergs and snowy forests. Love it.    Naval combat was also improved - Shay's ship has now mechanical gatling cannons and burning oil barrels.    Beautiful music.  Even though I enjoy this game a lot, I would reccomend buying it when it's -25% or more off the original price.

Turn based combat system? Yes please!  One thing I appreciate about the game is that so far I haven't encountered any battles that felt repetitive. The maps, the environments, interactive elements on the maps (starting fires ftw!), and the variety of opponents have kept it fresh so far. Of course I need to state that I'm only on Chapter 2 at this point, so maybe that changes. Some battles have been easy enough, others have been challenging. There's been a few battles that I've had to retry but it's been a fun challenge, not a drain on my enjoyment of the game.  So far, I'm loving this game and have been looking forward to playing it as time permits. I started over 6 hours into the game to switch from a basic character to an expert (custom) character. Having become more familiar with the game, I wanted to be able to customize my character more. I'm 20+ hours into this game and I'm still enjoying it which is a positive sign!

This game is one of the greatest I've ever played. That's not an easy thing for me to say. Everything about this game is unique. It gets a perfect score in my book. Also, it has the all time greatest boss fight at the end of the game, hands down. I love this game to death.  The gameplay is the best part of this game, the game can twist and turn any which way when your progress is lead by pure luck. The way the card system works is very simple and easy to wrap your mind around. The combat is excellent and fluid, it's awesome to watch. The combat isn't just hacking and slashing, it's about timing blocks and dodging opponents you can't fight all at once. The combat is reminscent to the first Fable, in fact, much of this game really is a Fable game without the brand name, but the combat is so much more interesting here than in any Fable.  The graphics are lush and colourful. It has that wonderful atmospheric fantasy mood that Fable set so perfectly.  The sound quality is top notch for the most part. There is a few times when the sound does cut out but a simple restart fixes that immediately. The soundtrack is awesome and really has an epic vibe to it. I was even thinking of buying it if it's sold on Steam. It's one of those soundtracks that'll take me back years from now. I love the clanging of the swords and the thumping of swords against shields. The voice actor behind the Dealer is on the same level of deep and mesmerizing as Morgan Freeman. He's like an English Morgan Freeman, I can't stress enough how good of a voice actor he is.  The story line is interesting, it's not a normal storyline. You enter at the end of the adventurer's story. This is a retelling of all his adventures. So it's a game about retrospective and reflection. The Dealer makes very interesting remarks and ponderings that make me think on a philosophical level. What kind of game does that?  I love a game that I can put hundreds and hundreds of hours into. A game that has endless replayability and isn't limited by just having a storyline. This is one of those games. It doesn't ever have to end. There's an endless mode. There's also 200+ cards to collect. Each card is an encounter. Every game randomizes these encounters and even throws in some that benefit you and some that debilitate you to a certain extent. This game definitely earns its pay and has lot of bang for very little buck.  If you're on the fence about getting it, don't be. This game isn't hard to fall in love with. I'd recommend this game to absolutely anyone.

I'll keep this short. I loved this game. It was enjoyable, despite some small control issues. You had to approach each room like a puzzle, but could be creative on how you use your skills. A few parts of the game were unintuitive, but even then they were beaten once you really took in your surroundings.  Then you make it to the final level. It's the steaming pile to cap off an otherwise good game. No checkpoints, enemies every two feet, and a unique mechanic that doesn't add much to the game, at least for me. I've looked around, and many people have begged the developer to add checkpoints, and that the final level destroys what was an otherwise enjoyable game, but those pleas have fallen on deaf ears.  It's a shame, because I liked the game, but the final level ruins the whole experience.

So much better than I expected. The story keeps building and building. Really scary at times, thanks to brilliant sound production (just because the pixels are lo def doesn't mean the sound has to be!) and an amazing soundtrack that hits all the right notes, sometimes brooding, waxing to a climax, or even silent. The soundtrack uses strings as its backbone. It's pretty to listen too, and lends the affair a cinematic scope. Use headphones!! Fantastic story, very addictive with a lot of cliffhangers to keep you going. The puzzles are simple and won't bog you down, but are fun to uncover. Love this game <3

app_name: Valiant Hearts: The Great War™ / Soldats Inconnus : Mémoires de la Grande Guerre™
review_text: This is one of the most original war games available. None of the playable characters ever wields a gun. It's all about puzzles and figuring out how to survive the war, rather than win it. The animation has a unique charm and fits well with the game's tone. The characters are all very likable; the sympathy the player feels for them amplifies this game's effective communication of the horror of the Great War and makes it conclusion all the more heartbreaking.
Played it on the PS4 and have had as much fun with it there as I do here. It's a pretty good buy.

app_name: Injustice: Gods Among Us Ultimate Edition
review_text: If you like DC Comics and fighting games, this game is worth picking up. Comes with all DLC to date (and I'm pretty sure there isn't going to be anymore).  If you don't want to fight other people online, there is a full story mode to go through with a DC Comics quality story (which is to say, there is an alternate universe, so nothing really matters). There is also STAR Labs, which is similar to the challenge tower from Mortal Kombat (2011). However all the rewards that come from doing STAR Labs are automatically unlocked already in the Ultimate Edition, so there isn't a whole lot of point to play it, since it can become quite frustrating and doesn't really have much to do with the main fighting game.  The hype has died down for this game, but there are still people that play it both online and offline, but there seem to be issues with the online. The netcode is not good, by any means. It can be bearable, or it can be 5 seconds of input lag, followed by frame drops, followed by losing connection to your opponent. The game is no longer region locked, however playing against someone on the otherside of the world is not going to go very well.  The game has gone through some significant balance reworks, so a lot of characters are now viable, but the game is very zoner dominated, so if you prefer fighters that are all about getting in your opponents face, you should probably give Injustice a miss.  Overall, if you're already a fighting game enthusiast, you have no doubt played many games that are better than Injustice that you should stick to. But if you are new to fighting games, or just a DC fan, then Injustice is very worth picking up, combos are a lot easier to do than in other fighting games since they are less time restrictive. Blocking is simplified; hold back to standing block in one direction, hold down to crouching block in both directions. Forward and backward throws can be broken with the same button. All characters share some attack moves, such as uppercuts, sweeps and bounces. All characters have a character power, which is a gimmick that can be used to help you play that character better.

I have played this game since I was first introduced to it by jingles. (Jan, 5 2013) When i first started playing i was in love. It was the only thing I ever did all day. The thought of getting to jet drove me to play for 14 hours at a time. The game was great. Then the updates started to come... At first it was just harder to make money and xp. People hated it but I kind of liked it. Then the BR system came and balance left. Matchmaking had trouble getting fair matches but even that wasnt so bad. Then the russian bias got real. Im not one of those people that complain that I died to X russian plane/tank but after seeing russian tanks and planes survive things that would destroy any other tank it got annoying. (planes putting out fires, t-34s bouncing tiger 2 shots in the side, ext) But even this wasnt what made me quit this game. It's the company. They are absolutly terrible. Constantly censoring anyone with an opinion than dosent match theirs. They threaten to ruin RB if we dont let them attack youtubers that help them by finding cheaters? And even steam isn't safe. They constantly have people downvote any review that is negative. I can forgive russian bias. I can forgive the terrible BR system. I cannot forgive this company for the way they treat their community. To Anton Yudintsev, you made a game that was amazing. I loved it so much and always will. But what you have become as a company will destroy you in the end. Listen to the community, let them help you make the game better. If you do that, this game has a chance to rise back up into greatness.

Rough round the edges, and poorly optimised (as of writing), the game is a bit difficult to recommend, but I'm recommending it regardless for the following reasons:    The game runs reasonable fine on 1440p for me, albeit slowdowns during lightning effects against hordes of enemies    Visually, the game is great, some of the lighting, shadows and volumetric fog is well done, and the player models 'look' and 'feel' like Warhammer 40k    The atmosphere is pretty well captured, it feels dark, grim, wondrous, scary    The voice work is good, it adds to the game's atmosphere    It plays well both on keyboard / mouse and controller (I almost prefer the latter in this game)   There are however a couple of things that won't make the game 'perfect' just yet:    The game is badly optimised in anything but 1080p    Finding relics only really help you with filling up the relics list in increasing your willpower marginally, but you cannot actually use them    Occasionally, tooltips, hints or key press indicators (around doors, relics or buttons) are missing, so just press 'use' on everything you see for now.    Obviously, I am not done with the game yet (only just finished chapter 2), but what I have played so far makes me want to play more and come back to it. I do hope that at least he performance issues are being resolved soon, as I would love to give the game a spin on 4k.

I saw this game on sale at a somewhat random occasion on the store, and was at first quite interested in the concept.  This, however, turned out to be a very underwhelming experience, and the first genuinely BAD vr experience I've had overall.  So let's start from the top, with a simple question: does this game deliver on its promises, ALL of its promises ?  The short answer is no. Now for the long answer.  Apollo 11 VR sells itself as 'a new type of documentary', but a documentary it is not. What it is, is a short, undercooked project with no genuine lasting impact, and very little short term fun or entertainment to be had. There is relatively little in the ways of information or factoids to be learned here, save for a fairly inelegant info dump in one of the later scenes. The 'mix of original archive audio and video' is used in a rather unpleasant way as well - rather than here to complement visuals and audio, it feels closer to a tacky attempt at simulating historical fidelity, and it gets old very quick.  Another issue comes in the form of very limited interaction. The store page mentions several critical sections of the game being interactive, and well, it isn't lying - you CAN take control of the command modules, the lunar lander and explore the moon's surface, but it is extremely limited. Perhaps the comparison is a bit harsh to make, but I expected from those sequences something akin to a simplified Kerbal Space Program, and it is in some aspects - but there is so little to do, in such small capacity, that one has to wonder if there even is a point to putting this here to begin with.  The issue of visual fidelity also needs to be addressed. Apollo 11 VR goes for the laziest, most basic direction possible in terms of graphics, and persists on being just kind of mediocre graphically. It doesn't take a lot of trickery to make even average assets on an accessible engine look stunning and this application tries to utilize none of them, which is made worse by the fairly immersion breaking oddities one may come across, such as spinning lense flares or the lifeless eyes of the few human models one gets to see.  The most drastic problem that overarchs all of those is that Apollo 11 VR feels uninspired, flat and basic - more than a shame considering it is set out to pay tribute to one of mankind's most significant accomplishements of the last century. This won't make you love NASA or space faring or the inventivity of man. If you already love those things, it won't give you a new perspective on them - in fact, if you're into building space shuttles and sending them out into space, you're better off playing Kerbal Space Program, which has practically everything game offers sans the overdone 'inspirational music' and without pretending to be historically accurate about anything.  One last problem about the game, as a VR title: it can be potentially very nauseating for some people. I have the huge advantage of not suffering from any motion sickness in VR, but those few scenes and panning shots of the moon or of planet earth can be extremely dizzying, and I can imagine that people who are more sensitive to the effects of motion sickness would not be able to get through these sequences without taking off the headset. A particular early sequence in which the player is set through a fly-by shot of the shuttle prepped for take-off is very uncomfortable, but doesn't really offer any of the thrill that one may expect from literally flying around a shuttle the height of a downtown appartment building.  As for longevity, well, I don't think it's quite as important as some may expect from a game like this that tries to be more of a set experience than something you'd go back to, but it struggles to reach 60 minutes. I hopped around the surface of the moon for as long as I could take it before getting bored at the complete absence of activites (don't trust the whole 'deploy experiments' thing, there is no moving of parts or assembly required, just one press of a button and models magically pop up), and still couldn't get to make this last more than an hour.  It could have been a lot longer, and a lot better, if more creativity had been employed in the making of the interactive segments, which in themselves should have been more numerous. Not to be an ideas guy, but I expected a lot more from it - I've got a set of controllers that allow me to grab several things at once, twist them around and whatnot, so I expected the devs to do what plenty of other games do and let me take the whole shuttle apart to see how it's build, or let me deploy those experiments by hand, or physically move the controls and push buttons inside of the shuttle, but there's none of that.  To finish this review, I'd simply like to reiter my earlier recommendation of KSP for those of you who wanted to pick this one up as a semi-simulator of sorts. If you just want a simple demo to show off VR, there's plenty more options that fit the function more than this one, a lot of which are FREE.

So much fun, a challenging game with a huge arsenal to choose from at your own will, amusing humour and an amazing soundtrack by Machinae Supremacy (that's included as separate files for free!) for just a few bucks? This is a robbery. For the developers.  It's not just a good sidescrolling shooter. This game does its job, with a blast. Don't get fooled by the cheesy looking graphics, as the game was released for quite some time before it even reached Steam. They get the job done and JnG looks pleasant enough for an old 2d shooter.

I usually don't go in for this type of game. This market lost me to Wolfenstien 3D and wing commander fairly early on. Then several years ago, in a nastalgic period, I came across this game again. The dungeon themes were replaced with a more historic and reality based theme, It was far more fun than I remembered it being. Either something else came along or the dogs continuous barking made me stop playing again.  When the game released v3.19, my now grown son said 'Hey I found this game that you're gonna love'. I laughed when he told me, he had childhood memories of it. Since Sami offers it up for free, I'll give it a go again.  The dedication, helpfullness and great nature of the developer(s) of this game show not only in this new gem but in the community that rallies to support it.   As for me, I became a lifetime supporter of this game within weeks of downloading v3.19 and try to send in a little something extra when I can. I hope steam allows many people to appreciate how compex, exciting and addicting this game is NOW!

This is a very action-packed game, which involves you playing as one of the machine-spirits that reside in and guide our modern-day trains, as they undertake the perilous journeys to and from locations in the world, where half the threat is derailment and collisions, and the other half is being destroyed from within, by petty vandals and their vile ilk!  As expected, this is probably one of the most blood-pumping action games out there, where threats lie waiting at every corner, (and hell, even the corners themselves are threats, if you're going fast enough!) tugging and pulling at your desire to derail yourself, just for the pleasure of spiting the ungrateful commuters within your metallic frame, who probably didn't even pay for a ticket!  I wholeheartedly advise everyone to buy and play this game - although if you've got a weak heart, I'd recommend checking with your doctor first, as the adrenalin this game causes to be pumped through your system may just kill you.

I'll recommend this for those who are fans of the Battlefield series. It's a definite download for those who love playing a part in super large-scale battles. The game itself may take some getting used to, but overall, It's a really fun game to play.

Dead Rising 2 is the amazing sequel to the hit game for the Xbox 360 Dead Rising. you play as Chuck Greene, a motorcross sport champion who lost his wife in the vegas outbreak. He now comes to vortune city to compete in Terror is Reality to get money to get zombrex for his daughter Katey who was bitten by her mother during the vegas outbrake.   This game is visually stunning when considering the release date. It adds a lot of new features just like any good sequel should. jsut like the original Dead Rising it has a very interesting story that will have you hooked by the first cutscene. Just like the original Dead Rising, it ahs multiple endings providing the player with lots of replayability. the difficulty increases as you progress through the game to ballence it out as you get powerfull the more you level up by getting pp (Player Points)  The characters are fleshed out and the story is thought out. You have a reason for everything you do (well almost). you get attatched to these characters jsut like you should with a good game.   There is still that classic Dead Rising random element that you can do. such as using a bench to kill a zombie while wearing a mankini. this fun random element is one of the many reasons that Dead Rising was as popular as it was when it was first released.  The combat is still great with very few bugs/glitches. It makes things fun but sometimes challenging which gives a great contrast depending on your mood.  Overall, Dead Rising 2 has stood the test of time and is still so much fun to play and I definitaly recommend it to everyone! I rate it 8.7/10

Long Live The Queen is a very unusual game. It's a sort of survival game where you play the role of a young princess and make decisions for her. There is a constant stream of decisions to make, and you also have to decide which skills to level up and when. So there is a lot more choice here than in a typical visual novel. It sort of feels like a choose your own adventure game with RPG elements added in. It's actually quite challenging, and you'll feel proud when you get an ending screen that doesn't involve Elodie dying some ridiculous death you could have never foreseen (they are almost all hilarious, by the way).  It's a fairly short game but it offers an insane amount of replayability. Almost everything you do (or don't do) comes back to haunt you later. I've played the game for several hours and only seen a fraction of the content. It is well written and well made. I highly recommend it.

An extremely mellow short film of a game, Submerged is by no means a bad game, but it outstays its welcome and completely fails to justify its $20 pricetag.  While I did purchase it for sale at $5, which I think is a significantly more reasonable asking price for what it is, it doesn't change the fact that the game is about 4-5 hours long and has enough story for maybe half that. Its pictographic record of what happened to the city and what led you there is fairly redundant, which I suspect was so you could piece together a reasonably clear picture without going out of your way to collect all the secrets, but it's most apparent that the game doesn't have that much to say when halfway through your flashbacks between missions change from an explanation of the past to literally just recapping the opening cutscene and the game itself.  Gameplay-wise, Submerged is just another Ubisoft-style sandbox hidden behind a mellow, mysterious atmosphere that brings to mind Shadow of the Colossus if you took out all the fights with colossi. Find a waypoint, climb to the waypoint, repeat until win. Calling the climbing mechanics parkour would be inaccurate to say the least - there's no skill challenge involved, no possibility of failure and no room for intuitive thinking. You can only climb on specific sorts of ledges, even when there are easy shortcuts clearly within the realm of your character's physical abilities.  All in all it works, especially since the main draw of the game is the relaxed atmosphere, but it's just not enough to justify its purchase or the time needed to play through it.

An excellent Metroid clone, this one gets almost everything right. I think the general creepiness of the world feels like the original Metroid, but the controls are more precise like the SNES iteration. I love that the game never tells you exactly where to go next, this is what's missing in today's action/adventure games (with the notable exception of the Dark Souls series).  The upgrades that allow you to progress from one area to the next constantly surprised me - I was almost always wrong about what was needed to access a new location. A few examples: you don't need missiles to open doors, you don't use bombs to blow up weak blocks, you don't roll up into a ball to get through tight spaces, and you don't get a freeze gun to turn enemies into stepping stones. There were a couple exceptions, but for the most part the developer did an excellent job coming up with new ways to solve these old puzzles.  The music is some of the best I've heard in gaming, from any time period - dark synths with the occasional bit of creepy chanting. And the graphics, while a little bland in some of the wall/floor textures and enemy sprite designs, more than make up for any shortcomings with several rooms that are absolutely jaw-dropping. Many of the weapons also put on a nice light show, and are worth tracking down for this alone.  Speaking of weapons, most of them are completely optional, and unless you go back and thoroughly explore you won't find half of them. You probably also won't find many of the other secrets the game has to offer - I already know I didn't get the best ending, but I'm looking forward to going back in the near future.  If I had to come up with a complaint, I would say the bosses, while looking very impressive, all had fairly easy patterns that did not really change during the battles (most simply got faster as you damaged them). This is a minor issue though, and did not affect my enjoyment of the game much.  If you enjoy Metroidvanias, this one has my highest recommendation.

1st playthrough- Go as UN Humans. Ran out of influence. Unable to contract leaders and such. No biggie, but troublesome. It was the first time and was tring to get a feel for the game. Gave up when influence got to a consistent loss of -14.  2nd playthrough-UN Humans again. Game went on a little longer but ran out of influence again. Game doesnt really explain how this works so checked online to learn for a future playthrough and kept on. Realized that making ships auto update was actually lowering their combat scores significantly, some fleets went from 10k to 6k. Will manually update them in future playthrough, for now i'll ignore it. Rebelious factions ended up completely splitting my empire in several others. Even my home planet was gone. Checked online on how to avoid this. My species was the weakest of all, it was time for next playthrough.  3rd playthrough- Create custom race. The C'thuns, chilldren of Cthulhu are born. Militaristic race. Specialize in psyonics and warfare.  Conquered 3 other empires, liberated several species. The Chaotic fairness of Cthulhu was unstopable. No unhappy factions. Most other races idolised mine. Created several protection pacts to aid in political relationships. This allowed to eventually fully explore galaxy, only to realize you can't find all the ancient race artifacts. This mission progress was stuck at 4/6. Literaly all systems scanned. Whatever. Maxed out influence. Constantly maxing out minerals and energy. Ended up wining some wars probably because the enemy empire had no more resources to spend. Conquered 25%-35% of the O-shaped galaxy, manually updating ship classes was working great, but something was a bit off. I couldnt figure out the best ship fit for any given situation and the internet only provides information on the amount of tears people have because the ships are unbalanced. Whatever.  Our Empire's worst enemy? The United Nations of Earth. Literaly one of the most overwhelming federations, had about 50% of the galaxy for themselfs and had friends all around. If I went in with a 20k fleet they would come with 3 50k fleets. Fallen Conquerors Empire awakens, my grumpy northen neighbor. Instantly accept vassalization as I have no way to fight back such power. No problem for the C'thuns, we can acknowlegend superior races, for now. Realize most of my political relations are now locked. I can trade, so no big ussle, but the era of the conquering C'thuns was over. It was time to prepare for revolution. Invest all into research. Build more research ships to assist planets. Convert some planet facilities to labs, while avoiding negative balaces. Other races would attack here and there, no problem. Big daddy Fallen Empire would come to help and the mighty C'thuns could hold their own, eventually our enemies would be conquered by the fallen. A ton of years pass. About 500 maybe. Still not strong enough, but it was a matter of time.  Big Daddy Not-So-Much-Fallen Empire wages war agaisnt one of my protected friends. Fellow empire started it, actually. Realize I can't break the protection pact with them, as being vassal to another empire locks this options. Stuck in war with my big daddy for an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can't shoo away. Realize that since Im a vassal, protected empire is also red to me. Wtf? I am now being attacked by my protectorate, and by The Fallen. Why? I'm not even in the middle of them, but after watching all my space stations explode, eventually the time comes for surrender. The 'friendly' empire and The Fallen are the ones dictacting the terms, I have all options locked, since im not neither the main attacker nor defendant. 50% of MY planets go to The Fallen, because they won the war. I can only watch on this decision making.  This last paragraph went on a loop, eventually losing the game because the Mighty C'thuns are conquered with wars they have no option but to wage, againts all the other parties involved and eventually they decide to surrender with my planets on stake. I can't remove or atribute protection promisses, so I was completely locked on this one.  I can't really give a good review to a game that, however it much feels spetacular with details beyond other similar games, with really having much fun in working on all the possibilities and strategies, after a while it ends up reveiling it is a very unbalanced game with glitches and game breaking bugs, leaving a taste of unfinished game in your mouth.

If you know you have the patience for a game about exploring and solving puzzles slowly, then go for it. It’s the best looking game, and the way it tells the story is inventive.  Only the audio has glaring faults. Like they didn’t fence off the sound zones properly. Sometimes sound and music will stop at the edges of the map. Near buildings it’ll sound as if you’re inside, even though you’re not. And similarly when you’re inside it can sound as if you’re outside when you step near certain walls. The script and acting can sometimes also sound just a bit off. Like it needed another pass in editing, and another take in the recording booth. Also in the end credits they only have music for half the credit roll, so you end up staring at scrolling names in dead silence. There’s just a layer of polish missing on the sound front.  Apart from that it does what it sets out to do very well. Some of the puzzles require you to use your brain, and feel fun to solve. Others are the 3d equivalent to pixel hunting, but take place within clearly defined borders so you don’t go crazy searching for the clues. And boy does it look good. Might be worth it for that alone. Most importantly though the story has a good payoff. It’s a mystery with supernatural elements, and those often tend to fall flat in the end when the veil is lifted. This doesn’t.

app_name: Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist
review_text: No in depth review is really required for this, but i thought I'd take some time to have a little gush about an intriguing little game staring one of my favourite British comedians. It has a fun premise, a fascinating plot that keeps you involed (I would have been willing to keep going for several hours), and a nicely detailed artstyle that really give a sense of cluttured personality. I strongly beleive that the next game they make is full length though, or the players who aren't really really psychoticly into walking simulators will lose interest, but it serves its purpose: get people interested and spread the word about us. Reviewers who get borderline furious about this are getting way too upset over this short little teaser that at no point made any grand claims; all the hype i saw was from peple who played it and liked this experience and were able to aknowledge that developers can't 'rip off' something they already co-designed. I have a feeling most of the ill will towards this game comes from people who just don't like Simon Amstell or his work. Get over it, guys, we're all going to die. On the whole, I'm excited to see more, and I look forward to seeing what's coming next from these guys.

app_name: Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut
review_text: Deus Ex Human Revolution is a brilliant yet flawed game. A game that I love for a multitude of reasons. But as per usual, I want to quickly place a little disclaimer for those planning to buy this game with a LOW-END PC. You'll be able to run this game perfectly well with no issues. Maybe 720p or hell, native resolutions. My old laptop didn't pass the minimum requirements (it had a 1.8GHz Dual Core CPU) and it ran the game with 30FPS at it's native resolution (1366x768) with minor slowdowns at times.  But the game is well optimized and not really a bother in that department so don't worry about that.   Now. Let's get into the meat of this review.  Deus Ex Human Revolution is the prequel to 2000's Deus Ex. There were no other sequels (Don't mention the Fall or Invisible War, they don't count in my book) and it plays out the story of Adam Jensen. A former SWAT member that got ''kicked'' out of the team for taking part in the Mexican Town Massacre. This leads to Adam becoming the head of Security at Sarif Industries. Recommended to David Sarif by his ex-girlfriend, Megan Reed. I'm not going to spoil much of the story as the game's story is a brilliantly crafted experience.     The gameplay    It works and is easier to understand than 2000's Deus Ex in my opinion, but then again, I'm an idiot and took me a while to understand Deus Ex (2000)'s UI. The gameplay has been a bit simplified but the enemy AI is quite dumb at times but are accurate. There is infact Health Regeneration (which is meh in my opinion when it is done wrong which means that you're basically immortal), but it only heals you after a battle so you don't worry about running around looking for Medpacks, but that means that Devs can skimp over the level and not have to bother with Health Packs. The gameplay let's you do the usual ''Play it your way'' that most Stealth games let you. I'm calling this a stealth game as the game rewards you more for stealth rather than the original rewarding you equally for any sort of playstyle. The controls feel quite fluid in my opinion as it worked well. At first it was a bit awkward but then it became easier for me to play and was easier to see why they chose the default keymappings as they were. I also recommend having a 5-button (or more buttons) mouse due to the fact that the Augs themselves are mapped to F1-F4 like the original, but at times, it's easier to just press a sidebutton on your mouse to activate the Stealth Cloak Augmentation or the Smart Vision Augmentation.    The Audio    The OST itself is a brilliant one with tracks that consistently fit the mood of the area or situation you're in. The main menu track itself is a beautiful one that brings joy to me each time I boot up the game.  The opening theme itself, named ''Icarus'' is amazing to listen to in both in game and outside the game. Either way: The OST is lovely and awesome. That's always a plus in my opinion.     Enviroments and Levels    The game will often recycle areas but for reasons within the story, you'll go to Detroit and Hengsha twice. But that doesn't mean that the game is just being cheap and making it seem awkward. It's just reusing the same areas but with some sort of reasoning within the story and has some new areas to explore or new side missions to play around with, or even a new bunch of characters or existing characters that have new interactions with for your past actions. The enviroments seem realistic and yet futuristic. Most areas have atleast two or three ways of traversing around or fighting your enemies. The thing I hate about the areas and gameplay is that you can camp in the vents and just pick off the enemies one by one which makes it a giant camp fest if you're not bothered to try thinking to defeeat your enemies.   Well, in my personal opinion, you should most definitely play this title for all the positives. And the Boss Battles are reimagined so they're not giant turds like they were in the original version of this game.. BUT this game has more glitches. (none that I encountered but some others have)

A very, very fun to play Metroidvania, with lots to like:  + Three different characters, each with their own abilities and items. + Lots of hidden items. + Many different zones and monsters. + Great sense of humour (do not turn on abridged mode! :D). + Wonderful soundtrack. + Difficult, but not too difficult.   + You can throw fruits at enemies!    The art style looked a bit weird at first, but after a little while it started to grow on me, and it fits perfectly with the rest of the game.  All in all, a  MUST BUY  for any Metroidvania fans (or for anyone that like action games that are fun to play and obviously created with a lot of heart).

It's difficult to recommend Depression Quest, not just for its controversial nature but also because it tackles a topic that's rarely dealt with in video game or visual novel narratives. To me, Depression Quest is more of an interactive semi-visual novel, which isn't a bad thing ♥♥♥♥♥, but don't expect an orthodox 'gaming experience'. At first I was very reluctant to give this story a go, but I went through the darkness and 'won'. It definitely has some merit to it, so if you don't mind placing yourself in the role of a person struggling with depression or just with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ conditions that are going on, then give this 'game' a go.

Pretty good game. I got really sucked into it. The environment was well constructed. Eden is reminiscent of Rapture from Bioshock and slightly like Sierra Madre from Fallout: New Vegas too (what with the weird monster guards roaming the place). The puzzles were enjoyable but a bit on the easy side. I didn't feel compelled to use hints or skip or even look at the map once the whole game. The voice acting was pretty bad though. Very robotic. The story could have been a lot better because the setting and background story to the setting was really good. As it is, it kind of felt like you only touched on the surface of things. The bonus adventure was very worth playing too. Delves a bit deeper in to the story.

Hunting Unlimited 2010 is a rather fun virtual hunting simulator, designed to allow you to hunt from the comfort of your computer. Various locations around the world are available, as well as various types of prey such as; Deer, Elk, Bear, Lions, Elephants, and more. I, myself enjoyed the simulated hunt in the Northeastern United States with a 30-30 Winchester Lever action, which also happens to be the same type of rifle I own and have hunted with in real life. Various scents, lures, blinds, and more are available to help you in your hunt, as well as an array of various weapon types from Rifles to Crossbows, designed to let you make your simulated hunting experience unique to your style.   I have played hunting simulators in the past and this one ranks up top with the better ones, for its realistic feel and approach. The landscapes are varied and immersive, the ambient noises are a nice touch and the graphics, while not great, aren't so bad you can't enjoy the game. If you enjoy realistic hunting simulator experiences, I would recommend this over one of those Cabela's Hunting games any day.

review_text: i know .. no body likes gfwl & the ports are pretty bad but still, it's a great game if you know how to fix it *download the latest version of gwfl here  http://www.xbox.com/en-US/live/pc/DownloadClient  *go to your library -> your game -> Right Click -> Properties -> Set Launch Options & put : -nomemrestrict -norestrictions start the game, download the update & enjoy!  now let's move on to the game it-self .. it has nice graphics (with some small enb magics you can turn it into the most realistic game ever 'ofc if your pc can handle it') amazing story with double endings, there are many things to do beside doing the main missions like hanging out with your friends, bowling, playing pool, eating, drinking, shopping, browsing on the net, dating, watching magic shows and many many other things (which make the game enjoyable even after finishing it) also, there are many multiplayer/singleplayer mods to try 'yeah, the multiplayer isn't totally dead', so this can give you a lot of fun hours .. i would rate it 10/10 but gfwl sux so 9.5/10 !

A very polished experience, especially compared to the original! It improves on the original with a new graphical style, tighter controls, improved item combinations, new preset challenge runs, and tons of new items, pickups, dungeon layouts, bosses and more! It's a straight-up upgrade to the original!  Gameplay resolves around a very simple but well-executed formula: explore, collect items that incrementally improve your stats, kill the boss, progress down to the next floor, repeat. Nothing beats the feeling of getting all the best items and becoming an overpowered killing machine!  The game is very difficult and unforgiving. In true roguelike fashion, the game features perma-death: if you die, that's it - start again from floor 1! No second chances! You'll have to make do with a different dungeon and a different set of items on your next run!  Tons of replayability - hundreds of unlockables (including characters, items, challenges and additional bosses!) and thousands of interesting item combinations. 100+ hours of content - no exaggeration!  If you love pain, you'll love this.

What mostly bothers me is the terrible user interface, which makes the creation of custom loadouts very difficult (which was one of the best parts of armageddon) and general navigation through the menues a pain in the ♥♥♥.  When it comes to gameplay a few new modes are avaible, such as body count, which I thought was fun. But there is no neat way of previewing maps (like there was in armaggedon) or simple way to quickly change match options (like there was in armaggedon). I'm not against change, but when the change mostly concists of removing good features then it is really hard to give a favourable review.   So in conclusion: Buy armaggedon, it does everything better.

For the player looking for a special kind of game, that person is at the right place. Nothing in this games happens with no reason. The cat symbolises our inner evil self, and the rats symbolise our will to overcome, and become better. The gameplay itself is considered to be flawed by some, as the results of having the same setup may vary. However, just as the cats and rats symbolise our internal struggles, this seemingly random reaction at times of what should be systematic results is actually really only there to symbolise the following thing: that in life, even with the proper formula, you need luck and patience. This game is so deep, it has made me onder about several philosophical questions. I love the graphics, they are very colorful, sharp, I almost daresay sexy, and they make me happy and cheerful. The soundtrack is amazing, and I think it compares to Hotline Miami in terms of quality. In short: Gameplay: 5 Stars, Graphics: 5 Stars, Music: 5 stars. Truly an amazing game. A masterpiece, and several years ahead of its time. Try it out!

TL;DR - Fantastic game, great gameplay and AI, but can be a major pain in the glutaeus when using a keyboard  GRID is a diverse motorsport/racing game. While the graphics aren't that spectacular, the gameplay is well worth the price. This game has been overlooked by many who play Forza and Gran Turismo, but GRID surpasses the previous two in many respects.  Gameplay: The gameplay is solid. The physics are fairly realistic, the vehicles behave like you would expect, and the AI is much more natural than other games. They often quarrel among themselves, sometimes getting into large accidents and spinning off the track. The 24 Hours of Le Mans is a fantastic race, and I'm surprised not many other games contain it. The game plays fantastically on a controller, but is a major pain in the glutaeus if you have only a keyboard. I haven't been able to test out a steering wheel yet, but I heard it plays even better than a controller. The damage system is well implemented. Hitting a wall at an angle will damage your wheel, suspension, steering, possibly the engine, depending on your speed. With a damaged steering, your car will pull to the side, sometimes to the point where you have to quit the race.  Vehicles: GRID has a large selection of vehicles to choose from. Between tail-happy classic muscle cars, Touring cars, high-performance supercars, purpose-built drift machines, and many other categories, there is a car for every type of racer.  Tracks: I haven't gotten extremely far into the game yet, but of what I've seen, the track selection is fairly large. You have Yokohama, the Le Mans circuit, Circuit de Spa-Francorchamps, a track in san Fransisco, a Michigan demolition derby track, and a host of other tracks.  Race types: Good variety in GRID. Your average circuits are to be expected, but GRID also includes downhill drifting, freestyle drift, touge/midnight touge racing, demolition derbies, open-wheel racing, GT championships, and my favorite of all, the 24 Hours of Le Mans.  Graphics: I haven't been able to test it fully, since my computer is as advanced as a toaster, but the graphics in full are nothing too special by default, but if you modify one of the files, you can enable much better graphics.  Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone wanting a different racing game and has a computer more advanced than a 2006 toaster.

I'm writing this review from a long time Dota player's perspective. The similarities are few, but the differences are so welcome. I would hesistate to call it a sped up condensed version of Dota, purely because it's 2d. This takes away so many things that the whole experience is different.   Games are handled much more casually, with players being able to drop in and out of matches. There is a level system external to the gameplay which unlocks the first 20 characters each level, and from then onwards unlocks a new skill option, one per level. You will gain one level per match, at least, and if you win probably 2/3 levels. Overall I found I had earned more things from levels than I was able to keep up with, which is a good thing.   The characters are fast to learn and there is not a lot of clutter on screen. The simplicity of some moves can sometimes be annoying, especially when you get dunked several times over by the same combo, but you eventually learn the pattern and solve the problem, much like bloodseeker's rupture. I will say now that the artstyle is great, and the game intro is super ♥♥♥♥ing cool. Also each character has a theme song that plays during your skill selection, pretty nifty.   The levelling system for your character within the match rewards good play and there is almost no (noticable) rubberbanding. Teamplay and foresight are key, being outnumbered is usually lethal. The respawn time is about the same as Dota's, but for the last 10 seconds you get to play a mini game to collect gold before you spawn, although it's not really necessary.   My main criticism is probably that out of the 20ish characters there are 3 that, at the moment, are only available if you pay. And those characters are hard to learn, because you can't use their skills thus can't get a feel for them. I haven't dabbled in any of the cosmetics, but it's worth mentioning there's no pay to play aspects other than purchasing the extra characters.    Overall, as a dota afficionado, I would recommend this game. It captures the frenzy and a small amount of the strategy of dota, without being anywhere near as time consuming or mentally demanding. No real criticisms, it's very well executed and cuts to the chase.

app_name: You Have to Win the Game
review_text: It's a retro styled platformer. It's like how I like my women, 2D and hard.

A story about a boy and his shadow, this game makes it's players totally immersed in everything that's going on. The puzzles are actually a little tricky at times and are a lot of fun to solve. I find myself being connected to the other player on a different level, since everything depends on total co-operation, and because you always have to be close to eachother, or you die. And the way the game looks is really charming in it's own kind of way!  I recommend this game to anyone out there that needs something to play locally, since you can beat it in a single session. I also joined a couple buddies to play through this game at Gigacon 2014, and i had a lot of time to observe it. We beat it in a single sitting, for about 3-4 hours, and we had an absolute blast. It had a really artistic feel and is something i have been looking for for a while.

A great strategy game. Slightly different from Napoleon Total War. Solo campaigns are longer and better in my opinion. Multiplayer has fewer players than NTW, but it is still good. I'd recommend this game instead of NTW for people who love playing solo campaigns.
