As much fun as Hard Reset in its own way, way better than any Pain Killer game. Fantastically gory game, and for those with a love for the almighty katana. For all you Eye Cybermancy gamers and Killing Floor zerkers this might be right up your ally, it sure is for me. I love this game, the visuals are fantastic, the gameplay is smooth, fast, relentless and quite tricky when it comes to the large number of secrets hidden throughout the game. The game has good humour, over the top gore, and personally, I think this game is fantastic on PC. Max out the settings and you're good to go for hours of merciless mouse torture. Shadow Warrior does what it should do, it's an ode to the authentic shooter genre like we've known it from Duke Nukem, Serious Sam or the original Shadow Warrior. This game is fantastic from the beginning, right through 'till the credits begin to roll. I highly recommend this game, it is a must-buy.

Homeworld is, hands down, one of the best RTS games of all time. Not only are the gameplay mechanics amazing, but it possesses one of the best narratives in the genre. The story is emotional and moving -- but without the forced melodrama you'd find in some other games. It's a straightforward tale told with sincerity.  The classic version of both games play like the original release, so check them out for the original experience.   The Remastered Editions enhance the graphics... but they also rebalance gameplay mechanics. This is most apparent in Homeworld 1. Strike craft are rendered all but useless, forcing you to use corvettes as your 'fighter wings.' You also no longer have to refuel them. Frigates and capital ships have been variously nerfed or overpowered. So, if you're a veteran of the series, your 'old school' tactics may no longer work. These changes angered some people, though I actually appreciated having a new twist on an old classic. It made the gameplay feel fresh, even though I've beaten the original version a dozen times.  So, whether you're a new player or a veteran returning home, there's something for everybody. Want the original experience? Play the classic editions. Want a new twist? Play the remastered editions. Either way, Homeworld is still one of the best strategy games ever produced.

On the surface, this is a fun little platformer game with aspects of twin-stick shooter. Like others have remarked, it has impressive art design. Unlike others, I didn't find myself very compelled by the story and overall game design. Does it have a message? Yes, you can definitely see the parallels it draws between its characters and the hardships that we, as inhabitants of earth, face economically, environmentally and socially.  But, was it fun? Kind of. Will it leave a lasting impression on me? Probably not. Is it worth the $20+US? No...I would say about $15 relative to other games I've played that are similar indie platformers.   I understand this was an indie title that took 9 years in the making - don't really understand why so long - possibly finances? In all honesty, I've played other indie games that were far more enjoyable to play and left a lasting impression - I'm talking about you Environmental Station Alpha, Cave Story and Valdis Story. Opposed to these others, I can't honestly say that I'd come back to play this one. It's very linear. Controls are just ok. There's a section near the end that requires some experimentation with platform jumping. I'll give a hint...if you've been using the analog stick in the flying portions preceding this, you definitely want to switch to the D-Pad during said jumping section near end of game. Something weird convolutes the analog left movement stick with the jumping mechanism, intermittently wonking out and prompting premature flight, loss of hang-time, etc. You'll see. Maybe the devs will fix this.  Anyway, bottom line, it is a fairly enjoyable game that I would recommend...with one caveat. If you don't mind spending the $20+, go ahead and purchase; otherwise, wait for a sale at around $15 or so.

*I'm evolving this review over time  While the game has a few more minor things that could use improving, the overall construction of the game is well though out and well executed.   + The music complements the theme and pace of the gameplay nicely and has a enough variety for the size of the game. It's also good, well composed music to boot + Solid animations and sounds that make you feel every hit you give/take  + Great visuals. Has real attention to detail with the Mexican art style and borrows a little from GRim Fandango, while remaining its own style + Level design is excellent and Guacamelee STCE should be used as a showcase for great level design to anyone aspiring to build platformers. Each new mechanic is introduced to the player beautifully, then combined with other previously learned mechanics, which provides a progressively tougher environment to fight through. There is also an almost perfect mix of player versus environment and player versus AI and this also gets more challenging at a good pace throughout the game  + Fast paced combat + Funny + Seeds other game art and pop culture art into the game with it's own style e.g.    Manny Calavera skulls can be found on posters throughout the game    + Cool game mechanics with things like    INTENSO (my favourite thing in the game and what an awesome name for it too!), Dimensional Shifting, Playing as a Chicken, etc.    + Moddable +   Has the land of the dead!   + RPG mechanic is well executed + LOTS of save points that are very well spaced out     - Mini map needs level detail, not just room shape - No quest log for side quests or clues on where to go to finish these - Enemies can interrupt special moves - Knockback is more frustrating than it needs to be. You get knocked back too far and it takes too long to recover, which really breaks game flow - If you die, you have to re-open all treasure chests you opened before dying after last savepoint. This is a minor one, but I feel it breaks game flow a bit - There need to be more teleportation spots in the game. When revisiting areas to get the extras with new skills, not being able to teleport to the next area without having to traverse a huge amount of ground, becomes very tedious   - Controls while feeling fairly solid, could be better - The stick controls could handle player intention a bit better e.g. if player is pushing the left stick predominantly up but not perfectly, then the game should still take it as up, not sideways - If you fight a boss and die, when you respawn your intenso meter doesn't return to the fullness level it had before the fight - Throws often don't go where the arrow is pointing - Pushing off a wall for Goat Fly often ends up with Juan just dropping off the wall - Platform clipping is unforgiving and it gets annoying fast when you're jumping around on floating platforms  - Double jump doesnt work if you jump from holding onto a wall - The throwing mechanic is broken. Objects will often not be thrown in the direction of the arrow and this is infinitely frustrating during sequences in the game where this is necessary to move on to the next bit - Intenso meter doesn't return to original state of fullness when you respawn if you die in a boss battle   +- I'm in 2 minds about the wall jumping mechanic in the game. It's one of the biggest, if not the biggest mechanic in the game and the levels are clearly designed to take full advantage of it works with jumping from wall to wall and not being able to jump up the same wall in consecutive jumps. While this presents the player with a challenging mechanic, it's also very frustrating to use while traversing areas because it leaves no room for recovery from slight mistakes. This is really evident in the beginning of the game before Juan gets his dash skills.  Personally, I would have made the early design decision to go with a consecutive wall jump up the same wall and used a limiter like jump stamina. This way, most of the challenges would still work and the level design wouldn't need to be any more involved for developers to prevent player out of bounds issues.

I could not find a single thing I liked about this game. The intro sequence runs at 15 FPS despite being an FMV, the default controls are godawful, the character controls extremely poorly even after you modify the controls to make sense, the art style is off-putting, the dialogue is painfully bad, the music is bland and uninspired at best and grating at worst (it is not possible to listen to the main menu music for any length of time),  But what made me stop playing was the tutorial. The game doesn't tell you what buttons to press to do anything and doesn't let you look at the controls unless you exit to the main menu,  if  any of the buttons work at all  which they didn't my first time playing ; I had to exit to the main menu and open the tutorial agan before the game arbitrarily decided to let me  use the movement keys . Not to mention that it was extremely easy to render the tutorial outright  unwinnable  if you didn't know what controls did what; I ran into this  twice , first when I killed the first enemy from a distance instead of walking inside his hitbox and using an item that killed both of us, second when I got to the shop and bought the first thing I was allowed to buy, only to find out that I was supposed to buy something else which was more expensive and now I didn't have enough money for it.  When the game refuses to tell you what to do and becomes unwinnable if you don't know what to do  during the tutorial , you do not have a playable game.

With no check point system and kind of sloppy controls, I ended up getting stuck towards the end of the levels where I needed to die or dying on the levels where I didn't need to die far too often and ended up having to restart over and over again. Just from a glace at the reviews, you probably get a pretty good idea about what it's about. CKII is about managing political intrigue and your own personal royal family while maintaining a strong and united enough duchy/kingdom/empire to expand. A lot of the game is just a son-murdering and prisoner-ransoming simuator, and that's what makes this game so very unique in the grand strategy genre. This game just gets grand strategy so right.  I've already sunk a few dozens of hours in the game, and I've only scratched the surface. In my largest game, I've been able to reunite the kingdom of Ireland, take all of Wales and half of Scotland, but it all fell apart after my king died, my brother somehow became king of England under my nose, and took all my holdings in Scotland, and my son was a craven, arbitrary imbecile. Soon my country started revolting into various factions, and my back-stabbing brother decided to get into the mix and start declaring war on my now-isolated Wales, and it also turns out he got The Holy Roman Empire on his side, when my only ally was the king of Garcia in Spain, who was too busy murdering Muslims and having incestual relationships with his cousins. Needless to say, Ireland fell. Then I tried to be a republic (DLC). That failed pretty quickly, turns out when vassals hate you, they don't want to vote for you. Also, republics love war just as much as the Crusaders. Speaking of which, recently I've started again, this time as a Spanish king myself, and I've been having a totally different experience crusading against the southern Muslims, while having some nice inbred children of my own, while trying to deal with the fact that my sister has claims on all my lands. Most of my effort in that game has been devoted to murdering her as quickly and quietly as possible, but, unfortunately, a drunk co-conspirator was a little less serious about the whole 'quiet' part. Oh, and turns out, there is a lot of Muslims south of Spain, and some of my fellow Catholic rulers were a little less into the whole 'war' part of crusading.  Needless to say, there are a lot of dangers in Crusader Kings II. There is never a moment of complete peace, there's always somebody who wants you or your kids or your spouse dead, there's always an ally who's always nagging you to join his war, and there's someone getting some sort of terrible disease, there's always someone to throw in prison, always some vassals to please, and there's very often some sons or brothers you ought to kill off before they become the king of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ England. There is no end game crawl, and you'd be hard pressed to find another grand strategy game that pulls that off better than CKII.

The Talos Principle is a masterpiece.  Before I purchased this game, I expected it to be similar to Myst. The screenshots and the game description made me think this way. But The Talos Principle isn't like Myst at all. Instead, this game is quite similar to Portal. That's fine. I enjoyed both Myst and Portal very much. The only difference is that The Talos Principle is magnitudes better than Portal. It's simply THAT good.  At the time of this review, I've played this game for 42 hours. And I'm only about 80% done. Plus I have the DLC to look forward to. I bought The Talos Principle during a sale, but it's easily worth buying it even at full price.  Edit:  OK, I've now played this game for about 71 hours, and I've completed the entire base game plus the DLC. The Talos Principle really delivers on quality to the absolute end. If anything, the last 5-10 hours of the game were some of the most fun and intriguing.  Road To Gehenna is a really good DLC that adds new elements to the game. For example, the computer terminals are significantly more interactive, and the story is richer than in the original game. Plus, some of the puzzles in the DLC are geographically enormous, spanning hundreds of feet in all directions, including vertically. New characteristics like these are part of what makes Road To Gehenna seem much more like a sequel than a DLC. It's definitely worth buying.

This is by far one of the games that you're looking for, if you're on real time strategy games, immersive gameplay also really fun to play, the first hours might be rough for some people, but you can enjoy everything about it, there are 3 races with plenty of strength and weakness (humans, elves and orcs, pretty nice people that always help you and they are fun to chat with, it's an awesome community, it's not a pay to win game... it's more like a learn to play and win game, you can't be bullied by people more powerful than you, they have a pretty balance pvp system, there's something here that you can't find in any other game and makes it great and kinda addictive, also pretty good moderators, i recommend this game, for new players and for veterans, because of the always challenging gameplay, build your village, establish an economy, build your army, rise an stronghold, siege cities, upgrade your armies, get dragons, tame/kill ogres, kill demn unicorns, burn orc villages, burn trents and their sacred elf woods, burn human cities, actually burn and kill everything that moves or not, and loot their bodies, because why not?, you won't regret it

app_name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
review_text: The story was predictable as hell but the journey is really well done and enjoyable. There are no puzzles you will have trouble finishing but they are still involve some clever use of the game's control scheme. Play through it in one session for the best feels. It is well worth the price.

Cons:   *Not many cars  *Most of the songs are what can only be described as 'electronic fart noises that 6 year old kids listen to while they play Minecraft.' A few songs are tolerable, but you'll probably want to play this game on mute to avoid the tasteless music and incessant phone-ringing.   *The auction system is a complete joke.  If you don't show interest in a car, the AI won't bid on it at all. If you so much as bid on a car once, the AI will spam it with bids until a car with a starting bid of $4,000 has well over $40,000 in bids. All exaggeration aside, the last car I bought started at around $20,000 and ended at over $60,000. At $500 per bid and a $40,0000 raise, that's 80 bids. 80. 'Come ONNNNNNN, JUST LET ME BUY THE CAR.' is something you'll probably say to yourself a lot.   *It's pretty repetitive. Unbolt this part, beat on it with a hammer until it breaks, buy a new one. You'll be running back and forth to your PC a lot, so I suggest that your first upgrade point goes to a tablet. It'll save you a lot of time and frustation.  *Did I mention that there aren't many cars? I think there are maybe 10 different ones. I also got the Fiat DLC for free, somehow, but I don't think everyone else will. Still, not nearly enough cars for this price point. The lack of variety really makes it even more repetitive than it already is.   *Not much driving going on. After you finish restoring your poorly-modeled, generic-looking knock off of a Peugeot 505, you might want to drive it. Your options are a small skidpad that was ripped off from Beam MG Drive, or the testing area.   *Poor car models. Looks more like CMS 2012, but I still can't run it at the highest settings on my PC with 6 GIGs of memory. Medium-high settings at around 30 FPS.   *The customer orders are tedius and more or less all the same. 'Loud exhaust, fix all driveline issues, repair all body panels.' Every time. Every single time. It's always the same problems with every car.   *You need 9,000 XP and $50,000 to unlock the garage and be able to auction and restore cars, which is probably the only thing in the game worth doing. It took me about 16 hours to get to that point, give or take. So it'll take roughly 16 hours to get to the point in the game where it'll be worth playing, but then you need to do more customer jobs to raise money to buy and repair cars, because buying the parking lot and other parts of the garage will eat up most of your money at the beginning of the game.   *Overpriced, along with the DLC. It would be a great game for $10, and $15 including the DLC.   *There's not really any simulation going on. Everything is too simplified and easy. Maybe I'm just not in the age group for the target demographic or something. There's a lot more to a car than 50 bolts and some body panels.   *So [loading] many [loading] loading screens. Why. How could this game possibly need this many loading screens? Need to scratch your nose? Loading screen. Go to the auction? 2 loading screens, and then 2 or 3 going back to your garage. And just for the fun of it, a loading screen to launch a loading screen. It's like being on Oprah when she decides that everyone wins a loading screen. 'YOU get a loading screen! YOU get a loading screen! EVERYBODY GETS A LOADING SCREEN!'   Pros:  *I guess it's pretty entertaining for a little while. While what little charm it had wore thin a long time ago, I still enjoy it. I honestly don't think my enjoyment of the game makes up for everything else. It's not good, and not bad. It's basically the definition of mediocre.   Edit: If you look at it as a car-based puzzle game, you'll be a little better off. As a car mechanic simulator, it's not that good. As a car-based puzzle game, you'll have a hard time finding something better. I don't have much of the DLC, but I'm sure with the cool cars they've added on it'll be even better. Not everyone will like this game, maybe even most people. I still like it. It's relaxing, though a bit tedius sometimes. You don't need to know much about cars at all to play it. Just pay attention to what parts need to be removed in what order and you'll be okay. Would I recommend this game? Probably not. It seems to have a pretty specific audience. That doesn't make it a bad game, but not everyone will find it enjoyable. And I feel like a small Eastern European game company who tries their best to make a good game deserves a good amount of support. Like others said, it seems pretty pointless that you can't customize your cars in the base game. Also, you get the parts from the DLC cars in your parts catalogue for the DLC cars, even if you don't have the DLC.

BloodRayne Betrayal is a game that doesn't really deserve a thumbs up or down, but something in between. The core gameplay is there and is fun, as are the graphics and sound. The game plays very similar to pre-SotN Castlevania, which is great.   The problems with the game boil down to the controls and difficulty, which are in some ways two sides of the same coin. The game is almost ruined by some of the downright unfair and cheap segments later in the game, which are made worse by the not-100%-responsive controls.   The story also leaves a lot to be desired. I wasn't necessarily expecting anything that great from this game in this regard, but it ends way too abruptly and I feel the game should have at least another four or five levels of content. It's like they cut off the last quarter of this game - final boss and all. The game is also laughably short, even for a 2D platformer (I beat it in three hours on my first try at the game). This could've also been fixed with a few more levels added.   Overall, this game is good, but leaves a lot to be desired. If you're just looking for something to play that reminds you of old school Castlevania, it's a thumbs up and you should try it. Anything else? Probably not so much. Maybe try it if you're bored and see it on sale.

Cave Story+ is a very charming side-scrolling platformer/shooter. Many of the characters are quite humorous and loveable. The game is challenging, though not frustratingly so (at least for the most part). There are also several challenge modes and difficulty levels for those who want variety. The game also has quite a sense of humor. For example, when choosing a difficulty level, there's an option to confirm and cancel. When you put the cursor on Hard, the word cancel changes to 'I'm too scared!' There are other funny moments in the game itself, as well as some touching moments. Also the music is some of my favorite. There are a few versions of the soundtrack, but I personally prefer the retro version. Overall, this game is definitely worth it to buy!

I'm not a big gamer, I only ever play the Nurburgring, I use a Logitech G25 with separate shifter and pedals. I'm in my mid 40's with a family so can't spend day in day out practicing. I've driven the real Nordschleife 'tourist' circuit in a Jaguar XF Sport with other real cars on track too. (I'd like to see complete random cars on track, that start in random positions of the circuit when you do a free practice for added realism!)   I got this game on early access (and spent most of my time on Monza until the Nurburgring made it's glorious appearance.)   So this review is ONLY based on a comparison for aforementioned track. I run a Crossfire R290 reference setup on a 32GB Asus ROG Tytan (i7-4970) so graphically, my setup should handle anything and everything I throw at it.   Assetto Corsa looks great, Project CARS looks a bit greater however the ForceFeedback on PCars is awful. AC on the other hand gets it spot on. Touch a rumble strip in AC, you rumble. Touch a rumble strip in PCars, nothing. (most of the time.)   PCars offers more in the way of variety and content (a lot more to be honest) but if I'm after a quick(ish) lap of my favourite track, I come back to AC. It's not quite as pretty but plays much better with a heightened sense of reality that I look for in a Sim.

What a strange game.   Perhaps it's a good sign that over the course of playing The Beginner's Guide, I developed multiple interpretations of what it's trying to say.   The Beginner's Guide is the story of two indie game developers and the relationship they share over the course of a dozen or so developed games. One developer walks you through the other's games, one at a time, explaining what he thinks each game is trying to 'convey.' They are all walking simulators, and at times, you get the pretentious cringe of trying too hard to feel meaningful.  My first major takeaway is that The Beginner's Guide exists to help you think about games differently. It is obviously *for* 'games as art.' Games that are less about gameplay and more about message. It's here to walk you through how to view these types of entertainment in a way that does not prioritize completion rates and collectibles and action. It's like an art teacher teaching you how to appreciate art.  But that is only one of the game's many messages. The Beginner's Guide has a lot to say about a lot of different things, and some of them may not even necessarily make sense to you. There's things in here that I suspect may only be relevant to other game developer types. About the sort of... mental needs you build up. The attachments to certain ideals you have.  I'm not entirely sure I understand all of what The Beginner's Guide is trying to communicate, but... well. It impacted me just the same, in ways I didn't even feel prepared for. The feelings this game conjured in me lasted for days.  Maybe that's mission accomplished.

Criminally underrated, this is one of the most atmospheric and immersive FPSes I've ever played. Set in a severely devastated post-apocalyptic nuclear hell of a Russian wasteland, Metro 2033's stunning visuals do a great job transporting you into the dark depths of the underground subway station. Due to the level design and obsessive attention to detail, you can almost smell the choking odors of the metro's damp, dusty depths. I don't know if it's the deep mammalian part of my brain that's doing this but I felt almost suffocated during these segments, desperate for fresh air and a blue sky; things we take for granted in real life.  However, when you do get to the surface, things are hardly any better. A weak sun shines bleakly through a permanent radioactive fog, and the very air you breathe is a poisonous fume. Terrifying monsters, almost biblical in appearance, roam the wasteland. If humanity's home was once the surface, it certainly no longer is. It belongs to the demons now. If anything, Metro 2033 carries an undeniably strong anti nuclear war message that will be hard to forget. The feeling of hopelessness in the ruins of the world is so prevalent I found myself having to take a break from time to time. It's like a realistic Fallout without all the trademark Fallout silliness present to lighten the mood.   I only have a few gripes about this game, mostly about the human enemy A.I. You fight your fellow man during several encounters in the game (yes, even when the world is this effed up people still find reasons to kill one another) and you often have the option of stealthily tackling situations. However, the enemies behave erratically, sometimes they seem oblivious to the point of blindness to your presence, other times they spot you hiding in the dark behind a crate from a mile away and start sniping you with pinpoint accuracy. There's no 'caution' mode where the enemies have to investigate your last known position since they found a comrade with an arrow in his throat or whatever, they just instantly know where you are. This can be frustrating since ammunition is so scarce you'll likely want to avoid loud firefights if possible.  Ammo is so rare in this world that premium ammo is used as currency (as in 1 bullet for a piece of bread or something). There are also home made pneumatic weapons, that operate like deadly nerf guns which need to be pumped up between firing. The shooting and gun play feels impactful and desperate due to the scarcity of ammo. As you see your last bullets chugging away you'll find yourself running around hopping in fear with a mutant snapping on your heels. I've found myself resorting to using my knife a few times. Very stressful stuff.   The mutant A.I. works pretty well, possibly because a mindless monster charging at you is easier to program than ruthless, calculating Nazis. The sound design makes you jump at every clatter and scurry in the dark. I felt quite vulnerable as I scanned dilapidated rooms with a flickering flashlight. I actually found myself breathing a sigh of relief when I found my drunk Russian A.I. companions after a long periods of separation, which the game presents to you regularly. I normally find A.I. companions in video games annoying and pointless, but the atmosphere and tension in the dark depths is so oppressive and depressing that even A.I. badasses who speak like Borat are great to have by your side.   This game is definitely worth experiencing, I can't wait to play Metro: Last Light.

A trip back to oldschool RPG worth every penny!  Divinity: original sin is very similar in style to the old RPGs in the forgotten realms series (Baldur's gate etc). But unlike those games the combat in this game is all turn-based. I found the story interesting and there is a lot of areas to explore in the game. There is a lot of dialogue in the game and you can speak to most if not every npc in the game (including animals if you have the skill for it), although most non-quest related npc's have the same dialogue options. Divinity:OS also has a lot of humor in it and it has a certain sillyness to it in some places, which i love about this game. Quest wise there is a good assortment of quests in the game, many of them linked to eachother in some ways. It didn't feel very linear to me, there are pure sidequests in the game just for extra loot, xp or extra story. Oh and there is no such thing as a waypoint marker on your map telling you exactly where to go and what to do which i found very refreshing. You have to rely mostly on reading notes and diarys and using your brain to progress further. At the same time, in some cases it can be a bit too much. One thing that stands out is the need to solve puzzles in a few areas that involves really tiny buttons hidden in the environment, sometimes requiring your character(s) to have points in perception to even make them appear. It's not a huge deal but it can be annoying when you get stuck for hours on one puzzle during the main story (one in particular made me stay up until 6AM pulling my hair out until i finally got through)   Combat in Divinity:OS is fairly standard turn-based combat and i must say, very challenging at times even on normal difficulty, i found it easier a bit into the game though as the characters grew in power. One nice addition that i really like is the ability to use the environment and the combination of elements (fire, water, air, earth) to create effects on the battlefield. Like for example electrifying a puddle of water with a lightning spell, stunning everyone standing in it (including any of your own characters standing in it) or setting of an explosion by throwing a fireball into a poisonus cloud.  This game also has a crafting system as well which i didn't use that much on my first run. It seems a bit hard to figure out what items you need to combine to make stuff in some cases unless you search the steam community or google. The system itself is fairly simple, just combine ingredients by dragging and dropping them onto eachother or to some tool in the environment (like a forge or an anvil), but you need to find books or papers describing what items to combine and even then, there are ingredients that can be added onto the end result of the craft to create new items that i didn't find a description for anywhere. I guess i'll have to dive deeper into this aspect of the game on my next playthrough.  Well, what more can i say? I loved the music, there is a great mix of moods, happy, sad, action and humor (a certain song played in taverns, a favorite). Graphics i won't go into that much, i enjoyed the level of detail in the game but it isn't next gen graphics, very minor issue imo. The other aspects of the game like story and gameplay is so much more important. Bugs then? I encountered one problem throughout the whole 50 or so hours of gameplay that seemed like a bug, getting stuck in a dialogue at one point. It was solved by restarting/reloading so nothing big. Other than that i had two crashes at the end of the game, after playing for about 18 hours straight!  All in all, i am very satisfied with this game, it was so much better than i expected it to be and it brought back that good feeling i had when i used to stay up for hours, immersed in games like Baldurs gate or Planescape:Torment. I really hope to see more Divinity games in the future or at least an expansion to this game. Thanks for making this wonderful game!

Thoughts: I finally realized what was lacking in The Wolf Among Us that made it feel less like a game compared to Walking Dead Season One, and it's also lacking in Season Two: in Season One, there were a few sections where you had to explore and interact with a large open area in order to solve a puzzle or problem. This large exploration area not only gave some meat to the game, it also helped to flesh out the characters more as you could talk to them and catch up with them. This is pretty much lacking in Season Two: instead the game feels more like a series of cutscenes with dialogue options interspersed with QTE action sequences. There are some areas you can explore, but the areas are small, there's not much to interact with and the puzzle-solving element is minimal. The lack of this makes Season Two inferior to Season One, IMHO. All that said, it's still an enjoyable ride. Clementine is a fantastic character and I loved that there were several 'little girl' options for her dialogue, like hugging a person or giving them *sad eyes* to gain their sympathy. There were quite a few harrowing decisions to be made (although I have to say none as harrowing as in Season One), one QTE sequence in the first episode that is not for the faint of heart, some interesting and likeable (and a few utterly hateable!) characters, many horrible deaths, a few heartbreaking betrayals, and one dream sequence in the final episode that was an utter gut punch... Ultimately a fun roller coaster ride, but I wish Telltale would put the exploration and puzzle solving elements back in their games.

Although $10 is a little pricey for a game that is not very long, it makes you think in a way many games do not.  This full-fledged game should be no surprise to those familiar with Lucas Pope’s work.The free versions found on his website are unique and explore seemingly simple ideas for a greater purpose. For example, the Republica Times game explores the complex notions of the power behind media, government corruption and political unrest. These same themes spread into Papers, Please, which makes it a very powerful experience. It helps to split the screen into an overall border watch view on top, which shows people standing in line, the person approaching the booth and the movements of the guards. It will also show terrorist attacks and where you will go when given the tools needed to sedate (or kill) people rushing the wall.  For more on why you need to give this game a shot, visit  http://fovgames.com/2014/01/13/papers-please/

app_name: Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten
review_text: This was a good play.   Short and sweet: Light story, simple system, intriguing game.   It's a classic tower defense game given a different take (it plays like any other tower defense - the ones that dont require you to maze, and to just build towers to take down opponents - but feels more like an RPG than a TD). It does it well, too, may I say.  Looking into 100% achievement rate; hopefully in the nearby future.  Update: I'm nowhere near 100%. I hit the level cap so overpowering them isn't the answer so much as having a proper working strategy. Things just became much more difficult.

Absolutely loved this. Possible to finish a play-through in 1.5-2 hours, and ideal when you want something light to kill time. If you know the original novel, you'll enjoy the tone and style of this game. Even without, it's a light-hearted, fun and surprising piece of interactive fiction. In 1 playthrough I got abducted by pirates, lost a boxing match, led a mutiny to become captain of a ship, got shipwrecked and enjoyed brief romantic dalliances in Russia and New Orleans.
it ses i do not have steam!

Who doesn't know Lara Croft in the gaming community? Every gamer has fantasized about her (of course, Angelina Jolie's portrayal helped a lot). Attempting to change something that looked established requires guts, and the guys at Crystal Dynamics have plenty of guts. This version of Tomb Raider is different to the ones we adventurers love. First of all, because it's a merge between several genres of gaming. Sure, you can define this game as being an adventure game, but it's also a shooter, an RPG, a platformer... heck, it even has some stealth in it too. And second, this is not the Lara Croft we know and love, despite the visual differences. This game works as a prequel to the adventurer. She presents herself as a survivor, and this is the primal task of this game: surviving, no matter the cost. The gameplay and dynamics of the game are impecable, the graphics are beautiful, the story is well written and the atmosphere overall is dark, spooky and often pessimist. This game does everything right, and you know it since the first minute you play it. This game is an experience every gamer should have in his life. There is only one negative aspect I can say about Tomb Raider: every time you alt-tab out (every single time), the game crashes to desktop when you attempt to go back to it, leaving no message at all. This can be annoying, but it doesn't jeopardize your progression too much, since the checkpoints are plenty and well placed.  Final score: 5/5. I truly loved this game.

Let me make something clear.  If you've grown accustomed to the Cookie cutter Monopoly that is Call of Duty, Battlefield, and even the most recent power titan; OVerwatch.  This isn't the game for you.   There is an unrealistic amount of complexity in it's simplicity. An aged feeling of a young lad racing home from school with only one goal in mind- To play a great game.  I'll explain a few things that replicates the sensation of the game. As best I can, rather.   GRAPHICS -   Astounding. I, being a man of class, would like my outfits to match my tools. A black, lightly dusted cloth adorns both your character, his outfit, and his weapons- leaving only his facial features to differ. This is not a lax of developers. This is an ingenius method to keep you focused on the game. Enthralled. Entertained. Complex designs distract from what you came to do. Play.  GAMEPLAY -   I was able to fool a dinosuar into believing himself to be my comrade. After standing atop his mighty form- I charged boldly into battle. The other dinosaurs, assuming him to be a comrade of their own, refused to nip at my ankles. This is development at it's highest asset. Games like The Stomping Lands, Ark, etc simply can't compare in the level of complexity. A.I pathing is simply ingenius. I've seen multiple instances of enemies rushing past my partner to attack me instead. Now, one would assume that this was a feat of bad coding.  False.  The A.I actually factored in my superior aim, and priotitized me as a far more viable target. This made more sense to me. Don't target the weakest. Target the strongest. Take out the elite.   PVP -   The game has a randomly occurring PVP mode that is absolutely breathtaking. Often times, Enemies will stop spawning. Without rhyme or reason. In these episodes of peace and tranquility, you are damn near influenced into firing at one another to pass the time. What was already an overwhelmingly fun experience is now an outrageously in depth combat system waiting for exploitation. Killing a friend doesn't seem to cause a mission failure. Or being killed for that matter. Or death in general. This doesn't make the game *Easy*- it adds yet another complex layer to the game that deserves a spot in Valve's vault of greatest hits.   Overall -   Buy this game. Letting this opportunity pass by is insanity. When I purchase something, I usually grade a game on the hour to minute ratio. For each dollar spent, a game needs to entertain me for an hour. At 0.50$- I spent a whole hour plus playing. That's nearly 200% profit of fun. Words cannot explain the feeling of blasting the same two different dinosaurs for an entire hour straight. The only reason I stopped playing was because my house had caught aflame from the sheer heat this game gave off.  !0/10 Best game available.  IGN- 9/10 Gamespot 9/9 GAme Informer 4.8/5  This review is false.

Like the 1st game, BS2 is built upon a solid gameplay formula and fascinating worldsetting. Unfortunately, the execution falls apart. Stoic Studio behaves like that spiteful, arrogant artsy kid, bragging about the genius of their work but simultaneously mocks you for playing their game.  If you're new to the turn-base strategy genre, the game is going to feel utterly alienating. And Stoic really doens't bother to hold your hand. You're thrown into the thick of battle to fend yourselves. You're going to make mistakes and you're going to feel it. Not in a satisfying 'everytime I retry I get a little better' kind of way. But in a 'I'm hours into this playthrough and I just realized I don't have enough high level characters to get through this battle and now I must start all over' kind of way.  If you're a perfectionist then you're going to hate this game. The game doesn't allow you to make saves. You frequently find yourself having to replay entire chapters of the game to reverse a bad decision. Even that is frequently marred by the devs' sadistic, spiteful attempts at making life difficult for you. You want to get a power save to import into the next game in the franchise? We'll make it that the point of import is hours before the end of the game. So you'll have to replay hours of the game and watch unskippable cutscenese over and over again if you want that perfect save files.  Some games feel like a labor of love. Both Banner Saga games feel like labor of spite. Spite towards Stoic's own fanbase. As you play the game you never feel appreciate. You feel like a sucker sticking out throughout the deliberate abuse the devs hurl your way. Because they want to be 'different'.  Play the game game only because you want a genuine challenge, or if you really like viking mythologies; don't play the game because you want to support indie gaming. Stoic won't thank you for it. And it showed.

Great RTS. Best one i've played recently. The only complaint is that map navigation both in galactic menu and solar systems leaves a lot to be desired along the lines of control. As for the rest of the game i love the epic weapons. the constant action and limitless armies you are able to produce. strategies are diverse and for the most part all counter-able, so game balance is not too much of an issue yet. i would love to see more combat unit choices to be introduced in the future including space crafts (not just orbitel tech) and stand alone space station capable of their own solar orbit as epic (t4) or expensive T3 vehicles. i would also like to see unique units in each faction or (some) planets.   All and all i would say this game may some day compete with warhammer as far as play-ability.

As a big fan of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I was surprised to see how many things changed with XCOM 2. Along with the new futuristic setting, almost every aspect of the gameplay has been tweaked or modified in some significant way; altogether, it makes XCOM 2 feel wholly fresh and unique – even if not all of the changes are for the better.   What stood out the most early on was the steep learning curve; it wasn't until around the 30-hour mark that I felt like I had a good understanding of how things worked. The “Veteran” difficulty setting struck me as being WAY too hard for a first playthrough. I recommend setting it to the easiest mode, at least for the first bunch of hours.   Of course, the complexity that makes it hard to warm up to is part of what fuels its replay value – there is an enormous amount of depth here. You can modify soldier weapons and some of their stats with special items, equip different kinds of armor, manage research projects and constructions, keep track of limited supplies, manage special development projects and special reseach projects......umm, actually there are TOO many things to keep track of. It reminds me of the excessive micromanagement of the first Mass Effect – the depth is definitely there, but it takes too long to get anything done.   The weakest part of XCOM 2 is the story. It comes across as rather cliché average sci-fi, but at least has a very strong presentation with stylish cutscenes and good voice acting. Visually, the whole game feels “brighter” than Enemy Unknown, but still has the same great use of color and special effects. It's a lot of fun to take screenshots during the cinematic moments in battle – give it a try!  It's easy to compare XCOM 2 to Enemy Unknown and point out its flaws, but at the end of the day the turn-based strategy battles and base-management elements have a similar kind of engaging, almost compulsive appeal with very high replay value. It is intense, entertaining, and will push your intellect to the limit. Just be sure to treat this game the way you would any hostile alien: approach with caution.  (Rating: 9/10 “Great”)

'Morrowind' dubbed '#1 rose tinted glasses game of all time'  I started playing morrowind at the ripe age of 5 years old. i would spend countless hours exploring the continent, talking to npcs and crafting my own story. morrowind was a foundation for my imagination. I have many fond memeories from this game, my homeboy Fargoth, Egg hat man, Nwah, Vivec, balmora, Toddtest, and the talking mudcrab just to name a few. the world is immersive with an interesting asthetic that had never been done before. The music is beautiful and will stay with you forever. This game is a true RPG, made before the times of catering to filthy casuals.The only thing i think is missing is a lack of playable dwarves (I know, the dwemer are basically dwarves).  I am proud to say that this game instilled the strength of 'Firmcenter' gaming within me. This has to be my favorite game, and holds a place close to my heart.   For when it was released, and what it is, i give this game 10/10

app_name: Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut
review_text: Perfect.

Eternal Senia reminds me of old JRPGs I use to play on the GBA. Beautiful pixel environments with gorgeous art styles for cut scenes. Multiple endings reflecting on your actions.    Gems:   The story is well written with so many feels through out the game.  The artwork is beautiful. The environment is simple with lovely detailed CG/pixeled backgrounds. The music is stunning. Again, it has that classic RPG feel to it. I seriously wish the was a soundtrack available.  Gameplay is not too complex. Anyone can sit and relax while playing this game without getting frusterated.  Easy, normal, and hard mode bosses for those who like a little bit of a challange.  I love they added little bit of MMORPG flair to the game. How cool is that you are can make your own armor/weapon upgrades! Battle system is unique. It took me a while to get use to using the arrow keypad. Other then that, its really simple.  Finally mutliple endings. Like I said, you get to chose your own ending.   Game is fun for being a really short one. I know people are meh when it comes to the bonus room. I find it interesting to read all the inspirations and ideas that went into this game. However the race mini game is brutal.   I really hope they make another Eternal Senia.

SOMA's story has an unexpected depth with so many layers that it could easily be made into a movie or a sci-fi book. There's a horror aspect to it, of course, but the player will walk away enriched in a far more profound way than that. This isn't as much a game as it is a awesome course on 'Meaning of Life' and other topics like 'Is there life after death'.  One thing is sure, if you are mature enough to appreciate the deeper questions of life then this game will be unforgetable and the most time you will spend with this game will be while you are NOT playing it.  That said, someone looking for ONLY the Horror may walk away disappointed. You get to savour quite a few hours before the ♥♥♥♥ really starts hitting the fan, so it requires more patience than your ussual run of the mill Horror experience. And there may not be enough gore for those that essentially crave that aspect of Horror.

Banished   is a wonderful sim and is mechanically very similar to the economical aspect of the medieval sim     Stronghold     but without the currency aspectt. If you like a challenging game where you need to plan for the long-term to avoid failiure then you will enjoy this game.    The game   is very beginner friendly and intuitive. It has a great turorial and a very good     Wiki   [banished-wiki.com]    which contains all the necessary information.    The gameplay   is diverse, the difficulty is scalable to reflect the player's playstyle. The game can be simpe without the need to worry too much for the villagers but it can also be punishingly hard with harsh winters and the threat of natural disasters.     The game   is challenging at all stages. From having to keep your villagers from starving and freezing to having to account for several hundred villagers and their needs. However, since the game doesnt have a currency aspect you will have to trade wares to thrive and in it's current state most of the trades are favourable which removes some of the complexity of trading.    The game   has full workshop support which gives you the oppertunity to continually add content as you like. The game also seems to gradually get new content and features    So, is this game worth it's price?  -Yes Is this game for everyone?  -Is any game? Do you reccomend the game?  -Yes

Artistic grand journey meets minimalistic simple strategic gameplay.   The Banner Saga does very little wrong, from it's hand painted environments to it's grid-style battlefield the game is as pleasing aesthetically as it is from a gameplay perspective. Your followers are all at risk of dying by the choices you make which forces you to take a longer look at your decisions before you blindly go through with them. The story is compelling to say the least. I'm not one to upsell and I don't want to spoil much of it, however you can see the story playout from multiple perspectives and meet up 3/4ths through. The most compelling aspect of The Banner Saga, and the probably the reason I enjoyed it so much was it's ability to tell it's story so smoothly. You grow fond of characters, dislike others, silently mourn the loss of a follower or bless whatever gods these fictional warriors believe in for ridding certain individuals. All in all, I killed a man for looking at me disrespectfully, which in hindsight may have been an over reaction to nothing, but after all what is an RPG without some evil decisions

For what seems like a stereotypical fantasy TBS, Thea: The Awakening has the ability to keep you playing it for 'one more turn' with it's beautiful and simplistic atmosphere. The game offers an incredible amount of depth and characterisation, although it might become tedious in late-game. It is clear that a lot of thought and research has been put in the events that occur during the game, drawing you in this fantastic scandinavian and celtic mythology. I'd recommend giving it a try, maybe you could find the same level of enjoyment as I did playing it. I found the coop a bit harder to grasp, as it feels like there's not a lot of benefits from trading with the other player. Also it requires a bit more patience.

For version 1.0.3  Though the developers have released this from Early Access, it really should not have been. First off, the bugs:     missing image assets     broken dialog trees/subquests     spelling mistakes     crafting window which gets laggier and laggier each time it's opened.     constant shaking of the screen when left unattended for long enough (in my case, once to answer a phone call and another to deal with a someone at the door).   Beyond the bugs, the content of the game itself is surprisingly sparse. You just constantly descend without much incentive to explore other than to discover upgrade stations. You can also find NPCs and get their subquests, but even if those subquests aren't broken there's no real payoff for completing them.  At its current level, the amount of active development and polish needed before this would be worthwhile is probably measured in months, not days or weeks. I'd check back in six months to a year to see if things have gotten better or if the move out of Early Access is an indication that the dev team is abandoning the game and so might as well call it done.

Early Access Review

The game is pretty much what I expected. Some aspects are better than expected - creatures animate really well which is quite an achievment for preocedurally generated animals. The graphics are a little worse than I had hoped here and there but some planets still look amazing, the vistas where you can see other planets in the sky knowing you can just take off and travel to them is quite remarkable.  I don't like the fact that you can't seem to look around the cockpit or generally look down when flying.  The planetary flying itself is sometimes a little buggy and landing is a bit too imprecise. I really want more control over my height above the ground and the ability to hover would be great.  Storyline (or whatever you want to call it) is interesting. I'm not expecting anything mind boggling from it, just a reason to keep travelling and upgrading.  Overall, I like it - 8.5.

Fun overall for those that wish to wait, or have nothing better to do. If there was a tech tree to go down, or more variety of buildings, this game would be better.  6.3/10 - Would have colonists starve the biologists and then starve because of that again

The controls, graphics, animation, and general quality are really solid, but the content is spread far too thin and the game consists of mostly doing the same things over and over. Occassionally you'll see old things mixed together in new ways - an enemy spawner next to a difficult stationary enemy, for example - but then that combination will get re-used dozens of times before you run into anything new, and that new thing may very well be a slightly faster version of an old enemy with different graphics. Tough enemies can take a minute to kill even if you're taking no damage and they pose no threat to you, making them more chore than threat, which only adds to the sense of tedium.  The difficulty is also extremely inconsistent. Some enemies plink away with 1 damage and easily avoided attacks, while more difficult to avoid attacks often take half your life bar or more. The game's first boss was vastly more difficult than the second.  I would have been happy to play this same game with levels a tenth as long and a constant stream of new situations, instead of its current form, which feels like mostly padding.

Do you have three dollars? Buy Super Hexagon, then. Looking by my mere three-hour playtime, it may not seem like the game is worth it, but that's because this game is very much reminiscent of old vector graphics coin-op games like Asteroids and Missile Command. Gameplay is simple: move left and right, dodge the walls. The art is appealing, the gameplay is ridiculously easy to learn but very grueling to master, the music is fantastic, and it's a game you can easily pick up and play at literally any time for just a few seconds at a time or for an hour or two if you feel up to the challenge. If you like arcade-style games or twitch reflex games, this is definitely a game worth getting.

Overall, I still think Broken Age is a game worth playing. Beautiful art, great voice acting, good-to-great writing. There were a couple of things that didn't work for me -- Shay, for example, is clearly less interesting as a protagonist than Vella, especially given some of the revelations in Act II, and there are puzzles which require you to use knowledge gained by one of the characters in the other, even though they're not in communication with each other, which is just maddening from a logical standpoint. There are also one or two puzzles that are problematic in the way they are set up.  Still, I enjoyed it. As a Kickstarter backer, I got more than my money's worth, between the 11 hours of adventure gaming and goodness-knows how many hours of documentary footage about the game's development cycle. One of the very few games I've finished over the last couple of years, and that's got to be worth something, right?

app_name: Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris
review_text: This is without a doubt the worst game I have ever played in my life. The puzzles are very easy, uninspired, and boring. The map is poorly designed and not very helpful. It's too easy to get lost and not know where you are or what you are supposed to do. The combat is chaotic and it is very easy to lose your character. The controls are poor (typical of Lara Croft) and it is easy to fall off of a ledge or miss a jump. I loved all of the other Lara Croft games, including GoL. But this game just plain sucks. If they paid me to play it, it would still cost too much. Horrible. -10/10.

EDIT: I am leaving my orriginal review between this and the actual edit.  This game is very good so far. The graphics and game-play is nearly unparalled. However, the tech-trees and upgrade potential are almost non-existant, taking away from a lot of the possible complexity. It has been said that these are planned for the future and when that happens this may be the best game of its kind. For now though, it is still a very fun game to play, mainly with friends but even random players and AI for practice.  EDIT- This game has gone nowhere in a very long time. The developers have agandoned everyone who suppoted their early-access and decided to make paid-for DLC that should absolutely have just been an update. I feel absolutely cheated and do not recommend anyone get this.

Wonderful game, a great addition to Legends of Eisenwald. Really big map and a lot of things to do. Taking over enemy castles initially was hard but it was because I tried to capture them all. I changed my strategy and started taking a few and protecting them and it worked much better. Once I captured all, enemies stopped respawning, and I needed to defend my lands only against a few raubritters.   Side quests are good, many have a nice touch of humor. I really liked Underwater Bees, I think it's hilarious :) Political references are nicely done as well, not sure what others complain about. You can forget about it after all and treat it lile any other story, stories tend to repeat themselves century after century. Other pluses are: + Plenty of enemies to max out your army. + Patrol in your castle - I brought them to max level and they were able to defend my castle twice against rogue knights! It's worth training them often. + Autumn scenery. I wish original LoE had some of them, looks really nice. + Interesting quests that make you think and explore the lands.  + Huge map, I think it's the size of the biggest map in LoE. + Enemies respawn stonger. I captured all castles about a week before November 8 and chased a few bandits. Some of them got so strong I lost a battle. Don't chase bandits with skill ambush in forests, they will destroy you in the first round.  There are a few minuses though: - Saves related crashes. After a few ones I read up on forums and found that it's best to use quick save (F5) or rename standard names. For some reason, standard names saves are very likely to cause crashes.  - No endless mode. I know it's one map smaller game but I can't help wishing for some random quest generation and armies respawn. I realize it might become boring but it would be so cool to enjoy for a while a victory and rule over my lands with an iron hand :)  9 raubritters out of 10

Hatred is by no means the best game ever made nor the most violent but there is some enjoyment to be had here. It reminds me ALOT of the original postal gameplay wise...in fact it is postal gameplay wise. Its a twin stick shooter at the most basic level.  Visually the game is alright. It by no means looks bad and it has a style that probably enhances the visuals with its crushed colors. Its a game you should be able to run at 60fps without any issue.  I had bought this game merely out of spite for all the negative press it has been getting from people who had never played it. Demonizing and calling for censorship...of a game, I wasnt expecting much from it but from what Ive played so far im enjoying it. Classic gameplay without question but its hard enough to keep you coming back and trying to keep pushing further into the levels.  Worth $20? Hard to say really. If you like twin stick shooters it might be. The game has good production quality and its not sloppy but if you dont like the genre it wont change your mind. If you are a casual fan then wait for a sale. Its a good value at $15 but paying full price is as close to showing the modern gaming press that you disaprove of their antics as you will ever get.

Arguably one of the best, this is definitely my favourite strategy game out there. It brings a new take on Turn based strategy, the likes of which I have not seen before. I have not played any other XCOM games so i won't be able to compare them but I will definitely go and check some out.  The backstory is somewhat generic, but fun all the same. You are defending the earth from invading aliens, and the whole of the earth is dependant on your brains. Even when you're not in battle you have to make decisions such as which countries to save, which parts of your base to expand, etc etc. You control a squad of soldiers, who get upgrades as they rank up, which makes them tougher and stronger. However the element of luck is always there, and you can never be 100% certain that you will return from a mission with you war veterans or even with the whole of, or any of your squad.  Overall XCOM enemy unknown is brilliantly designed and developed, and i can't wait to rack up some more hours on it.

Okay, so before I say much I will just point out that I have not completed the game yet. I'm currently on a mission but got stuck due to a bug/glitch that makes parts of the map disappear. So, I'll restart the mission and move through it slower in order to hopefully have the map fully load.  Anyways, for what it is - A tactical shoot 'em up with placement and semi-control of your AI companions, it's quite enjoyable.  Personally I find the storyline to be quite enjoyable and cool. I also must say I love the voice acting.   Some tedious legwork in the base MAY annoy some people, understandably, but hey it's not too bad. And sometimes the NPC's will say something as you walk by. Always cool to hear what people think of your character.  In addition - You get to create four people right after the innitial mission however you want. The levelling system is intriguing as well and I find myself constantly thinking 'Wow, I feel like I'm literally an agent/group of within the XCOM base.' It's really a nice feeling when I was such a huge fan of 'Enemy Unknown'.  Is the game fun, as a baseline qualifier? Yes! It is fun! Sure, it might not be what you're looking for in an XCOM game, but it's worth the buy and the play for those of you who like FPS games. And for those of you who enjoy retroesque storylines and stuff of the like, this could also find it's way to your heart as well.  8/10 - Though, if this bug persists my rating may change to a solid 7.   If you read all of this, pat yourself on the back! Thanks for the read.  And, for the creators of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified, thank you!

Also, the lighting system they said they were going to implicate before original DS2 came out but never did was KINDA expressed a bit here, making it practical to use a torch in some locations.  The thing that I hate though is how sparse the pvp is in this game. I'm assuming its because the community is split on the pc.   Overall pretty damn good 8.7/10

app_name: Dark Messiah of Might & Magic Single Player
review_text: Come for the kicking stay for the stealth.  Frankly this one of the most unintentionally funny games I've played and at times it's also genuinely fun to play. That said it's not without an abnormally large number of problems I'll be getting into. The game runs like butter in 4k maxed out (Source engine game from 06 after all) and the visuals have held up well overall thanks to some fancy lighting effects and general visual flair and well as a reliance on physics that would make Half-Life 2 blush. The lip sync is great and the animation is decent even though that's primarily because it's a Source engine game and you'll often recognize some canned animations reused over and over if you've played other titles on the engine. Faces are a mixed bag with some humans looking great and others obviously not being capable of and facial animation. All the monsters look great but the people aren't all well detailed and are sometimes more ghoulish than the beasts you encounter funnily enough.  One thing that could have made up for the wonky animations would have been good voice acting but unfortunatley that's another thing this game lacks to a frankly laughable degree. Things like he ability to see your feet and phyisically use your hands to pick objects up in the world (In addition to some slightly sickening head bobbing) make up for that quite a bit and can make it incredibly immersive at times even if you'll see your sword floating out of your hands or just walk past all the enemies like I did. The overly drawn out tutorial followed by a long drawn out linear opening are a few issues that keep you from getting into the meat and potatos of the game but during this time you'll have held every useless object in your hand (if your me) or destroyed everything with your awesome kick.  There is stealth, there's magic, swordplay (You can dual weilding daggers, using a sword and sheild, just a sword or a staff all of which can also be used to block with), archery and donkey kong which is my preffered playstyle. The most effective weapon is the ♥♥♥♥ lying on the floor. You'll find yourself mostly jumping on enemies as it ragdolls them even when they are already lying down, picking up a body to block attacks, kicking people and generally being merciless as enmies limp away only to get kicked. While kicking has limited stamina it's quite useful as ledges and spikes are everywhere. It kind of reminds me of Theid with the whole game feeling like a source engine version of that title for better or worse.  It's biggest problem is the lack of polish which only effects the 2 of the 3 most important things in the game those being the the gameplay and story. It's a wee bit janky and the occasional badly compressed FMV's are another thing that makes it a chore to sit through. In Half-life 2 if you got bored at least you could climb around the room and throw stuff. Funnily enough NPC's actually react twoards your bad behavior for the most part outside of cutscenes but then the game will reload a past checkpoint after you've been chastized even if all you did was throw a bottle or jump on someones head. I guess this is also because unlike Half-Life 2 you can ALSO kill pretty much anybody which could have lead to some awkward moments if you walked into a room and accidentally killed off an important charcter needed for progression.  I disliked everybody I met in the game which is why it's a bummer I can't just kill everybody all the way until the end of the game. Regardless the price is right and I advise anybody who hasn't already to pick it up as there is a lot of freedom in terms of what means you use to progress.  I don't know if it's really good or really bad but overall I reccomend it. Oh and Ubisoft AND Arkane had a hand in it whcih probably explains a lot.

Even 20 years later... so sweeet. What a blast playing the original DOOM again - with a controller no less. I remember when it first came out - playing at 2 am in the dark... and my wife snuck up behind me and yelled BOOO ! ..... I jumped 3 feet and nearly made brownies. Not so scary now but the nostalgia alone is so awesome. Can't wait to work through to DOOM 2 and 3. This BFG Edition is sooo worth it.

Awful. Are you looking for a game where you can play basketball or a game where you are a coach and run a team. Of the later is the case, it's a pretty good gsme but if your actually looking to enjoy playing a game you are out of luck. For a $50+ game you need to spend additional money to buy coins to upgrade your character and get customation features like tatoos and clothing, which is utterly ridiculous. Unless you do this to upgrade you are Awful and can't make a ♥♥♥♥, defend, or dribble to save your life. Which inhibits how well you can do, which inhibits your ability to improve. Addittionally the controls are nightmarish. No longer can a relative amateur sit down and play. You need to one use every button(gamepad) or your entire keyboard to move your character, control their dribble, time your shot, order other players, and design team plays. You litterally don't ever play just one player as you need to design plays and order the other players, who by the way, sometimes ignore you. Unless you are a fantasy team maker and know all the players stats and team strategies you will be utterly lost. Oh, and did I mention that your coach will bench you for significant portions of the game?  That's not all. No longer is this a game where you get to play. Every five minutes is interrupted by a feature length film. Why would I want to watch fake highlights of the game I just played. I don't need to sit through sports commentary on my career. I want to play the damn game. Literally every quarter there is a video of going to the locker room or sitting with the coach. Then between games there is your sponsors, your family, and other garbage to sit through. I like having a bit of commentary during the game to make it feel more real but this is ridiculous. However, if you like that stuff them it won't be a problem.

While some might criticize the choice strictly for the themes involved, 100% OJ is actually a very well-structured and fairly balanced game. Easy to learn but tough to master, it's nice to pass the time with and has plenty of replayability in terms of multiplayer and the near infinite combinations of decks, characters, and maps. There's also plenty to unlock in terms of cosmetics, and it's especially refreshing to see a game completely free of micro-transactions and the pay-to-win mentality, as none of the unlockables give any advantage, just spruce up characters to taste. Not to mention the game is still being supported years after release with content updates, DLCs, new achievements, and seasonal events.  One bit of advice though: Stay off the boards. While at times friendly, the community is surprisingly elitist when it comes down to it, perhaps because the Fruitbat devs monitor their forums closely enough to equate feedback into rebalancing, and this has spoiled the recipients somewhat. That or they were just ****s to begin with. Decide for yourself.
Early Access Review

A twin stick shooter that was made by a man who loves addictive gameplay as much as he hates epileptics. It's like Audiosurf's more aggressive and rave-y cousin. Very fun and overlooked, with its only real flaws being that it works best with very fast-paced music and that visual intensity affects score. Comes with a nice default library of songs that are fun to play and surprisingly good listening. It also has a very interesting perk system that forces you to decide between the safety net of extra weapons/power-ups and boosting your multipliers to get the highest score possible.

During the lead up to release I was of the opinion that this game was unrecoverable, but I think it's gone from unrecoverable to suitably recoverable in a few patches. It still has many issues and incomplete features, and is likewise not worth $40 unless you are a 40K fan (and regularly pay $40 for a box of plastic men still on the sprues).  What is it: Eternal Crusade is a lobby third-person shooter set in the Warhammer 40,000 universe. The ideal gamemode is about 16 v 16. There is facilitation of both melee and ranged gameplay. Players can customize their loadouts with things like power swords, combi-bolters, lascannons, artificier armor, power klaws, meltaguns, and so on. You can play as an Ork, a Space Marine, a Chaos Space Marine, or as an Eldar. Each faction has classes set up in a similar manner to Team Fortress 2. The melee combat is sort of a rock-paper-scissors setup where heavier melee weapons endure longer when 'rock meets rock'.  Largest issue: Movement The animations are clunky and inorganic. You cannot jump unless you have a jetpack, so a tiny bump in the ground can prevent you from moving or even combat-rolling over it. Melee attacks teleport you forwards; it is a 'lunge'. Besides technical issues like desync or framerate, it is an issue in large melee cluster♥♥♥♥s because everyone is teleporting around. 'Battle lines' do not form so allies (or enemies) shooting into the melee end up shooting you or your allies just about as much as they shoot their intended target.  Vehicle movement is just as bad. Invisible walls or environmental objects prevent you from doing anything creative with vehicles. You are restricted to narrow predetermined paths.  Further:  The game has an issue communicating what is happening on-screen. Many actions do not have sounds, their sound doesn't always play, or their sound effect is not audible enough, whether from low volume or lack of punctuation. An example of this is throwing grenades. Sometimes your character will announce throwing the grenade. Sometimes they won't. Sometimes you will hear and see the grenade throw animation. Sometimes you won't. Almost all of the time you won't even hear the grenade explode.  Another isssue is that the player camera is too close to your character and your FOV is very restricted. Space Marine [Game] did that better, there is just no question about it.  The game has a PvE mode against Tyranids. It is an incomplete feature. Just ignore it.  It is a full-priced game with micro-transactions concerning functional items (weapons) and cosmetic-only items. Players power increases with level and due to low population will inevitably throw max level players with low level players. There are RNG lootboxes for weapon mods and skins.  Items cannot be melted in exchange for credits, though you can't get duplicates, so eventually a tier of lootbox will tell you that you already have all the items you can get with that lootbox. You can access all weapon types without paying any more than the base price with a bit of in-game earned currency.  The interface requires 7 clicks to get to a weapon and modify it or change it.  There are balance issues (one faction more powerful than all others).  Overall I applaud the developers for being brave enough to work on this game and release it in the end, but it is a mess and every aspect of the game's design could have been better if it were copied from another game, and pasted here with a Warhammer skin on it. It tries to copy Space Marine [Game] and fails; it tries to be unique and succeeds in creating a uniquely terrible game.  I am sorry, guys. I know you worked really hard but your last hope is to delay the console release as much as possible and hope it attracts a crowd there. Here, on Steam, this game risks being unrecoverable. I thank you for all the hard work you have done, and I will enjoy it as much as I can.

Everything you'd expect from a Double Fine game: interesting gameplay, unique and colorful art style, funny and fun. The bloodline system is ingenious! The tactical combat is rather simplistic but still satisfying, though sometimes it feels repetitive especially in the latter years if you've nothing left to gain but victory. The kingdom management is probably the shallowest aspect of the game; still fun but less interesting as choices dwindle. Character classes are an interesting lot, and the leveling system feels good. Random events are wickedly fun to discover. The enemies are cool, but I think the game would have benfitted greatly from a few more mob types and bosses. Overall good game and easily replayable. Sure its not perfect but it's perfectly fun! I'm MASSIVELY happy to have backed it and recommend it anyone interested in something new!

It's the better, more realistic version of CoD, as well as a much nicer and better community. Most people that are angry are usually just joking. I've so far only encountered 2 lobbies out of 10 that have had a few angry players, but none that are comparable to 12 year old squeakers that believe they know everything about the game, merely just anxious players trying to make their point come across to their teammates. Challenging, fun, fulfilling. I'd love to see what gets added on to this game throughout the years!

Guacamelee is such a fun platformer - even if you're not completely sure about getting the game, DO IT! There is a strong Latin American (Mexican) presense in the game, perfect for anyone, even if you know no Spanish. There are plenty of jokes and easter eggs, but combat and core gameplay are what really make this. Every level has a new set of challenges, different from the last, so each portion of the game feels fresh. Bosses are hard, but not impossible, making for awesome and fast-paced battles. The story is alright, but I think the added DLC makes up for it. Do yourself a favor and pick up the game!

Reviews clearly don't mean anything to the Steam community because somehow this abomination keeps doing well in sales.  If you're a fan of the Heroes of Might & Magic series, avoid this defecation of a 'game' at all costs, because it removes just about everything interesting and fun about the previous games and replaces it with a generic cut and dry style of play that robs the factions of their uniqueness and dumbs the game down into an extremely predictable, formulaic experience.  If you're not a fan of the HoMM series, please, go and buy ANY OTHER Heroes game. If this is the first game in the series you play you'll probably wonder why they made 6 of them considering what an absolute piece of unfun trash this one is. I would recommend this to new players even less than I would to fans because at least fans might appreciate some small scrap buried deep down in the remains of what is now barely recognizable as HoMM.  Oh, it's also horrendously buggy two years after release. It got I think 3 patches released before Ubisoft stopped supporting it and just started releasing DLC. This is nothing but a shameless cash grab, milking dry a classic franchise that could've had so much left to give if Ubisoft wasn't such a terrible company. They drove the original developers to bankruptcy and brought in a team of unknowns for a very short time after release to salvage the mess as much as they could - there were constant crashes and glitches that would totally halt your progress through a campaign mission and force a restart, and some of these persist to this day.  And then there's the highly intrusive uPlay integration for those of you who dislike aggressive 3rd party DRM on your Steam games.  Overall there is no reason for anyone to buy this game. If just one person sees this review and chooses not to give Ubisoft their money because of it, it was worth typing out.
