Addictive Tower Game that is more than just another gem game. Don't let the title confuse you - there is no need to have played the prior versions of this game to jump into this one. Further, there is much more mathematical and stats depth to this game than what I initially expected. You can really self-modify this game (don't confuse this as a software mod, I am referring to modifying settings and difficulties in-game). There are many different ways to earn bonuses via the stratified difficulty settings by category and type. The variables are so many - each playthrough of this game could become very unique. This is like RPG meets Tower Game. Admittedly, I am satisfied especially with the 75% off sale price during the current Steam sale, so if you're waiting for a similar price point, it comes around.

Just Cause 2...ah yes. If Michael Bay made a game, it would be Just Cause 2!  One of the best games I have ever played. The map is just colossal (larger than GTA 5's map) and so versatile with vast and clear blue ocean, snowy mountains, tropical forests, deserts and city environments. The story is hilarious! You, Rico Rodrigez (badass), team up with 3 criminal factions in order to overthrow a crazy midget president (yes a midget) by causing loads of explosions. This game is so expansive and crazy, it's the epitome of open world. And then there's the free multiplayer mod, all the explosive madness of the single player just with 1000 more players, absolutly hilarious. For a game thats 5 years old Just Cause 2 is absolutly amazing. If you can't wait for Just Cause 3 (which i'm so looking forward to) then buy it! Explosion!

This game was amazing, plain and simple. Trying to explain the plot is so difficult because of the interwoven themes and genres that baffles me still about how well it works.   Mechanically, I never felt once like my choices were just tossed off and without meaning, just a number that ultimately turns out the same. Every choice had weight. Some choices were difficult. Some were ultimately very satisfying. All were interesting.  That is something -very- hard to pull off these days, but through masterful writing and an impactful story, they have made it real.   All in all, this game is way more than what I had purchased it for. Not just for the fact that I'm probably going to restart the experience anew right after writing this, but for an experience unlike any story I've seen or heard of before. This is a rare gem, and I thank the creator for it graciously.

app_name: Adventure Chronicles: The Search For Lost Treasure
review_text: I remember enjoying Escape The Museum, the previous game, where the heroin was stuck in her museum with her daughter after a violent earthquake. Here, Susan is contacted by a mysterious man that will trigger a trip all around the world.  Adventure Chronicles is belonging to what I call the early era of hidden objects games, in other words, where you're cleaning scenes by finding items on a list. So don't expect a game where you're roaming around and solving puzzles. However, the game adds some elements like items you need to dust/find in broken containers/behind burnable stuff. In other words, you'll have a lighter, an hammer and a brush to help you. Other items will need specific ones that will be used only in the scene. There is also a 'geocache' object to discover, with a riddle describing it.  While the game can be finished quickly, if you want a 100%, you're free to come back a second time in the scenes to find another list. It's a nice way to invite you to play it completely.  However, keep in mind that some objects are little in size or so well hidden that you can't see them without a proper orientation of your screen. This is the main problem with these games from the first era and Adventure Chronicles doesn't escape from that.  The backgrounds are correct and the soundtrack is also nice.  That said, Adventure Chronicles, while I love it as I've played a retail version of it years ago, right now, in 2015, should mainly enjoy the hardcore fans - as the genre headed towards an adventure oriented mechanics and that new fans will be probably disappointed and be bored quickly.

app_name: Game of Thrones - A Telltale Games Series
review_text: I bought this game as soon as it came out.  I don't regret my purchase, but I wish I had waited until the end. The episodes are too spaced out for you to remember everything that you did and who all the characters are.   Time will tell, but it really doesn't seem like the choices I made matter that much. Every time you get things working for your house, no matter how good or bad they are, you seem to get knocked back to square one.   I still look forward to the rest of the game, but I think the game left a lot of potential on the table with the IP and the nature of all the 'what-ifs' in the series.

Strife was a great game in its day, and it still holds up. This port, however, I've had no luck with. The mouse movement is terrible, both jerky and unresponsive (and this is the 'fixed' version, so I hate to think what it was like before). Setting an Xbox gamepad is painful, there are no default layouts, or suggested layouts. Honestly, buy this for the wad files, and play it in a better sourceport.

DMC is all about the action, and it definitely delivers in that regard. Fighting as Dante, you are able to pull off some of the most incredible combos with your weapons. By the end of the game, you have quite the arsenal and it is incredibly rewarding to incorporate your many weapons into your combos. From the fast angel weapons, the reliable sword, or the slow but powerful demon weapons, I found that I used all of his melee weapons regularly. The ranged attacks were less interesting. Swinging to and pulling enemies was also incredibly fun. The story was fine, but nothing special overall. The characters were interesting overall, with Kat and Mundus being some good examples. There was also a nice sense of progression due to how rapidly you unlocked both new weapons, abilities, and combos. There were also several very humorous parts, and the music is very adrenaline-rushing-good. All in all, I'm pleased with DMC. The Vergil's Fall DLC continued the story further, but Vergil was not quite as fun to play with as Dante. It was interesting to utilize the same combat system with a different skillset, and Vergil's increased ranged strength was nice. However, his 3 melee weapons did not offer much in the way of variety. Also, the story here is even weaker than the base game, which docked some of the points overall. The one flaw with the game was that the camera control could be quite frustrating at times, and I also felt like I lost more health from missing jumps than I did in fights. I do look forward to other Ninja Theory combat games after this impressive title.  85/100

SINGLE PLAYER - Nearly a perfect sandbox first person shooter  MULTIPLAYER -  The actual multiplayer is fun and fast paced. The issue? The multiplayer is so broken that it could take you literally an hour to find a game, and after one game, Farcry 3 will crash. After every multiplayer game. This is because Ubisoft chooses to not have dedicated servers and make people play through their service called uPlay. You can't play with steam friends. You have to add your friends on uPlay. You don't get steam achievements, you get uPlay achievements. uPlay is literally the dumbest thing ever and Ubisoft should be ashamed of themselves for releasing Farcry 3 and not EVER fixing the multiplayer crashes and bugs. I'm not the only one who experiences this, almost every player who plays on direct x11 will deal with it. A small number of people can play fine with Direct 9x but why limit yourself so much graphical degration for a game you payed for that should of been COMPLETE. I'm never buying another Ubisoft game again. They lost my buisness and i highly reccommend you not buy any Ubisoft games if your interested in playing any Multiplayer. They've also been known to intentionally degrade graphics on PC on some of their games to make it look more like the console versions. (Watch Dogs for example) Thumbs up my review, let people know before they buy. The decision is yours!

You are Marius Titus, a Roman Centurion who must defend the city from the barbarian hordes descending from the North.  The game follows Marius' efforts to defend the people of Rome and flashbacks reveal his past campaigns and experiences leading up to the final battle.  Looks awesome, but enemies only have a few different skins (so you kill the same people hundreds of times) and the game is basically the same thing over and over in different places.  This is a game I do like, but wouldn't say is a must-play.  As far as medieval sword and shield combat is concerned it is solid, very addicting to play.   Once you get the hang of it it is a lot of fun, but the plot is a stereotypical historical-looking fantasy revenge story.  The multiplayer has great replay value, but can still get old after awhile.  Recomend, but pick up on sale if you can.

Nice combination of several mechanics that create a pretty unique tactical turn based yet real time strategy. It's got a good sense of aesthetics and it feels nice and beefy in content. The additional unlockable companions and ships are a neat touch. Mechanics are simple, although controls take some time to get used to and to master (I'm still learning), There is a decent amount of maps and modes to play, the graphics are nice and the music is pleasing to the ears. It lacks single player mode though and there aren't that many players online so far so if you don't have friends who also own this game you need to reconsider buying this game. Also, since there are no categories for players you may end up against a true master and be slaughtered. Still I recommend trying this game because it is fun, just be sure to not reach 2h limit in case you think it's not your cup of tea.

Bought this in the sales for £3, an interesting and engaging title, if a little too short. The game throws you in at the deep end, literally, and you take control of the female protagonist as you try to figure out exactly wtf is going on, a decent variation in gameplay keeps the whole thing flowing nicely and whilst the voice acting isn't exactly Oscar winning material, it's decent enough.  Keeping in mind this a small Indie developer title, i was pleasantly surprised by how enjoyable it was, some gripes i have with the game: It CTD five times, all during the first act, which resulted in the game being unable to detect my savegames next time i ran it, thankfully they were all still there, the game just refused to 'see' them. The devs are aware of this and say that simply quitting and restarting the game fixes it, sadly not for me, so i resorted to starting a new game and copying my old savegames over the new ones, the game was then able to see them fine. I'd still recommend it though.

A nice decent game. I got it for free, (which was great) and I'm pretty satisfied. It's a nice relaxing game game, with no clear objective or storyline. The plot is that you are a solar-powered craft flying and the sun, which powers your craft, is setting. You can collect energy boosts that, for a split second, stop the sun from setting. The endless concept is not something new (at all), but this game is. Good graphics and ambience, and it kind of reminds me of an iPad game I have called Forever Drive  (https://itunes.apple.com/en/app/forever-drive/id442923846?mt=8)  which had futuristic graphics with an endless concept AND a map editor- a perfect replica, only race-themed.  So, conclusion: I'd recommend it, but not for it's full price. Get it in a bundle, or when it's on sale.

app_name: Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten
review_text: I first played the demo version on my old laptop (R.I.P) four years ago after seeing it on XGen. I was really addicted to it, even though it was short 'cuz it was a demo. I was amazed by it's unique gameplay, setting and mostly the music. I remember that I kept humming the soundtrack for it all the time. I then forgot about the game, and soon, my laptop broke. Fast forward four years later, seeing this on sale in Steam. When I saw it, I thought 'Hey, why not buy it after all these years?' and so I did.  The game now looks different, however the soundtrack and the gameplay is still the same. Then I looked into the options and saw you can change the art style to the original one. Obviously, I picked the original, since the game feels more better that way. It's better to play it like you've played it before.   I really recommend this game because of the unique gameplay, and you could probably fall in love with the soundtrack. I am currently humming the map theme now as I type this review. There's really not much else to say, since it's better if you experience it first-hand. Go on, get it while it's on sale. Totally worth it.

140 is an amazing platformer game. It took me about 3 hours to complete the normal levels, and it was very fun. I totally recommend this game to anyone who is thinking of spending their money on it. If you're like me, the difficulty of the levels will make you focus more. But if you're not like me, you'll probably be throwing your computer out the window on the final level.  Ratings: Music: 10/10 - Amazing soundtrack! The way the sounds of the objects doing different things morph in with the soundtrack is really nice. The soundtrack is definitely my favorite part of this game. I would normally put a 'Sound Effects' thingy after this one, but, the sound effects are practically the music... Graphics: 7/10 - Minimalistic graphics, but that doesn't take away the fun of the game! Gameplay: 9/10 - Gameplay difficulty is well-balanced. The only part I don't like is that part before the final boss where you have to jump across cubes that are expanding and shrinking, while huge cubes of static slam down on them, squashing you. Overall: 9/10

I only play PvP Meltdown and I love it.   Its a refreshing change from my usual diet of aim heavy FPS games (Quake, Dirty Bomb etc..) although quite similar to Dirty Bomb in its own way with the combination of team composition, positioning and wave timing being important for success (at least in Meltdown)  I love shooters but find MOBA's too boring, this takes the two styles and makes a whole new fun one of its own.  -- EDIT After playing over another 100 hours --  Still playing Meltdown and still enjoying it as much as the first week. Sure, there are a lot of issues that they need to look at :  1. Matchmaking 2. Frame rate for certain maps (and AMD cards in general) 3. Scoring system encouraging kills rather than objectives (minions etc..)  but the core gameplay is so good that I keep coming back night after night.   There seems to be relatively few games these days where you can really mount an amazing comeback..You're over 100 minions down, 1 guy keeps calling a surrender vote, everyone else is saying keep calm, just get some levels and stick together and slowly but surely everyone starts to focus together, the waves get cleared, you pick off a few kills, the minion scores start to even up and you can feel the other team start to lose hope, they start throwing themselves at you but never quite getting enough kills to turn the tide of the comeback. In the last few minutes of the game the minion scores goes in our favour and its a glorious hard won victory. NEVER SURRENDER.  If you're the kind of person who likes a game with layers and depth that really rewards how much time you put in I can't recommend this enough.  (Again, this is all Meltdown, tbh I think it would have made a great game all by itself)

Reminds me very much of the classic Thief-games, much more than other modern stealth titles; stealth and avoiding confrontation is really important, as often even a single enemy can kill you. Explore your surroundings, learn the patrol routes of the enemy, find the holes you can slip through, or create the by making distractions and/or killing a few enemies here and there. The game is really vertical in nature, meaning you can climb ledges and rafters to find safer routes.  All in all a very fun title, if not quite a classic. Graphics are nothing particularly great but more than adequate, and the only real minus are the occasionally clumsy controls + the annoying boss fight. Still, a recommended title for fans of sneaking around undetected.

I spent 1.9 hours on it and never got past the first mission.  Refund Requested.

I have a few hours in this game now, enough to say that I can write a review.  Firstly if you are into visceral melee combat in a game, this is your game. There are points where you are swamped by so many Skaven (Rat men to the non initiated) that swiping your attack through the heads of many is as enjoyable combat can get in any game.  While many play this sort of genre because they like zombies, and I forsee some not liking it because they are rats (My fiancé is a LFD2 fan 1500+ hours) but for anyone who just loves the play style then you will love this game.  Graphics: The graphics are modern, dark, dirty, medievalesque with a high attention to detail. The immersion brought on by the graphics is superb. Walking around a corner and seeing a Skaven shadow cast on the floor as it's creeping over the roof above you, to only be skewed by a teammates arrow as his head appears over the ridge, I have an asus gaming laptop and this game runs exceptionally smoothly at 1080 ultra wide with everything up to high, no slow down at all.  Sound: The voice acting is the most shining star in this the audiophiles torrent of sound. Each character, each script is perfectly chosen. The skaven themselves taunt you, talk amongst themselves when they think they are alone, and the ominous tone of the Skaven attack bell is enough to send a weight into the pit of your stomach.  Gameplay: Apart from the obvious afore mentioned viscaral combat, and what seems to be exceptionally balanced items. The gameplay is a good mix of horde/tank/scavenger gameplay with some interesting things into the mix. One of these things are that there are multiple paths and plenty of hidden areas to explore as you race through the map. Stay in place too long however unique rats, assasins, ratling gun skaven, packmasters, globe throwers are there to attack you at random. But these special rats are NOTHING when compared to the Rat Ogre. This brute can be agroed with ranged weapons with ease, however his blows are nothing short of untankable almost all the time. In harder difficulties these special Skaven can wipe your team in second. However for me, the sound I dread is the marching, clanking formation of the elite Skaven pack rats. Their high HP, high damage if allowed to surround your team will annhilate you faster than you can regroup.  One last thing. Expect to fail if you go alone with bots they can't cut it with only one real person in the team. Also expect to fail in your first couple of runs unless you are carried by your team. This game is different and it will take some getting used to. However, you will take some Skaven heads, you will be spinning around for where that Assasin went, and you will run from the ratogre.
Game has bugs, Lips sometimes don't even move, TokiToki City is small and you can move around clumsily just like this was a low end PS2 era game.  You can also be a SSJ.  10/10 Nostalgia

Classic Batman at his finest. Arkham Asylum is a dark and brooding facility used to treat the mentally insane. It has been home to the Riddler, Mr. Freeze, The Penguin, and a variety of other classic batman villains, who leave their distinct mark on the facility in the form of posters, interview tapes, and other goodies you can find allover. The Joker gives a stellar performance, with Harley Quinn, and his various clowny goons for backup, in what amounts to a fantastic piece of 'experience' gaming, allowing you to take on the role of the Batman himself, and all of his gadgets, gizmos, whatsits, and his predatory shadow stalking style. Arkham is mostly open to player exploration and includes many little secrets to unlock and discover, but many of the areas have to be unlocked through story progression or attaining a specific type of gaget. Overall, it's freely explorable once you have access, and the voice performances are 5 star. The physics also the rock the world.

I played the PS3/4/PC version and i have to say the PC version is the best , but it has some bugs. like the slowmode bug and the white border bug. Solutions to that can be found on the Steam Forum.  The Game runs beautifully at 60fps @ 1080p on my PC.  If you call yourself a real survival horror fan, you need to get this game. BEST Horror Game (in my opinion followed by Silent Hill 2 )

Welp tired of seeing so many reviews from people with under an hour play time. Even just a few hours rlly isnt enough to give it a good review. People i guess were just itching to write negative reviews when this came out lol I mean theres always gonna b issues on launch, especially nowadays xD No need to say the game is complete garbage cuz of it -_- But heres my view on the game so far at 12 hours playtime:   The game progresses a bit slow until you get use to how things work and what you need to do. there is a bit of key objectives that do progress u in the universe. After doing these objectives some things will then start showing up, one example is an anomoly that was suddenly in an old solar system i recently explored. If your someone who wants some super fast pace fps shooter with mild exploration, this isn't for you. its a casual pace exploration with a wide variety of environments. i believe, not 100% sure, u'll see a more variety of planets and creatures the farther you go in the main objectives and farther you explore from your starting spot. You'll gradually learn a bunch of different languages that help you with speak to creatures, which cang et you nice stuff. you'll stock up of tons n tons of upgrades for everything which lets you custimize what your using for how u like it. If you want a bullet bouncing, cone exploding plasma gun, you can do that, or you want a mining lazer that will never overheat and does huge damage to creatures, you can do that too. all these mods r based off your one muli tool you start with. you eventually find ones with more slots for upgrades which let you really deck out your gun to your liking. Same custimization goes for your ship and even your exosuit. And the only way to find so many blueprints is simply exploring, cant really rush the game to get a decent experience at all. Planets i explored never had too many creatures(yet) n most were barren with not much vegitation but closer you get to center the more plentiful the planets become(from what i read that is). the combat is a bit funky at first as well(still getting use to space fights xD) but its satisfying when you get use to it :D so Overwall:  Cons:  -Very Time consuming -slow progression -Not an action packed fps -Cant build structures(as far as i know atm) -Space fights are tough to get use to -Can have bad spawn locations(such as super cold/hot temps or radiation) -limit starting inventory space  Pros: -Looks amazing -lots to explore -Nice casual gameplay (space fights r evil tho) -a lot of diff creatures(some are basicly reskinned tho) -Simply Fun and entertaining -earnng ingame cash isnt hard -a lot of surprises with every solar system(anomolys, black holes, space pirates, ect) -able to custimize weapon/personal suit/space ship -tons of mods for gear -Get to break into places with explosives @_@ - much more since i barely scratched the surface of this game  Overwall if your not sure wether to get this game you can wait it out. see more vids and reviews, but if your looking for a casual game to kill some time and you enjoy exploring new areas, then BUY IT. You'll love it ^^

Corpse of Discovery is a pretty weird but unique title, you will start each day with a main objective, normally to explore a vast unknown world but something seems off as the dialogue comes across that things keep happening around you, how'd you get there, what is the real aim and where are things going.   The game looks visually stunning, from what seems like the vast lands of Mars to an exotic and colourful world to explore but dangers around every corner. Your character is after the truth, to get back to his family but questions remain about why you're really there.   Check out the video for a little more insight into how it plays, looks and feels.    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tZppJVGHwxM

Here is an honest review...  The game itself is great. It's basically what Cube World was suppose to be and more. If you don't know what Cube World was, then let me go ahead and just describe what Trove is instead. In Trove you can go into randomly generated worlds filled with dungeons and a scant few other interesting things. Clear dungeons for loot, mine for ore, fish, etc. The goal is pretty much just to level up and get the best gear, so it's not unlike other MMOs in that sense. The game also features some optional building elements (building a home/etc).   All of that being said, the game suffers from major server issues. Trion, the developers, are notorious for hosting their games on extremely low quality servers and Trove is no exception to this. 'Rubberbanding', or the server lagging to the point that you are instantly reverted to your previous location from a few secions prior, is a common occurance. Waiting for the server to load the land infront of you is not in any way uncommon. The average ping you could expect to be playing is is anywhere from 200 to 1,000. Now 1,000 ping may seem bad, but it's a hell of a lot better then when the servers are down, which is quite often. There is rarely a day that goes by when the servers are not shut down, without any warning might I add, for an hour or two. Pretty much every time the game is updated, majory or just by a hotfix, you should expect the servers to be down anywhere from 2 to 12 hours.

Well worth the wait. A nearly infinite galaxy to explore, filled with rich, exciting planets - all with things to do! Scan for new lifeforms, be the first to catalogue them, mine and sell your materials for credits, use the credits to upgrade your ship, suit, and tools. Or you can simply fly around and take in the sights. Is the game perfect? Hell no. There are a few glitches here and there, but does this deserve the crap ratings it's getting on Steam? Hell no, again. This game is amazing. Appreciate the hard work that went into it up to this point - and trust that the developer will continue to work tirelessly to fix the minor issues ongoing.   If you have an old crap PC and GPU, then don't get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if your FPS is 10. I'm running this on a 4k gaming rig, i7 5820, GTX 1080, etc etc, and I'm getting 60+ fps in 4k.

app_name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
review_text: THIS GAME LOOKS BEAUTIFUL!!!!   If you enjoy games that have great atmosphere and music (like Trine) then you will love this game.   Unfortunately it's over way too fast with a play time of 3-4 hours depending on whether you spend time trying to get the achievements and how much time you spend soaking in the beautiful scenery. The game is pretty linear and the puzzles are mostly designed to see how well you can manipulate both control sticks and triggers (I highly recommend a gamepad) at the same time. The story is also fairly simple with the characters only communicating in gestures and a sort of gibberish leaving the story to be told through the visuals (did I mention that they're beautiful).  As beautiful as the game is $15 is a little bit steep in my opinion unless you REALLY like just walking around listening to music and looking at the visuals instead of proceeding with the story. It has been on sale for pretty cheap many times and I definitely recommend picking it up on sale.

80% - Mafia II: The Real Mafia Experience  This game opens up as an interesting story that keeps going until ends up on an even more interesting story, going from a thief wanna-be that joins the US Army Light infantry Airborne unit to ends up as one of the biggest Mob leaders of New yor...... Empire city.  The first mafia has been just a rip off from The Godfather (IMHO, best PS2 game ever). But this game REALLY does a good justice to the genre of mobsters sandbox. Of course, there are flaws, but nothing too big. The weapons are somewhat lacking, and the ammo is not universal between some of them like how it should be (the .45 ammo used in both M1911, and both Thompsons) and the Crosshairs are not really useful either at all... but this is not the first time we have seen this, so its not really game-breaking.  The graphics DOES looks dated somewhat, then again, we are talking about an 2010 game here, but trust me, it won't look like that in a lot of times, the biggest complaint would be also that the Cutscenes are not rendered with the same quality than the in-game engine, but that they are inferior too (something odd and EXTREMLY rare in games). But the shadow quality is at least, good, and i cant say much bad about the textures either.  The game tries too hard to be interactive, maybe a little bit too hard. Some parts of it itself are glitching because the interaction is up to where your character is looking, not where you are pointing at, and being a Third Person Shoter, that's not a good idea. Not that its a big problem, after all, almost nothing that you can do inside your house is really useful... you will be only using the fridge, the guardrobe, maybe the radio, and the phone for certain missions.  Talking about the radio, a big complain would be the lack of radio stations, in the first part of the game that takes in the 1945 has just 3 radio stations (too little) but at least the song in them its not bad, its pretty good. Then, after the second half wich takes you into the US of 1951, the radio stations are there, with the music of the time, not even their names changed.  Now that i mentioned the second half, i have to say, its REALLY well done as an enviroment, some places changed, the cars changed, and you can see everything by yourself how the whole US changes in the time of the war and after the war.  The main difference of the 2 parts would be the weather, wich in the first part is snowing (vehicle handling is affected) and the second part is Autumn/Summer.  About vehicle handling: Its no TDU or car simulator, but its doing a pretty damn good job at it. I haven't touched the arcade setting, but the realistic vehicle handling its just fantastic.  The AI its just the good old classic Sandbox AI, TERRIBLE. And the cops may look like if they took car driving lessons from the ones in GTA. But at last, the Cops AI its not so bad, it does behaves somewhat in a realistic manner, the only exception would be that going over a red light its not considered law infringement, or at least i haven't been chased by passing over a red light.  This game is FORCING YOU to stay in cover, wether this is good or bad, its up to you. Also, i should be explaining that the AI only reacts to you, yes, granted, this is better than COD, friendly AI actually does something, but the game really put the spotlight on you.  The system to buy things is bad. You cant buy cars, the tunning its not good until you have unlocked everything in the last section of the game, and the cloth stores do not tell you wich item you have already bought before, or wich one you haven't. This is turning the game into a more GTA IV style approach, as you cant even buy houses (not that it really matters, as there are just 4 houses for you, starting one, first half, mid half, and a bad last half one).  The dialog is greatly written, and there is nothing else to say that i just love it.  You WILL have to remember that this game doesn't give a thing about your money, as in 2 parts of the game they force you to leave everything behind.  There is a lotpicking minigame to steal cars, but dont get too excited, it may be silent, but its still attracting cops, its not really realistic at all (how hard would it be to make it realistic? really!), but its a nice add to the general game.

Great action match-3 game. Getting enough loot to upgrade you weapon or getting another perk means constant getting just far enough that you can always feel that the end is *just* a few monsters away. You'll finish it before it gets too repetitive (and I took even longer to finish it than the avarage). Oh and then there is the music. A perfect match to the game and it's a delight every time *that* track starts playing.

THE ONLY BUG IN THE GAME: I'll start with the one thing which broke the atmosphere of the game, (for me anyway), the bug which exists in the DLC tomb. I got annoyed with this because i simply don't expect there to be a bug in the DLC, but it wasn't really all that much of an issue to be honest.  THE FIX: Simply leave the tomb and re-enter it and the bug will auto-fix meaning you can complete the tomb.   That was the ONLY issue i had with the game, the rest of the game played flawlessly for me from start to finish.   A BIT OF A POINTLESS RAMBLE: I've played most of the Tomb Raider series from the Playstation 1 era, and while i never completed them and found them boring after a while because i didn't know where to go (my fault) i still bought the next installment of the game when it was released because there was something that i did enjoy about the games.   Since the PS1 era games, i haven't played another Tomb Raider until this one, and since playing this one i have the urge to go and get the others before it and play them, not sure why, but i do.   REVIEW:  I enjoyed Tomb Raider from start to finish, minus the DLC bug, but even the DLC was worth it as it added some more room for learning and getting familiar with the mechanics of the game a little more.  Everything from the look of the game (graphics and art style) to the voice acting and gameplay mechanics made this game very immersive, and i felt like i actually cared about the main character. There was at times the old fashioned Tomb Raider camera niggles leaving you not totally sure about where to jump next, but i found that just going with the flow worked out rather than thinking about it too long.   The gameplay is fluid and the puzzle solving isn't overly complicated or complex to the point of silly, if anything I'd say they lightened up a little in this department, (going from memory of the Tomb Raider games on PS1), but the puzzles were very rewarding and there was a lot of thought put into them and some times i was left stumped as to what to do next.   I loved the hunting for survival aspect of the game, even though i wouldn't have actually died if i didn't hunt, i still loved this aspect of the game. Perhaps next installment of Tomb Raider they could actually impliement that into the game. I personally hope they do. It's not like a Tomb Raider can put things on hold while they head on down to the store for some pizza and nachos.   The Skill and Salvage aspect of the game works very well indeed, i actually did look forward to earning a skill point or getting some salvage it added greatly to the immersiveness of the game. It also made searching every nook and cranny of the environment more of a need instead of a chore, and there was never a point in this game where i felt like i was doing something that felt like a chore. I enjoyed searching and rooting around environment, just in case i found something awesome that would help me or give me enough salvage to go upgrade one of my weapons.   From here on out, I'll certainly be riding on the Tomb Raider bandwagon, and looking forward to the next installment.  I hope they continue the story and in the meantime, I'll be going back to some of the older (graphically modern) Tomb Raiders.  I'm so glad this was on sale, otherwise i wouldn't have bothered with it thinking it was going to be like the old PS1 style, actionless and directionless puzzling platformer type gig. This game got me hooked on Tomb Raider!

This is the simplest yet most deep game you can get. I am current just over 1000 hours in, and I can tell that I'm no where near done learning. Theres more to do, always room to improve. By far the most accessible competitive game out there. Worth the $20, though I would pay hundreds for the time I've enjoyed it. Buy this game.

This game is just what Diablo 3 should have been.   It's more of a predecessor of Diablo 2. It's dark, it's gothic.   Lots of items and skill variety and the to playthrough the story was a blast. It keeps you constantly going as your character develops and you just want another upgrade before logging out.   The only downside so far in my opinion is the Multiplayer mode.   I didnt had any crashes or the like, but you can basically compare it with Diablo 2 Open Battle Net. So its possibly to play with a cheated character and ♥♥♥♥ like that.   If they would put a bit of work into a Multiplayer mode with server saved characters like closed bnet, it would be a hell of a game.   Either way, you can put hundreds of hours into it and playing with friends you know is still a blast.

This game isn't all bad. The gameplay resembles mass effect 3's multiplayer, as was said multiple times. Though what I do need to say is that the last thing this game will do is hold your hand and tell you what to do. I left the tutorial knowing how to run, do some of the parkour and some of the other basics. Though I had no idea of mods, getting materials and other things.  I mean, most of my success was from playing mass effect and using some common sense. Though I feel quite helpless without my friends, and i dont enjoy playing alone at all. I dont expect tobe told about everything, but the equipment part of the game is very confusing and very much turned me off. The leveling up (not affinity) requires you to be put in a, what I feel at least to be an extremely unnecessary and bland 'test'. You fight enemies in a computer generated landscape almost copypasted from assasins creed. They dont tell you anything about it, which feels quite weird.  The gameplay is pretty good, and although my military buff side of me doesn't like the impracticality of designs for characters and weapons that is not at all a complaint, because that's just opinion. The core gameplay is fun, but the grind and sheer scale of the game can be frustrating to overcome. I'd give this game a 5/10. (note this isn't gameinformer, 5/10 is average in my books)

Quite simply the best game I have ever played in my 18+ years of playing video games. The world is so immersive, a seemingly endless stream of quests to complete, and so many classes that are all good that you want to play them all (except bard, screw bards). None of the classes are ragingly overpowered, even though mages can feel like it (specifically enemy mages) with time stops and imprisons galore, which just means that you have to be more strategic in spell placement as well as party composition.  Otherwise, there are tons of characters within the game, both companions and NPCs, that are quite interesting, including the ghosts, djinn, statues, etc. that will give you fun riddles. Maybe it's just because the Forgotten Realms world had it's lore well established long before Baldur's Gate became a thing, but whatever it is, this world is unlike anything I have ever experienced before, with little to no hand holding, yet it doesn't feel unfair. There is a strategy to get through everything, you just have to figure it out for yourself.  There are some bugs, but I found them mostly funny. High Watcher Oisig in the base game and a group of peasants in the expansion just kept randomly showing up in the most obscure places, and it was really funny to just see them pop up.  Best moment definitely goes to the part in Throne of Bhaal where a group of dark elves are disguised as random animals. I just wanted to slaughter a moose and, lo and behold, it was actually a drow. Go figure.  10/10 I'm glad I got to experience this for the first time through the Enhanced Edition on steam.

I regret buying this. I loved the first game. It was so close to being perfect, but it had some very game breaking problems that I feel could have and should have been fixed. Instead Zero left it broken and made this.  This is quite obviously unfinished. Lack of balance, basic UI bugs, crazy strong AI that loves to kill you a little too much and seems like it's cheating. At the very least, I'd wait a month or two for some patches.  Beyond the lack of polish, I feel, lies a game that is just inferior to the first. The turn-based systems lack the amount of control that the real-time systems did. For example, you can't reinforce your ships during combat, or position your forces around an enemy before attacking, or make any kind of hit and run moves. Just seems like it loses a lot and gains little, which I think sums everything up perfectly. Can't say i recommend it, and I wish I hadn't supported them.

If you are debating getting the game here are a few things to know:  - It is not a very long game, I completed it in about 3 hours - You can play the game as a single player or in local co-op mode, you are allowed to switch between the two during gameplay - Regarding other reviews that mentioning glitches, I had none. I went into this game with fairly low expectations, thinking it was just going to be a middle of the road shooter with meh story. For the first half hour to and hour that's that I got, but after that the game took off and turned out to be quite the diamond in the rough.  The combat is your standard run and cover style where you're equipped with your primary assault rifle, a secondary (shot gun, sniper, etc.), pistol, and grenade type. This in it self isn't that great, but when you take into consideration you can dismantle enemies it becomes more interesting. If you shoot off their legs they crawl at you, blow off their arms they run in an kick you, snipe their head they become 'friendly' since they don't know who their shooting at anymore. This mechanic saves the meh combat system as you can do some interesting things with it. The boss battles are pretty bad though, often one-shoting you as your teammate just run around yelling at you and telling you where ammo is. The controlls are also a bit wonky, like middle mouse button reload, but it's not that bad once you understand it. But in all honesty you shouldn't buy this game for the combat, you should buy it for the story and characters.  Throughout the game you get introduced to more and more characters you can take with you in your squad during the chapters. You build, or lose, trust with them and can get several different endings to the game depending on this trust level. Nearly all of them are memorable, are well thought out, and amazingly voiced. The over all story had some good unforeseen plot twists as well, making me think it was over about three times before pulling another one out to keep the game going. This is defiantly what you should get the game for.  There is also the unique mechanic of voice recognition. Yep, you can talk to your NPC teammates. This is how you build that trust with your squad during battle and the interactive cut scenes. Did they get a sweet headshot? Praise them with a 'Nice!' or 'Sweet!'. Are they too far ahead? tell them to 'Regroup.' Do you want to confess you undying love for Big Bo? tell him 'Love You' of 'Looking Pretty Sweet'. That being said it can also backfire. I'm not sure if it was something in my set up, but it kept getting my voice lines wrong or not registering them all together. I'd try and tell my team to charge and someone thought I called them an 'Idiot' and just yelled at me and stopped following orders. I'm a streamer though so the audience, and I found it hilarious, this might be annoying for you.  Over all this is a really good game, a truly overlooked gem.

My previous review was poorly worded and executed, so I thought I would simply write a new one that explains why I think that this game is absolutely garbage.  --  1.) The characters are flat. Character development goes nowhere. This point makes me livid, as characters are supposed to be the main focus of your story. They help with the mood, setting, plot, theme, I could go on... But if all your characters are flat, then I don't think your story is very good.  2.) The writing for the story is god awful.  3.) The trailer is deceptive. It includes phrases that promise for features like texting your 'friends', romancing people, and ultimately allowing you to have a huge effect on the plot. Here's a nut-buster, all of these aren't really features, or aren't in the game at all.  4.) The UI for the game is awful, especially for a game worth 10$. Not only does the UX fall behind because of how it looks (the GUI looks as though the game was made from the same engine that made free games like The Witch's House, except those games are better than this one), but it also is rather jarring how the text box jumps into the middle of the screen for player actions, which makes it seem as though the creator didn't think this through.  5.) This is the worst one. The creator of the game self-inserted himself into the plotline. Here's the kick in the balls you were expecting:  --SPOILER WARNING-- He's literally the most happy, creative, artistic, influential, friendly, famous, and ultimately most important person in the game. Once he dies, a ♥♥♥♥-ton of people literally break down into depression. It's naseating how he has the gall to do this. --IT'S FINE AFTER THIS LINE--  It just shows how the creator's mindset is like. Once people started to complain about his game, he literally started to yell back at people, whether or not it was constructive criticism.  6.) The plot is predictable, at least to me.  --  All in all, I wouldn't recommend this game, especially not at 10$.   I hope the creator can actually make better games than this in the future, and, once I read the reviews and pay attention to how people talk about it, I might buy it. But, right now, it seems unlikely that he can make a good game at all.  Hopefully he can prove me wrong.

The game is constantly being tweaked and the developers clearly care about giving the players the best experience they can provide. Overall, a ridiculous amount of fun can be had with this game. I highly recommend giving it a few hours.

I would recommend this game to anyone looking for something new to play. This game in my opinion is one of the best free-to-play games out there and I urge anyone to give it a try! Just like most of the other comments, the graphics aren't the best but it has something about it that makes you want to keep playing and you do get some satisfaction killing other players and bots its that enjoyable. I'm not going to beat around the bush that this game is perfect because it isn't, there are some minor issues that I have been experiencing and I'm not sure if other players are having the same but it doesnt affect gameplay too much, 1) Bullet travel in slow-motion doesn't always level with your cross-hair (if that makes sense?) 2) The game can lag quite a lot depending on the server or map location (the game isn't too demanding but can differ on certain computers) 3) The cross-hair itself needs a little tuning done to it as it feels kinda goofy (personal opinion) 4) Some of the players you might come across are children (to put it kindly). I know I have only played 2.7 hours at the moment, but its been 2.7 hours that has made me laugh due to the people I have been in servers with and the enjoyment factor is brilliant. I hope this review changes your mind if your not too sure about downloading it but all I will say is just give it a try and see if you like it.   P.s - I will type-up another review once I put a few more hours in to the game and see if I come across anymore issues.

It is a nice game made by someone who obviously knew NES games very well. The game painstakingly reproduces visual style of NES and SNES eras, and makes fun of some of the glithces that were found back when. it is obviously inspired by super metroid, although there were areas which looked like homages to titles like Altered Beast.   There are few issues with it, though:   It definitely needs a dash key. Dashing by double-tapping an analog stick is difficult.   Weapon quick selection is ... weird.   Loses momentum after first few hours and becomes quite a bit more boring.   Secrets are a bit too over the top and could be better designed. Some items apparently can only be found by repeatedly probing every wall you find and carefully investigating every part of a map. The strange part is that story can only be uncovered via finding secrets.   Some bosses near the end are cheap. (Bird bee boss, for example)   In short... it is a decent game, but Super Metroid was much more fun when I played it.  Still, for essentially a one-man product, it is damn impressive.  Worth checking out if you're into metroidvanias and retro styled games.

I pre-ordered Deathwing the moment it came on Steam. Waited and waited. Played Beta. Loved it. Game Launch, and there are some serious game breaking bugs present. This was a little saddening. We got a patch, a week or so later, which fixed most of the major problems while creating some new ones.  That all said and done, Space Hulk: Deathwing is absolutely awesome. I'm a huge fan of WH40k and i've always loved Space Hulk. The turn-based virtual re-imagening of the board game by Full Control, was great. The little picture in a picture of what the terminators were seeing in first person had me begging for a First Person Shooter of the Space hulk universe. And boy does this game deliver that.   The Atmosphere is perfect. It is filled to the top and overflowing with WH40k theme and feel. No matter which direction you are facing, you will know you are in the WH40k universe and not some other space ship FPS. The detail put into the textures and the maps is just fantastic.   Though you'll rarely get a chance to stop and admire the beauty of it all, as breathing down your neck almost constantly is the Tyranid Swarm. And Swarm they are. They are fast, they are terrifying and absolutely lethal. You'll not get a moment to check out the beauty and work put into them either as you slay them, wave after relentless wave, with Bolter, Flame and Sword. Due to the player being a Deathwing Terminator, you do not move with the same speed as most other FPSs, so positioning and even the direction you are facing can mean the difference between you, or your squad, being wiped out.   Then there is all the little details. Once you have reduced a wave of Genestealers to nothing but corpses and bloody chunks, listen gleefully as your hulking Terminator's footsteps turn from a thudding stomp to a squelch and squishing noise of blood and guts beneath your boots.  The weapon sounds are awesome, playing with a sqaud of four the resounding noise of the bolters or assault cannons is music to any WH40k fans ears. One of these days a developer will come up with the fantastic idea to have weapon noises with its own sound adjustment in the options menu, so you can turn it up more!   There are lots of little lore and story scenes to be found around each map. making exploring rewarding, albeit dangerous.  Despite being a fast paced and epic FPSs, there is also a fantastic tactical element to the game. Closing and blocking doors behind you as you advance to slow the swarm down or create relative safe areas. There is a very 'Aliens' vibe to this game. One player working to close and lock a door as the other players struggle to hold back the swarm.  I really love this game. It has a few bugs, and more than just some people have had some pretty bad experiences with it. But for me, it is just fantastic. My only real problem with it, is it would be nicer if there were better wargear elements to it. Pick ups and or equipment, much like in the absolutely amazing Dawn of War II's Last Stand. So that you might have two Tactical Terminators that aren't identical. At the moment there are only 9 chapters, and 3 of those chapters will have you going back over some of the same maps. So i dare say, some DLC or expansions will add some more, and hopefully with some desired features that the fans have been asking for.  It's all these things that make for a great First person version of the board game. It is hard, it is brutal, it is fast, it is chaotic, it is epic and it is glorious!

app_name: Five Nights at Freddy's: Sister Location
review_text: This is one of the best games in the entire series, if not the best game. It improves on visuals and the voice acting is brilliantly done. The way the game flows like a story and doing something different each night, instead of doing the same thing every night, but progressively harder. The lore is some of ther best i've seen at this point and the voice acting gives character, personality, and emotions. The lore is more complicated than ever overall the games, but it is still fun, vauge and interseting to find and put together the pieces. The gameplay is more immersive than the past four, and has a great balance of visual and listening gameplay. It surprised me how much listening you had to do. It has element from the past four games, FNAF world, and The Silver Eyes, which helps solve the story even more. It has gamechanging easter eggs that really make us re-think the lore. This is a amazing and brilliant game and i love to bits. This game really changed the fnaf series and felt like a much-needed fresh breeze in the franchise. It even getting a Custom Night! I cant wait for custom night and whatever Scott does next.

In the end during a bout of frustration, I reloaded the game and suddenly, the section I was trying to open opened up, however wasn't registering when I clicked the buttons. So I had to open and close that area for it register. I REALLY wish I could thumbs up the game but I just can't.. That's the first time I've been that frustrated from a game and it wasn't my own stupidy/lack of puzzle knowledge that caused it, if it was, this would have been a very big thumbs up :/.

This review has been changed from positive to negative after the most recent update from 'Crimefest'.  The game by itself is a good game, but these shady antics have officially made a good game turn bad by a shady company going back on previous comments.  At one point in time we were 'shamed' to think this game would ever incorporate microtransactions, now we are seeing them in what can only be described as 'CS:GO' style, by giving you safes like drops in CS:GO, where you have to pay almost 3 dollars of real money for a 'drill' which is essentially a key, to open the safe. This alone wouldn't be terrible as it just gives you a cosmetic skin, except that isn't really the case.  These above mentioned skins give you stat boosts along with being skins, which essentially turns a great game that was already borderline ridiculous with DLC that was accepted, into a game with lots of DLC now being greedy with microtransactions. It's sad to see a great game soiled with greedy producers, especially with a game that went far and beyond expectations with copies sold as well as DLC sold, so it is simple greed that has tarnished a great reputation with one swing.   If you don't mind pay 2 win in a game with tons of DLC already attached to it, then go for it. Yes this is a fun game, but in my opinion there is no place in a full priced game with lots of DLC to also include pay2win microtransactions.   Look elsewhere and save yourself the frustration now.

Well... how to resume that poor Call of Duty clone as fast as possible... easy!  PROS: +The 'WHAT-IF' occupation of America scenario is interesting. +Decent graphics (DX11) +Crouch, prone positions (it is rare that you have the possibility to prone in modern FPS). +Soundtrack is decent +Multiplayer mode has potential, if that's your bag!  CONS: -Improbable silly story. Koreans invading not only USA but many other countries? C'mon! -Campaign playtime is VERY short (3-5 hours top, depending of difficulty level) -Scripted like hell. Lots of enemies running at you until you kill that specific RPG soldier so they stop spawning! -Lots of 'invisible walls'... and door blocking lockers until lifted up by NPC. -Your running speed is like my grandpa walking speed. -Collectibles are annoying to search as your prompted from NPC's to carry on and move on to next objective.  OVERALL: That is about all that come's to mind for now and if you are slightly interested in Homefront, buy it only at a decent deal. Besides, there are plenty of wargames alternatives.  RECOMMENDATION: I only recommend this game for wargames purists, that always want some more wargame and can't seem to fill their shooting needs.  RATING:  5.0 / 10

Played the game during a free weekend FYI.  Honestly, this game was fun but i cannot recommend this game at its current price of $30 (even the on sale price of $15 isn't worth it without friends.)  This game feels a rip-off of a few other games (Left 4 Dead and Payday 2 to name a few). It attempts to copy what made those games great but falls short. The few things it was somewhat innovative in (the ratling gunner and the atmosphere) were well done, but those alone don't justify the price tag. It feels more like you're paying $30 for a tech demo, as the graphics are undeniably beautiful, and even those will grow old. While this game is pretty, there are numerous bugs which should be fixed pronto.  To list my issues, I will first say the 'campaigns' are inconsistent. They are usually too short, as they either end before they get good, or are unable to keep up a good pace once they do grow to be fun. Unlike Left 4 Dead, it feels more like quantity won out over quality. Mods would be very good for this game as it will grow old to anyone who's played every level, which can definitely be done within an afternoon (which is what i did). The weapons and rng are annoyingly imbalanced. Each character is limited by what weapons they could wield, so each time you complete a mission and get a weapon, more than likely you won't even get something you can use on your preferred character. Despite the trinket and updates promising better rng, it still screws over the players.   To finish up, I believe the game is good, but nowhere near the worth of its price, and that will not change unless they provide more content or allow the playerbase to create their own content. This game's players tend to die out over short periods of time (because it grows boring fast), so don't bother purchasing this game at full price until changes are made or with a group of friends when it's on a good sale (50% or more off).

I did hear very postive reports from people I knew about this game and they weren't wrong at all as I found out. First off, It is a free to play title but it's free to play model is very nice but it doesn't really reward you for paying that much, more of a supporting the devs style of microtransactions.  I recommend playing on a standard server for the first 20 levels until you get the hang of it since it can be quite a hard game at times and you don't want to lose your character on hardcore. I haven't played this game that much due to other games that I wanted to play.  The balance is nice and the community relative peaceful and nice for a free to play game since they do kinda hate people who like D3 but as long you don't mention that if you do like it, then you should do just fine. A match 3 game with a nice little twist. You collect troop cards to build on and level up throughout the game, and it's the strength of your team that helps you win each match. You can join a guild and earn numerous rewards. There's a LOT of hours of game play in this game!  You have to earn gold to take part in things throughout the game, and I see numerous negative reviews complaining about how they have no gold to do things throughout the game. I don't understand...even as a casual player, I've earned more than enough gold to do just about anything that I want in the kingdom, and still have a cushion.  The game can be highly addictive, if you like match 3 games. It's not just a mindless match 3 game, either. You have to plan out your moves, otherwise you could end up in some serious trouble.  Of course, you have the option to purchase diamonds to buy special chests and other things in-game, but you can also purchase chests with gold and glory that you earn; although they're not as 'high class' as the diamond chests, they're pretty good nonetheless. Anything you need...except for the diamonds, of course...can be earned in numerous different ways throughout the course of the game.  The game play itself is a lot of fun. Depending on what sort of troop you're playing against, the game can go quickly, or it can be an intensive grind match that lasts and lasts. It's the grind matches that give you a serious sense of accomplishment in the game when you win one, which is something that you really don't find in other match 3 games.  Overall, I think this is an excellent game, and well worth a try for even the most serious match 3 game player!  (Review edited 11-24-2016 to add:)  The longer I play this game, the more I love it. The developers are constantly adding new things and making good changes to keep the game fresh and interesting. It is the one game in my game library that I play all the time, and I keep coming back to it on a daily basis!

Okay, so here's the thing: we all know that Evolve (and Turtle Rock by extension) ♥♥♥♥ed itself over on launch horrendously. They locked a lot of content that should have been in the game from the start behind paywalls on day 1 that should have been at the very least been passed out to players who prepurchased the game, if not just put in the ♥♥♥♥ing game for free. It is completely fair to leave the game for this reason, and to hold that massive and obvious mistake against Turtle Rock and never play this game or buy it ever.  BUT. AND A HUGE BUT. ( ay ;] )  The truth is that despite this insane PR suicide by Turtle Rock, the game is legitimately very fun and polished, and since returning to give it another shot I have enjoyed it quite a lot. After 2 full DLC packs of hunters and monsters, along with multiple map packs and game modes that were added free of charge (and even a couple hunter/monster variations), the game boasts a level of diversity that makes it very diverse and interesting from game to game. Also because map packs and game modes were put in for free, you can still play with just the base game and it works perfectly fine, no limits on matchmaking or anything like that.  If the CURRENT STATE of this game was the state of the game on launch, I garauntee that it would have exploded in popularity and would still be popular to this day, no question.   THAT BEING SAID, there is the obvious issue of the playerbase, which has dwindled significantly over time. Queues are difficult to find and full teams are rare at certain points during the day/night. There is a ranked mode that is pretty much superfluous because there's almost no chance you will ever get to utilize it properly with this few remaining players.  Now then, what does that mean for you, as someone reading this review? Well, right now, during the Winter 2015 sale, the base game along with the first seasons pass (4 extra hunters and 1 monster) costs just $16. The second seasons pass costs 12 (4 more hunters, 1 more monster). Personally, I think buying the 16 season 1pass/game package is well worth the money, if not just to give the game a try. It certainly behooves me to recommend the title to you, because i play myself, but Iwant to make it clear that even without obvious bias, I would styill recommend this game for this price to anyone who is intrigued by the idea of the game and wants to play.  In short, give it a shot while it is at a massive ♥♥♥♥ing discount, you will be surprised at how improved the game is, and the more people that end up playing, the better the community and game will get. Turtle Rock has mostly attoned for their sins, although begrudgingly, and we can't expect them to make it F2P because of consoles (filthy ♥♥♥♥ing casuals that they are).

Got the Steam version just so I could leave a review on this game.  Do I recommend this game? Yes and no. If you're looking for an OSU or a DDR clone then you're in the wrong place. Stop leaving negative reviews because it's not the gameplay you expected, that is unfair and childish. If you are looking for games similar to OSU, check out Touch Online.  And no I am not being paid 'in-game currency' to publish or write this review. This is all me.  I've been playing Audition Online on and off since the days of Nexon (roughly 2007) and the game has gone through some changes, both good and bad.  For starters: The Steam port is just awful, there is some notable lag spikes in the Steam version versus downloading the game directly from the Redbana website.  This is part of why new users were scared off, the other issue is the lack of noob friendly gameplay and rooms. The community is bad, it's awful, don't let anyone convince you otherwise. I've been banned from rooms for being too good, so I know the pain of getting banned over how you play the game.  The game is also full of non-English speakers, so there is a lot of language boundaries. Not to mention all of the locked and afk rooms. The game is dying, but not giving it a chance is helping it die faster. The thing that differs Audition from other rhythm based MMO's is its unique gameplay. It requires a steep learning curve, and that scares a lot of people off. Even back in the days when it was popular, it was scary, but at least noob servers were offered in those days. Redbana is partly responsible for the game's decline, but so are these negative reviews.  It is corrupt that they tried paying users for good reviews and it is sad that the community is trash, but no one here seems to be trying to fix the issues at hand. The negative reviews that say all the items in the game cost money are blatantly lying. Yes, some items in the game cost real money, but not all of the items. All MMO's have in-game purchases that are over-priced, get over it. I'm surprised many people dislike the graphics, if anything they're adorable. The game has a unique look to it. They never tried to be realistic like many other Korean kpop games. There is nothing else like Audition. The updates are little to none, and not all of the songs are popular, but they lack money. The sheer fact the game is still running is outstanding in on itself. The people behind Redbana have a certain love for it, if they didn't, it wouldn't still exist.   Audition IS a good game. It's fun. Every time I come back I get addicted again. It's challenging and it keeps players on their toes. The game should be reviewed based on its gameplay, and it has fantastic gameplay. There is no denying that. If for a moment you forgot the trash community, the in-game purchases, and lag spikes, you've got a great game.   RECAP:  Pros: * Character customization * Challenging gameplay * Cute graphics * Many modes * Lots of songs (This game is very friendly for YouTube gameplay videos, as many of the music is composed by Redbana) * Items do not affect how well someone plays, a non-paying user is just as good as a paying user  Cons: * Lack of updates * Corrupt GMs (game masters) * Unpopular songs * In-game purchases (NOT REQUIRED!) * Takes forever to level up * Unfriendly to newcomers * Toxic community  In the end, if you're looking for a challenging rhythm game, Audition Online is for you. If you're looking to make friends or play something similar to OSU, look elsewhere.

I have a love/hate relationship with this game. Every time I play it, I get frustrated, but I love basketball and 2K is the only option on the market (EA doesn't have any idea on what they are doing). The teammate AI run around aimlessly, the opposing CPU will make heavily contested shots 9 times out of 10, and player tendencies don't mean anything. Most of the issues I have with the game only pertain to the top two difficulties. PROS: - Runs smooth - Graphics are nice - It's basketball - Game modes are fun CONS: - Controller support is wack - CPU plays at an unrealistic level on higher difficulties  - Teammates don't make sense - 2K doesn't support the game, and each update made the game run worse - The servers are dead - Player animations are used on multiple people, and get stale - Running plays doesn't work well - The refs are biased in favor of the CPU - CPU disregards player tendencies   With that said I still play this game quite a bit, and if it was $10 or less I would recommend it, but with 2k17 almost out, there really isn't any point to pay the $60. Hopefully 2K starts to support the PC version more!

I first bought this game on sale last year and I can successfully say that it was one of my best purchases of 2015. As an avid LoTR fan (I read the trilogy at least twice ever year and the Hobbit is read seasonally), I didn't have great expectations for this game. I expected it to cash in on Tolkien's saga and leave me with a copy of the Batman games. After all, it plays the same, and it has many of the same overall mechanics. Well, after the first 2 hours with Shadow of Mordor, all my doubts had been shattered. In that time, I had been killed by an orc captain within 5 minutes, watched him grow in power, trained for another 15, killed him once, saw him come back, and killed him another time for good measure, this time taking off his pretty little head so that his friends knew who was in control. In all my years of gaming, few games have dragged me into the meat of the game so soon (exculding the rather lengthy training ground/backstory) and punished me so hard for not taking my surroundings seriously.  Let's talk about the good things first. The setting is great. There's no doubt about it. Whether you're in the massive, dirty strongholds of Udun, or in the vast fisheries of Nurn, the game always feels right. Shadow of Mordor did Tolkien's world justice and my first 5 hours of the game were mainly spent sightseeing. Gameplay is also a relative strong point. All the mechanics within Shadow of Mordor are very well put together and I've encountered very few glitches during my time with it. While the glitches that I HAVE encountered always seem to lead to my death, they've been usually been acceptable considering that I was in what most people would consider a 'precarious' position (i.e. holding onto a cliff for dear life that would lead to certain death if I was to fall). The physics engine/free climbing feels like a polished, superhuman version of Assassin's Creed 3/4. It's generally well done, and if you're able to suspend your doubt for the sake of gameplay mechanics, it's actually quite good and extremely enjoyable. There are 3 main modes of attack. Combat, stealth, and ranged. All are well-balanced, but many people prefer to just ignore stealth and ranged to just focus on combat. In doing this, they miss my favroite way to play Shadow of Mordor: The unseen shadow. Sometimes stealth can feel a tad overpowered in Shadow of Mordor, but when you're in the midst of a packed stronghold, you'll be thankful that orcs can't see more than 3 feet in front of them (with almost no peripheral vision). While both stealth and ranged are good options to have, straight combat is easily the most developed style of dealing with your enemeies. While fighting slightly repetitive, it's extremely deep and has many ways to keep itself fresh. Perhaps the strongest point of the gameplay is how it progresses. As you advance in the story, you'll earn more skills, and eventually earn entire new ways to play. Some of these skills are story-bound, and that's not a bad thing as it manages to keep things fresh at both the game's highest and lowest points. The story, while forgettable to those who would rather focus on gameplay, is another piece that does the original works justice. Everything fits neatly into the LoTR universe and some of the attention to detail that the game's creators put into the glossary is staggering. Besides all that, without spoiling anything, everything within Shadow of Mordor fits so well into Tolkien's original works that I actually consider this game part of the story despite the fact that I know it's not canon. Overall, great setting, good progression, and an amazing use of the source work to create a believeable story.   The cons of this game are generally based on opinion. While I don't have many real complaints, I'm going to list a few that I've heard. First, the fighting is very repetitive and pretty easy in most circumstances if you decide to just go in as a sword wielding maniac. Most orcs are easy to cut through and even when you're surrounded by 30+ of them, there's no reason that you should get hurt if you've made it at least through the first few missions. The captains and warchiefs are much larger challenges that can actually kill you (and kill you FAST) if you're not careful. They require a much more tactical approach to removing and this jarring transition between 'easy, almost Dynasty-Warriors gameplay' and 'strategic chess match' can really throw people off. I much prefer facing off against more difficult opponents and the 'Dynasty Warriors' gameplay can get old quickly if that's the only way you play. Another general negative thing about Shadow of Mordor is the mid-point of the game. When you get about half-way through, the game starts to lose its charm for a few missions and it seems like objectives become both drab and boring. While this doesn't last long, it's enough to throw a lot of people off and impatient players may quit altogether before reaching the game's amazing conclusion.   Overall, Shadow of Mordor's variety and polish make it one of my favorite games that I played last year. While it lacks slightly in some areas, it does a ton of things correctly and makes for a great single-player experience. I'd rate it a solid 9.1/10. If it's on sale, get it and don't be afraid to purchase the DLC too. Both the Lord of the Hunt and Bright Lord campaigns are incredibly good in their own right and are easily worth the price tag (Bright Lord easily being my favorite DLC for any game in a long time). While Shadow of Mordor isn't for everyone (especially if you didn't enjoy the Batman titles), this hardcore Tolkien fan is satisfied to know that there's at least one good game out there featuring my favorite fantasy world.  Buy if on sale.

Evoland is promising to start; beginning with a nostalgic feeling of the old RPG classics. Unfortunitly, that feeling only lasts for the first 10 minutes as the good memories fade into bad reminders of the annoyances each of these games brought that seemed to be over shadowed by the achievements of the time.   Evoland is a corky and nostalgic trip down memory lane with promise, but to only fall flat in the end.  4.5/10

Almost too addictive.   In short: you (and friends) gather resources in a large randomly generated world to survive for as long as you can. You'll need food, and gear suited to surviving the harsh elements and attacks from evil creatures.   The first few playthroughs are going to be hard, but do yourself a favor and try not to look up walkthroughs or tutorials. A lot of the joy of this game comes from exploring and experimentation.   What keeps the game fresh is replaying in different worlds with unique setups, and random encounters. My biggest problem with Don't Starve is that there isn't really a strong end goal to justify the number of hours you'll sink into this game. You basically play until you get bored, but (at least for me) it's hard to get bored of this game, so you just keep playing and playing until a week has passed, your girlfriend has left you, your houseplants are all dead, and you're fired from your job.

This game (especially back when I first started playing it) was surprisingly unique. The crafting is crazy, and the game world is randomly generated (leading to all manner of flooded tunnel wackiness). It's a little clunky in terms of combat, but I don't think that's really the point of the title anyway. If you need a good time sink, stop here, because this game will eat every bit you have to offer.

They updated the graphics but downgraded the gameplay. The original THPS2 gameplay felt way better than this HD remakes gameplay. E.g. they somehow couldn't get proper nollie flips done. Basically you do a nollie but then the flip animation is the one of a regular flip trick. Although I undestand that this issue isn't noticable or bothering for many players, to me it is a major flaw. Especially if you consider that THPS2 already did its flip trick animations perfectly fine 12 years before this remake was made. I would choose playing the old graphics with the old gameplay of THPS2 over the ones of the remake any time. Summarizing my experience with THPS HD, I can't say it was worth the time. To me it is nothing but a pretty lazy remake and an even lazier try to cash in on the good name of the old THPS titles.
