I'm gonna begin this review in the same way I begin all my Far Cry reviews - by talking about Far Cry 2.   Far Cry 2 was not a perfect game. It's story was very limited, and thus the context and motivation for your actions were lacking. It's saddled with a number of half-implemented mechanics, and fully-implemented but frustrating and repetitive mecahnics. However, it was laden with an incredible atmosphere, a genuinely reactive world, and (most amazingly) the landscape of the game felt real, not built. You felt like you were actually watching the setting African sun filtering through the dust and the trees as it fell over the still river water at dusk. It's a mental image that I cannot forget.  Now there's a few reasons I bring up FC2. A lot of people don't enjoy it. and I get that. It can be frustrating and it's not the most accessible or guided experience. BUT, what it does do is it plops the player in a big sandbox, gives them limited resources and intelligent and dangerous enemies, and says 'make your own story'. And because the game refuses to spoon-feed the player, and in that need for the player to adapt to the changing circumstances around them, FC2 allowed a constant creation of 'this one time when I was playing Far Cry 2...' moments. It aschewed OTT collect-a-thon busywork. It aschewed the asinine tower-climbing that has become that crumbling pillar upon which Ubisoft's games stand. It gave the player a bunch of rather vague mission parameters, a jungle, some fire, some deadly enemies, and a bunch of fairly underpowered weapons and said 'good luck'. And it was exhilirating. It was exhilirating to be forced into a cat-and-mouse stealth battle with a number of men whose clothes matched the surroundings. I was exhilirating to be unable to flush them out of hiding because you were in green grass and green grass won't burn. It was exhilirating to have to use your hearing to locate enemies because you're under a canopy and it's too dark to see them. It was exhilirating having to turn your eyes away from the road to look at your map only to look back at the road and see an enemy vehicle coming your way, knowing that if you don't get to your gun fast enough that you might die. It tested your skills as a player. It forced you to focus and made a man out of those that took the gunplay for granted.   Then came FC3. And all of a sudden the HUD was filled with markers and minimaps and text, and you could see enemies through walls, and the map was littered with garbage that you had to collect or else you wouldn't get the achievement that said you collected all the garbage, and the entire map was the same and recognising your location by it's appearance was all but impossible (but that didn't matter because you had GPS to hold your hand), and the enemies all wore the same bright primary colour because there's nothing more tactical than making yourselves visible from the moon, and once you cleared an enemy stronghold they were gone for good and you'd effectively progressed by making the map less fun. Hurrah?  I was excited for Far Cry 3. I lined up to play a pre-release build at a video game convention, and I bought it and played it and finished it and it was okay. And then a few years later I got a better graphics card and I reinstalled it, and I uninstalled it again within 2 hours because once you've finished it, going back is like returning to the second grade.   And then Far Cry 4 was released. And I didn't get it. Because it was more of the same, wasn't it? Because I was bored by FC3 and the obnoxious characters and the obnoxious hand-holding. For the record, I suck at Dark Souls - I'm not the world's best player and I don't relish a punishing experience - but the 'winning formula' that Ubisoft had struck upon with FC3 failed to capture my imagination. I didn't hate it. I still remember the first time I played it through. But the gameplay failed to challenge, and the story failed to engage, so the game itself failed to give me a reason to return. But I love the series because of its potential. Because even when it was Crytek property I loved the conceit - an open-world (of sorts) FPS sandbox in an exotic locale. I loved that at one point Ubi had created a set of reactive mechanics that, together, created an experience that was greater than the sum of it's parts. So I bought FC4 (on sale of course). And...it was fun. At least, the first play through was fun. The hand-holding wasn't as obnoxious, the game looked better than FC3, the characters still grated, but the story wasn't COMPLETELY devoid of heart. The game was still using collectibles as a substitute for meaningful content, but at least those collectibles unlocked weapons for you to use. The game was full of predators that add a degree of unpredictability to the game that I felt was severely lacking in the 3rd installment, and your plans for stealth can often go awry when a stroppy leopard stumbles into the mix. The enemy strongholds can be reset, or contested, which means that danger is never ENTIRELY eliminated from the equation. It's a better game. It's fun.   Upon replaying you can fly over the land and see how uniform it really is. Lacking still is variety in the terrain. The landscape is little but a bunch of locations connected by a series of roads, with nothing much that stands out in between. This place is not lived in, it's not real. It's a 2D game board on a table with a carboard prop every 5 squares, and a bunch of plastic army men stationed here and there. The enemies are still painted day-glo, just in case you forget where to shoot, and most of the missions involve going somewhere, killing something, and/or collecting something else. There's a re-hash of the FC3 mission in which you can burn a bunch of plants, and there's a single contemporary song in there somewhere, because feelings are like cold hard numbers, and Ubisoft have a steadfast belief in the simple arithmatic formula of 2 x (memorable moment) = 2 memorable moments. There's also a bunch of side-missions that involve taking drugs, because that was a thing they did in a different game that people bought.   But...it's fun. It easy to pick up and play and you're rarely far from a firefight. There's enough unpredictability to make it feel a little different each time you log on (because UPlay). It's got a little more lustre in it than FC3 the second time round. It's no FC2, and it's still adhering strictly to Ubisoft's slogan of 'video game, the video game', but it's almost, ALMOST, a compromise between the accessibility of FC3 and the dynamic engagements of FC2.   It's not a bad game. It's not a game-changer, but did you expect that? Get it cheap.

This is probably my favorite platformer of all time.   I'm not the best at them, and get frustrated by them very easily, although I do beat them eventually. But with this game I was never frustrated ever. The controls are very tight and very fluid. The challenges aren't frustrated at all, its not like some platformers where if you are off by a micrometer you die, instead it feels a lot more natural and flowing, while still being very challenging in a fun way.   This game is also extremely well paced. Doesn't feel like you are wasting time ever. Instead its a constant stream of fun with enough variance and inbetween to keep you going forever.   I don't bother reviewing most games, mostly because I always think they suck but this one is just that good.   Its better than: Super Meat Boy, Electric Super Joy, and other platformers in the genre. You can tell as you play it that the creator is 100% a genius. A true genius.

It can often times be very difficult to give a binary recommendation of games, yes I recommend this game or no I do not. The Beginner's Guide is a definite example of this, ultimately I do recommend it but caveats apply. I will explain why but I will not say much of anything about the actual game.  The main thing I will say is if you are looking for a game that will provide 100 hours plus of gameplay, this is not your game. If you are looking for a new experience or maybe you want to be left thinking and perhaps even inspired then you may wish to experience this relatively short but intriguing game.   At only an hour and 45 minute, give or take, there is not much to the game as far as hours to dollar but you may value more then hours played as in you may value your overall experience more, if so then I can recommend the game to you. Otherwise go get any other number of open world games that can provide 100's of hours of gameplay, if you are tired of those or just want something completely different then give The Beginner's Guide a try, it is the cost of a coffee and a donut so though short you could do much worse for your investment.

Game Dev Tycoon puts you in the role of a budding video game designer at the dawn of the PC revolution, and takes you well into the theoretical future of the industry.  While a simple game at heart, Game Dev Tycoon offers a surprising amount of depth as you experiment in how to create the perfect game. Different genres need more focus in certain elements, along with a carefully crafted balance of design and technology. Topics such as Fantasy can appeal to every age, while only the youngest gamers are drawn to games about Virtual Pets. Finding the mix of genre, topic, and design elements that lead to an industry-defining game design takes a lot of trial and error, but the rewards are worth it--assuming you don't go bankrupt first, a real concern as you struggle to balance training your staff to produce better games between actually releasing new titles to generate income.  Game Dev Tycoon's clean interface and simple but well-defined graphics contribute to an overall rather pleasant experience where you never really have to wonder what's going on. The only negative things I can really comment on here are that things like game reviews and convention screens can be mildly annoying to sit through, and that the development screen doesn't give hard numbers on how much time you're dedicating to each area of a game's design. Otherwise things run quite smoothly and it's always easy to find exactly the option you're looking for.  If you like business simulation games (a combination that does quite well inside of the game itself!), Game Dev Tycoon is a simple but very pleasant example. Even if they aren't normally your thing, it's possible any gamer might enjoy a small look inside the world of game development.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a RPG Hack and Slash indie game created by Dean Dodrill. The game sets place on the land of Falana, a world inhabited by anthromorphic animals. While some people may find the character style odd, I in the other hand love it, as it's much more different, compared to other games similar.  The game's art AND mechanics are made by the game's author himself, which is a big bonus, for a indie game too. Personally, the game is a tad bit underrated, I guess. More people should try the game out, and experience it themselves!  The art of the game is stunning, especially when using full resolution, and having a quality screen for your PC. The art stays beautiful, even to the end of the game without rushed art, as you'll be adventuring in sprawling magical forests, and grim graveyards, and the soundtrack fits the game perfectly too!  Conversations in the game happens by having the both characters on the other sides of the screen, and having text AND voice conversation at the same time. The voice acting may feel a bit too cheesy sometimes, but it's very well done, and the voices fit the characters so well too! The character art is very well made too!  The game's mechanics are simple and easy to get used to, but still brilliant. The game has some chain attacks to use with easy commands. The friendly NPCs are almost all in one village, where they give quests for you. You can't interact with them too much, but it doesn't make the game worse though. There's almost only enemies outside the main village, apart from special occasions, like quests.   The game doesn't have much for customizing though, for example; New suits or skins. It's a slight shame that you can't really change anything visually for Dust. The game runs with a slower computer too, like my laptop that I use to play the game with, and the FPS is very good in the game.  The story of the game is very gripping experience, and not just a gliché RPG plot, but a story that has good twists and emotional parts, that MAY have gotten me to have a few manly tears now and then...  In overall, Dust is a very unique experience, with a good story, and art! The game's longevity reaches up to almost 30 hours, if you're going to complete the game 100%, as there is many side quests to complete! The game needs to more attention, as I strongly support indie developers myself too. I'm hoping that the game gets a sequel some day badly, as it leaves you wanting for more! 10/10

If you love the combination of modifiers and dice rolls of table top gaming you will be in orgiastic nirvana with the most beautiful women when playing HEROES OF NORMANDIE.  Playing HoN reminded me of when i used to play games like Napoleon At Waterloo, Battletech, Cyborg Commandos etc where doing things like moving troops into different degrees of wooded terrain would make them harder to hit as well as increase their survival chances on the battlefield. If your caught out in the open you will be a very easy kill depending on what has found its sights on you and the range of its weapons. Battlefield wreckage will also block field of view making it harder to hit a target but you can fire on the wreckage and if your dice roll does enough of damage you will have a clear path and view. Going up against vehicles and tanks can be rather tricky. I was quite surprised how maneuverable they were on such a small map giving them a sense of realism as they were anything but easy targets for my bazooka infantry and armor units.   Movement and combat is done by giving orders to units which they will carry out when pressing the proceed button. During combat you can select individual weapons to fire depending if they are in range. Clicking on them will give you their strengths and what their main purpose in combat is such as suppression or just out right destroying the enemy.   During the supply phase you can move units that were not previously given orders since you are limited to the amount of orders you can give each turn. These units cannot fire. You also have a Bluff order during the orders phase which is a fake move or lie.  Graphics are amazing capturing the tabletop look perfectly with square chits covered in unit stats and great looking art work of the many different unit types. Terrain is displayed gorgeously and right clicking on it and units will bring up important information such as defensive bonuses. Infantry bleed a gushing red and tanks explode violently reminding me of those old mail order wargame ads in the back of comic books which came with tanks you could attach rubberbands to so they would explode in half on the plastic maps they also came with.   There are also plenty of comical visuals with commanders and officers cracking jokes during mission preps along with pleny of sexy female officers giving that inspiring spark to fight on! HEROES OF NORMANDIE definitely captures the brighter side of combat not done in most strategy games with its heroic imagery while still feeling like serious fun.  Sound effects and music come together as a explosive union of audio majesty as thundering tank fire from cannons shake the battlefield with shattering might and infantry rifle fire goes zigging across tree lines to hit their targets. The sound of tank treads can be heard crushing the ground leaving a trail of defiled landscapes. The rolling of dice fills the air with thrilling anticipation of a hit or miss.   HEROES OF NORMANDIE the complete package of tabletop gaming glory! The only thing missing is the smell of napalm.  Thank you Slitherine and Cat Rabbit for this masterpiece and for the deep release discount :)

Payday 2. It used to be my FAVORITE game. Of course, that was a couple years ago. I played all throughout the Beta of this game (The month) and then till Imfamy came out. It was SPECTACULAR back then. I come back and things are so... different. I get a totally different feel from the game once I play. I remember people ALWAYS doing stelth on missions where it mattered more but I see a LOT less of that because of all these new weapons. That's amazing and all, sure, hell, I didn't even like to Stealth much but I understood the apeal. I come back to people running around with poison weapons, where bashing people with your gun isn't a thing, attachments are insane now and plenty are worthless, again, these poison weapons and flame weapons make it to where you REALLY don't need too much of anything else. Sheilds? Molatov! Path blocked off? Blow em up. That's fun and all but it feels lacking of what the first game used to have. I love the harder modes. Overkill is easy but Deathwish is just that usually. Visuals are good but I just think that it could be better optimized. the movements feels slugish at times and armor seems unbalenced. Pistols are broken as many people say and they have micro transactiosn. <-- That's messed up. Other than that, I enjoy the game. It's a lot of fun to run around and, well, get to your Payday! Would I recomend it? I honestly couldn't bring myself to do that because of how little I've played in the past month of me coming back. Again, I don't know very much about all the new stuff but it has a different feel I don't like. Seeing the newer reviews and how the ratings for this game have gone down is pretty upsetting. It's sad really to see this happen.  It matters how the game is. The game has gotten worse since the beginning. It actually felt good after it came out! The gameplay was new, smooth, and an upgrade. There werren't overly useless weapons like there are now so you actually could see 'Oh, ok! This weapon is better!' rather than having all these random weapons and only having a couple that are actualy viable per class, leaving the other half of weapons to be confused by new or returning players to where they get them, fail, and you feel like you're doing worse or it's jsut stupidly hard because there's no guidence. There's no 'This is basically what you use at a higher level'. Going in heavy is basically pointless in Deathwish now. I mean, it was easy when it came out but now the game feels clunky, and sort of laggy in a way and I'm getting 90 FPS continuously. I remember when it ran much better than this and it's dissapointing.  The game developers haven't even opologised about there mistakes. LEt's take a look at other game devs. LEague of Legends just recently posted about how thye want to listen to the community. Here, I'll quote it.   http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/riot-games/editorial/champion-update-and-flawed-fencer  ''For ChampUp, success isn’t measured by the quality standards set by artists or designers. Says Rhee, “Fiora’s update shouldn’t be judged by ‘What did we want to make, and did we make it?’ It’s measured by, ‘How do players feel about this? Do players love this change? We try to surprise and to do things players don’t expect, but that end goal is always present.” The objective quality of art assets or VFX are a lower priority than whether those elements reflect player passion for a given champion. A miss is a miss, regardless of its technical execution.''  This is BEAUTIFUL. Seeing developers admit they were wrong in some sort of way and to explain exactly why they did it.  The conversation between the devs and moderators for Payday 2 got NOTHING done. The questioning was poorly exicuted, it was repetative, and Almir avoided giving some sort of strait answer. He's the community manager (some other, better word for that would be nice), isn't he? If he can't handle his own mods telling him off in a poorly exicuted way, I don't think he should be any sort of head, now should he? He couldn't answer easy questions that people could figure out anyways. I thought of many, legal ways he could have counteracted things AS IT WAS GOING ON. That's fairly sad. No, that's sickening. As one of the moderators said for the problems 'It shouldn't have happened in the first place'over and over and over again.... It was painful to listen to her say that without any real script. Just repeating most of the same words for 5 minutes, acomplishing minimal anything.  Yes, a lot of my grammar and spelling is bad but I don't really care. If you can understand it and correct it in your head, than I've done ok, yeah? If not, do point out where these are and I'll go along and fix them. If it's to improve, it's fine.  Mmmm, there's a LOT I could say. Like how I loved the game when it first came out and expolain in depth why but I'm not sure I should have to. The game's Steam Community rating is at 65% curently (75%?). That's just sad. SAD. Can't wait till the game says mixed ratings. Maybe THEN the des will fess up and they might just get an upvote for finally saying something after being tourtered from this. Sure, they have money. But I hope there isn't a Payday 3. I can't immagine what type of terrible shooter that'd be. Yeh

Early Access Review

It's tough to write a review for this game. It is fun. It has a great story line that I have fallen in love with. It keeps me playing. multiple story lines that sort of connect and some that don't. Still great story telling. And maybe that is where I find my problems. Don't get me wrong, the game is great. The graphics, game play, audio, fighting, etc. Most of it is great. There is one place I find fault. Some background, I've played every game calling itself an rpg. I'm not sure I would call it an rpg. Sure you are role playing but you have one role to play and that is the main character. You carry some swords and bombs and potions. But you are pingeon holed into the character you play. This game is not really an rpg and more an action adventure with amazing story telling. Quests are very unique and very compelling to follow. Even the side quests are compelling enough to stick with them and play through. But there is no actual role playing. You don't create a character of your choice and do your own thing. The world is open but really only to persue a different quest line or story line. You don't get to actually do anything outside the stories presented to you. That's not bad but it makes for a horrible rpg.  It is hard to pin point what disappoints me about whitcher. Believe me, what does leave an empty hole with the game is nothing big. The game is great. I love a lot of it but it is missing the actual rpg aspect. I can't start the game and go, 'well this time I want to be a elf mage' or 'this time I am going to steal everything in sight.' Really it is the minute things that you do that have no impact at all that irk me a little. I can walk into any home and loot the place with the owners there and nothing happens but that I get a lot of loot. The people, the world, are kinda devoid of interaction. The game has specific things that it wants you to interact with and anything outside those things and you get a cookie cutter response. most town folk give you some random saying if you try and talk. Many objects are just for looks. The world lacks actual interaction outside the game mechanics.   The game is great, but I imagine, once I have finished the main story line, and maybe visiting other dlc story lines, outside that there isn't much replayability. I guess I could focus on building my character differently and focus on spells rather than fighting or focus on potions or whatever, but it's all to the same means. There is really no reason to most of the lines of character building other than to advance the story line. The faster you kill the faster the story line advances and specing in fighting seems to progress the story line further.   The story telling is advanced and your choices to have an affect on how the game plays out. But honestly this is just one of those books where you pick an option and turn to a specific page to see how the story pans out, except you have decent animated graphics to join it. Haven't beat the game yet, but my review stands as I have experienced all the mechanics and gameplay. It is a rinse and repeat of gameplay. Only the story builds up. I know the story will be awesome and that is worth the game but after I have reveealed the story and played it through, there won't be much left to do. There is no, 'well I played as a elf thief and have backstabed everything to death, now lets do it as a wizard.' developing the main character any different won't change much except how battles play out or how the story progresses. I guess that is my qualm, no matter how you develop your character, the story plays the same. Whereas say, in skyrim, how I develop my character changes the quests I do...actual freedom based on how I decide to play.   Still, the game is great and far worth the money, but to me, not goty quality. just my opinion.

I've been looking for a game similar to Sim Tower for years! Glad I stumbled across this one.  First overall impression is good. Runs smoothly, nice graphics, clean interface. Menu shows enough options to construct some nice buildings. I also like the buzz and influence features.  Remains to be seen how mechanis work in the long run. Especially elevator strategies.  IN ADDITION:  Played some hours by now. And still like it, but:  * A real letdown is that elevaters and stairs have to be placed next to other structures. Sim Tower from the 1990s allowed them to be placed in front of them, adding a third dimension. Also, no escalators, as it seems.  * Different from Sim Tower this game is not so much about elevator management, but about ressource and pipe / line management. You only have a limited supply of energy, water at one time. And you always need to plan ahead of the needs of your tenants.  * Take your time. It's a slooow game. You may (and will) hurry game speed, especially during the night.

Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is an MMORPG. The rebooted/revamped version of the atrocious Final Fantasy XIV, and the 100th billionth game in the Final Fantasy franchise.   FFXIV:ARR is much like what WoW used to be when WoW was good. They took much of what made WoW great back in vanilla/The Burning Crusade and used it to shape FFXIV:ARR, adding a modern touch on top.   After the failure of Final Fantasy XIV, Square Enix got rid of most of the development team and learnt from their mistakes. What they've ended up with is an amazing MMO with tons of content and fine details to keep you playing for months.   The game offers a unique class system much like FFXI, where you're free to change your class at any time you wish, by simply changing your weapon to that of the class you wish to equip. There's 9 classes to choose from, with each playing a different role: tanks, healers, and DPS's. Each of these classes later turn into jobs, offering more abilities for you to gain and unlock. There's also 8 crafting classes, and 3 gathering classes available.   The game is filled with various dungeons, raids, and trials which are essentially boss fights.   Many MMOs lack true end game content, however FFXIV:ARR is mostly focused on end game content. Many consider the game to not start until you reach level 50 (which takes anywhere from a few days to a few weeks, depending on how you play and how often you play). The game offers many dungeons for leveling, and even more for late game. Many of which are harder versions of leveling dungeons. On top of this, there's multiple raids ranging from your traditional raids with many players (24 in this case), or smaller 8 player raids. Finally, for those who love boss fights there's plenty of trials to keep you entertained. These are mostly primal fights with varying levels of difficulty.   There's tons of gear in the game each offering unique looks, allowing for huge amounts of customisation. In terms of character customisation, there’s quite a few options for you to choose from. There’s 5 different races, with each offering two sub-races of sorts. For example, your traditional “human” race has both midlanders and highlanders. The game does not offer sliders for things such as eye shape, nose shape, etc., but instead has four different types for you to select, with each sub-race having a different selection. As well as this, there’s plenty of hairstyles for you to choose from, with a wide range of colours to select as well as a highlight colour.   The game’s OST is absolutely amazing, and possibly one of the best I’ve ever heard in a game. There’s tons of tracks with unique songs for each field location, dungeon, trial, raid, and everything else.   I highly recommend checking it out, even if you do not purchase the game.    The game is updated every couple of months adding more items, dungeons, primal fights, new music, and much more. So there’s always plenty to do.   FFXIV:ARR is subscription based. You can pay $12/month for 1 character per world, with a maximum of 8 characters. Or you can pay $15/month for 8 characters per world, with a maximum of 42 characters. Though with the way classes work, you won’t be needing more than a single character usually, so the limit is hardly an issue. Some people are turned off by subscription fees, however $12/month is a small price to pay for such a great game, which constantly gets more content. The lack of F2P or B2P also prevents P2W aspects, and usually means the community is better in general.   Overall, Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn has to be the best MMORPG I’ve ever played. The sheer amount of content has kept me hooked for over 400 hours, and will continue to do so as the months go on. If you’re looking for a great MMORPG to play, and have the money to invest, I could not recommend this more.

TransOcean is a pretty cool and fun game where you just run your own maritime shipping company and you can run as many ships that you can afford. The ships range from a tiny freighter to a Panamax to a UCLV (a really big ship) and you can ship goods from ore to counterfeit goods to weapons to and from countries in the world.   Gameplay wise, it's pretty simple and there is a mini game where you can dock and cast off. It does get repetitive after a while but if you play the game in bursts, it's fun. There are challenges where you can accept company contracts to ship a certain number of goods from one port to another in a certain time frame, which is rewarding in the end. There are also random events that pop up where you decide to avoid it or go through it, as well as customs checks from time to time (often on Hard difficulty). One neat feature I love about the game is there is online connectivity where players who play this game effect prices of goods if a port is visited often.  However, what I do find is that when you start expanding, the amount of ships that you have to manage gets overwhelming and I wish there was a way to easily load your freighters at multiple ports.  Overall, I do recommend this game but remember to play it in bursts or it will get repeititive. Score wise, about a 8/10.

I'm not a connoisseur of music. I mostly listen to soundtracks, using them as an auditory trigger to try and relive the resonant moments that I felt when watching a movie or playing a video game. Sometimes I close my eyes and try to unravel the music. I don't claim to do so with any expertise; but there are minor revelations, and then I marvel at the composer's expertise and imagination at constructing the end result.  Circuits is a puzzle game that peels the curtain back a bit further. The concept is simple: you are given auditory snippets which you must arrange in the correct manner in order to reproduce a song. There are up to three layers in a song, and (prior to the last two levels) the game allows you to listen to each layer individually - a fascinating insight into the mind of a composer.  There are additional puzzle elements - switches, loops, extraneous sound bites - but Circuits introduces each complication gently, and removes them before they overstay their welcome. This restraint in puzzle design helps ensure that the experience never grows stale.  ---- Pbbt ----  Once upon a time there was a boy who could only make one sound. No matter what he did - how he shaped his lips or moved his tongue or pressed air through his teeth - that single sound was the only one that would ever emerge. Which sound was this? Stick your tongue between your lips, press down, and blow. Yep, that's the one.  Still, this was not the worst affliction in the world, or so the boy's parents told themselves. They enrolled the boy in a school for the deaf, where he learned to use his hands to sign his thoughts to others. It was a hardship of course, but one that the human race at large understood and even sympathized with. And so the boy grew up into a man who did not dread the greater world. Instead he faced it with a straight back, a strong heart, and a grin on his face.  Until the fateful day when he heard the last movement of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony  (link) . In his mind the voices wove a glittering fabric, rising and falling strands of color and exaltation that created a single Ode to Joy. The man listened to Beethoven's masterpiece again, and then again, and then again and again, and there was a moment when he realized that he was both lost and in love, and perhaps the two were not so different? Yes: the man was both lost and in love, and not knowing where he was, there was nowhere else he would rather be.  That day a path was created for the man, clear and straight and true. He would become a singer. Not a great one, of course - the man was not delusional - but perhaps if he studied and trained enough, he would be rewarded with a small place in a great choir. And then one day his voice would be added to the song he adored.  It was not to be.  I will spare you the details of the man's tragedy, give you but a clouded view of the moment when the man realized that his body had betrayed him from birth, that his hopes were cobwebs and his dreams but mud. On that day the man sat alone on a park bench and cried. He did his best not to, knowing that in doing so he would only bleat out his cursed sound over and over and over again. But his sorrow was too great; it pounded against the dam of his soul and would not be denied.  There was laughter.  Who would be so thoughtless? Who could be so cruel? The man peeked out from between his fingers with red-rimmed eyes, only to discover a face that was thoughtless, but not cruel.  'Mister,' the little girl said, still laughing. 'That's really funny. Can you do that again?'  That day the man discovered a new path for himself, a future that would be filled with joyful children. And, he reflected, was that not an even greater blessing than the one he had originally desired for himself? ----------------------------  On a personal note, the music in Circuits - synthesized voices and electronica - does not hold the greatest appeal for me. What would I prefer? Something like Mozart's deathbed scene from 'Amadeus'  (link)  (forward to 2:00 to see his music start coming together); oh, that would be glorious! And yet the fact that I enjoyed Circuits so much speaks well of its merits as a game.  ---- Pbbt (Epilogue) ------  Of course it was not a greater blessing. The man remained lost and in love.  Yet the laughter of children did make him happy, and if it was not the greatest happiness he could imagine - well, those who fly too close to the sun often plummet to their death.  Still, for the rest of the life, the man woke from dreams where he sang to rapturous applause - ' O Freunde, nicht diese Töne! Sondern lasst uns angenehmere anstimmen, und freudenvollere. ' When his eyes blinked open, sometimes he would lie silent. Sometimes he would wipe tears from his eyes. And sometimes he would smile and grasp the fleeting substance of his dream, using what was left behind to light the shadowed places of his soul. ----------------------------

New York Taxi Simulator takes place in a world that does not resemble New York in the slightest, where nothing is simulated because there are no penalties, collision does not exist on all objects, vehicles suffer no ill effect for slamming into one another, or buildings, or anything which is solid, and to top it all off, there's a weird effect where a siren is baked into the music randomly that made me think my lone taxi fare of carnage was going to attract a penalty. It didn't.  I got a customer to his destination with 40 seconds to spare after driving the wrong way down identical* streets for about 3 minutes, sometimes on the sidewalk, sometimes through pedestrians (of whom I saw a total of TWO, and aimed for to see what happened - they are ghosts is what), and was told that I was a 4/5 star driver, and very professional. I drove him to his stop like this game is 4/5 stars: only in its fever-dream world.  * If you told me this game's streets were procedurally generated, I'd believe you.

This game is AWESOME! Perhaps the most overlooked fantasy 4x game of all time. Don't let the mediocre sprite graphics fool you into thinking it's a bad game - it is perhaps the deepest, most detailed, and most complex fantasy 4x I have ever played. From designing your Pretender God to laying out your troop formations, your decisions have a very real impact in the style of game you will play and the options that are open to you.  If you prefer style over substance, this game doesn't have the visual flash you're looking for. If you want a deep, rich, immersive game with many options to choose from, hundreds of spells, hundreds of unit types, incredible game design, imaginative civilizations drawn from mythology, this is your game.

I was having a ton of fun with this game - it is rather grindy, and can be unfair at points, and is almost obtuse in its ability to explain basic functions, but can be fun. It's like Diablo - you want to stop playing because you feel you aren't making good progress, and then a cool rare item shows up.  And then all of that gets destroyed by a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥ save system. There isn't one, you see - it saves when you exit. Or 'periodically' or whatever that means. I couldn't tell you when it saves. Well, actually, I can - right after your computer is shutoff thanks to a random brownout. Or more specifically, right after you go back into the game and try to restart your instance only to find out that the last 5 hours of progress have been wiped and they expect you to start your ♥♥♥ over in a new world with a ship that you traded in a while ago.  Yep - lost 5 hours worth of ships, rare items, gold, and everything. It isn't fun. And no, the backup didn't help - the backup WAS that old ♥♥♥ save FOR SOME REASON.  If I had manual saves, I'd have lost maybe a half-hour - tops. But that's not the 'design' of the game. It's some stupid hipster cloud ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about instances, and servers, and who-gives-a-crap. The game basically showed me lots of cool stuff and then robbed it from me. For that, it deserves a special place in hell.  I want my $12 back.

app_name: The Fall of the Dungeon Guardians
review_text: Please note the following points before reading the rest of my review: - I haven't finished the game yet. I'm through slightly more than 50% of the Dungeon levels, which is probably a little less than 50% of the total playtime, since the first few levels were less complex. - I have more playtime than I can reasonably have accumulated on release day. I've bought the game through the developers' shop and activated it on Steam a few days ago. I didn't receive a review copy but instead paid full price. So this review is by no means biased by having gotten something for free. ;)  Now that that's out of the way back to the game:  Gameplay: First and foremost it is a grid based dungeon crawler that apparently draws significant inspiration from genre classics like Dungeon Master. There are no outdoor areas. The game (in contrast to for example earlier Might and Magic titles) is played in real time, meaning monsters will move and act even when the player doesn't do anything, but here an active pause function was implemented. This allows for a much more tactical combat experience than can be found in some other, more 'retro-ish' dungeon crawlers like Might and Magic X Legacy or Legend of Grimrock for example, where modern computer RPG features like active pause, hotkeys and quickbars where deliberately ommited to provide a gameplay experience closer to 'the classics of old'. Also in other regards there are nice comfort features that you could use. For example when you mouse-over a key on the map screen the place where you picked it up will be highlighted on the map. (EDIT: In my original review I mentioned at this place, that progress-relevant items like keys can potentially be almost invisible on the ground IF dropped in a very dark corner of a room falling close to a gap or stairs for example. This has since be fixed by a patch implementing an optional highlighting option for dropped loot, which can be switched on in the options ... just making the game even better.) The only thing I'm not so sure about is the number of classes. Since I'm still in my first playthrough it's hard to say, but there are only four classes. Even though the skill trees are quite varied and for example the man at arms may be played as a damage dealer or a tank... For longevity I think some more exotic classes would have been nice. (To be fair however: The classes in this game are MUCH more complex than in other retro-ish dungeon crawlers and I guess balancing additional classes would be quite a bit of work ... but still, would be nice. ;) )  Visuals: Overall the game provides a quite modern look while still reproducing the atmosphere in classic dungeon crawlers. If I were to compare The Fall of the Dungeon Guardians to other recent high profile grid based dungeon crawlers I'd say it's mostly on par with them, though if you are really looking at them comparing little details there might be a very minor lack of polish here. (One example would be: At the start of the game you go down to the bottom of the dungeon via elevator passing multiple levels and also some cross-bracings ... and that's where the edge of the platform merely clips brazenly through the cross bracings. ;) ) Once the intro sequence was over and I started playing I quickly got absorbed in the game to the point where I completely stopped noticing these miniscule hickups which are VERY rare anyway. The only thing that got a little bit 'more' negative after playing the first three levels was the lack of variety in wall textures within one texture set, which became apparent once I started spending more time searching for hidden switches, but I'd just say it's 'noticeable, but not problematic'. The different sets after clearing a few levels are very varied though and all are incredibly pretty and convey a very different atmosphere every time you change the 'area'. Also the spell effects and illumination look very nice. It's just incredible when you play in a dimly lit room and rain down fire on an entire group of enemies, temporarily lighting up everything just to see the ash of your incinierated foes fall to the ground while the dungeon (and your room) returns to it original lighting conditions.  Sound design: The sounds works very well with the game and overall the ambient soundeffects are very atmospheric and do a great job forming the overall positive picture.  Bugs: The only one I'm still having right now is that 5.1 digital surround sound via HDMI (from an nvidia GTX 970) doesn't work, but that's a Unity thing: Search their developer support Forums and you'll find out that most developers ultimately 'fix' the problem by using an original Creative Labs Soundblaster card, because the audio component of Unity just is very, very bad. Two other minor problems I had were so little I might not have noticed them had I not deliberately looked for problems. One was fixed before I could report it and the other one was addressed by the developer right away, who by the way is very responsive and friendly.  Conclusion: (note: this is prelminary, since I haven't finished the game!) The Fall of the Dungeon Guardians is a lot of fun. It's by no means an easy game, but it offers very comprehensive difficulty settings, which will allow the most casual of players to still enjoy the game while pure masochists will be served just as well. The atmosphere of the game quickly sucked me in. The representation of the deep dungeon and the sense of being lost in those tunnels ist just that strong and from what I've played so far I truly think it might just be one of the best grid based dungeon crawlers of the last few years.  (Also note that the game offers a map editor, but I didn't have time to check it our yet.)

Building on the successful AC2, AC Brotherhood follows Ezio Auditore in his ongoing quest to express his feelings toward English Lit by stabbing, shooting, and poisoning everyone from poorly directed guard characters lifted directly from a Shakespeare play to sinister Italian men in tights.   AC Brotherhood introduces a major change in the ability to bring one's horse into the city. Yes, rejoice! You can now focus on important things like bringing democracy and freedom to Rome's denizens without being burdened about said denizens' freedom to safely cross the street!   Veterans familiar with the series won't find anything new with this one-trick pony, history buffs might recoil at the revisionist treatment of famous historical figures, and Ubisoft's game launcher remains awkward. But there's nothing more satisfying than running down 15th century blackguards and ruthlessly punishing them for nothing if not their poor choice in wardrobe.

It's a good game, but a problem comes in the fact that it, like I said, isn't finished. There are still situations in which a certain boss (Lil Hunter) can make or break you with no real input on the other player's side. You can go into that fight and have a clear room to fight him in, or a room full of enemies, even multiple elite variants. Glitches, crashing, and general confusing issues are also problematic. I assumed these things would be fixed once it was out of early access, but even after acknowledging it in November, it's May, and it still isn't fixed. As it is right now, I simply cannot reccomend the game. If you want a good shoot-em-up roguelike, you might wanna try Enter the Gungeon. I've only heard good things about it.

Tl:dr; It's epic, intense, extremely detailed and takes a while to learn.  Do you cringe to see your RTS tanks and helicopters move at the same speed? Do you want a modern style RTS on a big scale? Do you want semi-realistic ranges, strength and fighting power for anti-air, vehicles, tanks, infantry? Look no further.   Wargame has (to me) been the breath of fresh air the RTS genre sorely needed. It's on a massive scale, and allows you to zoom out to see the entire map, but you can also zoom in to follow a particular unit in incredible detail.   This game has been around for a while, but thanks to the community, the devs are still working on putting new nations out.  Next to the positive things mentioned above, here are a few things you should consider before buying: -The scale works both ways, it's easy (as a beginner) to get stomped by something you didn't know existed. -The learning curve is very steep in the beginning, know that you need to make your own unit deck, since the default ones are useless. -Don't read the chat if you're easily offended. -(in my opinion) There's little GOOD wargame footage on youtube etc. from which you can learn as a beginner, reach out to the community to get some good decks at the start!
Be sure to check your dietary restrictions for extra amount of sodium. If the RNG is against you, you'll be feeling it every way shape and form. But its otherwise an amusing enough time killer game.

This is a rehash of a very good older turn based strategy. Very polished and smooth playing. I noticed a couple of profoundly troubling things regarding the game and its length. It is way to short to be an xcom game. Xcom games are supposed to be a time sink. They are supposed to help you forget what is going on in your possibly dreary or even exciting lives. I would also like to be able to field more than one squad at a time. More skyrangers please!!!   All in all I love this game it is a remarkable remake with a great set of DLC. I hope you get it and enjoy all of the insane moments that make you facepalm hard enough to come out the back of your head.  All in all 9/10 would miss an alien with 100% chance to hit again.  ♥♥♥♥, I forgot about that bull#@!%$ mission with all the damn chryssalids where the ship crashed into the town. app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: GROUND ZEROES
review_text: I read quite a few reviews on here before buying it, with mostly positive reviews. However i cannot recommend it.   It's short, after you play through the first mission it's basically doing the same map over and over again.   I am a huge Metal Gear fan, as you can see from my hours spent on the Phantom Pain(which i do recommend).   The whole experience feels flat, just when the game starts to crank up, it's over.   Do yourself a favour watch someone play through it and buy the Phantom Pain.   Cons - Too short, doesn't feel fleshed out, Demo-like, controls aren't as sharp as previous MGS.  Pros - Graphics, Plays well on older systems, Story, Cut scene.
I can't think of a game that has moved me so greatly within such a short time span. It is simutaneously not The Stanely Parable and yet its even more brilliant. Kudos.

I would highly recommend this game. It has a great plot, characters and battling system, also to add on to that, you don't have to kill anyone! Which is great. Finally, there's an RPG where you don't have to kill anyone. There are also many interesting secrets, an example is W.D Gaster a creepy and mysterious character. The game isn't very long, yet you feel like you spent so much time playing the game. Every minute of playing this game is worth it. There are also three paths you can choose, such as neutral, where you spare some people and kill some people, then there's genocide, where you kill everyone and in the genocide run everything becomes dark, depressing and violent, the one good quality of the genocide run is that, you get to fight sans in the genocide run. Sans is a skeleton with a brother named Papyrus, I would say that sans is the best boss you could spend you're time fighting. Anyways back to the different paths, then there's pacifist, where you spare everyone and encounter one of the best bosses Asriel Dreemurr. One of the reasons I love the Asriel Dreemurr boss fight is, because it's a boss battle with lots of hope, which is something I usually don't see in other games. Here's another quick thing to add on, this is a 'kids game' and yet despite being a ' kids game' it can be so dark and it just flies over kid's heads. I really respect that and I enjoy when something can be a little dark, because it's something you normally wouldn't see in a ' kids game'. Now as for the graphics, i know people who have criticized Undertale's graphics, really my opinion on that is that, I love Undertale's graphics, despite it being pixely and for me that just enhances the experience and it just overall fits the game itself. After saying all that in all I would give Undertale a 10/10, I highly recommend playing this game and I don't think I will ever see a game like this again.

The co-op  might  be considered fun, if you're in an extremely generous mood. Unfortunately, you'll still be left with the feeling that you were cheated out of your money as it's clear that this game was very poorly planned and executed by all parties involved with its development. The further you advance through the game, the easier it is to see that they progressively cared less about delivering a quality product and more about simply meeting their deadline. It's not unlike a 10-page essay written by an extreme (but slightly charming and able) procrastinator who uses double-spacing and 16 pt. font to make it  look  like a 10-page essay, and then proceeds to forget to check the spelling and grammar.  It's likely that this game will leave you feeling quite bitter, since you can catch glimpses of all the potential that this game had which is, in the end, all completely wasted.

The music is amazing, especially some of the DLC characters. It may not be a game for everyone, but it is a game you can love (and hate at times) with friends.  And you will die. To seagulls. A lot. I've put in more than 40 hours into this game on the Xbox 360 version, as well as the non-Steam version, so don't mind the lowly 9 hours I've put into the game here on Steam.  This is a fantastic game, and I personally prefer it over Far Cry 3. I was a huge fan of the original Far Cry (no, not the one on Xbox called Instincts, but the very first one on PC!). It was a flawed but fun game, with glitchy AI but beautiful levels and an open world design, where you could do a mission multiple different ways. I was worried when Far Cry 2 was announced to be in Africa and not a tropical island like the first, and that Jack Carver wouldn't be returning. I bought Far Cry 2 anyway when it released on PC, back when games didn't always come with Steam keys.  I was immediately addicted. The game is very gritty, with just about everything out to kill you. It's definitely not for casual gamers.   Weapons start rusting and breaking after long uses, eventually exploding in your hand, damaging you and forcing you to scavenge for a weapon off the ground while enemies are shooting at you from all directions. Cars can start to break down, requiring you to quickly get out, pop the hood, and use your magical wrench to fix it all while enemies are driving down the road trying to find you.   Bones will break. Shrapnel will stab into your thigh. Bullets will require pulling out of your arm. You'll need to heal yourself, which uniquely has your character fix himself through multiple animations of ripping out large chunks of metal from his legs, bandaging himself, etc. It all looks fantastic and gives the game, as I said earlier, a very gritty feel.  The game is flawed, just like Far Cry 1. The AI is iffy. It's hard to stealth. The story isn't delivered very well. Everyone talks like they've got to get to the last rocket off Earth. There's respawning guard outposts (though you can easily go around them, to be honest). But even with all of that said, I still think the game is much more unique and fun to play compared to Far Cry 3. I love exploring Africa, it looks gorgeous. If you ask me, I think the engine they used for FC2 (Dunia Engine) looks much better than the slightly cartoon-y style FC3 had with the Dunia Engine 2.  I'd recommend the game if you're looking for a different, less casual type of FPS. It's got an incredible amount of detail, the weapons are fun to use, there's some very cool features like weapons breaking down, the healing system, and the way AI interact with each other (enemies will try to drag their friends away after they've been hurt, for example).   It's a very underrated game, and I hope one day we'll get another Far Cry like this. One that isn't afraid to be different and try new things.  EDIT:   I recently started playing Far Cry 4 on my Playstation 4, and I just wanted to say that if you were a fan of Far Cry 2, but sad that FC3 removed a lot of the neat ideas 2 brought with it, you should definitely check out FC4.   It feels like a mix of all the things I loved about FC3 and brought back a few things I missed that FC2 had, like fire realistically spreading (FC3 sorta had it still, but it didn't work well), being able to go to sleep to change to a specific time of day, and hell, even a certain character returns from FC2! I won't spoil who it is, but it took me by surprise, since he wasn't a particularly big character in FC2. He's also the first recurring character in a Far Cry game, other than one other character who returns from FC3. Seems like Ubisoft is starting to make the games connect a bit!

Best strategy game ever made. Nothing even comes close to how good this game is in scale, control scheme, realism, and thoughtful gameplay.  Playing this game should be a mandatory part of high school education. It illustrates in no uncertain terms just how important it is to perserve the peace in the world. When you see squads of infantry with names and faces getting turned into minced meat by 203mm artillery because you ordered them to hold a town at all costs... ... That will make you think twice about voting for stupid politicians and supporting militarist and nationalist policies.

The early game where you are slowly unveiling the galaxy for the first time is enjoyable. You're discovering what the game has to offer and thinking ahead about space you want to control. Who will be your allies and enemies?  There are problems later in the game, unfortunately. For example, the war system is nonsense. When war begins you are restricted to choosing roughly 3-5 planets that you will take from the enemy (there is a 100 point cost system for your war plan). During the war you can destroy all their armies and land troops onto every one of their worlds, but in the end you can only accept the 3-5 planets you declared initially.  This means that you have to declare war multiple times against an enemy to eliminate them. When a war ends you enter a period of peace (a long period) which you must wait to expire before war can be declared again. This is simply tedium because you've already destroyed their army and scooped valuable planets out of their empire.  Worse, if you are in a federation (which is how I chose to play) then you can only declare war every 40 or 50 years or so (which is probably a few hours of play, though I have not run a stopwatch on it). During the periods you cannot declare war you're twiddling your thumbs hoping the current federation president accidentally declares the war you want, or that your enemies declare a war against you (though the AI is not likely to declare a war against your superior empire). The system is incompetent.  There are numerous bugbears throughout the game that suggest development ended prematurely. For example, you're forced to yield control of planets to the AI, but this AI neglects your citizen's basic need of happiness, giving rise to rebellions (what this game calls 'factions').  The UI is sometimes obtuse and on occasion wildly misleading. You will make several mistakes on this basis. For example, the game mislead me to colonise planets with the wrong species, resulting in them being miserable and rebellious. On top of this, the game offers poor or no solutions to correct the problem. These planets I made mistakes on are likely to be permanently doomed. My only out is to become evil and purge (kill) them, but this would be suicide due to the political ramifications.  I hope they can improve and polish these systems with further iterations of this game (patches, DLC, expansions, whatever). In the meantime I think you're better off playing a 4x game that is more mature.

The game is so-so, 5.5/10 (bumping up to 6/10 when you take into account that I bought it for 99 cents) - very minor spoilers - The graphics are good but the effects are AMAZING. They really 'bend' lightning and objects around, and the game is very creative when it comes to using them. The atmosphere is top-notch, Outlast tier. The story is (would be?) the most important aspect of the game, but falls flat on its face. The main character is clearly too emotional to handle that kind of job, since he starts seeing deep ♥♥♥♥ simply because he needs to do his job (which ain't that bad) The horror isn't that strong and I loved it. Proves that we don't need jumpscares to have good horror games, since the atmosphere really stole the show and it does make me want a sequel of the game. One that doesn't have such a bad main character and lousy story.  Overall, it's a average-to-good game and I recommend it for its price, but don't expect anything from the story or the characters. Try looking at the 'technical' side and see how well done the game actually is. It's a great foundation for future games to build on.

I've went back and forth on deciding whether to up or downvote this game and I have decided to downvote. The reason for my downvote is simple, after a couple play throughs you realize the game lacks depth. I have failed in only my first play through and then scored over 900 on all play throughs afterward. Did I just magically become a genius? No, it is because I found the trick to succeeding every single time. I of course ignored this flaw because I thought the developers were going to continue to improve the game over time. I was wrong. In a recent news update it has come to light that the game will only be maintained via bug squashing and support. So basically this is the finished game.   I was really hoping for more interactions with other nations, russia needs to be more than a minor detial, and more random events that forced the player to adapt. Due to these limitations, it seems there are really only a couple ways to truely succeed. This is of course a problem when the description of the game includes, 'a world of possibilities' as one of the reasons to buy.

I enjoyed Shadowrun, I enjoyed Dragonfall, and the Director's Cut is, without question, a solid improvement on both.  The new content is well-balanced for the timeframes in the campaign at which they are accessible, and add interesting depth to various characters (this is particularly noticeable for the Lodge mission!)  The new tactical interface is a vast improvement over something that already was pretty solid and functional, and Harebrained has patched out what few glitches I noticed within days of release.  Overall, I'd strongly recommend this, even if you were leery of the original Shadowrun release.

Race Driver: Grid is a beloved modern classic, so everyone had huge expectations for GRID 2. I myself bought it on day one...  Sadly, some basic features are missing in GRID 2: - Cockpit view - Assists options (this is a huge one) - chat in online lobbies   And... The DLCs are overpriced and they further split the now small community (the game is region locked). Codemasters implemented the so called 'TrueFeel Handling System'. The handling is constant drifting on 'ice covered' tracks, because if you keep on the non-existent racing line/not drifting you take the corners slower - ridiculous!   Less cars, less liveries (most are ugly, a thing a 10 year old would put on a car) Small amount of mostly fake tracks which are very narrow, making a regular online race into a crash derby + all that social media / 'fans' thing in the single player campaign... No words.  You are not a racer, you are a teenage pop-star, who is given cars to drift/crash and show off to the crowds. That is what Codemasters went for.  A shallow copy of Race Driver: Grid...  At least they had the decency to leave out 'Race Driver' . Good choice, Codies.

Nightsky is a casual physics platformer puzzle game with exceptional sounds and graphics. Although, despite sounding and looking amazing, it’s gameplay can be repetitive, I can still recommend this and here’s why.  Pros:  ♦ Great Atmospheric Graphics (It’s simple art style but it all fits together and looks amazing) ♦ Relaxing Eargasmic Sound (Relaxing and calming sounds that just fit together and make playing the game so much better) ♦ Relaxing/chill gameplay (Gameplay isn’t 100% but if you want a game you can easily pick up and put down in your spare time or want something to relax to, then this hits the nail on the head) ♦ Nice number of easy achievements (You can get all the achievements just by completing the game) ♦ Reasonable price considering the amount of work that has gone into the Graphics and Sound (Though if you are buying it for the gameplay, I’d say buy it on sale for a couple of bucks) ♦ Controls that just work (They just work) ♦ Interesting Vehicle Concept (I won’t spoil it, but vehicle concept is very interesting and fun) ♦ Interactive Credit Concept (This was a nice little way to do the credits and made reading them that little bit more enjoyable)  Cons:  ♦ Really Repetitive (I say this as I was happily playing and then all of a sudden when I expected the game to almost be finished, it tells me there are more levels but to progress I have to redo the old levels and find a “Hidden Star” which it never told me about. This concept is so annoying, as having to redo levels you’ve already completed to find a hidden object just to progress the main storyline seems really redundant and stupid) ♦ Really Easy (For 90% of the game all I had to do was hold down the left or right arrow and roll to the next screen/part of the level. This is kind of silly for a puzzle game to be this easy) ♦ Non-Existent Puzzles (I say this as I mentioned above I could hold left or right and progress easily. Also the only puzzles I seemingly found were timing jumps or rolling balls into the correct spot at the correct time, which I imagine a 5 or 6 year old could figure out easily) ♦ No Steam Trading Cards (Would be a nice addition as the graphics of the game are amazing and I imagine they could create some really stunning backgrounds, emotes and badges). ♦ No way to tell how far you have progressed in a level or how many are left (There is no level numbers and I could only seemingly tell how far I had progressed via exciting and selecting the level I was on. Then again it still didn’t tell me how much of that level I had left and how many more levels were left. The only way I could tell how many levels were left was via the Achievements. This concept is annoying as they should show each level and part of level as locked, not hidden, to make it easier to know how far you have left). ♦ No real storyline (Tried to implement some kind of Storyline but never executed it well enough to make any sense or significant impact on the game) ♦ Wasn’t aware some levels had hidden objects that I needed to collect to progress later in game (Not being aware of this until I needed these hidden objects to progress is really annoying as I would have searched and collected them on my first run through to save me having to repeat the levels again just to find one hidden object)  On a Side Note:  ♦ I haven’t finished the game as much as I wanted to because even though I had only played 2-3 hours of it, it was already getting on my nerves. I say this because it was repetitive and never really offered anything new in the terms of its puzzles per level and every time I progressed, I felt like I was just playing to get the next achievement. Then when I got to the point where it said I had to go back to levels I had already complete and find hidden Stars to progress… it just ruined the whole game for me and I closed it. I ultimately wanted something new, not having to go back and search old levels for something I missed on the first run.  Overall, even though there are a lot of cons, I never finished the game and probably won’t and the gameplay is repetitive, I can still recommend this. I recommend this if you want something easy and relaxing that has great graphics and eargasmic sounds. Therefore, I recommend you pick it up for that reason. However, if you are buying it solely for the gameplay, I’d recommend buying it on sale at the cheapest possible price due to lack of actual puzzles and how repetitive it is as mentioned in my side note and cons.

There is literally nothing bad that I can think of about Scribblenauts Unlimited. The custom content allows you to add in virtually anything to the game to complete the puzzles with. So if you're stuck for a solution, make your own!  Also, the inclusion of adjectives in this game is something I wanted since playing the first Scribblenauts game, and they did it in a BIG way. You can come up with all kinds of strange things. For example, I bet you've never been able to say you were flying around on a giant rainbow penguin with demonic wings that could breathe fire. With this game, now you can.  Your creativity is the only thing that limits what you can do in this game (aside from the profanity filter). If you haven't played it already by now, do it. You'll have an absolute blast.

Writing this review much later than the release date of the game, and im well aware that the reality of someone reading this is slim to none. But I couldnt pass up on the opportunity. Through all of the negative reviews and glitches of this game, I would still rather play this game than 90% of the others on steam.   Im 30 hours in and barely into sequence 6. There is so much to do in paris that it is a never ending trail of fantastic entertainment. I couldnt imagine a better way to play through the french revolution. The charm of AC has always been its work into the detail in architecture and historical accuracy (to an extent of course, I know Shay Cormac didnt actually murder George Washingtons older brother).   So if I can help convince one person to play this game instead of listening to the glitch ♥♥♥♥♥ers, I did a good thing. The story and detail of this game make up for any glitch that comes up through the entire game. Happy hunting initiates.

Wait before buying this game.  I have a PC that could handle this terrible port most of the time. That said, I still experienced plenty of bugs that at best slowed the game and at worse crashed it. I enjoyed the game but there are many issues with this port and it has not been optimized for PC.  The game is basically what you would come to expect from the Dead Rising series. There are lots of zombies to kill and weapons to use. Crafting has been streamlined. Any item can be created at any time if the blueprints for it have been found and the items in the player's inventory. It is important to note that when leveling the character, Nick Ramos, any point put into unlocking crafting options does not unlock blueprints. Instead investing points in a crafting category will let the player use any item of a particular type to craft an item. For example, the 'Laser Sword' is a combination of a flashlight (electronic item) and gems (thrown item). If the player invests in the 'electronic item' category then they can use any electronic item and gems to make a laser sword. The game also features combination vehicles that can be made anywhere.   Survivors are no longer useless like they were in the previous games. Now survivors have half decent A.I., aren't restricted to escort/babysitting missions, and can be used to create a 'posse' that can be given basic orders (attack/follow/scavenge).  I recommend not using any DLC weapons or vehicles during normal gameplay as it can unbalance the game quickly.   Hours played: 66  Final score: 7/10

Skullgirls is a fast-paced 2-D fighting game that puts players in control of fierce warriors in an extraordinary Dark Deco world. Featuring all-new game systems which test the skills of veteran fighting game fans while also making the genre enjoyable and accessible to newcomers, Skullgirls is a modern take on classic arcade fighters with a hand-drawn high-definition twist. It’s a one-of-a-kind, action-packed competition complete with awesome combos and an intriguing backstory.

A massive undertaking for any studio, much less an indie, this game combines the hardcore military simulation that the Arma series is known for with a surprisingly epic campaign that manages to be realistic, dramatic, and compelling all at the same time. It has multiple branch points, multiple endings, and showcases a very plausible tour of duty for a spec ops unit during a conflict between a psuedo-Ukraine and Russian-backed rebels (which turned out to be quite prescient...)

It seems I may have overestimated this game... But I cannot down rate it either.  The story is alright: survival horror is done right, I was really scared of glasps. Ammo is scarce, especially on higher difficulties, you'll get more points instead of the ammo. The plot is great too: lots of references to past RE games, we finally got Claire back,  but I really hate that stupid Barry's appearance change , (Scratched that because I solved this prob with a mod replacing his face with the one from Remaster). I also like that some of the mechanics from RE6 are back, like finishers. It kept me playing until I got all achievements and S ranks on all episodes and difficulties.  And now to the most disappointing part - the Raid Mode. At first it was really exciting, I've been replaying the first episode for 50 hours. All these new additions - passive and active skills they are really great addition to Raid. You can build up your own set of skills and create various play styles. There were only 2 gauntlets +1 I got from Throwback Map pack. I was looking forward to release of online feature and a new difficulty. Eventually after release of the last episode, the online feature was delayed, and we got a new difficulty which doesn't change enemy spawns, has 4 chests instead of 3, and all enemies were 6 levels above you. This couldn't bring any challenge. I've finished new difficulty a week before online was released. Then they promised to raise difficulty, and I had high hopes for this... and what did they do eventually?   They've risen the enemy's level by 15 above yours.  . Considering the power of my current guns, I can beat literally any stage on any difficulty with lvl 1. There was nothing new after online was released,  you can't even perform grapple breakers in co-op game  which is ridiculous, though you can perform them in campaign, how screwed up is that?  Conclusion: 7/10. This was the most awaited game for me this year, which I stopped playing much faster than expected.

Originally released as a mod for the first Half-Life, Fistul of Frags has been rereleased on Steam and is better than ever. This fantastic shooter allows you to don the spurs of a cowboy and wield some badass wild west weaponry to shoot, stab, and kick your friends. With a simplistic concept and unique, classic game mechanics, Fistul of Frags is a fun little shooter that will keep you hooked for hours, just don't forget to pass the whiskey.

You will often hear people refer to this game as 'Like Minecraft, but 2D.' Because Minecraft was infact very iconic to the genre, this is a fact. However, their genre and dirt blocks are pretty much the closest thing they have in common. I can't say this enough, because of the fact that I find this game alot more entertaining and fun than Minecraft. In Terraria you have: An amazing and atmospheric soundtrack for every biome and situation; Unique items; Various Bosses; Many tiers of gear; NPC's who will come to live at your house and sell you stuff; An endless possibility of fun and exciting adventures, like killing such things as a flying fish, pirates, zombies and even crazy clowns. All in all, a tremendous amount of worth for all you're paying and if you have the money and it's on sale, you have little to no excuse as to not aquire it.

Overall I great improvement from the first, definitely runs better than most.  However, it feels as though we are aimlessly doing nothing at least from the first opening missions that is.  I am yet to try multiplayer or the coop.

app_name: Learn Japanese To Survive - Hiragana Battle
review_text: Introduction to the Hiragana part of the japanese language. The developers are also working on a Katakana part to be released later. You learn by succesfully 'defeating' hirgana enemies by translating them correctly. On the developers homepage you can also buy studyguides in digital or paper form among other things. If you dont enjoy studying the traditional way (through books) this game may be for you. As far as i have gotten the impression this is supposed to be a introduction to tthe japanese language, and you are likely to need further studies after finishing this game if you wish to truly learn japanese.

Welcome to the game of rolling dice, a simulator where it doesn't matter who you picked or what you do, because every decision you make comes down to whether you can roll 1d6. I played 12 games of this 'game' and let me give you a rundown of how each turn plays out. You get to move your players into positions to give them strategic advantages then fight the other team to knock them down. The most common 'advantageous' roll you'll get is 2d6 to pick one depending on what you want.  So you roll 2d6.  Double skulls. Skulls knock down your player, not theirs.  So you use one of your 'team rerolls' to change the outcome.  Double skulls. Your player falls over and your turn ends instantly.  You haven't moved anyone, or done anything. Your turn is done. The other guy then takes his turn, knocking down every single one of your team regardless of the odds. Heck, he can roll 2 dice disadvantaged and he'll 100% of the time score adouble knockdown that you can't avoid. Half of your team will be injured or KO'd in the first round and unable to play for the rest of the game which is IMPORTANT, as he now outnumbers you 11 to 5.  Now it's your turn again. Somehow get 2d6 to roll.  Roll double skulls.  Use a reroll?   Double skulls.  You're saying to yourself at this point 'wow, this guys just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting. What a moron this never happens to me'. I played 12 games and this happened at least once in EVERY SINGLE GAME. Did it happen to my opponents? NO. If they tried to make plays where they needed to dodge twice, each time at 17%, would they make it? 100% of the time, yes. Not a single person I played against lost more than 2 rolls in the entire match. By the time it got to game 10, I was so sick of this rng nightmare that I was conceding on the third turn after most of my team were dead or had broken legs and missing limbs while his players were at the line with not a single penalty.  I was under the impression that thinking about this game mattered in some way, but trust me, it doesn't, If I could go lower than 1/10 I would for this, but for the sake of it, lets just leave it at 1/10. Without reducing my settings to the lowest possible on quite a high end machine, the game crashed out constantly or took so long to register an action that a quarter of my turn was already wasted by the time people moved. On the first day I played, the servers were so broken it was disconnecting people midway through the match which forced both teams to concede a loss.  This game is -not- playable in its current state and I would not recomend any of you spend even £5 on something you could replicate by buying 3d6 and shoving them down your friends throat while their young children watched. £35 is like asking a poor man for 3 of his limbs to give him a cup of water, not even slightly worth it.  DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.
