Orcs Must Die is a third person, action, tower defense game. You play as the War Mage, who's job is to kill Orcs, often in rather comical ways. In each level, the Orcs will spawn in waves and try to enter the rift and it's your job to kill them. This done via laying traps, using weapons, or placing guardians to fight by your side. After each level, you will be given a new power to use and skulls based on how well you did; the less Orcs that make it through the rift and the faster you do it, the more skulls you earn. These skulls can then be spent on upgrades for your traps and guardians.   After many hours of gameplay and tens of thousands of Orcs slain, I can safety say that this game IS FREAKING AWESOME. I've sunk about 45 hours into this game (counting the dlc missions). Let that sink in: 45 hours of gameplay! There are triple A games out there that give a fraction of gametime with several times the cost. It's a steal, esspecially if you can get on sale.   However, this game is about exactly one thing: killing Orcs. Beyond that, there's really nothing else to do, but for its price, its a hard deal to beat. If your own the fence, try the demo or watch some clips on youtube. And if you like what you see, buy it. Especially if you can get the entire series bundled and discounted.   TLDR: 10/10   Disclaimer: No Orcs were harmed in the writing of this review. Harmed before, oh hell yes!

Interestingly little game, but frustrating at times. I am glad i only paid a couple of bucks for this because it felt 'unpolished'. Despite the frustrations, it was still fun and entirely solvable. There is a story plot which is... crazy. The frustrating parts I had: rules do not always seem sufficient to play - sometimes you have to make intuitive guesses about the nature of the clues themselves. Keep in mind the golden rule for this game: 'all puzzles should be optimaly solved.' Remember this rule - often times you may find ONE solution, but it is not the BEST solution. (Insect boxes come to mind here) Sometimes how the puzzle works is not apparent until you start clicking on things, or clicking for a hint. Sometimes the rules or hints themselves are sub-optimal. Sometimes it is simply a click or drag fest (the 'dont overlap pieces puzzles) But don't worry, you should have all those bubble gum hints saved up, and I think three attempts on one puzzle was the worst I did. I will pass on one spoiler type hint    Certain CODES can be solved by looking at the Negative space, or by covering the left or right half of a symbol

Truly, this game is very under-rated. It has an amazing mix of elements that everyone can enjoy. It can be hardcore or casual. It has a class system like no other MMO. This game really deserves more praise. It is easily the most unique 'classic' MMORPG. Of course, there are a few minor issues (Most of it is getting used to navigating the map system); but, what MMO doesn't have them? This game is perfect for Final Fantasy fans while being very accessible to people who know nothing of the series. This is the ONLY MMO that I have ever played that I actually feel deserves a monthly subscription. I have played WoW off and on from 2006-2013. I played Guild wars from release until 2011. I have even played Guild Wars 2 since closed Beta until recently. Of course, I have played alot of other MMO's. That being said, FFIV: ARR has interested me and entertained me FAR more than any of those MMO's. It has a certain charm that the other MMO's that I have played don't have. I honestly feel like this is the most 'well-rounded' MMO that exists. I recommend everyone to pick it up and see for themselves. It never hurts to try! I am just very concerned that this game may fall into obscurity and become free to play...   Would I recommend it?   THIS IS THE ONLY GAME REQUIRING A MONTHLY FEE THAT I WOULD RECOMMEND ANY HUMAN TO PLAY!

If you've ever been interested in trying to juggle the demands of an economy, cultural identity, education, military, and generally everything a supreme leader has to deal with, plus catering to the whims of a sometimes illogical populace...then this is the game for you. It's like the sociopolitical version of Civilization.  I was running Canada. My people were some of the smartest on the planet, winning Nobel Prizes with ease, then the global economy tanked. My forward thinking economic policies helped to blunt the recession...for a time. Then, slowly, my secular policies came back to bite me as unemployment, homelessness, and religious extremism began to rise.  10/10. Would get car-bombed again.

With his army smashed and little way left to reclaim what was his, he’s forced to recruit platoons from oft-ignored less savoury races. He starts with a few zombies and a couple of skeletons. That’s not going to do it.  Full Review //  http://www.honestgamers.com/12692/pc/reverse-crawl/review.html

SCB  is a great arcade game, one with gameplay that can be enjoyed in any decade, same as other great arcade games like  Asteroids Deluxe . The objective is super easy to grasp and easy to control in a way that feels like eating comfort food while snuggled in bed. That written, the gameplay itself is active and captivating; challenging and non-stop. The sounds and music all do their job well, with the exception of the bad menu theme and annoying menu sound effect(s). The unlock progression is good, and the game's short play length is extremely easy to come back to time and time again. You could play this game for five minutes or two hours and have an equally great time either way. I never get bored of this game (partially because of the weapon changing), and I can feel myself get better at it the more I play.  The game is free (not from lack of quality). I'm almost certain you won't regret downloading it. This may even become your new favorite game.

Ask yourself a very simple question: Do you love the old Micro Machines games?  If the answer is yes, then chances are you'll love this too.  It's pretty much everything you loved about the old games: fast, close and fun races; innovative tracks based on breakfast tables, playrooms, school rooms and pool tables.  You can even set the view to the classic 'top down', which makes it a lot easier to spot short cuts but isn't really how the game is meant to be played.  The single player campaign is rather short. I finished it in less than four hours, which is something to be aware of.  I also found online to be a little bit buggy and laggy, though this could have been my connection rather than a server side issue. I'd have to play more to find out.  I haven't played local multi-player yet but it should be a hoot!  If you're not sure, try the demo. For me it turned this game from a 'wait until it's on sale' to a 'I need this right now!'  It may be a short and quite simple game, but it's very, very sweet.  I can't wait to get this game on with three other peeps, it'll be an absolute blast!

Sweet controls. Engaging music. Rad grafix. INDIE DELIGHT!  I played the demo for this game back when it first came out on the Wii and instantaneously fell in love with it. The super-hip use of the retro-esque style really caught my eye. Not to mention I'm a sucker for colorful things. Although the look of BIT.TRIP RUNNER is what brought my attention to this game... it was the awesome, tight controls that made me stay. It's a great mix of platforming, style, and controls that anyone who can appreciate those things should consider picking it up.  The aesthetics and minimal-yet amazing controls aren't the only great things about BIT.TRIP RUNNER! The music for this game is also magnificent. Little beats come out whenever you successfully pass an obstacle. It's so cool. It really makes you feel like you're a part of the game, as though you are orchestrating these really cool tunes. Personally, it's the game's best feature.  Despite it being such a cool game, at times it CAN be a bit frusterating. Especially if you aren't particularly great at platformers (I have no problems there, considering I'm a wiz at platformers!) You'll find yourself getting screwed over by obstacles that you don't know are coming, which will take you back to the beginning of the level. But then you'll know what's in store for you! So don't give up!  And getting to the finish line is one of the most satisfying things.  All in all, I have deep appreciation for the game, and this review was more a way for me to publicly gush about this game than it is a review. If you're reading this, you already know that I think this game is great. So go try it for yourself and see if you like it! BIT.TRIP RUNNER is one of those games that everyone should at least try once. It'll show you that there are some amazing indie games out there!

A peaceful life in exile, where you fantasize about starting over from the roots with just a hand full of comrades. This is what Banished offers as a town building simulation. Unlike it's competition, the challenge is in building a successful settlement and that all depends on micromanaging it's development while weathering the natural disasters of everyday medieval life. Those disasters include weather, the dangerous work of mining, and the great risks of fire, starvation, and disease. You'll likely abandon a few towns before you get this game right, but it's interesting to watch life unfold and it feels rewarding to succeed. It's a perfect game to sit down with a hot drink in the evenings and just mellow out to the calm rhythms of rustic life.

Scores are at the bottom.  Setting:   You are Garry; an alcoholic mourning the loss of his family. One afternoon, you go for a plane ride on business to deliver a few things. All of a sudden, a volcano erupts, and the turbulence bring you down. Even though you were certain to die, a strange package activates an ancient power in an attempt to save you. You wake up, about to be sacrificed to an aboriginee tribe's deity. You notice that there was something even stranger about these people. You free yourself, kill your opposition, and solve an ancient puzzle that hides an ancient weapon. The temple caves in, and you just barely escape death for the second time. This is where the game begins.  Review:  Usually, when I see a game with such negative reviews, I'm ever tempted to buy it, just so I can confirm the reviews are honest. I had just gotten a USD $50 gift card for Steam. I bought the games I wanted, and had USD $4 remaining or so. I'm very impatient when I have money, so I had to find something to spend it on. This game, along with Takedown: Red Sabre, came on sale for USD $1.49 each. I caved, and bought both. I will tell you, the time I have in this game was real play time; not just letting it run for cards. That was just compensation for the time I wasted in this game.  I usually appologize or beg to be heard out for giving a negative review, but I feel it's not necessary here. As soon as you load the game, you notice your framerate drop tremendously, even on higher performance PCs. After you find a way to stablize your framerate, you begin the game. You see a dream of your character's wife calling to him. The dream ends, and you see your character. It's obvious that cutscenes were a last minute idea for the game. I've seen more stable animation in Garry's Mod. Why, oh why do you share this man's name, Garry? The voice acting is less than pleasent, and the graphics are horrendous on all but the highest performance PCs. The story is not well put together, but passable. The inventory system is interesting, and is good in concept, but severely lacking in implementation. The bad combat system and bountiful amount of bugs almost rival that of Aquaman: Battle For Atlantis. Almost. Oh, who am I kidding; nothing is worse than that. The plus, however, is that the game does have a good soundtrack. That alone may save it from getting eternally condemned to the less than 4/10 zone.  Scores:  Story: 5/10 Stability (Lack of Bugs): 2/10 Stability (Performance): 2/10 Combat System: 3/10 Soundtrack: 8/10 Replay Value: Undecided...  Final Score: 4/10. Recomended buy price: Undecided...  Final Thoughts:  That was honestly unintended. I consider a game 'condemned to death' if their overall score goes below 4/10 (even if it's 3.9999999999999999999999999999999) which is generous, considering most people say that about 6/10 games and sometimes even higher rated games. I cannot recommend this game. I will play it again, if at least just to complete the story mode and establish the score for replay value. If you genuinely want to judge this game for yourself, I won't (and can't) stop you from buying it. I do, however, recommend that you AT LEAST buy it when it's on sale for USD $1.49.

I avoided this game for a small time as I was a backer of Pillars of Eternity and assumed this was merely a knock off given the success PoE had in crowdfunding. I was wrong.  When I finally got the game, I really wish I'd got it sooner. Few games compel me to 'trophy hunt' but this is one of them. In fact, only three Steam games ever have; this, GameDev Tycoon and Skyrim. Though the latter I no longer have everythign thanks to expansions.  What really makes this game great is the sheer amount of choice. It really reminds me of my days playing Baldurs Gate or Aracanium. But also the dialogue is quite amusing. Sure some bits are a little obvious but others less so. It doesn't have much in the way of difficult puzzle solving, but it's still a fun story to play though.  I waited on reviewing the game until my PoE had come in. I backed at $350 tier and was eaglery awaiting PoE. While I've only spent a few hours in it thus far, it did not grab my attention like Original Sin did. I'd therefore have to say thus far Original Sin blasts PoE out of the water. My only gripe is character progression, I'd like to have seen something a little more closed in so that classes were more meaningful.

Such a good game, even if you don't like or have never played Tomb Raider before. The game is Brilliant, the story is amazing and shows the turn from innocent archeologist to battle hardened tomb raider is done perfectly, the way the game starts with not wanting to kill anyone, and how it advances to all mofos must die is brilliant, and does not come on too quickly like in Farcry 3. The gameplay is highly similar to the Uncharted series, which is a extremely good thing, but the shooting is much more tactful (somewhat like The Last Of Us) on normal+ difficulty, where ammo is not abundant for anything except the bow until late in game, (I think i stopped using the bow approx an hour from the end due to many enimies).  So there we have it, good traits from games such as Uncharted and The Last Of Us (Addmittedly they are PS3 exclusives so you may have not played them if you only plat PC.), it is deffinately worth purchasing, especially if it ever goes on offer!

I purchased this game in Early Access, I didn't play much then, but I can say there has been TONS of changes since. I'm going to keep this short cause I dont want to write much. So have a Pro/Cons list.    Pros    Challenging after about 10 days ingame   Great music at each time of day   Leveling + Perks   Cartoon graphics, this might not be a good thing for the  HARDCORE GRAPHICS  people   Other things I cant think about as of writing this     Cons    Tutorial, but once you know its easy   UI a little bare, probaly will improve   Price changing; you set it to a % increase, but you have to change it for other items for example: Sword = 150%, but then you want your Boots to be set lower, so you have to change it. Then someone knocks your Sword off, then you have to pick it up and put your price back up to 150%, and so on. It gets to a point were you just keep everything at one %, only thing that would need to be done is make each item have thier own price mark up, so this isn't a problem.   Overall? 8/10, minor fixes, but still worth the money.  Well I guess I lied about not writing much.

I've always heard a lot about this game, and been intrigued by it due to it's credentials for controversy. Finally decided to buy it and try for myself. I wasn't expecting much in terms of gameplay but am I in for a surprise. 10 years on and I have to say I haven't played a game this fun for a long while. Yes, it's very crude and sets out to offend, and production values are pretty low, but that's actually the point, and in fact where the wacky fun comes in. I don't play video games to be polictically correct!  The very wide variety of weapons and items in an open world with plenty of NPC in-fighting allows for creative play which IMHO is unmatched by any game in recent history. The fact that you can wee on yourself to put out a flesh fire is unprecedented (and dare I say, unlikely to be replicated) in gaming history and reason enough to experience this game.   They simply don't make games like this anymore. If only someone has the guts to make and, most of all, publish something like this today!

DOTA 2 is the best in the MOBA class. I've played LoL, DOTA and some lesser known MOBAs and DOTA 2 is by far the best. In addition, it is F2P which is amazing. Unlike LoL or HoN which require you to use a rotating hero list until you buy your own with real money or accumulate enough in-game currency to buy a single hero, DOTA 2 immediately gives you access to its entire library of heroes, for free. The only paid content are cosmetical items that do not change gameplay. Graphics are great. Gameplay is great. Crashes are very minimal. ITS FREE.

WARNING: SPOILERS  If you're a fan of The Lord of the Rings franchise, then this game is definitely something you should consider playing. Personaly I haven't seen any of the LotR movies or read the books, although I have seen both of The Hobbit films that have been released to this date and I immediately fell in love with them, and after playing this game I am much more interested in the Middle-earth Saga.  For those who don't know, the LotR universe and The Hobbit universe are both set in the same place: Middle-earth.Therefore within Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, you are going to come across some very recognisable characters if you are a fan of the fantasy orc slaying franchise. Anyway, lets get on to talking about the game itself. You play as Talion, a once Captain of an army called The Watch. After your Wife and Son were slain before you by someone known as The Black Captain, you soon await your turn along side your family. After facing certain death, you are resurrected by a powerful Wraith who was once a man working for The Dark Lord, Sauron. Talion being unknown to this Wraith's true identity aswell as the Wraith himself, they embark on a quest to find out who he is and where he came from.  The gameplay in SoM is outstanding. Put aside a few glitches and bugs that I have encounted, Monolith Productions did a near perfect job on the mechanics. The combat is very familiar to any that have played The Arkham series, some developers have tried this kind of mechanic, but only a few have made it work, like they have in this game in particular. The parkour feels very similar to Assassins Creed and the way Talion moves feels very life like and not choppy or glitchy. The Wraith who's soul is bound to yours, gives you superhuman like abilities, such as jumping off incredible hightes without taking damage and being able to take control of Orcs and turning them against each other. Talion, being a Ranger for most of his life is very skilled in combat. He wields a Sword named Urfael and a Dagger named Acharn. They can both be upgraded throughout the game using collectable items called Runes. Each of his weapons have unique ablities when equipped with a Rune. The Wraith is a very skilled Bow man, and holds with him Azkâr (his bow). Azkâr too can be upgraded by Runes.  The graphics are absolutely beautiful. By far some of the best I have seen in any video game. The character designs are incredibly life like and have insane amounts of detail put into them. The voice acting is fresh and faultless, and when it comes to the Orcs and Uruks, they sound exactly how I'd have imagine them to. Sometimes it is admirable to use the newly added screen shot mechanic to pause the game and just gaze at how brilliantly designed the Monsters and enemies look in this game. The Graug, which is a fifteen feet tall troll like creature, looks incredible. I wouldn't want to come face to face with one of them in real life.  One thing I do have to talk about in this review is probably one of the best features about SoM, the Nemesis system. The Uruks are ranked in this game according to what power level they are. The higher the level, the higher the ranking. They each have their own unique randomly generated name and personality. A feature that I do like is when an Uruk kills you, if you find the exact same one again it will recognise you and taunt you about the last time you and him met and lost. The Nemesis system is made up of Grunts, Captains and Warchiefs. Grunts are just a common Orc or Uruk that you, as the player, will come up againts throughout your journey but a grunt can prove itself by killing you and therefore be promoted to a Captain. A Captain is a higher level of Uruk, they are body guards to the warchiefs and are stronger than your common enemies. Warchiefs are the strongest kind of Uruk, and are not found on the map, instead they must be drawn out by completing a certain objective, for example killing a number of its own Uruks or killing off its supporters with a certain weapon. Once you have defeated a Warchief, it will drop a Rune which you can add to its assigned weapon. Although if it kills you, it will only grow in power, as of now the highest level of power it can reach is 20. However, each Nemesis has its weaknesses which can be discovered by interrogating an Uruk that holds intel or just by finding it on a note somewhere scatted around the map.   The world you play in is fairly big, and to save you from running on foot from place to place, you have the ability to take control of a terrifying beast known as the Caragor and ride it which increases your speed. As well as this, there are watch towers scatted around the map and, if discovered, you can fast travel to them. After completing the game, there is still a whole bunch of things to do, such as side missions which include killing a certain number of Uruks in a certain amount of time to earn an award or Mirian (the games currency), or freeing slaves of Sauron. There is also a few collectables in the game, such as artifacts and Ithildin. There are 42 artifacts spread out across Mordor, once you have found one you can activate its memory and listen to it which can sometimes be quite interesting. Ithildin, like artifacts, are spread out across Mordor. There are 32 of them and are small glowing markings hidden on walls and can only be seen once you are in the wraith world, this is also the case with artifacts. You can enter the Wraith world by pressing the assigned button on a controller or keyboard, this is used to locate targets or to spot artifacts and Ithildin.  Overall, it is a well polished game. With stunning graphics, brilliant gameplay and an intriguing story-line, I have fallen in love with it. Although, after a while the Nemesis system can start to get very old and boring, which takes the toll on the game since it plays a big part in it. Although it feels very rewarding when you slay a high level Warchief after it has defeated you multiple times, it can get very repetitive. With all of those points taken into account, Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor gets a 9/10 from me.

Five and/or seven out of seven, depending on the quantum state of Dr. Allen Carter's interpretation of the afterlife.  It ain't a perfect game by any means. It's very unrefined, even after release; voiceovers of inconsistent quality, text sometimes reading more like a foreign language than English, story left open-ended, performance issues here and there, an end-game cutscene that makes the Uncanny Valley look shallow in comparison, those sorts of things. Planet Explorers has its trouble spots, to be sure.  Underneath that bit of rough, though, is a diamond, raw as it may be. This game's got good bones. Unlike most voxel-oriented games (including ones in the public spotlight much later), Planet Explorers offers the ability to build things on a smaller scale than terrain and buildings; vehicles, weapons, and even (to an extent) body armor are all able to be custom-designed by the player, and sharing these custom creations online with other players is an absolute breeze using the in-game workshop. Both the pre-defined map in 'Story Mode' and the procedurally-generated random maps in 'Adventure Mode' offer spectacular landscapes. The wildlife feels both familiar and alien at the same time, and the storyline - while rough in execution in many respects - is believable and engaging.  Most importantly, though, is a development team that has demonstrated itself to be committed to working with players to fix problems and continually improve the game. Communication has been bidirectional and top-notch, and the developers are quick to squish bugs as they're reported (even amid the influx of post-release feedback).  All in all, a great game. Rough around the edges, sure, but shiny and clean is for AAA shops; Planet Explorers is an example of an Early Access game gone right even amid the risk of things going horribly wrong (as tends to be the case for games with even a fraction of the scope offered by Planet Explorers).

I would only hesitate to call this a game only for lack of a better description, but don't let that deter you from experiencing Viridi first-hand. There is really no reason not to download this game.

It's not all that heavily updated-- I used to play a lot of different total-conversion plugins (mods) for the first couple of EV games, and, aside from a few differences in the interface, playing Endless Sky feels more like having gotten a new TC than a whole new game-- but I don't see any reason to consider this a bad thing.   Also, it's nice to see more free and open-source software (FOSS) on Steam.   Now all I've got to do is figure out how to mod in the Tachyonic Fighter from Frozen Heart and I'll be very much set. :D

This game is buggy, the 'totorial missions' of sorts leave some important details out at times, and the UI is a disaster of epic proportions... there are dozens of gripes about this game... but even with all of the con's, this game continues to pull you back in with the beautiful detail and core gameplay.  While this game missed it's potential by a large mark, there is hope in the future for this game with updates, DLC, and hopefully lots of mods. It is much faster paced than the older X series games. It in itself is a very fun and enjoyable game, but if you are looking for great polish or amazing story pulled together by great voice acting and brilliant UI to help you through it... Look elsewhere.  If you can stand a few bugs, and some frustration, this game will keep you entertained for a long time. If not, look back at this game in 6 months to a year.

Sky Force Anniversary: ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~   Sky Force Anniversary is a classic fast and furious arcade shoot-‘em-up game.   You will have to go through 9 missions with each starting at the normal level. You will need to achieve 4 requested challenges to unlock the next difficulty level. There are 3 difficulties per level: Normal, Hard and Insane.   Every time you destroy an enemy, a star will appear at the exact place of its destruction. Make sure you collect as many stars as possible per mission. You will be able to spend your stars to upgrade your vessel health, guns, missiles, shield and Mega BOMB (YEAHHHHH). You will find out very quickly, it is important to upgrade your vessel or you will not be able to achieve your challenges or get through to the end of the mission.   Do not forget the people in red suits; they will need to be rescued too. Also, if one of your steam friends is playing Sky Force Anniversary you will be able to see where he/she was killed and you can rescue him/her for additional points.   There are also 22 in-game cards to collect and each of them has an additional ability which will be very useful to you. The game runs smoothly, has good graphics and a good soundtrack. I prefer using a gamepad but you still can play with the mouse and it is enjoyable too.   Positives: ~~~~~~~~   - Classic Arcade Game - Runs Smoothly - Plenty of goodies to upgrade and abilities to gain - Addictive - Achievements - Trading Cards  Negatives:  ~~~~~~~~~   - Would of like more levels - A bit repetitive  Looking for a fast, furious and addictive shoot-‘em-up game? Don’t look further than Sky Force Anniversary!  7/10    MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HERE      FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

With all the overwhelming reviews for this title, along with the promise of psychological horror got me really interested, but playing this in the first place was quite the mistake  The game progressive at an alarming rate and becomes stale pretty quicky. The attempt at horror is just terrible, this game hasn't offered me any of that good old paranoia that a game of it's type promises. The dialogue feels rushed and it leaves no impact on me at all. The hacking bits were nice, but became somewhat boring and it didn't give me the degrees of freedom as I expected it to. The story seemed to have been alterable at first glance, but it's all in a fine line, everything along it, you see coming. This feels like nothing more than an flash game with a price tag, and that's what upsets me most.  I'm going to see if I can refund this, don't be fooled by the massive amount of short and undetailed positive reviews.

The Showdown Effect is what happens when a bunch of game devs, who happen to be me massive action film aficiandos, play a game of Super Smash Bros. and think 'This could do with more dismemberment.' It's insanely addictive. Crazy weapons, hilarious gamemodes, fun levels (not too many on release, mind) and a cast of characters ripping off Every Arnie Character Ever, Jack Bauer, Mr. Miyagi and more; and stick them in a sidescrolling multiplayer deathmatch of complete awesomeness. Just get it. You won't be disappointed.  EDIT: Game is dead. No players. No content updates. I began playing this game on a couple of weeks ago after finally making the decision to buy it. The game plays like 4-player L4D2 in many ways but no zombies. Good graphics, sounds, ambience, music, characters and storyline. Every game is different! Things are mixed up so each mission or campaign will be all its own.   Higher level players are wonderfully helpful to noobs. The voice features are excellent and I recommend that you prepare to use that in the game to coordinate with your team. This game is PERFECT for those of us who like to play together as part of a team which helps one another. If that's your sort of thing, this is the best game! I have met some of the nicest players on there!  If you don't have this game, GET THIS GAME! Sale or no sale, GET IT!

The Frustration of not being able to do the 'right thing' in the begining, the sadness and despair, the lack of energy...I remember all this too well. This game is fantastic, I played it endlessly on xbox and now that I have it on steam I find myself playing almost every day to compete in the daily.

Cons -To many cheap deaths or unavoidable bullets, especially so durign bossfights -Not enough content. I beat the story mode in a bit less than an hour without much reason to go back besides getting a higher score. Which isn't fun when the missions the same everytime to me and is excacerbated by small number of missions. And small variaty in enemies and bosses. -Handles continues and deaths in a weird way. HP is accustomed to a timer. Killing things gets you a few seconds on your timer while getting it takes time. The timer is also always counting down and in the case it hits zero you die. You can use a continue to restart. Its just a weird system -In tunnel areas its extremely easy to hit a wall and possibly insta die because the hitbox of the wall and the graphic are not always in the same place as to allow you to know where you will take damage and not. -Hamfisted story thats hard to care about and gets more in the way than anything. -Narration in some made up gibberish language instead of english. At that point, why even narrate? -Everyone is an ugly furry, no sexy husky men or anthromorphic dragons or horses to be found.  -Repatitive gameplay thanks to lack of content.  Pros +Really good looking Shoot-Em Up. Both techincally and in graphical design and artistry put into characters, the world, and even the UI/menus. +Is still a fun game if you can look past the frustration from cheap deaths but probably still fun due to the basic Shoot-Em Up design behind it all   Summary Its an okay game. Don't be expecing a instant classic but its a game thats worth a dollar or two if you are interested in it. The current $10 retail is just to much with all I have seen in this game (which isn't a whole lot). Im actually glad I didn't get this on a Vita for more than I now think its worth.
Early Access Review

In 25 hours of gameplay time, I cleared out 8 regions out of 30 odd total regions. I don't feel like I'm progressing at all even though I'm at level 20. Game's original design being a MMORPG shows a lot and makes the game a huge timesink.  Let's proceed to the pros and cons:  Pros: -Good combat with interesting skills. -Artsyle is pretty good and immersive. -Lorestones are lovely with those pretty good ballads. -Character faces, bodies and animations are pretty good when compared to the something like Skyrim, but it's a result of game's aesthetic design. -Wonderfully crafted lore by R.A Salvatore. -Unique items actually mean something and finding one of them is very rewarding again unlike Skyrim. -Skill system is intriguing and allows many versatile gameplay choices. (Although I went with full might because Amalur belongs to the Nords!) -A good variety of combos.  Cons: -Towns are huge immersion breakers. They consist of three buildings and people sleeping on the inn halls. Also filler NPC's that give generic answers don't sleep at all. -There aren't enough dialogue options and having a high persuasion skill usually means better loot for the quest. (But one time, I managed to end a quest with it. NPC said 'But you had to die' I said 'But I don't want to die' then he went 'Oh, ok then.' that was great and hilarious.) -Too many shallow side quests with little variety. Gets very very repetitive and that's one of the major reasons I'm done playing KoA:R. -Regions are connected through narrow roads and you can't discover the sides of these roads. Instead of feeling like an open world game as it aimed, it becomes a network of regions. -No horses, no way to go through one end of the map to the other quickly. You're dependant on fast travel. -Enemies that you kill on the roads spawn back too quickly and it rather becomes a tedious task. -Not much diversity on enemy types. -Enemies do not have origins. Why Kobolds are Kobolds? Why Ettin are Ettin? Is their sole purpose of being in the game is getting killed by the player?  Grand Finale: Game is good, I can't bring myself to play to the end but for these 25 hours was pretty fun and I never felt so engaged to a game since Skyrim. But seeing that I'm at 25 hours and only completed 8 regions, I thought that I should stop. This was not a decision taken by boredom, in fact never felt boredom playing this game but it seemed like the logical thing to do. If you have time and like RPG games it's a must play. Even if you don't have enough time to complete the game you should play it for the atmosphere until you feel it becomes repetitive. For this kind of experience, this game is dirt cheap.  I feel like if the dev team had time, money and it wasn't built upon a failed MMO project, it could have been a great game. Unfortunately Big Huge Games bankrupted after low sales of this game, so we're not getting any kind of sequel. It's a damn shame because the world of Amalur is so immersive and has enormous potential as an universe.

I played a TR Engineer and had a blast with this game and felt good when I saved the life of a friendly MAX or vehicle.  The only thing that irks me about this game are the K/D padding snipers that can be annoying as hell to fight. Same goes for the Heavy Gunners with the invulerability. OK, so I would have like a sprite based RTS more, but you cannot deny how fun the gameplay is.  As a old school C&C diehard fan, this is like candy. All I've wanted from an RTS since Red Alert 2 is more of the feel those classic games provided, and its taken this long to get us there.  8-Bit Armies is as basic as it gets right now, but its FUN. My first 8 player FFA online made me feel like I was 15 again, skirting responsibilities to stay up later to play.  It is shallow however, but there are shades of greatness here. If Petroglyph keeps adding to this, it could be a great treat for RTS fans like myself who have been looking for the glory days of C&C.  Great job Petroglyph! I'll be telling my friends to pick this up!

app_name: Castlevania: Lords of Shadow - Ultimate Edition
review_text: This is a mediocre game that suffers severely from several key flaws.   First and foremost, it is a very poor console port that suffers from severe playability issues. The controls are unfamiliar to PC gamers as the mouse is not used for anything in the game. You can bind keys to mouse clicks, but you can't look around with the mouse or even select things in menus using the mouse.  The problems continue as you're not able to exercise any control over the camera, so you're often presented with clunky and awkward viewpoints and the camera will sometimes change from behind-the-character to in-front, for no reason. This will cause you to start running back the other direction, which will then cause the camera to flip back the other way, which will cause you to once again start running the other direction... you get the idea.  The second, and really far worse problem is the pacing of the game. The game opens with a battle (as any good game in this genre should) but before you even get to the battle, you have to deal with an obnoxiously long scene of Gabriel riding into town. Each camera pan and tilt is torturously slow and I really found myself wanting to skip cutscenes even though they are usually my favorite part of a game. This went on for the entire first act, which is about when I quit playing.  It actually takes you about 2 hours of play and a wandering course through several bog levels to even hear a mention of the namesake Lords of Shadow. It is then revealed that they are bad guys (obvious though it may be) and they are responsible for your wife's death. Apparently they had never caused trouble before 5 minutes ago, so no one had bothered to kill them. This is the only explanation for why you basically just head out alone to take on the infinite undead army, with absolutely no backup (except for Captain Picard).   You're in the Order of Light, a completely generic brotherhood of knights committed to blah blah blah against the darkness. Unfortunately, all they are good for is dying of disease in convenient locations to provide you with loot. Shouldn't the Order of Light have been--oh I don't know--trying to kill the Lords of Shadow all along? In the game world, it is common knowledge who the Lords of Shadow are, what they do, and where to find them. It's no big deal that they are unleashing hordes of Werewolves, Vampires and Necromancers on humanity... until they killed your wife, I guess. And then once you do decide to kill them, you don't bother telling anyone else in your Order because you want the 'element of surprise.'   Not joking.  The ultimate evil in the world has been left to fester unchecked for so long that 2 guys with swords constitute a surprise attack. This isn't exactly a Pearl Harbor scenario. What exactly has the Order of Light been DOING? Oh right. Dying of disease. In a swamp.  The game does have some redeeming points. They hired Patrick Stewart (Jean Luc Picard) to do the lion's share of the voiceover work, and they definitely got their money's worth. He puts in his best Shakespearean effort, but some of the monologues are so long and meandering that I was often left wandering the point was. Again, the pace of the narrative was ridiculously slow.  There is a Shadows of the Colossus tribute battle where you fight a big Ice Titan, but it didn't have nearly the challenge or puzzle elements of the original. Still, it was a high point. Unfortunately there's another 15 minutes of meaningless dialogue immediately after it, which then dramatically reveals that you have to kill the obvious bad guys.  It's not often that I don't finish a game I start, but this is one of them. I simply can't put myself through any more of this.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is the latest main Wolfenstein game, a series of FPS games, which sometimes have very light stealth implented, where you shoot and kiss many Nazi and other fictional beings nearby. This time it was developed by MachineGames and published by Bethesda in 2014. Smartly enough, developers decided to focus fully on single-player, with no multiplayer modes. Otherwise it would have got hated by Return to Castle Wolfenstein multiplayer fanatics for not being same, who don't care about singleplayer campaign. Game was developed with Id Engine 5, also used in RAGE, and was also made for PS3, PS4, Xbox 360 and Xbox One. There is no difference worthy to mention.  From technical side, I must note that AMD cards users will have harder times with this game. I remember how it would lag hard and crash even at intro movie at launch day. Good thing I updated to official Catalyst drivers and it got fixed, so I could enjoy my low-end laggy experience. No, I don't mind, I am used to being behind the times tech-wise.  The plot in this game is quite exciting. The Nazis, thanks to Deathshead, one of villians in previous Wolf games who now takes a main anatogonist role, advanced far above the Allies forces in technology, taking a horrifying shapes. It doesn't take them long to win the war and soon you will be out there, fighting your way through the world rebuild in evil Nazi ideology and style in 1960.  It's also executed cinematic-wise, awesomely. Blazkowich is back to his square-jaw and he now has non-stop inner monologues which deepens him as character. World is potrayed in dark tone. Your only friends are often weirdos. It has amazingly directed cutscenes and jaw-dropping setting. I also liked how action jumps from one point to another, and game never dumps a lot of info on you, saying little to create a big picture. Also helps with tastefully placed newspapers. Though it does have a lot of shockers. Adult thing and all. But at times it felt that some shockers were there just to increase the rating really. And why main hero is totally cool with NPC drugging him with boiled water, not punching into face?  You also get to make choice between two characters in the beggining of a story: Wyatt and Feigus. Big deal it's not. It barely changes cutscenes and story, they say same general things in each line. Just depends on how much you want to hear F-bombs. Feigus 'timeline' lets you find the permanent health limit upgrades, which is more useful than Wyatt's 'how much each armor pickup gives' upgrades. But also each of them gives you ability to access certain places and Wyatt seems to have more of them. Oh, and a single another NPC is different for each story.  Oh yes, upgrades are part of collectibles that you can find during each chapter. And the thing about collectibles and perks is that they are saved in your global profile, so choosing chapter will not reset them. Not sure about 'New Games' though.  Oh, yes, perks. Instead of grinding for experience, these work like achievements: You do some certain stuff, like kill 3 enemies without releasing fire button while dual-wielding, and then you unlock a small upgrade, which slightly makes it easier for you. All of them are categorized after certain playstyle, which should help you get better at what you like to do best. Though I just challenged self to get them all during main play.  And yep, there are few playstyles. While you can't really beat game just by stealth or mayehm, it helps variety, lots of fun. You can stealth sometimes, which is quite easy and satisfying to melee kill enemies, but there are few situations where you are allowed that. Easier to take out commanders before they call reinformcement, but you can't stealth kill tougher enemies and then you just position to prepare for big fight. It's kinda weak by itself though too. It may get old and there is supposedly-pro-stealth chapter with melee-only enemies who are more fun and easy to melee straight on. Also, people silently insta-dieing because a knife landed on a heel of a shiny boot are still hiralious.  Then it can be off to a straight-on shoot-em-all style. There is a huge variety of retro-futurustic weapons, all of which get upgraded slowly through the game. Yep, progress kept in global profile. You can also dual-wield two of same weapons, increasing your firepower. Can switch modes of each weapon individually. And game doesn't rely heavily on iron sight, so it's awesome.  But as game comes closer to the end, you will meet a bunch of tougher enemies, who have tons of health and will rip you apart at closer range. I also should note that levels, while aren't exploration maze, albeit still have secrets, have more than one way for a firefights, so you can flank. Or be forced to be more dynamic by tough enemies, as you have to move before getting into their death range. And thankfully, is has enough firefights that last a while. And not only that, but game has interesting first-person cover system. You hold down the button and can either lean left or right, or peek up above the cover, or even lay down to shoot some boots.  Health system is another thing that I find incredible. As you know, Wolfenstein are one of those hitscan-abuse games, barely any projectiles to avoid. And it's not fully about stealth either. So that makes fully traditional points health system fit badly, since you can't avoid random bullets. Regenarating health is better, but it allows you to fully recharge by hiding around cover. So developers used a combination of those. You see, health system can be divided into sections by 20 points each, which can regenerate. So if you got 33, then it will come to 40 soon. And I totally dig this system, as it fixed both complaints that I can die anytime by random bullet because I have only 6 HP and can't fix from current position, while also making sure that I still feel that I screwed up if I end up hiding with 20 points, making me scavenge for health packs. Some say that it first was used in older Chronicles of Riddick, but I don't care. What I want is for it to be used in more hitscan-heavy games like this. So yay for developers for using this one!  And I also should note how awesome this game is in audio-visual part. The art-style, with help of high production and some good game engine, as well as masterful usage of haze/fog and lighting, delivers some amazing vista that look like a concept art that came alive. Music, while used cinematically, meaning that there are silent and simplistic parts, still sets off great different moods and helps the experience. Like, get to final level and see and hear for yourself. Not to mentioning that there are enough variety and satisfying cutscenes to keep you interested and beat the game on a single breath.  There are also few more small details, like you can cut fences and special metal covers with your laser weapon or ability to pull the turret off the place, though you will have to either recharge it if you run out of ammo by placing it back, or just abandon it later.  You also can't help but to feel that developers really wanted to potray Blazkowich as tough as he is during gameplay itself. Probably to make you feel badass. This man can survive ten thousands stabs during cutscenes, so much that at some points you may stop beliving.  Wolfenstein New Order is an amazing game that combines the high-quality cinematics with high-quality gameplay, which is something not to be missed. It's also the first Wolfenstein that I can fully call amazing without huge flaw. As far as I am concerned, it's a FPS of the 2014 year, along with Wrack. Beat it at least once. Watch the trailers too, they are awesome.

app_name: Total War: ROME II - Emperor Edition
review_text: Great improvement from initial release. DLC is pretty disappointing, but the mods are awesome.

Let me start off by saying, this is not a bad game.   The visuals are nice  It ran well on my machine Did not notice bugs of significance There are a decent number of guns, all of which sound and look great The sound track is perfectly servicable  The voice acting, while not great, gets the job done And the AI makes damn sure that you stick to cover when you can lest you find your head has a new air hole.  So why can I not recomend this game? Because even though I only spent $5 I do not feel like I got my monies worth. At the time of this review I have put 3.4 hours into it and that covered the entire single player campagin. None of the levels left me any real desire to replay them. The characters where all fairly stock and I didn't feel any sort of connection to them. The games background (the rise of North Korea to a superpower) was just too unbelieveable and you could see exactly where they had to file off 'China' and replace it with 'Korea'. And finally, the game doesn't even have any sort of satisfactory end to it. It just sort of... stops.  As I don't personally play multiplayer, I can not comment on it. But if you looking for a good modern military shooter, look elsewhere.
Can I have my money back?

This game would be amazing, great concept poor execution and upkeep. It has impoved greatly since the CEO became wealthy enough to support more devs and art designers. But still it lacks bug fixes it requires to be a finished game, whilst more 'content' is added over underlining issues being bandage fixed. The mechanics of the game are poorly thought out and if you want to be competitive you will have to understand the 'prediction system' in the game a system that compensates for latency between players and the server and abuse of this mechanic makes the top players the 'best' ontop of stamina management and positioning in fights. The truth is its a greifer game and steam is bringing alot of sheep in so it has injected more life into the game, because the game is so tedius and unpollished the steam charts have shown a decrease of 1000 active players daily down to 500. Were before steam release it was around 200(That is being generous). Not that this game is hard it has a very low skill ceiling and simple combat mechanics, the crafting system is very indepth and time consuming being the real grind of the game. It takes a few days to skill a new character and the meta is constantly shifting due to the devs incompetance to properly decide on the direction they want to take. Along side the player gms who still exist under a veil of lies stating there is no gms/hcs that are allowed to play. It is all deception in order to create the illusion there is no bias wen it comes to the people who run the game. The game has a long history of abuse by the children given power to answer petitions because Starvault can't fund outsourced or payed Game Masters and Councelors they use their comunity as a source instead. Obviously anyone can understand the issue with that. My point being if you want to get a sandbox game to fulfill your desire to full loot people and risk your own loot at the same time, this game might be for you if you can get past the curruption, hackers, duping, annoying bugs that seem so simple to fix but have been in game for over 5 years, the ♥♥♥♥ comunity filled with people who want to play a greifing game competitively then sure maybe this game is for you. I only log into to pvp its all I can enjoy to do but gl getting the resources to support only doing that. You will have to farm tedius unexciting pve content that is lack luster compared to veterans farming spots and never beable to compete with people who have 5 years of experience ontop of nearly unlimited resources. I personly will continue playing sparatically because I have so much time invested in the game but I dont see many people continueing playing as a new/begining player.  Sincerely  -CDXX

app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: A very nice game. Didn`t have any technical issues, works perfectly(GTX770). But it also has some different sides, that we`ll discuss below: Pluses: 1. 2 big places with wide open space (sands of Afghanistan and jungles of Angola-Zaire border region) 2. Big variety of different weapon 3. Graphics are pretty nice out here. 4. Nice soundtrack, picked up somewhere from the middle of 80s. Minuses: 1. Really bad and unclear story. Only those who played previous games can understand the story and it`s weird 2. The monotony of gameplay. Missions are really very simillar to each other and it`s weird x2 3. Side missions is the worst part of the game. You have a standart list of quests, and when it comes to an end, MGS just gives you a permission to repeat the same mission, that you`ve completed about 15 minutes ago.

Intel i7 3930K Sapphire R9 390 with slight overclock 16GB RAM Installed on Samsung 850 EVO SSD Acer XG270HU with Freesync  With this hardware I experienced unbearable frame drops even with settings lowered to the point where everything looked disgustingly fuzzy. Initially, applying the frame rate unlock fix helped a little, but not nearly enough. Not even Freesync seemed to help. I had heard reports that the game has been fixed over time with patches and this is simply not true, or if it is I can't imagine what terrible state it was in before. I am requesting a refund.. Please don't waste your time.  I absolutely loved Dead Rising 2, even though it had slight performance issues. This is something else though. Hopefully Capcom learns their lesson from everyone that refunds this and gives Dead Rising 4 the proper port it deserves.

First, this is not a game it is a simulator. Compared to FSX it has better flight dynamics. I have over 10,000 hours in several multi-engine jet aircraft and it has the feel and reaction of the real thing. FSX feels like driving a bus compared to x-plane. ATC is better in FSX and is okay for a simulator. X-plane ATC is so bad I never use it. I plan my routes to include descent and setting myself up for an approach without ATC because it is just unusable and doesn't even come close to the real thing.    Scenery in x-plane is better for atmospheric conditions and the out of the box terrain is comparable to FSX out of the box. FSX does have better add-on scenery available. X-plane surpasses FSX on the actual runway. X-plane runways follow the terrain and are very realistic. FSX has better stock aircraft than x-plane so plan on adding a payware aircraft unless general aviation is your thing.    If checklist are your thing, FSX add-on aircraft like PMDG 737NGX are probably better than many x-plane add-on aircraft from a switchology standpoint. I have the PMDG 737NGX for FSX and the FJS 737-200 for x-plane. Systems functionality is more realistic with the high end FSX add-ons, but x-plane add-ons are comparable and generally cheaper. Cockpit graphics are better in FSX, but x-plane is catching up. Weather conditions more accurately affect the aircraft in x-plane. Try a 30 knot crosswing landing in FSX and x-plane and there is a noticable difference with x-plane being very realistic.  It all depends on the desires of each simer. If you are really into checklist procedures and in depth systems operations then get FSX and pay for a high end add-on like a PMDG aircraft. If flight dynamics and a very realistic feel to the aircraft that is close to the real deal then get x-plane. I prefer x-plane and if it had a decent ATC I would probably uninstall FSX and exclusively go with x-plane. I split time between the 2 right now. Hope this helps anyone trying to make a decision.

The humour was ok, but in the Third they just took it too far. Not at all interested in the spaceships and laser gun stuff, I'd rather just have good old Stillwater. However, it's still great co-op, and the PC version actually works (thus I can recommend it), none of the probs of it's predecessor. It ran great on my ageing machine of the time, and it has to be said, it does look a lot better than SR2.  If it's cheap I'd recommend it, baring in mind the car physics are rubbish compared to GTAV, but that the co-op is very often more fun than GTAV in my opinion - you don't keep getting passed through various public servers full of 12 year-olds just to have a private game with your friends (that is when you get disconnected or change character - lame game management in GTV). The drop in/drop out campaign from this and SR2 are awesome. Shame about SR4 though, I absolutely hate it. Don't waste your money on the BS DLC stuff though.

It's breathtaking, enormous, gorgeous and packed with amazing adventures. Problem is, the adventures to be had are so white-washed and thin that everything this game promises only about 50% are truly achievable and remarkable. Crafting is so bland and unremarkable that everything it is now needs to be upgraded, rehabbed and made better by the devs. We, as gamers, need more to chew on. The story is so veil thin and unremarkable that a game of this magnitude absolutely DEMANDS more and much, much better. There are so many 'No's' but also so many 'Yes's' that this game deserves a chance to be made better by the devs. It truly does.    So, what exactly is wrong with this game? I'm sure you've read all the 'haters' reviews. 5 minutes of game time and they're bashing the game because it won't work properly, run properly or even at all. Thing is, Hello Games has even stated publicly that over 1/3 of all the tickets inputted into their ticket system have well BELOW the marked specs for the game. BELOW the specs. Head scratcher? Nah? Common ♥♥♥♥ing sense. Listen, if you're pc or laptop does NOT meet the specs, don't complain when it doesn't run properly. Period. That's common ♥♥♥♥ing sense.    What else is wrong? Well, travel is fantastic. Exhilarating even at times. There's a few things that annoy me personally. One, the distance from entering a planet's stratosphere to meeting the ground takes a whopping 30 seconds, if that. I KNOW this game isn't based on realism, but c'mon. From outerspace to ground in less than 30 seconds is not 'believable'. Equipment degradation happens way to quick. Personally, your life support shouldn't need 'fixed' every minute. Makes no sense. These ♥♥♥♥ing drones. Seriously. If you happen to be extracting minerals and one of these ♥♥♥♥ers happens to come too close it'll set off the whole bunch of em against you. While easy at first, the fact you can visit planets that you will get swarmed in 30 seconds by a dozen or so. Just, not fair. Also, what is their purpose? Why are they even scanning everything that you seem to want to extract?   There's no real cement to the story. No real reason you seem to want to travel, to extract, to help. We get some written dialogue, no spoken. Even aliens don't really beep or moan or anything. You get written 'dialogue' pertaining to the alien thoughts and spoken word. While I do like the fact you can 'learn' the language it takes a LOT of time to know enough words to understand even 1 alien. Needs some work to make a little better.     All in all, there are probably too many things to nitpick about. The game does a LOT right. It really does. Travel, the many, many accessible upgrades you'll get for your mining tool and ship. It all adds up to a lot of fun. We need more and a lot different randomizations for each planet and camps. Too many look identical in their make-up. Aliens all look the same. 'Puzzles', ie, random objects you need to solve in order to accomplish some kind of goal are entirely all too easy. They're also all the exact same in the end. You have, maybe half a dozen or so random puzzles you'll have to solve over and over and over again. Needs more randomization and some harder puzzles implemented.    The game looks gorgeous. There's some really annoying pop-in that happens and no amount of graphical distance spacing seems to help. I believe it's the tech and NOT a GPU intensive job. The tech is just making assumptions based on your distance from the objects and THIS needs fixed as well. Badly. It happens ALL THE TIME. You'll notice it. It doesn't neccessarily take away from the immersion but it can be annoying when you're playing with everything on 'high' and nothing helps. While the game looks amazing at times, stupid things that people like to see are not available. You're just a floating arm. Looking down reveals you have no legs. Getting in and out of the cockpit could have a really cool cut scene that can happen showing your entire body. It does not. In fact, you don't even get to pick if you're a man or a woman. You're just a human, I'm assuming.    Sound design is wonderful but can be weird at times. You might notice some sound 'lag' when shooting asteroids or whatnot. It rarely happens, but again, should be fixed.    The game NEEDS some kind of mapping allowable while you're adventuring on a planet. That would be handy dandy. Star maps are okay but can get tedious accessing and trying to figure out where you're going because it doesn't auto align itself.    All in all, it's a good game that can be great. If the devs really follow through and fix what's missing and/or broken this will evolve into an epic space/adventure sim that will just OWN the genre.

app_name: Sword of the Stars Complete Collection
review_text: My experience says after 100 to 200 turns. Just one more turn then i'll call it a day. And before i knew it i was at turn 350. This game is pretty addicting.  The free roam in space, colonizing and defending planets. Every game you make is different even if you use the same map over and over. I recommend this game to anyone who likes space combat sims. Although the graphics are not that great still you get hooked. You can play this game like it was 1993 when you had those endless DOS games where it took you months to complete. Exact same story here, you can play months on huge maps and still you haven't completed a map. Just try it and see if you are convinced.  When you're at it and it's on sale get the full package with all the expansion for more turns and research stuff.  Would glady go another 3000 turns and ruining my life.

Borderlands 2 was a game that I tried to really like, but to be honest I can't really recommend. It suffers the same problem vanilla Diablo 3 had in regards to difficulty where you had to play through the game to unlock harder difficulties and I remember you had to purchase DLC packs and level caps to get new, better weapons.  On harder difficulties enemies became absolute bullet sponges that took forever to kill. Even as a Gunzerker I was frequently running out of ammo to kill basic enemies and mobs. This is probably the worst instance of grind in a game I have ever played through.  Even some of the DLC is not enjoyable. Mr. Torgues and Tiny Tina's were both funny and memorable and the latter had the added extra of making Tina less annoying and more likeable, but I don't think it's really enough to save the other packs from being unimpressive and forgettable.  If you can get the game, season pass, and new characters for maybe less than 20 bucks it might be worth it for a playthrough or two. Even with the sometimes lackluster, maymay filled writing you can find enjoyment. But unless you're an avid BL fan, you can skip this and find another shooter worth your time and money.

Capcom's 30 year history of the masterpiece, turns into complete rubbish.  All old legendary game franchises has and had some 'death point' on their lifetime. Duke Nukem, Silent Hill, Resident Evil, C&Q, Medal Of Honor, they all had the games that hit the finishing blow to them. And sadly, very sadly, as a Street Fighter Veteran since my childhood, As a guy who gave over 4000 hours to Street Fighter 4 Series, this game is very very close to share the same fate.   Yesterday, when i was seeing this kind of comments, i was telling 'this guys are stupid this game just came out just give it a time already!' 'But after putting much hours and seeing the overwhelmingly awful situation of the game, few days is definitely not enough to put this abomination together.   This unfinished rubbish, had everything better in BETA, I'm sorry not Beta FOUR god damn diffrent Betas plus some hidden short-time ones and they worked better than the full version. This is a huge disrespect, and whats huger is the price of the game. 50$ for a game that has poorer quality and worse developers than free2play games and companies. I wish it was only the technical issue, but everything, just every aspect of the game smells like low-budget, carelesly done crap.  ENough of the exaggurated info, lets get to the mistakes of the game. First of all, currently it doesnt work, nothing, just nothing works right now. And thats not even the main issue, most of the techincal issues about servers can be fixed within a days. There are also frame rate issues, OFFLINE INPUT DELAY, No V-Sync disabling options. Stuttering, Teleportations, and every god damn graphic issues you can imagine. But thats not just it! The game itself is 'bad'. Even without the techincal issues. I'm not talking about mechanics, I'm talking about the 'FULL GAME' First of all, 'Capcom Fighters Network' is a complete joke. Horrible design, annoying menu controls, and limited options is just the small part of its faults. So you want to invite your friend to the game and play with him ? If it was SFIV you click 'invite' via Steam. But this, this feels like quantum physics to solve. First of all you click to causla match because you want to play 1vs1 with a friend, and no. It isnt there its just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ option to find random people randomly. Then without hope i clicked VERSUS because maybe they put it in there and no, its just a classic offline 1v1. Then i said ok lets create a lobby, because lobbies were actually working yesteday, and now they don't. So i created a lobby, and looked at the screen there are no options to invite, looked agsain with higer attention and NO!, there isnt one. i just pressed random buttons on my controller repeadetly and a very small sub menu appeared in the lower left of the screen called press (Y) for Lounge Options. and clicked it and i saw the 'Invite' button. I was happy and i clicked to it, and i had no friends on the list. Because the game uses it's AMAZING (!) CFN system. Then i returned to the menu to go on a new amazing adventure! Adding a friend! Of course there isnt anything like this on the menu, whats fun with easy menu controls? You must click to CFN and you search for Rivals, you ASK your friend for their SFV tag, and add them to FAVORITES awkwardly. There are also no chat options so its a silent game, even no microphone! No voice chat, because it just distracts you from the heart of the battle right? And i invited my friend, oops invited my favourite to the game and my lobbyt gets shut down. So CFN system is really amazing! When you are in middle of a ranked game a distracting huge pop up says 'This guy wants to fight with you! and when you return to menu there isnt anything, any exclamation marks. any pending invites so you must go on another adventure to find out. And you find out there is a notification board, hidden in the sub menu in the right (without an excalamation mark on the top of it) and you join the game that way!   The story mode is also amazing, i bet they also thought for 4 year old children to enjoy the game because stories are made of pictures that looks like children's coloring books. 3 picture for 100 speaking lines and you just hit a 1 round training dummy 3 times to complete amazingly deep storyline(!) for each character. So, isnt it amazing. And there is also an amazing survival mode in year 2016! Yaay! Bot punching for hours for some good old fight money!   ANyways lets speak about game quality cand competitive multiplayer. We have a full roster of SIXTEEN characters. It's a great number. Who needs lots of characters anyway you should main just one to compete better(!). Look at tekken TT2, it got released with 60 characters and only 16 is being played in competitive scene. So they felt like it's a waste of effort. Lets get their 50$ for nothing! Graphics are not 'stunning' its just mediocre. Some good, some bad. Music is the same, some good, some boring. Nothing like past games though. Graphics and Music was always amazing and top notch in past games. I like the ranked system, i like unique character design and V skills and thats all. Thats all i like. I hate the easiest combo system ever designed for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 3 year olds to learn and master. When i make the hardest combos in he game it feels like jabbing the opponent, i dont feel proud, i dont get hyped. It's just too simple. I hate the 50/50 situations on wake up, I hate the lack of kara's, option selects. I hate the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly missing juggles and lots of special moves and normals which half of it has weird not-fitting hitboxes.  My last wish for capcom is shutting down the game and delay it to the june. Fixing the issues and balancing the stupitidies, because this game had an amazing potential.

I'm going to be very kind with this title since it is free and I know some of it's messy development story. You can forgive the art style which goes from good to more like someone tossed in the concept art pieces and called it a day. Characters are interesting enough and it doesn't have a heavy handed Soviet storyline which I part suspected. Actually rather ignores a lot of that and just uses the Soviet era as a setting. Characters come off a bit better because of it.  However, I can't be totally kind with the writing. The first major offense is the emotional attachment between the characters. Aside from Slavya who is pretty much the poster girl for the game, and Lena who clearly is pegged as the second choice girl to Slavya, the MC (main character) is pretty much at odds with the others. The problem is the writing team focused too hard on making the story neutral and I suspect they didn't really develop the other character's as heroines till later. Probably only had 2 pegged for the initial project.  Up until day 6, the story you can consider is in neutral arc. It's literally harem mode as all these girls throw themselves at the MC but no one really gets picked. What this causes is moments where there is clearly some good moments between the MC and one of the heroine, then he's back to being slug boy and wanting nothing to do with anyone.  His character is probably the biggest hinderance to the story as he's just not believable at times. Specially his reactions. Again this is mostly due to the length of the neutral segment of the story. By the time the individual stories start coming forward, he comes off as just merely going with the flow and not really caring.   There are other weaknesses in some of the characters. One seems to have multiple personalities which doesn't come out till the end and makes you wonder why the MC is willing to overlook the fact she is borderline homicidal. She even gets probably the best ending of them all as the others have rather cookie cutter endings.  Really a lot of this could have been written better but I think what you'll see here is complications from design decisions which just snowball later. It won't be Katawa Shoujo. Not by a long shot. Even the weakest story arcs of Katawa will shine brighter than this. But it's not a bad use of time. I'm certainly glad to have played this.  All in all, it really is a mixed bag. From a story perspective I'd maybe give it a 7/10 tops. Adding in the art issues and general quirks from it's development, probably a 6/10 at best. I hope for the future sequel as I hope they learned a lot from this game's development. But we'll see.

Interesting story to follow in a beautiful world. I have been reading more than exploring which is making me skip some text to get through conversations. I did find Shadowrun Returns a little too linear with no options yet to revisit and reattempt hacks/conversations. Never say no to a challenge when offered.  I felt like I was closing in on the finale after 6 hrs of play, which turned out to be wrong as more game play was revealed. I do not have a grasp for the companions I bring along on missions so I hope they allow that to develop more as it goes on. They are simply mercenaries with little to no character developed through the battles. Those points aside, Shadowrun Returns is worth playing though as it is fun and draws you into the cyberpunk/mystic future that the art and turn based play style have created.

app_name: The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky
review_text: This game has so much potential. However, there is way too much dialogue for my taste and you will be at the very beginning of the game for about 10 minutes minimum and that includes the animation that plays for an EXTREMELY big amount of time. I swear, they shouldve made THAT their trailer for this game. in the end, there is way too much dialogue and information, and not enough gameplay. and by information, I mean they will tell you what to do, but then go into huge amounts of detail why and such, which eventually you forget. I only made it out of the beginning and gave up on this game. If you are into more story than game, then this is a good game. otherwise, this gets a 6/10 from me.

This game excels in many ways and in short -- you should buy it.  Most captivating is the atmosphere. This game was developed by Microsoft and it is very apparent that they took inspiration from their home state of Washington. The vast temperate rain forests containing abundant lakes coupled with cloudy skies truly strengthen the setting. Taking on a vibe of mystery and horror the story of Alan Wake is also quite interesting. I'll be honest I mostly play games for the story much like one would read a book or watch a movie. In this regard Alan Wake was incredibly fun but at times I also found myself 'grinding' through the game in a sense, wishing to simply continue the story. I suffered from one or two 'rage quit' moments but ultimately pressed on and I am glad I did. Another refreshing strength of this game is the unique gameplay. The combination of the flashlight weaponry with unique puzzles and challenges is very refreshing compared to other games and made the game less monotonous. All in all, while not perfect, Alan Wake is a very enjoyable game and everyone should play through it once.
Campaign: 8/10 MP 0/10 Zombies 7/10  MP Sucks, Campaign is very good and engaging, Zombies is pretty fun to.

Some in game images I took are over at  www.pixelcore.co.uk   If you're reading this and you own either Bioshock or Bioshock 2 then great news! Bioshock Remastered should now be in your steam account.  It's probably a good idea that you know my PC set up before we continue so you can get an idea of how your PC will handle the game and for the purpose of this, I'll be taking a look at the first Bioshock as that's the oldest and because it's my favourite.  PC Specs:  CPU: i7 5930K 6-Core  Motherboard: MSI X99S Gaming 7  RAM: Crucial Ballistix DDR4 32GB  GPU: GTX 980 Ti  Now lets begin!  First of all, those silly devs forgot to put mouse control in the menus and instead, opted for arrow key control. Great! Good start. Is it 2016?  Anyway, let's go into the menu and see how many great options there are.  Basic menu options. This this is disappointing, especially to not even see the same options that we get in Bioshock Infinite. Also no borderless windowed mode, that's a killer. This is the level of control I expect to see from an XBLA indie game. Not to worry, onto playing the game!  As to be expected, the game runs great on my machine. No flickering, no hitching and no FPS drops to be seen anywhere. The game looks good and seems to have had that smudge effect removed from the original, while still retaining the Bioshock atmosphere we know and love.  You can see in the image above that everything looks much sharper and clearer than it did before. It makes an already great game just a bit more playable for the gamers out there who can't stand outdated graphics. Let me make this clear though, this is not a complete overhaul and is a touch up at best. I can't complain too much because 2K gave the collection to everyone for free on PC, and I've had no performance issues since booting up the game.  If you want to relive a classic or haven't played a Bioshock game before, then Bioshock Remastered is an excellent way to get started. Just don't expect too much. If you want to take a look at what a complete overhaul looks like, have a look at Systemshock and the great the work the team are doing on that game.  Here's a few more screenshots for you to take a look at! Bioshock Remastered is out on PC, Xbox One and PS4 right now.
