Early Access Review

Summary:  A nice mix of what is good about Hearthstone and Magic. The main draw for me personally is that it fixes what I dislike most about magic oustide of the massive money investment you need to play Magic. It accelerates acquizition of land cards or in this game, shrines. If you've ever hated not drawing lands Spellweaver has a system in which you can shuffle one card of your choice back into the deck and look at the top 5 cards of your deck, if any are shrines(lands) you can add that to your hand. That and the fact that the shrines are more mulilayered, some giving you new hero powers for example and the fact that you can choose whether you want to increase your mana(which is identical to HS in use but not in how you acquire it) or power level which is a flat resource that never depletes but is required to play certain cards.  So for me that's huge, I hated having to draw land cards in the f2p versions of Magic and potentially not being able to play anything. This keeps the game fun and fast without the need for cards that ramp up your lands like in Magic.   Outside of that, the game is very much like Magic except with the addition of the mechanic I listed and the hero power mechanics, which change the game very drastically. The card art and certain card designs, effects and archetypes are very familiar if you play Magic. But it's unique enough to not feel like a complete copy. There are more complex mechanics like the support line and the speed mechanic and the way in which you block is a bit different than Magic as well. So don't be fooled by it's appearance. There's a lot to enjoy here and a lot of fun unique mechanics to learn.  CONS:  Crafting/Disenchanting  My main issue with the game right now is the way in which you disenchant cards to craft new ones. You use shrines as currencies, which if you read what I said before are lands. The problem in this game is you need to specifically have shrines for the color in which you are crafting for. And not just that, you need to have at least 20 shrines at all times, so you can't disenchant below that. Why does this matter? Well, at the start you have 0 shrines, you get 20 from the starter decks. So what this means is, you need to either one disenchant a lot of cards of a certain color to first meet the 20 shrine limit before you can even start earning shrines that will go towards disenchanting OR you have to unlock the starter deck for each class which costs 40k gold, which is about 3 packs(it's quite a lot). You can get starter decks by leveling up but it will take a lot of hours to do this. So realistically you'll be spending either a lot of time or potentially money to get enough shrines to make cards you want. Which is nothing new, but the way in which you do it in Spellweaver is very unintuitive. Rather than have a flat rate, it's set up behind this 20 shrine minimum and not just that you have to then transfer shrines from different colors over to the color in which you want to create a card for, but not just that, it taxes you shrines, so the exchange rate isn't even a 1-1 ratio. Imagine in HS if you disenchanted a Hunter card but then had to transfer the dust to Mage first before being able to use it for a Mage card of your choice, but that 100 dust you got from disenchanting got reduced to 80. You'd be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.   Art, UI and Game Options  So if you've taken a second to look at the gameplay, you'll notice right off the bat that this game does not have the most unique appearance. It's card art looks very similar to Magic, it's main menu while efficient in what it does is bland. Even the name isn't interesting. It comes off too much like a Magic clone, and that will hurt it imo. It could really use a rehaul in a lot of areas to help give it it's own unique style that it really needs. The game options however are bare bones, the game is locked at 30 fps and while there is a windowed mode, you cannot adjust the resolution of it, so you'll be stuck with an awkward and ugly game window if you choose to go that route while playing. The 30 fps isn't too bad, you'll get used to it but if you go from other TCGs that run higher you might be annoyed by it.  Conclusion:  Overall though, it's a very good game. Fixes thing you might dislike from other TCGs and innovates with it's own twists. The areas in which it lacks while very important can be adjusted and overcome. The core gameplay is great and fills a solid niche between Magic and Hearthstone.

It may be squalid and zombie-infested, but Dying Light's city of Harran isn't a depressing wasteland – it's a vibrant, ambitious, open-world playground. Here, buildings are for climbing, the undead are there to be destroyed in creative ways, and there's always something interesting to be discovered nearby. It takes a while for that to become clear, though; at first, you might even think Dying Light is really about running scared from mobs of seemingly unconquerable zombies, who can quickly drain your stamina and wear out your improvised weapons. Don't be fooled.Yes, it's a struggle to survive in Dying Light's early hours. Combat is initially clumsy, with the diverse and deadly zombies able to soak up a disturbing amount of punishment before they die for good. Jumping – which is unintuitively mapped to shoulder buttons on consoles – can take a while to get used to. Getting mobbed is usually a death sentence. So is attracting the attention of the much more dangerous things that come out when daytime dynamically gives way to night, at which point the focus shifts to tense stealth — or, if you’re discovered, an adrenaline-pumping sprint for the nearest safe point.Before long, though, you'll build up a skill set that turns your rotting foes into objects of fun, letting you vault across their shoulders, quickly slice them apart with dramatic slow-motion kills, or trick them into gathering around explosives before blasting them all into the sky. Even nighttime becomes an opportunity to raise skills faster thanks to increased XP gain, rather than a period of sheer terror. It all feels great, too; once you adjust to the controls, Dying Light's first-person parkour becomes natural and fluid, and weaving high-speed paths through its decaying slums and picturesque old-world buildings is so much fun that I almost don't hate the lack of a fast-travel option. Combat, meanwhile, gets increasingly satisfying, although it never quite loses its awkwardness. Even when expertly shredding zombies with elementally charged tools of death I built myself, strikes are still heavy and clumsy. And while the guns you'll find later can pop heads from a distance, their low rate of fire and zombie-attracting noise makes them more of an occasional quick fix than a game-changing weapon. To Dying Light's credit, though, your adversaries are surprisingly capable; while the rank-and-file Biters are dumb and fun to manipulate, more powerful enemies – like the quick, agile Virals – are formidable close-quarters opponents, ducking your strikes and sidestepping out of your reach while looking for an opening to attack. Hostile bandits are even deadlier, able to dodge and block at close quarters, throw knives from a distance, and use guns and group tactics to kill you if you get overconfident.

The Dwarf Run is an RPG/strategy adventure game, with a few puzzle elements. The game I'd consider it most similar to would be the Drakensang games, with some hints of Blackguards (it's of similar difficulty to Blackguards, if not more so). The graphics are ok, not it's strong point. Similar to games that perhaps came out in 2005. The music is excellent however, and the game does a good job of creating atmosphere. The writing is very good as well, with elements of humor throughout. The game is pretty linear, but that's not exactly bad. The only fault I can find is the fights are perhaps a bit too difficult. Many fights might come down to who gets the last hit in. There are times you might think a fight is impossible, only to discover there is another room where you can fight 1-2 more batches of monsters, and they drop a weapon or level up one of your guys, and that tiny edge is what you needed to make it through the next fight. Some of the encounters take thought, and require a solution you would not normally think of, forcing you to figure out an unorthodox solution. All-in-all, I think this is a good game.

Amazing game. Brings back fond memories of the mechanics of the Descent series (before Freespace), but with it's own unique take on the 6DoF (6 degrees of freedom) genre. The feel of the movement and combat is just right, and the game strikes a perfect balance of high speed action and item/resource management of an roguelike rpg. The game rewards skill greatly, and encourages you to conserve your ammo and use each of the many weapon types to their maximum effectiveness. Repair kits are uncommon, and take up vital (and limited) inventory space, so crucial decisions must be made about what to keep and what to leave behind. There is also a surprisingly deep crafting element, allowing you to combine weapons, hulls, and ship components to create new ones. These items, especially weapons and hulls, can dramatically alter your playstyle.  There are many types of weapons of various rarities, each with their mechanics, playstyles, and ammo types. There are ballistic (shotguns, minguns, railguns, etc), plasma (big 'ol energy 'globs', flamethrower) , energy (lasers, bolts), missiles (dumbfire, homing, 'grenades', etc), 'dart' (wolfpack missiles, cluster rockets, swarms), and 'advanced' (gravity missiles, crazy stuff). Each weapon rolls various modifiers when it drops, affecting its properties damage, rate, accuracy, etc). All of the weapons can also be crafted with others to form new ones, though the more powerful 'recipes' require that you unlock/find a blueprint first. Crafted weapons are often quite different, especially mechanically, from their 'ingredients'. This leads to a wide diversisty of emergent playstyles depending on what weapons you are able to craft. Also, crafted weapons are affected by the modifiers of its ingredients, so holding onto early drops with 'great stats' is a viable decision if you want to craft something awesome later on.  There are also several different types of ship hulls and components. Like weapons, these roll various prefixes which affect their stats (speed, boot, ramming damage, etc). Hulls can also significantly affect your armor, primary, and secondary weapon capacity. Completely new additional ships can also be unlocked by completing various tasks over the course of your playthroughs.  The graphics are excellent for this game. The corridors and tunnels look great, and the action is quite smooth. The lighting effect on weapons fire makes tracking enemy projectiles easy (though evading all of them may be another thing altogether). There are many interesting enemy designs, with different, color-coded variations of them equiped with different weapons. The color coding makes it easy to identify at a glance which variant you are facing, which is crucial when dealing with them.  The sound effects and music are great. The soundtrack in particular is excellent. The composer is currently offering his album on bandcamp, which I happily purchased recently. It is a combination of pulse pounding electronic, chiptune, and orchestra. Each track is fantastic in its own right, and is dynamically altered depending on the situation (exploring, fighting, etc). I espeically like the track 'Chain Reaction' when it shifts to the base/synth heavy 'combat' variation. Do yourself a favor and by his soundtrack!  This game is a must have for anyone who enjoys a 6DoF shooter, in the likes of Descent or Forsaken. It is not a 'Descent/Forsaken Clone' nor does it claim to be. It *IS* an amazing 6DoF game with its own unique style and gameplay mechanics that stands out as an excellent example of this genre in its own right.  Final verdict: Buy This Already! / 10

When I first heard of No Man's Sky it was way back when Elite Dangerous was in its first year and my friend at the time was raving about how No Man's would be WAY better and how he would wait till its release instead of joining me in Elite: Dangerous. Weeeeelllllllllll....Elite is still a far supierior game, WITH Multiplayer and players affect how the direction of the game pans and and in a way the story plot. The price tage of Elite and all its expansions, if your wait for the initial price to drop can all be obtained for under $30 each, is still cheaper than No Man's.  Pros: Great graphics, amazing visuals and colors, nice crafting system. Gek perfumed farts.  Cons: Crappy flight controlls on planet surface, resource collection quickly becomes a grindfest, almost all animals are hideous Spoor abominations, lack of enemy diversity becomes apparent, space combat blows, next to no game plot,   Naming things becomes meaningless as no other player will ever see your planet named LSD; where acid rains constantly, Acidillos roam the land while Rave Worms travel in packs making thier mating calls and Magic Mushrooms grow in abundance. For the same reason Tony G's Traders will never be recognized as a galatic spanning franchise in-game (I renamed every trading postin honor of Tony G).   Maby the single player nature of the game is due to the fact that Hello games copped out on buying servers and to save face said there was still a chance (although infintismal) of meeting another player in-game.  For $60 AUS you could get a lot of things that leave a longer lasting, and more positive memory, than this game has laft; A night out with your friends, taking your parents out to dinner, a 1 foot joint to celebrate 420 Day, a new set of tyers for your bicycle, a 50gram pouch of tobacco, 10-20 humble bundles of games, or a birthday present for your girlfriend/boyfriend.  No Man's Sky is as vast as an ocean and as deep as a glass of water. Its name is very apt as in the end not a single man (or woman) will be flying the skies of this game.

review_text: I love this game, but do not buy Ground Zeroes~! It is not worth 20 dollars.   With phantom pains release, ground zeroes will be out-dated and rather pointless to purchase.   However, the game itself is very fun and has great game mechanics that I haven't seen in many games. Although its similar to its predecessor, it was an interesting experience. Its not often that a sequel is this good. The weapons are better, the plasmids are better. Hacking is surprisingly easier. It delves deeper into the tortured history of Rapture making playing the original Bioshock more meaningful. But the story telling can get get a bit bland and I felt disconnected from the protagonist. However its a classic FPS, with all the open world games we have right now, this is indeed refreshing,

The best  Saints Row  in the franchise. Unlike the first one, this to me doesn't feel like a  Grand Theft Auto  clone with few different traits. It is its own thing with a near flawless balance between crazy random fun and dark, serious, realistic moments. Customization is  extraordinary , and the cars & their radios are awesome. If you're looking for open world joy, this is highly recommended.  8.9/10.0

2 hours in and i can already review this BECAUSE ALL THE BAD REVIEWS ARE FOR THE SAME REASON   1) 20 hours in game glitches and you lose your crew 20 hours wasted! BLah blAh blah  Don't play the game on IRONMAN SETTING YET!!! Imagine trying to play fallout 4 with only autosaves o.O  Its new obviously there are going to be bugs. And obviously at times a bug is going to cost you, Having a save to go back to to overcome a bug is not save scumming it is common sense. Any bad review because they lost 'all their work' 20 hours could have easily been expected if you did not run ironman on firstplaythought, just resist the save scum urge if you really wish.  2) THE RNG IS SO BROKEN BLAH BLAH  The game rolls the dice for each squad mate at the START of a turn between 1-100, if you hit chance exceeds roll it hits, so at times no matter how many times you reload the autosave and try it differently if the roll was 100 you are not going to hit, and at time no matter how remote and how you do it differently if the roll was 1 you will not. This gives the appearance of broken rng to dumb people because they can't comprehend the roll is not made when you select 'fire'  ^ With all these bad reviews gone(80% of them) it leaves just the complaints of performance and forced turn timer  For performance: yes it cannt justify the resources the game is taking, but on med-high settings i am running smooth and will increase fps in future patches im sure definatly above the playable threshold so far for me  For the force timer: Don't listen to these people they don't know what they are talking about, the game is ACTUALLY hard now where as in xcom EU and vanilla overwatched everything with op squad was good game on hardest settings. There is an actual tactical challange now and it fits right with the story now that aliens control earth.  Overall: Still xcom, still best turned based tactical strategy around, publisher is worth supporting, yes it would be nice if performance was more optimized and few less bugs on day 1 but this will be fixed, can easily see spending wayyyy too much time on this game, I'd still advise getting it on sale at this point however as you may be able to get its for 40$ ish soon or if you look around.

Nether is an enjoyable game. It doesn't have much in it, but the PvP is so enjoyable, it's still worth playing.  I bought it when it came out, to support developers, however now I am waiting for more content.   Pros: Very fun PvP. Pros: Unique trade system. Pros: Guns are not very rare, so you're not kicked out of PvP for long. Pros: Character is shared across servers. Pros: You game experience for kills, and experience yields real changes in your playing. Including new skills.  Cons: Not a whole lot of content of weapons. Cons: The game is quite challenging in all aspects without friends. Cons: Scavenging becomes very hard with such a hostile enviroment.  All in all, I rate this a 6/10. When more content becomes available, I can see this getting somewhere.

review_text: Fallout is the perfect example of a game that really brings the player into the wasteland of D.C. The immersion is amazing and has been perfected, it sucks you into the core. The gameplay is exciting and fresh with some repetiton but in a good balance with exploration and fighting. The story is great and the ending is a brillant close. The level of replay value is amazing with so much content even in a single playthrough due to the vast expanse of the Capital Wasteland. Easily one of the best RPGs that has been made and will probably remain as one of the best.

In this game, the main premise is a large scale rivalry between powerful mages with varying specializations and studies, who bend cities by their will toward good, evil, or whatever.  Gameplay is reminiscent mostly of Heroes of Might and Magic, in a good way. This is a 4X game with an especially strong emphasis on exploration and extermination, with heroes who go questing, conquering, leveling up, and looting for themselves and their empire. Campaign actions are made on a high-level campaign map. Battles play out on a lower-level map in a tactical turn-based manner, taking into account the terrain and structures of the tile on the campaign map. Both maps use hexagonal tiles. Armies (unit stacks) are composed of up to six units. In a battle, all adjacent armies participate. In some ways, this approach to combat feels like a middle ground between Civilization and Total War.  Much of the design is reminiscent of Master of Magic. Cities and units vary according to the class of the player and the race of the inhabitants. There are six classes (arch druid, dreadnought, rogue, sorceror, theocrat, and warlord) and six races (high elf, human, orc, goblin, dwarf, and draconian). The variety is good but not dizzying, with a solid array of standard unit types and a handful of specialists available in any city that has the requisite buildings. Spellcasting plays a major role on the campaign map and in battles. The spells span a wide spectrum from an assortment that is modest in cost and effect to the immensely powerful and expensive high tier. Each school of magic (among air, earth, fire, water, creation, and destruction) is distinct, with its own characteristic effects and strategies. The interplay between questing, empire building, warfare, and spellcasting is fun, engaging, and balanced.  Compared to other 4X games, there is a diminished emphasis on exploitation. Rather, the exploitation here is ultimately focused on serving the exploration and extermination. You won't find options for cultural, diplomatic, or economic victories here, and the gameplay options are limited likewise. This is not a game of peace. [edit: Interestingly, Triumph has hinted that this is an area that they will expand in upcoming updates.]  The overall fit and finish is very good, although not without room for improvement. The UI is strongly reminiscent of Civilization V—a good choice of inspiration. Some aspects live up to this standard better than others. There is a Tome of Wonders (akin to Civilopedia), but it's a pain to navigate (no back button?! among other problems), and some of its pages neglect important information. Some stats show breakdowns on hover, as they should, but some breakdowns lack desirable detail, while others are simply omitted. I'm curious to see if any of this improves with ongoing updates.  Unlike Civilization and most other games in the 4X genre, a game of Age of Wonders III at normal pace is significantly shorter. Expect a commitment of three to six afternoons instead of three to six full days. Considering the pesky existence of real life, this is a very desirable trait.  If you like 4X and high fantasy, and you'd like a game that combines the two in a form that's easy to swallow, then this is a great choice.

Yes, as with any previous Elder Scrolls game, there's some bugs here and there, but im at over 30 hours of play at the moment and nothing game breaking happened to me. The game is HUGE, of course there's going to be a bit of bugs along the way. The world is gorgeous, quests are actually interesting for most of the time, unlike with others mmos. Alan Wake is one of those games where I'm not sure how to feel about it. It has strengths and weaknesses, but they are extremes.   Pros: Alan Wake draws heavily on ideas from Stephen King novels and is more or less a fan fiction in the form of a video game. As a result, the game has possiblly one of the best plots and stories I've seen in recent memory. Unlike others, the narration style and the manuscript reveals that annoyed some I actually found to be very immersive. Additionally, the environments and atmosphere are incredibly well done, providing the perfect settings for a horror game where constantly moving mists and shadows keep you wondering if something is out there.  Cons: The gameplay is horrible. Not just bad. Horrible. It is painfully repetitive, simple and never really evolves, even at the later stages of the game. I actually physically groaned every time a fight sequence came up because I could feel myself losing interest in the game, in spite of everything it does so well. It is a game would have been better if they just made it a point and click adventure game. Very rarely do I find myself wanting a game to end so I have an excuse to stop playing it. The camera style is over the shoulder and off-angle making moving in the game painfully difficult for no reason and platforming sections needlessly difficult. You will die several times simply because you cannot walk the way you wanted to go. Additionally, the game is suppose to be a horror game, but squanders the incredible environment and story it has by going into slow-motion and zooming in on enemies as soon as they spawn. This pretty much prevents anything from ever sneaking up on you because it gives you so much reaction time. It also reveals all of its major scares ahead of time in the manuscript pages. I'm okay with the reveals because it is part of the genre, but at least hold on to a few of them. Finally, the game combat is just too easy. You constantly swimming in ammo and batteries to the point where you'll pretty much never run out of anything.  Verdict: If you are a fan of Stephen King or you have a bias towards games with good storytelling and writing, then you'll probably find a way to enjoy this game. If you want a game that is fun to play, you don't want this title. Honestly, I played through to the end for the story, but the game felt more like a chore and I didn't enjoy the experience. So recommended with an entire salt shaker.

app_name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
review_text: I would definitely recommend this game. I got it awhile back and played it alone. It was fairly difficult at first because of having to control two characters at once, but I eventually got the hang of it. Fantastic scenery and character development. I grew to like all of the characters, and even though they weren't speaking the same language as me, I could still understand their troubles by the tones of their voices and their expressions. It had a very good use of interactive environment, and everything seemed to be involved. Beautiful story, and incredible ending. It was very emotional, and everything went by very smoothly. I never experienced a single glitch throughout the entire, short-lived game. It is a very reasonable price for a short game that I will always want more of. Definitely one of the most touching games for me, including its gameplay, storyline, interactions, plot advancement, characters, and controls. This cinematic game will forever stay with me. Thank you for taking the time to read this.  Edit: I will also comment on the soundtrack. Not only were the voices emotional, but it seemed like a lot of time was spent developing the sounds and the soundtrack. Beautiful pieces and great melodies made this game's emotion just that much more powerful. Absolutely fantastic and touching.

If you're looking for a genuinely challenging game of good, clean, puzzle-solving, and no less than roughly a dozen hours worth of play before completion, I sincerely recommend 'Toki Tori.'  In 'Toki Tori,' you play a fun-sized, flightless-jumpless bird, collecting eggs by navigating around platforms, and dodging enemies, utilizing your array of tools to your advantage. The challenge is that not all the tools are available at once, and they have a limited amount of uses, pre-set specifically per level. This knowledge provides clues to achieving your goal, placing you in a sport of trial-and-error until you find a way that works for you.  If practicing puzzles isn't your cup of tea, there isn't much I can recommend here. The game can get slow and sluggish; as more elements get added to levels, the possibilities expand, and you must keep trying similar things in various combinations until you find one that works. If you're akin to puzzle-style experimentation, you've got no problem, because the higher levels especially require tons of patience before you figure out what to do.  The art style of the game is cozily cartoonish; the physical setting and music of changes per level, which doesn't necessarily add to the gameplay, but rather to its warm and friendly vibe. A great (and my favorite) aspect in this game is the Rewind button, allowing you to carefully step back in order to do an alternative action without having to respawn. This makes learning the levels more hands-on, as you can explore a potentially incorrect move without the fear of it breaking your success so far. Furthermore, since there's no time limit, you're free to scout and plan without being pressured.  To label 'Toki Tori' as a simple kid's game (I've seen people do it) is a great injustice to the hours of gruelling, mind-mastering required to be victorious. This game makes me feel SO fulfilled and smart when I figure out how to finish a level. While I consider myself an experienced puzzle gamer, 9 hours in and I've yet to finish Normal mode, and there's still Hard and Bonus to go.  As a whole, there's not a lot of replayability here; once you've done all the modes, it's simply a nice trophy for your achievement cabinet. However, with over 80 levels, and greatly increasing difficulty, a substantial amount of commitment is required to finish the game on your own (No walkthroughs! Like a true puzzle solver!) If you like a cute, quality game that exercises your brain, I say get 'Toki Tori' and experience it for yourself.

AGATHAAAA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  First Person Medieval combat? Done right? Javelins and quarterstaves? Count me in. Chivalry: Medieval Warfare is a brilliant idea actually done right. Setting: It's 1500. Agatha doesn't like The Mason Order. War! And that's about it. 2 teams of feudal infantry face off in free for all, deathmatch, or objective game modes. Players choose from 4 classes. Vanguard: Polearms and two-handed weapons, meant entirely for brutal banzai charges. Archer: Fires arrows, fights with a wimpy dagger. No armour; dies quickly. (Doesn't wear a Ghillie suit, thank god) Man at Arms: Light and nimble: one sword, one shield fighter. Quick, and lightly armoured, dances around enemies. yooouuuu gguuueeessseeeddd iiiitttttt Knight: BIG. ARMOURED. SLOW. STRONG. BIG SHIELD. BIG AXE. BIGGER SWORD. BIG ARMOUR.  Choose a class, customize his weapon loadout (axes, throwing knives, swords, smoke bombs, pikes, spears, long swords, broad swords, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ swords, maces, mauls. battle axes, little hields, big shields, slings, bows, crossbows, dagggers.) And enter the fray.  Comabt is first person, based off of blocking, and hitting. Blocks, be it with weapon or shield, must be in ther general direction of the opponents attack, the larger the object, the more room for error. Kicks and shield bashes wear down opponents stamina, ad open up opponetns for cheeky stabs. Attacking is based on a directional slash, swing, or stab; all with varying speeds and damages. This simple yet intuitive system creates complex and intense dulas mano-et-mano, as well as hectic stab-fests in large group melees. Arrows must be drawn back and aimed, flails don't give a rip who they hit, and quarterstaves are useless. All together, you get a hectic and distinct melee combat game which can be described in one word:  FUN!  Simple enough, Chivalry rocks. How does it perform? Textures are quite good, though nothing special. Vistas are well lit, well colored, and quite beautiful. Simply; the game looks great. Frame rate is a bit... meh. In accordance to the graphical fidelity, they seem a bit low. Lower end systems should only expect 30 FPS, and even higher ends can barely scrape 60. Combat is intensive, but not THAT much. Regardless, you can run the game fine, even if framerate occasionally gets a bit wierd. (On a GTX 760, I'm averaging 45FPS in heavy combat. I get almost 90FPS in Battlefield 4.) Opponents' limbs fly off spectacularily, blood splatters, and sowrds clang very pleasingly. Furious war crys, crackling fires, painful screams, it all sounds great.  Overall: A quick, brutal, and FUN hack and slash first person melee fighter, with well thought out sword fighting mechanics, tons of weapons, engaging game modes, and a whole lotta happiness for $20. Get it, on sale; $8 is well worth this joyride.

Killing Floor is a good multiplayer co-op zombie game. Highly recommended!  I expected many similarities to Left 4 Dead (co-op and zombies, right?) but it's actually very different. I personally find it to superior to the Left 4 Dead games. There are eight classes/roles you can play and level up, and each have different perks. That, in combination with the many different weapons lead to teamwork and gameplay very different from L4D, where Survivors are able to essentially perform the same roles and use the same weapons.

This is a nice gem of a game that just has me come back again and again.   It is basicly 2D minecraft. You gather materials and build what you want in this virtual Lego land while fighting off monsters that try to eat you along the way. However Terraria does focuse more on the 'action' side of things with tons of weapons and monsters alike along with a great sence of progression to it. The progression is what really sets it apart from other sandboxes with me as it makes you earn new faster tools, stronger weapons, exotic resourses, and amazing NPCs through a mixture of explorations and boss battles. For me this progressions system, though simple, is what has me coming back to this game over minecraft when I'm in the mode for a sandbox game. I'm not saying Terraris is the best sandbox game because its progression system, just that is what I feel sets it apart from the other because of it.

This is a great cart racer that surprised me with its quality and variety. It has a huge roster of characters to choose from and the tracks are fantastic as well. Controls are easy to master and the driving feels really smooth. Again I highly recommend this title for anyone who enjoys cart racing games or SEGA fans in general.

Like a good sequel, takes what was good about the original and develops it further. Now the puzzles take place in different rooms, with each puzzle room consisting of several smaller interconnected puzzles to complete. Difficulty escalates throughout, but generally seems fair, and if all else fails there are hints. Like the original visuals are very good and the only downside is the brevity of the game, especially in one of the chapters. However, overall it is a solid recommendation.

This game is dreamt up by the creative minds from the newgrounds community, a site of user creative content that came before youtube. I will try not to get to into the storyline (because of the lack of it) but this game has a lot of dark humor. Your main weapon is the tears from your eyes as you try to go deeper and deeper into a cave/hole/hell trying to escape your mom.  The game is about risk and reward and one part old school keyboarding skill. Sorry kids no gamepad. You are often come across a dilemma of which item to bring with you to the lower deeps of the game as you face powerful bosses and miniboss. Should you give up two life hearts for an attack upgrade or spend all your coin in the slot machine in hopes for a good item.   This is a good game and it is very addicting since the map changes every time you play. In life as in games, it is all about risk and rewards and a bit of luck. This is well worth your money.

The game is a great throwback to Windows XP and basically sets a feeling later through it of unforgivingness. It basically tells a story on how two best friends later start to fall in love and how they are not ready for a relationship with a ending that can't be changed no matter what happens, There is nothing really bad about the game but let me say what is and isn't good in this game.  Positives + -/+ The games writing is good but nothing really rememberable except the easter egg messages you can get from using the secret profile pictures hidden in the game. + The game is sadly really relateable through a lot of the situations the main charecters have to go through and how it ends. + The game gives off a really nostaligic feeling with profile pictures that can be selected are trending stuff in the years that happen following the story, Like for example the Album cover art for Muse's - Absolution. -/+The game has alot of different choices you can pick from That can change the dialouge greatly but not the ending. -/+ The game is a generally short story that can be read fully once in about 15-30 minutes or so.  Negatives- - You can not at all change the ending of the story whatsoever.  Other then that this game was really relateable for me since i am going through a lot of depressing stuff in my life and a lot of stuff happening in my love life, It can really pull at anyones heartstrings, Even people who never went through stuff like this. I would overall rate the game a 73/100. Its not really rememberable but it really makes you feel bad that some people have to go through stuff like that. I hope you found the reveiw helpful.

app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: GROUND ZEROES
review_text: Solid 60fps on all 'high' settings at 1080p running a G3228 @ 4.1GHZ, 16GB RAM and a 2GB 750ti, can't complain about that realy, managed to get 20-30 fps useing Nvidia DSR at 3940 X 2160 all low settings of couse (not realy playable due to frame rate bounceing about a little too much). sadly no mouse control in the menus(at this time) . only issue encounterd so far was sometimes a movement key would continue to be registerd after release untill tapped again.   so a solid port with few issues in my expirience so far (3 hours of play), looking forward to playing some of the trials while waiting for the phantom pain. Recomended for metal gear fans wanting that fix before the real game is out.

Many hours can be sunk into Train Simulator, which is an enjoyable game however is still running the old 2009 engine from Railworks 2, which is in need of a refresh. However this hasn't happened due to the sheer quantity of DLC available on TS, thus upgrading the engine would result in a new game and the current DLC becoming unplayable. If you do get sucked into the black hole that is the DLC market, it can become rather pricey once you start purchasing custom content, some of which will run nice and smooth and others not, as they are made by other parties and not Dovetail.  Purchase this game if you're into trains or you're after a new simulator, however watch out for the epxensive DLC!

Disclaimer: As of writing this I have only completed the Gessen Storyline and the Hebijo one (see the first edit at the bottom on what I think of it), yet to do the others.  While on the surface it looks like Anime ♥♥♥♥ The Game, great storywriting and characters as well as great hack and slash gameplay makes Senran Kagura more than just fanservice.  I was surprised when I played through the Gessen campaign. Pleasantly surprised. Having no expectations whatsoever for the game (indeed, I only got this because I wanted a hack and slash and I forgot Dynasty Warriors was on Steam), I was prepared for just some mindless killing and a bit of ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥. I am very picky when it comes to narrative in videogames. It has to grab me from the start, and Senran Kagura did just that. The campaign I played had a dumb as hell plot at first, with the stupidest of reasons for the members of the school to fight each other. However it eventually turns into a touching plot about mentorship, friendship, and the idea of good and evil. The 5 girls in this particular campaign at first look like one dimensional tropes, but you eventually learn of their tragic backstories which may or may not have used what I like to call the Batman Trope (You know what that is, and if you don't, I'm referring to the event that made Bruce Batman to begin with) that led to their current path as shinobis. The beauty of this is that they are characters you feel an attachment to, and enjoy watching grow, you also get to fondle their breasts and put them in the most revealing of outfits. So there's that.  Enough about the story, how is the gameplay? My answer, very good. I can barely manage with Keyboard and mouse although this game is clearly meant to be used by controllers. But I do not have one at present, so I can't really say. Do keep in mind that the keyboard controls are actually alright by itself though (Q is LB and R is RB for menu controls. You're welcome.) The combat is well executed in my opinion with great visual effects, as well as a constant 60 fps despite how busy the screen is. The fanservice here is characters who take too much damage get their clothes ripped. And I have managed once or twice to even get the undies off my opponent if I hit her hard enough, so if you want that kind of fanservice this game has you covered. Edit: The camera is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mess. For all that's holy LOCK ON TO A TARGET ASAP.  Costumes are well designed and are what I can describe as Anita Sarkeesian's worst nightmare. You get all the dlc from the Vita version in this port for free as well.  The lingerie lottery though is a bit of an interesting system. 98 lingerie sets are waiting to be unlocked. To unlock one pay any amount of cash you want; but the more you pay the less chance there is of a repeat. Being a fan of blind bags and TCG booster packs and the thrill of packing something you don't have I love this feature. Though most of the stuff is HIDEOUS imo and of the ones I have I'll only use one or two of those. (also on a side note I have regressed so much that I snark at lingerie designs. What has my life come to.)  The Dressing Room is where you customise your shinobi to look as: a) Hot and sexy as possible b) Cute as possible c) Cool as possible d) Downright hideous And the options can be overwhelming. Once you buy the stuff that is. Schoolgirl outfits, Christmas, nuns, aprons, any kind of fetish you have, there is probably a costume for it (Slight exaggeration, there are only a few fetishes here). Though the fullscreen mode is a tad underwhelming. I like to call this the molestation mode, but all you can do is swipe their clothes off and fondle their breasts. That's it. They do have reactions to your actions, but they all use the same animations anyway. Not like I wanted this part or anything, but it does feel phoned in to me.  In conclusion, is Senran Kagura worth buying? I answer with a hearty YES. At least one of the campaigns is great and at the very least has me interested into playing the rest, and unlocking the rest of the characters. If you don't like fanservice at all this probably isn't for you, because there is A LOT of it. The gameplay is solid, performance is great and the customisation is pretty good as well. I will play the rest of it then update this review.  EDIT 1: I've played the Hebijo campaign. And while it was a bit weaker than the Gessen story, it was still an emotional rollercoaster, dealing with the topics of restoring honour, loyalty, redemption and revenge. The characters' backstories are also well written like the first, but the reason why I say it was weaker than the Gessen story is more of a personal thing, I just successfully predicted the ending of it and how it would pan out, making it less interesting and making me think it as very cliched. Overall though I recommend this part and this game even more, especially if it means that the other 2 campaigns are at least as good as this one. Also Miyabi's side quest is hilarious and I recommend you play it at least ones. Now I'm off to do the Hanzo campaign. I'll be back.

Also, don't worry about getting HL source, they just ported the game over with as little effort as humanly possible, in other words, it's one big pile of glitches and flaws. This game was ahead of IT'S time, but in our time, it's the definition of dated. app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: Words cannot describe how fantastic of an experience this game is. You will laugh, you will cry, you will cheer, and you will rage.  Let me say that again if you think you're an unemotional prick who's seen everything in video games so far like I was.  You WILL laugh. You WILL cry. You WILL stand up and cheer. and YOU WILL RAGE.   You can be an angel, you can be a devil. You can send anything on a mach 6 balloon back to base. You can sneak around and be stealthy, or you can go guns blazing to destroy everything in your path with no mercy. The game does not care what you do, how you do it, when, or why. And it WILL reward you no matter how you play.  It's hard to describe this game with words. This experience just has to be played. Don't get fooled into thinking this is a cold war stealth game, this is a fantastic story based game encompassing multiple genres that simply has to be enjoyed personally, simply trusting reviewers like me that you will like what you see, no matter what type of games you enjoy.  This is a HIDEO KOJIMA GAME.

The Witcher 3  has gotten thousands of positive reviews from players, and for good reason too. It is one of the best games I have ever played, without a doubt. I bought  The Witcher 3  for 25 dollars during a Steam sale, and have racked up more than 100 hours in the game. Yeah, it's that good! Everything about  The Witcher 3  is just absolutely amazing. The graphics, the characters, all the different locations, the weapons, the monsters, and the list keeps going on and on! The only complaints I have regarding  The Witcher 3  is that it there are a handful of strange bugs, but the same can honestly be said for any videogame out there. The combat is also a little dull and repetitive, however it is nowhere near being bad enough as to be considered a serious gameplay flaw. The last aspect of the game that annoys me is Roach. Roach is Geralt's horse, and his mechanics tend to be a tad bit wonky at times, for example, a couple of times during the game I'd call Roach over to me, but instead she'd just gallop in the opposite direction. Other than that, I see no major flaws with  The Witcher 3 , and definitely recommend that you buy this game. It is worth every cent, if not more!

The game play is fast paced and somewhat entertaining with it's combo autobattle system. Though after a almost 2 hours of playing I realized all i was doing was hitting 1 button fast while in combat and then using a potion as needed every 9 or 10 fights. This I can look past since final fantasy games for me has always been more about the story that pulls you in and the sense of accomplishment you get when you overcome the various hurdles thrown in your path for character development. This game failed miserably in providing either one of those. This game has you change main characters every 15 to 25 minutes during the first few hours of play. There is no depth, it's full of cliches, and lacks from any sense of cohesion that could possibly be existant in a storyline except for the fact that there is a war going on inside a city somewhere. I'm sure if I devoted my time in reading all of the background articles the game wants you to spend reading I could of gleaned additional information, but I bought this game to be entertained via cinematics and gameplay. I did not want to be informed of key elements of the story via stopping game play to look up the excessive amounts of datalog files... All things considered I found this to be the first Final Fantasy game I've played that was not enjoyable. After two hours of time I've given up on both this game and its sequel that I bought.

A true love hate relatioship is what I have with this game. It took heavens know how many versions to get a decent political system and I am guessing that took all the imaginitive powers right out of SEGA. They took an unpopular expansion to TWM2 with the Hordes and tried to redo it with the acumulated knowledge of the past failures in this series. The only failure they failed to learn from was creating an AI that doesn't have to cheat to be competitive. It does not follow the same monetary constraints the player is constantly hindered by. Speaking of which; in order to prompt looting and sacking the ridiculous amounts of money needed for conversion, upgrades and forced research unit upgrades are beyond practicality. A few games of 100 turns and you will see that the game was intended to be much longer, was consolidated and ad hoc things added to make up for a lack of design. These are not even relevant to the DLC that has been consistanly piece mealed although included in the original release. This is quick shove of a title onto the shelves with DCL being hopes of improvement for the consumer. I for one have not nor will I ever try DLC content, especially if the base is this flawed. All and all the death of a series. Murdered by SEGA for profit and DLC hits.

I bought this game back in June or July and it didn't work on my laptop. The developers are well aware of this problem, but they don't seem to have any inclination to fix the problems that I and many others experienced. So, if you want to burn two dollars for a game that doesn't work, then go right ahead. Otherwise, steer clear of this game until you hear that the developers decided to do something to fix it.

To avoid the impression that I see nothing good in Hotline Miami 2 let's go through the good things first: +New masks!  +New weapons!  +Good soundtrack! (by saying good soundtrack, I mean there were few good tracks tossed in there) +Alex and Ash! Oh.. okay - this one needs some more details. Alex and Ash is a mask choice that lets you play as 2 serial killers at once. One of them - Ash - has a chainsaw and another has a ranged weapon - any ranged weapon you can find on the ground or the standart pistol that Alex gets at the start of the level. Very fun character despite buggy A.I.. Sad thing is that you can't choose any mask for any level you want now - there are different timelines and different roles you must take, so no - you can't go Fists of Fury every single level. And oh yeah - some masks are very unique, but the total number of masks reduced when compared with the first game.  Now let's get to the truth which is difficult to accept - Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number is very hard to recommend. Don't get me wrong - this game is not absolutely bad, but it's a sequel to the Hotline: Miami, and as such it's not very fun. Actually it's far from the original Hotline Miami. Developers tried to make this game more realistic and that created a lot of problems. Let's talk about them. Before I start ranting on the combat system, let me tell that this game isn't as fast as the first one. And pacing really kills that mad blood lust of running without any fear of death from the HM1, because sometimes you have to play boring characters in long cover based shootouts (levels with a detective character are especially guilty of this). Other thing I didn't like was the story. It's forgettable and quite frankly, very generic when compared to HM1's 'Acid-Hallucination-Trip with a talking rooster who knows more about what's going on here than you do'.  Okay, let's get down to the combat and level design: -Melee system is now almost useless, because weapon throws aren't as powerful (half of your thrown weapons will drop 10 centimeters away from you and will not reach their target), so you can't stun or kill enemies without firearms as reliably as you could in the original HM. What makes melee even worse is level design. levels are now huge. You can only see very small part of the floor without endangering yourself. You easilly die by the shots that were fired from across the map, where you couldn't even see. Needless to say, levels are now unnecessarily difficult. In the first game every time you died, you died because you made a mistake, made a risky play or just had a bad luck with A.I. (A.I. likes to react to those gunshots that they want to react to). Now you will die much much more and not because of your mistakes - no. You will die as much as it takes for you to remember every single enemy on the map that is 2-3 times bigger than in the previous game. Small rooms and corridors were changed to big open halls and open large rooms full of regular enemies and the larger ones that take ~4 seconds to kill. I know, they were in the first game too, but this time some of them carry automatic rifles and are followed by several soldiers. Also, that room is surrounded by 3 other rooms full of enemies. If you try to kill them all carefully - you will fail. There is little careful planning in this game. That aspect of the game, just like fun melee system, was swapped with running with your gun (or knife if you run out of ammo) from room to room trying to clear them out before you die, so you could catch your breath and thin out enemy numbers as much as possible by luring them to the doorways. Sounds fun? It isn't. It just is not fun, because as soon as you feel that you cleared all the enemies except 1 or 2 that are standing in the room across the corridor you will run there only to get shot in the head by the guy, who was standing under some object that made him almost invisible. You may say that it used to happen in the first Hotline Miami and dying is the part of the game. And you would be correct. You could die by someone you couldn't clearly see and dying was a part of experience - but you have to remember that due to bigger levels, autosaves are now very rare, making you curse this game for killing your character in the cheapest way possible.   When I played the first Hotline Miami, I never raged. For me it was adrenaline fueled run, where every kill was satisfying - especially when going into the room with Fists of fury. In Hotline Miami 2 and its open, large levels it's rarely possible, so prepare to cower behind the corner, fearing for your life when you know the level is about to end, but you must go through the last corridor. And you know that if you slip up just a little bit - click one button a moment too late - you will die and you will have to go through the entire same floor that is big enough to fit 4 floors from HM1. Believe me - at that point no amount of good retro themed soundtracks will help you. Prepare for the endless grinding and a new type of story telling that doesn't really fit the mood of the first game. If you never played Hotline Miami - go buy the first one. If you are not sure if you want buy this game after playing the original - don't bother.  *No, I didn't like this game (but that doesn't mean that you can't like it - if you do, please - enjoy it). Finishing this game for me it was a chore and I would rather eat a bag of caterpillars than play through this drawn out nonsense AGAIN. And not because it's that bad - it's just too long and makes you play as characters you don't even like. On the other hand, caterpillars aren't so bad also - they are rich in proteins.
Best atmosphere of any game I have played for a long time, it will make you work for it though. 10/10

app_name: Ghost Town Mine Ride & Shootin' Gallery
review_text: I think a dark ride in VR is really a great concept. Rush of Blood on PSVR really works well, but this game loses me the minute it has me floating around and pulling a trigger to move wherever my head is pointed. I know there are control options, but you just can't avoid the floaty and not well grounded mode of travel. Can we finally stick a fork in that one? No more moving by pulling a trigger? Please?  Still, the opening scenes are nice, the goofy animatronic figures are fun, and the mine cart ride itself is good. This could be a fun diversion if they'd fix how you move when you're out of the cart.  I've got to go lie down with a wet cloth on my forehead now.

First off, a disclaimer. I haven't played many visual novels, maybe a couple before this one. As such, I'm not particularly savvy as what makes or breaks these types of games. In fact, I'm not even sure if VNs can be considered games, but that's a discussion for another time.   Lucy -The Eternity She Wished For-  is a remake of a VN that was originally released in Korea in 2010 and was funded via Kickstarter. The story is familiar enough, boy meets (android) girl, is stubbornly reluctant to bond with her at first, but she eventually warms her way into his heart. It reminded me of  Alex+Ada  a bit, seeing as that graphic novel deals with the relationship between a human and an android in a world that is openly hostile to the idea of human-like robots (the world in  Lucy  is less hostile to androids). Unlike  Alex+Ada  though, this one sticks the landing.   There's more going on in the background with the boy's open aversion to androids, what ties into his family, and, naturally, the question of whether a robot can have feelings is explored, leading to comparisons between a robot's programming and a person's upbringing. While I felt like these questions were deftly explored in this context (as well as another one I won't spoil), there were also a few subjects the VN didn't delve into as much as I would've liked. The already-limited interactivity (by my perceived VN standards) compounded this issue and was somewhat frustrating, particularly when placed in a situation where you wanted the character to be given choices to do or say something. After all, the character's behaviour is, at times, difficult to understand, although he's still a (rebellious) teenager so there's that. In exchange, you are offered alternate responses from time to time (a very long time) that have immediate impact (no ramifications that I can see) and unlock achievements in-game. However, it's only the very last dialogue option that alters how the ending plays out.  I can't shake the feeling that  Lucy  would have been better served if it had had more time to expand on its story, but then I remind myself it was a small, Kickstarter-backed, project (with a budget of $14,000), what puts things into perspective. There's only one VA in the game and that's Lucy (Korean and Japanese), the rest of the characters are silent, and they're not that many.  Even so, for all its weaknesses,  Lucy 's story managed to grip me, and move me to the brink of tears through its effective (and borderline criminal) use of dialogue, music, and art. Like  Chuunibyou , it blindsided me with a tonal shift I did not expect. Its narrative is cleverly told, so much so that it merits playing the VN a second time around to fully grasp everything that goes on. Like I said before, there are a couple of endings (actually, more like three) that depend on your last choice, as well as an epilogue that I believe gets rewritten if you unlock all the endings.   It took me about 6 hours to complete, unlocking all achievements and extras. It's a beautifully-told, emotional rollercoaster that stands above its flaws and is definitely worth experiencing. I cannot help but think it pulled some punches due to budget constraints. The KS page does mention it has a streamlined storyline so maybe the original is longer and more comprehensive, but  Lucy -The Eternity She Wished For-  is one VN you should really consider checking out.

This is my personal 2015 game of the year. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt does nearly everything right and is the benchmark of open-world RPGs. The story is excellent and the characters are very interesting. This seems rather rare in the video game industry, considering game developers aren't necessarily the best storytellers or writers. The RPG elements are spectacular, especially the fact that the decisions you make will impact various aspects of the game in different ways. This isn't Telltale bull ♥♥♥♥, this is the real deal. Decisions actually matter in The Witcher 3. The combat is also compelling, especially at the higher difficulties where you really need to plan for battles accordingly. I'm currently on my second runthrough of the game, as there's plenty of replay value here. Hell, just one playthrough is filled with hundreds of hours of content if you choose to explore everything the game has to offer. I'm looking forward to the upcoming expansion as well.  Pros: + Story and characters + Legitimate role-playing elements + Game length + Replayability + Immersive open-world + Compelling combat + Gwent + Expansion potential + Visual fidelity + Optimization + No observable FPS cap + SLI support and great scaling  Cons: - A few bugs here and there  Grade: A

Have you ever played Icarus Proudbottom Teaches Typing or Frog Fractions? If not, stop reading and start in on those free flash games; I'll wait.   If you've made it back with your sanity in one piece, or if you've already recovered from losing your mind, you'll probably have noticed the thing those games have in common, which is that they're not exactly what they appear to be. There's a simple mechanic at the core of each game, but the real game is more in the meta commentary about what the game actually is. Games about games, like The Magic Circle, are the decidedly postmodern expression of restless developers who aren't satisfied with the complacent feedback loops and progression curves of modern games, but unless they're literally making a point about the meaninglessness of control (The Stanley Parable), they're best when they actually manage to be a game, even as they deconstruct the entire notion.   Enter Pony Island, a self-described 'suspense puzzle game in disguise,' which basically establishes the game-within-a-game 'Pony Island' as a limbo-like punishment for gamers, a one-trick...well...pony, in which you leap your magical pony/unicorn over gates over and over again until you agree to cede your soul to Lucifer. Pony Island itself, then, which does far more with its retro framing device than You Have to Win the Game or classic Strongbad cartoons, is a game of constant one-upmanship; players 'cheat' at the devil's game, at which point Lucifer changes the code, forcing players to once again hack their way around his conventions. Along the way, the game pulls tricks from Eternal Darkness's book, cleverly attempting to convince players that the game is failing so that players will feel smart when they out-think the devil and progress to the next act.   Except, and here's the really clever part, the heart of the game really is 'Pony Island.' Even though you're aware that this black-and-white wireframe jumping simulator (which eventually gets two upgrades--a laser and wings--that don't add much to the difficulty) is a repetitive anti-game, there's so much framework built into Pony Island itself that you can't help but dive back into the original game. And along the way, you'll even get to see the various iterations of design, from a minimalist text-adventure rendering to a pathetic 3D version, and even a few different skins, including a cheery, full-color 'modern' version. If the goal is simply to not play 'Pony Island,' players can simply quit at any point--Mullens doesn't go so far as to obfuscate your menu options. But because there are hidden 'Pony Island' tickets to collect by completing cryptic tasks--along with equally meaningless Steam achievements--players soldier through the banal hopping in order to see what clever trick comes next.   And there's a lot of content here, from optional tasks like interacting with the desktop's 'Settlers of sAtan' and finding passwords buried in broken option menus, to a series of 'hacking' puzzles that involve placing basic operators into holes in faux-code. It's nothing overly strenuous. Even when loops and splitters are introduced, which calls for a lot of mid-routine micromanagement, the game isn't actually trying to keep the player from winning; it's just trying to convince the player that it is. That's the genius: 'Pony Island' represents every repulsively designed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t time-suck, and Pony Island redeems them all. This even fits into the whole idea of games-as-limbo, in which players can either uselessly throw away their life/time/soul, or can find something of merit within the limns of all that code and thereby make something more of themselves. (It's one of the reasons I turned to criticism in the first place, as actively participating in entertainment is far superior to passively observing it.)   Even though there is no part of the final level that I even remotely enjoy, I couldn't put Pony Island down. It kept wrapping new and surprisingly devious tricks around the same-old-same-old pony express, and the context kept me going. Is there any practical difference between shooting a laser of corrupted binary data at demons or blowing a gust of wind at butterflies that just want to tickle you? No, just as 'Pony Island' itself could be just about any game. What matters, then, is what's around the mechanics, and in that, Pony Island has found gold, and the fact that it doesn't settle for simply being a series of puzzles (like Please, Don't Touch Anything), is what elevates it to a Game That Matters--a game that, in finding both structure and absurdity, succeeds more than Frog Fractions. It's a joke that laughs with you, not at you.

Insurgency is a military shooter. Simple as that.  Honestly, I do not like this game, but I can see why many people would. I like shooters which focus on slightly lengthier 1v1 fights and teamplay; I only play Team Fortress 2, pretty much.   I got this game because NODE played it a lot, and I thought I would enjoy it myself. I should've known better, however, because I've played both Arma III and CS:GO, and disliked them both.   Now let's get to the good part of this review. This is one of the most realistic shooters I've played. You have to pay attention to all of your surroundings, both visually and audially. You have to be careful yet ready when rounding corners, and you will die very easily. Basically Arma with CoD-sized maps.   Military-style tactical shooters are quite popular nowadays, and if you're into that, get this game now, or wait for it to go on sale, or something. If you're not into that, however, don't think that this is a more univerally-friendly tactical shooter. Insurgency isn't for everyone, and hopefully you know what you like before you consider a purchase.

Sadly there is the problem with the price. Even though I felt highly entertained I only did so for round about four hours - because that's how long it took me to play through. And for nearly 20€ - that doesn't feel quite enough. So I highly recomment if you can get it on sale!

A straight up classic team/deathmatch shooter with brilliantly crafted maps and excellent gunplay. A game that still has a large amount of players even though it's pretty old. It has a wide selection of third-party maps and a variety of unofficial modes to enjoy. So if playing the game 'out of the box' gets boring after a while, you'll still have more of the game.  It still has a large amount of active players worldwide and a ton of servers to play on.  The dealbreaker is obviously the price of this game, considering it's really old. You should probably wait for a sale or when this game finally gets a price cut. Or just play CS:GO.

Time Rifters is a single player coop shooter. You stack your performances throughout 4 playthroughs to blast all the cubes that are strategically placed throughout the level. You must balance your zone control, weapon upgrades, and skill in order to achieve 100% completion.  This game rocks my socks... 4 times in a row. The music is rock hard, the level design is both spot on mechanically as well as visually. Seriously, the amount of aesthetic diversity in the levels is immense. For those who have this game already, take a close look at the wall in the tree level. There's a pixel matrix style effect that is so subtle I doubt many will notice it but the fact that it's there speaks leaps and bounds about the love and care poured over this game.  Content wise, there's 3 episodes consisting of 5 levels each which will take you about 30 minutes each. But if you actually want to beat them aka 100% them you'll be going back a few times. And then if you really want to push yourself you'll try to 100% the level before you've used all your guys. When you've had enough playing with yourself there are online replays that you can either upload yourself or download to play with. A handful of youtubers have already posted their's up so you'll be able to play alongside them right off the bat.  Downsides? Well even after coming back a few times to up your score, the content feels a little on the short side but in my opinion it's still well worth the $10 price tag because of the immense polish around the game and you'd regret not having played it more than you'll ever regret having spent the money on this rather than something else.  Lastly, a quick note about the VR. If you're a virtual reality developer this is a mandatory buy for you. Buy it and see how to do VR implementation correctly. You don't have to copy it but atleast take a deep look at it and see why it works wonderfully from the autocorrecting camera depending on where you walk with the joystick to the UI they use to the menu and even the level design itself. Look at it and feel intimidated because they're setting a high bar to measure up to.  For those of you who aren't VR developers and wonder if this game is as good without an oculus rift, OF COURSE it isn't! EVERYTHING is better in VR but that doesn't make it a bad game outside of it. In the case of Time Rifters it works just as good and still is worth your time and money.  4/4 Time Lords, would rift again.  Edit: They've just released a daily challenge mode/level editor as a way to offer more content. No excuses now, get buying!

GTA Online, basically.  Get this game. Mostly due to the fact that it's free to play, but also because its a solid game. It has a lot in common with the extremely popular GTA franchise, with its massive open-world, car stealing, citizen killing and varied weapon selection, but it obviously lacks a coherent story, since it's mostly a Massively Multiplayer Online game, so if you're looking for story, don't try this game. If you're looking for quick fun, action packed gameplay, try it out.   The customization is INSANE in this, you'll probably spend a few hours just to create your character. And the customization doesnt stop here: weapons, clothing (you can customize the clothings, not just what your character is weraing, meaning you can not only change colors but apply designs, logos, emblems, etc on them) and the many vehicles are 100% customizable (and usually upgradable aswell)  Thanks to its random missions and its nice PVP mode, the replayability is extremely high in this game. Just jump in and play.  Graphics 10/10 Soundtrack 9/10 Replayability 14/15 Gameplay 12/15  Overall - 9/10

I've seen the same (major) NPC spawned twice in the same room, each with broken animations.   I've had missions where I had to start riots to progress, only to have the rioters spawn two blocks over, and clumped up in such a way that their bodies were intersecting each other, clearly a glitch.   I distinctly remember one of the early missions I did being *entirely* broken, requiring me to restart the game *twice*, just to figure out a way of avoiding the glitch.  Climbing on the outside of a boat, trying to infiltrate it stealthily? Hope you haven't momentarily been glimpsed out of the corner of one guard's eye. It's not enough to actually make him 'alert' to you, but he never seems to become unsuspicious, and worse seems to psychicly know where you're at, even though he can't see you. I had to restart a single mission THIRTY times, just because of this and other glitches.  Glitches aside, the story meanders, and fails to have a cohesive plot. The protagonist is railroaded into one story after another, clearly more to force the plot to carry you along with major historical events (riding the same horse as Paul Revere, for example) rather than writing a good story against the backdrop of the Revolutionary War. The developers clearly had a checklist of major and minor historical figures and events that they wanted to force you into meeting.  The voice acting of the main protagonist is dull. He has two tones: Grey, and loud. The writing is shoddy, with his emotional state seemingly random.   The mechanics are a bit haphazard as well. Hunting? It's never really made clear what that's for. Possibly for (near-pointless) crafting for (absolutely pointless) trading, and the occasional collection quest, but I have tons of materials in my pocket (because infinite pockets) that I'm never quite sure if I'm supposed to be selling or saving, so I've stuck with saving (and ultimately doing nothing with them).   Climbing trees? Dangerous, not actually all that useful (since it slows you down). Same with buildings, at this point. Gone are the days of AC1 and AC2's free running being a transportation method. The roofs of buildings are often too mismatched or unconnected to ever be useful. It was so bad that even the developers realized they needed to shoehorn in an underground maze that unlocks fast travel points around the area, so you can quickly traverse the city without having to deal with actually playing the game to travel.   The maze you unlock fast travel with? Dull. It's atmospheric at first, but after spending 45 mind-numbing minutes exploring ever nook of it just to make sure I missed nothing (there was nothing to miss, only the fast travel points are down there), I now have absolutely no reason to visit it ever again, and regret spending so much time with it.   Side missions? Most of them involve little to no plot. In fact, the vast majority involve finding four people in a city, and pushing a button/key while standing next to them. The most complicated the dialog gets is something like 'Thank you for delivering this'.   I'm around half way through the game, and most of the time I spend playing it has me either rolling my eyes, yawning, or incredibly frustrated.  I'm only playing it because I feel it's necessary to not miss part of the over-arching story. I read books. I *own* books (enough to fill two seven-foot-tall bookshelves). I've been reading my whole life, and sci-fi/fantasy stories are my bread and butter. I can't *not* finish this game before moving on to the (reportedly better) AC4, but I'm NOT enjoying the experience.   The first time I started playing it, I spent 19 hours with it before I gave up. It's the first PC AC game I didn't play through to the end. I'm back now a year and a half later, playing it again, just so I can finish it and move on to the reportedly much better AC4. I'm 48% of the way through, and wish it was already over.  If you're not like me, and can stand to skip this bit of the story (or are willing to let someone else spoil it for you), do not buy this game. If you DO need to buy this game, I recommend spending as little money as possible.

Playing FFA Regicide with friends. Using the Game of Thrones soundtrack add-on for extra epicness. After an hour of warfare, alliances, and betrayal, my city falls and I brace myself for defeat. Suddenly, I see a message: 'Anon has changed their status with you to ally.' He lets me bring my king and villagers to his city for protection. He tells me to hide my king near his castles for protection. Under his protection, I begin to rebuild my empire. After a few minutes, I see another message. 'Anon has changed their status with you to enemy.' I watch as the crossbowmen in his castle execute my king. The Rains of Castamere begin to play, mocking my defeat. It was at this moment I realized how amazing Age of Empires II was.  True story
