* Boring plotwise thus far (Though this may be partially due to some disappointment of mine coming specifically from me really loving Bloodborne's original plot) while shoving the old game's lore in your face with almost no new lore and ♥♥♥♥♥ier item descriptions and all while forgetting what made DS1 so memorable   * You have to play through the Poison Swamp level, the Skeleton Catacombs,    Anor Londo   , and the   Grand Archives    again  * Poise is needlessly cryptic after an unexplained rework that makes it only really effective during certain moves while attacking (to the point that it has no easily noticable effect if you're keeping old poise in mind and the community thought it was turned off for months; if I have made an error in my description of the mechanic, let it be a testament to how non-straightforward poise is now)  * The creation of Vitality (equip load stat) as separate from Stamina seems to have been done to prevent fast rolling with heavy armor from being easily done, but all it does, especially with the decrease in the potency of the effects of Havel's Ring and Ring of Favor, is make fast rolling something no one wants to work towards  * Bows and whips still suck and still have much smaller numbers compared to all the swords and such in the game  * A weapon infusion that makes quality builds (40 STR 40 DEX, with the highest amount of weapon choices and therefore highest build versatility and added damage from dual scaling) even better than they already are continues to make casters seem like a more gimmicky choice (thankfully this is partially mitigated by infusions that scale VERY well with int and faith but they fall into the pit of split damaging)  * Invaders have a hard time random invading without getting ganked to hell and back and the only secure method of red phantom fun is through the soapstone into a SL 120 meta fight club (Reduced health and healing items + higher chance to invade co-oping players + the Blue Anti-invader covenants + seed of a giant tree = ♥♥♥♥ you random Reds)   * The covenants are just the same ones again with no real changes and just one mildly interesting new covenant while continuing Bloodborne's blunder of making the covenants tacked-on and not relevant to much and removing the PvE covenant concept from DS2 (The Solaire-fanboy-fellating Sunbros are back alongside two Forest Hunter covenants and the linked Way of Blue/Blue Sentinels covenant plus the Darkwraiths but under the command of discount Gwynevere, complete with her own sidequest ripped from DS1's Lautrec sidequest, because thinking of a new sideplot is hard! The only really conceptually new covenant is the Mound Makers and even that one needs work to make its covenant interesting or desired. Also, the rewards still suck and they add nothing to the story and are made even more meaningless by just being swappable items.)  Displeased, wouldn't recommend unless you're really thirsty for a live and thriving community to coop and fight club with despite the continued inability of From Software to adequately innovate on and perfect its multiplayer mechanics and the lackluster, overly self-referencial lore, and even then, do your research to see if you'd feel at home after the other Souls games.

So, just a quick warning, this is a ramble. An unorganized, opinionated rant. If you want the tl;dr, it's that XCOM 2 is highly moddable, so if there's something you don't like in vanilla, I can gurantee you'll find a mod that fixes it for you. And while the arguement that 'you shouldn't have to mod it to make it better' is definetely valid, I feel like a lot of the complaints are those of personal preference, as opposed to inherent flaws.   ________________________________________________________________________________  There's something I really do have to adress here, and it's that a lot of the negative reviews seem to stem from the idea that this game isn't like the Long War mod from Enemy Unknown/Within, and that the mission timers are too restrictive. Aside from being personal preference, they're valid reasons to dislike XCOM 2, but at the same time, both of those problems can easily be changed with the plethora of mods out their. Hell, the True Concealment mod fixes the timer issue, and I've used it nearly since launch.   It seems like a lot of people were really hoping for this to turn out like Long War, which, for the unfamiliar, was a mod that expanded upon the original game so much that it could've been compared to the Enemy Within expansion. Multiple base assaults and defenses, new UFOs, weapons, classes, skills, missions, enemy types in the form of 'bosses', alien research systems, all contributed to, well, a longer war. Overall, it just added so much to an already great game.  XCOM 2, however, is not Long War. It's not Enemy Unknown or Enemy Within. That might seem like an odd thing to say, but that includes the mindset and strategies you'll be using. You're a guerilla force now. The aliens kicked your ♥♥♥ in the first war. ADVENT is their puppet government, controlling the populaces of several large, advanced cities, with the rest of humanity scattered about in small rural towns and the wilderness. As XCOM, your job is to now get as many resources as you can scrounge up, break down the Elders' plans, and free humanity from these ADVENT-burger-advertising ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.   You don't have the resources of dozens of first world countries to back you up. You don't have highly trained military veterans. What you're working with are scrips and scraps, the bottom of the barrel. You're a resistance, a bunch of rag tag, xenophobic individuals, who really hate those ADVENT burgers. You don't have the luxury of time on missions or on the geoscape. You have the turn timers, and you have the Avatar Project, basically you're doomsday clock. Once that thing is full, you have anywhere from 10 - 20 days to make a dent in their research before you get a classic game over.   XCOM 2 is a game about guerilla warfare. You have to beat the time. Obviously, this won't sit well with some people, and again, I encourage you to take a gander at the modding scene. Aside from the expected gameplay changes, there are some really great quality of life mods, such as Numeric Health Displays and Show Soldier Icons. And don't even get me started on all the soldier customization options. Seriously. In my current campaign, I'm rolling with Cole Train and Mr. Torgue, in addition to various Halo and Titanfall armor pieces. The mods are the established meta of this game, and it's a meta that you can choose.   So, overall, yes. I recommend XCOM 2. It's a fun game, highly customizable, with a lot to do. There are some mods that I'd encourage you to download before even playing the game, or at least to look at them. Grimy's Loot Mod, ADVENT Ascension, Capnbubs Accessories Pack, Free Camera Rotation, any map pack, Free the Hood, Numeric Health Display, Quiet Bradford, and True Concealment are all mods that I use in my current campaign, in addition to a large number of other mods. I'd recommend that you check out the XCOM subreddit and ask some questions if you need any help. Great community.

review_text: I am PLEASED to see this game on steam. I had purchased this game back in the late 90s when it was out for PC, the game discs got scratched and I could never afford it again. Now it is on steam, and that is awesome. The game play is EXTREMELY long and you can't argue with what you will get!

If there's one thing you'd expect from a 'game' of this nature, it's gorgeous graphics and a wonderful soundtrack. This game most assuredly has both of those. The developers made a very interesting and unconventional decision when they chose to give the world you inhabit (for all of ten minutes) a mosaic-like quality, but what can I say...it works. For what it sets out to do, pretty much EVERYTHING about this game works. Is it 'challenging'? No. It's not meant to be. Is it 'long'? Well, from what I can tell thus far, it may indeed have quite a bit of replayability as there's a sufficiently large landscape to explore, and quite a number of achievements to unlock, but quite how many hours of value you'll get for your whopping great eight-dollar investment I can't yet rightly say.     As long as you have some idea what you're buying, you shouldn't have much to complain about. It's a 'walking simulator'...NOT CALL OF ♥♥♥♥ING DUTY. If you want to shoot guns and snipe enemies from afar, you've come to the wrong place. If you're happy to wander around a surreal, serene landscape for ten minutes then witness the end of the world, you just might get a little more out of it. It's NICE, okay? (In a, er, semi-nihilistic, apocalyptic kinda way.) Between this and the recent Australian film These Final Hours, I can safely say that I now feel perfectly at peace with the notion of Armageddon.    You know what this is? It's a thing of extraordinary beauty. Simple as that. A work of art. Think of it as an excellent 'tech demo' with a strong aesthetic and a THEME. Something which most of the more fully-fledged 'games' out there tend to lack in, in other words. Definitely not one for the 'speed runners', but the more open-minded and open-hearted among us might even find ourselves MOVED, dare I say, even if only for ten minutes or so.    Verdict: 9/10.

I love Artifex Mundi games but this is not their greatest. I tried hard to summon the strength to finish but the game unfortunately got on my nerves.  Pros - The concept of time travelling to find and solve clues is great! - The artwork, as always, is good (not the best in this game but still looks nice) - The story seemed like it would be interesting from what I played so far.  Cons - The worst culprit by far is the female narrator. She drove me nuts! She narrates what is happening to her like she is reading the weather and it's going to be sunny all day. Not convincing at all and I couldn't even click through the narrative to shut her up (she really needs shutting up). - The HOS seemed too cluttered (yeah, I know they're supposed to be) to the point where I struggled sometimes to distinguish one shape from another. - The time travel tool gives you a ! which indicates an area you can explore/solve a clue next, but I got to the stage where there were no ! anywhere and for the life of me, I couldn't find the last item I needed to progress. I even consulted a Bigfish guide but gave up when I couldn't find a solution.  Sorry, Artifex Mundi. I love and have played most of your other games but this one is not your best.   Hala xxx  P.S. Please don't use the same female narrator again. She was awful :(

It is not perfect, but I'm loving it. They did release it before it was 100% and could have avoided the backlash if they put more emphasis on that fact that they released it for the tournament. Right now it is definitely more competitive/multiplayer focused. The real single player will be out in a couple months. The only real complaint I have is that the Arcade Mode is missing, but capcom is working on it.   It is so clean and crisp. They had some launch problems with the online, but majority of games do have problems at launch. This game needs a fair chance. Do research on what you are buying. I knew what I was getting into buying early on. I payed $45 for SFV and I'm completely satisfied. The slow release of content over the next couple months will just make the game even better.   If you want single player and aren't in for the multiplayer just wait a few months. If you love being competitive then definitely purchase now. Street Fighter has been one of my favorite game series since birth and this entry did not disappoint me. I actually like it more than SFIV.   Capcom said this is an evolving platform. They will continue to improve and add things to the game. Voice your concerns with Capcom on the Capcom Forums if you want the game to improve.

A brilliant art game worth 1 hour and a half of your time. Hard to describe without giving some details away. Please play the game for yourself.  Post-Game Thoughts:    Whether or not the story is real (he is, after all, selling this game along with its games' soundtracks...), Davey still does an amazing job of giving these games justice. I never thought there could really be a person who creates art for themselves. Personally, I love showing people the stuff I've poured my heart into but also find enjoyment and purpose in knowing about something of my own creation.

I am very on the fence about this game to the point I had trouble deciding to up or down vote. I love x-com/banner saga fighting style. This game took a chance to try to differentiate itself by giving you 2 turns that you can use for any character. They did this obviously to try to be different. People have been comparing it more to chess than X-com. The problem is this is not chess and it doesn't make sense to move 1 guy 8 times in a row while your other guys sit there. I tried it and have to say I don't like the move this piece at the expense of that piece style. I bought the game and so will continue to try to put some more time in but this is a core piece of the functionality of the game. Turn based strategy games are 90% the fights and this really hamstrings it for me. I'll update if that feeling changes but for now this game is just a decent try by an indy that will be forgettable which is a shame because the setting and turnbased system is something that had me really excited.

Ive played other games of a similar type but this is by and far a much more well rounded and interesting game. The storyline is amazing and you want to know what has happened to the character you first interact with.  12/10

Great. Challenging. Frustrating. Oddly relaxing. Addictive. You will love it. You will hate it. You will hate yourself. But come on, on last try, right?  As someone without naturally quick reflexes or much skill, but with a bit of patience I can assure you: even if you suck, you will get better if you keep at it. It just might take 57 hours.  Also, if you value your sanity I recommend playing this in windowed mode without sound while you're watching something or listening to podcasts/audiobooks. Not that the soundtrack isn't great, but you'll see what I mean. You will see.

Ive owned this game on two platforms. Recently i bought it again. This time during the summer sale.   First thing ill say is the multiplayer is rather grindy. Too have a really awesome car it will take a good 1-2 weeks or so (depending on if you wanna spend atleast 2+ whole days grinding missions and what car you are saving up for) for people with limited time to play. Although, you dont need these really fancy cars, helicopters, planes and now luxury yachts. A basic car, few weapons, abit of armour and friends can really bring out the best of what this game has to offer.  MONEY MAKING TIP: This wont make you money upfront but it can be worth it. Buy a CEO building maze bank being the cheapest (1mil). If playing solo grind these two missions in the 'CEO Work section'. Headhunter and sightseer. These missions are fairly easy. Especially if you have an Armoured Karuma or helicopter.  As a side note i really like how theyve made there servers. Having public lobby's, private lobby's (so on.) Theres nothing better than being in a public lobby and watching a truck being chased down by two turreted-limos! (and maybe a jet)  As for singleplayer, i think theyve done a good job developing the characters and then fitting their personalities into the game. The missions are fun, dont follow a predictable path and can be quite challenging at times. The story line can be short.   I would also like to point out that all the updates have been free. Stunt races free, heists free, all the updates and DLC has been free. No paid ones whatsoever.   NOTE:  Most of the reviews ive seen have been complaining about bans, or to be more detailed, false banning. If you encounter this issue (which i personally havent) I would suggest contacting Rockstar's support teams and resolving your issue. If you have been banned, its rather accidental (and therefore can be resolved). Or for a reason.

I just 100%'d the game (steam achievements) so I'm going to try and write a review. Yay!  DeadCore is a fantastic FPS parkour puzzle speedrunner game. The objective is to reach the top of a mysterious tower by running, jumping, and using your trusty Switch Gun to activate and/or deactivate switches, enemies, moving walls, and gravity fields, while trying not to get disintegrated by lasers or fall to your death (which is by lasers most of the time anyway because a floor of lasers follows you upwards whenever you reach a new checkpoint). Most of the enemies don't actually kill you, but the turrets and troopers launch you away (often into lasers) and the mosquitoes slow you down (so you can be killed by moving lasers).  The whole game can be speedrun in less than an hour, but it takes several hours to finish the first time, familiarise yourself with the levels, learn some speedrun strats, and find the hidden Sparks to unlock the game's true ending.  + The controls are simple and responsive: WASD to move, E to boost, M1 to shoot, M2 to aim (personally didn't find much point in aiming), and M3 to blast. + The feeling of speed is very nicely communicated (did I describe that right?) + The graphics are very nice and sleek-looking, even on very low (;_; my computer) + The levels are well designed, with some tough challenges, often with multiple paths, and encourage a bit of exploration to find the collectables + Speedrun mode! Leaderboards! Beat the devs! + Beating the dev times, completing a paticularly difficult section of a level, finding short cuts, finding hidden collectables, and just being launched high into the air and boosting around, gives a lot of satisfaction. +/- The difficulty ramps up quite a bit, and in the later levels you will die many times to the challenges. This is a personal thing, I enjoyed the difficulty but some people won't. - Story doesn't really make sense. Or maybe I'm too literal-minded. - You have no body and it's a bit hard to know what your hitbox is going to do  Overall a great game, I highly recommend it to fans of first person parkour or speedrun games, and people who like a challenge.

I have a total of 90+ hours in this game (most of it is from the patch that disables steam overlay and timeplayed)  Would I reccomend this 'game'? No.  The biggest issue with the game is its censorship. its not hard to bypass, but its there, which is a huge negative in my opinion.  Then theres the translation issues. If you dont get the patch (which youre an idiot if you dont), unless you can speak and understand fluent japanese, there will be a huge portion of the game that is nigh undecipherable. Spelling, grammar, incorrect sentence structure, its as if the translation team literally spent 0 hours trying to translate this properly, and instead sent it through google translate.  My biggest personal qualm would have to be the still images. There is probably only 3 variations of each location. Of which there are about 10. Thats 30 images total. Put together with the different expressions and poses the characters are actually in, makes it seem as if they arent moving, they are simply being copy and pasted into a different place. Its very immersion breaking and kinda hilarious. Not in a good way. This is all just personal qualms, but they are prevelent through out the entire 'game' (its not a game... there are like 5 decisions, which are totally stupid and seem utterly pointless)  The final issue i have with this game is the characters. Do i even need to say anything about Aoi? He is the luckiest son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ on earth, having nearly 20 beautiful women all near him. At an age where his hormones should have been RAGING (Hes 14-15, give or take a year or so). Sure hes awkward, but so much so he is utterly clueless for most of the novel. In fact, its almost like He was written to be a bland narrator instead of an actual changing person. I dont think i saw him one time in the entire novel say anything that wasnt unexpected or surprising. Not even when he was talking about his 'injury' (he scrapped his knee. boohoo. hes a little ♥♥♥♥♥). Hell, even (WARNING: MAJOR SPOILERS) when they learned what happened to isuka he acted like a emotionless robot narrator.  There are alot of Visual Novels that have been released first in japanese then translated into english for a steam release. You really want a fantastic Visual Novel experience? Get Clannad, or Katawa shoujo, or the numerous others that are a higher quality when it comes to story, length, and characters Do not waste your money on this.

Spelunky is an action-packed, proceduallry-generating, strategic platformer. You'll get addicted to this charming cave crawler in absolutely no time. You can either compete with friends in local deathmatch, or you can compete online with others in the Daily Challenge mode, which updates every day. Of course there is always the classic adventure mode where you have been called to explore the depths of hell, and gather it's riches. This is the very definition of with risk comes reward, especially after dying multiple of dozens of times, you will eventually liberate the worlds riches, and they wil be all yours! Fight bosses and fend off enemies that will kill you if it's the last thing they do. Each and every enemy has a different plot to brutally end your life. But don't let that stop you! You will gain skills and knowledge in your journal and eventually become the sensei of caving. However, only one question faces you, will you become a world renound explorer, or be mercilessly killed by the creatures the dangerous caves behold?

app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain is a masterpiece in it's own. However, to most big Metal Gear fans, like myself, it really isn't that good of a game. Here's why. MGSV is a game that to us fans of it, is a huge step forward in gameplay. All other MGS titles have been either top down or 3rd Person, like MGSV. I personally think that it is a fantastic game, but only on the gameplay. The story however, the most important element to all MGS games, is not that good. Story is sparse, and offers no closure on this series like it was promised to do. This, is why MGSV is LITERALLY a Phantom Pain. This aside, I do reccomend it. If you miss out on this title, you'll miss out on a fantastic game.

This is one of the best games of the last years.  AI War: Fleet Command is a strategy game which you will love. Building your econemy, your ships (lots of ships; if you say, I'll attack with 400 ships, there are really 500 ships on the map...and you need them), creating your tactics and win against the AI...or lose. Sounds normal? This game has some more stuff than other games...or better, it is doing everything a bit different. It is relativ hard to get into the game. But after one, two, three houres of playing you get it (hotkeys, fight mechanics, etc. ). And than it gets really good.  The 'story' behind this fighting is, that AI populations have taken the world we know (or better the universe) and the human species has to recover and fight back. Every solarsystem is to capture, because the AI got everything, so you have to fight from the beginning. 'War is not fair' are the introducing words of that game. And that's true. The AI got reinforcement out of nowhere, but that's not a minus for the game, because that's how it works. You get better, the AI too, so get some friends and play it coop, it is much more fun to tell someone how unfair it is, that the AI is sending again 600 bombers to you homeworld ;) and it is impossible to beat the AI alone on higher difficulties.  For these who don't like micro-strategy, just take everything you have and click on the enemy. They have so many livepoints, that you have to concentrate you fire always on one ship of thair ships, so it's not that important which ship is where, just that it is in combat :). Or you have the option to play as a champion. Than you have no base, just one big ship which gain lvl and better weapons over time, so you have to care about nothing than your 'hero' (a little RPG in strategy).  But the other are right, be warned: This game is huge. You play normaly over 7 houres on one campain. If you play with friends on bigger maps, it can take over 20h, so be sure to have enougth time.  And...If you like soundtracks, buy it! Don't think about the game...this Music is epic, you can listen to it for hours and there are so beautiful songs between (AncientShadows, Cries of Zenith are my favorites ;) ) ...amazing...(with the expensions there are over 5.5h music)  So if you like space strategy games or really good musik buy that game...and on sale day like now (the holiday sale) it is nearly for free. (I would recommend to buy the expensions too (the collection))

When this game first launched it was an ok linear visual novel/strategy game. It had some improvement over the first game, but also some steps backwards. With the content added in the 'Captains Edition', this game evolved into something great. You still must play though the original meidocre campaign to unlock (and make sense of) the second campaign, which is where things take a turn for greatness. Part of the reason why it is so great, is due to the first campaign being not so great. The masterful way that they fixed the game, was by taking the short comings of the first campaign and turing it into the strength of the second campaign. The pay off of it is incredibly satisfying.  Obviously this is all IMO, but if they had just made the game that people thought they wanted in the first place (myself included), it wouldn't even be as good as what the game is now.

app_name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
review_text: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons ties its gameplay, or perhaps more accurately, the controlling mechanics to its narrative well. This is its strongest element. Each hand controls a brother, which seems simple enough on paper, but it can take a little while to become familiar with them.  This is where things start to progress downhill, in my opinion. The game is very much story-driven, only taking about 3 hours to complete. The beautiful and sometimes grim European fantasy landscapes seemed to change too often, too fast, and did not ask much of me to progress. Puzzle difficulty increased marginally from beginning to end.  The simple story is filled with conveniences in its plot, and also lacks in depth. Its unfavorable portrayal of female characters throughout struck me as odd. The wonderful score can only distract from these faults for so long. There are a couple very strong moments within the game, however I would not recommend this title on those merits alone.   Edited for tone.

BEWARE! ALWAYS ONLINE DRM!  The first three levels (2 tutorials + first real level) are really well done and so far I 'was' having fun. The game's DRM though prevented me from enjoying the rest of my evening, as apparently the game servers went down and game told me I am unable to load the saved game I made 2 minutes before, because I lost connection to the almighty game server. Stupid me, welcome to 2016 when the game tells you it is late and it's time to stop playing.  Thanks to that hidden feature, at least I have time to write this review. So let's start with three major points:  1. The game is a technical disaster. Two 770GTX GPUs in SLI here - game settings fixed texture quality to Low with no way to change and also fixed maximum resolution to 1080p with options above, greyed out. (found out there is a way to set higher resolution via launch options and it works great, but apparently the devs didn't want to risk someone having a slight dip in FPS) 2. Game divided into episodes. Seriously, this game is supposed to release a new level every month. The game developer/publisher wants me to play one level for a whole 30 days before they decide to give me the next slice of the pie I already paid for. That is of course if it lets you play, which gets me to the next point... 3. ALWAYS F-IN ONLINE DRM! This is absolutely amazing, but apparently if you play with your internet connetion on, the game creates save games that are online-only! The game comes with a parental lock already implemented and it doesn't matter how old you are. When the game servers want to sleep, so should you! Stop complaining and welcome to 2016 world of DRMs. Truly unbelievable.  Honestly I would say to wait for a patch, but the issues I described are design flaws and they won't be fixed. It is a pity as I loved every other previous Hitman game. This one also is very very good, but there is no way to play it... it is either missing levels or missing ability to load save games.  That said I could at least enjoy the rest of the beer I'm drinking, while writing this (instead of playing the game) and I hope someone will hesitate to buy after reading this. Let us all hope this episodic-always-online-♥♥♥♥ won't become the new era of video games.

Bitweb is a top-down action puzzle game where you control the walls around to to avoid enemies and collect items for points. It unfortunately suffers from several problems:   - There's no tutorial, help text, or manual. The effects of the items could use some explaining. (For example, did you know that you can throw the blue stick things using the spacebar? I certainly didn't!)  - The core gameplay mechanic, 'xor-ing', is unintuitive and difficult to figure out. Nothing in the game indicates what clicking on the screen does exactly. The walls change sometimes, but sometimes they change even when you don't click. Eventually, I figured out that where you click on the screen matters, as well as whether you use the right or left mouse button, but I still have no idea what to do to progress beyond randomly mashing on the mouse.  - In general, the game feels unpolished. There's no menu screen or GUI except for the score and high score. Hitting Escape immediately closes the game window, and it doesn't even bother to save the high score.  All in all, Bitweb is a good start to a game, but not something I'd recommend playing in its current state.

Geometry Dash is by far one of the greatest and most addicting platforming games I have ever played, and I applaud RobTop, who has made a masterpiece with this game, available on Steam and mobile devices.  The game's concept is simple in nature: you control a cube, and you must jump over and duck under obstacles such as spikes and buzz saws in the correct order to complete levels.   However, from there, things get more complicated: the cube can turn into a spaceship, a UFO, a gravity ball, a wave, and a robot, through use of special portals, and all of those transformations act differently. The speed of the stage, size of the cube, and location of the cube can change through use of other portals, and the cube can even split into two separate characters that must be controlled simultaneously. Most stages will have at least 4 or 5 of these modifiers, and they can either make a stage much easier or much more difficult.  There are 20 official levels in the game as of Update 2.0, and they range from very easy to almost impossibly difficult. Levels are rated by difficulty, including Auto, Easy, Normal, Hard, Harder, Insane, or Demon. Every level has its own unique techno-electronic soundtrack, composed by musicians who upload their content to Newgrounds.  I myself have completed all 20 of these official levels. It was extremely hard, but I did it.  Upon completing one of these levels, you are awarded stars, as well as secret coins if you managed to find them during the level. Collecting stars and coins allows you to unlock other costumes and colors for your little cube so that you can change its in-game appearance.  There are also thousands and thousands of user-created levels made with the in-game level editor that you can play to earn stars and user coins. There’s plenty of fun to have beating as many levels as you can and earning hundreds of stars, or making your own level for others to play.  In conclusion, I cannot recommend Geometry Dash enough. It is an addicting, fun platform game that will push your platforming skills to the limit and provide hours of entertainment, and everyone should at least give it a try =)

Batman: Arkham Knight is a dense and enthralling action-adventure game with a winding, if predictable, story that does make you feel like the Batman both inside and outside the Batmobile. There are too many Batmobile gameplay segments, however, making this predominantly similar in theme to that Batmobile-focused Batman arcade game. This is unfortunate, as the presence of the Batmobile ensured a much larger, multi-layered Gotham City that looks wonderful and was crafted with an unnecessary level of detail. The combat and stealth are the same as before, but their adjustments and brevity keep the familiar Batman sections just different enough to feel new. As intended, the Batmobile is a nice change of pace, even if its numerous sections get old and nearly overstay their welcome. From start to finish, there is constantly something interesting to take in and someone interesting to take down, making Batman: Arkham Knight in the end a game worth playing.

I can't say I can reccomend this installment in the Civ franchise. Civ5 is an amazing and addictive experience, this one not so much. It's incomplete. The maps are crowded and boring with half as much resources as play than in the previous Civ. The tech tree, while being new and experimental, is confusing and messy. It just doesnt feel right and you have to mod it just to make it easier to follow. The rivaling civs are boring, it's easy to lose track of who is who because every civ is some boring no-name with some generic corporate acronym they are representing. I see that Firaxis is trying to do something 'realistic'...but it just comes off boring. Also there just isn't much to do in this game...until the expected expansions.  This is a problem with games nowadays, shipping incomplete games devoid of polish or satisfying content. The Sims and Civ are the biggest offenders here. Stop selling 45% of a game at full price, dumbasses.   3.5/10

By far one of the most memorable and underrated RPGs ive ever played. This game recieved mostly all negative reviews on release and was hated by most critics. I didn't know any of this before I saw in an EB Games and picked it up for a cheap price on disk.   Two Worlds is definitely a flawed game. The writing is ♥♥♥♥, with everyone speaking in the old style english language that sounds ridiculous and out of place. On top of the writing is the atrocious voice acting (which is funny). The starting game cutscene even features writing where a character repeats a Monty Pyton quote word for word which is farcical. The devs also decided to use laughable names for certain things in the game, for example calling some sort of plague 'The Taint'. Two Worlds was also riddled with bugs on release (patched with expansions in Epic Edition) which didn't help at all in the way of reviews. Looking past those issues though, Two Worlds is an enjoyable experience. Reviews on Youtube do great in making this game look like a laughfest of asinine writing and technical flaws, but besides those issues, the game at its core is an ambitious underachiever which still succeeds in providing to the player for the most part.   The main menu music was the first thing that stood out when I started the game, which complimented the pretty wonderful soundtrack. Two Worlds takes place in Antaloor, a mysterious and expansive setting that always kept me expecting more. I never felt like I was playing a walking simulator (even though the world is huge), nor did I feel like I was being attacked left and right. The game did nicely in striking a balance between a good amount of action and passive adventuring. Two Worlds also includes a multiplayer component, with PvP and Co-op. I never really played it though because the population was mostly Eastern European, so English was pretty rare. The combination of the two leaves a lot for the player to do. Questing, exploring, looting, messing around, and kicking ♥♥♥ is always an option. The cities are big and populated, and felt very lively. I personally was in love with the variety of awesome armor and weapons, which is what I liked the most.You can also choose how you want to play, throughout the entirety of the game. There are no preset classes or anything, so you can play however you want to. You can play melee the whole game, or be a hybrid archer mage warrior. How you choose to fight is only limited by what you have in your inventory and your skill levels. The combat system is also one of the few ive experienced that actually works. The targeting system is automated which can be troublesome but rarely is it actually. You can't always button mash to win though, since you can easily die, but its satisfying and rewarding. The combat is nothing innovative nowadays, but it works and its fun. I always looked forward to what kind of loot I would find. I would be ecstatic when I would find a new piece of armor that made my character look lawesome. The graphics for it's time were decent at best. Far distance rendered poorly and the textures and effects were pretty basic but taking into account how expansive the world is, with all the different types of environments, it was justified. The armors and weapons did have pretty intricate details though. Even if you had to game maxed out and ran at 60fps plus, it still looked choppy thanks to the animations. Hours can easily be lost in this game when you realize all that there is to do in the game world. If you really choose to, you can hate this game. Two Worlds has quirky dialogs, a poor storyline, weird people, terrible voice acting, questionable sound choices (attacking someone with a sword plays punching sounds?) and ugly animations. To me, these issues were relatively unimportant, which is why I enjoyed the game as much as I did. Two Worlds always had something that allowed me to forgive it for its issues.  So much in this game can be done in the way of customization and how you want to play. I still consider myself pretty lucky to have given this game a chance and I still remember experiences from 5+ years ago. To add, I can safely say I enjoyed this game just as much as any Elder Scrolls game, which seem to be the standard which any RPG is based on nowadays. Two Worlds lacks polish and is nowhere near perfect, but underneath all of the minor issues, is a gem. A gem of a game that is immensely underrated and misunderstood. Despite all you may read, this game is an immersive and rich experience that can leave you glued to your screen for hours. It's up to you to realize that not every game needs to be technically perfect, its how you appreciate it and your ability to see through the rough edges.

Before you begin reading note that most people here tested the game before it was even avaible for public, currently it's f2p and most bugs and issues have been fixed and no lag seems to affect the servers anymore, so forget about that, it's all good now, botters are also gone, Ave maria.  Cons: 1. The way I see it what matters is the experience itself and not the game's features, if you're looking for a good time with your friends, this might not be as fun as Ragnarok, and by that I mean, you don't get to stick to your friends, the questline will push you further and further into more missions rather than make you grind mobs in a group, eventually you will find yourself teleporting from map to map to complete your missions and so on, so forget about team work unless you're running a guild which is incredibly expensive or dungeons that you only get to do past level 50 twice a day.  2. If you like to play by the market and go full merchant shekelstein, go ahead, but not without premium, so forget your profit because you won't get any with a 30% tax and no currency trading or whatsoever, you can only trade items and with premium you get a 10% taxation on the market, which is still a great rip off in your profits, IMC crippled us good here.  3. Another problem you might find is leveling up, not that it's hard but you'll have a hard time figuring out when to use your exp cards and knowing what maps you should clear first, also, you must clear all maps and do all quests otherwise you stagnate late game and get stuck with no cards and no missions, you mustn't do them too late nor too early, otherwise you'll have hard time grinding less than 1% exp mobs, worst case scenario your equipment gets trashed and you are left broke with no money and no conditions to come back.  4. Unfortunately, aesthethical customization is an issue, you don't have many options besides your hair which you don't even get to choose the color, you'll have to grind mobs to get different colors, and hats are mostly either expensive and hard/impossible to get or they're so common everyone has them, very limited in my opinion, a waste for such a well detailed game. No visual diversity at all.  Pros: 1. Great characters, great animations and the music is simply amazing, it won't make your head ache and it synchronizes damn well with the map themes, the graphics are awesome and certainly drew most of the game base by it's aesthethic sense 10/10 for drawing efforts.  2. After the updates there is no lag and mostly no bugs, not sure if they fixed all classes but it's all good as far as I've gone through, the players in the brazilian server are quite friendly and will help you out, and most certainly will need your help in return sooner or later, goldsellers are unable to profit due to no silver trade and steam currency packs are now selected by server and will probably have different prices, so no more exploiting, no need to ♥♥♥♥ everyone equally like before, IMC disposes of a bad decision making team shame on them, but it's fixed for now, I hope.  3. The game simply offers you many features and builds, you'll find yourself immersed in your class, be it a full highlander glasscannon or a supporting hybrid tank heretic gypsie druid, althought some classes are useless as far as I'm concerned, you can ♥♥♥♥ up your character easily so don't go around doing stupid ♥♥♥♥ pretending to know what you're doing.  4. Just go and see for yourself, it's grindy but fun, everything about it is well done and the gameplay feels really great, the PvP is pretty fun too, the game is one of a kind, go check it out!

The good kind of Free 2 Play too none of that 'Free 2 play but if you spend money you're better than anyone else' BS. I wish there were a few more people playing PvP, but that's a personal gripe. I'll be honest: the first time i played this game, i hated it because the physics are terrible when compared with the original Sonic games. I don't know how anyone could screw this up. After a while, i got used to it, but this game really doesn't play like the originals. They aren't that bad, it's just that they were way better in the originals. Putting that aside, the game is filled with nostalgia, with recycling stages, enemies and bosses, but changed somewhat. The special stages are based on the original Sonic, and you can unlock Super Sonic which plays much better that the standard one. There's 4 stages with 3 acts and a boss each, plus a final boss. There's also leaderboards (the score attack is kinda useless) and achievements. The graphics are just okay and the music passable. To sum it up, if you can overlook the physics, this is a decent Sonic game, just not one of the good ones.

Just Cause 2 is an open world blow'm-up simulator in the same vein as a Grand Theft Auto or Saint's Row; half the fun is messing with the physics of the world.  The major success of Just Cause is that it gives players the tools to explore the world to its fullest extent. Your character's grappling hook is the most obvious of these, giving you the ability to traverse terrain at high speed, rope in enemies, or tie objects together. With a little imagination, it's the best thing since the Gravity Gun of Half Life 2... and both can be used to overturn vehicles!  Furthermore, the protagonist is rather agile in his ability to manoever. While his ability to safely hop on top of a moving, swerving car makes little sense, it also makes him able to do fun things... like throwing delicious explosives at pursuers. He can ride anything, grab on to anything, and jump anywhere, and it results in a very liberating experience once you get the hang of 'the rules' of these manoevering abilities.  As a car-jacking game, there are a TON of vehicles, and excuses to use them. Even when you acquire air travel and fast travel, there are many reasons why you'd use land vehicles; either they're more practical for quick getaways, have weapons attached, or you just want to ride on an occupied vehicle to keep your hands free to blow things up.  There are only two minor downsides to this game. First, the story; it takes itself a bit too seriously for a game where you can tie someone to a jet as its taking off, and it doesn't relax its tone until the end. Second, this game lacks the ability for multiplayer - yes, there is an awesome multiplayer mod, but it's pure free-roam and without NPCs; the game proper does not support multiplayer when it feels like it should (having one player driving, another car-surfing, and another para-gliding would be an awesome way to make a getaway).  However, these flaws are minor; the gameplay is satisfying, the world is gorgeous, and the price is right. Heck, the price may even be too low; Steam Sales have pitched this game as low as $2 when it is easily worth much more. Unless you really don't like gunplay and violence, this game is an absolute blast and recommended for anyone looking for some creative destruction.

I thought you would be playing the hero that ends up saving the day, but in the end it apears that i was the villian the whole time. The campaign is only about 4 to 5 hours long, but that is as long as it needs to be. Even thought this game is 4 years old I still think people should play it, especially those who love a story that will captivate you.

-Personal opinion of an truck enthusiast  A very amazing driving-simulator game. 7 different truck brands (some brands can offer you more truck models), enable you to relax and drive across the central part of Europe. With map-expansions, the world map gets even bigger. At the moment, Scandinavia and Eastern Europe map expansion is available for you. Of course, there are several other DLCs, such as paintjobs and trailer packs.   I play this kind of simulation for 5 years now. I am sure, games made from SCS software can never disappoint you, but everyone gets tired of games, especially if they are ''only'' singleplayer. In this case, the official Euro truck simulator 2 Multiplayer  http://truckersmp.com/en_US  can help you. Good community, fair staff and lots of truck enthusiast play here every day. Lots of different servers available!   So, in my general opinion this game deserves more than one cookie...Some pros and cons:  Pros: -Very big map, so the game can't be completed in 1 month at all, if you play normally -7 truck brands, all of them got original names -Truck tuning for those who want to get their truck ''famous'' on the roads -Realistic envirionment, AI traffic (sometimes just n00b), trailers and companies -Some jobs take more than 2 hours :)  Cons: After a long time of playing, you realise that the map is too small...  (19/10) - Would buy at any time again!!!!!

I'll skip the intro:  Pros:  + It is absolutely gorgeous + The visual style is unique, however similar it may be to Team Fortress 2 + Atmosphere is fantastic all the time, from morning to dusk, from a sunny day to night on fire + Hank and Delilah seemed like real human beings and not just plot-movers, thanks to dialoge writing and the voice actors + Overall plot had me interested + Music was well-produced + Audio was mixed pretty great  Cons:  - Pacing is non-existent - Hair-thin plotline - A lack of nature... in nature, where there should be at least some critters - Gameplay is ultimately shallow for a pretty large game world - Game world is ultimately a lot of corridors - A lack of exploration - Extremely short, between 3 and 5 hours (you might be able to get 7 hours, but that would be very difficult) - The game ends just when it starts to get legs - The game world might appear vast with nature, but it feels claustrophobic and dry  A fantastic job to the dev for having the dedication to put out this game, and it truly beautiful. Yet, it lacks substance, though. It blows my mind that the demo with the two bathing girls and their stereo, which was shown a long time ago, was a good percentage of the game.   Firewatch felt a bit like Gone Home: the same amount of substance, but put into a much larger room.  I think if we could craft our own stories in the world, through mod-tools, this game might actually have some legs. But the world is too small even to consider that a possibility.  Really big bummer. I had some fun and I enjoyed all the sights, but I'm very disapppointed that this game was only ankle-deep. It's unfortunate even I (who loved Gone Home) can't recommend picking this game up at any more than $10.

This is about the only multiplayer game I play these days. As an MMO, you can level up your abilities and fight in large-scale battles. As an FPS, you can drop in an out at will without causing certain death of your comrades. The game supports a huge variety of play styles, with multiple player classes and the ability to both pilot and co-pilot both land and air vehicles (I've always loved the idea of being a gunner on a vehicle that someone else is driving, and this game does a good job of implementing that).  Of course the main downside is that as a free-to-play game it waves microtransaction opportunities around in your face. Fortunately most of them are cosmetic, so it's not straight-up pay-to-win. Even given the fact that many people will outlevel you even just through regular grinding, there is still plenty of opportunity for any player to get kills via skill and/or luck, to help with strategic objectives such as capturing points, and to provide team support in the form of repairs, ammo, healing/reviving, etc.  Another negative aspect of the game is that when playing via a casual drop-in/drop-out style, it can be hard to find a group that isn't just screwing around. The game makes it easy to join groups of players, but it seems like at least 3/4 of the time there's no point because everyone is scattered all over the place and nobody is in charge.

Take part Mass Effect, part Halo, and throw in a dash of Star Wars and you get Advent Rising. This is the utmost praise, however, as Advent Rising is a fantastic game. It is clear that Mass Effect borrowed heavily from this game as the Geth seem to be ripped straight from it. The fiction behind the story is some of the most engrossing sci-fi I've seen in a while, which is no surprise since it was written by Orson Scott Card.  The gameplay is third-person, with the use of guns and special powers. The guns do feel really nice, but I found myself using the powers more often, especially in the later game. The level design is superb as well, and I never felt lost, even in some of the bigger environments.  The game is not without it's faults, however. Consulting   PC Gaming Wiki   [pcgamingwiki.com]  is a must for essential fixes, but I still had a fair number of issues. There were graphic anomalies when things got intense and there were lots of explosions. cutscenes would sometimes hicup as well, although the dialogue did not skip. The most annoying thing were the game crashes which happened a handful of times. Thankfully, the game saved at the exact point of the crash so nothing was lost, but still annoying.  Iffy port aside, this game is fantastic. It really is a shame we will probably never see the planned sequels as this game builds a very promising lore and world around it. It's certainly worth playing, just know that it will probably never get a proper finale.

If you enjoyed previous Assassin's Creed games, you'll probably enjoy this one just as much. But be warned: the rumors are true, the game is a little buggy, and the framerates drag from time to time, even with a brand new beast like a GTX 970.   You'll find the same things in this game, that have drawn you to other games in the series. Lots of free running, lots of sneaking around, and lots of side quests; additionally, they brought back the idea of giving you an objective, and letting you accomplish it how you see fit, be that via brute force, stealth, or by taking advantage of numerous distraction opportunities. I'm not sure how anyone else has reacted, but the co-op is quite a bit of fun as well...It's something that this game series should have had a long time ago, in my opinion. The graphics are also pretty fantastic in this new installment.  Take this for what it's worth. I'm enjoying the game, but am disappointed with it's less than stellar release, however I am contented waiting for further updates. If that doesn't sound like your cup of tea, I recommend passing on this one, and maybe grabbing on sale in several months when more issues have been worked out. I'll be honest, Ubisoft kind of pisses me off, but I'm glad they have been sticking with it so far, and continue to release update patches.  All in all, given that I love this game series, I'll give it a recommendation.

So that feature is really only half done at best. To impliment this feature they stripped away the absolute best feature of the game. TWO HEADED GIANT has been removed. This feature is literally the make or break on a game like this. Without TWO HEADED GIANT there is no reason for anyone to return and play after unlocking and making a few playable decks. The free for all online is boring at best and the overall tone of the game is under whelming. In my world, Legend Of Grimrock would be called 'The reincarnation of Eye Of The Beholder', or something of the sort, as I have really good memories of the first Eye Of The Beholder game from the early 1990s (although I never beat it), and Legend Of Grimrock looks just like it. Just recently I realized Eye Of The Beholder itself was a reincarnation (or what some people would call 'a clone' or 'a ripoff') of a similar game called 'Dungeon Master' from the 1980s (which I've never heard of until recently), but 'nuff said about that.  Back to Legend Of Grimrock -  The game is a first person dungeon crawling Action/RPG. You play a group of 4 adventurers (aka convicted criminals, but nevermind about that :P), whose goal is to survive the dungeon by means of solving puzzles and fighting monsters while staying alive in the process.   The default party consists of two fighters (one human, one minotaur), one wizard and one rogue, set in a fixed formation of two rows - two characters in front, two more behind them. You can choose which character to place where and change it while playing, but you can't change the formation. The idea is that the two front characters use melee attacks, while the other two need to attack from long range (either magic, throwing weapons such as knives, or missile weapons such as bows).  Up until now (8-10 hours ingame), I'm really having fun. Technically, everything looks and feels good. There's nothing overwhelming about the graphics or the music, but they are definitely good enough. Come to think of it, there's hardly any music ingame, and I think it's a really good idea. The lack of music makes the game feel more realistic, and it lets you pay the worthy attention to the sound effects, which just like with Eye Of The Beholder, play an important role, as they serve as warning signs from certain enemies. The controls are simple and intuitive (left click to move items, right click to attack when it comes to battles). Some of the puzzles are very easy, others are more difficult. I did find it necessary to look for help online in a couple of incidents so far, but I did manage to solve most of the puzzles myself (up to where I am at the moment, can't say anything about the puzzles I haven't reached yet).   All in all, this game is fun. If you like dungeon crawlers, get it. It might not be a masterpiece, but it is fun to play.

DO NOT BUY, UNLESS YOU'RE WILLING TO KEEP PAYING SEGA AND CA FOR CONTENT  Just a week after release, they decide to release yet another DLC. The second one, since release. You only get half the game for 40 euro, so be awere - you'll have to pay yet another 15 euros to get the rest of the content, that should be in the game at release.  That said, amazing game - Love raiding the damned British people, or turn Rome to a pile of ashes with my armies. Combat has gotten alot of fun, and seem alot more dynamic. Theres alot of micro mangement, and you always gotta keep an eye on your cavelry and flanks now - which is awesome!  The campain map is at times dull, but the diffculity of the game is awesome! I usely play at very hard or legendary, but had to play at hard, just to survive the first 50 turns. If you don't watch your back, thoose damn vikings are gonna tear your empire apart and sail away, before you can even turn your armies around!  I would have rated this game with a positive review, if it hadn't been for CA and Sega's buisness strategy. Forcing people to pay 40 euros for a game is fair. But it's not fair if you release 2 DLC's within a week of release, for 'Just another 15 euro'. I would gladly have payed 55 euros for this game, if i knew that i would get the entire game! But these sneaky releases are just some bull, to force every fan out there to spend more money! That is the reason why I'm not giving a positive review.

After seeing all the negitive reviews I decided to review it myself. Most negitive reviews circle around the fact that the NPCs were OP, with top-of-the-line Engineer upgrades. If you read the recent changes and patch notes, you will see that NPCs have been stripped of their Engineering OP-ness. So that's been taken care of :P  Gameplay can go from a very relaxed delivery, to a hectic battle in a matter of seconds. There is always something to do, even if its just exploring. It's also incredibly fulfilling to buy your own ship and customize it. Not to mention the game is beautiful, and can run on medium graphics cards well.   Pros: Relaxing gameplay (if you want it) Exciting gameplay (again, if you want it) Beautiful ship interiors Lovely fighting Massive scale Simulated trade markets VR support (God, I want a headset)  Cons: Always online DRM, even in solo play (Grrrrr) The galaxy map is cluttered, makes it hard to see the proximity of closer systems Controls need to be HEAVILY customized, the default layout sucks (unless you have 34 fingers) It doesn't NEED a joystick (i've got many hours on m&k) but it really deserves it (I suggest the cyborg V.1 if you like E:D, its only $20) The launcher stays open when the game boots (I hate game that do that)

You emerge from the womb presented with three dialog options. We’re not talking ‘red blue or green’ and we’re certainly not talking ‘attack defend or route.’ Your choices are some meandering fancy like “scoop up slime, hold your breath, or call for help.” Welcome to Monster Loves You, where dialog choices comprise the whole of the gameplay. Revel in stat bonuses for choosing the right option —it’s always the right option— and accrue new dialog choices based on your newfound stats. But watch out! Don’t get enough stats —it’s never enough— and you will unknowingly close yourself off from other dialog options.  If you think that choosing an option is actual gameplay, this is the game for you! It’s like Final Fantasy X’s combat with none of the consequences or combat. If you want to be mentally stimulated then this is not the Cart Life for you. I think this game is actually for kids. Like the literal kind of children, not the autismal man kind. Cute 4 girls but you know what? Girls want to play a video game. You know casual appeal of Bejewel and Peggel where you choose a touch and stuff goes? In Monster Loves You there is choose a touch but then you just choose more and more touch. Monster does not even love you until late-game.   Has: - Artistic Direction - Be your own monster! - Touch or mouse. It’s all good.  Lacks: - Gameplay Element (really dropped the ball on this one) - Animation - Sokoban Block Puzzle  Winblows 8 Touch Screen Bonus - You are not an iPad!  2 / 10 Boring as a generous bag of wet nails. What kind of monster will you roll? Care enough to continue playing to find out!  -- Cosmopolitan  0 / 0 'This game doesn’t have any GUTS!!!' --Shounen Jump “We give it a Three..... “ --X-Play Adam Sessler 3/10 “Scrub ♥♥♥ game for indie nooblords.” -- IGN 9/10 “Fun for ages 10 and down” --Fisher-Price 2 inches 'Throw ‘er back in!” --Bait & Tackle

app_name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
review_text: Brothers has a simple story to tell, and, in a few spaces, that story could use a little work – but more importantly, it employs a core gameplay mechanic that flawlessly mirrors the core themes of that story, creating a powerful gameplay metaphor that embeds the player in the story more effectively, perhaps, than any linear-narrative game I have ever played before. Aided by an impeccable aesthetic design that shifts effortlessly between the adorable, the breathtaking and the horrifying, and perfect pacing and duration for it's purpose, Brothers more than overcomes its flaws.

If you've been looking for a good looking 'graphical DF' - Look no further. Banished is a deep and rewarding experience that can feel either zen-like, and at some times, extremely stressful. You will (try to) keep your citizens, well-fed, happy, healthy and live a productive life in general. Banished is actually one of the few 'civilization management' games that i've actually felt attatched to the characters. They're born, go to school and work their lives away at trying to further their civilization only to end up dying in the end...BUT, their children and their childrens children will carry on and that's something that really strikes me with this game. Seriously though, it's an incredible experience, and it was all crafted at the fingertips of one man. This man deserves every penny he makes. 10/10 - A Must Buy

Even worse than AirLand battle. The AI still relies on spam and rushes. The AI still gets several times as many points as you have. The AI is omnipotent. Multi-ton tanks can drive up 90 degree slopes faster than I could climb them. Naval combat (the 'big' feautre of this game) is a blob-fest with no tactics whatsoever. Your units still have absolutly no common sense. Units move stupidly close to enemies when out of thier primary ammo (such as a helo that is out of ATGMs or an artillery piece that is out of long range shells) and promptly get killed (rather than staying put.) Radar guided AA autocannos and IR missiles are unaffected by ECM (a plane's only defense aganst AA.) Artillery firing from 20+KM is more accurate than a sniper rifle. The deck system has been entirely f---ed up. (I can only call in five cards of a unit catagory at a high price compared to ALB.) Most units are entirely useless compared to thier alternatives. This game is still micro-intensive. Mountains (and all the rocks on them) no longer block LOS. Open fields can sometimes block LOS. The AI has an 'everything' deck. Where as we would have to choose either no bonus or a bonus specific to a deck type, the AI can have an Armored, motorized, mechanized, airborne, marine, support, naval deck with all of the same bonus (and much higher unit avaliability) as you can with a specialized deck.  Its every bad thing about ALB and then some. I've only seen two improvements: AI now includes a varying unit composition with its spam (i.e. AA with its armor) There are a few hundred new units.  This game is not even worth the $10 I paid for it while it was on sale, nevermind $40 if it was not.  Edit: add naval to the list as well. REDFOR is still OP. Its even worse if you're playing against the AI. The first mission in one of the campaign basically places you in a hopeless situation. It seems like the ♥♥♥♥ers that built this don't understand a damn thing about 'balance.'

7/10  The Good: Just as The Walking Dead, this game is a point and click adventure. The story is interesting, entertaining and morally ambigious. It is how the player reacts to the moral questions that decides where the story is going.   The Bad: One of the biggest shortcomings of this game is its limited interactivity. Sometimes you seemingly just listen to conversations and watch events unfold for minutes at a time, without having the chance to effect change. Worse, even when given the chance to make a choice, it is often only cosmetic. The other problem I had were the numerous quick time events, they felt simplistic, and a contrived way to create tension.  The Verdict:  The story and moral choices are what makes this game entertaining. Though the game struggles to offer meaningful interactivity in many situations, and is a tad heavy on the quick time events. I hope Tell Tale Games can look to their excellent Walking Dead Season I to improve upon that in the next season for Wolf Among Us. Don't think its worth the full price, but definitely worth a consideration when it is on sale.

Many people will detest the new direction the franchise has taken, but just as many will appreciate it. One thing is certain though - this game is better at being Tomb Raider than Hitman Absolution was at being Hitman.  Great graphics, great optimization (no surprise given that Nixxes ported it), and the plot is a lot more interesting this time, though still very predictable. The new Lara is a much more likable character though!  There are genuine shooting mechanics this time, which will please some and anger others. But the signature platforming elements remain uncompromised, as do the accompanying puzzles.   For the purists: Unlike in Hitman Absolution, the 'instinct' mode can be almost completely ignored for the whole game and there aren't any sections that are downright unplayable without using instinct.
If you don't buy this, especially when it is on sale, WHAT THE HELL IS WRONG WITH YOU!

Recommended, ONLY if you can get at a significant discount. I personally rate this in the $5-$7 bin. That said, it's a wonderful little game.  Minecraft-style survival paired with an underwater world that looks REALLY good. The atmosphere is the best part of this game. Near the surface, shafts of light shining through, manta rays and fish swim by, Go down deeper, the dangerous fish come out, go to the deepest depths, vibrant phosphorescent colors shine and all sorts of weird creatures abound.   The main 'adventure' mode is short, took me 2 hours to complete (and could have done it faster)   If you want a relaxing (well, till there's a kraken attack on your base) atmospheric exploration game, this is it. Worth a try if you can pick up on sale.

I really hate to write a negative review, But at it's current price, I connot recommend this game. The graphics are not as good as they are in the video, and I have a very high-end PC. The NASCARs are not licensed, and therefore have been changed, and look like kids toys (Not a good thing) The cars are difficult to drive, and spin whenever you go near the throttle, and the crash graphics are the worst I've seen in a car game for a long time  Dont get me wrong, this game has done some things right-The car and track selection range is pretty big, and there are mods out there (Although the community is not very active) And when you do manage to get them moving, the cars handle very realistically.  Overall, If this game was a lot cheaper, it would be amazing, but I am disappointed that I paid $44 Australian for this, and it did not meet expectations. I am going to reccomend this game, because I trust that it is better than it seems at first, And will change this review if I can get some assitance.  Rating-  Physics-7/10 Range-9/10 Crash graphics-There isnt a low enough number AI-8/10 Price-2/10   EDIT: I have just discovered the workshop, and will update this review based on the content I find there.

Thankfully this is a rather short RPG because I don't see how anyone could tolerate it much longer than that. Pretty much every dungeon is exactly the same, big sprawling maze with random encounters and the occasional chest. The hardest thing about the game is finding the next level of the dungeon, really. Mobs generally aren't too tough and it's easy to be overpowered in this game. The bosses are kind of a joke; even the final boss took practically no effort at all. The story kind of stops caring about a quarter of the way through the game and there's no sense of atmosphere at all. It's not even that f funny, either. There's some jokes but they're far too infrequent for it to really be a comedy game. The last dungeon has a big difficulty spike which is a bit unwarranted but even then, hopping into an optional dungeon and then back into the last dungeon basically destroyed all the challenge I was having. It's just... bland. I don't like RPGs in general and only got this in a bundle, and it was short enough for me to not get bored of it, at least. I wouldn't call it 'bad' for what it is, but I certainly can't say it blew me away or anything.

I don't usually like indie games, nor am I a fan of strategy for the most part. This is an exception. It's strangely charming. The soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful--enough so to warrant me downloading it from the Humble Bundle a while back. The visuals are serviceable, and absolutely do not detract from the experience at all; in fact, it adds to the feel of the game. This game is such an exception to what I normally like: amazing visuals and a mind-blowing experience. Faster Than Light is a different breed, and it's so good it's hard to dislike.   The gameplay is actually easy to pick up. People everywhere have always said that this is a hard game. It is and that's not a lie. However, the learning curve is quick. Just do the tutorial and you'll have it down. I'm not a particularly good player either. Really, if you're worried about the difficulty--don't. It'll make you miss out on the rest of the game.  It's primarily about light RPG elements and micromanaging your crew and ship while fleeing the Rebel fleet and finding, and fighting, friends and foes along the way. As far as I can tell, each game is randomly generated. This makes for a new experience every time. Loot is an important factor, as is upgrading and maintaining your ship. It's a very simple system, but full of difficult choices. It manages not to be overwhelming but still have some depth.   Overall, this is easily one of my favorite games. I have a very busy schedule, so I have to pick up and play for a little bit at a time, but it does have the depth to play for a long time straight.

Good game. A F2P action RPG with a great backstory and soundtrack. The steam transactions are for cosmetics only, so it's not a P2W in any way.  PoE has an enormous passive skill tree, so you can build your character in many different ways. For active skills you will have to drop some gems from the mobs and level them up. There are lots of items as well [LOOT! lots of LOOT!], many different weapons/equipments and their rarities, including unique kind items. You can also use orbs to customize your items.  PVP works fine. Lots of quests. Beating PoE on normal difficulty feels like a basics tutorial once you enter the other op levels, the game gets a lot harder by the Cruel and Merciless. It took me a while to slay Simi, the mo♥♥fu♥ing monkey.  {http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=286665871}  Dying repeatedly was 'fine' since i wasn't on the hardcore league (death=delete).  I haven't played Diablo3 yet (there's a lot of discussion involving these 2 games), but even though D3 graphics are probably a bit better, this game seems good as well. It's definitely worth a try.  I had a few desync problems, and it used to get worse when in party. But then i found out about this command /ccs which is a way to manually sync with the server, and some info about the desync here:  https://www.pathofexile.com/forum/view-thread/710359   Their support is really good, if you ever need help in PoE issues don't hesitate to contact them. The forum is also always there for you:  http://www.pathofexile.com/forum   There's also a twitch stream feature, but i haven't tested it yet.  8/10

I would give Wargame: Red Dragon 9/10, 8 for the overall playing experience, and 1 for the superb support and constant maintanence to this game provided by Eugen.  I am no stranger to the RTS franchises and I must say that Wargame: Red Dragon has one of the harder learning curves of its rank. With about 150 hours of playing, I still don't have a firm grip of the intricate parts of the gameplays and mechanics. Though Wargame: Red Dragon is an impressive game overall, it is difficult for the new players to become the part of the active community due to its time consuming learning curve.  This is the first Wargame franchise I have played and I found lack of guidance in early experience of the game. It is necessary for the new player to spend hours on solo campaign/skirmish without much guidance to try and feel the every bits of the game. Also the overwhelming amounts of information in deck building/armory panel did not help in simplifying the experience.  As for the playing experience, Wargame: Red Dragon has many immersive battlefield system such as terrain, morale, logistics, garrisons, flying altitude, stealth/reconaissance that will keep you well occupied through the match. Each engagement requires careful examination and preparational positioning and only then, will you can gain the upperhand advantage.  If Eugen gives more friendly guidance for newcomers, I know many more players will be hooked on Wargame: Red Dragon rather than 'veteran players' from previeous franchises dominating the community. As of now, in my opinion, Wargame: Red Dragon is mostly dependent on its hardcore fan base to keep it a relevant community.  Thanks for reading.

“If there were no gods, it would have been necessary to create them.”    Pillars of Eternity is an isometric role-playing game (rpg) developed by the company Obsidian Entertainment with emphasis on tactical combat.     Atmosphere & presentation:    + Vast and mature fantasy world with great love for detail. + Excellent background music enriches the atmosphere.  + Additional game mechanics, like the bounty hunter missions and castle construction, create a welcome diversion to the mundane tasks of an adventurer.  + The extension White March increases level cap and delivers additional characters, equipment and side story elements. + Clean user interface and good inventory management.  + Great replay value.   o The different factions are interesting in the beginning, but their general involvement with the player is rather small.  o Satisfying execution of almost every aspect of the game, due to several patches.    Combat & gameplay:    + The ability to approach a potential combat situation in multiple ways is well balanced in the game.  + Transparent combat mechanics allow the player to understand each encounter.  + Implementation of a dynamic difficulty system provides rpg newcomers, veterans and masochists with a satisfying challenge. + Impressive customization system allows for extensive weapon and armor modifications. + Broad spectrum of skills offers good character development. + Lower spells remain efficient on higher levels.   o Party size is limited to a maximum of six characters. o The player can decide to travel alongside a companion party or custom party.     Characters & story:    + The main plot is complex and multi-layered.  + Well written dialogues and narrative. + Very good voice acting of all characters. + Certain quests offer several ways to complete them. + Dialogues and events can be solved by an attribute or skill check.  + Major decisions of the player are reflected in the end sequence of the game.   o While some characters are interesting and provide an authentic development, others remain immature lacking depth.  o Not all dialogues with non-player characters are synchronized.  o The protagonist cannot start a romance.   - Any character class can learn to pick locks and disarm traps, which diminishes the attractiveness of the rogue class. - The creation of a multi-class character is not possible.    Summary:    Overall, Pillars of Eternity offers high-quality content and sophisticated gameplay. The world is fantastically immersive, and represents a wonderful role-playing experience.     Amusing quotes:      “Let’s try this again: Step aside or die chocking on your own innards.”      “What kind of coward asks for his own man to be killed? The kind who will be so enraged by it, that no amount of pain will stop him from beating you so savagely, that you will carry the disfigurement into your next life.”      Trivia:    NPCs with gold name plates were designed by the backers. Interacting with them will allow you to experience each one’s unique history.    Achievements:    Estimated time for 100 % completion: +200 hours  Singleplayer achievements: 48 Multiplayer achievements: none

For those in trouble in getting the game running (like me and others) : **no menu visible **no 16/9 full screen mode **low resolutions **car can not drive backwards  It took me some time in browsing forums, but it comes to this in a nutshell. Salvation is found in these two mods : 1) SilentPatchIII 1.1 Build 5 2) SP DDraw for GTA III/VC Build 4  -->unpack and install them in your steam folder 'GTA3' and game will run like a charm on windows 10.  Bravo to the modders, bad points for Rock Star.  And last but not least, this setting is also required in the menu : Options - Display - Frame limiter - 'on' When it is set on 'off', the car physics are weird, even some cars can not drive backwards.  You are ready to step into vintage gaming and playing the game that is the founding 3D-father to all later sequels of GTA and games like Mafia, Just Cause, Saint Rows, Saboteur (not on steam) and yes, even assassin's creed

From the looks of it, whether the game will open at all or run at playable state is hit or miss. My mid range pc plays it alright and I havent noticed anything major with it but I've seen people with high end rigs saying that it wont work That being said its a really enjoyable game. Theres also the added challange of civilians mixed in some areas which adds a lot of depth. The new characters are interesting and well designed. Overall its just enjoyable and I hope it doesnt wear out with more gameplay  tl;dr - Good game, hit or miss whether it will run well/at all
