If you like indie games, super replayability, random generation to the max (weapon state, level, storyline order), dark often scary levels, and if you like games that you can master reciever is here to fill that empty spot in your stomach.   If you don't like shooting boring robots and turrents then you'll be like me. In between this game.   I love having only so many clips and even fewer bullets. Shooting and keeping track of how many bullets i have left. Scavaging the apartment rooms, sinks, toilets, and sometimes couch cushions for ammo. I love the feel of the game that i still am not completely sure what is going on and the story is literally given in a random order each time with few details leaving me with piecing it together gaining constant Ah Hah moments when i've achieved a fact! This game definately hits home with things i want in my game. Innovation on FPS, replayability, and i can play quick session, or long rides. I do only wish that i was not fighting robots and turrents. The literal most boring of enemies!   Its a dark, lifeless, seperated world, cloaked in mystery! Why can't i face demons, or Mr. Smiths or something. Oh well, that is my one complaint and that should not turn you away! Hope you escape this dreamlike world with the knowledge of the reciever!

Great ARPG along the lines of Diablo II, no hand holding going on here!  Path of Exile deposits you in Wraeclast, with nothing but your wits and a starter weapon to survive with. As you kill enemies and complete quests, your power grows through skill gems and passives. This is all fairly normal for the genre. PoE takes a major departure though by not locking anything to classes. Want a waifish witch wielding a warhammer in warplate? Go for it!  The other exciting part of PoE is the race leagues. These are series of timed events, started with fresh characters in a permadeath setting. Various items are available for points earned when competing and surviving these events.  Finally, Path of Exile is free to play, and not pay-to-win. The only for-pay option which effects gameplay is exxpansion of the shared stash, all other microtransactions are cosmetic only.  All in all, Path of Exile is a great game, whether you want something to pick up every now and again, or to play hardcore in the race leagues and go for glory.

Probably one of the best open-world style games I've ever played. The only better one I can think of is GTA: San Andreas. The story line of this game is stellar. Awesome combat style. I definitely recommend using a USB controller (Xbox) for easier controls. The only flaw I could think of is, the biggest issue is with its camera. The camera often repositions itself towards center even when you’re using the analog stick to maneuver it while driving. This can significantly complicate navigating tight quarters or getting a look around your vehicle in open spaces. The camera can also be frustrating in some combat situations, though this is far less pronounced. It's not a major flaw, but it's still worth mentioning. I would rate this game, overall, a 9.5/10

What to say about this game... There's a lot. There were moments of fun, awe, frustration, shock, horror, and even a bit of arousal in the haunted halls of the once great underwater city of Rapture. You start the game as the only survivor of a plane crash, and make your way to a lighthouse. What happens from there is about 10-15 hours (depending on how you play games like these) of exploring a mysterious abanndoned city that's definitely seen better days. Thrust into this land with no knowledge of anything about it, the first scene has you witness a brutal murder by a hyper-mutated freak, a 'splicer'. Your only help is a voice named 'Atlas' through a radio, who's goal is to help you and himself get out of the city alive. Full of twists and turns, a great atmosphere that is CONSTANTLY reminding you that you are in fact underwater, plus, you get to shoot bees out of your hand. There are some problems, and I'm not sure if it's just how the game is or if it's my computer, but at points the game will lag for absurd amounts of time, usually when you're about to hack something, and that can disrupt the flow of action... a lot. Other than that and a bit of a punishing difficulty curve, this game is now one of my favorites and I can't wait to continue the series.  Overall score: 9.3/10, would return to Rapture (and will).

As many people have said, if you look at the disrecommendations, this game is very easy and boring. However, what those people fail to realize is that, they didn't try hard enough. This game is so boring and simple if you just run through, grab the objectives, and dodge bullets. Now, on the other hand, if you actually go for the achievements, try sneaking through undetected, getting every coin, and not dying, it quickly becomes very difficult and fun. Several people have stated it lacks challenge and strategizing, but that's probably because they played the first levels designed for newcomers, and didn't even try to do good. My friend and I played through the entire game, getting every trophy and achievement, including a hidden one, and it was not easy at several points. For example, in one level, guards spawn every 20 seconds, and form giant conga lines of destruction. Now try sneaking past their unpredictable routes into a guarded room, knocking out the guards without getting seen, so that you can hack a computer and hope that everything works out to let you get through the other 2 rooms, past some lasers, and giving you enough time to grab the cash and get out. My friend and I got rather good at the game and it took us about 30 tries to get lucky on that level. This game has tons of gameplay, and even more replayability with the many character combinations and strategies you can use on each level. I highly recommend this game to anyone.

I never played the other Devil May Cry games, so this obviously colors my perspective. However, the fanbase of DMC seems rather Japanophilic (and I'm a Silent Hill fan so I know what this affliction can do to fanbases). 'IT ISN'T JAPANEEEZ THEREFORE IT SUCKS' is both terrible logic and the sign of someone trying to feign being educated and sophisticated.  That aside, the plot has some good ideas (the idea of 'Limbo' and the like seems inspired by tabletop RPGs like Kult) although its social/political/economic commentary is about as deep as the kiddie pool. The cliche pseudo-Marxism has me rolling my eyes.  But what makes this game good?  The gameplay is FUN. Seriously, the combat is incredibly fun and fluid and fast. It has depth and variety and tactics yet manages to not be too arcane, the movements and animation are stylish and awesome, and stringing together combos and the like is just a blast. DmC just provides pure flowing hack-n-slash joy.  Also, the visual design is striking.   And the music. Oh man the music suits the game perfectly and totally indulges the rebellious spirit. Its awesome.  So, whether its a 'good DMC game' is something I cannot comment on. Is it a good game? Oh hell yes.  PROS: + Awesome, fun fighting with a good balance of depth and accessibility + Stylish, striking visual design and art direction + Killer soundtack  CONS: - The social commentary can come off as pseudointellectual trash that Fails Economics FOREVER  OVERALL: Turn off the brain. This game is all about fun combat, fun music and awesome aesthetics. And it delivers in spades. And I'd REALLY like the developer to sell replicas of Virgil's coat.

Pros:  -Immersive sky battles -Great Graphics -Good Controls -Good player-base  Cons:  -If you want to do good, you have to fork over a lot of money to the devs -Boring tank battles -No Story -Hackers -Poor balancing    Verdict  With amazing visuals, large scale battles, and fun dogfights, this game may seem like the best free to play game. But it is no where near free, battles bring in little currency, costing you real life money. With-out a story and with unbalanced multiplayer, this game is fun for the first 5 hours, but declines from there.  4/10 - Bad If you have interest in this game, look away. If you want a game that is somewhat like this one, look into the Battlefield series.

Actual Sunlight follows Evan Winters, a man who is in the midst of one hardcore existential crisis. I don't think I'd be wrong to say that much of society today are facing similar feelings and thoughts as Evan. I have read articles on many kids and young adults that are dealing with depression and suicidal ideation and unfortunately, too many go through with it. So I know this game will hit too close to home for many who give it a shot. It's not so much a game, however, as a character study. What you take from it I would assume is how much you can relate yourself to the protagonist. If you are the literal equivalency of your facebook profile I can only imagine that you would find this game to be a nonsensical story with a whiny main character. If that's what you take from it: congratulations. Your life is perfect. However, if recent stories on rising depression and suicide rates are any indication then you would be in a miniscule percentage of the human populace. That is why I think this game is important. Sure, we're making strides on 'anti-bullying' campaigns but nobody is really touching these issues.   For kids in school with 'no friends' and teenagers transitions into adulthood who are now getting socked in the head with their first existential crisis, and for all of those soon-to-be thirty somethings who feel like they've wasted their lives, I implore you, the next time something nice happens in your life take it in stride. Much of life is unhappiness. But those little things are what keep us going. Sure, you may die alone and depressed, but what about all of those great games you've played? What about that totally sweet thing you did the other day that totally mattered to you?  When you play this game remember that it is not you. It's a character study and a damn good one. I wouldn't exactly call it 'art' but I would certainly say it's important. It does what creative writing majors are taught never to do and that's to make your protagonist way too ♥♥♥♥ing depressed. This game makes it work and makes it worth playing.

When EarthBound was released in 1995, it didn't sell well, the graphics were seen as kinda jarring, and overall people thought it was really weird, but it gained a cult following and eventually people realized how good it was.  Since LISA's been released in 2014, it hasn't been selling well, a lot of bigger reviewers seem to think the graphics are 'unpolished', and overall seem to think it's really weird, but it's got a good cult following, and hopefully you'll realize how good it is.  Basically, IMO, LISA does everything today that EarthBound did in its day, including being a damn solid RPG that you should buy right now.

I couldnt decide what to write in this review , so im gonna share with you guys my favorite apple pie recipe Enjoy! :  Pastry  2 cups all-purpose flour   1 teaspoon salt   2/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons shortening   4 to 6 tablespoons cold water   Filling  1/3 to 1/2 cup sugar   1/4 cup all-purpose flour   1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon   1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg   1/8 teaspoon salt   8 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples (8 medium)   2 tablespoons butter or margarine   1) In medium bowl, mix 2 cups flour and 1 teaspoon salt. Cut in shortening, using pastry blender (or pulling 2 table knives through ingredients in opposite directions), until particles are size of small peas. Sprinkle with cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all flour is moistened and pastry almost cleans side of bowl (1 to 2 teaspoons more water can be added if necessary).  2) Gather pastry into a ball. Divide in half; shape into 2 flattened rounds on lightly floured surface. Wrap in plastic wrap; refrigerate about 45 minutes or until dough is firm and cold, yet pliable. This allows the shortening to become slightly firm, which helps make the baked pastry more flaky. If refrigerated longer, let pastry soften slightly before rolling.  3) Heat oven to 425°F. With floured rolling pin, roll one pastry round into round 2 inches larger than upside-down 9-inch glass pie plate. Fold pastry into fourths; place in pie plate. Unfold and ease into plate, pressing firmly against bottom and side.  4) In large bowl, mix sugar, 1/4 cup flour, the cinnamon, nutmeg and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Stir in apples until well mixed. Spoon into pastry-lined pie plate. Cut butter into small pieces; sprinkle over filling. Trim overhanging edge of pastry 1/2 inch from rim of plate.  5) Roll other round of pastry into 10-inch round. Fold into fourths and cut slits so steam can escape. Unfold top pastry over filling; trim overhanging edge 1 inch from rim of plate. Fold and roll top edge under lower edge, pressing on rim to seal; flute as desired. Cover edge with 2- to 3-inch strip of foil to prevent excessive browning.  6) Bake 40 to 50 minutes or until crust is brown and juice begins to bubble through slits in crust, removing foil for last 15 minutes of baking. Serve warm if desired.

No Man's Sky is an ambitious indie game with a AAA price tag. With this in mind, your expectations may or may not be met.  For an indie game, it's great! The worlds are vast, the feel on each planet is mostly unique. Sometimes, I've come across a couple planets that seem similar, but I've also experienced:  A lifeless rock planet abundant with gold, with floating monolith-like formations A planet with about two dozen different species of animals and a few dozen different species of plants A mostly water planet with small islands of snowy evergreen trees A planet light on flora and fauna, but with many abandoned (and some inhabited) alien spaceships A planet abundant with another expensive resource, but with clues of a different alien civilization all over to discover A planet that appeared barren on the surface, but had a series of interconnected caves FILLED with gorgeous plant life and stalactites  Whether free exploring or following what seems to be a main storyline, this game is great for people who want a slower-paced game that's meant to inspire awe, wonder, and above all, curiosity. I strongly disagree with people who say it's a $5 or $10 game - there's far more to it than other games at that price point. $60 is certainly high for now - I think $40 is sort of fair, and $30 is the definite sweet spot for the value of the game.   Another note - there are different levels of solar systems, with each advancing level requiring fancier spaceship parts to reach. The screenshots shown on this page reflect the planets found at the most challenging to reach solar systems, so they're a little deceiving. I've loved the planets I described above, but don't expect to see planets like those in the screenshots until you're well into the game.  OVERALL: Controls are a little clunky at times, but mostly fine. Occasional frame drops are promised to be resolved through patches, and don't make the game unplayable in the slightest. The planets I've seen have been gorgeous in their own unique way and I love exploring what each planet holds. 6/10 at the current price, but at $30 would be a 9/10

I still haven't beaten the game. I did all the sidequests I could before the main story missions, and then halfway through the (rather thin) storyline, the map suddenly and unexpectedly doubled in size. But before I went any further, I wanted to come in here and say just two things about why I'd recommend this game:  1) Yes, it's sometimes annoying when (a) your car gets shot to bits and (b) the enemies are rushing you with semi-automatic shotguns and (c) you need to take your malaria medication and (d) you can't find safe cover to rip the bullet out of your arm and (e) your weapon jams and (f) that fire you started is licking at your heels ... but when all of these things happen at once, it's some of the most exciting FPS-play I've ever had. Far Cry 2 is full of variability, randomness, and multiple approaches, and the game is at its most thrilling when things go wrong.  2) The world is just beautiful, and the developers work to immerse you in it. It fits together so well; it's explorable for its own sake; and the weather effects are lush. That heavy equatorial sun desaturates everything, and makes the air feel thick as you tromp through towns and jungles. The nights are cool and mysterious, particularly driving over sand dunes in the moonlit desert on the edges of the map. And when it rains, turning everything gray, it feels as refreshing as the end of an IRL drought. I'm playing on a laptop with an integrated chipset and the settings turned down to medium so the game stays smooth, but I still find myself smashing F12 to take a dozen screenshots every hour. That said, enjoying this takes the right frame of mind. If you can be patient and appreciative, you'll love it. But if you lament a lack of Elder Scrollsy fast-travel, maybe not.  The only caveat I'll give: if you insist on playing a hero, this isn't the game for you. Nearly everyone you interact with is a despicable, heartless human being. Bandits, mercenaries, murderers, drug peddlers, tyrants, human traffickers, corrupt officials. And you'll be the worst one of the bunch, like it or not.

Midway through my second playthrough prompted me to wholly recommend this title. I would give it a 92% out of 100.   A 'sorta-sandbox' type game that isn't quite as open as Grand Theft Auto, but does occasionally have you 'on-rails', has you working your way up the ranks of a Mafia family in 1940's and 50's New York City, (called Empire Bay). The main combat uses a cover system much like Gears of War or Rainbow Six Vegas.   While the cover system's usual ' cover / wait / shoot / repeat ' mechanic is nothing new or anything revolutionary, the story of Mafia II makes this game stand out like no other. A rich cast with great voice acting really pulls you into the environment and makes you care about their outcomes.  Gritty adult themes, language and situations make me only recommend this for adults only. But if you were a fan of any mafia style movies (Godfather, Goodfellas, Casino etc.) I cannot recommend this title enough.   Cheers, Dr. Y.

Do you like third person platformers? You'll like this game. You are born into the world with not only the ability to double jump, but you can quad-jump, and you can glide after each jump! Platformers dream come true.  The imagery in the game is beautiful and twisted. Some scenes are wonderfully gorgeous, while other scenes are ruthlessly violent. I'm not really a screenshots kinda person, but I did end up taking a lot of screenshots of this game. And the hair physics...you wouldn't think something so small as which way Alice's hair blows in the wind would be such a big deal but it is surprisingly pleasant to watch during those moments when I stop to smell the roses.  The platforming complexity is decent. Hardcore types might be turned off because the path forward is relatively linear and the puzzles themselves are relatively straightforward, but it's still a satisfying experience. Especially because this game has not frustrated me even once, which is surprisingly difficult for games in this genre.  The fighting isn't incredibly complex and the moveset is fairly limited, but it does give you four different weapons, fast melee, strong melee, fast ranged, strong ranged. Some attacks work better than others against some enemies. The fighting adds a nice break between platforming segments; I don't grumble when a fight starts, but I don't get all excited either.  For the completionist, there are lots of little things to look for that are hidden away. I'm usually pretty thorough at searching for things and I've managed to miss two or three things in each level (out of about 30-40). Fortunately, the game allows you to replay previous chapters you've beaten, so you can get a perfect score.

What is it? - The idea of the game is to start with 4X games like Civilization - Then once all space are colonized / controlled by empire border, it turns into 'Grand strategy' game. i.e. like Crusader Kings or Europa Universalis with extensive diplomacy - The end game is fighting the 'Fallen Empire', ridiculously advanced AI controlled race.  Positive: - Many Unique Spins to the old genre  1. Randomized Tech Tree ('Deck of Card, randomly pick 3, Player choose 1, deck reshuffled)  2. Survey Ship giving 'Anomalies' (i.e. Chain of quests)  3. War Goals (I was told this is like other Paradox games, which I never bothered to play)  4. Extensive Diplomacy option  5. Extensive 'Leaders' and personality which affects everything they interact with  6. Ethics and Divergence: Your population , especially those in distant planet, may believe  in different things and start to build their own fully functioning, independent empire  7. Technology like Genetically modifying pre-sentient race you find into sentient creatures  8. Ability to Research the debris of your destroyed enemies and reverse engineer their techs.  9. Real time (no turn based) game allows for easier multiplayer (no waiting for everyone else's turns) 10. Ability to create 'Federation', with 'Federation Fleet' controlled by the Federation president. The Federation fleet has the bech Technologies from all federation members! 11. Wormhole FTL (faster than light) travel. Hyperlane and Warp are similar to Gal Civ / MOO, but Wormhole is unique. You create a wormhole station,and you can create a two ways wormhole in space for your fleet to go through and back. Gamewise this mean you can pop up BEHIND ENEMY LINES and avoid the usual 'Strong Border, Weak Core' strategy.   Negative: - Sector AI is HORRIBLE. It builds very slowly compared to the resource it have and you cannot command it to build any ships. Since your 'CORE WORLD' (i.e. world you can control directly) is limited to between 5-10 (start with 5; increase with research), you will want to MOD this game to increase that number.  - Tachyon Lance is Overpowered. Lazers Pew Pew Pew. Everyone died at range 120. GG.   (All the above supposedly fixed by October 2016 in patch 1.3. Fingers Crossed)  - Limited Ship models, I'm sure Paradox will sell 400 types of DLC for it.  - Ships cannot be controlled directly by player; and at the end there is little strategical option other than your fleet composition and AI behaviour (Swarm or Bombardment, etc)  - Hidden Complexities: You will need to read a lot of Wikipedias to min-max this game. The fact that there is a 10% penalty to research speed for each planet you have and 1% penalty per population you have is not being shown explicitly and easy to miss (would you realise if a 2400 research becomes 2540 research when you build new colony?)  - Random deck of Tech means that I have to research quite a lot of unwanted tech until I finally draw the technology card I want or desperately need. e.g. if you make a noob mistake of not picking technology that allows you to build Colony ship on your first choice, then you are stuck with no expansion capability for a long, long time.  - After doing the same quests from anomalies for the 100th time (a few are buggy, like Throne of God), it gets boring. The idea of having to research alien language for each alien you meet is just another 90 days delay to game's progress.   -All are interesting idea (like Polution in Master of Orion 4 recently released), but ends up just like another boring micromanagement. I want more of the ability to control my army at strategic level like Commander Adama in Battlestar Galactica and less building another hydroponics farm or risking my stupid Sector AI governor starving my people to death.  CONCLUSION: Paradox is known for developing patches for months to years after the game and for listening to the customers on what need to be fixed and improved. They cater to a very hardcore strategy gamers who would still play their games even if it is lacking completely in graphics department (i.e. Total War in Space this ain't).  But by far this game has potential to be their most popular game (it is their bestselling as far as release date sales so far). In this games they bothered making it pretty with 3D world and battles. In this game they bothered to make tutorial (VIR) clippy. This is probably their most accessible strategy game (unless you count Magicka).  On the plus side, they are famous for making diplomatic games. With a bit of imagination, this can simulate your grandest of space opera role playing - after all, every trait and personality are depicted by numbers: relationship status, ethics and edicts. And if you are not into immersion, you can always play this like a normal 4X games and conquer the universe as usual.  I think the game is reasonably solid as it is, it has STRONG FOUNDATION. You can get 100-200 hours easy without complain just expanding and conquering the universe. Playing passive, as in all 4X games, is not too smart - but Technology cap means at least you won't be both outsized and outsmarted). Paradox call this 'Tall Empire' vs 'Wide Empire'. At least for now, as usual in all strategy games from Total War to MOO4, wide empire is easier.  What excites me is the potential this game can be in a year from now. When they actually add enough ethics specific or race specific technologies into the deck so you won't run out the 'samey' old tech every game; when they fix the sector AI and enemy AI to make them tougher (the AI is already one of the better one in the market as it is), when they kept adding contents, refinement and fixes. This game could be great. But even as it is, this game is good!

If you liked Alan Wake you may or may not like American Nightmare. The game was okay, had an intresting plot, tons more weapons, spiders, taken that look even worse than in Alan Wake etc. American Nightmare unlike the first game is not a survival horror game, its more an action based game. The plot takes place in the popular tv show 'Night Springs' in an epsode written by Alan himself were the champion of light (Alan) must defeat the herald of darkness (His Evil Twin Mr Scratch). The game takes place in three places: The Motel/Rest Stop, The Observatory and The Drive-in Theater and upon reaching the end of the Drive-in Theater Mr Scratch sends Alan back to the start meaning you have to play through the game again with small differences, this happens twice, in other words, there are Three Areas and Three time loops. The third loop adds the giant, long story short they're scary. In my opinion the game was mostly good but I didn't like the weapon unlock system because they required pages which I sucked at finding. I also didn't like where the game was set and I would take Bright Falls over this. Also spiders.

The gameplay is fun, it could use some optimization though. It also needs a tutorial, the learning curve is not the best. The atmosphere is far better than most modern multiplayer shooters, and the weapons are incredibly detailed. Do not expect fast paced WW2 style action though, get ready to be crawling in the mud and stabbing people to death with a bayonet.

I have literally played this game probably a thousand times. First as a teenager, starting off with the download-version, then buying the hard copy. Now I've bought it on Steam and I still discover new things! (and of course, ACHIEVEMENTS!)  Did you know that you don't always start off with sheep? That sometimes you get turkeys? Yes? Me too. BUT!! Did you know that sometimes, you don't get sheep, you don't get turkeys, sometimes....... you get llamas. And, even more rarely, you get cows! Brand new information, thought I'd share it with the world :-)

When I started this game, I didn't know what to expect. I started running into the grassy field in front of me, and found nothing, even after 20 minutes. I questioned this 'walking simulator', however crouched down, and started walking much slower. A few minutes later, I heard a deer call, and being a novice, simply walked toward it ( I didn't know yet that you are equipped with a tracker that locates where the deer was) I pulled out my rifle and scoped in to the general vicinity that I believed the deer to be. Shortly, I saw it in my sights. I took careful aim, fired, and completely missed. The deer ran away, and I didn't get a kill that hunt.  All in all, I absolutely adore this game. The gorgeous wild beauty mixed with the enjoyable tracking and hunting of your animal makes this game incredibly fun-for me at least. See, this game isn't a game where you get kills every other minute, this is a game in which up to hours of time climaxes in one moment where you have your animal in your sights. If you blow the shot, you can expect a minimum of 20-30 minutes either tracking the same animal down, or looking for a different beast all together.   Another thing about this game that puts people off is the price tag. Although the game itself is F2P, you have to buy hunting licenses for all animals expect the Whitetail deer. Furthermore, the only viable way to get equipment such as deer odor (to conceal your scent from the deer's) or a tent (to start your hunt at a place which you placed your tent in previous hunts) alongside rifles, shotguns, and handguns;is to pay occasionally large sums of real money. For some, this is the ultimate turn off. I believe it to be irritating that you have to pay for this content, however I am still content with the game itself.(See what I did there?)   9/10 for a solid, realistic, and accurate hunting game with a few flaws.

The game is a mix of GoT epic storyline and Kotor combat engine.You assume the role of 2 noble characters that fight against all the corruption of Westeros.The game is great if: -You like Kotor -You like GoT -You like totally unexpected plot twists(A song of Ice and Fire style)  The only problem with the game( at least with my style) is the lack of balance between characters.Their skills were opposites and i found myself changing difficulty settings between chapters.The 2 men don't complement each other well and one was OP'ish while the other one was frustratingly weak.(the first char you play is the OP'ish one)  The story is,like A song of Ice and Fire itself filled with 2-3 characters you love and a army of evil and corrupt idiots that you want to turn into your darts target.The plot twists were really unexpected(really,the last thing you could expect) and characters *spoiler*(read this reversed) daed yats ot tnaw t'nod *end spoiler*  Really great way to immerse yourself in the world,as the game was canonised by RR Martin himself.The near-turn based style complements the scene,putting fast paced action and slow motion scenes into the ...decently... made scene.Lacking the great graphic efects of ,say,Skyrim,it immerses the player through Story.   Warning,you may experience dreams of torturing characters from the game,if that happens,DON'T PANIC!Its normal for Game of Thrones stuff.  9,75/10. (Really,the 0.25 is about the characters whoose eyes i poked out with a hot iron.)   *Note:i am not a psycho.These are just jokes.Treat them accordingly.

Update(After Comment by Tom- Developer): It seems software is FINALLY working now. I had a bit of trouble trying to figure out what to use it on- finally settled on Bioshock Infinite- and let me tell you- playing it without and with, is night and day! Have the SSC set to 7.1 Shanghai Beyerdynamic DT 770M, and it just envelopes you in the surroundings- every scream, gunshot, broadcast- even the wind, you are totally aware of it suddenly. Glad I was convinced to give this another try :)   For those of you having problems with still distorted audio and the like- ensure you're playing music, or software with high enough fidelity. I usually import my music at 320K and iTunes automatically splits it into stereo- this becomes obvious upon playback when using this software, as the software is stripping the stereo channels into separate channels, and it doesn't sound very good- not the software's fault- just something to keep in mind-GIGO (Garbage-In-Garbage-Out).   tldr; I would complately recommend this software now- seems like most kinks are worked out, and it's a good deal for more immersive gaming.  _____________________________________________________________________________________________  Update (A week later):  I have received no reply from dev either from this review, or from the discussion page as dev had requested. I am requesting a refund. A word of advice, until issues are fixed and or dev starts fixing the problems, I would recommend holding off on this.   Original: Sorry, I also cannot get this APP to work, even after I read that the dev had released an update to bind to WASAPI, but I figured I'd give it a try. I could also not get this to work after I installed the trial version directly from New Audio Technology, but I figured I'd give this version a shot- especially with the dev saying he updated it.   Problems (If you care to read): Cannot get sound to output through headphones using software as default playback device- unless I run the software in stereo mode (which kinda' defeats the purpose I must admit). The only way I'd been able to get the software to work otherwise is to go into recording devices, and set my headphones to 'listen' to this recording device on playthrough... this also defeats the purpose, as it does not allow controlling of sound directions- it just patches through.   For reference I'm running Windows 10- using Steelseries Siberia V2 headset (USB). I watched some Youtube Videos on this software, and the demonstrations are incredible! I'm sure if this software would work properly it would be amazing. Missing features or bad decisions: - AI is too bad. They only attack in same way whole game. - No forced attack - No moat (Srsly Firefly? No moats?) - Can't pick which kind of lord (arab/european) you play in Sandbox mode or options - No 45 degree rotation for buildings, which was one of the VERY few good things in SH3 - You can't determine which goods, and how many, your estates deliver - Bird's-eye view missing (Very important! Especially for building) - All the lists are missing, like the ones showing all your units, where your gold came from etc. etc. - Where is the map maker? - Can't close/open gates on your own - TOWERS DON'T GET DOORS WHEN WALLS ARE ATTACHED TO THEM!! (this really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off, as I am a person who cares a lot about such details, which is why I really stressed this point when I made my suggestions list for SHC2 while it was still in development) - There is no restart button - Building limit and unit limit is WAY TOO LOW - When you play with 8 players the unit limit is WAY too low. What am I supposed to do with 140 units? Even after only 3 players were left, I could still just build 333 units, that's not enough to be fun! - Same as above goes for buildings too, the limit is way too low - Couldn't find a strong walls option when playing against NPCs - Walls are TOO WEAK!!! One guy on Metacritic said it feels like they're made of chalk, which is absolutely true. They are in fact so weak that they're pretty much useless, combine that with the missing moats and you can't have any decent defense - Horses die way too easily, which makes knights almost useless. I once sent a large group of knights into an enemy group of archers, and most of them lost their horses before arriving. They need to be a LOT stronger - the marker on the minimap that shows where you currently are is too hard to see, it's very thin and black, should be changed to red or something - When you click on a unit that was sent out to attack someone or something, you can't see what he's going to attack, the marker should come back - Peasants and workers don't talk anymore - I really miss that one feature from SH2 where you could zoom out farther, but couldn't build anything while you did it (the button was an eye in a red circle or something like that). It was nice to be able to see your whole castle in that mode - No torture buildings (or the opposite of them) - Not enough new soundtracks - I don't mind using a few good, old ones, but I've only heard like 1 or 2 new soundtracks as of now  Found in other threads: - No ladder men or siege towers - Only one kind of keep    Other Bugs:  • Siege camps • Walls aren't deleted properly • Unresponsive units (they don't listen sometimes) • Camera 'jumps' sometimes when moving around the map • Some video options glitch the graphics, lines in middle of screen and such • Ranger animations are messed up - they hold the bow sideways away from them leaving one hand empty...  Suggestions:  • Fix UI • Add usable gates • Engineers, add them • Remove siege camps • Soldiers walking from camp site to barracks • Replace defensive turrets with old ones • Stronger walls • Nerf range on fire throwers • Nerf arabian archers (their range is insane compared to regular archers) • Up the damage from fire • Voiced peasants • Bring back the videos for buildings (doesn't matter if you rip them directly from Crusader, they look great) • Longer peace time (60 minutes) • Less slashing animations for pikemen (it feels odd) • Remove negative popularity from random events • Remove ALL events when turned off (including winds) • Count build distance with player keeps instead of areas • If areas are kept, increase color opacity • Add numbers on players and their keeps when choosing a map • Target your own units with attack • Round towers • Improve menu UI...The font, oh the font... • Perhaps fix the Rat, he feels way too gentleman like, dumb him down • Fix AI so they can actually defend their castle and attack in a proper way • Increase building and unit size. Remove buildings already present on map to increase this? • More NPCs running around - chickens, drunks, peasants, kids to make the place feel more alive

This is what a Naruto inspired rpg would be. Or at least what I think it'd be... until I tried the game myself.  Pros:    A huge selection of skills, so there are a lot to choose from    Decent music. I'm sure it's just a standard rpg-maker music but for me, it's actually pretty nice to listen to    Tons of Naruto reference.    Cons:    A lot of grammatical errors. The devs  really  need to get someone to proofread this game.    Repetitive gameplay. Remember I said earlier that this game was inspired by Naruto? So the kage (head of the village) will give you a mission, along with a pre-determined party member. You completed the mission, got some reward from him and that's it. That's how you spend your day.    Money. As you progress in the game, it becomes increasingly easy to get money and during those 4 hours in the game, I've never had any money problem.    Unbalanced. My entire party could literally wipe out an entire enemies in one turn without mana (or chi) problem.  Just go to the pentagram symbol. Pay 10 golds and voila! No more mana and health problem. Rinse and repeat to grind.     Naruto inspired game? Nah. This game is way too similar to be called 'inspired by' (Though the devs never mention that). Only with a little bit difference here and then. Bell mission with Kakashi and team 7? Check. The drama between Naruto, Sakura and Sasuke? Check.     Max. By the time you reached lvl 15, he'd stop leveling up. Wait what? No, you didn't hear me wrong. He literally stopped leveling up because by then the game wouldn't be able to handle his power. Hell, I'm not even gonna be surprised if he already awakened his mangekyo.
Alright well... probably my favorite bullethell since Deathsmiles 2 because there is so much crazy ♥♥♥♥ happening and the music is great. Really great game.

Insurgency is a game for what i have been waiting for so long !! A fast paced shooter with realistic gunplay and hardcore gameplay ! This mix is working great and this game is a lot of fun !  Good thinks !  + Guns feel amazing and every kill makes you ♥♥♥ ! + Very nice graphic.Yeah its not frostbite but what do you want from a indie deveployer ? + Very tactical ! You need to use smokes and flank the enemie very often witch gives you a tactical feel ! +Amazing costumization mode ! Its like in Csgo where you get Money at the beginning and you can buy equipment for it  ! Well Insurgency has a very similar system.You get a amount of points you can spend for equipment witch works just great ! Do you want to get a sniper scope on your Ak-74 ? Or do you want AP bullets and a handgrip for the same amount of points ? You choose ! +Very nice and detailed Maps ! +Differend playstiles for each Weapon and equipment ! If you have a scope on your Ak than you need for sure snipe the enemy ! If you have smokes than you need to flank the enemy ! If you use an LMG than you need cover your teamates or dont let the enemy get to a position ! +Alot of differend gamemodes witch needs alot of differend requirements from your playstile. +Quite a lot of differend weapons. +An amazing community with friendly and helpfull players ! (MOSTLY)  The bad thinks  - Sometimes very frustrating balance ! Some of the maps are way to unfair for the Insurgents and Some are way to unfair for the American Capitalist pigs ! Balance is the biggest problem in this game  - Only like 1000-2000 people play this game. Its enough to find a very good full server but still im scared that the community will die in the future  And that was it ! The game is fully worth for the full price because of the amazing experimence you can get.

While in the last game, we played as Lee, an intelligent, strong, adult male, this time, the playable character is Clementine, the young girl who we spent a large part of the last season protecting. Clem is still no more than ten years old, and the way that potentially changes how the player will interact with the world in this season is exciting. For her age, Clementine is certainly quite clever and strong, but the world of The Walking Dead is full of monsters, zombie and otherwise, and there's no question she's more vulnerable and less powerful than Lee was. One of the challenges of this is balancing between giving the player agency in the world without giving Clem influence she shouldn't have from a narrative point of view. This is going to have to be a very different story, and with the setup, it's somewhat hard to see how it will pay off the way the first season did, but we'll have to wait and find out. In terms of gameplay, very little has changed from the first season. Most of the important interaction comes from dialogue choices, with QTEs and a few simple fetch quests tossed in to break things up. Like in the original, you will sometimes have to make some tough choices, and the game will keep track of how you choose, leading to slightly different situations. I sometimes miss the more difficult puzzles found in Telltale's earlier titles such as Tales of Monkey Island, but their more recent games seem to be going for a different type of genre, so it's probably best not to make direct comparisons. This is less an adventure game and more of a visual novel, albeit one that does a very good job of keeping the player within the lines while simultaneously making them feel like the story is their own. Perhaps things will change up in later episodes, but I don't really think they have to if the main concept is pulled off properly. screen1136x1136-9 From a technical standpoint, well, this is an iOS version of a Telltale game, so things aren't going to be completely airtight. In particular, I should give a clear warning to people on older hardware. If your hardware was not officially supported but could run the first season in some fashion anyway, don't count on the same here. Things went pretty smoothly on my iPhone 5S, but I've seen tons of complaints from people on circa-iPhone 4 tech. Given Telltale's history, don't count on much technical support after the fact, either. One thing that did work quite well is the save game import. As long as you kept the first season on your device, you'll be able to import your final data for that. There aren't many ramifications in the first episode apart from the 'Previously' opening, but I'm sure things will come into play in less subtle ways eventually. From here, I'll write up a bit about each episode as they're released. As with the main review, I'll do my best to avoid spoiling anything current when talking about each one, but there may be spoilers for prior episodes as we go along. Tread at your own risk!

WOW! This game is not for everybody, but if you like the genre is amazing. It's extremely complex, detailed and deep. You can play as a strategy game if you are a risiko fan who wants something 100 time more complicated and it's one of the best I've ever try. But you can also dream to be in a medieval novel, tring to follow the story of you family. That's my favourite part since I'm not yet good enought to master it and conquer the europe, so I just try to manage my character and his relations, living the game like the new episode of Game of Thrones and it's absolutely immersive and captivating on every level, from the count of the smallest county to the emperor of the europe.  There just a problem, and it's not that small and it's the price of the game with the DLC that you need to play it. I've bought it with many DLC, paying more than 30€, which is a very good price, but I had it with 75% discount and even if this is a great game I'd not have bought it for 120€.

I would rather not spoil a thing, but if you love exploring, good stories and mysteries, this ia a wonderful game to go to, and that's what you will probably expect. But there's some more surprising elements. I finished it in one go, but I'll be thinking about it for days to come.  Wonderful experience.

app_name: Sid Meier's Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword
review_text: Best expansion for the best PC game out there. The base game, Civilization IV, is great. It is a really in depth 'civilization simulator.' You take control of a civilization starting at the dawn of time all the way to the modern era and beyond. The game is very in depth with all of the options at your disposal for how you manage your government, economy, religion, espionage, foreign policy, and many other factors. You can be Gandhi and set up a fascist theocracy with a socialist economy and nuke everyone on the planet. There is a lot of literature out there about how spectacular this game is so I’ll just stop here.  One of the few flaws is the combat. It is all percentage based, so you can get in some pretty frustrating situations. Maybe you go into a battle where you have and 80+ percent chance of winning, but there is still a chance you can lose. Even at 97+percent I’ve lost some times. This combat system is extremely frustrating when you “get haxed” and lose on battle you should have won. Another issue is that in late game the combat really just becomes “who can have the most units crammed into a tile.” Your (and your opponents’) empire will get so big and have so much production that it becomes quite cumbersome to manage a war with all the military units you’ll have around. Since you can fit literally infinite units in one space, it really becomes a contest of who can get the biggest army and march from city to city. These flaws pale in comparison to how great and addicting this game is, however.  This expansion, beyond the sword, is the best. It adds even more units, buildings, and civilizations to the game. Also, it comes pre-loaded with some of the best mods, including Rhye’s and Fall of Civilization, which takes this game to a whole new level. Over all it’s as close to a 10/10 game I have ever seen. You won’t regret spending the money to buy this, especially when it is on sale.

The menu is a bit messy, for me finding how to play multiplayer was a pain, joining through Steam doesn't work. Overall it's a nice game, if you see it on discount it's definetely worths to buy, but don't play it alone.

This is utterly terrifying. I first played the game in 2014 when it first came out which then only had Easy, Normal, and Hard difficulties available. While I played it on normal it was still very tough to get through. The AI for the Alien truly makes it an enemy like no other. You'd think you'd be tailing it as it walks down a corridor until suddenly, and without warning, it'll turn it's head in your direction then you're Alien chow. Or you'd walk along another section and hear the Alien thumping around in the vent, to all of a sudden drop down right in front of you.  When this game first came out I thoroughly enjoyed it as it really sells that retro-future ascetic used in Ridley Scott's first film Alien. A lot of people I've seen play this call the first Alien film a 1980's film. It's not. Production started in 1977 and was released in 1979. The decor and architecture of browns and greys was 'the thing' back in the day. That makes the film a 1970's film, not the physadelic colors of the 80's. Yet another look this game nails. Wondering around the Torrens and Sevastopol station you'll see many reminders of where this game gets its backbone from. The seats and walls are emblazoned with the drab 2-tone covers, the monochromatic monitors displaying text and basic graphics common in 1960's and 1970's computers.  And then, and THEN the music starts playing. The music is adaptive to your situation. In an area devoid of enemies you'll usually hear a calming melody which sets the mood that, yes, while you are in a dangerous environment you're not alone and not in immediate danger. But then the alien gets near, you hide, the alien gets nearer still, then the music changes. The trombones and horns start singing as you hind in that locker or under a table, you can't move and only hope the alien will move on. And in a couple of sections of the game you'll even hear little ditties that came straight from the original firm to further emphasise you're in space and deep in the Xeno-verse.  The vanilla game is truly epic with some only a couple of scripted scenes with the alien, the alien is pure unfettered AI looking, sniffing for you. A really tough challenge is to play the game on Nightmare difficulty, however as I write this review, I've started playing the game yet again this time with the Unpredictable Alien and No Motion Tracker mods. It's bad enough the alien is 'somewhere', and the motion tracker can only approximate it's position especially in maps with multiple levels to it, but try playing this game with only audio clues to try and keep tabs on the alien as it scuttles each level you're on.  The game isn't without faults though. Bipedal NPCs seem 'stiff' while walking. No so great when seeing humans walk like that but is a great effect on the Working Joes. Talking of which, the game is called Alien: Isolation, not Attack of the Working Joes. There's far too many in game, though like in Deus Ex are best left alone as they can be really tough to take down without the right tools, and neigh on impossible if they don't like you while the Alien is nearby.  Voice acting is film quality but while in-game (not when a cut scene is being played out) lip-syncing is a hit-and-miss. Though that's not a problem on the 'Joes as they have no lips to sync. There are also a few missions where you have to traverse the same map 2 or 3 times, I'm not talking about maps you play early in game you have to play later on in the story with different enemies oh no. I'm talking about you enter a level, you get set a waypoint on the map (not available in Nightmare difficulty) for the exit, you get there but the exit is locked. So you have to go to another point on that same map, do something and return to that exit. I understand Creative Assembly are trying to keep the tension up by prolonging it for as long as possible but it can get very tedious for speed runners.  I love the Aliens franchise and this is THE DEFINITIVE Alien game for any one who loves the lore like I do. A masterpiece on it's own, but with the few mods that are available, you can make it so much more terrifying like never before.
Just please don't buy this game, it is bad, unrealistic and most of the time you can't even save.

app_name: Call of Duty: Black Ops III
review_text: This review solely include my opinions on the multiplayer portion of the game.  I think after ten hours of gameplay, I have an overall feel of how the multiplayer fairs.  Here are my general thoughts:   When I first started the game and had to pick my first specialist, I thought: What are these? As I read further into them my stomach sunk, but still, I was eager.   Pressing further into my first match I was happy to find it was fun. I liked it. Guns handled about how I would expect them to - tight and solid. The maps too were also quite balanced, especially in domination. But that's about all I liked.   Wall running, parkour, what have you - to me this is the weakest mechanic in the game. Yes, it works well almost 100% of the time. Only exception being when you clip around a corner and fall of an edge, you just begin sprinting along side the wall. While annoying, it is something easily overlooked. Additionally, when you're in a firefight and start wall running, it snaps your view, jolting it away from your target and getting you killed. Those with fast reflexes may be able to manage swinging the gun around back in time.   Another big gripe I have with the game are specialists. (turns out that feeling in my gut wasn't the leftover beef.) How should I say this? They're overpowered? No, not quite. Rather, their abilities are overpowered. For example Ruin's ability is to leap in the air and ground pound. Killing everyone within the radius. Sparrow has a bow which not only is a one-shot, it explodes. Even if she misses, the likelihood of you dying is still quite high. Same deal with Prophet. He has a railgun with a fast buildup and one-shot. Specialists are highly lethal and you can't do anything about them. Run around the wrong corner and boom, you're dead without even seeing the aggressor.   Overall, I find the game enjoyable. That's it. Would I recommend the game? No. While ambitious, I think Treyarch walked too much a similar path as Sledgehammer. Hopefully Infinity Ward is able to redeem my trust next year with their installment in the ever growing franchise. I don't want to wait another three years to buy one of my most loved franchises.

app_name: Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword
review_text: Its far from as good as Mount & Blade warband.  What i felt most disapointing was the singleplay. Sure it has some new mechanics but i didnt find them any good or fun. Also you don't get those epic and fun fights like you do in warband. Becuse you spend most of the fights hiding behind a rock, tree or your soldiers so you wont get one shot by some random rifleman 100m away.  The rifle combat is so awful. The rifles are very strong so you can often get suprised killed by anyone. Useing a rifle yourself is even worse since the bullet can fly anywere. So shooting becomes more of luck then a skill. With the high relode time just makes it worse. If you want to fight with rifles in a mount and blade game i recomend the napolic dlc for warband. Becuse the rifles are more accurate so its more skill based, It feels more epic with music and cannons, I think relode is faster or atlest it feels faster.   I only got the hours on the game becuse the melee combat in multiplayer was the one fun thing.

I must say that Unepic is quite Epic! The possibilities are vast in this game! There's a bunch of upgrades and skills to explore. The entire game is a wild card! Level design is great and the objectives are never tedious. A must for those who care to enjoy something different.   Ah yes... and...  Wow, the end is really cool!

I'm disappointed in this version. No music! First and foremost. Sure you can add it in with mods, but I thought bringing games to the Steam platform involved modification. It's not that hard fella's, Standardize it, that was half the reason I paid money for this again. Next there are glitchy animations, the sky never glitched in any version or source port of quake I had. My sega saturn has smoother texture animation than this port. This is basically GLquake and Winquake packaged together with the core files. No effort whatsoever. You would think with this one game being the grandfather to Valve and the entire Steam storefront operation they would pay respectful homage. No. I feel ripped off. Bad Valve, Bad Steam. No Megusta. The least you could do is make a free-to-play Quake: Source package like TF2. That would be truely respectful and fitting. Oh right, ID's basically owned and being dryhumped now though. Missed opportunity.
Early Access Review

app_name: Call of Duty: Black Ops II
review_text: I have been a Call of Duty fan since Infinity ward's Call of Duty 1 and United Offensive, and Black Ops 2 shows Treyarch's extreme Capabilty of making amazing games across all platforms. Black Ops 2 is in my opinion the BEST Call of Duty to date. Treyarch stepped away from the usual Call of Duty formula and set out to try many new approaches in this game and in my opinion have successfully made each approach awesome.   The new engine that Black Ops 2 runs on is just Gorgeous!!!The overall graphical fidelity and the colour pallet are so beautiful. It's the best graphical experience in CoD history. The capability of the game running so well on lower end graphics cards just amazes me.  The fact that you change between 2025 and the Cold War in the campaign gives you such an amazing blend of old and new and makes you feel like you are in Black Ops 1 for some moments. The Campaign has lets u make vital choices which change the course of the game. There are 6 different endings, a first for the Call of Duty franchise.  The Zombie mode is the best it's ever been, especially with the dynamic map Tranzit. The concept of having to complete objectives in Zombies is just spectacular as it complicates the gameplay positively and allows you to think about about which player should do whuch objective.  The Multiplayer is THE BEST Call of Duty Multiplayer experience you can have! A wide variety of amazing weapons and gadgets, Beautiful and well designed maps (including a modern remake of Nuketown) and ease of use match joining system is fantastic! I can click find game - TeamDeathmatch and within seconds I'm in a local game with a very low ping.
It's a riot
Early Access Review

I was really excited when this came out and I tried to give it a chance. However, the blantant imbalance between factions really kills where the game matters most in multiplayer. Not only are factions imbalanced, but unless you already have a top-tier fleet you will get pummeled by other players who have maxed out cheese builds.   It is a shame because I really love the core mechancics of the game. It looks beautiful and the core design really captures the tabletop game of old. However, the devs (or I suspect GW) just want to push the name and not a good product. Typical of GW-licensed video games sadly.   If you want a fleet combat game I would look elsewhere (not that there are many options out there).

Nominated this game for the 'Whoa, dude' nomination during the 2016 Autumn Sale!   I'm pretty glad with the resurgence of alternative competitor titles nowadays that completely took advantage from the greedy corporations that bought some top franchises from the past. If you know the Simcity fiasco from EA that later got rekt from a competitor through Cities Skylines, then Planet Coaster is your way to go if you're one of those long-time fans who got dissapointed with Rollercoaster Tycoon World.  Although this game might feel a bit unfinished in certain aspects such as the managment, Planet Coaster focuses more on your creativity. You're given set pieces that you can use to build whatever you please using your imagination (and some wonky controls). But seeing how positive the devs responded to the community, I have high hopes for future content. I'll be happy to pay for any upcoming DLC to support these devs and help keep the game alive.  Please take note that the game really demands a lot of resources from your PC. Previously I've played this with 4GB RAM (below recommended specs) and I couldn't play when my park starts to get 1500+ peeps, it starts lagging like hell. I decided to buy additional 8GB RAM JUST for this game - and it plays smoothly. So be sure you met the minimum requirements at least to save you from any frustation.  GG Frontier - can't wait to see what you have in store for this game in the future - DLCs, expansions, etc. Good job!  Get this game if you LIKE building and creating things, but do reconsider if you really are looking for complex management stuff, because at the moment the management aspects are a bit too simplified IMO.

Warning! This is a Review of a hobby artist. I have no clue about professional programs. The programs I used before are: GIMP, Photoshop CS6, Photoshop Elements, Paint Tool SAI  After playing around with the program for a couple of hours I have to say... It's simple. But really, the best program, I have ever used to draw. It helps a lot, if you want to draw outlines. Especially with a graphics tablet. With the built in function to smoothen the lines, you will draw perfect lines around the second or the first time trying. In Photoshop, you have to make first a reaaally big picture and draw like this, so you can make it smaller afterwards to hide eventual wobbly lines. Or in SAI, you may be confronted with vector based lines, which are perfect, if you want perfect quality outlines. In openCanvas however, all you need is a stroke with your pen or mouse, and it already looks great.  All the brushes are perfectly adjustable and easy to work with. I was really impressed by the kalligraphy pen, where it took less than a minute to adjust it to my needs, while in Photoshop, it took quite a while and didn't look good after all. Or maybe it was just my imagination. In fact, I was really impressed, how easy this little program works.  I wasn't very sure, what to expect with the filters, when I saw them advertised on the shop page. But they have some really nice little filters, which can twirl the image, make waves, pixelize(mosaic), diffuse in a very smooth way etc. etc.  The user interface is adjustable to the maximum. While it has similarities to how GIMP handles the many windows, it feels a lot more stable in handling and using.  Now one thing, I wasn't really sure if needed. But it came in handy when using. Perspectives. You can practically adjust for very impressive static structures and visual effects. It is for sure damn good to use when you are a beginner and don't draw in perfect perspectives from the beginning of your picture. But I could imagine it to be also really handy for professional artists too. (I think, I will have much fun with it!)  Rotating the picture as you need while drawing makes hard to draw lines easier and you don't have to turn your tablet upside down. Really nice to have this implemented. It is a far nicer rotation tool than GIMP, Photoshop or SAI. Also it is more handy.  The last two things (And I am sorry to put the least good things in the end) You can add text. Well, every other tool I know has this feature. I don't know, why it is worth mentioning. But okay. And.. this is ACTUALLY really neat, if you think about it. The program itself takes up only 18MB. It makes it the smallest, but best program to draw, I own.  Sure, I feel really hyped about this and I will update the review in a few weeks with a speed art and a much more settled opinion. But I hope you liked this review and it helped you considering to buy it. It is worth every dollar/euro/septim/gold coin or whatever you like to buy stuff with.  Here are the prices of the porgrams compared: GIMP - free Photoshop CS6 Standard - 699$ Photoshop CS6 Extended - 999$ Paint Tool SAI - 5400 Yen (Around 50$ And no, it is NOT freeware) openCanvas - 49,99$  If you have questions or want to correct me, just comment and I will try to answer it, correct it or add it to the review if important.  Edit #1: As I am not sure, why my 'play time' is so low, I was quite busy with it. There are actually some bugs, you should be aware of.  - Your stylus may not be recognized after using the arrows to scroll on your drawing. This isn't really a big problem, but can be really annoying after a few hours. You can also solve it by either Alt+Tab out and in again, or by drawing a line with your normal mouse.  - Sometimes, you are not able to load up a .psd file. If you want to keep working on a picture, you have to copy every layer, save it as a separate picture and import it to OpenCanvas. This happened to me only once after switching very often between Photoshop and O.C. Rather use .oci  If you find yourself having the same issues, consider reporting the bug. End of Edit #1

Great goodness this port is BAAAD The game is near a decade old but it struggles to play in certain areas so much I had to dumb down my resolution and turn on the 30 fps limit. My Computer is old, but it's not so much a clunker that it should have any reason to run Resi4 horribly.  Capcom dropped the ball again!(you had TWO shots at this port!) They're in my book near Ubisoft in PC ports!   As for the game itself: I have never played RE 4 up until now. I just heard so much hype and praise around it, especially when RE 5 and 6 came out, or any 'personal top games ever' I hear from people. And I would like to say.  They're not wrong. I like this game but I don't 'love' it.  It is a fantastic game yes, and I am enjoying it. Maybe its my personal inability to get hooked or maybe I actually don't like it(probably the former) but this game is in no way bad.  Stuff I like: +Tense... especially when I never played this before and everything is new to me. +Managable. On 'Normal' I've been having to ration ammo but I rarely ever run out to the point where I have to knife everything. +Tank Controls... yeah... the tank controls made it harder to perform fast,precise actions therefore added to the tense 'I GOTTA GET OUTTA HERE!' moments +Inventory Tetris isn't that bad... I kept my inv. clean and never really wound up with the infamous clutter this game is known for  Stuff I didn't like: -Horribad PC Port -Ashley's voice -Ambiguous healing amounts: When I need to heal I sometimes catch myself struggling whether or not the weaker mixed herbs or a single green is enough -Knife distance: Nyeh! NyeH! get closer DAMNIT!!! -Bad Keyboard Mouse... apparently... never really used them cause people told me not to and I defaulted to controller.   So the stuff I didn't like are basically minor gripes. This game is GREAT!   BUUUUTTTTT it'lll probably be for the best to get it on console to avoid half the problems of running it.

At first I hated this game, thinking that it 'ruined' the Hitman series, so I left it after the first missions (probably the third one); fortunately, one day I tried it again and I completed it, discovering how cool it actally is. The first half part of the game was pretty boring to me, but then it began really interesting. Sure, there were still some missions which annoyed me (they're the ones where you have to get behind a cover and stay there for a long time in order to escape from a place and reach a new one, without having any targets to kill), but 90% of the rest was really amazing and I felt like playing on older Hitmans. If you're looking for some old-like 'silent' action, missions such as Streets of Hope or The King of Chinatown are the ones which you're looking for. Except for the exaggerated amount of bloom and lens flares which can be very annoying, the rest of the graphics is amazing. Performance is pretty bad, so I wouldn't suggest this game if you have a bad PC and you aren't going to buy a high-end one. Plot is ok/good, but what really surprised me is the longevity. It took me 30+ hours to complete it, even without having done all 'additional objectives' (although I've repeated many times some missions in order to get SA rating). Now, I can say that I'm disappointed for some aspects of the rating system (no penalties for found bodies? What? No timer? Too bad), for the disguise system (they're useless if you don't use instinct), for the exaggeration in the use of covers and for the cover system itself. Recommended!

Despite a rough launch this is one of the best mmo's I've played in years. The biggest issues right now are the bot infestations and all the typical problems with new servers (lag spikes, dc's etc). The bots are only in the really low level areas but for your first 2 or 3 hours of gameplay you'll sometimes find yourself literally surrounded by them.   The other caveat is that the learning curve is duanting even for a KRPG. One wrong mistake in charcter building and you could easily lose 200 hours of game play.   This is not a casual game. It will punish you severely for ignorance so information is the true in-game currency. On the brightside it's designed so that if you screw up a character then your next one gets a lot of benefits to help you get back to the higher levels in a fraction of the time.

SKULLGIRLS Developed by: Reverge Labs Lab Zero Games Review by: Aaron Matthew Holmes  Skullgirls, a 2D fighter game developed by Reverge Labs, Lab Zero Games, and published by: Autumn Games, Konami, Marvelous AQL (PC), and CyberFront (Japan), was originally released in April 2012 for the Playstation Network and Xbox Live. The game has recently rereleased on Windows and STEAM systems this year. The game, in a fantasy setting, takes place in the 1940’s post-war America. Skullgirls features 14 characters, one non-playable (Marie), and 5 DLC characters. Skullgirls allows the player to experience single-player and multiplayer battles, however, single player allows the player to view each characters story as they progress through battle after battle.  For the review of Skullgirls, I’ve played through the game with one of the most iconic characters in the game, or at least, one that I’ve seen cosplayed numerous times at conventions; Ms. Fortune. I can’t necessarily avoid spoilers as the game has been out at least a year at this point, so feel free to continue reading past this point, or skip to the end for my overall review/rating of the game.  Skull-Girls-2  Playing through Skullgirls, and selecting one the character Ms. Fortune, it’s immediately seen just how quickly this game is violent, yet comedic at the same time (see above image). Ms. Fortune attempts to intervene with a creepy guy hitting on an innocent waitress, only to be beheaded, however, there is some fort of magic that allows her to control both her body and head even while detached to then attack and beat the crap out of the man. Skull-Girls-3  As the storyline continues, Ms. Fortune finds a strong opponent, known as a “Skullgirl” who possesses strong powers, strong enough that they could grant wishes (at least from my first playthrough and understanding).  Skull-Girls-4  After the battle, Ms. Fortune is presented the opportunity to take control of the same power as the Skullgirl to grant her any wish, but decidedly doesn’t use the, obviously evil, power for that. She decides to continue life as she has.  Skull-Girls-5  I’ll definitely be playing this game, in single player only, with the other characters to see how the other stories turn out and to see what kind of twists there are within each. The developers of this game have found a good balance of storytelling and comedy with this fighting game, and it’s definitely changed my thoughts, positively, on fighting games, if only for this game.  Audio: 4/5 Well used audio, several variations for attacks, hitting, and being hit. Soundtrack is lively and fits with the battles and story scenes. Only thing that’s missing is well-done voice acting to finish this off for a perfect 5.  Story: 4/5 The stories vary from character to character, and are humorous throughout the game. The game does, however, throw you into matches with different characters without explaining why you’re fighting them, or how you encountered them. The game does this with specific battles only it seems.  Controls: 3.5 -> 4.5 My rating on the controls is based off the fact that I’m not a master at fighting games, in fact, I’m a “button masher” who just gets lucky when playing these types of games. The game does offer a tutorial system for battling, but when you need to memorize what key on your keyboard or gamepad matches the in-game ‘key terminology’, it becomes confusing and a game of “let’s see what this button does!”. The controls are much more suited for those who are familiar with the fighter genre and can master combos, skills, and moves with the different characters.  Graphics: 5/5 The graphics in this game are beautiful and well designed, especially when it comes down to the characters themselves. The cutscene artwork, level artwork, and overall graphic design of the game is not inconsistent in any way shape or form, and a great use of the talents of the artists who worked tirelessly on this game.  Overall Score: 4.5/5 This game, while definitely suited toward the Fighter-Game audience, can be played by those with little or no experience, so long as the difficulty is set low enough, and provides a humorous yet enjoyable experience for those who give it a try.
