I found this to be well worth playing, but it left me somewhat unsatisfied in the end and wishing there had been far more content. After finishing one playthrough, I immediately started a new one but quickly realized that the game would not grab my interest enough for a second one any time soon, though it is partially my fault perhaps.  As you can see from my 'hours on record', I finished the game in under 27 hours (subtracting the aborted second playthrough), so I'm not quite sure where they got the 80 hours of gameplay idea from. As noted below, I take shortcuts when playing, but I wouldn't expect those to shave 50 hours off of play time, more like a quarter at most.  As a casual gamer, I very much enjoyed the tactical combat aspect. I actually prefer a 'heroic' gameplay approach in which my squad usually has the tactical upper hand, as opposed to more hard core players who prefer to have to struggle hard to reach objectives (I just don't have time for that - thus part of the reason play time was shorter, but not all the reason IMHO). As such, I tend to tweak player stats early on to give them a bit of an advantage (just a bit!). I actually found that this makes combat far more exciting for me at least. I would very much prefer a game in which one good shot will lay you, or the enemy, flat, as it would in real life, and tweaking stats can create such a situation (unfortunately for the player squad only). I find the concept of spamming heals on party members to survive an encounter to be *extremely* unrealistic and immersion breaking in anything but a fantasy setting, so the tweaked stats allowed be immersive roleplaying of a heroic squad versus more average opponents. I loved the increasingly effective gear replacements and the gun modification mechanics, as well as the various differences in the tactics required for the weapons, which also helped immersion greatly. Someone else here said that gun ranges seemed the same, but for me, the chance to hit was eliminated as a factor through tweaking, so I could see clearly that ranges were in fact quite important. This suggests to me that some tweaking of balance might actually make this game better for some people. Just for comparison, there are plenty of other RPGs I've played in the past, with tweaks/mods/God abilities etc., where long term playability was in no way effected by that. A truly good game should accomodate all sorts of play styles. Anyway, overall, I found the tactical aspect to be the most satisfying part of the game. Being able to preposition my squad and then draw the enemy into a shooting gallery was actually quite fun. Granted, that also points out the weak enemy AI others have mentioned. The AI does more typically rush into their weapon range and then end up unable to fire because they've run out of action points, making them sitting ducks out in the open. However, in situations where they are already in range and under cover, they will remain there, and they did seem to seek cover if it was close by.  I generally do not like scripted games at all. I prefer open world/sandbox almost exclusively, but I make an exception for this genre due to nostalgia from the original Fallout series. Others below have complained about the overall story and how it seems to be window dressing on the tactical combat experience. This was generally fine for me, and I was glad that it was perfectly possible to play encounters in a different order then the 'standard story line' in many cases (but not all). At the least, doing things out of order did not seem to break anything for me (such as being unable to finish important objectives - with one noteable exception below).  On the downside, though, I found that navigation was slow and at times extremely confusing (and thus quickly boring). I found myself repeatedly referring to walkthroughs and the like to figure out what the criptic instructions of NPCs was meant to tell me. It was also very common for important instructions to quickly scroll by to be missed, so I was not even sure what I was supposed to be doing. The worst was a large map midgame where it is possible to get very, very confused and commit immersion breaking mistakes, requiring a reload to an earlier save.  The other immensely annoying aspect of the game was the constant lock picking, alarm deactivating, trap removal. Those activities actually took up a huge chunk of each map to the point that, considering that the contents of chests were often literally junk, I ended up skipping over only to miss the occasional important item. Thus, this became an extremely tedious negative experience which greatly subtracted from the overall fun. Also, the question of whether a given container was trapped/locked/alarm protected did not seem to follow any kind of logic.  Also, let's face it, this genre and the game mechanics that go with it are really becomming outdated, and this game, while providing a somewhat modernized and, IMHO, polished execution of it, still does not make up for the fact that the mechanics are artificially held back to a kind of simulation of 1990s technology. This to me is the greatest cause for the lack of depth in character development and other such aspects pointed out by others. While 3D rendered, this *is* really a glorified isometric game in presentation, and I found the low resolution of the characters to be a bit confusing in that it is not as if someone is going to be playing this on an Android phone (or is it?) I think they could have upped the resolution of the characters by a bit, and for instance have more of them appear to reflect what they were wearing.  Edit: While I'm on the subject of graphics, I have to say that the base model used for player characters is *UGLY*. There is really only one head shape each for male/female, with a few different skins slapped on seemingly slightly off center, and I had a really hard time coming up with characters that came anywhere close to someting I could identify with (this is an RPG after all). This is not a big deal, so I mention this only as a minor complaint. The other thing I found to be *extremely* distracting was that the NPC portrait displayed on screen when conversing with that NPC invariably looked nothing like the 3D character, including clothing, colors, hairstyle, etc. This to me was just sloppy and incomplete. Rather than putting an emphasis on having portraits that would get lots of likes on Devient Art, they should have gone for volume and made sure that every unique NPC had a unique portrait. Judging by some of the really bad portraits available in the initial character creation screen, my guess is that they hired an expensive artist to do these portraits and ran out of money. That was definitely a design mistake.  Certainly the game is visually beautiful to look at (when zoomed out), but after having played the Fallout reboot series and other Bethesda RPGs, which provide a relatively modern immersive 3D first&third person experience in a fully unscripted open world, it becomes increasingly difficult to be fully pulled in by this old-school, scripted, controlled viewport experience.  Not only that, but the freedom of the Bethesda approach has allowed very deep modibility which extends the playability of the games for many years, whereas this game ended up being just a minor distraction over a couple of weeks, sort of like a short TV miniseries.

I was crossing my fingers and toes that this would be good, I played and played doom 1 and 2 to death, I found every secret and spent hours combing the maps to find secret levels. I was absolutely delighted to find that the game shares old dooms penchant for absolute chaotic violence and in equal measure encourages you to scour the maps for cleverly hidden secrets. Power ups, secret levels, fan service 'in jokes' and nostalgia combine to smash your face with the best unadulterated kill fest and treasure hunt in decades... Forget the haters, most weren't alive to experience the thrills of the original. Hats off to Marty and the team at id for modernising and paying homage to a classic.. Well done boys and girls.. Buy this game.  Haven't touched the multiplayer or the 'snap map' component... But really that's not what this game is about.. It's all about the campaign..   More of the same please!!

I've played this games over 30h and I can safely say that this game is good. Not the best fighter I've playde, but best game of STORM series. Actually this game has her own advantages and disadvantages:  Advantages:  - New detailed graphics  - New fighting system (Main leader change)  - New Story Mode  - Online  -Adventure Mode  Disadvantages:  - FPS problems on start (after first patch, problem was solved)  - Frequent game crashes (mostly in Online Mode)  - In Online Mode exclude possibility to mute your opponent  - Adventure Mode is really boring  This game is last in STORM series and actually she could be better. I will say that I liked the game despite all disadvantages and I hope this is not the last NARUTO game.

Finally I can fulfill my dream of being a professional net master!  The game starts with only simulation mode unlocked - you're faced with front kickers trying to score a net and once you grab their balls 5 times it unlocks arcade mode. Arcade mode fires balls from cannons and the cannons can turn into power ups - fling the balls back at these to enable Matrix style bullet time mode, tiny net mode, beach balls, giant hands, tennis balls or put 6 wall panels up that deflect one ball then break.   Story mode gives you 2 rooms full of arcade and simulated kickball modes with loads of challenges, such as 'save 5 balls against Japan' and 'catch 4 in a row and don't let your balls drop'.   Multiplayer mode gives you a code, like in Just Dance Now, which another person enters into the Android or Apple version of the game on their mobile - they kick the ball and you master the net to stop them.   To simulate a full size net place, the game accelerates your movement if your room is not massive - you can turn this down in increments or off completely if you enjoy breaking your face on furniture/walls. I would recommend making sure Steam VR is set up so the orientation has no physical walls to the left or right of you - it's better to punch your mate who is watching from the sofa than it is to break your controller on a wall.   One thing, from the video promoting the game, they obviously want women to play but there's no way to play as a woman (everyone refers to me as 'he').   I would like to see more additions in arcade mode, such as Trump mode (tiny hands) and a variety of stadiums and players of both gender - the weather variety is nice, though since it can be sunny, raining or snowy.

app_name: Call of Duty: Black Ops III
review_text: With all the recent flops undeserving of the COD Title, Black Ops III is a breath of fresh air. Both Multi player and Zombies are very well made with all the details and options we've been waiting for. With multiplayer zombies map modding coming out, it has the potential to be one of those rare games worth thousands of hours.
With its sometimes mind-numbing puzzles, fast paced action, and pitch-black humour, this game is a worthy successor to the first.

Early Access Review

The STORY:  Like most transformers things (besides the animated movie), the story is garbage. It is just megatron trying to turn the planet into cybertron again. no biggie. You stop him and there is drama and a big ending finish. Not a selling part of the game. Honeslty, I watched the story on my first play through just because but I could have skipped it and been happy.  The CHARACTERS: You get to play as the transformers DUH! You get to be a dinosaur, a VW beetle, a Ferrari, a jet, a semi truck. I mean come on. One good thing that seperates this from the stupid ♥♥♥ movie transformers is that bumble bee is his old goofy self again. He is also literally the only transformer I like. If you like the transformers than that is great.  The GAMEPLAY: OK. THis is where ti shines. The gameplay is absolutely amazing. I have not played a game with gameplay this fast in a very long time. It is very refreshing knowing that people still make games like this. You play as a transformer, who through his actions must fight off the bad guys. I mean its not deeper than that, but that is all you need. The fighting, at times, is so fast, it is almost impossible for my brain to keep up. The dodging has to be spot on, the aiming has to be spot on. It is a game that actually takes skill to play. It is very fast paced and I have noticed that it overall made me a better video game player because of it. It has made my reflexes much faster. I would compare the fighting to hard mode on DDR. If you havent played that, then try it. The fighting needs your constant attention, if you look away for 1 second you are sure to die. This of course is on hard mode. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME BELOW HARD. I tried it on easy and it was waaaaaaay to easy. I had to reset after chapter 1. Here is an example of how hard it is. I beat chapter 1 in like 10 minutes on easy. It took me like 3 hours on hard. I beat the VERY first fight in the game where you just fight grunts on easy in no time at all. After setting it to hard, I died 4 times. I died probably over 30 times fighting the last battle of chapter 1. After the game I was like, 'cool. I just beat it on hard I am a cool guy'. Then it told me I unlocked 2 harder difficulties. Great! So hard mode is VERY hard but it is not unobtainable hard. These new modes I am sure will make me wish I was dead. In the hardest mode you die if you get hit even once. There is also TONS of unlockables. You get challenge mode which lets you play different challenges with different characters to unlock cool weapons and stuff. It is super fun. 50 challenges in all. It took me an hour just to do 4 on all difficulty modes. You get to keep your weapons and stuff to help you through the harder things. There is NO tutorial. You can upgrade your weapons and even make your own weapons and perks and even your characters level and stats, like strength, speed, courage, int, ect. It is very RPG based like that. Once again, there is no tutorial but you can figure it out. I had no idea you could upgrade stuff until the middle of the game. I figured it out after just messing around in the menu and I became a BEAST and I was one bad a## mofo ready to take on all the constructobots at the same time. You also get tons of weapons and perks. They are limitless all with different attributes and whatnot. It's crazy. If you wanted to level every character to max and get all the best weapons and beat everything on the hardest difficulties, it would literally take thousands of hours. I almost forgot, there are 2 space battles in the game. Almost made me J*ZZ.  The MUSIC: It is a ROCK and TECHNO mix. It is pretty cool actually.   The GRAPHICS: It is amazing. At times I wasnt sure whether I was watching an actual drawn video game or the cell shaded graphics. It is a throw back to G1 Transformers. It is very nastalgic and very exciting and fun. The graphics will do 60 fps at 1080. It makes for very fluid gameplay.   The CONS: (none really) So the main complaint about this game is that it is very short. This is true, if you only play it on the easiest difficulty. The first time I played it, it took me about 12 hours. That is just the main story. You have challenges and perks to get and all kinds of stuff. It will take you about 10-12 hours to beat on hard, but then you got 2 more difficulties to beat and 50 challenges. I don't even want to think about how long that is going to tae me, but I will have so much fun doing it.  The VERDICT: Amazing game. I waited for it to be 50% off because of all the bad reviews on steam. It is way worth the 50 dollars. I loved it so much I bought it for a friend, so I spent 50 bucks anyway. My only regret for this game is, I wish I would have bought it earlier when I wasn't in school so I could play it all day. I would have gladly paid 50 dollars for it. It has loads of content. Loads and loads. DO NOT LISTEN TO THE NEGATIVES. I am telling you, if you like brawlers and very fast hard gameplay, get this. It is super fun.   95/100

As it stands this is basically unplayable. Performance is slightly improved from the previous version but there are some weird bugs now.  Over 9+ hours of play this is what I have found that I consider game breaking:  1. When you re-load a game the game forgets what ever trades you had set up. So as you may leave the game with a positive trade balance, you will now suddenly find yourself deeply in the hole. 2. The moment I hit more than 500K people living in the city my office start dying for no apparent reason. This has a knockon effect to all the other industries. Basically the only way around this is to 'import' office services, but that quickly eats up your exports (not to mention you cannot sell other stuff as they eat up your precious export slots). 3. Randomly areas go from 'happy with entertainment' to 'not enough entertainment' even if nothing else has changed.  As it stands, it's unplayable. I had it crash once on me as well, but considering how the game itself is broken that's not my biggest annoyance at this point.  If Steam would give refunds, I'd want one.

Dota 2 is a great game. I love it but it's not for everyone. Don't take this the wrong way because it's awesome but you shouldn't play this if you don't want to get screamed at or scream yourself. Everyone in Dota thinks that they know best and some times they do but if you screw up just once (because once is all it takes to loose in Dota) they will tear you a new one before you can apologize. Repentence for this treatment you are given a great moba which is sooooo much better than lol. You actually have to work as a team and everyone matters. The game is won and lost by your very actions. It's great and competitive and super fun. It looks nice and runs nice, it just takes some practice to get good at. Once you are good or atleast reasonable you can just sit back and enjoy (I'm not saying you won't rage at noobs or your own mistakes). 15/15 acing it everyday. Thats Dota 2!

HOLIDAY EXPRESS STANDALONE GAME REVIEW -- NOT A REVIEW OF TRAIN SIM 2014  If you are an old-timer like me, this game will stir nostalgic memories and flights of fantasy involving that much anticipated electric train arriving in Santa's bag with shiney tracks glistening under the twinkling lights of a Christmas tree, the faint smell of ozone as the engine crackled to life, and the artificial smoke beginning to magically flow as the mighty engine began its journey of delight. The game is wonderful at any age where the heart is stirred by a love of trains and a desire to get on the floor and switch on the transformer to start an imaginary adventure. Nope, it isn't the usual serious rail sim fare. While it does use the Train Simulator 2014 UI and does have tools to edit your layout, the game is a more casual and relaxed experience.   You can earn some achievements, gain some experience points, and collect the trading cards in much the same way as the primary game. It may also spark an interest in more serious virtual railroading for those who find the game enjoyable.  At the steeply discounted price of $2.99 for Holiday Express through the rest of the month, it is hard to go wrong with a game that delivers such a fun experience. (Note: You do not need to own Train Simulator 2014 to play this standalone game.) And who knows, it might just be a good fit as a virtual stocking stuffer for your gaming friends.   My last experience with Train Simulator was with a much earlier version. I have to say this sure is improved and a lot more fun. I have a feeling that every once in awhile in the days before Christmas I'll be punching that left controller stick to hear the train horn/whistle and with childish glee guiding an engine around curves and up inclines just for the fun of it.  That said, it does have some rough edges that might make it a little tough for the youngest players. The on-screen directions will tell you to stop at a marker, which you can see in the 2D map, but which isn't visible in the 3D view. In the 2D view, you can't see your speed to know what you should be doing. The controls while easy to use with a controller could do with more granularity in managing speed and braking - the jumps with the slightest touch are fairly big. So mom or dad probably will need to be nearby to give a little bit of coaching on using the controls for young players just starting out.
If you've ever played a zelda game, and love open world exploration, you NEED to own this game.

Absolutely abysmal. Graphics I can forgive; no, I don’t think this game is crap because the blood is pixelated. On the contrary, I think the art assets are stunningly well done for the limited resolution they had to work with. And yes, I understand this game is old, but that is no excuse for how dreadful the controls are. Everything about how the character rotates with the mouse, and the animation not actually depicting where you’re going to shoot, Postal is just miserable. I normally try to give a game at least an hour, more if the genre demands it, but I could not wait to be done with this game. Had it not been part of a bundle, I would not have been happy with purchasing this game.

This game was something I didn't think id be interested in, Being a big fan of hotline miami's fast paced action the thought of stopping to hide bodies didn't seem interesting to me but I picked the game up in the sales for cheap and im glad I decided to play it. It has a multitude of levels to play as well as some bonus levels and the workshop which lets you play other people's levels. With the base levels you get about 6 or so hours worth of playtime though each person might struggle with different levels, miami beach for example, I beat it on my third attempt in about 13 minutes but i've heard some people saying they were stuck on it for an hour and a half.  I had an issue with my PC which made me lose all my data on my hard drive and when I got back up and running I installed Party Hard to find that I had lost my progress ( I was finished the final stage and about to start the bonus stages.) But I kept all my unlocked characters so I got to experience the story a second time in about 2 days it was still fun.  There are unlockable character's, The guy trying to get some sleep, The cop, the ninja,   Katie   and the butcher, each character plays differently i.e. the cop can carry bodies without suspicion but can't use traps.   Not many games compel me to finish entirely and get all achievement's but this one was definitely good enough to make me do it, Toward the end of the game I already had a good 10 or so achievements out of the 26 I believe and that was with me only trying to get one (the 20 kills combo to unlock the butcher) the others came naturally though the game.   The soundtrack is pretty great though It did start to get a bit repetitive towards the end of missions considering it's a pretty small loop but it's not too bad.   I may start to try get all the cards so I can finish the badge next and i'll basically have done all I can with this game.  I would definitely recommend this game to any one who enjoys Hotline Miami or even Hitman and it's definitely worth the price though if you aren't sure if you'll get what you paid for then wait till the sales and buy it then but I guarantee it'll be worth it!

app_name: Call of Duty: Black Ops III
review_text: First thing's first, take the 'recommended' with a grain of salt. I would give it 3 out of 5 stars, but this stupid rating system is binary.  Okay, so a little while back I wrote a review out of saltiness for loosing too many games in a row, and I need to apologize for that. As my apology, I would like to submit this new review with more thought put into it and slightly lower sodium content as well.  So basically, this game is Call of Duty.  What? Is that not good enough for you? Fine, I'll go deeper.  All in all, the game is about what I would expect of Call of Duty, you run around various maps and shoot the enemies. That's all there really is to do in this case, because for some reason the only game mode anyone on PC plays is Team Deathmatch.  There's some new features, like any sequel, like paint jobs and weaponsmithing, but after I was reeled in by the game's supposed gun customization and black market, but I bought the thing and it went 'aha, I tricked you! Those features are laughable at best and I'm just another Call of Duty!' Basically all weaponsmithing did was show you what attatchments you could put on a gun, and it turned out to be no different form just applying attatchments and a camo to a gun the normal way, since you couldn't use your crafted gun until you unlocked it and all of the corresponding attatchments. The paint shop was interesting I guess, and you can make your guns have some pretty cool designs if you're willing to invest an hour or three, but half the time my designs won't even bother to show up in-game. There's also contracts that update daily and weekly, so there's always some kind of goal you can give yourself if reaching max prestiege and level 1000 (FREAKING LEVEL 1000!) isn't enough motivation for you. Once completing these contracts, you get tokens which you give to the black market merchant (which I say loosely because he's basically just some snarky jerk in a hoodie) and you get to open a futuristic treasure chest with a chance to get weapon camos, customization items for your soliders, and other types of astetic items, most of which you will never use because they're for a gun nobody ever uses and frequently get duplicates of. But you can also get melee weapons which are super cool, but the chance you'll actually get one is next to none unless you have so many tokens you either never stop playing or you spend your entire paycheck IRL buying them.  Speaking of the weapons, I feel like there's a clear distinction between guns that are good and guns that are bad. Back in Black Ops 2, you could use basically any gun and do well, but now there's a clear best sniper, best pistol, and so on. As for the actual gameplay, it's just the regular COD formula except you can wall run like in Titanfall, jump around like in Halo, and you can play as a selection of specialists with uniqe abilities and weapons like in Rainbow Six Seige. Boy, COD sure did rip off other games this time around. But you can swin underwater in some areas a bit and I think that's origional, but I never really used it because the controls get a little rebellious at that point. I never really got used to the whole movement part, but it is amusing to wall run once in a while, even though it usually gets me shot in the face.  Visually, I don't have a ton to complain aboout in BO3. The graphics are nice I guess, but it's a little hard to appreciate them when people are trying to murder you with automatic weapons and high-caliber rifles. Speaking of which, snipers somehow became wizards in this game. It seems like all they have to do is point the barrel of their gun in my general direction and the bullet would find it's way to my frontal lobe on its own. This led me to believe that sniping was really easy in this game, but it actually feels harder than it's ever been, leading me to wonder how the heck those people pulled it off. Until I watched a few killcams and saw they actually just put red dot sights on their sniper rifles, thus completely taking away any difficulty in aming the thing and defeating the purpose of it being a 'sniper' rifle.  However, the thing that sets it apart from all other CODs is that this fish has some personality. There are wild camos to be unlocked, ridiculous outfits and taunts for your characters, and no shortage of crazy melee weapons. They're rare if you don't spend every waking second grinding for those stupid tokens, but seeing your soldier dabbing to celebrate a victory on the podium is worth it in my book. And a quick word of advice, do give the melee weapons a shot. I know it seems stupid in a game about shooting things, but going melee only is probably the most fun I have in this game and I found that I usually led my team in kills by doing this. Aside from the combat knife and boxing gloves which the game just gives you, the melee weapons I had were the Nightbreaker, some kind of ancient weapon made of bone and flint that kind of looks like a prehistoric Halo energy sword, and a spooky dagger called 'Malice,' which I prefered to use. I would pair this with perks that protected me from enemy radar and one that silenced my every movement so I could sneak up on unsuspecting enemies, stabbing the filthy snipers as they tried to collect clips for their sick montages. I would also play the specialist whose special weapon was another melee blade, except you didn't need to switch to it and could just press a button to lock onto an enemy and dash forward to pierce their chest. I found that I prefered the 'up-close-and-personal' method of combat; I guess there's a part of me that is refreshed by being able to see the fear in my enemies' eyes as I take vengence on them with a presumably cursed dagger named after the thing I feel for most people I play against.  But all things considered, it was essentially just another Call of Duty. It introduced a few new features, but after a while it just all morphs together and feels sort of 'meh.' I'd recommend just getting the $15 multiplayer-only version of the game (if it still exists) and get a friend or two to play with you, otherwise you'll just end up like me: a lone, salty soldier whose only ambition is to take revenge on other players and open more futuristic treasure chests.

I didn't believe other players who posted that the jump 'puzzles' were terrible, and now I have a $14.99 game to forever haunt me which I will never finish. Listen to the others. Heed the warning I did not. They're not puzzles. You just switch 'dimensions' that make one wall phase out of existence and the other wall phase into existence while jumping rapidly from wall to wall while having to change directions. It's aggravating and awful, and these jumps are all throughout the game after you beat the first boss. I can tell this would be a good game if not for thes horrible jumps. If you believe you have the reflexes of The Flash, Superman, Spider-Man, and Neo all rolled into one, then go right ahead. Otherwise, avoid if you like keeping your money in favor of games that will just ♥♥♥♥ you off and disappoint.

app_name: Total War: ROME II - Emperor Edition
review_text: I will say. This game was a complete let down. I've been a total war fan since the original Shogun Total War to Shogun 2 Total War... I have purchased every total war game you can name. I thought Empire Total War was my biggest let down until I invested 63 hours of my own time in a constant repeat of the same turn over and over again... hoping it would work its self out. I have invested 812 hours of my time into Shogun 2 Total War which to this day I still love. My last few hundered hours I'd play with my buddy(s) and we would constantly talk about awaiting the release of Rome 2. How awesome Rome 2 will be. How we will conquere the ancient roman era.... Instead we constantly have desync issues.... We can't even manage to get through a fifth of our campaign.... before we have to trash it and attempt another. I am now at the point I don't even intend on attempting another coop campaign with anyone and actually look at just uninstalling the game all together. I love playing Total War Games.... Ever since Shogun 2.... I can't play a Total War campaign alone.... It isn't the same with out your buddy.... no matter how many minutes they take to go through with their turn. If your a kind of person who enjoys playing by your self on a game.... by all means buy it.... but if your looking at taking over the world with your best friend.... then there is no reason to attempt the game. Sorry for the let down ladies and gentlemen.....

After completing this game I can say that this was an emotional thrill ride. All of my emotions where trigered through out the playthrough of this game (mostly anger, and scared-out-of-my-♥♥♥♥-im-going-to-lose-at-59-seconds). I was confused (at why someone would take my money and torture me), happy (after finishing the first level) and sad (because, this game touched me where i pee pee (metaphorically)).  This game follows the story of a helpless little triangle and his day to day strugles with living in a world in a world filled with square, pentagon and hexagon shaped odjects, and how he found a path in all the chaos and flashing colours (seizure warning). Every 'minute' of his little life is filled with faster and faster moving objects, and you, must help him find a way through it (while crying you self to sleep each night because you can't finish the third level).  Yes, this game truely is, ...yes.  If you have the mental ability to withstand an arrow to the knee, and have the physical ability the catch a fly with chop sticks, you may be able to win this game.

A classic gem who's first Flash installment I still have on my laptop.  An addictive and extensive tower defense game set in a fantasy world, wherein you are a gem crafter; A mage that uses magical gems to cast spells. Gems that can be upgraded and combined to form more powerfull versions, which can then be used to arm empty towers, road traps or thrown as bombs.  An extensive story line, great graphics and musical score, and tremendous flexibility in how you proceed through the world and each scene.  A huge amount of achievements and the addition of talismen and special towers have extended this into an even more flexible and enjoyable series.  My only hope is to see more of these fantastic Flash games grow out of their original platform base.

app_name: METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN
review_text: TL;DR: Story overall good, but sometimes meh and confusing, villain disappointing, characters good, gameplay absolutely amazingly fantastic. Still a full recommendation due to the extreme degree of freedom you as a player have in this game.  Grandiose gameplay, astonishing freedom to approach situations, rarely a restriction that tells you 'you gotta be stealthy or else instant failure bro' (happens in 'total stealth' mode and the opening mission). Being a sneaky Snake fails? Well, just roll with it and shoot soldiers in the face. You can still complete the mission, it just might not be an S-rank anymore and be a little harder as well. The buddies are a great help - Quiet is universally helpful, the dog is the ultimate stealth companion sniffing out any enemies within 60-80m and D-Horse can get vehicles to spin out if it takes a dump on the road. Never even touched the D-Walker mecha you get later on, probably very useful for a louder approach.  The story/characters will be confusing if you haven't at least read up on the story of previous Metal Gear games. It also could use a bit more focus, espeially in the second chapter where you mostly replay old missions with added difficulties (meh!). A few story threads could have been tied up better (chapter three was axed, after all). The cassette tapes that you can listen to greatly expand the lore of the game and easily span a few hours of material.  Oh and I really was ashamed when I found out why Quiet was left half-naked by the developers. Ashamed for them. I might have bought that reasoning if she had been treated well by the game's camera, but she's reduced to eye candy and fanservice for drooling teens and pre-teens who don't have internet access way too often.  Online invasion mode is something I could really do without. Not that well implemented, often not that well balanced and riddled with connectivity issues.  Another bugbear are the development times and dispatch mission times. Weapon/Gadget development is instant at first, but later requires up to two and a half hours of time in which the game needs to be running and not paused. At least 15 of my 130+ hours were spent AFK or on the desktop, allowing development to happen while I didn't want to actively play.

app_name: Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~
review_text: Even from the preview I saw, I knew I would love this game, and was extremely excited for it (which I haven't been THAT excited for a game in a long time). Bascially, if you want to know some stuff about Japan, and want to be taught about it by some cute girls that you can forge a relationship with, then this is right up your alley!  You play the role of a guy who's trying to learn Japanese, so he decided to go to Japan to be mentored by two brothers he met in an internet chat room. But, lo-&-behold, these two guys were actually sisters! You get to pick 3 of 6 places to take tours around before your time in Japan is up. Now, if you wanted to just learn about Japan, this is awesome enough as it is. BUT. Depending on which places you choose to tour, you develop a relationship with one of the two girls! TOO MUCH AWESOME. Not to mention, the endings are simply adorable. If you're someone like me who enjoys cute and innocent romances like 'Ai Yori Aoshi' or 'Clannad,' I can just about guarantee you'll fall in love with this game! ...And one of the two girls! ;D  The soundtrack is amazing (I would have the game on in the background just to listen to the tunes), the visuals are great, and if you're actually trying to learn Japanese, it's great because in the dialogue, you can view the Japanese right above the English! The info they give you is fantastic, and the romance storylines are really nice!  All in all, I highly recommend this game! I sure had a blast playing it, and now I kind of want to learn Japanese so I can play through it while reading the top text. Not only that, I also have the goal of going to Japan in real-life to get firsthand experience. This game is a great way to get introduced to a new culture, and I surely hope they expand on this game in the future! Maybe a sequel or add-ons...? I hope so!

Getting proper enjoyment out of Space Hulk: Deathwing requires one to jump through some hoops. Luck needs to be on your side so that you won’t run into performance issues, with a good tolerance for repetitive content and, preferably, some friends to play multiplayer with also being required. And even then, there’s still the issue of the AI that turns the game into a snooze fest very easily. Space Hulk: Deathwing’s biggest redeeming factor lies in its visuals which provide a faithful representation of the Warhammer 40k universe that is bound to please fans. Take a few steps further than that, however, and you’re bound to run into disappointment.  Full Review  [www.noobfeed.com] .

Monaco is a difficult game to describe because it doesn't fall into a well-tread genre, but it's part puzzle game, part top-down action game, and overall a lot of fun. Up to four players form a team of criminals attempting a heist, and the game is a race to collect all of the money and treasure without getting caught by the gaurds. It's heavily designed around online multiplayer, and the open lobby system makes it easy to get matched up with random partners in crime.  One of the best things about the game is how it handles difficulty and varying player skill. Aside from levels that get progressively harder as the storyline unfolds, success in each mission is less about getting through the mission at all and more about doing it as quickly and effeciently as possible. So if you end up with a mix of veteran players and n00bs, everyone can still do their own thing and feel like they are contributing even if some players are doing more of the work. The time/speedrun system works well for replayability, because once you become better at the game it's a lot of fun to use your new skills to plow through some of the earlier levels.  There are eight different characters in the game all with different abilities, and the balance between characters is pretty good so that there are not obvious best and worst characters. Also each level has different aspects that can make certain characters more advantageous, although it's always possible to complete the levels with any set characters. There's also an entertaining and somewhat convoluted storyline for the game that gives each character a unique personality.  The core gameplay and level design are both top notch and that's why the game makes you want to keep playing levels to try for better times. I would recommend it to anyone who likes action-y games, especially if you are looking for an online co-op game. Even for people who don't generally like online multiplayer games it can be a good intro into that kind of game because you can start out as a novice and not feel like you're in way over your head. Great game and I look forward to more games from Pocketwatch.

Sort of like Passage, but fun and a JRPG. Takes all the best parts of random item drops, grinding, and stat boosts and cuts off all the excess, leaving you with a fast-paced, enjoyable gem of a game. It's probably the lightest rogue-lite I've ever played, complete with - fairly plentiful - opportunities to save at no penalty (if there's an unlockable difficulty with no saves, play that, though it really  should  have been unlocked from the start if it does exist, and included if it doesn't) - but it's still challenging enough, and the procedurally generated worlds are surprisingly satisfying to carve your way through. Definitely worth getting, even at twice the asking price.

The story is ok. Graphics are ok. Gameplay is ok. I had read the reviews before I got it so I think that I knew what to expect.  The two biggest flaws in the game are around sound and combat. I don't like music in the games and sound effects/ voice acting were not there. It was like playing a game with no sound at all. Combat was a little too dumbed down for me. Would have liked more depth.  There is slight customization of the main character, but no open world elements that would drive you to want to replay it. Story line is designed to be linear with only slight variation in how you can solve problems. Combat v puzzle.  I see this geared more to a younger audience. Others might tire of the repetition after the first two areas.  I recommended the game, not because I loved it, but because it delivers on what it is.

Not a bad game, 7/10.

Okay, so we all know this game has some issues, so let's start there.  Cons: -Constant crashes in multiplayer -Multiplayer not connecting at all -A meh at best single player experince -Weird tyranid spawns -Poor optimization -Vermintide-esque horde splatterhouse <-- (enjoyable game btw)  Now let's talk about the good stuff.  Pros: -Absolutely stunning and immersive Warhammer 40K environment -Decent singleplayer AI (for the terminators) -Sometimes surprising Tyranid AI(i.e. flanking, ambushes, etc) -Fun multiplayer experience (when it works) -Nice voice acting (I want some combat dialogue damnit)  This game is new, and they have been working on it for a while, but I think it can become an excellent Space Hulk game. The base is definitely there and we have never seen a Warhammer environment so passionately designed before. It needs patching, like any newly released game. It needs optimizing, it needs some fuggin Terminator combat dialogue. But it's a good start. There are times I really feel like I'm in a Space Hulk and there are times when I know they're showing off beautiful level design. The AI needs some work, and these phasing Tyranids are most likely a performance thing, but my god if that motion detector wasn't there you'd eat tyranid scheiße way sooner. I'm gonna keep playing, andi'm gonna hope for the best.

Wait for a sale unless more depth is added.

I'm writing this to address all the short-play reviews that are giving downvotes that the game doesn't deserve.  If you're looking for a free, easy game to zone out on while you listen to other things, then this is the one for you. It's light weight, cute, and has very simple mechanics that are transferable from other games, so if you've played any platformer, you should be able to master this game quickly.  A lot of people whine that you have to pay money for 'cubics' (the in-game currency) to buy anything useful, but that's completely untrue. Virtually every block can be found in-game or crafted from blocks found in-game. The only things really worth spending your cubics on would be more personal realms (beyond the initial free one given to each player), extra rooms for your realms, or cosmetic items. Blocks found in-game CAN be purchased with cubics by the extra lazy, but it's so easy to find the blocks you want that there's no reason to.  In the first day of play (about 5 hours of zone-out time), I managed to get over 1,000 cubics and level up several times, unlocking 'perks' which allowed me to craft more advanced blocks, tools, and toys. Once I had these things unlocked, I was able to get more ambitious with my building projects making a castle that rests on narrow outcroppings of rock above a lake of lava. It was easy and fun to make and made my personal realm a hang out spot for the friends I made in-game.  My greatest complaint for Cubic Castles, without a doubt, has to be the extremely shoddy camera control. Nowhere in the tutorial does it explain how to control your camera and for the first day or so, I assumed there was a fixed camera. While there are benefits for having an overhead view of your character and landscape, I think the game would benefit greatly from a first-person or third-person view. In its current state, navigating below-ground or under any sort of structure can get in the way of the camera and obstruct your view entirely.  Another feature that is lack-luster is the PvP combat system which revolves entirely around 'wands' that can only be crafted by experienced players and are not very intuitive in actual combat resulting in a high chance of missing. Also, there's completely no penalty for dying or benefit from killing another player.   Overall, though, I have to recommend the game because it IS entertaining and it's so light that even weak rigs can run it at the same time as another video or livestream or even another game.

Always online functionality - check! Servers don't work - check Lots of outdated filler cards - check UI and graphics from 2001 - check  Let's ship that game!   Blizzard must be laughing their a**es off.   Edit March 2016:  Still cannot recommend the game.  While the server difficulties are solved, the game is still lacking in many ways.  There are annoying card bugs that have been there since the launch. Stainless stay true to themselves and don't bother fixing even the most annoying bugs. (They have done the same in all their past Magic games, for example they have not and will never fix some glaring bugs in 2012 and 2013 editions, one of which makes a whole (paid DLC!) deck unplayable, others make some cards useless. So there is no reason to think this will improve.)  The card selection is overall better now, but the game is still dominated by only about 3-4 standard decks. Add this to the very slow gameplay with very long timers and it makes for boring and frustrating play. There are of course still a lot of useless filler cards, but overall it's doable to unlock all cards with reasonable effort, but this gets harder and harder for new players, so I'm not sure how the playerbase is supposed to grow. Ranking mode is pretty useless, the levels don't really reflect your skill as there is no ELO system.  No chat, no lobbies, no 3 or 4 player, no archenemy.  Simply not fun in this state.  I hope Wizard pulls the plug on this one and lets a better studio have a go.

So, I just finished this bememoth of a CRPG. And I find myself in a bit of a pickle. Usually when I finish a game, if I've stuck with it for its duration, I feel very strongly one way or another as to whether or not it was good.  I don't feel that way this time.  So then, how do I review a title that both provided some of the most enjoyable RPG action I've played in years, but that also occasionally threw up a baffling design decision that detracted greatly from the overall experience?  The answer, I think, is that I recommend the game, but warn you lovely people.  Divinity: Original Sin wants you to like it. That's immediately evident. The first third of the game is a constant stream of reworked CRPG tropes, a strange mishmash of the familiar, and you know what? That works. That works extremely well. It fuses Fallout and Baldur's Gate into something honestly beautiful. It's funny, it's clever, the plot's central mystery unfolds with a refreshing lack of cynicism and delicacy that's all too devoid from most modern games, it looks great, it runs smoothly, and most importantly, the combat is an absolute treat. Learning to use elements to manage enemy lines and unleash ridiculous combo attacks is one of the best things I've done in a game this year.  But Divinity starts to fail you. It creeps up slowly. Around the 40-50 hour mark, you start to notice that very little has actually been happening. The game spirals to a satisfying enough conclusion, but the sense of adventure and refreshing take on the old-school is slowly lost.  And then Divinity decides to flip players the proverbial bird and introduce loads of forced stealth sections, the most egregious of which found me actually holding my finger to the quicksave key.  Some would argue this is part of the experience. I'd counter that things change for a reason. I didn't play CRPGs in the 90s because I wanted a quicksaving simulator, I played to have an adventure. Divinity offers 30 hours of a truly classic CRPG, and 40 of a middling one.  This is enough for me. The genre has been sorely devoid of great new games for a long time. But, I reiterate, this is a recommendation with an attached clause: don't expect a gamechanger. Don't expect to not have to fight Divinity on its own terms. This is a CRPG, with the warts you've forgotten about securely in place.

I like the look of RPG Maker games and this game used it well. I enjoyed the use of the many terrains.  I did not like the main character, Arres. He was suffering from memory loss, sense of self, and random behaviors so it was hard to get to know him. So much about him felt like a mismatch.   The story felt somewhat typical with the twist being the labyrinths. I did not like the labyrinths most the time. They were tedious and frequently I was at a loss on what to do or where to go.   The turn-based battles, when they weren't over the top random, were enjoyable. We never got to see the enemies hit points and as a strategist I would have liked to see those but now I'm just whining.  Game has promise but due to unappealing storyline and mindless wandering I can not recommend.

This would be a fine game except for one HUGE issue: there is no way to rebind keys. It is pretty pathetic for a game that just came out last year to have this issue, and it makes certain aspects of this game absolutely miserable and nearly unplayable. Some people may not see this as that big of a problem, but on my laptop where the arrow keys are very small, it becomes an enormous barrier. So much frustration could be cured if movement could be transfered to wasd rather than the arrow keys. It is hard to enjoy the game when pretty simple parts end up killing you because of constant misclicks due to the unchangeable controls.  Otherwise the game is okay, but honestly not that great. It's like a gameboy game on the pc. Not worth the purchase in my opinion.

app_name: Attack on Titan / A.O.T. Wings of Freedom
review_text: I ran the game on two of my machines one with a laptop with i7 6700hq 16gb gtx960m max @ fixed 30fps and my desktop i7 3820 16gb gtx1070 max @ fixed 60fps both ran pretty rock solid once I got things working.   So for the hiccups, firstly I found that my laptop did not detect the game and kept it on low power mode for some reason so i had to force my laptop to run it in performance mode via Nvidia 3D settings. Of course this was only a problem for my laptop.   Second it didnt read 1080p initially in windowed mode, when i set it to fullscreen it became available. It also does not give you the option to utilize higher resolutions than that either.   Third the game does not have a built in v-sync at all, i had to force v-sync using the Nvidia 3D settings to avoid the tearing, luckily it didnt affect framerates or latency in any noticable way.   Fourth on initial startup for both machines I was prompted to set the game on windows 7 compatibility mode for better performance. The game then kinda just switches it for you after accepting it, it was really odd to me.   and Fifth the game is horribly optimized for keyboard and mouse, this is a game you absolutely need a gamepad to play.  once you get past that stuff the game itself isnt too bad, the controls are a bit unorthodox but its something you can really get used to within the first 10-20 minutes of gameplay. You really wouldnt think this was made by koei since all they ever do is make 3d hack and slash games.  so far for me it seems to work fine though, the comments though seem pretty unjustified in most instances. The game has its problems though if you have the tolerance to the problems.

Too bad there is no neutral option, so I had to choose to recommend it.  This is a weird one. The game definitely got flaws, a lot of them. It's not very well fleshed out in general, to be honest. But it is very, very compelling where it's at its strongest.  Betrayer is noticeably repetitive and doesn't have many engaging mechanics, and the ending is considered puzzling, cliffhanger or even lackluster by many. But its creepy, atmospheric setting, striking presentation(which you can fine-tune to your liking!) and brilliant sound design more than make up for its flaws. All exposition is provided via text, however, and there is little environmental storytelling. It tries to be an semi-open-world RPG, but to be honest it's much closer to a fetch-quest driven FPS with RPG elements.  It's an atmosperic, immersive story of how flawed humans are. Overall, this game is kinda closer to its artsy-fartsy kin, rather than to mechanichally competent products. In my opinion, it's well worth the asking price, and if you're into this kind of janky creepiness - go ahead and try it.

Short version:  -This game is a great fighting game -Has online problems on launch most likely due to having 2 platforms on the same server alongside just needing time to adapt to the issues concerning the netcode. -All dlc is free. -They said it'd be barebones on launch. -If you're a casual/looking for a single player experience, wait until more features get added in the coming month or so to buy this. -Try using software like xpadder if you're having issues with your stick/controller.  -If you're serious about getting good at this game, buy it now.    To everyone complaining about the lack of content currently in the game, we were all warned a suitable amount of time before release that there'd be little content outside of multiplayer on release. Most people should be aware of that by now, so it's not really a valid arguement at this point. As much as people want to call Capcom out on the lack of features, they didn't actually do anything morally wrong this time lol. DLC is free too, you'll be able to earn it all, so any complaints about these two subjects are basically invalid.   As an actual fighting game, this is solid, the gameplay is fresh, combos cater to the newer players enough and there's still a lot of depth to it; it pleases older and newer fans just fine in my opinion. Alongside having an already diverse cast more characters are actually on the way, Alex is set for release next march. Alongside this, a bunch of other features and extras will be added as time goes on like an actual arcade and story mode alongside the market. The tutorial mode that's available at least teaches you some basics, the rest is kind of for you to figure out really. That's part of the fun of these games anyway, it is sort of poorly done in this case, but it's nothing you can't find out for yourself by asking around/doing research. You'd have to do research at some point anyway if you plan on taking this game half-seriously, so there is that too.   Online mode has been relatively OK for me so far. I used a wired connection, so maybe that's why but I've had hardly any issues with lag. The one time I've lost a match because of it was against some guy in Canada, which isn't too bad given that IV had netcode that made it even more difficult to play with people this far away most of the time. Aside from this one incident I've won all my matches pretty cleanly with hardly any contribution from lag. I also feel like people need to understand that on launch, any online-based game is going to have problems. There's hardly ever been a massively online game that had no online issues right out of the box, because most servers aren't able to handle it well initially. SF has a massive fanbase and it was crossplay too, that means players from two different platforms are going to be on the same server, which sort of justifies how poorly it's been handling the load so far. They'll improve it with time, that much can be certain at this point.   I'm guessing it's because of maintenace but I haven't been able to find a match recently after waiting a while, so I can't really say much as far as actually finding a match. I did however struggle earlier for a while trying to make a lounge with a friend for much longer than it should have taken, which was pretty bad. We did actually get it to work eventually and our matches were pretty smooth. It seems like there's a lot of difficulty finding matches because of what's probably a server-related issue.   About the controller issues, it's not impossible to play with your controllers, you'll just have to use something like xpadder. I use xinput so it hasn't really affected me though.

The framerate in this game is locked at what seems to be 10 FPS. It's hard to tolerate. I've never seen anything this bad. Maybe this game was made in Basic. And as mentioned, this might not work after a bit. The shoulder button is a bit too clumsy for this dextrous task as well. Very unfortunate.  Test PC: i5-750, 760GTX, 8GB RAM Going to let the developer keep my 49 cents. Controller updates would be greatly appreciated. Keep trying.

Attila is very likely to Barbarian Invasion an expansion of an original game, fielding a lot of advantageous updates**.  The difference between both are the price. While BI for Rome 1 was sold as an expansion, Attila is sold as an stand alone expansion quite full priced. Granted you can buy it for about 24 € outside Steam - and legal too - at a lower price Attila is worth it and works out. What does not work out is the optimization.   Attila is more demanding than Rome 2, but offers also better graphics, including MSAA, and more detailed units. While vanilla it looks like it is modded but it is not.   Attila is Rome 2 2.5, without a year of patches. It is much better and whole, but still not worth a 8/10 that was given by the most of the reviewers.  Rome 2 was about civilized scam, Attila is about barbarian scum. Armchair generals will love it. Also the multiplayer works much better and fluid.   I can recommend a buy but not full priced. Look for legal alternatives instead and be prepared you have to lower the graphical settings even on high end computers.    CA officially explained that 'extreme quality' is meant to be played on yet non-existent hardware. Yet 2 settings below that you still can find yourself embarrassed with low framerates.   This all has a high price though: People with AMD processors (not graphics cards) will suffer a lot as they did in Rome 2, on quality settings or below Attila becomes barely playable. I am currently collecting results in the TWcenter benchmark thread.   Warning: 7 DLCs are already reported on SteamDB.info, so get yourself ready for a DLC fest!  +4 many 'new' features that people wanted to have in Rome 2 +1 better music but still repetitive +3 much better graphics, vanilla it looks like modded! +2 multiplayer has been improved a lot: Stability, slightly overhauled chat and lot less lag, and most important no slow motion units so far  -2 on the flipside very high requirements, that are either very GPU limited even on HIGH-END computers (maximum quality preset or extreme preset and even quality preset) OR CPU limited on lower settings like performance and high performance -1 still severe lack of optimization for AMD CPUs, which now kills the game at all for people that have AMD processors. - to high priced as it contains a lot of features that were (intentionally) missing in Rome 2, 7 DLC listed and hidden zero day!   I rate Attila with a mild 7/10 and can still recommend the game without serious pain.

I have read a few reviews on the store page so i thought, even though i have still invested just a couple of hours into the game, I'd write a few lines to point other potential buyers in (what it think is) the right direction.  When you go for Mortal Kombat you really already know what to expect. The game mechanics are tried and tested and there is really no way for you not to have fun.   Want fast paced fights? Check! Want ninjas, monsters, necromancers, shaolin monks and whatnot? Step right over here! Want Fatalites? We gotcha!  Developers brought a few new ideas into the mix this time though, first the brought back brutalities which are simply finishing moves much like fatalities only triggered by combos. Second, they decided to make every character unique by differentiating it with three combat styles that gives the character access to a particular moveset. It might seem like a stupid thing, but having access to a specific set of inputs really changes the whole game. Take Scorpion for example: The ninjutsu style gives him pretty much the same moveset as MK9. A second style instead, gives him access to his two swords that make it easier for him to launch enemies into the air and start juggle combos.  Besides this the game also has multiple modes to keep you entertained. If you want offline play you can meddle with the story mode or try out single matches, the kript, the towers.. really a lot of things to keep you busy here. Online mode is no less, you have faction war (you basically choose a faction and every win in the online mode adds point to you team) with particular events like invasions.   The true weak point of the game is poor optimization. Besides the large game size and the huge patches, the game keeps on running sluggishly. I understand that I am playing this on a portable PC but i'm quite sure the game can definitely run on medium settings at least. Instead i'm stuck on running it with all Visual effects off and at minimum resolution (800x600) just to enjoy it properly. Even with this configuration though, the game has some hiccups at times.  As for DLC's i don't really see the point in whining. One may consider these to be a major or minor weak point, but i just don't care. If you think DLC's are not worthy of your money, the only thing you have to do is not buy them. They don't really cut off any extra parts of the story but just add a handful of fighters... I don't really see what the fuss is all about.  In the end, I think the game itself is worth the price, given that there are interesting ideas and the gameplay is fun. I can see how the optimization will throw off a lot of people but i think it'll get sorted over time.

Controls are clunky and painful, protagonist has an absurdly annoying voice that you will immediately be sick of, when the player walks around while crouching it's one of the most comical animations I've ever seen, and the shooting mechanics suuuuuck.  But it's still one of my favorite games, becaaauuse... 1. It balances player choice with a smooth narrative. No matter what direction you choose, the story always compensates and fills in the gaps with finesse. 2. The skills actually reward you by giving you crappy skills to begin with. You start out as a top operative but can't shoot worth a damn, and then after several missions and a few upgrades, you're finally getting the hang of things and notice a dramatic improvement in the mechanics. 3. The supporting characters dynamically react to how you treat them. This is the closest we will get to scripted AI dialogue where our responses affect the NPC's attitudes and behaviors in conversations and remain consistent throughout the game unless you resolve the conflicts. 4. Gun modifications make sense and follow a semblance of realism, which isn't unpopular nowadays but adds a nice addition to the game.  This is a super toned down version of Just Cause with fantastically crafted dialogue. And right now it's 3 bucks. You have no reason to not buy this game.

Dishonored is one of the games I enjoyed most last year. It has around 10 hours of gameplay and you can play it exactly how you want to! Do you want to be silent? Sure! Use your Blink-spell to get higher up the building and use your crossbow to take out your target. Want to massacre everyone? Just kick in the door and start shooting with your gun, slash with your sword and summon plague-rats to eat your enemies. Don't worry about being shot! Just slow down time and dodge the bullet, after that, just slowly aim your gun on the head of the enemy, shoot and resume time again. You can even finish the game by not even getting noticed and also by not killing anyone! It's all possible!  Remember, every method takes it's time and it's skills. Decide which strategy you like best.  Rating: 8/10 It has some flaws, but it's almost invisible while playing! With the DLC's released you can even listen to the other side of the story. A must-have for people that like different styles of combat.

app_name: The Aquatic Adventure of the Last Human
review_text: From the haunting melodies by Karl Flodin, to the wonderous seascapes of post-apocalyptic Earth,  The Aquatic Adventure of the Last Human  is an audiovisual treat. I'm not much of an art-critic, but to me, this is a game that feels...significant. I'm overcome with this feeling of inspiration. At any moment, I could sit down at my desk, turn on the PC, and write something really powerful. Anyone who read it would also become inspired, and the cycle would continue until the entire world became just a little bit grander.  Well, maybe I'll do that tomorrow. For now, let's focus on the game itself. Some of the first videogames I ever reviewed originated in the arcades, so I tend to pay more attention to basic qualities like controls and design. My approach to reviewing this game is to strip away all of the extraneous elements. The visuals are lovely, and the soundtrack is excellent, but right now I'm tuning all of that out. All I see are lines, dots, and rectangles. If I open my ears enough, I'm sure I'll hear some bleeps and bloops. With this scenario in mind, do I still consider  The Aquatic * a good game? Yes!  Aside from light exploration elements, this is a game that revolves entirely around boss-fights. As a  Darius  fan, I've always been a sucker for oceanic-themed adversaries. While that series operates under the basic trappings of a 2D shooter,  The Aquatic  goes in another direction. Each of the 12 bosses are approached differently. Aside from each boss having a unique look, they also have their own patterns, weaknesses, attacks, and environment. Not only do you have to pay attention to the projectiles the boss might fire, but also your immediate area, and the following action the boss is liable to take.  This is not a game to approach lightly. You're going to die, possibly a large number of times. In my view, all of these deaths will be fair. The sub, even at its default speed, is fast enough to avoid every attack, it's just a matter of understanding movement. Yes, it will seem slow at first, but there will be cases where you can avoid attacks entirely with a little fore-thought. The first boss (a giant worm) has an attack where it spits several smaller worms at the player. The player can attempt to hang back and dodge every single worm, or they can work their way around the giant one. By doing this, the player avoids the entire attack, and gets a nice opportunity to do a lot of damage to the boss. Unless you're after a specific achievement, the sub can also take quite a bit of damage through the acquisition of hull and auto-repair upgrades.  The most important weapon you'll have for the boss-fights is your harpoon. In order to get the most out of this tool, you have to grasp the basics of risk vs reward. The harpoon can be charged to hit distant targets, or the button can be mashed repeatedly if an enemy is close. Naturally, the closer you get to the boss, the more dangerous they become, but they can be destroyed more quickly. As you develop strategies to defeat these bosses quickly, you'll discover the real depth found in this game. It's almost entirely boss-fights, but it does them justice.   Since the game delivers in terms of the more important qualities, I feel more comfortable talking about its artistic side. Videogames that take place in or around large bodies of water have always intrigued me. When most other games have the obligatory water stage, I can't stand them. I think it's because nobody really appreciates the ocean, they just want to have some harebrained swimming mechanics, in order to pad things out. Videogames that embrace the ocean and the life that inhabits it, such as the  Ecco the Dolphin  series, are just incredible.  The Aquatic  really captures those immersive moments, where you're blown away by all that's happening around you. The world's surface (and humanity) is long dead, but the seas are as lively as ever. The minor visual details like the remnants of human architecture and various types of marine life bring everything together.   The soundtrack can not be praised enough. This is a short game, so it's welcome to have a unique track for every part of it. I've always said that good music can elevate any game, and this is as appropriate an example as any. The boss themes in particular are superb. You're the last human in existence, fighting off an abomination, for reasons you can't quite grasp. The music in these tense and disturbing situations really preys upon the game's sense of hopelessness.   While  The Aquatic Adventure of the Last Human  isn't lacking in quality art and sound, it also holds up well purely as a videogame. There is some entertainment in poking around a small yet visually dense world for upgrades and other secrets. However, most of the fun and challenge is in learning, defeating, and then mastering the myriad of bosses. Overall, this is a unique experience that's definitely worth checking out.  *Sorry, but I can not write out that title every time.   If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group:  Follow Original Curator Group

I'm not even sure where to start. The developers of this game are a group of idiots for one. They had originally started development on elite dangerous, under the promise that there would be no dlc's and no p2w micro transactions. Instead of doing dlcs at the time, they decided that they would purposely stop support on the first release of the game to continue with another release called (Elite Dangerous: Horizon). This was a standalone game that mirrored Elite Dangerous in every aspect, but added a few more features. When the community confronted them, they stated, 'In order to keep our product going, and keep our promise, every big update will be a new game'. Are you kidding? The community outraged (except a select few drones, willing to kiss the @ss of the devs). The devs were going to make a new game, with every update, on an EARLY ACCESS game. It was the dumbest idea, any developer has ever tried. Due to the community uproar, Frontier decided (finally) that it was an absolutely terrible idea, and started releasing DLCs. The game now, is no longer in Early Access, and it's going to be a dlc fest (if they even continue development). Go to #1 for links to facts.  Now that the standalone has become a dlc, they decided to label it a season pass, and in case you were wondering, it’s not. (Not sure if this will be fixed, due to community uproar). The “Season Pass” isn’t labeled as such, to signify it allowing you more than just that one dlc. It was labeled that way, due to more dlc’s with the label “Season Pass” in the header, getting bought, than those without it. They won’t be giving you any more DLCs if you buy it, no future content. Their excuse for using it, was “It’s a season pass because we plan on giving you the updates of the dlc for free”. Really? They were thinking about charging people money for the bug fixes to their crap dlc. That’s just BS. Go to #2 for links to facts.    Last and not least, the newest of all, removing support for 2% - 10% (the devs stated it would only be 2%, however, due to all the lies I’m sure they are continuing with their already FoS practices) of their player base. 32 bit, and direct x 10 support is being removed, after people with those specs have already bought the game, can’t get a refund and now, they won’t be allowed to play it. That’s their way of kicking their fans in the face, for pointing out their business flaws, and threats to boycott the game, due to its greedy and incompetent devs.  (You can see their refund policy below, even if they lied to their players, they won’t refund the game if that’s why you bought it, luckily, steam allows you to do so with a few guidelines, but it’s better than frontiers flat no, #3) Before you ask, I’m running AMD FX-9370 4.7 – 5.2 GHZ, 2 GTX 970’s , and 32gb of 1600/2400 ram. I’m not using DX 10 on any game that allows for 11, and it’s a 64bit system. I just find it to be a horrible thing to do to players, remove them after paying for it, with no chance of refunding. F*** Frontier, and its greedy practices  #1 Most fans have been reluctant to look for the proof of what’s stated above, here’s links to the facts: Separate game @ $60 (now a dlc for $20)  https://forums.frontier.co.uk/showthread.php/213620-Separate-game-for-Horizons   https://www.reddit.com/r/pcmasterrace/comments/3gl3ss/dont_buy_elite_dangerous_its_a_game_sold_in_kit/   https://www.vg247.com/2015/08/06/elite-dangerous-expansion-raises-ruckus-with-60-price-tag/   #2   https://steamcommunity.com/app/359320/discussions/0/357287304435279995/   https://steamcommunity.com/app/359320/discussions/0/530649887201428205/    #3 Other lied facts that I didn't include in the review: Kickstarter promises that didn't come true, or flat out lied about:  https://forums.frontier.co.uk/showthread.php/223142-Broken-Promises-A-Collection   https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/11/20/elite-dangerous-refunds/   #4 Money Hungry Dev Tactics  http://www.polygon.com/2014/6/13/5805734/elite-dangerous-150-dollar-beta

I went into this game with no prior knowledge of how this game's style was presented. I fell in love with the art style the second I walked out of the badger den. I loved the immersion that this game brought upon me when playing. It felt like I was in the forest, walking and foraging, caring for young badger-lings. Another point that makes this game wonderful is the music. The music within really adds to the fact that you are a badger caring for your young. When things get heated, so does the music making for a game with suspense around every tree. I'd put this as one of my all-time favourite game just because of the sheer immersive effects of the art, music and gameplay. Go buy it now! 10/10

First off let me say that this game is beautiful and quite enjoyable. It's major downfall is replayability. Much like Minecraft and many new survival games now available, we are encouraged to find our own goals to work towards. Building projects, expansion, amassing resources...you name it. The same applies here, but primarily this game will successfully run itself after a while and I find it dissatisfying to simply collect a ton of resources only to lose them because I built a new 4x4 farm.   If this is extremely cheap in a sale, I would recommend it because it can be fun. Just don't expect anything long term.
