A great tower defense game with a huge variety of towers, enemies and possible strategies.  This is a hidden gem of a very good tower defense game, comparable with Defender's Quest and Gemcraft, but ten times less known. What can you expect from the game?  - A huge variety of upgradable towers, unlocked gradually so you can learn about each one - Respeccable skill points that you can (and must) distribute according to the map you're going to play - Challenge modes that make the maps more difficult in exchange for better rewards - An endless mode with ever harder waves  - User-created maps and a map editor  Most of the fun comes from the well designed towers and traps. In their most basic form, TD games have usually three types of towers - the reliable peashooter, the slow firing group damager and a slowing tower. In Dungeon Warfare you can of course use these basic towers and combine them with traps such as: - Spikes shooting from the ground - A harpoon pulling an enemy towards the abyss - A push trap that pushes whole groups in the direction you wish - A blackhole that sucks nearby enemies onto a single tile, making them a better target for the following AoE attacks - A lich that turns any enemy it kills into a zombie fighting on your side - A rotating spintrap rising from the ground and hacking everyone who comes near into minced meat - A hex trap that turns an enemy into a frog  There are many effective combinations you can find and there is no set way of finishing a level. For example so far my go-to killzone consists of a chessboard of spintraps and spikes with a blackhole at the beginning and a spring trap at the end. The spintraps and spikes deal most of the damage to groups, blackhole pulls enemies periodically back so they have to travel through the kill zone again and the spring trap throws any straggler back into the fray. Sprinkle with a few liches to further slow down enemies and a gold enhancer and put a grinder at the end for any heavy units that make it through.  Another favourite strategy that some maps support is a using lot of push plates and harpoons combined with a slow trap, disposing of enemies by pushing/pulling them into the abyss. This is especially useful for large groups of slow, heavy enemies. It doesn't however work on thieves and horsemen who are too fast for the push plates and run through. Those must be disposed with a spintrap/flamethrower or spikes. The abyss also doesn't pose danger to flying enemies, those are better killed with a lightning trap and bolts.  All enemies have their weight and pushing/pulling traps have their force, so light enemies will get pushed further/faster than heavy ones, something you have to take into account. You can upgrade your push traps to have more force, but if there is a walkway behind the abyss, light enemies might get pushed too far and land safely on the other side, while if the trap is too weak, heavy knights and golems don't even move. Of course this can also be used to your advantage, as you can create endless cycles forcing groups of light enemies to go through your killzone multiple times...  You get the idea.  Graphically the game looks very simple, but unfortunately the screenshots don't make the game any favor as they look very chaotic. When in motion the game is quite clear and you know what is happening.  Don't let the screenshots dissuade you.  All in all Dungeon Warfare is a very good entry in the TD genre, well worth playing.

app_name: Tales of the Orient: The Rising Sun
review_text: Match 3 or more of the same tile, either by chaining them together, popping blocks already next to eachother or switching. While you do this you are rebuilding a village with the gold you earn from the games. When you match 5 or more of the same tile you get a bomb, in this game the bomb will be in the tile you clicked to make the match so you can plan where to place it. And you can rotate the board and there is a scramble on a timer if there is no more matches to be had.  It's mostly like other match 3 games except for the 3 different game modes. Fine for casual play of the match 3 variety.

Kerbal has allowed me to live out the fantasy of traveling into outer space, by desiging, building, flying, landing and often totally destroying my custom rockets. This game has captured some part of my soul, and even taught me a few things about how spaceflight actually works.  The learning curve is punishing and many Kerbals will die, but the clever engineer will be rewarded with spectatular accomplishments in outer space. There really isn't a way to describe how awesome it feels to finally figure out how to land Kerbals, probes and vehicles on other worlds. Or make a space station. Or fly a custom build plane into orbit.  Kerbal is literally a 'dream come true' game for me. If you are smart and patient, you will love this.

Wow, just wow. There's not much I can say about this game other than it has an amazing community and surreal spacial landscapes. I have spent hours traveling and exploring star systems, trading everything from precious metals to illegal narcotics, and even the occasional battle to ward off an enemy who wants what I have. Just imagine for a moment being a lone commander looking through your galactic map and you see something that sparks your interest, you have everything available to you to make your expedition happen. You are in control of your destiny in this game, you and the others who play are in control of what happens around you. One minute you can be lesurely flying to a space dock and the next you can be interdicted by a band of players who you may either have to fend off with anything from your words to your weapons. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys exploration, action, and strategy.

Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor: Road Warrior: Judgement Day: The Hunt for the Red October is kind of cool I guess.  You play as Troy Baker pretending to be Talion, a Ranger of Gondor who lives on the Black Gate of Mordor with his wife and son where absolutely nothing can go wrong.  Oh no, everything went wrong!   The Black Gate is attacked by, surprise surprise, the forces of Sauron and Trayvon and his family are murdered, then the game ends. Okay no, I'm just yanking your chain. It turns out that Talion and his family were sacrificed to bring back a wraith to the waking world. A wraith that was probably enjoying it's nap before some jerk who looks like my heroin dealer killed a few shmucks to try and... I don't know, catch him in a bottle or something.   The wraith, having been reading JoJo's Bizarre Adventure and playing Persona games on his down time, thought it would be super cool to roleplay as his favorite Stand by possessing one of the dead people and refusing them the embrace of death. And so begins the journey of Troyion and Spookyface as they exact their revenge on the orcs of Mordor.  But these aren't your typical orcs, no sir. These are the Senior year High School Rugby Team equivalent of orcs. Uruks are supposed to be larger, angrier, and all around ruder than their rank and file counterparts, though you probably wouldn't be able to tell considering how easily Tony tears them to pieces. And since the average Uruk goes down the same way I go down for 20 dollars whenever Terry is in their view, it's kind of hard to imagine that these guys will someday lead Sauron's black army through the gates of Mordor.   Well that's where the big thing that was advertised comes into play. Basically the game randomly generates some named officer Uruk's that serve as mini-bosses for Terrance to fight, such as Otrek the brain-damaged or Twerky the Goblin. Each one of these mooks has a set power level and abilities that make them differ from your average Uruk, they also have this novelty where they remember who Tron 2.0 is and what he did to them if they manage to survive an encounter with him. Though the novelty wears off after a few hours, especially later on when you're bottle necked into fighting them a certain way considering they have more abilities the higher their power level is (Or at least that's what I figured.).   Okay now I'm going to say some bad things about this game.   As overplayed as J.R.R. Tolkien's works are in modern times, Middle-earth itself is a very magical place (No, not that kind of magic, stupid, the other kind). Through the books, yes I can read, the movies, and even other video games, Middle-earth always felt like a real place, with it's own history and people and cultures. It's a place that, even with all it's dangers, you would want to explore and visit, see it's people and locations.   That magic just isn't there for Shadow of Mordor. I know it's based in the one place in Middle-earth that looks like my bathroom, and it's supposed to be much more grim than it's counter parts, but it almost feels like a cop out, like it cheated and just slapped on the Middle-earth name for brand recognition. It doesn't feel like a game set in Middle-earth, it's far too isolated and lonely for me to care about the settings and characters of the story.   I can't say much about the combat, I mean, it worked for me in the Batman games, and the saving grace for it here is just how vicious Talion uses his weapons on his enemies. It's like somebody killed his family or something.   But should you play Central-hearth: House of Trogdor?   I say get it on the cheap. If you can ignore all of it's story and play it like some sort of heavy metal inspired fan fiction, then you'll probably get a few hyucks out of it. I would like to see the nemesis system make it's return in another game, though, it seems cool enough for people to do neat things with it.   Intermediate-ground: darkness of Lamb of God gets 16 Troy Baker grunts out of 3 wizards talking about omens.   The curator:  http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation   Also, don't forget to visit my Patreon: I don't actually have a Patreon.

At first glance, The Princess' Heart isn't your textbook RosePortal product. The pre-made Enterbrain RTP visuals and mapping seems lazy. But is it? Is the game just a quick cash grab or is there more to it than a simple premade asset layer?   At first, when I saw the promotional screenshots for the game, I was appalled. Not only by what I saw as below average mapping (at least by RosePortal's usual high standards, compared to many other RPGs out there it doesn't stand out that much) but also horribly small characters that had barely anything redeemable to them. And the battle system - goodbye side-view custom battles, here we go, pre-made 'first person' combat with sprites not really animated at all.  And yet, I gave this game a chance and played it through. In full.  And I don't regret one single minute.  Why? Like I said, graphics-wise the game is very much below RosePortal's usual average. It's not all that about the RTP tileset: the resource can be used to create beautiful environments that would be very much on par with Whisper of a Rose's (it just didn't happen here, instead we have a bunch of square-looking mazes), it's more about the characters, both the playable and NPC ones as well as the monsters. RosePortal made it a habit to have each monster fully animated in combat, here we have a simulation of movement by close-up effects or stretching and un-stretching the enemy pictures. The character sprites are RPG Maker VX Ace's defaults, meaning they occupy one tile (that provides little room for them to look good) instead of RosePortal's regular, whooping three. While the environments are varied, some of them just don't look authentic. Instead of posting a series of trees or a large unpenetrable layer of bushes/trees as the level 'wall', RosePortal applied the one tile that I think shouldn't be used: a tree trunk on a black background... that looks grotesque when seen on the corners as the blackness between the trees would have been understandable in the middle but not at the corner. A few of the maps seem empty and barely decorated/filled with content, I'm mainly looking at the Old Dayaz desert area and Maplefield. The only actual custom graphics I've noticed are: the title screen and the intro movie, which both are really well done.  However, I'm bringing up what I said before: I don't regret one single minute spent on playing this game, not one bit. And that is because, quite frankly, The Princess' Heart delivers much more in terms of other departments than in terms of just visuals.  Let's start with the music. It's, again, downright beautiful. RosePortal have once again delivered an alluring, orchestral-sounding set of musical pieces which all fit quite well into the game's environments and narrative. I can't say it more clearly: buy the Deluxe version, just for the soundtrack alone, the music being already in the game files be damned. They deserve support just for the quality of that soundtrack alone. My absolute favorites are Dark Heavens (the demon boss combat theme) and The Beyond, named after one of the game's areas. Epicness absolutely ensues. Not a single RTP track was used in the making of this game, a stark contrast with the visual layer.  As far as the gameplay goes, this is your standard jRPG fare with a wee little twist. Just a little. There is no crafting option nor there are any weapons to be picked up (so that option is useless), instead like in Sweet Lily Dreams, the only thing we can equip our characters with are accessories. The combat system is simplistic but works - albeit it does have two new options. First, some spells have an area of effect - so a single-target spell may actually hit some neighbouring targets if you choose the right victim. That can actually save you a lot of MP which would normally be used for all-enemy-targeting spells. Second, you can swap characters in the active party not only outside of battles but also in-between turns! This can get you out of sticky situations - if some characters get knocked out and you have no means to bring them back, simply replace them with others, fully healed and just waiting to kick the monsters' butts. I happened to use this feature just once, on the final boss, but it sure counts: when it was almost dead and I knew my current party doesn't have what it takes to kill it in one volley nor will they survive its next attack, I just replaced them and in three further turns, the battle was over. I was the one left standing.  About the battles: they aren't a chore but they can be a challenge. Areas can technically be completed outside the beaten track as besides the final three dungeons, you can reach pretty much every location quite early on in the game. Enemies do NOT respawn in-between level sections most of the time, so you have to leave to the World Map - this may be a lifesaver if you're particularly wasted after just narrowly beating That One Boss. They do however have quite a level of difficulty, also due to the scarcity of items. There isn't an abundance: there's just what you get from the chests plus what you'll buy in the shops but with one catch: the prices rise alongside your overall character level so you won't be able to afford 999 of those Elixirs or Magic Waters. Most of the time, you need to make do with what you have found from chests. Money isn't earned by just winning the battle either, nor is it rewarded by the completion of a quest - you need to sell what you've acquired from battles in order to make some money.  About quests... well, there's just eleven of them, so not that all much, but then again a game advertised as 15-hour is less than a half of what you'd spend on Whisper of a Rose, so that number would kind of fit. What irks me is their overall lack of variety. Half of the sidequests involve you bringing the questgiver a bunch of high-quality drops from the monsters. The others do make much more sense but there's more than one occasion of the trope 'Guide Dang It' being invoked. And it's a bad trope to invoke. I mean particularly the Cambolton Fortress quest involving the king's soul. Honestly, given what the Counselor was saying, one would think that the first place one should visit is the desert city Daragit. Uh... suffice it to say that it's a waste of time. The solution is right there in Cambolton, it's just so non-intuitive and so hard to spot that I literally needed a guide to complete it and I wasn't the only one, judging from the forums. A couple quests end in a really anti-climatic way, such as the Arsonist one (why didn't I get the option to deal with the guilty party?!) or the Emily exorcism one (props for the 'Exorcism of Emily Rose' reference by the way) - why wasn't I able to actually WHACK the possessing demon instead of just having it expelled like someone snapped a finger and said 'begone'? Yep, the sidequests definitely lack polish. The only reward you'll ever get for them is Journey Points which are used to learn skills. And again, there's a glaring issue: at some point (as a little grinding  is  recommended to progress smoothly and you also get JPs after gaining character levels) there's simply TOO MUCH of these points to spend'em.  ----- review continued under 'Comments' as it was too long - apologies!

app_name: Fortune Summoners: Secret of the Elemental Stone
review_text: I have renamed this game to 'Kawaii Souls'. The art work is cute and the character designs are cute. The game story is fairly well made, other than the fact that it takes every opportunity to force you to explore a hardcore dungeon. I was kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at the 'hot springs arc', the part where the party of adventurous magical school girls goes to an Onsen for a field trip and I was so keen on seeing the artworks for that but...  I had to explore 2 dungeons before getting to the Onsen and guess what happens when I get to the Onsen? ****SPOILERS**** The Onsen is dry... ****SPOILERS END**** Now here we go to explore a few more dungeons. I stopped playing for quite a while after that.  It may sound easy to you, 'pfffft... a few school girls clearing dungeons, it'll just be one of those easy Japanese made weeaboo games.' Well, you are wrong, for the most part. There is a reason why I chose to call this game 'Kawaii Souls'. Because it's hard as ♥♥♥♥, therefore I hereby make a Dark Souls reference. I play on normal and the monsters are so hard to kill, oh my god, I sometimes contemplate killing myself. But it's a good point, to some, the combat AI is amazing. I feel like the AI learns the way you fight, and calculate strategies on how to break the way you fight. Normally there would be a sequence that each mob follow in combat situations in other games, and you just have to figure out that sequence and you'd get through the game easy. But it's the complete opposite in this game, if you don't constantly improve and change the way you fight, the AI would kill you off, easy.  Other than the amazing...ly hard combat, the dialogue and story is quite good too. The humourous and cute (omg the babbling Sana, so cute, kya kya) dialogues always cheer me up after spending hours trying to clear a dungeon. But sometimes I wonder what's actually keeping me here playing this game...  Overall, 8/10 game with over 20 hours gameplay. Would play again.

When I played the demo, I thought the game looked good enough to try out. After playing for a bit, I started getting...comfortable. I truly believed that the entire game was just creepy music/atmosphere and jump scares...no big deal. They even get slightly predictable, but I was still enjoying the atmosphere and puzzles.   Suddenly, the creepy, distant monster that pops up occasionally was actually attacking me! The game lulled me into a false sense of security and then yanked that security away. The noises that came out of me were created by sheer panic.  I've played a wide variety of horror games and this is definitely worth giving a shot!
Get the second one.

app_name: DARK SOULS™: Prepare To Die Edition
review_text: You'll feel like your getting the hang of it, but then proceed to die over, and over, and OVER AGAIN!

-If landing in hay bales kills you enable vsync-  Each game is like a story expansion of the one before it, with some extra new bits that sometimes are fun, but other times just get in the way. I'm glad they're taking a year off. They need it.   That said, this is one of my favorite series. Its like medieval GTA. The writing and story ideas I enjoy a lot. The first game will seem pretty bland if you've played anything newer. But I liked this era the most and Altair is my favorite.  I'd say pick it up on a deal if you're iffy about something a little aged with some repeated aspects throughout the whole game. 20 is kinda steep. If you didn't play it way back when, it might be a tough fit. But I can't really bring myself not to recommend just out of enjoying the philosophy of it.

Don't get me wrong, the textures, lighting, character design, voices, buildings, weapons and world are OK, maybe 10 years ago I'd be really impressed with this game. However it just doesn't cut it after Skyrim, it's not even better then Oblivion or Gothic 2. To me, it's just not 'open world' unless you can jump and look around the back of the cave for a few elusive coins.  Shame, because it looks like a nice world and it's obviously had a lot of thought put into it but the gameplay too generic, paint by numbers and boring. This is to RPG what Zelda is to AD&D

Ahhhh if you read my last review for Pink Hour you know how excited I was to play this one. And well.... it did deliver once again and put a smile on my face the whole time through!. The events take place after Pink Hour where you are warped into what seems a lab as you talk to your 'boss', then you are sent to heaven where the main game takes place. I really won't say much else as the game is short so it would be pretty much spoilers but I will say this one has 2 levels and a umbrella upgrade which was a nice touch (the umbrella would let you hover after you jump letting you skip from place to place). All in all this was another joyride of happiness and I still highly suggest you play both of the games! I hope KeroBlaster is just as good. (oh and it's confirmed that the main character is a girl potato.)  Pros:  - 2 levels   - Still has hardmode after you finish the main game, which means replay value  - Free   - Controlling miss potato feels solid for the most part!  - Funny and cute story.  Cons:   Even though there really isn't cons to the game I will just list a couple things that felt weird while playing.  - I didn't address this during the first game's review, but when you start shooting you are stuck into that position. So if you are shooting straight you are stuck to shooting straight and can't shoot anywhere else unless you stop completely and aim in the other direction and start shooting agian. It doesn't bug me much but it can for sure get a little annoying.  - Even though the umbrella was a pretty nice touch it didn't really seem useful for most of the second level except a few parts, and for just the story itself. Also sometimes if you jump from block to block to fast you will most likely trigger the umbrella which can as well get a little annoying.  Really nothing game breaking just a couple things to talk about since the game doesn't really have any cons lol   Thank you to the team who created this little fun game and I hope you keep making them !

This game starts out promising. With a fantastic art style and great ambient soundtrack it sucks you in, immerses you in its nightmare horror setting. But soon you realize there isn't much else there.  The gameplay basically boils down to blindly walking through spooky rooms and corridors until you reach the end of the nightmare and you wake up in a new slightly different nightmare consisting of more rooms and corridors. Occasionally you meet one of several different types of enemies, each requiring a different strategy to get past, be it hiding in a closet, sneaking past or just running away. Once you figure out how they're easy to avoid. Most rooms are just empty though. The backgrounds look nice and detailed but only very rarely is there something you can actually interact with, and usually it just means a close up view of the object. Every now and then a loud noise will try to startle you, together with spooky or disturbing imagery. It tries to scare you, but personally I was never scared or even startled.  Like this it continues for the 1-2 hours it takes to beat, and to be honest it's way too long for how little of interest actually happens. By the end my thumb was tired from having to constantly hold right on the left thumb-stick. That's what you'll be doing 90% of the time, just walking to the right.  There is a vague story. A girl died and haunts your dreams. The game drip feeds you some bits and pices of the story throughout the game but mostly leaves you with no story developement until your reach the very end of the game where you might find out what really happened, or not, based on a couple of branching paths in the game. Fortunately there is a 'nightmare select' menu so you can go back to these branches and choose a different path if you wish.  Bottom line, it's a game with a nice art style, good sountrack and atmosphere. But it fails in the gameplay and story department. It might be worth getting at a discout but otherwise I wouldn't recommend it.

Hearts of Iron 4 is an excellent strategy game. It does a good job of providing meaningful decisions in all aspects of the country (diplomacy, industry, research, military, etc.) without overwhelming you with options like its predecessor. The epidemic micromanagement has been replaced with useful tools such as the division templates. Army composition is important, so having the ability to quickly update entire forces is quite nice. Air combat and naval combat are also much more manageable now, with sea and air zones broken out into fairly large regions where you can assign missions to hundreds of ships and planes at a time to cover an area. (Fleets can be assigned to multiple regions, planes cannot, although they do seem to roam a bit outside of the region if they have the range and nothing to do inside.) Air superiority feels right in this game and has a strong effect and leaving your troops exposed to enemy close air support will almost always result in a loss. Supply makes much more sense than before and makes it so that the infrastructure damage to an area will slow down large armies quite a bit and weaken them significantly. Ports are often very important for getting supplies in and out of areas making naval superiority important as well. The damage caused to infrastructure by bombing can also be quite useful to stop the enemy's supply and destroying the factories keeping them equipped. Everything in this game just works together so well and feels like it has a purpose and that your actions actually change things without being too difficult to understand what is going on. I think this may be the best Paradox strategy yet, and definitely the one with the strongest and most complete gameplay at launch.

Telltale did it again.  Is Season 2 as good as Season 1?  Absolutley   Are the decisions just as hard as Season 1?  Absolutley, some even harder  Will you love this game?  Absolutley  The Walking Dead Season 2 is a great follow up to Season 1. It continues the story perfectly from season 1 and within the first few minutes you are aready feeling sad by what happens to the characters. I loved season 1 and was very scared for how season 2 would be, but Telltale came through with just as amazing of a game as season 1 and i could not be happier.   Combat and graphics and exactly the same as the first, but the UI is a little better and some extra combat mechanics that make the game more interactive. And the best part overall, the PC port is soooo much better than it was in the first one.   Overall play this game. I cant say much more, other than it is a great game and you will love every moment of the game.   LAST THING!!! PLAY SEASON 1 BEFORE PLAYING SEASON 2!!!

The Wolf Among Us is an amazing experience. The game contains just the right amount of drama and mystery to keep you entertained, as well as throwing in some action scenes where appropriate. The characters drag you in, and in some cases make you care deeply about what happens to them.   While the game is based on Fairy Tales, it's not at all like the 'For Kids' disney version, nor quite like the gritty, dark reboots, It's very clean, and although the characters are recognisable from their respective fairy tales, they feel like entirely new characters.  The only gripe I had with The Wolf Among Us (along with all Telltale games) is the fact that, no matter what you do, the game has a definite story; and it is going to tell it whether you like it or not. Your choices don't really matter in the grand scheme of things, with many dialogue options leading into the exact same replies, and the choices which do lead down different paths, have no major impact on the story at all.  That being said though, I still feel like this game is one of the best games I've played for years, I could not put it down, and found myself going back to repeat scenes just to see what would happen if I'd chosen differently. I'd give this game a 9/10.

I played this on the PS3 last year for the first time and from start to finish it is - without a doubt - the best Arcade Action RPG I've ever played. The whole scenario, story, backdrops, characters and playability are totally immersive and had me putting in countless all-nighters of play. I was going to buy the add-ons but since Steam are doing this whole collection pack for the same price of the Teeth Of Naros DLC on PSN I thought I'd go for it and I'm glad I did, even though I still remember the plot, Amalur is a great place to revisit especially since I've got two new maps, an increased level cap and some weapon/armour upgrades all in the mix. Obviously check the specifications first, I'm running at Ultra level on my PC and everything is....sweet as!  Totally Recommended to any and all RPGers out there!

This game is NOT easy. But, who's to say thats a bad thing? Honestly, I'm a little sick of all the reviews that claim the game is so hard, yes the learning curve is a doozy, but it isnt impossible to master. Infact, I have 27 or so hours on my record at the time of writing this, and I've already gotten the hang of vehcile and infantry combat. The accuracy system can be very rewarding, and the damage system is unforgiving, yet satisfying. Yes, it's a very old HL2 Mod, but by god, It has potential. Think of it as a free, kinda rough planetside 2, give or take a few elements. I recommend it if you want to learn how to be a serous and good part of a team, and enjoy a hard, unforgiving yet rewarding FPS.

This is NOT a free to play game. This should just be a demo. I like that they let you rent gear, and try stuff out, but you need every key they give you just to unlock enough gear to play a single game. If you go in as a free player, you will not have access to the highest tier of upgraded gear. Which means in end game, on equal skill level, you have no chance. The time it takes to unlock anything as a free player is ludicrous.  That being said, I love the theme and style of the game. I'll leave it installed in hope that there's some balancing to happen. I would gladly play a little money to play a game where there's no major team disadvantages than to play a free game where I have to hope there are no free players on my team.

Even though this gameplay style is the same we know and love from X-COM (The turnbased one not the mass effect ripoff one) comparing them directly is a bit unfair imo, when you consider the difference in budget and teamsize for the games.  With the very open communication from the developers, I'm thinking any gameplay changes/improvements/fixes that the majority of players want/agree with will most likely be implemented eventually.  I find it fun to play, with a pleasing art style despite the relatively 'lower end' graphics.  Yes, they had problems at launch with heavy lag. But that seems solved now and you can read in detail about what happened from the developer point of view. It's a good read imo, never seen such open honesty from a developer I find it refreshing...being honest about mistakes vs covering them up with marketting hype trash takes courage. Courage that I, for one, very much appreciate.  Helpful community vs some of those games that seem to have nothing but griefers and trolls. If you do want to troll though, well they do have a playable troll race for you so there ya go :). You could be a troll hacker with a shotgun. Just don't try to troll or hack or shotgun me ok?  Also, it has Dragons in it. I like Dragons. Except for the mean ones, they suck. But the good ones are good. Sometimes. Depends how you treat them really. Most people just try to kill them. I could not reccomend this game more! From the wide range of options you get when making decisions or just talking to anyone, to the unimaginably hilarious background chat provided by your companions conversing to fill in the silence. Every character is given a complex story and personality; never have I been so emotionally attatched to virtual characters. Every piece of music for any occasion is a masterpiece, be it for a heated battle or during your escapades with your companions. This game is expertly crafted so almost every major- and, in some cases, not so major- decision you make will eventually come back to bite you in the behind, fully immersing you in the dark, dangerous, fantastic world you are free to explore in. This game has touched my heart in so many ways, and even with the short amount of time I've had with this game I can see how much of my time it will consume- something I don't regret at all. If you have the option, I'd highly reccomend that you spring for the Ultimate Edition. It gives you so much more time in the glorious world of Ferelden as well as out of it. The game is absolutely, categorically one of the best RPGs of all time. It is always worth buying and playing, no matter what year you're playing it in.

6/10 GOOD GAME BUT EASILY FORGETTABLE   Legendary was released in 2008 during a time where the FPS genre was ran by the likes of call of duty,bioshock.halo,fear,red faction and games of the like so naturally the gameplay isnt too far off from those. it lacks variety and depth both in story and gameplay but on the flip side the visuals and  frame rate are pretty amazing for their time. the game had clunky irresponisve controls which didnt  make a big difference alot of the time but there were times (like during the minotar and griffin fights) were snappier controls would have been helpful but werent there so movements and actions had  to be pre planned and not done on the fly. overall this game is definitly worth a playthough with a few  things in mind: - dont take it too seriously  - dont try and compare it to modern games - put it on easy,kick your feet up and enjoy the  games nice visuals and loose story.

Gaming industry is finally showing some signs of life after years of stagnation. After being fed $50 boring titles by major studios we finally get something fresh and funny. This project is really unusual and so for we may talk revolution, like when Valve decided to move boundaries with Portal, or when Blizzard finished Diablo... So far I don't remember video game being so bold when pushing new ideas. Visually game looks really great, the city is not the mose detailed in history, but good enough. What is a really astounding is how engine handles the large number of NPC on the screen. Animation is smooth and realistic. Thanks to the soundtrack game is even more atmospheric and deep. This game is the most fun you can have for less than $1 In short - if you think you need $5000 system to enjoy pc gaming today - check out this game - you will be pleasently surprised... I only wish devs add editor and co-op, but so far it is solid 9,5/10. Ok, who am I kidding... 10/10

This is a pretty great game, with no real complaints to think about after completing it, other than the initial controls was weird having left-mouse do right-hand, and right-mouse do the left-hand attacks. I ended up swapping them, and things worked out. But thats purly YMMV material and has no basis on the game itself.  Gameplay is fluid, and interesting. Various ways to get through a level if you are not a completionist. Otherwise you just end up exploring every corner anyhow, and the various paths are exposed regardless. You can kill or subdue enemies in many ways. Althought theres some really fun ways to kill people, if you want to go for the 'good' ending, you need to curb your rampant desires.  The level design felt a lot like Half-Life 2, a mix of old with metal paneling and high tech gadgetry and even the Tallboys looked like the walkers (just two legs instead of three). But hay, I cannot give them fault for it, the game was meant to be steampunk!  Overall, very well worth the effort and play. I will re-play this one for sure for the other ending.

Age Of Empires and Civilization had a baby. It's everything you could wish for in both franchises, tired of how aoeII has you going only through the medieval eras? Annoyed with waiting another turn in civ when you could just tell that f*cking worker to come here?  RoN is the logical extension of that, it goes beyond the tried and true modalities of standard rts fare and achieves something hardly any other rts or for that matter game has tried.   With the tech tree removed, the player doesn't have to wonder what logical pathways the authors followed when they had you go from wheel to the binocular to the atom bomb. What you've got here is streamlined: Pop cap bothering you? Military upgrade. Wanna expand? Civics. Commerce cap? Economy. Production too low? Science of course!  And then you advance to the next age.  Which does look substantially different. The architecture, the playstyle (in part), the units all look like they're really from the future compared to the loincloth wearing barbarians you started with.  There are races, and they do get bonuses, which feel more like personalized cheat codes. What else would you call instant worker spawn (china), extra city expansion (zulus), 3 free horse archers per stable (mongols), 2 extra max farms (egyptians), no borders (some indian tribe), double capital (persians) etc.?  WIth so many nations it's not hard to find one to suit your playstyle depending on what you feel in the morning.  Little caveat: The game is ideological, the two types of government have a clear bias, one 'libertarian' (democracy/republic/capitalism) against one 'authoritarian' (despotism/monarchy/socialism). But it's not as visibly overbearing as what civlization does, where the difference between being LITERALLY FASCIST NAZI HITLER and a snarky liberal late night talk show host is wether you pick assembly line or the scientific method.  What's more like age of empires is the warfare, it's the good old rock paper scissor we all love to hate: cavalry beats archer, archer beats infantry, infantry crushed beneath the treads of a tank, tank is nuked by the science civilization.  The difference between one age and nother is evident, especially in gameplay, if you don't catch up you're dead behind.  Castles and towers and barracks and siege workshops all work exactly like they did in aoe2, with the thing above as well as expanding and contracting borders. app_name: The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky SC
review_text: If you didn't enjoyed the story of the first, don't bother buy this game; the gameplay is exactly the same as the first.  Those who loved the first don't need to be convinced as the story of the second is even better!

This was such a refreshing title when I picked it up and started playing it. Creepy autmosphere with black and white landscape. It's almost straight out of a horror movie with shooter elements implemented into it. Although the story of the whole game is a little confusing and the character you play just seems thrown into the middle of it all it's still nice to make progress through it and see what might happen next. If you plan on 100% completing this game you'll be doing A LOT of saving and loading in order to get all the kills you need, but if you enjoyed the shooting as much as I did you almost feel like there isn't enough enemies in the whole game entirely.
Play it. Love it. Play it again. Get the DLC. Play them all. Beat the whole game + DLC all over again.

I cannot say that this game is bad or terrible in a manner, but it's not as what one would expect. It's basically regular blackjack; however, on a computer. It would be much easier and more convenient as well as cheaper to buy a deck of cards and to find a friend tht would abide by the rules. The concept of the game isn't very original since it was based off of a simple concept almost everyone who has ever played blackjack most likely has thought of before. Even with all this, it's not a terrible game, but i wouldn't recommend it rather just buy a deck of cards.  Final Ruling: Not recommended unless you can't find any friends or family or are too lazy to leave the house like me. On a side note, both are reasons why I played this game instead of buying some cards.

For me- there are two kinds of open world games like this one: Action movie, stupid action without any good story to back it up, such as this game and Saints Row 3-4. The second one is the so-called 'GTA Rip-Offs', them being Sleeping Dogs and Saints Row 1-2. I will be comparing this to Saints Row 3 at the end, because this is Saints Row 3's 'Stupid, but fun' done right. So: welcome to Panau, an island filled with stupid accents, explosions and Rico Rodriguez. Now the gameplay is something like this: Rico is Zeus, if lightning was explosions, now Rico likes explosions, so he makes things explode. A lot. The game is basically the best action movie you'll ever play, and it is so fun that you won't even mind the horrible voice acting. At the end of the day it's 100% careless fun. Now to the Multiplayer mod: It's the best Saints Row MMO ever made. Now buy it. BUY IT. YOU MUST. IF YOU DID NOT PLAY THIS YET YOU ARE PHYSICALLY AND MENTALLY HURTING YOURSELF.

Three words: Pay to Win.  I have absolutely no problem with microtransactions, but when the said microtransactions give you a huge advantage in a game over other players, then it becomes a problem.   Want to have shotguns that can pierce shields? Buy the shotgun DLC. Want to have grenades that burn dumb AI that run through it? Buy the BBQ DLC. Want superior weapon mods? Buy the Gage Mod Courier DLC.  Want superior stealth capabilities? Buy the Clover DLC.  In order for me to perform as well as my teammates who have been playing the game for a while, I have to buy DLC after DLC.  And you know, even after you have all the DLCs to make you the most optimal player you can be, they'll release more DLCs with superior weaponery, weapon mods, perk decks, etc...  If the DLCs were made up of side-grades and/or cosmetic items, new characters, etc.. I don't see anything wrong with that. But going into games feeling like you can't contribute as much as your fellow players? Not fun. Unless you pay more for the experience.  While the game is fun to play, there are plenty of other fun games to play that don't include 'Pay to Win' transactions.

app_name: Broken Sword 1 - Shadow of the Templars: Director's Cut
review_text: Loved this game. I've never played Shadow of the Templars when it was new, so it was a totally fresh experience for me, and it does indeed hold up to today's standards in terms of game design.  However, as others, I have to point out that the remastering could have been done better, from a technical viewpoint. The volume of the audio clips is inconsistent, and some of them could have done with some digital noise filtering applied. Also, the video cutscenes end rather abruptly, using a slow fade-out would have been a better choice.

9.5/10  This game has some moments that I thought were strange: QTEs, karaoke, and physics (but complaining about physics in a game with outrageous kung fu seems petty). The good game mechanics outweighed the bad quite heavily. The one or two parts I didnt enjoy I was willing to play through to get back to the game I was enjoying. Dont buy GTA. Get this or Saints Row. Wei is a badass on Jet Li or Jackie Chan scale and not a punk with a cousin tagging along to go bowling.  If you think you need the DLC or definitive edition you are probably fine without it. Basically is new enemies/fighting style and a little bit of story.

Unquestionably the best first-person melee combat in any game I've played in my life. What Mirror's Edge did for running and jumping Zeno Clash does for punching people in the face. Instead of the usual fixed camera and gimpy limbs, everything is properly weighted and moves naturally, so when you grab someone by the shoulders and give them a knee to the sternum, for once it truly feels right. The bizarre and surreal style, setting and design of everything only makes it that much better. Beating people up has never felt so right.

- Early december 1808: I, the British Empire, and my Russian, Austrian and Prussian allies, divide up everything north and east of Paris upto scandinavia on continental Europe... leaving france, whom i'm at war with, with 2 provinces and the Isle of Corsica. Brittany in the west is a Protectorate of mine.  - Late december 1808: As i continue to build up troops at Gibraltar, for an inevitable invasion of the Spanish mainland (as these hooligans have tried to take Gibraltar from me on several occasions these past few years!), i begin peacefull talks with Portugal, i give them new technologies for their Navy and get them to break their allegance to the Kingdom of Spain! 'huzzah!' i say, you people know what is good for you! Then i try to make them my ally.... they don't even have to join the war against Spain from me...they can become a protectorate of mine...or not... i promise them trade, revenue, offer them silly amounts of money... they won't budge... i leave them to make up their minds and will check in again in a month or 2...  -Early january 1809: Austria looses control over the Bavarian province because of Bavarian revolutionaries... i step in, crushing the revolution with the full might of my northern continental military force... Bavarian bradwurst is now part of the English breakfast...  -Early february 1809: Due to having to clear up the mess those lederhose wearing revolutionaries made in the north, i've taken my eye of the 'Portugese matter' for 'just a second' and what do you know? Those fools have the audacity to a attack one of my trade convoys sinking two of my Indiamen class trade ships and subsequently declaring war on me...  -Late february 1809: I am MASSIVELY annoyed at Portugal now.... i send the Fleet at Gibraltar out to take care of the issue, adding insult to injury, i capture all of their vessels and add them to my own fleet.  -Early march 1809: I've decided to make an example out of Portugal, and send two full armies to the capital of Lisbon. I show no mercy and leave no Portugese soldier standing during the Battle of Lisbon that ensues... Having emerged victoriously from the savage battle, i'm still mightely annoyed and instead of peacefully occupying, i randsack, pilage, ♥♥♥♥ and wreck everything on my path... wich brings me much loot ! ... loot that apperently now will be much needed to fix the place up lol  -Late march 1809: The souvereign nation of Portugal ceases to excist...  -Late April 1809: Maybe i went abit overboard, taking ages to fix the place up :s  meanwhile Portugese revolutionaries have sprouted up making all sorts of racket in the town of Evora...  -Early May 1809: I crush the uprising by killing off the remainder of what men of fighting age are left in the Lisbon province... Now that there are no men left capable of fighting in Portugal, they ALL love me...  10/10 Would annex Portugal and decimate the male portion of the population again...

A twin-stick shooter with (mostly uninteresting) RPG-elements. Initially very satisfying and overwhelming, the veneer of big numbers and particle effects wears off a few hours in. The movement and attacking is well-done, and it's a genuinely challenging and usually fair game.   The coolest part is unlocking and trying out all the different classes (24! wow!) which generally do play slightly differently. Once I did that, I tried to focus on beating the game. A few dozen deaths in, I came to realize that the only way to really have a chance at winning is to grind, grind, grind on each of the giant floors with thousands of monsters to click on. Levels are king, and the most correct way to play is also the most boring. This is unfortunate.   A floor time limit, diminishing returns on experience per kill per floor, etc would go a long way to making this less of a slog, and more of the 'pick up and play coffee break roguelike' that it wants to be.  I recommend this game all the same, because it is a lot of fun and I maintain that there's potential here, if the developers are still interested in it. I see they do still add content every now and then.

app_name: School of Dragons: How to Train Your Dragon
review_text: It was a quiet monday morning. Sunlight broke through my window covers and shone on my face. I awoke. It was a beautiful day. The birds were chirping their merry songs and I saw the neighbors exchanging friendly conversation. I turned on my computer and got online. My friend, Kyle, messaged me. We got caught up on our lives. He mentioned a new game that he found. A unique one based on the popular How to Train your Dragon Series. Feeling adventurous, we both downloaded it and began to play. Immediately, a smilie appeared on my face. I couldn't help. I just new from the very beginning that this game was something truly magically. The music perfectly set the mood. I began to feel like a viking myself. When I began creating my character, the amount of choices overwhelmed me. I created a character that fit my persona and felt truly connected. Then cutscenes introed the game and oh god the cutscenes. So masterfully crafted you would think they got them straight out a movie. When I finally began playing, everything fit in place. It was perfect. The controls were simple and fun. The interface was easy and clear. Voice acting was top notch. I think they got the actual movie actors! Everything was fun. Please, do yourself a favor and play this game.  1/10 IGN- Game of the Year

I usually don't review games, especially ones that i have yet to complete. However, even with only a few hours under my belt this game is exceptional. It has a ton of references to pop culture that always managed to get a smile out of me and had great character development (at least for the girl i chose). The story is interesting and hours will dissappear without you knowing where they went. Unlike most visual novels, there are a plethora of choices as well as implications for said choices which is quite refreshing.  TLDR; Caught this game on a sale but after playing i would recommend even if it wasn't on sale! 9/10   UPDATE: Ending left a sour taste in my mouth. It was promising at the beginning but the ending fell completely flat. I enjoyed the ride but i can't give it such a wonderful review with how it ended.  UPDATED SCORE: 6/10

app_name: Unreal Tournament: Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Having been an avid fan of FPS since Doom, Quake and then the deathmatch games Quake III arena and this since I was practically 9yrs old - even to this day as an adult this game is by far most enjoyable even in par with the latest fps releases. I still remember the era when online multiplayer gaming with likes of Quake arena and UT lead gaming forward and it was a massive hype. This game is a 10/10 especially rating as a retrogamer too.  No UT game compares to this one, not even the latest UT3 of 2008 and its disappointing to say that with every new game there doesnt seem to be much originality in the way of weapons, firing modes, environments unless its user generated even then not much. UT'99 beats even the latest releases. just repetition of old weapon designs and levels with very few innovations, which is probably what disappointed devoted fans overtime.  Overall, the pros and cons;  PROS: enjoyable replayable experience, a wide range of unlockable levels and gaming styles (Eg. Team deathmatch, single deatchmatch, CTF etc), quite fast paced and refreshing.  CONS: Doesn't run well with newer systems since Win7 or newer. Win 8 and Win 10 users beware that you might suffer from fps lag and glitches unless you chaneg some of the preferrences settings. Eg. I suffered a lot of fps lag while gaming for first time on my new win 8 system, and it was as slow as a snail until I changed the desired framerate in the video settings from 40 upto 100. ALSO to note that the default resolution doesnt help improve visual gameplay experience unless you switch it to 1024x780 or something.  But overall - HIGHLY recommendable.

Here's a game you should definitely try! It's both great and well... incredibly average, but it's satisfying from start to finish. This is a short game, you can easily complete it in about 3 hours. It's a kinda sloppy melee first-person brawler. Its combat system isn't bad, but it gets clunky at times, specially in group fights. However, punching enemies into a 5 meter flight makes you feel like a badass. And the ragdoll physics on the corpses are a nice touch as well.  I haven't played Zeno Clash 2 yet, but I will soon enough, and I assume the combat system has been polished since 2009, although I've heard it focus too much on team fights, which is where the clumsiness comes in... But I digress.   The game shines in its world and characters, which are all really weird, but at the same time, charming. They present neat ideas that feel like they should have been much more explored and fleshed out, but everything seems experimental here, hence its length. For example: 'The Corwids are not slaves of reality, so they can be insane. Oxameter walks in a straight line without letting letting anything change his path... and that's what Oxameter does.' There are other Corwids with interesting... 'features', so I'd definitely recommend picking this up if you're interested in them alone.  Now, another problem I have, in regards to the exploration of the world, is that, since the game goes from one arena to the others, you barely have any time to explore the areas and take the time to appreciate the world they've created. While you're in combat, you'll be busy to look around, and the scenes end as soon and you beat everyone up. This still leaves you with an idea of what it is, but too vague for my liking. Again, I hope Zeno Clash II solves this 'issue'.  Voice acting is pretty bad, but it's bearable, and didn't ruin the overall experience for me. The cutscenes follow the same route, with some cheesy animations, but again, that wasn't my reason to be playing the game, so it didn't really make much of a difference.  So, for the conclusion. If you're interesting in world, creature and character design, this is definitely a must-buy. They've done a great job there, I thoroughly enjoyed it! If you're coming for the combat system, or a grand scale story... well, you'll not find it here, not quite. Still, I'd encourage you to pick it up on a sale, since it's a very interesting game to play. Well, I'm off to play Zeno Clash II now, I'm definitely interested in what comes next. Cheers!

app_name: NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst
review_text: This is a great Naruto game.yes, the game is locked at 30 FPS.It's very smooth and can sometimes loose framerate.The campain is great even though theres a lot of loading screens .The gameplay makes up for it.The Voice acting is awsome BUT the English voice acting is not great but meh.I recommend having the language in English or your language subtitles on and the audio in Japanese. The controller is alright if you either have a ps3 or Xbox controller.I don't recommend playing with a keyboard because it will make the gameplay very hard.The main problem is multiplayer, The Transmittion error. Namco Bandai and Cyber Connect 2 are aware of the ' Transmission Error ' when trying to fight other users online and the situation is currently being looked into and there was a patch but didn't fix it.Multiplayer is still fun and great but there is a likely hood that you will get a slideshow gameplay of ' Transmittion error' in the middle of the screen as you try to play.Even after the issue with multiplayer. I still recommand the game to anyone who is out there wanting to play this game if your interested in a anime,action and adventure game.That has a great Story line, Single player and multiplayer that is lacking with problems.The error ,for now, but it is very fun and great to play with people online.if you like these stuff i put down then this game is for you. i give Naruto Shippuden:Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst a 8.2 / 10

This game is frustrating as hell, and it will murder you hundreds of times without mercy.  It's also immersive and interesting to play. It doesn't hand you anything, so when you finally do attain some success you really feel the value of it. It manages to maintain a sense of quiet anxiety and an atmosphere of loneliness in the depths of space.  If you can handle some frustration and you're interested in seeing how far you can get before either madness or entropy claims you then check it out.

As much as I love this game, I cannot find it in me to recommend it.  I find this game to be very chill, flexible and therefore fun, which is why I spent countless hours on it (between the Steam version and the Origin version)... however some of those hours were spent on a loading screen... You will find that your old save files will take longer to load the more you play them, and the more DLCs you use for said save files. Hell, last time I played this game, my main save file took like two and a half hours to load. The Wish System in this game is supposed to encourage you to do different things with your Sims, but I find that it doesn't quite work as intended, ergo, the game can feel pretty monotonous at times.  If you want this game, I recommend that you buy it (as well as two or three Expansion packs) only during discounts.

When I first saw this game, I passed it off as another Minecraft clone with little to no effort put into it. Then I actually played it. I haven't seen the sun in 36 days. Seriously. This game is extremely addicting. I would especially recommend it if you enjoy the Metroid or Zelda franchises, as this game seems to be a fusion of both. For me, this is a must-have game.

THOTH is a very well done twin stick shooter that's minimalistic look does a great job at keeping you focused on the track at hand, staying alive. With 64 hand created levels it does a great job at providing a challenge while also teaching you its mechanics through gameplay. The main thing I enjoyed was how it felt extremely balanced, most things were intuitive enough that you understood how they worked after the first or second appearance, and you never were killed by a surprise. The main thing I would say that works against it would be the price. I enjoyed the time I put in, and I might put a couple more hours in to finish the remaining procedurally generated gauntlents, I don't know if it is worth 10 dollars. I got my copy through October's Humble Monthly, and I probably wouldn't have played this game otherwise.   All in all, I'd say this game is worth $5 USD unless you know you are really going to love it.

Its amazing that this was announced at the end of 2013 and people are STILL asking 'What do you do?'  Do some homework man... you're on the internet already so go find out!  Anyways, heres my impressions after 10 hours. *NOTE* This game is running fine for me after a few modifications, more on that after my impressions.  After exploring 2 star systems, almost a dozen planets total, im happy to say those who like the exploring/survival/chill game will enjoy this for sure. After almost 70 hours in Subnautica, i knew i would enjoy NMS. There is so much to discover!! The file size is only 2.5GB, but only because of procedual generation taking so little space, its amazing how much there is to explore. All the amazing small details you wouldn't normally look for. For example, i left my game running for a bit on a planet during the night and the clear sky showed that the planet has its on rotation and i saw the night sky slowing pan from the left of the sky to the right.   The game does of a few cons i want to point out. - not much to do in space (perhaps that'll change the farther i get into the game) - space stations feel empty. those poor Geks just sit around all the time and do nothing! :( - Inventory is really hard to manage, find as many upgrade slots as possible - controls still feel likely clunky after the 1.0.3 patch, so hopefully that will be polished more in the future  I feel like im one of the lucky ones that can run the game with little to no problems. I can provide some help perhaps for people who have the Open GL window issue.  i7 4th gen gtx 760 16gb ram  I first started the game and OpenGL window came up so it has to do with the resolution. I dumbed down the res to the 'reconmeneded' settings (1360 x 768) and then the game was able to launch. I then switched the game to run on my other monitor at 1920 x 1080 and its been working fine for the most part. Changed the FOV settings to 140, setting fps to Max and ive been probably pushing over 60 fps so far. After a long play session, say 3-4 hours the game would slow down significantly where exiting and then going back in would resolve the issue. Perhaps my gpu ran out of memory? I don't know, but I know Hello Games is hard at work resolving these issues.

Early Access Review

Alright. Take a look at my hours. In this short amount of time, I can review this game with confidence.  I'd like to start off by saying that this is easily one of, if not THE best survival games I've ever played.   Now it's not a survival in the sense of minecraft, DAYZ, the forest, rust, etc.   In this case, survival means the most literal sense of the word, staying alive. When a character dies, they are dead, and stay that way. A nice perma-death feature keeps you on your game.  You are trying to survive (and live...or continue living) in a war ravaged city. You need to hunt for food, medicine, things to keep you warm, weapons, and other survivors, well the ones that don't want to kill you...or raid your house while you're out...  This game does not hold your hand, it's gritty, it puts you in an environment, and into situations where you actually need to think about what to do with your short time with the cover of darkness. It tugs at your morals, and makes you think things you don't want to.   Is it worth going to the supermarket, knowing there are armed bandits, to get food because we are out? OR do we need to trade away our supplies for medicine, to save a woman and her children?  Every decision matters, try not to make bad ones....your game may end faster than it started.  BUT, you can always start over, make different decisions, kill (or help) more people, blah blah...  So with all that, I highly recommend this game if you are into any sort of survival, fight for your life game.  11/10. The story, the gameplay, idea, visual theme, atmosphere, its all great! I'm sure there's more stuff but hey, I'm really enjoying it. I can see myself playing this for a long long time....

Homesick is a stunner of a game with graphics that will remain unchallenged by the indie scene for a long time. Once you dig beneath the surface though what remains is your typical walking simulator game, with all the requisite puzzles and hidden pieces of text to flesh out the world. Whilst it’s worth playing for the graphics alone I really can’t say that there was much more that drew me in, mostly due to my resistance to reading large walls of text after I’ve slowly trotted my way through everything. Still I’m sure fans of this genre will find a lot to love and would not hesitate to recommend it to all the indie fans out there.  Read my full review here:  https://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/07/03/homesick-longing-for-a-world-long-since-past/

review_text: (I'm not going to write this as Jimmy, so don't comment, why no stutter?) I understand the developers would have spent around $1000+ to make this game. i7 4970 @ 4.0, 16gigs of RAM & 970 SLI.   I'm having a good time with the single player so far; no crashes, no stutters, no low frames.   Atmosphere is really well done, the AI don't talk nearly as much as they did in the beta, which is great. The enemies are just a little too cartoonish to be scary.   I'm not a fan of the skill tree they're building - sure, there are four areas to choose from, but your choices are made for you in each category. I would have liked a little more choice - maybe two or three options per milestone.   Sound production for music & background noise is good, but the weapons still need to not sound as ... generic? I guess, as they do.   Level design feels intuitive and there's a lot of places to go that aren't specifically about the mission.   It would have been nice if the major relics you recover had some influence on gameplay, even if it was simply stat-driven. But I mean, I just picked up a kickass looking power sword, and you're telling me it's ... decoration? :(   Anyway, fun game so far, 7/10, would wonder why the blood isn't purple again.

You won't be sorry.

PROS: - Great replayability. - Game speed adapts to your skill level (reflexes). - The humble developer sincerely thanks you for playing his game.  CONS: - Health complications: eye disease (vitreous floaters), heart disease, hyperventilation, epilepsy, seizures, etc.. You name it.   Final Remarks: If you are a type of gamer who likes to torture yourself,  One Finger Death Punch  (OFDP) is the perfect game for you. Unlike other crazy twitch reflex games, OFDP is a lot easier and forgiving because it gives you more than one health and various perks that immensely help you progress. If you constantly fail and have hard time beating at certain points, like I said the game will slow down to match your current skill level (reaction time and reflexes) and the game speed will increase if you don't make any mistakes or die. I assure you that the game is eventually beatable even if you are not fast enough.   I am real pro at this game so I can't resist bragging my awesome ♥♥♥♥ here. Hopefully this one screenshot greatly inspires you to play this little awesome game.  http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=386582052   . RECOMMENDED .

Supreme Commander multiplayer-lobby 2007:  A: 'What kind of CPU do you own?' B: 'A Pentium 4 3.4 GHz' A: 'Buy a intel Q6600 Quadcore and come back if you have: out!'  Supreme Commander multiplayer-lobby 2015:  A: 'Your CPU-rating is suspicious, what kind of CPU do you own?' B: 'A Q6600 Quadcore OCed to 3.2 GHz' A: 'Buy a Core iX Haswell CPU or equivalent and come back if you have: out!'  This is one of the very few games that even 8 years after its release manages to strain the most expensive hardware available. That is because Supreme Commander (FA) is a massively grand game. And a superb one at that. (And one that is not well optimized for todays multithreading).  You want to fight 11 other players on giant maps in the air, on sea and on land? Check. You want to crush the shield-generators of your opponents base with 500 Bombers just because you feel like it? No deal. Check. You want to have up to 12.000 Units duking it out in multiplayer? Sure, why not. Check.  One of the best alltime user-scores on metacritic proves that this one is a timeless classic. And even being a classic i often look at replays of my games and marvel at the level of detail that the designers have put into the game e.g. the little radar-antennas on my destroyers tracking the opponents, or the little Flak-cannons on deck training their barrels physically correct onto incoming airplanes. The game even today can be pure eyecandy.  The true joy though is in multiplayer, i will not go into further detail here...just buy it, its dirtcheap for what it offers, and try it out yourself. And oh, do not forget to install the community-driven multiplayer-lobby. You will find hundreds of players online there and games to chose from plus a plethora of mods and automatically distributed updates to the game:   http://www.faforever.com/   Download and enjoy. See you on the battlefield!
Early Access Review

The character art is gorgeous (on the rare occasions you actually see it) and the music isn't bad.  That said, 'I do not think that word means what you think it means' seems to fit far more often than it should, especially for a hidden object game; a few objects seem to have their names switched, and others are just... off. For example, if it says you need to find a watch, you're probably looking for a wall or table clock. Many backgrounds have very dark edges where you have to be perfectly lined up and rather close to your monitor to find that last item or two. The other items? Well, if you go around and click anything that looks out of place, you'll probably find most of them within a minute. Minigames seem to switch between ridiculously easy and time consuming enough that you might as well wait for the skip button, with a couple that could really use an explanation tossed in the mix.  The story seems more like an outline to work with than something that should have been released - absolutely no character development means the few snippets we see make very little sense as a whole, the 'ending' in particular. Speaking of the ending, it's... not really an ending; I'm assuming there is or will be another game that picks up where it left off.  If you want item hunt after item hunt and very little else, this might be worth looking into. Otherwise, it wasn't even worth it as part of a bundle.

So, this game is free. (Obviously.) And it's a visual novel. I was bored, so I gave it a try. (Spoilers ahead!)  Honestly, I feel like this game could have been written out a lot better. I do like the simple style of it. There are some games I believe that don't need to be overcomplicated or over the top. However, the story of this game. Depending on who you are can either make you love it or hate it.  Basically, Emily is a girl you're friends with in high school. No matter what you do or choices you make. Emily and you never hook up. Never. It just all ends. The message I believe the game is trying to get across is that no matter if you feel you are better for someone, or CAN be better for someone. Sometimes that other person just doesn't feel the same way. It's their life, and they're going to make their own choices no matter what you do.   The only downside to this game is pretty much how it's been written. I really do wish the storyline branched out a little bit. Like, maybe Emily ends up with someone else who is kinder to her. Perhaps along the lines of 'I know we didn't work out, but you taught me a lot about how important a good relationship is' or something like that. Just something BETTER for both characters, you know?  Overall, I feel the game is pretty sad. It's not really anything great. I do like how you have to 'type' on your keyboard in the game to type your message out. I did grow attached to Emily a bit, and that's saying a lot. I remember those awkward years of being in high school and growing up. Those are hard years, and you really don't know how to define yourself as a person.   I hope the creator of this game continues and uses this game as a learning experience. I see a lot of potential for a really good visual novel game using this format they've created. It's not the BEST by any means, but it certainly has a lot of untapped potential. Perhaps being able to talk with several different characters and see how their live's progress and being able to make more choices that have a greater effect overall in the game so there are multiple endings/outcomes.  Either way, if you want a throwback to your old days as a teen give the game a playthrough or two. It's free, and it really doesn't take that long. I rather liked it myself, but there could be so much more done with it. I hope the creator reads this review (and others) and takes in the constructive cricistim to make something that has the potential to be truly great.

app_name: 12 Labours of Hercules III: Girl Power
review_text: This third part does not disappoint from the first two. Although I'm sad to see the challenge stages go, I did enjoy that none of the levels felt like they were drawn out or tedious like in the end of the second game. The series in itself has been a most enjoyable experience in a style of time management gameplay that I have not seen before these game.

My review is negative not because the game is awful (it's not), but just because I think it's not worth all that hype around it. The plot is mediocre. Till the very end I was expecting to find something interesting, something maybe mysterious or just surprising. I still don't know what the developers tried to convey. The ending is also just weird, it's like none ending at all. I feel disappointed and depressed. The game itself is rather depressing. :(((

First of all, I really don't think the game deserves the ''very positive'' rating it has on steam right now.  The game itself is very short, and therefore I never found myself really engaged in the main story. The fantastic world that's there to discover is bland as there is hardly anything for you to interact with.   The graphics are ok and the fantasy world looks decent, but the animations, on the other hand, feel outdated.  The gameplay is the game's strong part, but even its uniqueness eventually wears off and it starts to feel repetitive around halfway through. I also encountered a few glitches where I found myself stuck between rocks and stuff. Sometimes I managed to pull myself out, sometimes I didn't and had to restart.  Would not recommend it unless it is on sale.

I'll start out by saying, this game is not for everyone. And from the reviews thus far, most people don't seem to be very happy with it; however, I do have some positive things to say about Gone Home. Personally, I enjoyed it.  I started Gone Home without expecting much, I knew it wasn't your average action-packed, puzzle solving game. Gone Home is more exploratory, it's an interactive story in which you explore your empty home to discover what happened. Why is nobody home? Where did everybody go? There is definitely quite a lot of rooms, drawers, cabinets, etc. to explore, which adds a bit it to the already short game time. I found myself wanting to know more about the family, and their story as the game progressed. The story in the game pulled at my emotions, I went from 'pssh...typical teenage behavior!' to feelings of hope and sadness...basically, if you're into storylines, this game is for you.  All in all, even though Gone Home is a simple point-and-click with absolutely zero action, I found that it is definitely worth playing.
